column2: WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) Eight of 10 widely sold brands of toothpaste do not live up to their advertisements as cavity preventers,the Food and Drug Administration said today.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) Reformers in the State Department, concerned by what they consider to be its declining role in foreign affairs, have offered 468 recommendations to strengthen the department.

Apartment house landlords voted unhappily last night to accept terms for ending the 15-day-old strike of elevator operators, maintenance workers and other building help. The men are to return to work today.

Those who oppose highseas fishing for the Atlantic salmon gained a little satisfaction from the meeting of the International Commission of Northwest Atlantic Fisheries (I.C.N.A.F.) held in St. John's, Nfld., earlier this summer, according to Richard A. Buck of Hancock, N.H.

Prices on the American Stock Exchange managed to inch ahead yesterday with its index closing at 20.24, up 0.05 from Friday's level. Volume was only a little higher at 2,266,870 shares, compared with 2,617,120.
Peter L.A. Folliss, an American and British financier, died Sunday after a heart attack at the Deepdale Golf Course in Queens. He was 57 years old and lived at 830 Park Avenue.

FISHERS ISLAND, N.Y., July 20 Albert B. Boardman 2d's 46-foot yawl, Madrigal, was the Division 1 winner, and Mariah, a One-Ton Class sloop under charter to Eric W. Peniston and George M. (Dooie) Isdale Jr., triumphed in Division 2 today in the overnight race that opened the American Yacht Club's 39th annual cruise.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 20 The self-appointed "death squad" of Sao Paulo, one of at least three Brazilian vigilante groups believed to be made up of off-duty policemen, has executed 10 men identified as petty criminal.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commis sion said today that the acquisition by General Mills, Inc., of a big producer of packaged frozen seafood "may have substantially lessened competition" in the food in dustry.
NEW DELHI, July 20 (UPI) Upendra Acharya, a 63-year-old Indian newspaper executive, died yesterday in the Hindu holy city of Benares.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (AP) Lieutenant William L. Calley Jr., charged with murder in the alleged Mylai massacre in 1968, asked today for a halt in general court-martial proceedings against him and dismissal of the charges.

One day after a family picnic and hike in a field, a 3-year-old girl became paralyzed and nearly died in Youngstown, Ohio, but her pediatrician cured her rapidly, simply by removing a tick from her scalp.

CAIRO, July 20 The Egyptian military spokesman said today that Egyptian ground defenses shot down one of 24 Israeli Skyhawk planes raiding the southern end of the Suez Canal zone this morning. He added that an orange parachute was seen descending, presumably on the Israelioccupied side of the canal.
The trial of 13 Black Panthers for an alleged bomb conspiracy will begin Sept. 8, State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh said in court yesterday.

Roman Scout and Naskra scored in divisions of the Lexington Handicap on the turf at Aqueduct yesterday. The former, owned by Mrs. Ada L. Rice, registered his third straight success while Naskra came through for the first time since last winter at Hialeah. The Lexington is at 1 1/16 miles for 3-year-olds.
The American Guild of Variety Artists has notified Radio City Music Hall that 100-or-so precision dancers, the Rockettes, will not work beyond tomorrow without a new contract.

Western Bancorporation, Los Angeles, yesterday reported consolidated net operating income, before securities transactions, of $34,821,047 for the first half of this year compared with $31,756,966 in the 1969 period.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission accused the McDonald's hamburger drive-in chain today of sponsoring a deceptive $500,000 sweepstakes promotion in 1968 during which only $13,000 in prizes was awarded. In a proposed consent order, the commission said that McDonald's, its advertising agency and the promotion company that organized the sweepstakes should have awarded all the prizes they advertised 15,610 items worth $500,000 at retail.

There hasn't been another American writer of Joan Didion's quality since Nathanael West. She writes with a razor, carving her characters out of her perceptions with strokes so swift and economical that each scene ends almost before the reader is aware of it; and yet the characters go on bleeding afterward. A pool of

WASHINGTON, July 18 Senator George S. McGovern, seeking to meet criticism that he is dovish on the war in Vietnam and hawkish on the Middle East, outlined proposals today for a Middle Eastern settlement, including participation of Palestinian refugee organizations in Arab-Israeli negotiations.

Neither Hystron nor Monsanto, two fiber-manufacturers who recently announced they were giving up their agencies in favor of creative and media services, understands fashion advertising, according to David R. Altman.

Fire bombs were thrown at a Jewish community center and a two family house several blocks away in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn shortly after dawn yesterday. No one was injured, but the front of the community center, at which some antipoverty funds in the area are administered, was heavily damaged.

WASHINGTON, July 20 President Nixon today firmly endorsed the opposition of President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam to an imposed coalition government, emphasizing that an election open to all was the best approach to a political settlement in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) The House completed Congressional approval today of a bill designed to generate 1.3 million new housing units, including a unique subsidy plan for middle-income home buyers. The bill went to the White House for President Nixon's signature.

Speculators in the silver market were watching their chart points yesterday. As one broker explained, when the chart points on the upside were pierced new buyers came in with orders. At the same time those who had sold contracts previously bought to cover their short positions. "It was an animated market," the broker noted.
The Rev. Bertin O'Neill, assistant pastor of St. Francis of Assissi Roman Catholic Church here, died yesterday at St. Elizabeth Hospital after a long illness. He was 64 years old.

Georg Jensen's huge, silverfinished doors swung wide and there were four (out of eight) selling levels crammed full of the classic silver work and jewelry as well as hosts of new modern furnishings, merchandise for which this store is famous.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 20 Enemy troops attacked again yesterday at Kirirom, the ravaged mountaintop resort about 50 miles southwest of Pnompenh that was reoccupied by Cambodian troops only last Friday, the Government's military spokesman said today.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 20 J. Stewart Beck, a vice president of the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital here after a short illness. He was 59 years old and lived at 9 Capron Lane here.
WASHINGTON, July 20 The National Opera Institute, with a two-year budget of nearly $l-million, was formally established today by some of the country's leading promoters of the arts.

Short selling of stocks increased again last month, but the amount of the increase was well below the rise for the previous month, according to figures released yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., July 20 The District Attorney of Lehigh County said tonight that no recording materials were found when the state police earlier today opened a tachograph a device intended to measure speed on a bus involved in a fatal accident here last week.

The city's Medical Examiner described yesterday the first reported death resulting from an abortion since a new state's law went into effect permitting a woman to undergo an abortion with only the consent of her physician. The law, passed by the last Legislature, went into effect July 1.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 20 Theodore Ackerson, executive vice president of the Bergen County National Bank in Hackensack, died of cancer today at the Valley Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived at 100 Crest Road.

BRUSSELS, July 20 Italy's Treasury Minister, Emilio Colombo, told his Common Market colleagues today that it would be an "economic error" if devaluation were sought as the remedy for his country's financial ailments.

WASHINGTON, July 20 Rhody A. McCoy, former administrator of Brooklyn's Ocean Hill-Brownsville experimental school district, has been dropped from consideration as the District of Columbia's new school superintendent after two members of the district's school board charged that he had been a divisive force in New York schools.
LEXINGTON, Ky., July, 20 (UPI) A colt sired by the 1964 Kentucky Derby winner, Northern Dancer, was sold for $67,000 today at the first session of Keeneland's summer thoroughbred yearling sale.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 20 (AP) Stepin Fetchit, the former film actor and comedian, filed suit today for $3-million damages, charging he had been defamed on a segment of the Columbia Broadcasting System's television series "Of Black Americans."
BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 20 Gary Inskeep worked hard for six months preparing for today, and in 12 hot minutes out on the running track, the hard work paid off.
GENEVA, July 20 The Swiss Government announced today that it would establish diplomatic relations with Albania.

SOMEWHERE IN CAMBODIA A 32-year-old captain in the South Vietnamese Army sat outdoors, staring down at his American boots, not up at the moon, while he wondered aloud how much he would mind the loss of an eye, an arm or a leg.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 20 (UPI) Brazil won the American Zone Davis Cup tennis final today, 3-2, when Jose Edison Mandarino defeated Canada's John Sharpe, 6-1, 6-0, 6-2, in the fifth and deciding match.

NEWARK, July 20 The Young Lords, accusing the Newark police of "brutality" during disorders that interrupted the Puerto Rican Day parade here yesterday, called today for a civilian review board of police conduct.
The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said yesterday that it had raised prices by about 10 per cent on high voltage motor-control equipment used in many industries, effective immediately.

NEW ORLEANS, July 20 (UPI) A tropical storm, with 55-mile-an-hour winds pushed northward through the Gulf of Mexico today, and the Weather Bureau issued a hurricane watch from Morgan City, LA., to Apalachiocola, Fla.
Sometimes Pedro ran round and round the room, screaming and disrupting the class. At other times he was abnormally quiet. Either way, he didn't learn anything.
BOZEMAN, Mont., July 20 (AP) Chet Huntley, the newscaster, asserted today that Life magazine incorrectly quoted him as saying the fact that Richard M. Nixon was President "frightens me."
A suspended detective went on trial in the Bronx Supreme Court yesterday on charges that he lied to a grand jury about taking bribes from gamblers.
Mrs. Sandi-jo Egbert of New York and Sheldon Secunda of New York and Fair Harbor, Fire Island, were married here yesterday afternoon in the St. Regis Hotel in a Jewish ceremony.
A Brooklyn couple and their seven grandchildren were among the winners of $100,000 yesterday in the June state lottery drawing.
PARIS, July 20 The first of three submarines ordered from France by South Africa in 1967 is to be handed over next Friday at Lorient.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 20 Arab diplomats say that since President Gamal Nasser's return three days ago from his 18-day visit to Moscow, lines have been rapidly forming among Arab states between proponents and opponents of a political settlement with Israel.

WASHINGTON, July 20 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon. The average discount rate on 91-day bills today was 6.385 per cent, down from 6.547 per cent last week. For 182-day bills, today's average discount rate was 6.442 per cent, down from 6.644 per cent a week ago.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 20 Mrs. Albert B. Bower of the Pelham Country Club, the defending champion, won the medal by four strokes today with a one-under-par score in the qualifying round of the annual Women's Tri-County Golf Association championship tournament.

The final of the knockout team championship, the principal event at the Fun City Regionals, which ended Sunday at the New York Hilton, was marked by one of the most remarkable reversals of fortune ever seen in a major contest here.

SANTA CRUZ DE TENERIFE, Canary Islands, July 20 (UPI) The fire-damaged cruise ship Fulvia rolled over and sank in the Atlantic Ocean today, 36 hours after an engine room fire forced the 273 crewmembers and 448 passengers to abandon ship yesterday.

President Nixon has taken the first formal step toward assembling a comprehensive historical record of his political career that will eventually be placed in the Richard M. Nixon Presidential Library.
A leading Alabama life insurer was accused yesterday of misinforming stockholders of the terms of a proposed takeover move.
Wells, Rich, Greene has lost the Samsonite Corporation account to J. Walter Thompson. It leaves officially on Nov. 1 and, according to the Denver company, the billings are $2.5-million.
WASHINGTON, July 20 (UPI) House members, satisfied that they were well along in their work, voted today to take a 25-day recess starting at the close of business Aug. 14.

One year ago today, with almost half of humanity straining to catch their businesslike, helmet-muffled exchanges, Neil A. Armstrong and Col. Edwin E. Aldrin Jr. lifted off the moon and headed for a rendezvous with their mother ship and the journey back to earth.

WINNETKA, Ill., July 20 Mr. and Mrs. John Galbraith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Angeline Galbraith, to Charles Foster Brown 3d, son of Mrs. Brown Jr. and the late Mr. Brown of Winnetka and Pinehurst, N.C.

ELLSWORTH, Me., July 20 John Weilburg, an early organizer for the American Newspaper Guild and president of they John Weilburg public relations agency in New York, died of cancer here Thursday at Maine Coast Memorial Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived at 29 Overlook Road in Haverstraw, N.Y.
Four insurance companies have given notice of intent to foreclose on $2-million in 15-year notes of the Visual Electronics Corporation, the company said yesterday.
Lower earnings despite slightly higher sales in the second quarter and first half of the year were reported yesterday by E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc.

NEW HAVEN, July 20 Mr. and Mrs. William Cahn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Cahn, to Martin H. Krieger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Krieger of Brooklyn. The wedding will take place here Sept. 20.

A report by the city's Transportation Administration on the May 20 subway accident in which two persons were killed, attributed the accident to human error and recommended a series of drastic reforms in the Transit Authority's hiring and training procedures.

PARIS--I ran into Senator Jefferson in the Crillon bar and he asked if I'd read his speech. "Yes," I said. "It seems to me you fellows are getting pretty far into foreign policy. Do you want to take over the State Department and the White House?"

The appointment of Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the Vermont State Education Commissioner, as Chancellor of the city's public schools removes another element of uncertainty from the future management of the decentralized system. Dr. Scribner comes with strong recommendations as a forceful administrator and innovator, and he has won special praise for his commitment to racially integrated schooling. These are highly relevant qualities in any effort to improve education in New York.
HOUSTON, July 21 (UPI) --Joe Pepitone of Houston said today he was quitting baseball and would ask the Astros to place him on the voluntary retired list.

Julia Leon, a young singer from Madrid who looks somewhat like Joan Baez but carries her own special bag of protest songs, gave her first American performance Monday night at the Folklore Center, 321 Avenue of the Americas.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- President Nixon's complaints about "the big spenders" in Congress were echoed today by Representative George H. Mahon, chairman of the House Appropriations Committee, in an effort to head off a liberal move for increased health funds.

TRENTON, July 21--The United States Attorney who is prosecuting Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other men on charges of extortion conspiracy told the jury here today that the defendants had been guilty of "coldblooded, calculating, contemptuous corruption in the largest city of this state."
Can it be that the reason some annual reports are hard to understand is that the companies are not trying to inform but to cover up?
A petition filed in Surrogates Court yesterday stated that the estate of Henry R. Luce had a gross value of $103,014,000.
LONDON, July 21--Britain, a country that produces only half the food it eats, felt the sharp impact of the nationwide dock strike today.

Three witnesses testified yesterday that a major Brooklyn chain store sent defective furniture to them and then got questionable default judgments against them when they refused to make credit payments until the goods had been repaired or replaced.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., July 21 --Kendrick R. Wilson's Troon, a Whitby 45-foot sloop which flies the host club's burgee, was the over-all winner of today's race on the 39th annual American Yacht Club cruise. A fleet of 38 sailed 22 nautical miles across Block Island Sound from Fishers Island on the first of four daily squadron runs that count for series trophies.
The City Council's Finance Committee refused yesterday to vote an appropriation for construction of a new building for the 79th Precinct Police station in Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES, July 21-- Jury selection in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three young women was completed today, and opening statements in what is expected to be a drawn-out, complex case will begin Friday morning.

Gloomy philosophers who expatiate on the futility of life and the frequency with which great efforts are made to no purpose could find numerous examples in tournament bridge play. The diagramed deal, a slight modification of a hand played Saturday in the semifinal round of the knockout team championship at the Fun City Regionals here, illustrates this theme.

ATLANTA, July 21--Robert H. Finch, the former Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, was described today by a top civil rights official in the Johnson Administration as a "gutless" man who presided over the "greatest give-away of human rights" in recent memory.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 21 (AP)--A University of Michigan surgical team transplanted the heart and kidneys of a 23year-old Delaware man today into three separate patients.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)--Walter Pincus, a former newspaperman and now counsel for a Senate subcommittee, said today that he planned to join in starting a national daily newspaper for several cities that have no morning publication.

The upswinging silver market absorbed some quick profit taking yesterday from nervous speculators, and prices dropped about a penny or a little more, for most contracts. Even so, the week-old gain of 5 to 7 cents for most contracts was still largely there.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21-- The Libyan Government today confiscated the property of Italians and Jews in the country. The Italians are to receive no compensation, while the Jews will be given Government bonds payable over 15 years.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 21-- Midwestern Governors acted today to bring thermal and radioactive pollution under more effective state control.

Frederick O'Neal, chairman of the Schomburg Community. Coordinating Committee, announced a fund-raising drive yesterday to help finance construction of an $8-million building to house a collection of Negro history and literature.

West Germany's Christian Union parties are breaking with precedent and taking on a heavy responsibility in refusing to send a representative with Foreign Minister Scheel for negotiations next week on a nonaggression treaty with the Soviet Union. The refusal ends along-standing practice of maintaining-a bipartisan front on matters of critical national interest.
PARIS, July 21--Fifteen European nations have approved a series of measures to protect the European environment against the misuse of pesticides.

BERNARDSVILLE, N.J., July 21--Kathy Linney of Plainfield and Mrs. James Whelan of Springdale shared the first round lead in the Elizabeth Goss roundrobin golf tournament today at the Somerset Hills Country Club.
MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 21 (UPI)--Superior Court Judge Aaron Palmer intends to rule Thursday on the fate of the Powder Ridge Rock Festival in Connecticut.

NEW HAVEN, July 21-- Lonnie McLucas admitted last year that he had fired a shot into the body of Alex Rackley in order to make sure that he was dead, an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified here today.

WASHINGTON, July 21--The Department of the Interior has asked the Justice Department to take action against 13 large companies on charges of polluting lakes and rivers with mercury. Shiro Kashiwa, Assistant Attorney General for the Lands and Natural Resources Division, was given the list of companies today,...

PENSACOLA, Fla., July 21 --Comdr. Max Eric Woyke, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Woyke have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Woyke, to Lieut. (jg.) Henry Hopkins Livingston Jr., U.S.N.R.
PARIS, July 21--Pierre Cardin showed women how to look in modern settings, and Gabrielle Chapel, who is in her 80's, seemed like the youngest girl in fashion at the fall openings here today.
LUSAKA, Zambia, July 21-- Hundreds of students stoned the British High Commission building here today in protest against London's decision to consider new arms sales to South Africa.

Willie Mays drilled a ball through the left side of the infield the other day and he had his 3,000th hit as a big leaguer. Thus did he reach another plateau of the many he has scaled during his spectacular career. But this had extra significance because he joined one of baseballs more exclusive clubs, one with a membership of only 10.
The Yankees won't tell their children about last night's 4-2 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers, in which the Bombers' greatest virtue was patience.
CHICAGO, July 21--A tight bank security system cannot provide a guarantee against bomb attacks, William Karl, security officer of the Marine Grace Trust Company said here today.
PURCHASE, N.Y., July 21-- John Buczek, the former Wake Forest golf captain who turned pro only two years ago, scored the most important triumph of his career today much to his surprise.

A State Supreme Court justice in Brooklyn said yesterday that he thought the defunct governing board of the former Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration school district in Brooklyn had no right to continue administering the three-year-old project. But he reserved decision on a move to force the group to vacate its offices.

For an Administration that said it does not believe in jawboning, President Nixon and his top economic aides have been doing a remarkable amount of it this week to convince the nation that the downturn in the economy is over and inflation is fading fast.

HONOLULU, July 21--Officials of the United States and South Korea opened a two-day defense conference here today, with American leaders hoping to persuade the Koreans to accept a reduction of one-third in United States' troop strength in their country.

WASHINGTON, July 21--Officials of the New York Stock Exchange and the exchange's economic consultants said today that there were good economic and statistical reasons why the proposed new schedule of sales commissions on stock transactions differs from the one that was proposed by the consultants in February.
Students with high school or college identification cards will be admitted at reduced rates to three attractions at the American Musem of Natural History.

The No. 10 buses along Central Park West were doing a rushing business. Boys and girls were riding, and young marrieds, and quiet elder couples, most of them carrying blankets, or pillows, or lunch baskets. They were taking advantage of the beautiful, beautiful evening to go to the Sheep Meadow in Central Park for the first of the summer's park concerts by the New York Philharmonic.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- The Nixon Administration sent its new Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare before a hostile Senate Finance Committee today with a long speech on welfare reform and a small bundle of concessions.
VALATIE, N.Y., July 21-- Rose Fried, owner of the Rose Fried Gallery at 40 East 68th Street in New York for the last 30 years, died at a nursing home here this morning. She was 74 years old.
WASHINGTON July 21 (AP) --A Senate committee was told today that migrant farm worker's, the lowest paid in the nation, were exploited by Texas politicians and huge corporations, such as coca-Cola.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)--Jim G. Lucas, Pulitzer Prize-winning war correspondent for the Scripps-Howard newspapers, died early today of abdominal cancer at the Veterans Administration Hospital. He was 56 years old.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Wednesday, July 22--Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia arrived here this morning on an official visit, his first trip outside his country since he led a coup d' tat March 18.

ROCKFORD, Ill., July 21 (UPI)--Jane Bastanchury, the defender, advanced easily today, but her Curtis Cup teammate, Cynthia Hill, had a narrow escape from an upset as match play opened in the 70th annual women's Western amateur golf tournament.
A bill to bar discrimination against women in public places, such as restaurants and bars, was passed yesterday by the City Council, 34 to 1. The bill will become law after Mayor Lindsay signs it.
PARIS, July 21--Algeria proved today to force French oil companies to increase their tax payments about 50 per cent.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., July 21 (UPI)--Dennis Eisman, a defense, attorney for an Army Captain indicated today that he might take legal action against an Army investigator who he charged had thrown him to the ground.
GLASGOW, Scotland, July 21--Robert Lister Macneil, 45th chief of the Clan Macneil, was buried last night at his ancestral home of Kisimul Castle on the island of Barra in western Scotland.

The New York State Banking Department said yesterday that roughly $1-million in checks would go into the mails next Tuesday to pay off about 750 creditors and former depositors of the New York branch of Intra Bank.
The Municipal Concerts Orchestra cut short a concert at a Washington Heights park last night after one or two rocks were hurled at the musicians half an hour after the music began. No one was hurt.

The Mak Transportation Corporation's terminal and garage at 144 King Street in Brooklyn was raided yesterday by they police, who said they found a tractor-trailer containing $60,000 worth of English bicycles that had been stolen Friday from a Brooklyn pier.

The city suffered another setback yesterday in its battle against air Pollution from apartment-house incinerators when landlords won an order from the state's highest court restraining the city from enforcing regulations requiring upgrading of the incinerators.

NEWARK, July 1--Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson startled a number of Newark residents today by suddenly appearing at their doors accompanied by plainclothes policemen, aides, television cameramen and reporters.

WASHINGTON, July 21--A leading advocate of import restrictions to protect United States industries said today that President Nixon was "not fully informed" when he described yesterday why he would veto a trade bill imposing quotas on products other than textiles.

BRUSSELS, July 21--Negotiations for British entry into the European Economic Community made a significant advance today as a compromise agreement over procedure was reached, setting the course for the talks over the coming months.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --Murray Valene, vice president of the Federal Copper and Aluminum Company of Minneapolis, said today that the three major copper producers, through their conglomerates, had created a giant monopoly of the entire industry.

FORT POLK, La., July 21 (AP)--Brig. Gen. John G. Wheelock 3d became commander of the Fort Polk infantry training center in brief ceremonies today. General Wheelock, 52 years old, succeeds Brig. Gen. Emil P. Eschenberg, who has served as acting commander for the last five months.

LANSING, Mich., July 21 (UPI)--Lansing's police chief, Derold Husby, refused today to disclose the cause of death of Laurie Murninghan, whose body was found yesterday. Mr. Husby said, such information should be known only to the killer and the police.

Mr. and Mrs. Herbert D. Strauss of New York and St. Thomas, Virgin Islands, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Strauss's daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Burnham, to Flight Lieut. Dennis John Pike of the Royal Air Force, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pike of Johannesburg, South Africa. The wedding is planned for Aug. 22 at the Dorchester in London.

In perhaps the most decisive move yet in Wall Street's month-old commitment to lower interest rates, bond yields on leading new issues of corporate and tax-exempt securities were set significantly lower yesterday.

LONDON, July 21--Scottish Theater Ballet, which has just ended a season here at the Sadler's Wells Theater, may be remembered by New Yorkers under its earlier name, and geographic location, Western Theater Ballet. Not much has changed except its title.
Prices on the London stock market closed quietly firmer yesterday on selective support, indicating hope for an early end of the British dock strike.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., July 21 (UPI)--A pathologist testified unexpectedly at the John Norman Collins murder trial today that he could not determine the time of death of the former student's alleged victim, a petite 18-year-old coed.

SUMMIT, N.J., July 21--Bernard J. Thole, a lawyer with the Mobil Oil Company in New York for 28 years, died yesterday in St. Barnabas Medical Center, Livingston. He was 79 years old and lived at 10 Templar Way here.
R.J. Reynolds, the tobacco company that cares more about good taste than good grammar, am about to launch a new cigarette which they think are almost as best as Winston.
The American Stock Exchange meandered its way yesterday. While prices were down sharply on the Big Board, the index for American prices dropped only slightly, closing at 20.17, down 0.07.

WASHINGTON, July 21--A Securities and Exchange Commission hearing examiner ruled today that information relating to the personal financial situations of individual officials of the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation could be kept out of the public record of a commission hearing.

HONG KONG, July 21--The Soviet Union and Communist China, nervously eyeing each other across their disputed 4,500-mile border, have taken a number of dramatic steps in their military build-up, according to well-placed analysts of Far Eastern intelligence here and in Washington.
Apartment house employe returned to work yesterday, ending a strike that had deprived thousands of New Yorkers of garbage collection, elevator service, hot water and other amenities since July 6.
WASHINGTON, July 21--A shot like the one that killed President Abraham Lincoln echoed again tonight in Ford's Theater here.

Certain operas, it is said, do not travel well, and Albert Lortzing's "Zar and Zimmermann" has always been held up as one of the prime examples. It is very popular in German-speaking countries, and has been ever since its premiere in 1839. But seldom is it encountered on the international circuit.
A young trustee of the National Urban League predicted yesterday that many colleges would operate this fall only as bases for off-campus student activity.
The Union Carbide Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings declined in the second quarter and first half of the year while sales registered gains.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Wednesday, July 22 (Reuters) --Vietcong and North Vietnamese troops last night attacked a military training camp, a military spokesman said today.
A group of ecologically aware young Americans at Ogilvy Mather have, on their own time, gotten up some public-service TV spots aimed at keeping the city's parks clean.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (Reuters)--President Nixon announced today that he would visit Mexico early in September.

LAWRENCE, Kan., July 21-- --After five nights of street disturbances and two fatal shootings, Gov. Robert Docking declared a state of emergency in this city today and ordered in a complement of state troopers to help keep the peace.

NEW VERNON, N.J., July 21--Mr. and Mrs. Joseph McMillan Hinshaw Jr. have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Stuart Hinshaw, to Raimund Gerhard Vanderwcil Jr. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderweil of Cohasset, Mass. A wedding in October is planned.
Denny McLain finally has his first victory of the season but he also has a badly bruised left shin.
STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 21--(AP)--The United States easily defeated Italy, 73-23, in wheelchair basketball today during the third day of the Paraplegic Olympics.
WASHINGTON, July 21-- Consumer prices rose a little less in June than in other recent months, the Labor Department reported today.
The first jury trial held in Criminal Court here since a recent United States Supreme Court ruling resulted in acquittal yesterday for a 30-yearold man who had been charged with jostling.
JACKSON, Miss., July 21-- In another abrupt decision, black municipal workers here ended their three-week strike today against the city of Jackson.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art should sell its recently acquired Lehman Collection to provide a fund for living artists. It should expand into the vacated Customs House at Bowling Green, take a floor or two in the new World Trade Center, and create other branches in Harlem, Queens, the Bronx, Lower Manhattan, Welfare Island and the South Street urban renewal project.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 21 (UPI)--A $15,000 fine, was imposed here today against a factory for air pollution violations.
WASHINGTON, July 21-- The Nixon Administration announced today that it would propose a new explosives control act to combat the growing number of bombings in the United States.

WASHINGTON, July 21--An alleged "confidential memorandum" linking Vice President Agnew's office with plans to cancel the 1972 national election and repeal the Bill of Rights was denounced today as a fraud by Mr. Agnew.

VIENNA, July 21--The Vienna phase of the Soviet-United States talks on the limitation of strategic arms is now certain to last at least until early next month. According to informed sources, both sides are hopeful that something positive will emerge before the recess.

Iain Norman Macleod might have become Prime Minister of Great Britain with better luck in timing, and there would have been no doubt about his Government's direction. He was the epitome of modern Toryism--even more so than Edward Heath or Reginald Maudling, with whom he had worked under R.A. Butler to give their party's policies a drastic facelifting and updating in the years out of office after the war.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 21 (AP)--The Government has ordered the mother of the former Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, to vacate the royal palace by Friday, informed sources said today.

CAIRO, July 21--While Israeli fighter-bombers continued their months-long pounding of the Suez Canal front today, an event of possibly greater strategic significance was taking place about 400 miles up the Nile.
DETROIT, July 21--The General Motors Corporation asked the United Automobile Workers today to help cut the costs of fringe benefit programs and combat discipline problems in the plants.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --Senator John G. Tower, Republican of Texas, accused the National Labor Relations Board today of "tragic ineptitude," and urged approval of his bill to transfer to the Federal courts jurisdiction over cases involving alleged unfair labor practices.
The city'S master plan has been assailed as unprofessional and "more a public relations device than anything else" by a panel of professional planners.

Edmund F. Martin, chairman and chief executive officer of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, has indicated that the second-quarter earnings of the country's second largest steel producer would be just as disappointing as the depressed profit in the first three months of 1970.
PITTSBURGH, July 21-- Arnold Palmer was honored as athlete of the decade at a dinner tonight at the Hilton Hotel.
The Ford Foundation plans to establish an independent, $30million agency that would grant money to police departments throughout the country to help them reform their operations and training.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 21 (Reuters)--England won six gold medals to close in on Australia and the Aussies and Canadians continued their battle for swimming supremacy at the Commonwealth Games today. Australia has 17 gold medals, two more than England.
Oil company earnings reports released yesterday gave the industry a split decision as profit advances and declines came out almost perfectly balanced.

LEXINGTON, Ky., July 21 (AP)--Frank McMahon, the millionaire from Vancouver, British Columbia, set a world record last night when he paid $510,000 for a full brother to Majestic Prince, who won the Kentucky Derby and Preakness for McMahon last year.

BOSTON, July 21 (AP)--Ilse Stanley, credited with rescuing 400 fellow Jews from German prison camps, died Sunday at New England Baptist Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived at Gilmanton Ironworks, N.H., with her husband, Milton.

Sharp gains made by the Phelps Dodge Corporation yielded the highest sales and earnings in its history in the second quarter and first half, according to the semi-annual report yesterday of George B. Munroe, president of the nation's second-largest domestic copper producer.

CAIRO, July 21--The authoritative newspaper Al Ahram reported today that the Egyptian reply to Secretary of State William P. Rogers's letter proposing a cease-fire and peace talks would be delivered to him in Washington "within a few days."
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 21 (AP)--United States officials confirmed today that the Agency for International Development has been investigating charges of fraud involving a $1million rice contract.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- The State Department suggested to the Senate Foreign Relations Committee Today that a potentially significant move, toward restoration of a coalition government seemed to be under way in Laos.
ROME, July 21--The Vatican made an unusually long and caustic reply today to widely published accounts of its wealth. But it said more about what it did not own than about what it did.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy told Congress today that "the responsibility of the executive and legislative branches is to keep fiscal [budget] policy in a relatively neutral position" this year to aid in a noninflationary expansion of the economy.
MADRID, July 21--Three building workers were killed and six injured today in Granada when policemen opened fire on demonstrators after being pelted with bricks.
Blue-chip stocks, which led the stock market's advance last week, took a nose dive yesterday and carried the rest of the market down with them.
A fire at the Spuyten Duyvil station of the Penn Central's Hudson division delayed hundreds of Westchester commuters last night.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --President Nixon will stop at Salt Lake City on his way out to the Western White House Friday and will visit Denver on his way home.
Robert Penn Warren, the poet, novelist, journalist and nature lover, was named winner of the National Medal for Literature for 1970 yesterday.

Acknowledging "some pretty crummy overcrowding" at the two city-run children's shelters, Social Services Commissioner Jack R. Goldberg outlined yesterday the city's plans for expanding its capacity to care for neglected and abandoned children.

An interview quoting Chet Huntley, the newscaster, as saying that Richard M. Nixon as President "frightens" him was described by Life magazine yesterday as accurate, according to the Associated Press.

Herman D. Kenin, president of the American Federation of Musicians for the last 12 years, and a vice president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., died yesterday in his room at the Hotel Lombardy here, apparently of a heart attack. He was 69 years old and lived at 14 Northfield Drive, Westport, Conn.
Shortly after his election as president of the National Football League Players Association early this year, John Mackey purchased a booklet on how to conduct labor negotiations.

PANAMA CITY, Fla., July 21 (UPI)--Hurricane Becky swirled toward Florida's Gulf Coast beaches today and forecasters said it may have winds up to 90 miles an hour when it hits about 9 A.M., Eastern Daylight time, tomorrow.
ROME, July 21 (AP)--The Italian Government plans to sell the storied island of Monte Cristo to a special watchdog agency to keep adventurers from hunting its treasures of rare wildlife and plants.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- Scientists expect major progress within two years in determining whether marijuana has bad effects on persons who use it habitually, the House Ways and Means Committee was told today.

Two chemists at the University of California, San Diego, report they have imitated in their laboratory a basic life process, the means by which plants convert nitrogen in the air to ammonia as the essential step toward producing life-dependent proteins.

WASHINGTON, July 21-- Eight months after President Nixon endorsed the Geneva protocol to ban chemical and biological warfare, the American delegate to the United Nations has warned that Washington could face a "quite embarrassing" situation unless the treaty is sent to the Senate for approval soon.

LOS ANGELES, July 21 --(Reuters)--Manslaughter charges were filed today against seven policemen allegedly involved in the killing of two unarmed Mexicans during a search for a murder suspect in a skid row apartment last Thursday.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 21--Senator Charles E. Goodell said today that he did not expect Governor Rockefeller to disavow a conservative group that is backing the Governor and Senator Goodells's Conservative party opponent, James F. Buckley, in the state election.

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 21 --Thousands of proud, cheering Puerto Ricans jammed the Isla Verde airport today and lined the six-mile route to the capital building to welcome home Marisol Malaret Contreras, Miss Universe of 1970.

WOLF, Wyo., July 13-- Seven thousand acres of prime pasture land, rocky slopes, meadows ablaze with wildflowers, a tumbling creek, towering pines and cottonwoods--that's Eatons' Ranch, the oldest dude ranch in the country.
A cluster of balloons tugging at their tether behind the Aqueduct grandstand yesterday reflected a bright new note of optimism on the part of management.
Another merger of two major brokerage houses appears to be in the works with the report yesterday that an agreement between Walston Co., Inc., and Hayden, Stone, Inc., is being completed.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --The Air Transport Association, speaking for the scheduled airlines, said today that "the financial condition is critical" in the industry.

CINCINNATI, July 21 (AP)-- Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., and his sister, Nancy, scored first-round victories today in the $25,000 Western tenns championships. But Zeljko Franulovic of Yugoslavia, the fifth-seeded player, was upset.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 21-- Louis James Dennis, a former administrative officer for the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, died Sunday night at Mead owbrook Hospital of throat cancer. He was 53 years old and lived at 140 Parsons Drive here.

BERLIN, July 21--The sixth session of the current round of four-power talks on the Berlin issue was held today. The representatives of the four victorious powers of World War II, which retain responsibility for the divided city, agreed to meet again in September.

The team owners of the National Football League promised last night that decisions would be announced today on two pressing points in their stalemated negotiations with the Players Association. The owners will make up their minds about attending a meeting the players have scheduled tonight with the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service in Washington, and they will also attempt a decision about the College All-Star game scheduled for Chicago on July 31.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 21-- Paraphrasing a time-honored chant heard at baseball games, the venders' pitch for Friday night's Roquepine Trot will be "you can't tell the horses without a Doc Robins' program."
MOSCOW, July 21--The Soviet Union reported today that its economy continued to show a marked improvement in the first six months of this year.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it had changed the schedule for six of its fall prime-time television programs. Robert D. Wood, president of the network, called the realignment at such a late date "unprecedented" but added that his network's affiliates had approved the changes "without a dissident vote."
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --Dr. Philip Handler, president of the National Academy of Sciences, urged today that there be Federal support of all graduate students.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Wednesday, July 22 (Reuters)--The Bolivian Governmnt last night decreed a state of seige in the country and announced, it had postponed until noon today a decision on whether to release 10 leftwing terrorists from prisons in exchange for two West German technicians kidnapped by guerrillas Sunday.

A new company headed by John J. Gilhooley, a former member of the New York City Transit Authority, has agreed to buy Public Service Coordinated Transport Company, New Jersey's largest bus company, for $29-million.
ATHENS, July 21--Premier George Papadopoulos today took over the post of Foreign Minister, left vacant by the death of Panayotis Pipinelis.
SAN DIEGO, July 21--Clay Kirby of the San Diego Padres was lifted for a pinch-hitter tonight after he had pitched eight hitless innings against the New York Mets.

The chartered-bus crash that killed seven children near Allentown, Pa., last Wednesday has spotlighted wide gaps in Federal and state laws regulating the nation's booming charter bus business. It has also raised new concern among Government safety experts over the "crash-survivability" of modern buses.
WASHINGTON, July 21 (AP) --Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson says that 153,000 welfare recipients have been given jobs or training in the first 21 months of the Government's Work Incentive Program.

MOSCOW, July 21--The Pravda denied today that designs on Israel's integrity Communist party newspaper the Soviet Union had hostile and affirmed that Moscow supported the right of every Middle Eastern country-- including Israel--to full independence.
The cost of living in the New York metropolitan area rose 0.6 per cent in June, outpacing price rises in the nation as a whole and in the four other largest metropolitan areas.

The Diebold Group, Inc., management consultants specializing in advanced technologies, announced yesterday the formation of a new company to expand its activities into Asia, Africa, the Middle East and Latin America.

Hearing the Byrds is always a pleasure. The Los Angeles band was one of the first progressive rock groups, formed in 1964, and it remains one of the best. The group appeared Monday evening in Central Park, as part of the 1970 Schaefer Music Festival.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 21--The Government announced today that it had suspended the use of the "tiger cage" cells at the prison on Con Son pending improvements.

It was argued in this space last week that the heavy cost of the Vietnam war, measured in terms of lost output, diminished profits of business, and reduced real wages of labor, tends to refute the old Marxist and New Leftist charge that capitalist economies depend on war to provide prosperity.

SYRACUSE, July 21--Predicting that "the disrepair, of our national house" would be very much in evidence in the nineteen-seventies, Arthur J. Goldberg proposed 10 areas tonight in which "we must alter our priorities in New York."
WASHINGTON, July 21-- Senator Edward M. Kennedy wants Congress to charter a new Public Counsel Corporation to represent the peoples' interests before Federal agencies.

The Penn Central has applied to the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to discontinue immediately 24 of 34 trains that it already has proposed dropping but which it had agreed to keep running at least until Oct. 1.

TRENTON, July 21--Joseph Bonaparte, once the king of Naples and Sicily and once the monarch of Spain, who helped his younger brother, Napoleon, preside over a conquered Europe, and who has been dead for 126 years, has been named as a defendant in a suit brought by a cranberry company in Bordentown, N.J.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 21-- The Beirut newspaper Al Nahar reported from Cairo today that Egypt would ask the United States to revise its proposals for a Middle Eastern settlement to state clearly that Israel should withdraw not just from Arab territory but from "all" Arab territory.
The Public Service Electric and Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the six months ended June 30.

HARTFORD, July 21-- When Miss Lorraine Joyce Grainger and Specialist 5 Arthur Pomeroy Day 2d met at the altar of the Episcopal Christ Church Cathedral for their wedding here this afternoon, it marked only the 18th day the couple had seen each other since childhood.
LONDON, July 21--Sailors can grow sideburns down to the bottom of their ears and no longer need to have their hair cropped short, the Royal Navy has announced.

City officials, the courts, a hospital, Columbia University and private landlords were embroiled in a growing squatter movement yesterday as about 170 families illegally occupying apartments insisted on what they called their "moral" right to remain.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) --The House Agriculture Committee tentatively approved today a bill to continue the basic farm program for three more years, voting down proposals to limit price support payments to individual farmers.

The nation's major banks, banding together to help yet another major corporation avoid serious financial difficulties, have agreed on the outline of a financing package designed to keep the troubled Lockheed Aircraft Corporation in business in substantially its present, form.

Two working score boards in one season? What have the fans done, besides paying admission, to deserve so much? The first one began operation July 12 at Watkins Glen. That is a simple, manually operated affair that lists the lap number and three leaders.
WASHINGTON, July 21--Israeli and United States officials today acknowledged that an American-born pilot was now a prisoner in Egypt, but said that he bad been an Israeli citizen since 1961.

LONDON, July 21--Prime Minister Heath, in office barely a month, was confronted today with the problem of finding a suitable successor to Iain Macleod as Chancellor of they Exchequer at a time of particularly pressing economic problems.
Two station wagons being prepared for delivery to the Police Department were damaged by bombs yesterday.
WHITE PLAINS, July 21-- James N. Rosenberg, a lawyer, painter, writer and philanthropist, died at White Plains Hospital today. He was 96 years old and lived at 457 Mamaroneck Road in Scarsdale.

CAIRO, July 21--The Egyptian Minister of National Guidance said today that one of the Israeli pilots captured on the Suez Canal front was an American. The Minister, Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, did not name the prisoner nor did he say when the prisoner had been shot down but described him as a Jew who had arrived in Israel "at the time when Israel was preparing for the 1967 war."

Mrs. Henry Richards Walcott has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Nancy Evelyn Walcott, to Thomas William Peterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. M.C. Peterson of Brookfield, Wis. Miss Walcott is the daughter of the late Mr. Walcott, who was a real-estate broker here.

Miss Gudrun Svensson, a student at the University of Stockholm, was married in her hometown of Junsele, Sweden, yesterday afternoon to Dr. Richard Weinacht Armentrout, an American biochemist doing research at the Karolinska Institute in Stockholm.
The Board of Health announced yesterday that it would defer action on incorporating its proposed amendment on abortion services into the City Health Code.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI)--The ousted ,chief of the Penn Central Railroad complained today it was unfair to picture him as a man who continued to draw an exorbitant salary while the line wallowed in a sea of financial troubles.
NUIDAT, South Vietnam, Wednesday, July 22--(Reuters) --Artillery shells fired by New Zealanders fell around a platoon of Australian soldiers last night, killing two and wounding four.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 21--The Libbey-Owens-Ford glass manufacturing company denied today Government charges of job discrimination against women.
Federal Judge John P. Fullam is expected to announce in Philadelphia today his selection of trustees to operate the Penn Central Transportation Company under the court's jurisdiction.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 21 --The Rev. Theodore O. Wedel, warden emeritus of the College of Preachers at the Washington Cathedral, died of a heart attack last night at the Alexandria Hospital. He was 78 years old.
The City Council yesterday approved a $325,000 six-month budget for the special five-man commission investigating charges of widespread corruption in the Police Department.
HACKENSACK, N.J., July 21 (AP)--Seven current and former East Paterson officials were indicted today by a Bergen County grand jury for alleged violation of bidding laws.
A $183,000 gold shipment bound for Manhattan from Westchester County was hijacked in the Bronx yesterday by two ski-masked gunmen who ordered a truck driver and his helper to "give up or die."

WASHINGTON, July 22 Wilma Soss, president of the Federation of Women Shareholders in American Business, Inc., charged today that the membership of the New York Stock Exchange wants all the advantages of being treated like a public utility with none of the responsibilities.

ROSLYN HEIGHTS, L.I., July 22 Dr. and Mrs. Harold L. Wattel have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Hope Wattel, to Gregory Keith Arenson. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Lewis Arenson of Skokie, Ill.
Earnings of the Kennecott Copper Corporation, the largest integrated producer of American primary copper, soared to record levels in the second quarter and first half, the company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Republican Senators were measurably more cordial toward President Nixon's welfare reform program today as hearings continued in the Senate Finance Committee.

Britain's Conservative Government bases its decision to resume the sale of arms to South Africa in defiance of the United Nations Security Council on two grounds. The official one is that the arms are necessary to implement the Simonstown agreement of 1955, providing for British-South African cooperation in defense of sea lanes around the Cape of Good Hope.
ROME, July 22 Premierdesignate Giulio Andreotti, apparently failing in his effort to form a four-party coalition, sought today to find a loophole in an ally's veto of his political program.
Reports that the Vietcong might accept a coalition Government in South Vietnam had a buoying influence on American Stock Exchange prices yesterday.

SIERRA MAZOTECA, Mexico, July 22 (Reuters) Hundreds of hippies are braving imprisonment and fines to penetrate this mushroom paradise in the State of Oaxaca, where the authorities are conducting a drive against mushroomeaters.
Mrs. Richard M. Nixon, representing the President, was among 500 people who attended a funeral service yesterday for Mrs. Thomas E. Dewey.

Twenty-six major New York State savings banks had a net deposit inflow of $27-million in the first half of July, the Savings Banks Association of New York State reported yesterday. By contrast, in the year-earlier period, these banks 15 in New York City and 11 upstate had a net deposit outflow of almost $134-million.

HACKENSACK, N.J., July 22 After wandering around a few days in the wilderness, the locked-out regulars of the New York Giants have finally found themselves a home away from home the Hackensack High School football field.
LENINGRAD, July 22 Sex and scorekeeping are the only factors dividing the United States track and field team here for a two-day meet with the Soviet Union beginning tomorrow.

Consolidated Edison announced yesterday that its most powerful generator, with a capacity of one million kilowatts, broke down Tuesday night and would be out of service for at least the rest of the summer.

"There are three kinds of lawyers, you know there are those who like cops, those who don't and those who know nothing, about them," Charles Howard Rogovin said yesterday. "I guess I'm the first kind."
ROCKFORD, Ill., July 22 (UPI) Jane Bastanchury and Martha Wilkinson, Curtis Cup team members, continued their winning ways today in the western women's amateur golf tournament.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., July 22 A 23-year-old unemployed laborer was charged today with homicide and rape in the slaying of a young East Islip woman who was abducted from her car around midnight Monday.
TULSA, Okla., July 22 (AP) Vince Carillot resigned today as the head football coach at the University of Tulsa, admitting he had been wrong in the transportation of a prospective player.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, Jan. 22 (AP) An Olympic champion, Kip Keino of Kenya, disdained threats on his life and won the 1,500-meter run today in a highlight of the Commonwealth Games.
At the age of 39, William Overmyer has been elected president of Reach, McClinton Co. And that's after only three months as executive vice president.

PANAMA CITY, Fla., July 22 (UPI) Tropical storm Becky struck the Florida Panhandle today with heavy rains that flooded the State Capitol and a tornado that flattened three houses. No injuries were reported nor any extensive damage.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 22 (Reuters) Unidentified debris that may be from a missing Soviet transport plane was spotted today of the coast of southern Greenland.
NORWALK, Conn., July 22 Miss Betsy Edith Karp, a sophomore at the University of Connecticut, plans to be married next June to Jeffrey J. Davis, a senior there.

CLEVELAND, July 22 (AP) Mrs. Frank Chapot of Wallpack, N.J., rode White Lightning to victory today in the open jumper time class at the 21st annual Chagrin Valley Professional Horsemen's Association show.
Dodge and Delano of Dodge Delano are going to greet next week with brand new titles they're entitled.

The American Waterways Wind Orchestra, a Pittsburghbased ensemble of 45 members that has played its way up and down the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers, along the Atlantic seacoast and on the Thames in England, arrived at Battery Park yesterday at noon for one of the concerts it is giving in this area this week.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22 The Penn Central Transportation Company is to be operated under the supervision of four court-appointed trustees while it remains in reorganization under Section 77 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation confirmed yesterday that it had been negotiating with the Government and a group of 24 of the nation's major banks for a financing package totaling about $430-million designed to keep the company in business in its present form.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday that investors in 32 Broadway and 58 Off Broadway productions during the 1969-70 season suffered losses of $1,481,977 after investing $12.5-million.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., July 22 Lieut. Col. Harry Z. Schreiner, a chaplain at Fort Sam Houston, died today at Brooke Army General Hospital after an illness of several months. He was 58 years old.
STOKE MANDEVILLE, England, July 22 (UPI) The United States increased its gold medals to 11 today to lead 28 other nations in the international Wheelchair Olympics.

DUGORT, Achill Island, Ireland, July 13 As if the English and the Irish lacked enough issues to quarrel about, a controversy is developing between them here on Ireland's Atlantic coast over the destruction of a fish through sport angling.
New York City was accused yesterday by the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies of having failed to use Federal funds and state facilities available for neglected children.

A contract to buy 206 airconditioned buses for the Transit Authority from the General Motors Corporation will be signed at noon today in the offices of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority at 1700 Broadway.

MIAMI, July 22 (AP) A 37year-old cab driver was arrested late tonight and charged with murdering two women who were taken hostage following the robbery of a suburban Western Union office Monday, the police said.
MOSCOW, July 22 (UPI) The Soviet Academy of Sciences announced today the death of Mikhail M. Gerasimov, a distinguished anthropologist and archeologist. He was 62 years old.

The Fresh Meadows section of Queens, a neighborhood of tree-shaded streets, trimmed lawns and hedges and lots of playgrounds, is rapidly becoming, of necessity, a sort of vocational school for homeowners.

It was a bad afternoon at the Stadium yesterday for Mel Stottlemyre and the New York Yankees. Stottlemyre, bothered all year by pitching arm troubles, almost got knocked into the box seats behind the Yankee dugout on a play at the plate in the third inning. Then he gave up successive home runs in the fifth inning that lifted the Milwaukee Brewers to a 4-1 victory.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (AP) The Ripon Society urged President Nixon today to woo voters in the "peripheral South" and abandon "the Southern strategy" because George C. Wallace's victory in Alabama killed it as a national tactic.

HONG KONG, July 22 Four years after it ceased normal academic functioning to make way for the Cultural Revolution, Tsinghua University in Peking, Communist China's foremost engineering school, has started admitting a new student body and holding regular classes again.

WASHINGTON, July 22 (UPI) Miles W. Kirkpatrick, who headed a study panel that sharply criticized the Federal Trade Commission last year, has been offered the chairmanship of the agency, Senate sources said today.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 22 (UPI) J.I.B. Farms' Rollicking won his second stakes race of the year today by beating the favored Hagley by three lengths in the $25,000 added Select Handicap at Monmouth Park.
GENEVA, July 22 Talks that the United States was to hold here at the outset of next week with its major trading partners have been postponed until the end of the week at Washington's request.
WASHINGTON, July 22 With less vehemence than last year but with the Administration now on the defensive, the Senate will begin another protracted antiballistic missile debate tomorrow.

Mayor, in Crown Heights, Asks Unity on Center Mayor Lindsay dropped in at the opening of an Urban Task Force office in the Crown Heights section of Brooklyn last night and called on a racially mixed audience to work together for neighborhood harmony.

MADRID, July 22 Friends, relatives and sympathizers of three building workers shot to death by the police during a demonstration in Granada yesterday began a sit-in this morning in the city's cathedral.
Viktor Pupols of Holly, Wash., is one of the 74 United States chess masters who are rated just below the highest grandmaster group.
Oranges, up nine cents a pound; potatoes, up six cents; apples, up four cents. grapefruits, up four cents each and so it goes.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 22 Doug Kaczenski, 17-year-old son of the Westhampton Country Club pro, gained the semifinals of the 53d Metropolitan Golf Association junior championship at the Nassau Country Club today by turning back Paul R. Schottland of Hollywood Country Club, 6 and 5.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 22 The engagement of Miss Diane Richek to Richard Abbey, son of Henry Abbey of Long Beach and Mrs. Shirley Abbey of Rockville Centre, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert G. Richek of Rockville Centre.
The Police Department's new taxi squad, whose men cruise the streets in dummy taxicabs, made its first five arrests yesterday in its drive to cut down on crimes against taxi drivers.

NEW DELHI, July 22 (Reuters) A Vietcong official said today that some members of the Saigon Government would be acceptable in a coalition Government for South Vietnam. [On the New York Stock Exchange the Dow-Jones industrial average gained more than 10 points following the remarks.]
Thomas A. Wood, president of TAW International Leasing, Inc., was elected yesterday to the boards of the Chase Manhattan Bank, and its parent, the Chase Manhattan Corporation.
Joe Pepitone, who is AWOL from the Houston Astros, said here yesterday that he had no intention of changing his mind and rejoining the team in St. Louis.
Floyd Patterson, who has not fought in nearly two years, agreed yesterday to return to the ring on Sept. 15 in a 10-round bout against Charlie (Devil) Green of New York at Madison Square Garden.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 22 Dr. Charles C. Hewitt, a psychiatrist, died at Mount Auburn Hospital today after a short illness. He was 69 years old and lived in West Hartford, Conn.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The House Agriculture Committee approved today an Administration-supported limit of $55,000 a year that any one farmer may be paid in subsidies for each of three crops wheat, cotton and feed grains.

WASHINGTON, July 22 How can black Americans make the most of their developing political power, despite their minority position in the electorate? A pair of experienced political professionals, speaking to that question the other day at the National Urban League convention in New York, produced some hard common sense and some interesting ideas.

William McChesney Martin Jr., chairman of the Federal Reserve Board from 1951 until his retirement last Jan. 31, was elected a director of the General Foods Corporation at its annual meeting yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y.
Prices on the London stock market closed little changed yesterday after recovering moderate early losses, Trading was quiet.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, July 23 At least 13 American soldiers have been killed and more than 40 wounded in the last 48 hours around a small hilltop artillery outpost near the Ashau Valley.

DETROIT, July 22 Three years ago this city was swept by burning, looting and killing. It was the nation's worst black riot and it ended with a pledge by whites in business, labor and government to solve the problems of the past while building a new Detroit.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, July 22 (Reuters) The Bolivian Government today freed 10 leftwing political prisoners in exchange for two West German technicians kidnapped Sunday by guerrillas, who had threatened to execute them.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation had its top executive echelon take bows yesterday before a special meeting of security analysts for its record first-half and second-quarter results announced last week.

The July soybean trio beans, meal and oil expired on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday and all went out showing strength. Their vigor imparted some price strength to the more distant months as well.

HYANNIS, Mass., July 22 Gerrit Hondius, a painter, died at Cape Cod Hospital today after an illness of three weeks. He was 79 years old and lived at 210 West 72d Street, New York, and in Provincetown.
George E. McDonald, the president of Mailers Union Local No. 6, announced yesterday that agreements on new contracts had been signed with The Daily News and The New York Times.
The average I.Q. scores of recruits entering the Police Department here in 1969 were the lowest recorded in recent years, according to a study financed by the Justice Department.

The print department of the Metropolitan Museum, which can organize a good show any time by thumbing through its own bins, has pulled out 5 etchings by Callot, 10 by Goya, and 6 lithographs by Daumier for "Against Violence," an exhibition that opened this week.
SAN DIEGO, July 22 Preston Gomez is a tall, dignified man who was born in Havana 47 years ago. He lives in Mexico City and works in San Diego as the manager of the Padres of the National League.

Charles H. Rogovin, who resigned in June as head of the Nixon Administration's program for assisting state and local law enforcement, has been named executive director of a new private agency to help police departments across the country improve their operations and training.

CINCINNATI, July 22 (UPI) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., continuing his quest for a third straight Western tennis championship, was extended in beating Patricio Cornejo of Chile. 6-0, 3-6, 6-3, today.

CAPETOWN, July 22 The official racial policy on the 8,000-member Chinese community of South Africa was explained in Parliament here today. The Chinese form a separate racial group with a "separate identity" and may use facilities of the white group "provided the white group does not object."
The Police Department reported yesterday that an offduty patrolman who had caught two suspects in the holdup slaying of a Bronx grocer Tuesday was forced by a hostile crowd to let them go.

WASHINGTON, July 22 A House subcommittee approved a drug abuse bill today that would give the Department of Health. Education and Welfare important jurisdiction in matters of research and classification of dangerous drugs.
BOSTON, July 22 A twoway television system to permit psychiatrists to treat patients 25 miles away has been put into operation between two Boston-area hospitals.
I have read carefully President Nasser's statement of May 1 and your sequent remarks to Mr. Bergus [Donald C. Bergus, "principal United States diplomatic officer in Cairo].
With the summer heatwaves, the rental season at the seashore and in the mountains of the Northeast is well under way. Owners who rent out their property to vaca

BRUSSELS, July 22 Acrimony was introduced today in the British membership talks as deputies of the European Economic Community sought but did not receive clarification of remarks by the British chief negotiator raising the issue of apathy of the British public for the first time.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., July 22 Harry E. Westlake, former vice president of the Kennecott Sales Corporation in New York, died at a hospital here after a long illness. He was 79-years old and lived in Ramsey.

ATHENS, July 22 Six Arab commandos seized a Greek jetliner today and by holding the 55 other passengers and crew members as hostages, won a promise of freedom for seven Arab guerrillas held in jails by the Athens Government.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., July 22 Mr, and Mrs. Frank Thomas Dainese have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Teresa Dainese, to Stephen Fay Sachs, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Henry Sachs of Pound Ridge, N.Y.
Members of Radio City Music Hall's famous dancing troupe, the Rockettes, late last night voted unanimously to accept a new management contract proposal and to call off a threatened strike.
The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday asked the Federal Courts to declare the Xerox Corporation's copier patents invalid and unenforceable.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 A 20-year-old American soldier was taken into custody here this evening after trying to hijack an Air Vietnam passenger plane and force it to take him to Hong Kong.
WASHINGTON, July 22 According to Vice President Agnew, the Nixon Administration has not liberalized its political outlook and does not plan to.
The bond market stumbled early yesterday, briefly interrupting the advance in prices that began five weeks ago, but then it regained its footing.
Edgar H. Smith, who has written a legal chronicle and a book of fiction on his 13 years on death row, has been elected a member of the American chapter of the P.E.N. Club.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The United States said today that it would quickly open discussions with Israel and Jordan on the basis of what was viewed in Washington as a positive though qualified Egyptian reSponSe to itS proposal for a 90-day cease-fire in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, July 22 William F. Buckley Jr., the fiery advocate of conservative causes, said today that the Voice of America ought to be more realistic and aggressive in commentaries on the Soviet Union even if it was diplomatically irritating.
LONDON, July 22 Amid scenes of furious uproar, the Labor party mounted a bitter attack today on the British Government's decision to consider the sale of arms to South Africa.
NEW DELHI, July 22--A flooded river in the Himalayan foothills swept 25 buses, 5 taxis and an army vehicle into a narrow gorge today and as many as 600 people may have died.

Representative Fred B. Rooney, whose Pennsylvania district was the scene last week of a bus accident that killed seven Long Island children, said yesterday that he would introduce legislation next week to impose broad new Federal regulatory authority over chartered buses.
Electronic Associates, the nation's leading producer of analog computers, introduced yesterday a new, low-cost teaching device.

John J. Gilhooley, whose Urban Industries, Inc., has agreed to buy Public Service Coordinated Transport Company, said yesterday that he would try using recent innovations to improve service on the bus line, New Jersey's largest.
American housewives may take umbrage, but I have observed that many of them fail miserably in seafood cookery.

The police have been at the center of so marry of the tensions that now roil the nation that individual policemen, police stations and police equipment have become frequent targets of attack by murderers and bombers. It was in this pattern that two Chicago policemen were killed a few days ago by sniper fire from windows in a housing project.
The Chase Manhattan Bank was condemned for its financial links to South Africa by the National Urban League yesterday as the human rights group closed its 60th annual conference.

A mountain is a mountain only when compared to a hill, and a masterpiece is a masterpiece only when compared to a piece by a master. So, it was interesting to hear a three-concert series of Mozart trios and sonatas launched Tuesday night with three of his lesser outcroppings of talent.

The guilty verdict last night against former Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio of Newark may have rung down the curtain on the career of a politician whose tenure in office ended in a storm of controversy as turbulent as the social tides engulfing his troubled city.

The Shubert Theaters, one of the nation's largest playhouse owner-operator concerns, has taken a 30-year lease on a new theater now under construction in Century City, the 180-acre urban development in Los Angeles.

Dr. Lewis H. Bronstein, associate medical director of Beekman Downtown Hospital and medical director of Gracie Square Hospital, died of cancer Tuesday at the American Hospital in Paris. He was 61 years old and lived at 46 East 91st Street.
The grooviest thing to hit Greenwich Village on Tuesday night and we do mean hit was "Sambo." Musically, it was certainly the greatest.

WASHINGTON, July 22 The Senate headed today for a showdown vote on the District of Columbia crime bill, with the odds favoring its approval but a stubborn band of opponents insisting that they have a chance of defeating the controversial measure.
NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., July 22 (UPI) Drug charges against Chubby Checker, the rock band leader, were dropped today in Niagara Falls City Court.
COHASSET, Mass., July 22 Miss Emilie Evans Dean, a graduate of the University of Colorado in Boulder, plans to be married in September to Jonathan Evans McBride, a graduate of Yale University.
Present and projected use of saccharin poses no known hazard to man, a special panel of the National Academy of Sciences-National Research Council has advised the Food and Drug Administration.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 22 Cambodian officials who took part in the first round of talks today between Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia and Premier Thanom Kittikachorn of Thailand expressed pessimism that there would be any significant increase in Thai aid 20 Cambodia.
A damage suit against the Penn Central Company and its officers and directors was filed here in Federal Court yesterday by Louis W. Goodkind, a lawyer who said he owned 500 shares.
DETROIT, July 22 (UPI) A 26-year-old housewife has told the police that she is the "pillowcase burglar" responsible for 150 to 200 Detroit-area burglaries in the last eight months.
WASHINGTON, July 22 Two leading Democratic economists told Congress in effect today to go ahead and increase President Nixon's budget.

BALTIMORE This is the blue crab capital of the world, and hard and soft shell crabs are to the gourmets of this town what bay prawns are to Dubliners, crawfish are to the Cajuns of Louisiana, and toheroa, that rare shellfish, to the gastronomes of New Zealand.

When President Nixon on July 1 named the new chief negotiator in the Paris peace parleys, he said that Ambassador Bruce would have "great flexibility in the conduct of his talks" except for two conditions. After this week's Presidential news conference, that flexibility appears to have been severely restricted.

An open hearing will be held at City Hall today to determine whether the city will award 20year franchises to two of its current cable television operators and whether to authorize the Bureau of Franchises to award all future cable TV contracts after competitive bidding.

The King Resources Company of Denver, which tried without success to take over the financially ailing Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., earlier this year, may now be facing some financial difficulties of its own.

"Good old man," said Angel Cordero in the winner's circle, patting Baitman's neck after the running of the feature race at Aqueduct yesterday. The good old man, a 9-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. William Frankel, had just won the mileand-a-sixteenth turf feature
The Berkeley, Calif., police hope to conduct tests soon of a new "stun gun" in law-enforcement situations.

Sales and earnings of the Eastman Kodak Company in the second quarter slipped slightly, although the half-year results set records, the nation's leading photographic equipment producer reported yesterday.
