A player on opening lead who is the lucky possessor of a suit headed by ace-kingqueen might be forgiven for supposing that it does not matter which of the honors he leads. Expert views vary, but the point is apparently a trivial one.
Irving Anker, who has been Acting Superintendent of Schools since March 1, was named deputy chancellor of the city school system last night.

Kinney National Service, Inc., and the Elektra Corporation announced yesterday that Kinney had purchased all outstanding stock of Elektra for cash, notes and convertible debentures valued at slightly under $10-million. Elektra produces records and specializes in folk, rock and classical music.
A retired assistant chief inspector of the city's police force was arrested yesterday on a charge of contempt for refusing to tell a Manhattan grand jury whether he had been offered a bribe.

A customer who had "a couple of shots of liquor" before signing a nearly illegible installment credit contract and a white French Provincial bedroom chest that was "repaired" by being painted two shades of pink dominated the testimony at a Consumer Affairs Department hearing yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, July 22 The man who is said to have fired the first shot into Alex Rackley the night he was murdered testified for the prosecution here today that members of the Black Panther party listened to a tape recording made after the victim had been tortured with hot water.
The Saturday closing of Fifth Avenue to vehicles will be extended south to 34th Street this week, but some southbound buses will be permitted among the pedestrians.
Miss Victoria Ford Joy and Richard Brown Emmons plan to be married in September.

City housing officials yesterday assured groups interested in the completion of the West Side Urban Renewal Project that no work would start on the next building until Federal subsidy money was received.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 22 (AP) The United States Army is trying to get soldiers in Vietnam who use marijuana or other drugs to turn themselves in and get help. It promises that those who do so will not be punished.

The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation and subsidiaries reported yesterday declines in net income for the June quarter and first half despite higher operating revenues and net income in both periods.
One of the largest mortgage loans ever made here $100million has been arranged to finance a 57-story office building being erected just north of Madison Square Garden.

The 26 team owners of the National Football League agreed yesterday to take their disputed labor issue with the Players Association to Federal mediation and also asked the assocation if it would be willing to direct the Kansas City Chiefs to start practicing for the College All-Star Game scheduled for July 31 in Chicago.
GENEVA, July 22 The International Commission of Jurists today accused Brazil's military regime of making a "Systematic and scientifically developed practice" of Torture.
WASHINGTON, July 22 The Internal Revenue Service issued guidelines today aimed at clarifying what types of interest payments banks that own taxexempt municipal bonds may deduct as a business expense.

Shortly after noon yester day 1,184,300 shares of the Goodyear. Tire and Rubber Company crossed the tape at 24 , 2 points below Teesday's close, making history as the largest single block of stock ever traded on the New York Stock Exchange.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 22 Gov. James A. Rhodes of Ohio called today for "decentralizing Washington."
If the Pittsburgh pitching staff is to win an award this season, it will have to come from the American Medical Association.
Stock prices surged upward in heavy trading in a brief noon-hour rally yesterday, only to lose most of their gains in slower and quieter trading later in the session.

The nation's leading organization of trial lawyers called upon judges yesterday to ban from their courts, for as much as six months, any lawyer who "willfully contributes" to disorder in the courtroom.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., July 22 "Is this the freshman team" a passer-by asked in wonderment at Adelphi University today.
CAMP HERO, Montauk, L.I., July 22 A force of about 100 men turned back a commando invasion from the sea in a predawn war game today.
Dave Meggyesy was sitting in his room talking football with a bunch of teammates when one of them asked him how much he was getting.
ST. PAUL, July 22 (AP) Croil Hunter, chairman emeritus of the board of Northwest Airlines, died last night in a hospital here after a brief illness. He was 75 years old.

CAIRO, July 22 The United Arab Republic told the United States today that it was ready to stop shooting and start talking on the basis of United Nations resolutions, according to a well-placed diplomatic source.
SAN DIEGO, July 22 The San Diego Padres knocked Tom Seaver out of the box in the ninth inning tonight and scored off Nolan Ryan in the 10th to defeat the New York Mets, 5-4.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., July 22 William John Heaslip, an artist, died yesterday at Morristown Memorial Hospital. He was 73 years old and live in Hackettstown.
LONDON, July 22 The Royal Shakespeare Company presented a glorious failure last night at the Aldwych Theater, the kind of luxury that only a great national theatrical institution can afford.

WASHINGTON, July 22 A high-level panel has urged President Nixon to withhold all Federal aid from communities that refused to undertake programs to increase the supply of low and moderate-income housing.
TRENTON, July 22--Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other defendants were found guilty by a Federal jury tonight on 64 counts each, one of conspiracy and 63 of extortion.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Representative Wright Patman charged today that the Nixon Administration had planned to proceed with a $200-million loan guarantee for the Penn Central Transportation Company even after the Federal Reserve Bank of New York had warned that the railroad might not be able to repay the debt.

WASHINGTON, July 22 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, who guided the 1965 immigration bill through the Senate, proposed today five revisions in immigration policy, among them better control over workers coming in from Mexico.

LIGONIER, Pa., July 22 The golf tour moves tomorrow into Arnold Palmer's backyard. Although Palmer lives a dozen miles away, in Latrobe, he is listed as the Laurel Valley Golf Club's touring pro. He and his partner, Jack Nicklaus, are the favorites to win the renewal of the $200,000 National fourball team championship.
WASHINGTON, July, 22 (AP) The state of Massachusetts urged the Supreme Court today to rule that the participation of the United States in the Vietnam war is unconstitutional.

Brooklyn is in fact one of the nation's greatest cities with a population almost as large as Los Angeles and much larger than Philadelphia.

LONDON, July 22 Britain and West Germany have agreed to develop a combat aircraft for service in the late nineteen-seventies, Lord Carrington, the Minister of Defense, announced in the House of Lords today.

DETROIT, July 22 The Big Four auto makers reported today retail sales of 202,886 American-type cars in the July 11-20 period, nudging ahead of sales of 202,300 units in the corresponding period a year before. The report was another sign of growing strength in the automobile business.
WASHINGTON, July 22 New orders for durable goods rose slightly in June from the May level but remained well below the order flow of the last half of 1969, the Commerce Department reported today.

SACO, Me., July 22 Walter S. Perkins, former president and chairman of the board of directors of the Burnham and Morrill, Portland food packers, died in his home here yesterday after suffering a heart attack. He was 62 years old.
INGLEWOOD, Calif., July 22 (AP) Favored One For All came up with a second effort in the stretch and prevailed by two lengths in the $132,850 Sunset Handicap as the Hollywood Park season ended today.

WASHINGTON, July 23 The Senate decisively approved today the controversial District of Columbia crime bill. The vote, 54 to 33, was far from the close outcome that critics of the measure had hoped to achieve after a week of debate.
One policeman suffered a fractured skull when he and a colleague, both in civilian clothes, were assaulted by a group of teen-agers near Police Headquarters last night.
LONG BEACH, Calif., July 23 (UPI) Vice President Agnew introduced today the McDonnell-Douglas DC-10 Trijet. The plane was hailed as "larger, cleaner and quieter."

During the nearly two decades since outside critics began to question the wisdom of dumping huge quantities of pesticides and herbicides on the nation's crops, some elements within the Agriculture Department have been stubbornly resisting reform and regulation of this dubious practice.

President Nixon earned considerable domestic and foreign applause last November when he announced his decision to seek Senate ratification of the Geneva protocol banning first use of chemical and biological weapons. The failure of the United States to endorse the 1925 treaty, which Americans helped draft, has been an international disgrace for 45 years.

WASHINGTON, July 23 It is no accident that the ceremonial leader of a White House delegation who arrived today in New Mexico for a tribal rite of the Taos Pueblo Indians is a 14-year-old District of Columbia schoolgirl named Kim Agnew.

WASHINGTON, July 23 President Nixon is heading west again tomorrow, with much of the United States Government in tow. This is news, quite apart from the serious economic and political business to be considered in California.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., July 23 The United Nations Security Council approved a tightened arms embargo against South Africa today because of its racial-separation policies.

The National Association of Securities Dealers suspended three New York City over-thecounter firms yesterday and took disciplinary action against five individuals for violation of its fair practice rules.
WASHINGTON, July 23 Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird said today that draft calls for the rest of 1970 would return to pre-Vietnam levels of under 10,000 a month.

Despite a crossfire of threats and accusations aroused by their labor impasse, the National Football League owners' committee and the leaders of the N.F.L. Players Association have agreed to meet with Federal mediators today in Philadelphia.

WASHINGTON, July 23 Diplomatic relations between the Nixon Administration and the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, long strained by basic policy differences, are showing signs of reaching the breaking point.

NEWARK, July 23 United States Attorney Frederick B. Lacey said today that further investigations of Newark city of fairs will be undertaken as a result of "material which has come to our attention" during the prosecution of former Newark Mayor Hugh J. Addonizio and other city officials.

LONDON, July 23 Harold Wilson, the Labor party leader, named his shadow cabinet today, appointing most of the 12 members to the same portfolios they held before his government was defeated in the election last month.
WASHINGTON, July 23 An independent expert on hunger charged today that 40 of the 60 leading dry breakfast cereals were so low in nutritional content that they constituted "empty calories."

WASHINGTON, July 23 (Reuters) President Nixon and President Urho Kekkonen of Finland conferred for 90 minutes today on the outlook for a United States-Soviet agreement on limiting strategic armaments and proposals for an East-West conference on European security.

CLEVELAND, July 23 (AP) Jane Bostwick of Blue Lakes Stables in Newbury, Ohio, led in today's beginners show in the 21st annual Chagrin Valley Professional Horsemen's Association Horse Show by winning three titles.
NEW HAVEN, July 23 Dr. Louis C. Graton, a retired mining gealogist and professor emeritus of mining geology at Harvard University, died yesterday. He was 90 years old.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 23 Vincent C. Hall's custom-built 60-footer Deuteron and Roland Voorhees's 42-foot Matthews Tyche were winners of predicted-log events that began the annual New York Yacht Club Cruise in a small way today and yesterday.

CINCINNATI, July 23 (AP) All favorites advanced today in the Western tennis championships on a drizzly day when unseeded Turner Howard's upset bubble burst.

WASHINGTON, July 23 Consumer groups here have gone to court with a complaint that an advertisement for Excedrin, a headache remedy, was "false, misleading and deceptive."

The New York Stock Exchange, the Association of Stock Exchange Firms and 43 major brokerage firms were accused of violations of the Clayton Act and the Sherman Antitrust Act in a suit filed yesterday in Federal Court here by a California group known as the American Association of Securities Representatives.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Friday, July 24 Thirteen persons were taken into custody last night during disorders in which windows were broken, fire bombs thrown and firemen hit with stones.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 23 The Northern Ireland government today banned public parades for six months in a move to ease tensions between Protestants and Roman Catholics that have adversely affected the economy of Ulster.

Dr. William J. Ronan, the chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that the city's subway system's safety rules would be changed today to prohibit any movement of a train on a red signal unless specifically authorized.

PARIS, July 23 Here and there on the French vacation scene, small bands of young New Left revolutionaries are trying to make good their warning that they intend to spoil the summer pleasures of the bourgeoisie.
WASHINGTON, July 23 The United States began today to strike back at the sweeping system of export subsidies of farm products used by the European Common Market.

CHICAGO, July 23 (AP) The casualty insurance industry announced the formation of an organization today to investigate fraudulent insurance claims. It will give priority attention to automobile accident rings.
The King Resources Company of Denver said late yesterday that it was still working on plans to refinance some $17million in loans due this year.

LEICESTER, England, July 23 (Reuters) Patti Hogan of La Jolla, Calif., upset the American rankings by beating Julie Heldman of New York, 6-3, 4-6, 7-5, in the semifinals of the Midland open lawn tennis tournament today.

CANANDAIGUA, N.Y., July 23 (AP) Thomas Tongyai, an undercover sheriff's deputy known as "Tommy the Traveler," was jailed today as a material witness in the special state inquiry into disorders at Hobart College.

David C. Croninger, president of the Metromedia radio division of Metromedia, Inc., has left that post effective immediately. Mr. Croninger had held the position since January of 1969.

The Federal Reserve System, which has been under heavy pressure from the Nixon Administration to ease its monetary policy further, has apparently quickened the rate of growth of money and credit somewhat.

Martin Birnbaum, art dealer, friend of artists and confidant of the rich and the celebrated, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 92 years old.
LONDON, July 23 A twoday court of inquiry into the causes of the nationwide dock strike that has closed 40 British ports ended today as the walkout by 47,000 longshoremen entered its second week.

BOSTON, July 23-Arthur Kohlenberg of Cambridge, senior vice president of Codex Corporation, digital communications equipment maker, died here Sunday. He was 46 years old and had suffered from Hodgkin's disease.
Agreement on a new contract between Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2 and the publishers of the city's four major newspapers was announced yesterday by the union's president, William J. Kennedy.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 23 (AP) Marilyn Neufville, 17year-old London schoolgirl from Jamaica set a world record of 51 seconds for the women's 400 meters at the British Commonwealth Games today and then refused to say a word about it.

When Herman Hickman, an unreconstructed rebel from Tennessee, was head coach of football at Yale he decided to protect his flank one season by bringing in as his assistant another flower of the Confederacy, Douglas Clyde Walker. Since Yale was Yale, the nickname the new coach had borne for 40 years was almost never mentioned. Herman always referred to his long time eatin' and drinkin' companion as "D.C."
FORT KNOX, Ky., July 23 "They're an outstanding bunch of young men," the general said, "Well motivated, always smiling, Always moving."
WASHINGTON, July 23 The United States today declared its serious concern over the first Soviet arms shipments to Libya at a time of delicate peace initiatives in the Middle East.

An admitted numbers operator testified today that she paid a detective $200 on the first of each month from the summer of 1967 until after she was arrested the following March. She was a prosecution witness at the Bronx Supreme Court perjury trial of a suspended detective, Eugene Goddard.
BANGKOK, Thailand, July 23 Premier Lon Nol of Cambodia returned to Pnompenh today after a two-day visit here that failed to produce what he sought assurances of more active Thai aid to Cambodia.

CUTTYHUNK, Mass., July 23 Eugene W. Carder's Hughes 38-foot sloop, Yearling, out of Stamford (Conn.) Yacht Club, was the Division I winner on the 39th annual American Yacht Club Cruise today when a fleet of 35 raced 34 miles from Block Island to Cuttyhunk.
The Mets and Yankees passed each other at 35,000 feet yesterday, hoping that they could regain some momentum on the ground and start passing teams in their respective divisions.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., July 23 Max Sloman, chairman of the board of Bing Bing, Inc., real estate, 119 West 40th Street, New York, died today in New Rochelle Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 88 Broadview Avenue.

The sculpture of Alexander Archipenko (1887-1964) occupies a curious place in the history of modern art. Though an artist of undeniable power and originality, Archipenko never attained the status that his remarkable gifts would seem to have entitled him to.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (AP) The House Agriculture Com mittee attached to the food stamp program today new restrictions including work requirements and minimum payments for recipients.

Albert Schiller, a retired graphics expert who created type pictures composed entirely of type ornaments, died Wednesday in Memorial Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 1671 54th Street, Brooklyn.

City Council President Sanford D. Garelik, a political ally turned persistent critic of Mayor Lindsay, yesterday helped block an appropriation for the Mayor's special com mission to investigate possible police corruption.

Hugh Mulligan, believed by police officials and experts on organized crime to be a key figure in police corruption here, lives in a modest Cape Cod home in Queens, goes to sports events with important friends and is said to look like "a pinkcheeked King Farouk."

PHILADELPHIA, July 23 (AP) The four trustees named to supervise the Penn Central Transportation Company in its reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws held their first meeting today with the judge who selected them.

WASHINGTON, July 23 A Justice Department analysis of the shooting incident in which four students were killed at Kent State University last May is reported to suggest that it was unnecessary for National Guardsmen to fire at the students to protect themselves.
Earnings of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation in the second quarter and first half declined sharply from year-earlier evels, reflecting lower sales and phasing out of old-generation aircraft.

OSTERVILLE, Mass., July 23 (AP) Shirley Englehorn of Caldwell, Idaho, set a course record with a one-under-par 71 today in the second half of the two-day pro-amatuer $10,000 Cape Cod Hospital golf classic at Oyster Harbors Country Club.
SYOSSET, L.I., July 23 Mrs. Bettina Hollis Powell was married to John T. Haneman Jr. here tonight by Judge James A. Eisenman of the Village Court of Laurel Hollow at his home.

LENINGRAD, July 23 The Soviet Union track and field team today survived rain, derisive hooting from its own fans and intermittent flashes of speed from the opposition and took the lead over the United States in the first day of a dual meet.
Technology is both hero and villain of "Future Shock," a new book by Alvin Toffler that has stirred interest in the publishing world even before it has reached the bookstores.

PARIS, July 23 It was the kind of day when many people following the fashion showings here wished they were in another line of work. Three of the couture's biggest guns blasted off. Where the shots landed, nobody was quite sure.

WESTBURY, L.I., July 23 Jean Mary, the Frenchman who will drive the favored Tidalium Pelo at Roosevelt Raceway in tomorrow night's $30,000 Roguepine Trot the sequel, to last week's $125,000 International is not a student of Shakespeare.

HOLLYWOOD, July 23 (UPI) Leith Stevens, director of television music at Paramount Studios, collapsed and died of a heart attack at his office today after learning that his wife, Elizabeth, had been killed in an automobile accident in the Santa Rosa Mountains near Palm Springs, Calif.

WASHINGTON, July 23 Henry A. Kissinger, President Nixon's adviser on national security, told a Congressional group today that the United States must proceed with deployment of a missile defense system to insure progress in negotiations with the Soviet Union on the control of strategic arms.

HAVERFORD, Pa., July 23 John Mulford, a partner of the Philadelphia law firm of Drinker, Biddle Reath, and Mrs. Mulford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Biddle Mulford, to John Calvin Hover 2d of New York, son of John Curry Hover, a partner of the New York law firm of Davis, Polk Wardwell, and Mrs. Hover of Short Hills, N.J.
WASHINGTON, July 23 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended July 18 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

WASHINGTON,July 23 (AP) Elderly or infirm persons who use sauna or steam baths may suffer adverse effects, the Federal Trade Commission warned today. It ordered a further study of the effects of the treatments.
BONN, July 23 Fritz Kortner, the actor and director, died of leukemia in Munich yesterday. He was 78 years old.
BRUSSELS, July 23 The Executive Commission of the European Common Market is taking an extremely serious view of the restrictive trade bill, now on its way through Congress.

TRENTON, July 23 The conviction of Hugh J. Addonizio, former Mayor of Newark, and four other defendants on all 64 counts each of extortion and conspiracy by a Federal jury last night has encouraged the Government in its prosecution of the other men accused in the case.

PARIS Twenty years ago Nathalie Sarraute, the French writer, composed the manifesto of le nouveau roman (the new novel). Today the specter that haunts her is le nouveau nouveau roman (the new new novel).

Arab guerrillas have provided another demonstration that their fanaticism recognizes neither national boundaries nor international law. By hijacking a Greek plane and threatening to blow it up with its passengers and crew, they extorted a promise from the Greek Government to release seven Arab criminals now in an Athens jail for similar offenses.
WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) The House approved legislation today that would extend unemployment benefits to 4.4 million more workers but defeated a move to cover some farm employes for the first time.

DETROIT, July 23 (AP) With more auto plants idle because of the change-over to the 1971 models, auto production in the United States plunged to 56,688 units this week, compared with 117,404 last week and 58,552 in the corresponding week a year ago.

If Milt Pappas is remembered for nothing else, he always will be recalled as the key player of the three Cincinnati wanted so badly that they wrapped up Frank Robinson in a pretty ribbon and gave him away to Baltimore.
The Manhattan District Attorney's office is investigating a network of city policemen who are controlled by organized crime, a highly placed law enforcement official said yesterday.

AREA A Plenty of bluefish, 2 to 4 pounds, being taken by jigging inshore boats from Mantoloking to Sea Girt, reports John Bogan Jr. Offshore boats chumming with mossbunkers from 17 to 21 miles east by south of Manasquan Inlet are doing well with bluefish in 5 to 14 pound class. Fluke pickings from Spring Lake to Seaside remain slim. Sea bass running in slightly better numbers from Mantoloking to Sea Girt.
HARTFORD, July 23 Senator Thomas J. Dodd, a life-long Democrat, announced today that he would campaign for re-election as an independent.

WASHINGTON, July 23 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that it was his "hope and expectation" that the nation's economy would return to full employment some time in 1971.

LONDON, July 23 Shouting "Belfast! See how you like it!" a demonstrator hurled two gas bombs into the packed House of Commons today, filling the gallery with thick white smoke and leaving members gasping, shouting and crawling beneath benches.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) With President Nixon's concurrence, Attorney General John N. Mitchell has told the Justice Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation to stop using the terms "Mafia" and "Cosa Nostra" because they offend "decent Italian-Americans."

The death of Chancellor of the Exchequer Iain MacLeod earlier this week was a loss not only to the British nation but also to the narrower world of contract bridge. Before he reached Cabinet rank in 1952 during a brilliant career as a statesman, he was a leading figure in English bridge circles.
City Controller Abraham D. Beame told the Board of Estimate yesterday that the city had privately agreed to pay outside individual consultants "rates as high as $500 and $700 a day."

ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, July 23 (Canadian Press) Oarsmen and scullers from the Fairmont Rowing Association of Philadelphia put together a victory and two second places today in the opening events of the 88th Royal Canadian Henley Regatta.

In response to rising tensions over the city's housing shortage, the Lindsay administration called a temporary halt yesterday to evictions by landlords who want to demolish or renovate structurally sound, rentcontrolled buildings.

Henry J. Taylor, syndicated columnist and former Ambassador to Switzerland, and Marion Janet Elizabeth (Rikki) Richardson, an artist, were married in Paris in a civil ceremony on July 3. The couple returned to New York last week aboard the France, after a week in Deauville, France.

WINNETKA, Ill., July 23 Mr. and Mrs. John T. Snyder Jr., formerly of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Jenkins Snyder, to Stephen Hunter Morris. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Morris of Providence, R.I.
CAIRO, July 23 President Gamal Abdel Nasser announced tonight that he had accepted the United States proposal for a three-month cease-fire at the frontier with the Israelis.
The oil industry continued yesterday to turn in mixed, generally lower earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

WASHINGTON, July 23 A New York City housing official said today that the problem of abandoned housing, now largely confined to Harlem, the South Bronx and the Brownsville and East New York section of Brooklyn, was threatening to turn 20 other city neighborhoods into "veritable ghost towns."
Banks, brokerage houses and a hotel chain figured in yesterday's major merger developments.

Henry J. Taylor, syndicated columnist and former Ambassador to Switzerland, and Marion Janet Elizabeth (Rikki) Richardson, an artist, were married in Paris in a civil ceremony on July 3. The couple returned to New York last week aboard the France, after a week in Deauville, France.

WINNETKA, Ill., July 23 Mr. and Mrs. John T. Snyder Jr., formerly of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Jenkins Snyder, to Stephen Hunter Morris. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Morris of Providence, R.I.
NORWALK, Conn., July 23 Edwin S. Malesky, a consultant at the Personnel Laboratory, Inc., Stamford, died here today.
WASHINGTON, July 23 Heeding President Nixon's criticism of "the big spenders," the House rejected today a liberal move that would have pumped $360-million more into health programs.
"He's got as good a left hand as any heavyweight I've ever seen. He can tear a man's head off with it just like Joe Louis used to do."

DETROIT, July 23 The Ford Motor Company today reported record June-quarter sales but an 8 per cent drop in profits and warned of "serious consequences" if the United Auto Workers win an "excessive settlement" in its new contract.

WASHINGTON, July 23 (UPI) The Civil Service Commission proposed to Congress today a plan to enable the President to adjust pay scales for white collar government workers automatically in line with changes in the salaries pair their counterparts in private industry.
Even though she stumbled slightly at the start Princess Roycraft of the Franlyn Stable had enough speed to win the sixfurlong feature event at Aqueduct yesterday.
ROCHESTER, July 23 (AP) John Calabria of Rochester shot a one-under-par 71 today and took a one-stroke lead in the state men's amateur golf tournament with a 36-hole total of 142.
As expected, Walston Co., and Hayden, Stone, Inc., announced yesterday the merger of the two brokerage firms into a company to be called Walston Hayden Stone, Inc.

STRATFORD, Ontario, July 23 Two new plays, Fernando Arrabal's "The Architect and the Emperor of the Assyrians" and Arnold Wesker's "The Friends," and one almost forgotten one, Shakespeare's rarely performed "Cymbeline," opened this week at the Stanford Festival. It is almost a certainty that at present none of the three is being produced anywhere else in North America.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 23 American airborne troops hastily abandoned a hilltop artillery base today just north of the Ashau valley, an enemy stronghold controlling infiltration routes from Laos, The action was taken after heavy bombing strikes and artillery barrages failed to stop a North Vietnamese army build-up around the post.
Shape with varying, degrees of comfort is the thing in the new collection of modern imported furniture due on Gimbels' ninth floor on Monday. The preponderance of unusual forms comes from France.

The New York Knicks, looking to the future, acquired the rights yesterday to Heyward Dotson, a Rhodes Scholar and former Columbia star, from the Phoenix Suns for a future draft choice. The Suns had selected Dotson on the seventh round of the college draft last March.

ROCKFORD, Ill., July 23 (AP) Jane Bastanchury, the defender, and Martha Wilkinson joined Mrs. Paul Dommers and Melanie Schiller in the semifinals of the 70th annual women's Western amateur tournament today.
The governors of the New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange endorsed yesterday a proposed computerized system aimed at sharply reducing the sale of stolen or missing securities.
LONDON, July 23 A British shipping official accused the Japanese today of being the worst offenders in polluting the world's sea lanes.

MOSCOW, July 23 Ambassador Jacob D. Beam said today that he had told William F. Buckley Jr. in May that he thought the Voice of America's broadcasts should have a "crisper approach" to get the American program across.

WASHINGTON, July 23 Sherman Edward Unger, the general counsel of the Department of Housing and Urban Development and an aide in Richard M. Nixon's political campaigns since 1960, will be the President's next nominee to the Federal Communications Commission, the White House announced today.
JERUSALEM, July 23 A committee of undergraduates at Hebrew University has cautioned that foreign students half of them American-are being made to feel too isolated from the Israeli student community.

Mrs. Elizabeth Allen Fay of Huntington, L. I., widow of Richard Hull Fay, who was a radio engineer with the Columbia Broadcasting System, was married here at noon yesterday to Robert Starkey of Westport, Conn., a vice president of the Ask Mr. Foster Travel Service here.

The vibrant sounds of the mobile jazz combo and cast of "Sambo" rocked City Hall Park yesterday as its sponsor, the New York Shakespeare Festival, made a public plea for $100,000 to complete the festival's summer program.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., July 23 Mrs. Robert B. Williams of Pompano Beach and John J. Bernard of Houston have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Justice Bernard, to George Alexandre Zara, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael W. Zara of Huntington, L.I.
In the menus below, dishes marked with an asterisk are followed by a recipe.

In an effort to speed traffic and cut labor costs, three transportation agencies said yesterday that they would introduce one-way toll collections Aug. 12 on nine Hudson River bridges and tunnels and three crossings between Staten Island and New Jersey.
After seven hours and 75 witnesses, the Board of Esti mate last night postponed until Tuesday a decision on whether to award two 20-year cable television franchises for Manhattan.

DETROIT, July 23 A Federal grand jury today indicted 13 persons, including the leaders of the Weatherman, on charges of conspiring to bomb and kill. Ten of the 13 are already being sought on fugitive warrants in other Federal or local cases.
WASHINGTON, July 23 Treasury bill rates declined at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

The Jazz in the Garden series at the Museum of Modern Art served up an odd coupling on Thursday evening Odetta, the artful, robust-voiced folk and blues singer, and the Fourth Way, an electric quartet that mingles jazz, country music and rock.
GRANADA, Spain, July 24 The line of old men was back on the railings behind Granada's curly, biscuit-colored cathedral this morning. The nearby passageways were thronged with pedestrians once more.

WASHINGTON, July 24(AP) Hearings have been set for Aug. 4 before a Senate communications subcommittee to work out guidelines for the use of broadcast time by the President and other political leaders.

Jan Kadar, the Czechoslovak director of the Academy Award-winning 1965 Czech movie, "The Shop on Main Street," whose first American film, "The Angel Levine," opens here Tuesday, will direct his second American feature, "I Never Promised You a Rose Garden." The drama will star Liza Minnelli and Estelle Parsons, who also won an Oscar for her role in "Bonnie and Clyde."

One of the great rarities in the autograph field an unpublished letter by Edgar Allan Poe was auctioned on Thursday night for $5,250. It is a brief letter, revealing the author's chronic financial distress and disclosing that the payment for his story, "The Black Cat," had been $20.
A rating chart of the nutrients contained in 60 breakfast cereals published yesterday in The New York Times was inaccurate in one respect.

NEW LONDON, Conn., July 24 Erin Martin made her public choreographic debut today at Connecticut College's American Dance Festival here. Things being as they are in the current transitional stage of moderndance, the work was presented not on the stage of Palmer Auditorium as might be expected but outdoors at twilight at nearby Harkness State Park.

Mrs. Florence Weltfish Goldin, consultant and until recently vice president of Grey Advertising Inc., 777 Third Avenue, died of cancer yesterday at her home, 185 West End Avenue. Her age Was 65. Mrs. Goldin was the widow of Dr. Samuel Goldin, a dentist.

Dr. Harvey B. Scribner, the Chancellor-elect of the city school system, intends to go into the schools and the communities to "get a feel of the situation" he will face after he takes over on Sept. 1.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., July 24 A neurochemist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology offered evidence today that L-Dopa, the drug used with dramatic success in treating Parkinson's disease, may work by entirely unsuspected means.
LORIENT, France, July 24 (Reuters) South Africa took possession of its first submarine, built in France, here today.
Louis Harris, a painter, died last Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, in his studio at 203 Bleecker Street, where he also maintained a residence. He was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 24 Representatives of the International Red Cross have protested the treatment of prisoners of war by the South Vietnamese Government. An inspection report shows that they told Saigon that its treatment of seven of 24 North Vietnamese soldiers at the Con Son Prison violated the Geneva Convention on prisoners of war.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) The Transportation Department today issued a new safety standard to prevent the threat of death or injury to children from power-operated car windows.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 24 (AP) United States fighter-bombers today attacked North Vietnamese positions around an abandoned American artillery base on a mountain in the far north and struck repeatedly at the summit to destroy anything of value left behind.
Rutger Bleecker Miller Jr., an assistant vice president of the First National City Bank, died of cancer Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived at 14 East 90th Street.

JEFFERSONVILLE, Ind., July 23, Dr. George Hay Brown, director of the Bureau of the Census, said today the factors that caused 5 million Americans to be omitted from the 1960 census had become more widespread in the intervening decade but he was hopeful 1970 counting techniques would reduce similar errors.

Several months ago a New Yorker dispatched a telegram from his Manhattan office to his wife's grammar school class on Staten Island to demonstrate one aspect of modern communications, which the class was then studying.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., JULY 24 A 29-year-old Foreign Service officer has resigned his position on the United States delegation, saying that he could no longer support American policies.
A warm gray haze hung over the city yesterday, and air pollution levels rose to what the city's Department of Air Resources called "near unhealthy levels."

SYDNEY, Australia, July 24 A prominent Australian dove has shocked his colleagues and upset opposition in political circles by reversing his widely publicized stand against aid for Cambodia after visiting that country as a member of a bipartisan parliamentary delegation.

ST. LOUIS, July 24 Philip J. Lucier, president of the Continental Telephone Company, was killed today when a bomb exploded in a company automobile on the parking lot of the Pierre Lacleve Center in Clayton, a suburb of St. Louis. Mr. Lucier was 49 years old.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 24 (AP) Sara Jane Stuhler of Amsterdam won the State amateur junior girls golf tournament today for the second straight year by defeating Chris Grygiel, the medal winner 4 and 3.

Mozart's "Cosl fan tutte" is a piece of fine crystal that if touched properly can give out sounds that creep into the ear and stay for a lifetime. Both farcical and deeply poignant at once, and ambiguous in the way that the greatest art always seems to be, this is an opera to be handled only by artists of discrimination.
JERSEY CITY, July 24 Frederick J. Fox, a lawyer here, died yesterday after being stricken in the Hudson County Administration Building. He was 66 years old and lived at 366 Hillside Avenue, Orange.
PEORIA, Ill., July 24(AP) Fires and sporadic shooting flared briefly for a second consecutive night tonight on the predominantly black Near South Side of Peoria, the police said.
All those children who'd rather have a peanut butter and jelly sandwich for breakfast than shredded wheat much to their mothers' dismay may have been right after all.
WESTBURY, L. I., July 24 Fresh Yankee, American-bred and Canadian-owned, won the $30,000 Roquepine Trot tonight as well as what might be termed permanent possession of France's Tidalium Pelo.

The city subway system's new safety rule prohibiting movement of a train past a red signal unless specifically authorized, went into effect yesterday without causing the delays many transit personnel had predicted.
LONDON, July 24 Sir Ivan Thompson, commodore of the Cunard Steamship Company from 1954 until his retirement in 1957, died in Liverpool Wednesday after a long illness at the age of 75.

WASHINGTON, July 24 Dr. Edward Teller, the nuclear physicist, warned today that radical political movements in universities were seriously jeopardizing scientific research related to national defense.
The London auction of the Plohn Collection of English silver at Sotheby's last week was a great comfort to those interested in the category.
If you have a feeling that business is keeping secrets in this bear market, you'll be interested to know that business doesn't think as you do.
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner has joined former Mayor Jerome P. Cavanagh of Detroit in forming a consulting concern that will specialize in the problems of cities.

Miss Laurie Schneider, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel E. Schneider of New York and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to John Brett Adams of London, son of Mr. and Mrs. H.C. Adams of Banstead, England.

A new investigation into the structure and activities of organized crime in the United States specifically not limited to the highly publicized Mafia, or Cosa Nostra has been initiated by the Senate Subcommittee on Investigations.

Tennessee Valley Authority engineers and power-pool dispatchers sought in an all-day meeting yesterday to determine the maximum help the system could give the Consolidated Edison Company to meet its critical shortage of electrical generating capacity.

LOS ANGELES, July 24 Charles M. Manson, the hippiecult leader accused of planning and ordering the murder of seven persons in the Los Angeles area last year, was described in court today as a "megalomaniac who coupled his insatiable thirst for power with an intense obsession for violent death."
CARGRAVE, England, July 24 Iain Macleod, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer, was buried today in the Yorkshire dales where he was born.
LENINGRAD, July 24 The Soviet Union track and field team defeated the United States 200-173 today.
Johnny Sample, the defensive back released almost a year ago by the New York Jets, has sued the club for $1,070,000.
"It's surprising how Puerto Ricans like to save money," a prominent banker remarked here the other day.

WASHINGTON, July 24 United States officials have received word from friendly dip lomats that Communist China is preparing to upgrade its diplomatic representation to the ambassadorial level in Warsaw, site of the periodic meetings between American and Chinese diplomats.

ROCKFORD, Ill., July 24(AP) Jane Bastanchury and Mrs. Paul Dommers will meet tomorrrow in a 36-hole final of the 70th annual Women's Western amateur golf tournament over the 6,346-yard Rockford Country Club course.
Wayne Granger was unhappy when the St. Louis Cardinals traded him to Cincinnati in 1968. Now it's the Cardinals who are unhappy.

SALINAS, Calif., July 24(AP) The settlement of a one-week strike by nearly 400 teamster members sent more than 6,000 workers back to their jobs today, harvesting the nation's main supply of lettuce crops.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24 Strong objection to President Nasser's move came from the leftist Government of Iraq and the Palestinian guerrilla movement.

We all have our favorite ages. I have long thought that it would be very pleasant to be a fifth-century (B.C.) Athenian, with a handful of Phoenician slaves to do the household chores and an uncomplaining wife to rear the kids. Rising early and shaking the dust of the slums off my feet.

President Carlos Lleras Restrepo of Colombia has called the bluff of the followers of the former dictator, Gustavo Rojas Pinilla. Despite their violent tactics, he has convened the new Congress on schedule. There seems little doubt that Mr. Lleras will be able to transfer power to his elected successor, Misael Pastrana Borrero, on Aug. 7, as provided by law, even if Colombia remains under a state of siege.

WASHINGTON, July 21 (UPI) The Justice Department today reached an agreement "in principle" that would settle an antitrust action to block the 1969 merger of Atlantic-Richfield and Sinclair Oil Corporation, one of the largest mergers in oil industry history.

The Mayor of Glen Cove, L.I., agreed yesterday to postpone for 30 days a tax-lien sale of the Soviet Union's 38-acre estate after the United States pointed out that the property was tax-exempt under existing treaties.
CAIRO, July 24 President Gamal Abdel Nasser said tonight that his acceptance of the United States plan for a cease-fire and peace negotiations "was not qualified, not conditional."

WASHINGTON, July 24 The United States formally presented a package proposal for a strategic-arms agreement to the Soviet Union today under which there would be a freeze on or a reduction in the size of offensive and defensive missiles systems without restrictting major improvements in them.

The city's Relocation Commissioner, Earl A. Rawlins, was suspended yesterday without pay from his $35,000-a-year post as a result of a Federal indictment charging him and seven other persons with conspiring to violate the immigration laws.

WASHINGTON, July 24(AP) The president of one of the largest orange juice processors, Coca-Cola, condemned today the treatment of its migrant farm workers. He told a Senate subcommittee that his company would improve the workers' lot.

The Milwaukee Road reported yesterday a loss of $4,730,137 in the second quarter of 1970 compared with a loss of $3,076,385 in the similar a year ago. The rail lines operating revenues advanced during the quarter to $72,094,488 from 68,792,246 in 1969.

PARIS, July 24 (AP) The United States last year contributed a smaller part of its gross national product than any other industrialized nation to help the world's developing countries, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development reported today.
BALTIMORE, July 24 A Federal judge ruled here today that a West Point graduate who has a "selective conscientious objection" to the war in Vietnam was not entitled to a discharge from the Army.

WASHINGTON, July 24 In the five weeks since the Supreme Court broadened the grounds for conscientious objection to military service, there has been a "substantial increase" in the number of applicants for C.O. status, a spokesman for the Selective Service system said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 24(UPI) The chief economist of the Truman Administration charged today that "unsound and upside-down" economic policies of subsequent administrations had spurred the inflationary trends that they were intended to check.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 24 A fire, said by the Nassau County police to be of suspicious origin, virtually destroyed the three-story main building of Hempstead High School today.
WASHINGTON, July 24 President Nixon signed today an emergency bill intended to put new vigor and as much as $10-billion a year in mortgage money into the sagging home construction industry.

WASHINGTON, July 24 State Department officials said today that the United States had not complained directly to the Soviet Union about its recent arms shipments to Libya, evidently in the interest of encouraging cooperation from Moscow on peace initiatives in the Middle East.

AKRON, Ohio, July 24(AP) The adjutant general of the Ohio National Guard has called "unbelievable" a newspaper report of assertions by the Federal Bureau of Investigation about guardsmen in the deaths of four Kent State University students during a campus confrontation last May 4.

Sometimes the defenders can make an accurate guess about the declarer's distribution. At other times they have no chance, as on the diagramed deal.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. July 24 The New York City Ballet has presented many premieres in its history but none has had the informal and charming intimacy that "Goldberg Variations" had last night at the Saratoga Performing Arts Center.

CLEVELAND, July 24(AP) Suzie Jackson of Wilmington, Del., gained both championship and reserve honors of Section A of the junior hunter division today at the 21st annual Chagrin Valley Professional Horsemen's Association Show. She rode Sudha Quill and Ambitions to the victories.

ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, July 24 Dr. Larry Klecatsky of the New York Athletic Club started his quest for five championships in the 88th Royal Canadian Henley Regatta today with an impressive sixlength victory in the second heat of the Association singles.

WASHINGTON, July 24(UPI) The Army ordered today a general court-martial for M. Sgt. William. E. Higdon, a decorated 23-year veteran of military service accused of theft and bribery while in charge of servicemen's clubs in South Vietnam.

After a series of tribulations that included several postponements and what might be called an artnapping, the promised show of prints withdrawn by United States artists from the Venice Biennale has finally opened at Museum, second-floor exhibition loft at 729 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, July 24 Charles H. Brunie, a partner in Oppenheimer Co., said today that the future of the entire capitalistic system in this country could be threatened if the sales commissions charged by brokers were not increased by an adequate amount.

JAMESTOWN, R.I., July 24 Eugene W. Carder's Yearling, out of the Stamford (Conn.) Yacht Club in Cruising Division I, and Mariah in Division II were the principal trophy winners on the 39th annual American Yacht Club cruise that ended here today, Mariah is under charter to Eric W. Peniston and George M. Isdale Jr. of the host club.
OAKLAND, July 24 Steve Kline's mother and brother drove 1,000 miles to see him pitch tonight and the young right-hander retired one batter for every 500 miles his family traveled.
MALVERNE, L.I., July 24 James B. Connolly, a stereotyper for The New York Times since 1953, died Wednesday of a heart attack near his home at 628 Cornwell Avenue. His age was 50.
SALT LAKE CITY, July 24 President Nixon left his big-city problems behind him today for a look at the concerns of rural America and a bit of politicking along the way.
MOSCOW, July 24 The Soviet Union appeared tonight to endorse Cairo's positive position of the latest United States initiative for achieving a political settlement in the Middle East.

Much of the merger activity yesterday turned toward West Germany. In Everkusen, Farbenfabriken Bayer, A.G., declined comment on an announcement that directors of International Coating Materials, N.V., had recommended acceptance of the Petrofina, S.A., group's bid to shareholders of the Dutch varnish maker despite an apparently higher offer by Bayer.

THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, July 25 (UPI)--The Netherlands, where thousands of young Dutchmen have taken up baseball, will send a team to compete for the first time in the Babe Ruth Baseball Tournament of Champions at Wellington, Kans., in August.

John J. (Jack) Sulger, Fordham's crew coach for the past 14 years will be honored at a testimonial dinner Aug. 8 at the New York Athletic Club's Travers Island House.

MONTPELIER, Vt., July 25 (AP)--An estimated 350,000 skiers pumped approximately $46.4-million into Vermont's economy during the 1969-70 ski season, according to a report issued here by the state Development Department.
The nation's hotels have begun to feel a slump stemming largely from the general business downturn.

Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Morgenthau of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Pattridge Morgenthau, to Paul Robert Grand, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph H. Grand of St. Louis.

A narcotics raid in the Woodside section of Queens yesterday resulted in the arrest of 11 persons and the seizure of what the police estimated to be $75,000 to $100,000 worth of illicit drugs. The raid was at the apartment of Michael Delgado, 27 years old, at 48-26 44th Street.

VISUAL oddities are nothing new to the Whitney Museum of American Art, but they are usually confined to that boring margin of novelty and innovation which in some quarters still passes for being "avant-garde."
Western Union is trying to get out of the business of delivering telegrams into American homes.
WILMINGTON, Del., July 25 (AP)--John B. Jessup, banker, community leader and crime fighter, died here yesterday after a long illness. He was 75 years old.

David Buran of Wethersfield, Conn., has been named head track coach at Trinity College. Buran, an assistant professor of physical education, has been assistant track coach since 1967, when he joined the staff.

Is President Nixon becoming more of a liberal? In the last few weeks, as a result of several Administration decisions on desegregation, some liberals have seen "hopeful" signs and some conservative supporters of Mr. Nixon, including Senator Strom Thurmond, have worried aloud that "liberal advisers around the President are misleading him."

WASHINGTON, July 25-- The winding down of the Vietnam War and the reduction of other defense spending will affect the employment of two million persons from mid-1969 to mid-1971, new Government estimates reveal.

LEICESTER, England, July 25 (UPI)--Julie Heldman, the No. 2 American seeded star from New York, said today she had quit tennis indefinitely and would Miss the $160,000 United States Open championships in New York Sept. 2 to 13. This was her second retirement in three years.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., July 25 (UPI)--Rudy Vallee, the singer, said today he wanted to run for the Senate from California to "clean up the mess in the Pentagon."
Studies that will cover multinational corporations, problems of underdeveloped countries and Federal economic policies since the New Deal era were announced last week by the Twentieth Century Fund.

A REMARKABLE phenomenon has been taking place during the past dozen years or so, namely, the extent to which, in America at least, the new music movement has moved onto the university campus. Nowadays one rarely reads the biographical data of a native composer born after 1930 without finding mention of the academic institution where he studied composition, or where he now teaches, or at the very least, where his music has been performed.
TEL AVIV, July 25 (AP)--Israeli planes returned to the Suez Canal zone today to continue their daily bombing and strafing attacks against United Arab Republic positions, an army spokesman said.

ROME, July 25--Attempts to consecrate the union between two people of the same sex through a formal marriage ceremony "are simply moral aberrations that cannot be approved by human conscience, much less Christian conscience," a leading Vatican theologian declared yesterday.

LISBON, July 25--Dr. Rui Manuel de Madeiros d'Espiney Patricio, Portugal's Foreign Minister, says that his country's policy in Africa is to improve relations with countries adjacent to Angola, Mozambique and Portuguese Guinea.

MANHATTAN, Kan., July 25--Miss Susanna Marie Wright, an official assistant at the First National City Bank in New York, and John Dickson Harper Jr., an assistant treasurer at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company there, plan to be married here Sept. 19 at St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

PALM BEACH, Fla., July 25--Mr. and Mrs. A. Parker Bryant have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leslie Parker Bryant to Cpl. George Holliday Hume, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Jaquelin Holliday Hume of San Francisco.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 25-- In hot, muggy weather that took the bounce from their aging legs, the top favorites went into action today in the national clay-court tennis championship for men 35 years and over at the Shelter Rock Club.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, July 25--Ian Stwart of Scotland upset Kipchoge Keino of Kenya, the favorite, and Ron Clarke of Australia today to capture the 5,000-meter gold medal at the British Commonwealth Games in a record time of 13 minutes 22.8 seconds.
MIAMI, July 25--Todor Zhivkov First Secretary of the Bulgarian Communist Party and chairman of the Bulgarian Council of Ministers, arrived in Cuba today for an 11-day official visit.
FLORA, Miss., July 24-- There is only one cotton gin left now and it's down at the end of Main Street on the other side of the railroad tracks.
MONTREAL, July 25 (AP)-- Ron Fairly's grand-slam homer in the fourth inning helped propel the Montreal Expos to a 10-5 victory over the San Francisco Giants tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 25-- Senator Russell B. Long, the powerful chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, has decided to attach President Nixon's welfare reform plan-- probably in a somewhat revised form--to the pending omnibus Social Security bill.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 24-- Lebanon's International Festival of Baalbeck is well into its 15th season, though a tone of austerity, seems to characterize this year's program when compared with some of the opulence of the past. The mood of the audience is more subdued and while still elegant, Beirut society is inclined to less display.
BOSTON, July 25--James Clark, a retired shopkeeper, lounged on a park bench and glanced indifferently at two police cruisers, a paddy wagon and a K-9 carrier as they arrived on Hemenway Street.
MILWAUKEE, July 25-- Weary travelers waiting in Milwaukee's Greyhound bus depot now have an alternative to staring at blank walls. For a price, they can stare at a television set.

The misery of being Mayor of New York is so established a political assumption--and with it the Mayor's desire to escape upward--that it is a surprise to find John Lindsay reasonably happy and healthy. He tells visitors that he enjoys the job, with all the crises, and that he looks at politics in terms of holding this city together for the remaining three years of his term.

MANHASSET, L.I., July 25 --Mr. and Mrs. William Hadwen Barney of Manhasset and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Marie Louise (Lee) Barney, who expects to be graduated next month from Dickinson College in Carlisle, Pa., to E. Ronald Beecher Jr., who received his degree from Dickinson in May. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Evan R. Beecher of Middletown, N.J.

HE IS, everyone agrees, the hottest thing in Nashville right now-- and if you're hot in Nashville, man, you're hot everywhere. He's just been in Peru with Dennis Hopper, writing and singing songs for Hopper's "The Last Movie." Johnny Cash, Roger Miller and Ray Stevens have been recording his numbers.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 25 (AP)--Bobby Isaac of Catawba, N.C., drove his 1969 Dodge to victory today in the nationally televised Nashville 420 Grand National Stock Car race.

GREAT FALLS, Va., July 25--Miss Irene Kobus, a former administrative secretary at the C.B.S. Television Stations division of the Columbia Broadcasting System Inc. in New York, was married here today to Ashby Kendall Raine Jr., a vice president in the international division of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company in New York.

PHILADELPHIA. WHO'S that handsome fellow on the flying trapeze? Who, that lanky, bare-chested, tall and winsome figure in pretty pink tights and gold sequined belt, swinging in mid-air, as the band plays a funky circus waltz and the TV cameras grind? By Jove, by gum and heavens-to-Betsy--it's none other than George Plimpton!

SAN JUAN, P.R., July 25-- Puerto Ricans celebrated the 18th year of their commonwealth government today with the usual parade and speeches, but strong and diverse voices are pressing for change in the island's political relationship with the United States.
HILLSBOROUGH, N.J.--A 15-year-old Austrian boy, offered a choice of touring the United States or spending three weeks at a golf camp, surprised his friends by passing up the tour.
NEW ORLEANS, July 25-- A group of black Roman Catholics has asked a Federal court to order the Catholic school system of Opelousas, La., to desegregate.

TENAFLY, N.J., July 25 --Mr. and Mrs. Harold Humphrey Whittemore have announced the engagement of Mrs. Whittemore's daughter, Miss Eliza (Betsey) Williams Taft, to William Dutton Colby, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Howard Colby of Brookline, Mass.

CRANBURY, N.J., July 25 --The First Presbyterian Church here was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Jane Ellen Dorrance, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John B. Dorrance Jr. of Penn Valley, Pa., to Frank Alfred Craven.
Dave Marshall didn't do what he was supposed to do yesterday--so he hit a home run instead.

STANTON, Del., July 25 (AP) --Virginia Cracker, the longest shot in a field of a dozen 3-year-old fillies, scored a stunning upset at Delaware Park today when she defeated Office Queen by 1 lengths in the $60,800 Delaware Oaks.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, July 25-- A novel method of taking a census of the wild elephant population in Ceylon is to be attempted by the Government's Wildlife Department soon.

DALTON, Pa., July 25-- Mr. and Mrs. William Warren Scranton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Scranton, to Richard Anthony Wolf, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Wolf of New York.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., July 25--Miss Alice Michele Cornacchia, a research assistant at National Endowment for the Arts in Washington, and Paul Henry De Forest, assistant professor of political science at Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago, were married here today.

For the third consecutive year, the New York Knickerbockers will do their preseason training at the State University of New York at Farmingdale, L.I., it was announced by Ned Irish, club president, and the general manager-coach, William (Red) Holzman. Arrangements for the use of the university's facilities were completed through the cooperation of the school's president, Dr. Charles W. Laffin Jr.

NEW PALTZ, N.Y.--Creeping urbanization has been diverted to spare the "Street of the Huguenots," this upstate town's unique monument to early America. Visitors will be able to see the fruits of the campaign to save the country's "oldest original street" when the 20th annual Stone House Day is held from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. next Saturday.
Preliminary--Pro-Amateur, Wednesday. $5,000 in prize money, 168 amateurs and 56 pros.

BERNARD MALAMUD is getting to be the grooviest, moviest author around. A film version of his novel "The Fixer" appeared last season, the movie of his short story "The Angel Levine" opens at the Little Carnegie Tuesday, and adaptations of his "Black Is My Favorite Color" and "The Assistant" have also been announced.

There were four weekend days of the Larchmont Yacht Club's Race Week sailing on which competition was scheduled for cruising yachts, and the fact that there was a gratifying number of starters every time was due to an extremely lenient policy about entry closings, said Donald B. King, the race committee chairman last week. This season's new system for obtaining and mailing entry blank was a handicap, not a help, he said.
MARK TWAIN braved the ocean in rough-riding tubs to get to Bermuda. The island, he commented, "is like Paradise, but one has to go through Purgatory to get there." Exactly.

AFTER the finish of the Belgrade 10-board match between the U.S.S.R. and the Rest of the World, four Soviet players and six "World" players, including the Americans, Bobby Fischer and Sammy Reshevsky, motored to Herzog-Novi, Yugoslavia's resort on the Adriatic shore. They were joined by David Bronstein of Russia and M. Ostojic of Yugoslavia. All 12 were scheduled to contest a double-round 12-man round robin in "blitz" style in "five minute" games.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25--A rift in the professional football Players' Association became evident today. It evolved from the decision by some members of the Kansas City Chiefs to begin training for Friday night's game against the College All-Stars in defiance of the association.
ROME, July 25 (AP)--Italy's national airline, Alitalia, canceled more than 50 international flights today because of a 24-hour pilot's strike.

The National Amateur Athletic Union junior track and field campionships will be held on Long Island for the first time since 1966. The meet is scheduled for Sunday, Aug. 2, at Wantagh High School, beginning at noon.

On the morning of May 1, 1960, a 30-year-old pilot from a coal-miner's family in Appalachia took off on a secret reconnaissance mission over Russia under orders from the Central Intelligence Agency. To Francis Gary Powers, an Air Force pilot with a tottering marriage, a restless yearning for excitement and an ephemeral feeling that he "hadn't really proved" himself, the C.I.A.'s offer of an 18month contract had seemed, almost too easily, ideal.

WINNERS in the 1970 National Coin Week competition were announced following the judging of 53 club and numerous individual reports at the American Numismatic Association Library in Colorado Springs. John Dunn, Harold H. Hartman and Clark A. Yowell served as judges.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 25-- Some of the old style has returned to California politics this summer with celebrities from the entertainment world signing up in support of established candidates instead of running for public office themselves.

SANTA ROSA, Calif.--The largest gathering of Scottish clans in North America--complete with wailing bagpipes, tartan kilts and sealskin sporrans swirling in the breeze--will be held here for the 104th consecutive year on Labor Day weekend.

JERUSALEM--"Nasser sets the trap"--that was the first editorial reaction of the Jerusalem Post after President Gamal Abdel Nasser's national day speech last Thursday night. As the text fell under more careful expert scrutiny, Israeli fears of a trap only deepened.

LISBON, July 25--Dr. Joaquim Pires de Lima, a lawyer, has protested to the Government that he is being impeded in defending a priest who was arrested on a political charge.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24-- The disclosure that Chilean Marxist guerrillas may be fighting Bolivian forces in the jungles north of La Paz has embarrassed the Chilean Government.

ROME, July 25--Emilio Colombo, a 50-year-old Christian Democrat who has been Italy's Treasury Minister for the last seven years, agreed tonight to try to form a new government composed of all four center-left parties--his own, the Republicans and the feuding Socialists and Social Democrats.

Oscar Lasdon is a Wall Street consultant whose writings reach back to the reports of the Temporary National Economic Committee of the 1930's. VIENNA, July 25 (UPI)--A surprisingly strong East German swimming team took seven of 11 titles today to dominate the opening round of the Tournament of Nations meet.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 25 (AP)--Don Allen of Rochester won his fourth state amateur golf championship today at Locust Hill Country Club with a two-under-par, 72-hole total of 286.

BALTIMORE, July 25--In the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer here this afternoon Miss Pickett Davis Randolph, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Middleton Elliott Randolph, was married to John Charles Lincoln Hulley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Mayham Hulley of Hyannis, Mass. The ceremony, performed by the Rev. Francis O. Chapelle, was followed by a reception at the Elkridge Club.
WASHINGTON, July 25 (AP) --Senate Democrats dismissed today as "totally erroneous and unfounded" President Nixon's charge of excessive Congressional spending.

NEW ZEALAND has supported its national health and youth programs through issuance of special postage stamps since 1929--the semipostal stamps discussed in the adjoined column. The first stamps each pictured a nurse and bore the slogan "Help Stamp Out Tuberculosis, 1929." Subsequent yearly issues have been inscribed "Help Promote Health" or the single word "Health."

RABAT, Morocco, July 25 (AP)--King Hassan II's referendum on a new constitution, which would give Morocco a single-chamber parliament with limted powers, won 98.35 per cent of the vote, official results showed today.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 25 --Democrats loyal to the national party, embarrassed by a take-over of the Alabama party by George C. Wallace two years ago, shut the door today on any such attempt in 1972.

HOMEOWNERS who would like to install a second kitchen in their basement or fam ily room, or those who would like to put a small kitchen into their summer cottage, vacation retreat or office, will no doubt be interested in a new line of compact kitchen units that have recently been introduced by the Crane Company, 300 Park Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10022.
The Health and Hospital Corporation reported yesterday that 1,190 abortions had been performed in the city's municipal hospitals between July 1 and midnight Thursday.

ATLANTA, July 25--At the point in life where many men are looking just over the hill to the golf links of a retirement city, an Atlantan, George W. Thorpe, is getting settled at the helm of a young multimillion dollar corporation that he recently put together out of the experience of his first career.

Commuters from Stamford, Conn., on the New Haven division of the Penn Central have discovered since July 1 that if they board an express train going to Penn Station instead of Grand Central Terminal, the fare jumps from $1.84 to $3.70.

LONDON, July 25 (AP)--Sir Alec Douglas-Home, the British Foreign Secretary, says that both the Egyptians and Israelis are starting to think of negotiations as their best course. He feels that the North Atlantic Treaty Organization must take account of new Soviet influence south of Europe and must possibly consider protection of trade routes around southern Africa.

BALTIMORE, July 25--Dr. and Mrs. Timothy L. Smith have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Smith, to Bradley Stuart Waterman, son of Brig. Gen. Bernard S. Walterman, U.S.A. retired and Mrs. Waterman of Alexandria, Va.

COWDRAY PARK, England, July 25 (AP)--The Jersey Lilies of Cowdray Park defeated Boca Raton, the United States team that won the Gold Cup English polo championship, 7 to 5, today in the quarterfinals of the Challenge Cup.
WASHINGTON, July 25-- International Intelligence, Inc.--Intertel for short-- sounds like a title by Ian Fleming, and the analogy is not completely inappropriate.

"Moving On," the latest novel by Larry McMurtry, who attracted attention with "Horseman, Pass By" (filmed as "Hud") and "Leaving Cheyenne," is an exhausting work-- nearly 800 pages long--filled with characters and encounters. One has a right to expect big meanings from such big reading, but power of insight is not McMurtry's forte here. His forte is words, words, words.

Two young brothers fell four stories from a bedroom window yesterday afternoon and were critically injured when they landed on the ground in the rear yard of the tenement in which they lived in Brooklyn's Park Slope section.

Three biting and unusually candid training films designed to give rookie policemen a taste of the street before they walk a beat are being distributed to many departments by the International Association of Chiefs of Police.

WASHINGTON, July 25 (UPI) --A new organization has announced a campaign to collect 10 million signatures in support of Massachusetts' appeal to the Supreme Court to declare the Vietnam war unconstitutional.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 25--A tight curfew on this city was continued tonight on the orders of Mayor Patricia Q. Sheehan, who said today that last night's restricted curfew was a "success" and had undoubtedly averted a serious crisis.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 25 (UPI)--The Cambodian Government moved Queen Sisowath Kossamak Nearireath, the mother of the deposed Chief of State, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, from the royal palace to a villa guarded by troops early today.
MANHASSET, L.I., July 25--Miss Jane Louise Batten and Payson Sibley Wild Jr. were married at the Congregational Church here today. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. George G. Parker.

PHILADELPHIA, July 22-- The city of Philadelphia has initiated a project aimed at increasing the automobile import business from a trickle to a flow.
GENEVA, July 25--The Economic and Social Council has given its approval to extensive reforms in the United Nations aid machinery for developing countries.

Several weeks ago, the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association conducted the 36th annual sister-brother championship over the Richmond County Country Club course in Staten Island. When all the scores were in there was a tie for first between Kathy Linney and her brother, Jim, of Plainfield, and Cynthia Ferro, 15-year-old junior golfer, playing with her 18-year-old brother, Stephen, from the Forest Hill Field Club. They had identical scores of 40, 38--78.

WASHINGTON--Now that the nine-month slide in the economy has apparently about touched bottom, how vigorous should the Government be in pushing the upturn toward full employment? This wholly new issue emerged dramatically last week as the Congressional Joint Economic Committee held an important set of hearings on the state of the economy at midyear.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, July 25--A plan to salvage the Central American Common Market, which has been skirting a breakdown since Honduras and El Salvador fought a war last year, has been adopted by the five member countries.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 25--Don Buford powered the Baltimore Orioles to a 6-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins today, with a two-run, eighthinning homer.

CAPE MAY, N.J., July 25 --Miss Joan O'Brien was married here today at noon to Edward Cranch Ernst in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady Star of the Sea. The nuptial mass was celebrated by the Rev. William Buchler.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., July 25--Mr. and Mrs. Philip Conway have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elouise Wright Conway, to Charles Snowden Jones. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Snowden Fisher Jones of Briarcliff Manor.

CAIRO--Gamal Abdel Nasser is a bird who has twice arisen from the ashes of defeat, his plumage glossier than ever. These last days he has shown what he can do with a firmer platform, like a tightrope.

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 25-- Frank Iannelli, the talented jockey from Providence, R.I., played the waiting game with telling effect today to score in the rain with Aisco Stable's Forward Gal in the $105,110 Sorority at Monmouth Park.

LONDON--A housewife from Battersea: "Every morning I go to the market, and the apples, the pears, the tomatoes are a couple of coppers [pennies] higher. My husband says, 'Don't buy no fruit.' But I like a nice piece of fruit in the afternoon."
Plans for an expansion of Italy's tourist business, already earning a record of $1.7-billion a year, have been announced by Gluseppe Lupis, the Italian Minister of Tourism and Entertainment.

A group called United Harlem Drug Fighters last night occupied an empty 36-bed ward on the seventh floor of Harlem Hospital to press demands for more drug-addiction care for Harlem youth. A spokesman for the 30 sit-ins said they would remain in the hospital until their demands were met.

WESTON, Conn., July 25-- Miss Jill Diane Friedman and Gianni Ponzini of Milan and Bellagio, Italy, were married here this afternoon at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Harold Friedman. The ceremony was performed by Justice of the Peace Daniel Forbes. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Italo Ponzini of Bellagio.

ARBROATH, Scotland--From the royal chamber of a great red sandstone abbey, high above this wind-swept east-coast fishing port in 1320, King Robert the Bruce and his nobles sent to Pope John XXII at Avignon a passionate proclamation of Scotland's independence. It was framed in magnificently ringing Latin prose by Robert's Chancellor, Bernard de Linton the Abbot of Arbroath.
The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced the recovery yesterday of two paintings by the late cubist artist Marcel Duchamp and $200,000 in United States Treasury notes.

THE first thing you see, in the large and brilliantly theatrical exhibition of photographs by Richard Avedon currently at The Minneapolis Institute of Arts through Aug. 30, is a larger-than-life-size picture of two hairy men locked in a loving embrace and gazing down the length of three galleries toward the entrance where you stand.
CHICAGO, July 25 (AP)-- Hank Aaron's 26th homer of the season and the 580th of his career backed Phil Niekro's two-hitter today and helped the Atlanta Braves to a 9-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
LINCOLN, R.I., July 25 (AP) --Be Back romped to a 4 length victory today in the $5,000 Little Rhody Handicap at Lincoln Downs.
LONDON, July 25--The Luftwaffe lost the Battle of Britain because it was simply not equipped for an offensive war, according to a former German fighter ace.

ROCHESTER, July 25 (UPI) --Top business executives in New York State show uncertainty about what the general economy will do during the second half of 1970 but express confidence that the state's economy will continue to outstrip that of the nation as a whole, according to a survey by Lincoln First Banks, Inc.

The conglomerates, such high fliers in the boom days, have been among the most severely injured casualties of the so-called Nixon bear market. It would seem logical that some of the lesser companies gobbled up by the conglomerates between 1965 and 1968 would have some regrets.
THERE now are more vegetable gardens in American backyards than ever before--50,000,000 of them according to some estimates. Tight money and high food costs are the chief reasons cited.

FREQUENTLY discussed by American stamp collectors, as well as postal officials, has been the matter of the United States Post Office Department issuing what philatelists call semipostal stamps-- postage stamps with two denominations, one for the carriage of the letter, the second with a small plus fee as a contribution to a health, youth or social service program.
