SCARSDALE, N.Y., July 26 Henry Bloch, a lawyer specializing in real-estate development, died today in Lawrence Hospital in Bronxviile. He was 87 years old and lived at 40 Park Road here.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Arthur F. Burns, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that the nation's supply of money has been growing faster than normal and that the rate would pick up even more during this month.

TRUMBULL, Conn., July 26 Almost forgotten and, for the most part, dejected and unhappy, 13 Pequot Indians ranging in age from the 50's to the 80's are whiling away their days on four little reservations in Connecticut.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, July 26 (AP) Protestant Orangemen marched in County Tyrone today in defiance of the Ulster Government's ban on parades.

The marriage of Miss Suzanne Stern to Jeffrey B. Nachman took place here yesterday afternoon at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Stanley S. Goldfarb. The Rev. Dr. Nathan A. Perilman performed the ceremony.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 26 James A. Ostheimer of Pequot Y.C. won the Soling Class championship today when the Long Island Sound Yacht Racing Association's eastern Connecticut, area regatta ended with ones race off Black Rock Y.C. Firsts in both of yesterday's races, Ostheimer placed fourth with Grimmet in today's nine-mile race in a 5-to-8-knot southsouthwest breeze and gained 27 points.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 (AP) The United States Embassy has warned its staff against traveling alone in Saigon because of what it called recent acts of violence against Americans by students or other anti-Government demonstrators.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., July 26 Dr. Francesco Miraglia, an ophthalmologist with offices here and in New York, died yesterday in United Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 319 Glen Avenue. His New York office was at 317 East 116 Street.

Howard J. Samuels, the chairman of the city's new Offtrack Betting Corporation, said yesterday that the $50-million the city hoped to make in the first year of offtrack betting was an "unrealistic goal."

New orders for machine tools, considered an important indicator of future business activity, increased by 11.4 per cent in June from the May total, hut this moderate advance left the order books of the tool builders at extremely depressed levels.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The Federal Communications Commission's first general forecast of cable television's growth suggests that the broadcasting industry's fear of destructive competition has been focused on the wrong areas and has been greatly exaggerated.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 26 Qabus bin Said, 28-year-old son of the ruler of Muscat and Oman, has overthrown his father, Sultan Said bin Taimur, in a palace coup, according to reports received here from the city of Salala.

JERSEY CITY, July 26 An application of radical concepts in multifamily housing construction is expected to get under way in this congested needy urban center late this fall, according to the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development.
LOUVAIN, Belgium, July 26, (Reuters) Ron Clarke of Australia was second to Emile Puttemans of Belgium in an invitation ace at 5,000 meters tonight.

GREENWICH, Conn., July 26 Herbert F. Schwartz at the tiller of his Ensign sloop, Wenden, triumphed by 3 minutes and 300 yards on Long Island Sound today in the Greenwich Cove Racing Association championship regatta.
Policemen called to stop the looting of a drugstore in the East Village last night were forced to fire eight shots into the air to disperse a threatening crowd of Puerto Ricans, the police said.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, July 26 While much of black Africa was upset by Britain's decision to resume arms sales to South Africa, whites here were further heartened last week by reports that Britain would participate with South African forces in joint antisubmarine exercises west of the Cape of Good Hope next month.
OXFORD, Miss. "We go to school games," said Harold Hall, a 31-year-old black law student at the University of Mississippi, "but we find we always root for the visiting team."
BUDAPEST It's called Corvin, after a Hungarian king of the Renaissance, but it could almost be Korvette or Klein's the way the summer shoppers are thronging to its bargain counters.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., July 26 (AP) Catherine Albert Eunson, wife and collaborator of Dale Eunson, Hollywood novelist and screenwriter, died today of a heart condition at St. John's Hospital in nearby Santa Monica. She was 67 years old.

CLEVELAND, July 26 (AP) Roy Foster slammed a decisive three-run homer in the first game and Steve Hargan hurled a five-hit shutout in the second yesterday as the Cleveland Indians scored 6-5 and 3-0 victories over the Kansas City Royals.
Differing airline approaches to a common goal of more passengers and higher revenues over the North Atlantic have been made public by the International Air Transportation Association.

An ancient Biblical story about the generation gap was translated into contemporary speech and modern dance yesterday in a Brooklyn church.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 26 Bob Kirtland's Early Bird continued to dominate Raven Class ranks as a fleet of 91 yachts sailed today in the Knickerbocker Yacht Club on Cow Bay area, Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound competition.
BERLIN, July 26 (UPI) Karin Balzer of East Germany broke the women's world 100-meter hurdles record today with a time of 12.7 sec onds, the East German press agency ADN said.

WEST CHESTER, Pa., July 26 (AP) About 200 Puerto Ricans pelted state and local policemen with bottles and rocks tonight for the second straight night. The trouble stemmed from a false report yesterday that a Puerto Rican had been killed in a fist fight with a bartender.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 26 (UPI) Jarvis Tatum blooped a double to right field to score Billy Cowan from first base with two out in the 11th inning today and gave the California Angels an 11-10 victory over the Washington Senators. President Nixon was among the spectators.
TOKYO, July 26 The Constitutionality of Japan's 250,000man Self-Defense Force is being tested in a trial that opened last week in Niigata.

WHEATLEY HILLS, L.I., July 26 War Count, owned by the Sta-Still Farm of Syosset, L.I., maintained his unbeaten record on Long Island today by winning the Amateur-Owner Hunter championship at the Meadowbrook Hounds Horse Show. The event was held on the estate of Mr. and Mrs. Charles V. Hickox.
SYDNEY, Australia, July 26 A young Danish office worker from Sydney received a hero's welcome here today after completing an oftenperilous voyage around Australia alone in an open 12-foot speedboat.
The deficit in the United States international balance of payments ranged between S1-billion and $1.5-billion during the second quarter of 1970, the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, July 26 Senator John C. Stennis, chairman of the Senate Armed Services, declared today that he would favor another thrust into Cambodia by United States troops if the Administration found it necessary to clean out enemy sanctuaries there again.
Paul Merrick Hollister, an advertising executive and author, died Saturday in Ruidoso. N. M., after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in Lincoln, N.M.
HOUSTON, July 26(AP) Two Negroes were wounded by the police in an exchange of gunfire in a black area of Houston tonight following a rally of black militants.
Groups of heroin addicts left the streets of Harlem yesterday to seek help in an unused ward of Harlem Hospital that had been taken over by a community group Saturday evening.
SAYVILLE, L.I., July 26 Lewis Wake in White Elephant captured the final race of the series today and won the Thistle Class Atlantic Coast sailing championship.

"Sensations," described as "a musical experience" based on "Romeo and Juliet," written and composed by Paul Zakrzewski and Wally Harper and presented by John Bohab and Charles Celian, has been, booked to open at Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street, on Oct. 14. The theater's current tenant is "The Boys in the Band."
COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., July 26 (AP) Charles S. Feeney, president of the National eague, was elected today to the board of directors of the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum.
MIAMI, July 26 Premier Fidel Castro tonight drew a bleak picture of the Cuban economy, with conditions in many sectors bordering on chaos.
AMMAN, Jordan, July 26 The Jordanian Government approved tonight the United States proposal for settlement of the conflict between Israel and the Arab countries.
CINCINNATI, July 26 (AP) Johnny Bench blasted three home runs and drove in seven runs today as the Cincinnati Reds sent the St. Louis Cardinals reeling to their eighth straight loss, 12-5.

NEW DELHI, July 26 A highly publicized first-of-itskind project to beam educational television directly to villagers in India from an orbiting United States satellite has been postponed for a year because of budget cuts in Washington.

ALBANY, July 26 The State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission has approved a total of $433,000 in grants to finance methadone maintenance programs in New York City. The grants were announced today by Governor Rockefeller.

The Accounting Principles Board, the senior rule-making body of the public accounting profession, expects to promulgate the final version of its highly controversial rules on corporate merger accounting this Wednesday, a spokesman for the board said over the weekend.

ECCLES, W.Va., July 26 (UPI) Leaders of the United Mine Workers union in southern West Virginia agreed today to ask thousands of striking coal miners to ignore picket lines and end a two-week walkout.

JERUSALEM, July 26 Israel was reported to have moved today toward accepting a United States formula for a limited cease-fire and the opening of peace talks with the Arab states, but acceptance was said to be conditioned on receiving military and political assurances from Washington.
MILWAUKEE, July 26 (UPI) The Boston Red Sox hit four homers, including a pair of tworun shots by Tony Conigliaro, and capitalized on three errors to rout the Milwaukee Brewers, 12-5, today.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26 (AP) Negotiations between National Football League club owners and representatives of the Players Association shifted to a new level today, with both sides splitting up into subcommittee "work sessions."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 A force of 2,500 South Vietnamese soldiers entered Cambodia today in an operation that initially met only light to moderate opposition.

PADANARAM, Mass., July 26 John Potter's Equation in the first division, Ted Hood's latest Robin in the second, John Baringer's Fastnet 45 Zephyros in the third and Dolf LeComte's A.L.C. 35 Sprinkaan in the fourth became the first winners of the New York Yacht Club cruise today.
BONN, July 26 Before departing from the Bonn airport, Foreign Minister Scheel described his mission as one of "historic significance."

Arrangements for bringing in 1.5 million to 1.7 million kilowatts of electricity starting today were announced yesterday by the Consolidated Edison Company of New York to offset its loss of two major generators for the rest of the summer.
NORTH SALEM, N.Y., July 26 April's Fool swept to victory in all four classes today to win the green working hunter championship at the Hill Horse Show.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., July 26 Miss Julie Ann Robinson and Fredric P. Kistler plan to be married on Aug. 22. A garden ceremony is planned at the summer home here of the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin M. Robinson. The Robinsons have homes also in New York and Barbados, W.I. Mr. Kistler's parents, Mr. and Mrs. George W. Kistler, live in Allentown, Pa.

Rieder, vice president of the Guaranteed Title and Mortgage Company, a division of American Title Insurance Company, and a director of the Tremont Savings and Loan Association, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home. He was 61 years old and lived at 97-28 57th Avenue, Forest Hills, Queens.
TEL AVIV, July 26 (AP) Israeli planes attacked Egyptian fortifications and antiaircraft batteries along the 103-mile length of the Suez Canal today, the military command announced.

ALBANY, July 26 (AP) The State Education Department announced a $1.3-million program today that is designed to save school-age children from "the horror of drug use."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 26 Syria today rejected the United States proposal, but informed sources here said that they believed this had been done for propaganda purposes to maintain Syria's stand of opposition to a peaceful settlement with Israel.

HONG KONG, July 26 (AP) President Nixon has written to the Most Rev. James Edward Walsh, the 79-year-old Roman Catholic missionary released earlier this month after 12 years in a Chinese Communist prison.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., July 26 Miss Judith Lenore Gubner and Gordon Edward Whitwell were married here this afternoon in the Lutheran Church of Our Savior by the Rev. Dr. Thomas Spitz.

BETHANY, Conn., July 26 A red sable ad white Shetland sheepdog, Ch. Pixie Dell Epicure, owned by Mr. and Mrs. A.R. Miller of Scarsdale, N.Y., won his first best-in-show award today at the 54th Elm City Kennel Club event at the Bethany Kennels and Stables grounds today. A field of 1,107 was entered.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 26 Four months after the ouster of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, friends of the new Government are most encouraged by what has not happened the Government has not collapsed.

MOSCOW, July 26 (UPI) The Soviet Union celebrated Navy Day today with announcements that its ships and nuclear-missile submarines are ready for war or peace throughout the world.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The emergency housing bill signed by President Nixon last week contains a potential for enormous demands on the capital markets, but there will be little impact this year, officials said this weekend.

LONDON, July 26 Britain's future military commitment in Southeast Asia will be determined by the series of talks with her Commonwealth allies that Lord Carrington, Secretary of Defense, will begin tomorrow in Singapore.

ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, July 26 Jim Dietz of the New York, A.C. won his fourth straight championship singles crown at the 88th Royal Canadian Henley Regatta today. Dietz defeated Roger Jackson of the ancouver Boat Club, Canada's gold medalist at Tokyo in 1964, by 10 lengths.
OAKLAND, July 26 The Athletics held a promotion called Auto Industry Day this afternoon and the Yankees made the symbolic gesture of sputtering to a halt after a promising start.

CHRISTIANSTED, St. Croix, July 26 (AP) Senator Alexander Farrelly scored a lopsided victory last night in gaining the Democratic nomination in a drive to become the first elected Governor of the Virgin Islands.

EDMONTON, Alberta, July 26 (AP) Denis Hulme of New Zealand and Pete Gethin of England drove their McLaren 8DDs to a one, two finish in the klondike 200 Canadian-American Challenge Cup auto race today.

TOKYO, July 26 This city suffered its fourth consecutive day of smog today as automobiles clogged highways leading out of the city.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 26 (AP) Boog Powell drove in six runs with a single and a grand-slam homer today and Dave McNally notched his 13th victory with a five-hitter as the Baltimore Orioles crushed the Minnesota Twins, 11-1.

LONDON, July 26 If Britain's Royal Ballet has ever had a finest hour or a finest three hours, to be accurate then that hour struck at the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden, Friday night. STRATFORD, Ontario, July 26 There is an "As You Like It" motel, a Romeo Street, and a Portia Boulevard, but mostly Stratford is a small, serene, un-Shakespearean city, surrounded by cows, barns and pastures, and seemingly undisturbed by the fact that for 18 years it has been the site of the famous Stratford Festival.

WASHINGTON, July 26 The impression is growing here that former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey's bid for a Minnesota seat in the Senate is aimed not at positioning him for another Presidential race but at putting him in line for the Senate majority leader's job.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 26 Desertions from the South Vietnamese Army in creased drastically in the last few months, averaging nearly 50 per cent higher than the rate last year, according to informed South Vietnamese sources.

WASHINGTON, July 26 (AP) Congress is poised to push the estimated cost of the nation's web of interstate superhighways past $75-billion-almost double the original 1956 price tag.

SPARTA, Wis., July 26 (AP) Three explosions shook the Camp McCoy Army base early today after a caller had told authorities that a bomb had been planted on the post. Electric power was knocked out for 90 minutes.

George Foreman and George Chuvalo, who will meet in a 10-round heavyweight battle at Madison Square Garden next Tuesday night, will hold six public workouts each at the Felt... Forum in the Garden.
Down was the direction of earnings reported yesterday by major oil companies for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

The American Smelting and Refining Company announced here yesterday that it planned to dispose of its remaining interest in the General Cable Corporation 2,820,50 common shares by offering the stock in exchange for Asarco shares.

WEST GLACIER, Mont. The Going to the Sun Road snakes its way for 50 miles through Glacier National Park, first under the upward thrust of pines, cedars, spruce and firs, then high above timberline, clinging to the sheer walls of jagged mountains patched with snow.

An anomaly among modern dictators, Antonio de Oliveira Salazar exemplified the power of a negative personality. He was ascetic rather than exuberant; aloof rather than gregarious; professorial rather than demagogic; understated rather than ostentatious. Yet he held Portugal in thralldom for more than 40 years, a record of durability unmatched by Francisco Franco, Benito Mussolini or Adolf Hitler, his flashier Fascist counterparts and good friends.

PARIS, July 27 Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China told a French radio and television audience tonight that France and China shared a common opposition to domination and intervention by "the great powers" in world affairs.

DETROIT, July 27 The General Motors Corporation reported today a June-quarter profit rise of 5 per cent from a year before, on a sales gain of 6 per cent. The profits were no record in fact, they topped last year's because G.M. was hurt by strikes in 1969. Otherwise the June quarter profit was the lowest since 1963.

More than a quarter-million dollars worth of counterfeit paychecks many of them said to be from the city's Police and Fire Departments have been cashed at banks here over the last year, the Manhattan District Attorney's office said yesterday. A Long Island printer has been arrested as a suspect.
The problem with a new piece of fine jewelry is that if it isn't different, it tends to look like more of the same old thing and if it is too different, the wearer is likely to get bored with it.

WASHINGTON, July 27 A Senate Foreign Relations subcommittee has discovered that when the United States withdrew its military forces from bases in Morocco in 1963 it entered into a private arrangement with the Moroccan Government to retain a large naval communications center.
LONDON, July 27 Hopes for a settlement in Britain's 13day-old dock strike rose today when port employers accepted the recommendations of a court of inquiry into the deadlocked wage dispute.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Representative Fletcher Thompson, Republican of Georgia introduced a resolution today to make Washington newsmen subject to the same financial disclosures required of House members and their staffs.

Wellington Mara, the owner of the New York Giants, warned yesterday that if the pro football labor impasse forced the cancellation of the first weekend of exhibition games on Aug. 7 and 8, less than two weeks away, the National Football League regular season would be in jeopardy.
London stocks maintained a steady tone throughout trading and closed higher yesterday in quiet dealings.

LONDON, July 27 (UPI) The Foreign Office refused to say today where the deposed Sultan of Muscat and Oman, Said bin Taimur, was being treated for gunshot wounds apparently received last Thursday in a palace coup led by his son.

The scientific instruments to be carried on the first spacecraft to fly by and photograph Venus and Mercury on a single mission were announced yesterday by the National Aeronautics and Snace Administration.

CHICAGO, July 27 Sears, Roebuck and Company, the world's largest retailer, anpounced today that its new central headquarters in downtown Chicago would be the world's tallest building and the largest private building in the world.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., July 27 A state Superior Court judge ruled today that a threeday rock festival scheduled for the Power Ridge Ski Area in nearby Middlefield this weekend would create a public nuisance and could not be held.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., July 27 Mr. and Mrs. Ronald C. Green Jr. have made known the engagement of Mr. Green's daughter, Miss Cornelia E. Green, to R. Park Palmer. He is a son of Mrs. Stephen Palmer of South Hamilton, Mass., and Sotogrande, Spain, and the late Maj. Harry Winfield Schenck, U.S.A. He is the adopted son of Mr. Palmer. A Sept. 12 wedding is planned.

Rush-hour subway service to Queens was delayed for as much as two hours last night when a stalled EE train in the 59th Street tunnel produced a chain of circumstances that snarled most of the system north and east of the Queens Plaza station.
NEW DELHI, July 27 Indian officials seemed relieved today that the visit of Mrs. Nguyen Thi Binh, foreign minister of the Vietcong's provisional revolutionary government, was over.
President Urho Kekkonen of Finland raised a Finish flag and cut a ribbon at ceremonies yesterday officially opening Finland House, the new home of the Finnish consulate.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, July 28 (AP) Heavy fighting was reported yesterday around the former resort town of Kirirom in Cambodia, on a plateau 50 miles west of Pnompenh. Four Cambodian battalions that seized the town 11 days ago were said to be surrounded by enemy troops and the situation was described as serious.

It would have been nothing short of miraculous if Dr. Alexander Heard, who is acting as special Presidential adviser on campus unrest, had been able to tell Mr. Nixon much that is not already known, at least outside the White House. To say this is not to take issue with Dr. Heard's generally perceptive essay on the mood of at least the most socially conscious and most vocal students.

YONKERS, July 27 With 20,000 gallons of paint having turned the dull, ancient grandstand into a shiny, psychedelic dreamland, Yonkers Raceway's 72-card, second-half meeting opened tonight in electrifying fashion.

RIO DE JANEIRO, July 27 Tens of thousand of forest Indians in Brazil who live along the path of the quickening march westward into the Amazon Basin face a choice between a probably fatal fight against civilization and the abandonment of their culture to become part of Brazil's.
LONDON, July 27 London's Festival Ballet should be to the Royal Ballet what the American Ballet Theater is to the New York City Ballet. It is not, but it is at least still trying.

GLEN COVE, L.I., July 27 Members of the Jewish Defense League climbed over the wall surrounding the Soviet Union's 38-acre estate here today and used a spray can of red paint to write slogans in Hebrew and English on the walls, a gatepost and on the roadway.
WASHINGTON, July 27 The House, heeding the demands of reformers, voted today to scrap the system under which it has shaped much of its legislation by secret vote since the first Congress in 1789.

WASHINGTON, Conn., July 27 Miss Sharon Forester Salembier, an assistant analyst with Smith, Barney Co., stockbrokers in New York, plans to be married here on Aug. 29 to John Russell Cornell, who is with the New York law firm of Cadwalader, Wickersham Taft.
The engagement of Miss Shana J. Dash to Dr. Leslie M. Unger, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Unger of Brooklyn, has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Earl Dash, also of Brooklyn.

EDGARTOWN, Mass., July 27 A second New York Yacht Club cruise event of the three scheduled since Saturday was blotted out by fog today. It was to have been a 25-mile squadron run from Padanaram. After waiting an hour and a half with no sign of a clearing Dev Barker, the race committee chairman, ordered the "proceed at will to Edgartown" signals to be broken out. The time was 12:30 P.M.

WASHINGTON, July 27 Attorneys for Mrs. Bella S. Abzug, the Democratic candidate for Congress in New York's 19th District, made a rare complaint today: That it would be an unfair burden to have to match Barry Farber, her Republican opponent and a professional radio interviewer, in "equal time" broadcasts of her own.

After the long and divisive debates about the legal and constitutional bases for United States military actions in Indochina, the last thing the Nixon Administration ought to be considering is another vague overseas defense commitment. It appears ready, however, to sign a pledge to "support the defense system" of Spain in return for continued use of air and naval bases there.

Jacob K. Javits, the senior Republican Senator from New York, introduced a bill in Congress yesterday that would allow the Government to guarantee up to $5-billion in loans to private corporations that were experiencing trouble in getting funds to pay their debts but were otherwise basically sound.
OJAI, Calif. After seven years and two million pies, Alan Hooker decided he wanted more out of life than managing a wholesale pie bakery in Columbus, Ohio, could provide.

WASHINGTON, July 27 The Federal Reserve Board announced today its approval of a new bank holding company in New Jersey that will acquire the assets of the state's fourth largest bank, People's Trust of New Jersey, and four other banks.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 27 Dave Ragan of Orlando, Fla., led the way through the qualifying round for the fourth annual Westchester Golf Classic today with a 32, 35 67 over the West Course at the Westchester Country Club.
In a main-event match between a pair of 14-game winners, Tom Seaver outpitched Gaylord Perry last night as the New York Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-3.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 27 Nancy Baroody of Lake ville, Conn., sold Midget, her four-time national high point small pony champion early this year, but she still manages to win her share of classes with her two new mounts.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 27 The Yankees broke their fourgame losing streak tonight in silent but effective fashion, beating the California Angels, 5-2, in the 10th inning.
WASHINGTON, July 27 Georgetown University has appointed to its board of directors the first Negro in this century and also the youngest member in the school's 181year history.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 27 (AP) Charges against two men accused of slaying State Representative Leon M. Jordan, Negro Democratic leader, were dropped today, Joseph Teasdale, prosecuting attorney, said.
The Board of Higher Education authorized the American Council on Education last night to make a two-year study of the City University's new openadmissions program, at a cost of more than $594,000.
The fragile remains of a Dutch colonial stockade have been unearthed in Kingston, N.Y., by a team of archeologists who got to the site before a modern enemy, the bulldozer, did.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) Government auditors have found that nursing homes in California were paid by Medicaid for care of patients after their deaths or discharges. In other cases, nursing homes have been paid twice for the same nursing care under the Medicare and Medicaid programs.
LONDON, July 27 The British tea break, a national institution that stirs a cool welcome among employers, was warmly praised today by labor experts.
WASHINGTON, July 27 The United States recorded in June its largest surplus of exports over imports for a single month since 1966, the Commerce Department reported today.
The Lindsay administration has substantially expanded the use of private law firms, a marked departure from the philosophy and practices of the Wagner administration.

TAMPA, Fla., July 27 (AP) The 12-Meter yacht Gretel II, which will carry Australia's honors in the America's cup trials off Newport, R.I., next month, arrived here today aboard the steamship New York Star.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 27 (UPI) A mild upset occurred in the rain-delayed opening round of the $50,000 National Clay-Court Tennis Tournament today when Jim Osborne of Honolulu, the country's ninth-ranked player lost to unseeded Patricio Cornejo of Chile, 6-4, 11-9.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 27 Antiwar and anti-Government members of the National Assembly say that harassment over their views is continual, but their most serious fear is for their political survival.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it had revoked the broker-dealer registration of a Seattle concern and barred its president from further association with any securities firm.
Twelve years ago, when I lived in New Hampshire, an abnormal influx of out-ofstate deer hunters in our area left most of the natives quaking with fear.
NEWARK, July 27 (UPI) A two-month old boy died here after accidentally swallowing some of his mother's methadone tablets, the state medical examiner said today.
The American Smelting and Refining Company announced yesterday that it would close its Selby lead plant near San Francisco "within the next several months."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 27 (UPI) Tom Hamilton, former player, coach and athletic director at the United States Naval Academy and presently commissioner of the Pacific Eight Conference, was named recipient today of the National Football Foundation and Hall of Fame's Gold Medal Award of 1970.

Mr. and Mrs. Leslie Zukor of Montreal have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Shoshi Zukor, to Howard Nusbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodwin Nusbaum of Rochester. An Aug. 30 wedding is planned.

BAYREUTH, Germany, July 27(AP) Agreement has been reached in principle to transform the family-run Richard Wagner opera festival into a public foundation, Mayor Hans Walter Wild of Bayreuth said yesterday.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., July 27 (AP) Dr. Milner B. Schaefer, director of the Marine Resources Institute at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography here, died yesterday in Mercy Hospital after a heart attack. He was 57 years old.

ROCKVILLE, Md., July 27 (AP) Mary Dwyer of Geneva, N.Y., and Mrs. W.B. Mahan of Corpus Christi, Tex., each shot par 73's today at Manor Country Club and tied for the medal in qualifying for the women's Trans-Mississippi golf championship.
WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) The Penn Central Railroad borrowed almost $60-million this year from Swiss banks to pay off some United States creditors, Congressional testimony showed today.
With no significant news to move it one way or the other, the stock market held to an even keel in slow trading yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, July 27 Mrs. Linda Kasabian, 21-yearold former member of a hippie group who is testifying for the prosecution in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson, began her testimony today amid a barrage of objections from defense lawyers.
RUIDOSO, N.M., July 27 (UPI) A Texas woman was rescued today from the wreckage of a plane 9,000 feet up Capitan Mountain three days after the plane crashed.
LOS ANGELES, July 27 (Reuters) Andre Previn, the composer-conductor, divorced his wife, Dorothy Langdon, today in a hearing that lasted less than 60 seconds.
Dr. Will M. Myers, a vice president of the Rockefeller Foundation, died of a heart attack Sunday in Fargo, N.D. He was 59 years old and lived in Port Chester, N.Y.

A Police Department trial commissioner reserved decision yesterday on charges that a Police Department detective obtained $5,000 as a reward from Montgomery Ward for the recovery of $100,000 in stolen merchandise.

It was a day of fence-sitting yesterday for stocks on the American Stock Exchange. The index closed with a tiny change up 0.02 to 20.34. There were 354 stocks advancing in price to 343 issues that declined.
WASHINGTON, July 27 The armed forces annually accept an average of 20,000 men who should have been rejected for physical defects, the General Accounting Office reported today.
LONDON, July 27 (UPI) Prince Charles today told five British high school students going to Washington next month to behave themselves in the White House.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 27 The Westinghouse Electric Corporation is giving "serious consideration" to filing dumping charges against foreign turbine-generator manufacturers, Gordon C. Hurlbert, executive vice president of power generation, said here today.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 27 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that future defense contracts would be negotiated on a "fly before you buy" basis designed to prevent massive losses to taxpayers because of cost overruns.

VIENNA, July 21 Not until 1972 are inspectors supposed to take up posts to insure compliance with the treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons. But disarmament experts in Geneva have already voiced misgivings about the effectiveness of the planned inspection system.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., July 27 (UPI) Rich Reese tripled in two runs in the third inning and scored on Tony Oliva's double tonight carrying the Minnesota Twins a 5-2 victory over the Baltimore Orioles in the final regular season game between the American League's division leaders.

If you're like a lot of tourists on their first trip abroad, you have discovered that the First National City Bank got there before you. The seasoned traveler suspects the truth: First National City offices dot the globe to a far greater degree than those of any other United States bank.

A Bronx vender who has sold hot dogs and sodas from a truck at the same Bronx intersection for 18 years was arrested yesterday and charged with using the truck as a base for the sale of stolen merchandise and forged documents.

OZARK, Ala., July 27 (UPI) Military officials at Fort Rucker said today that they had canceled the contract of a strikeplagued civilian concern that had been training military pilots for duty in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 27 Treasury bill races declined at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

A type of air pollution that had been considered of such low priority that it was reported only once a month has been strongly linked to the discomfort that has accompanied the stagnant air over the city for the last few days.

The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation is observing its 50th year with the highest second-quarter and half-year profits in its history and the best gains for the periods on record. I.T.T.'s figures include results of the recently acquired Hartford Fire Insurance Company.

Operations of the American Express Company and its subsidiaries in the first six months this year resulted in record earnings, according to the company's report issued yesterday.
Diners Club, which has been pretty quiet on the advertising scene lately, is about to pop close to $3-million worth of communications on the public at large.

The "world's largest innkeepers" (Holiday Inns) yesterday selected the world's largest ad agency (J. Walter Thompson) to handle its estimated $2.5-million a year of advertising. This is not the world's largest ad budget, but who's complaining.
Mrs. Helen Rogers Reid, former president of The New York Herald Tribune, died of arteriosclerosis yesterday at her home, 834 Fifth Avenue.

NOROTON, Conn., July 27 The Belle Haven Club crew from Greenwich, Conn., captained by Steve Hicks, took a four-point lead today in the qualifying series for the 47th annual junior sailing champpionship of Long Island Sound. The first two races were held in Lightning sloops off the Noroton Yacht Club.

The United Slates, Japan and Australia were urged yesterday by the Committee for Economic Development to step up their development assistance to Southeast Asia, particularly because of the withdrawal of American, British and allied military forces from that area.
Cocoa futures jumped the one-cent-a-pound daily permissible limit yesterday on a light volume of 574 contracts.

The Securities and Exchange Commission announced yesterday the suspension for 25 days of certain over-the-counter operations of Dreyfus Co., New York securities dealers and brokers, and the 15-day suspension of Thomas B. Bligh, a Dreyfus partner, from doing business through the firm. Both suspensions begin tomorrow.
MAYFIELD, Ga., July 26 The cornmeal-coated hands of Cleveland Dargan and Tom Rushing moved swiftly, picking up catfish fillets and dropping them into the boiling oil of six iron cooking cots.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 27 Defense Minister, Jung Nae Hiuk, said today that South Korean military officials would begin talks this week with United States officials on the modernization of this country's armed forces.

The five big companies that supply the multimilliondollar dry cereal market do not appear to be planning any changes in their advertising as a result of the blast leveled at them in Washington last Thursday.

CINCINNATI, July 27 (UPI) Richie Allen hit two home runs and Mike Shannon contributed a three-run triple tonight as the St. Louis Cardinals pounded the Cincinnati Reds, 16-9, to snap an eight-game losing streak.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., July 27 (AP) A Soviet trawler that came within 200 yards of the nuclear submarine James Madison last Friday apparently caused the postponement of the first launching of a multiple-warhead Poseidon missile from the submarine.

LISBON, July 27 Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, ruler of Portugal for 40 years until he suffered a stroke in September, 1968, died today at the age of 81. He suffered a heart attack and vascular collapse two weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, July 27 United States officials said today that under the American proposal for a cease-fire along the Israeli-Egyptian and IsraeliJordanian defense lines, the Jordanian Government would be committed to controlling Palestinian guerrilla organizations.

Last night at the Cubiculo, she presented six of her solo dances, two of which were premieres.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (Reuters) Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird, in testimony before a House subcommittee released today, said that he felt he had authority to permit "short incursions" into Laos.

Governor Rockefeller and Controller Arthur Levitt said yesterday they were supporting their own, separate party slates and were not interested in any coalition ticket that included James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator.

Governor Rockefeller said yesterday that he would ask the next session of the Legislature to appropriate $10-million in emergency funds for the construction of facilities to house neglected and abandoned children.

JERUSALEM, July 27 Premier Golda Meir was reported to be striving today to achieve unanimity in her broad coalition Cabinet for a positive response to the United States proposal for a limited ceasefire and peace talks with the Arabs. She is said to be hopeful of averting abstentions by certain Ministers.

HOUSTON, July 27 Carl Hampton, the 21-year-old leader of a black militant organization in Houston, was fatally shot by the police early this morning in an exchange of gunfire that left four other persons wounded.
PLYMOUTH, England, July 27 (AP) After weathering unseasonable English Channel gales, Trumpeter, the only United States entry, arrived here today and finished third in the round-Britain yacht race.

CHICAGO, July 27 (AP) The world champion Kansas City Chiefs will be at least a 10point favorite for the 37th annual College All-Star game in Soldier Field Friday night.

The eight members of the 1970 college golf team who will be honored guests tonight at the sixth All-American collegiate golf dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria enjoyed a practice round (of lunch) yesterday.

CLEVELAND, July 27 Benjamin O. Davis Jr., charging that the administration of Mayor Carl B. Stokes was providing "support and comfort" to enemies of the police, resigned today after six months as Cleveland's safety director in charge of the Police and Fire Departments.

TEL AVIV, July 27 Egyptian jet fighter-bombers struck at Israel today for the first time in a month, coming in low over the Suez Canal to raid positions in the Sinai peninsula. The Israelis said that their jet fighters had downed two Egyptian MIG-17's in dogfights.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (AP) The Food and Drug Administration approved today the first marketing of a pain-killing drug called DMSO, or dimethyl sulfoxide, but limited its use to swelling in horses caused by external injury.

WASHINGTON, July 27 (UPI) Vince Lombardi, the Washington Redskin coach, underwent surgery for the second time in a month today at Georgetown University hospital here and was reported "resting comfortably."

CONCORD, Mass., July 27 Harris Fahnestock, assistant director of the Massachusetts Intitute of Technology's Lincoln Laboratory, died at his home here yesterday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 64 years old.
WEST NEW YORK, N.J., July 27 Col. Leonard H. Nason, an author who specialized in war stories, died Saturday in Dufur Hospital, Ambler, Pa. He was 74 years old and lived here at 6040 Boulevard East.
CHICAGO, July 27 Several thousand Negro and white youths, hurling rocks, battled the police for more than six hours tonight. They roamed into the Loop business district and smashed windows.
GREENWICH, Conn., July 27 Robert P. Clarke Sr., a retired chemical executive and partner in a brokerage firm, died Friday at Greenwich Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived at 19 Pilgrim Drive.

The Consolidated Edison Company met a near-record demand by New Yorkers for electricity on a steaming hot day yesterday, aided by power imported from outside the city and by a nearly four-hour reduction of voltage by 3 per cent.

BETHESDA, Md., July 27 (AP) Representative Michael J. Kirwan, an Ohio Democrat who wielded great power within Congress and the Democratic party, died today at Bethesda Naval Hospital. He was 83 years old.
WASHINGTON, July 27 More than 350 antipoverty volunteers assembled in this city today to consider forming their own union.
Charges against checking accounts in New York City banks rose in June by 2.7 per cent from the May level to $4.37-trillion, the Federal Reserve reported yesterday.

Predictable did exactly what was expected of her, according to the "figures," at Aqueduct yesterday, but she made it close, indeed. Bet into favoritism by the crowd of 28,819, the Wheatley Stable's homebred won the one-mile feature race by a neck. The Hobeau Farm's Someday was another neck ahead of the third place Mereworth Farm's Hasty Hitter in the field of eight fillies and mares. Predictable's payoff price was $4.80 for $2.

SMOKE RISE, N.J., July 27 The engagement of Miss Pamela Jean Erikson to Wallace Franklin Caldwell has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. John Harold Erikson Jr., parents of the future bride. Her finance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert W. Caldwell of Kensington, Md.
The second major fire in two weeks delayed 25,000 Penn Central commuters from Westchester and Connecticut for up to three hours during the morning rush hours yesterday.

Alex Francis, head track coach at Kansas State College at Fort Hayes, and Bobby Winkles, baseball coach at Arizona State, were selected yesterday as coaches of the United States teams for the 1971 Pan-American Games.

WASHINGTON, July 27 In his efforts to master the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, which others have found unmanageable, Elliot L. Richardson, the new Secretary, is emphasizing the consolidation..

It would be difficult in the best of circumstances to have to replace so able and experienced a British Cabinet minister as Iain Macleod. Prime Minister Heath had to find that replacement as Chancellor of the Exchequer from a Conservative Government barely a month in office after nearly six years in opposition and his difficulties did not stop there.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, July 28 Qualified Western sources say that the Chinese Nationalist Government, under insistent pressure from the United States, has quietly cut the size of its standing army from about 600,000 to 550,000 and promises to make still further cuts.
Isaac Stern took an hour in the middle of a turbulent schedule yesterday to down six mugs of coffee and talk about what is wrong with the life of a musician and what keeps him going.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 16 Since 1670 the Hudson's Bay Company has burgeoned across Canada from a few scattered trading posts into an adventurous multimillion-dollar company that today even sells refrigerators to Eskimos.
TOKYO, July 28 The pollution of soil, water and atmosphere has reached crisis proportions in this narrow land, where more than 100 million people are jammed together in an area the size of Montana.

WHITE PLAINS, July 28 Miss Ellin Rita Schechter, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Schechter of Mamaroneck, was married here this evening to Douglas Frank Maxwell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Manuel Maxwell of New York. The ceremony was performed in the Fenway Golf Club by Rabbi Arnold Kaiman of Larchmont.

CAMDEN, N.J. The children said they liked the bunk beds. And the airconditioning. And the bunk beds. And playmates who didn't beat them up. And the bunk beds. And the pretty furniture. And the bunk beds.

PALMYRA, N.Y., July 27 Hundreds of Mormon pilgrims from over the country have gathered this week in this area of undulant fields of wildflowers and seemingly endless rows of corn as part of a commemoration of the 140th anniversary of the founding of their church.
NASSAU, the Bahamas She comes from the Corn Belt in Iowa.

WASHINGTON, July 28 Officials of the Smithsonian Institution conceded at a House subcommittee hearing today that paintings from the National Collection of Fine Arts had been sold without adequate review by museum directors.

BONN, July 28 A German ethnologist, Prof. Thomas Barthel, reports that he and a Peruvian colleague have succeeded in deciphering the 500year-old script of the Inca nation, regarded until now merely as ornamentation.

Eleven buses owned by Frank A. Tedesco have been ordered out of service by the New Jersey Public Service Commission. A bus owned by Mr. Tedesco crashed on July 15 near Allentown, Pa., killing seven children.
London stock prices moved lowed despite persistent optimism that the dock workers strike would be settled soon. Trading was quiet.

LIBERTY, Mo., July 28 The Kansas City Chiefs, the champions of pro football, will fly to Chicago on Thursday, play the College AllStars on Friday night and then disband if no agreement has been reached between the Players Association and the National Football League owners.

Lamar Hunt, who as owner of the Kansas City Chiefs helped engineer the merger in professional football, expanded his sports empire yesterday by acquiring the contracts of six top tennis pros Rod Laver, Ken Rosewall, Roy Emerson, Fred Stolle, Andres Gimeno and Richard (Pancho) Gonzales.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 28 Nancy Baroody of Lakeville, Conn., rode Shenandoah Flintstone to the small pony hunter championship and Neat 'N Tidy to the large pony foxchaser title today to score a double at the Orange County horse show.

"We need more advertising in this country, not less." Those memorable words, which will bring cheers from some and groans from others, were spoken just the other day by Norman E. (Pete) Cash, just past one milestone (his 52d birthday) and awaiting another (the beginning of his 15th year as president of the Television Bureau of Advertising).

Yields on new issues of corporate bonds, which dropped so sharply over the last five and a half weeks, are climbing once again, but tax-exempt bond rates are still declining. This mixed picture emerged yesterday as a heavy schedule of bond sales got under way.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 28 (AP) -Three seeded players lost to unseeded players in the $50,000 national clay courts tennis tourament today, but the defending champions and top United States seeded stars posted easy victories.
DETROIT, July 28 The Ford Motor Company called today for tougher factory discipline to curb employe absenteeism.
WARREN, Mich., July 28 George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, has run into an uproar here in his home state over Federal efforts to press for desegregation in suburban hous ing.
WASHINGTON, July 28 Dr. Thomas O. Paine resigned today as head of the space agency that he had led during its greatest success the landing of men on the moon.
A middle-aged man sits quietly in a big red-leather swivel chair, his eyes fixed on a green board with flashing red lights that forms a large horseshoe around him.

The American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington that spending by domestic steel companies to control air and water pollution last year was about $138million, up from $102-million the previous year.

Commuters on the 7:25 A.M. train from Brewster, N.Y. got 10 newly refurbished cars, free coffee and a handshake from Governor Rockefeller yesterday, but they said what they really wanted was for the trains to run on time.
Jean Starr Untermeyer, poet and former wife of the poet Louis Untermeyer, was found dead Monday, apparently of a heart attack, in her apartment at 235 East 73d Street. She was 84 years old.

Activities. The President met with his top advisers on the 1972 fiscal year defense budget. He announced that Dr. Thomas O. Paine, NASA administrator, was resigning effective Sept. 15. The President signed the Newspapers Preservation Act.
Six months after going into commercial service, the Boeing 747 jumbo jet still is bedeviled by a variety of technical ailmeets that have made on-time performance a spotty phenomenon.
CLEVELAND, July 28-Republican party officials here today urged Benjamin O. Davis Jr., who resigned yesterday as Cleveland's safety director, to run for Mayor neat year.

WASHINGTON, July 28 Senator Clifford P. Hansen, Republican of Wyoming, said today he had decided to vote against further appropriations for the supersonic transport, principally because of the plane's sonic boom and other environmental hazards.

A long-standing dispute between Gimbels and community groups on the Upper East Side has apparently been settled with an agreement by Gimbels to build subway entrances as part of a store under construction at 86th Street and Lexington Avenue.

CHAPPAQUA, N.Y., July 28 Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Brooks of Chappaqua and Wayne, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lynda Lee Brooks, to Thomas Adam Crowley, son of Mr. and Mrs. John A. Crowley Jr. of Chappaqua, formerly of Scarsdale.

In 1966 Richard Nixon confided to Jules Witcover in an interview that "I'm not one of those guys who reads his press clippings. I believe in never being affected by reports about me.... I never look at myself on TV, either. I don't want to develop those phony, self-conscious, contrived things.

ROME, July 28 Italy's Socialist party administered a setback today to the efforts of Premier-designate Emilio Colombo to put a governing coalition together again and form a Cabinet to end a 22-day Government crisis.

The United States Steet Corporation reported yesterday that its earnings declined in the second quarter and first half of 1970 down about 27 per cent in both cases from the 1969 levels although sales and other revenues continued to advance slightly.

Twelve doctors at Lincoln Hospital in the Bronx have asked to be relieved of their jobs in the pediatrics clinic and others have threatened mass resignations because of alleged "harassment and intimidation" by the Young Lords and other groups.

RABAT, Morocco, July 28 A government spokesman denied today that there was any United States military installation in Morocco and asserted that there had been no secret agreement between Washington and the Moroccan Government for maintenance of a United States Navy communications center in this country.
LONDON, July 28 Prime Minister Heath today appointed Geoffrey Rippon to be Britain's negotiator for entry into the Common Market.
TEL AVIV, July 28 (Reuters) Israeli jets continued their bombardment of United Arab Republic military targets along the Suez Canal with a day-long attack today, a military spokesman said.
The New York Mets continued their midsummer revival last night before 50,174 persons in Shea Stadium, when they demolished the San Francisco Giants, 12-2.

OCEANPORT, N. J., July . 28 (AP Briardale Farms' Ad Majora pushed through along the rail to win the $10,000 Oceanport Purse in the final strides at Monmouth Park today and gave Mike Miceli his third riding victory of the day.

MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., July 28 The promoters of a threeday rock festival scheduled for this weekend lost another round today in their legal battle to hold the event here at the Powder Ridge Ski Area. But crowds of young people continued to stream in, while others went on with preparations for the festival.

WASHINGTON, July 28 The Department of Commerce has approved the sale by an Italian company to Communist China of 80 dump trucks containing General Motors Corporation engines, United States officials said tonight.

WASHINGTON, July 28 The Senate approved unanimously and sent to President Nixon today a $4.4-billion education bill that, despite White House warnings, is $453-million higher than the Presideni's budget request.

LOS ANGELES, July 28 The star prosecution witness in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three of his hippie band tearfully described today what she said were details of the killing of five persons in Los Angeles last year.
CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) Continental Airlines, Inc., announced today a $160-million deal calling for purchase of eight McDonnell Douglas DC10 wide-bodied trijet aircraft and an option for eight others.
WASHINGTON, July 28 Three specialists here have advocated that all blood banks capable of doing so should test donated blood for a substance found only in association with hepatitis.
WASHINGTON, July 28 The Government's composite index of "leading indicators" of the economy continued to signal a sluggish outlook in June, the Commerce Department disclosed today.

BRIDGETON, N.J., July 28 (AP) Leon (Goose) Goslin a former major league outfielder, remained in fair condition today in Bridgeton Memorial Hospital after undergoing an operation for the removal of his larynx yesterday.
A bank employe's error has cost New York City $65,250.

WASHINGTON, July 28, (AP). New concern developed today over the physical condition of Vince Lombardi, head coach and general manager of the Washington Redskins, following his second abdominal operation in a month.
Vice President Agnew was honored last night at the sixth annual All-American Collegiate golf dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

A daily forum providing a wide variety of views and opinions will be established on the page opposite the editorial page of The New York Times, Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher of The Times, announced yesterday.

A Smithsonian Institution collection of 44 paintings and graphics by deaf and hard of hearing children and adults was placed on display yesterday at the New York League for the Hard of Hearing, 71 West 23d Street. The exhibition will continue through Sept. 12.

WASHINGTON, July 28 Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, former Under Secretary of State, urged Congress today to repeal the Tonkin Gulf resolution of 1964, which he once described as the "functional equivalent" of a declaration of war in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, July 28 The Government announced today that the Federal budget showed a relatively small deficit of $2.9billion in the fiscal year that ended June 30.

"My writing is clear as mud," wrote Gertrude Stein, an assertion for which, over the years, she furnished copious evidence. But when she was good she was good she was good, as illustrated in "When This You See Remember Me," last evening's half-hour program of readings from her work on Channel 13.

PARIS, July 28 The French Government today authorized the Fiat Company of Turin, Italy, to increase its ownership in the Citroen company of France, cementing a trans-European partnership accounting for production of 2 million vehicles a year.

LONDON July 28 (Reuters) Capt. Raimond D'Inzeo of Italy soared over a 6-foot-9inch wall on his Irish-bred mount Bellevue to win the high jump event at the Royal International horse show at Wembley tonight.

Samuel I. Rosenman, aide and counselor for a generation to Democratic Presidents and Governors, announced yesterday that he was supporting Governor Rockefeller for reelection and would head a group called Democrats for Rockefeller.

WASHINGTON, July 28 The Army moved today to hold Further investigations of seven officers implicated in the suppression of information about the alleged mass killing of civilians two years ago in Songmy, South Vietnam.
The executive director of Aspira said yesterday that more than 60 per cent of Puerto Rican college students dropped out of school in the first two years.

Edward F. Breslin, former justice of the city Court of Special Sessions and the Criminal Court, died of a heart attack Monday at Union Hospital, the Bronx. He was 71 years old and lived at 306 East Mosholu Parkway, the Bronx.
ELLOREE, S.C., July 28 W.P. Dent, an older brother of Harry S. Dent, a special counsel to President Nixon, was bound over tonight to face a grand jury on charges of robbery and assault and battery.

WASHINGTON, July 28 Temperatures in the 90's, high humidity and the virtual lack of breeze held a blanket of polluted air over the Washington metropolitan area tonight in the closest approach that this area has yet known to a pollution alert.

KINGS POINT, L.I., July 28 Mr. and Mrs. William Wachtenheim have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Wachtenheim, to William Ira Denberg. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome A. Denberg of Manhasset Hills.

LIMA, Peru, July 28 (Reuters) The President of Peru, Gen. Juan velasco Alvarado, tonight announced a new industrial law that forces Peruvian companies to hand over 10 per cent of their annual pre-tax net profit to workers, and also forces the companies to buy 50 per cent of their own shares for workers. and television speech on the 149th anniversary of Peruvian independence.

There are six communities in Brooklyn's Community School District 13, and Monday night, after two months of often bitter wrangling, campaigning and screening, a superintendent was chosen to oversee the children's education.

ELIZABETH, N.J. July 28 I. George Seget of this city, chairman of the board of the Service Machine Company of Elizabeth, died yesterday in St. Anthony's Hospital, St. Petersburg, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 79 years old.

The city awarded 20-year noncompetitive contracts yesterday to two Manhattan cable television operators and authorized the development of cable television on a competitive-bidding basis in the four other boroughs.

JERUSALEM, July 28 Defense Minister Moshe Dayan said tonight that Israel "is not so strong that she can afford to lose allies" an apparent allusion to the United States. He was believed to be acknowledging his feeling that Israel was compelled to accept the United States proposals for a limited cease-fire in the Middle East conflict.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 28 Since 1967 the Jordanians and the Lebanese have had confrontations with the Palestinians, and the United Arab Republic was able to act as mediator.
"My God, my God, now I know what hell looks like," a dazed young woman gasped as she was led from a stalled train through the Penn Central Railroad's smoke-filled Park Avenue tunnel.
PARIS, July Discreet French diplomacy has contributed to the release of 80 Jews from a prison in the United Arab Republic, according to reliable reports here.
LONDON, July 28 (UPI) Striking dock workers today voiced rejection of a plan by a court of inquiry to settle the 13-day-old walkout even before their leaders had an opportunity to vote on it.

ANAHEIM, Calif., July 28 Tom Egan, a husky young catcher with the California Angels, committed five passed balls and one error tonight, most of them contributing to the Yankees' 6-5 victory over the Angels.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 28 Ted Hood's Robin, one of several of his yachts of the same name and all painted blue, and John Baringer's Zephyros, a Fastnet 45, remained the only unbeaten boats on the New York Yacht Club cruise today.
Francis J. Honn has been named vice president, technical services and development, chemicals division, by the Olin Corporation.
OTTAWA, July 28 The Government was urged by a House of Commons committee today to set a goal of Canadian control of all foreign subsidiaries operating in Canada.

CAIRO, July 28 The United Arab Republic suspended today the radio broadcasting privileges of two Palestinian commando organizations in retaliation for criticism of Cairo's acceptance of the United States initiative for an Arab-Israeli settlement.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 28 Enemy troops occupied the state cement works at Kampot yesterday after the Cambodian defenders ran out of ammunition and abandoned the factory, the Government military spokesman said today.

Roberto Clemente, baseball fans know, has won innumerable games with his hitting and fielding, but Joe Brown, the Pittsburgh general manager, tells of another way in which Clemente is a most valuable Pirate.

The engagement of Miss Penelope Pearce Griswold to John Pollard McWilliams Jr. has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. M. Bright Alloo of New York and Southampton, L.I., stepfather and mother of the future bride.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday directed the Commissioner of Social Services, Jack R. Goldberg, to take immediate steps to reduce overcrowding in two Manhatan child shelters by leasing additional facilities.

SYDNEY, Australia, July 28 Stringent moves to control environmental pollution here were announced today following an uproar over a wave of noxious industrial waste gas that enveloped Sydney with a strong odor of rotten eggs last Saturday night.

TORRINGTON, Conn., July 28 Mrs. Mason Trowbridge, a sculptor and the widow of a former counsel to the Colgate-Palmolive-Peet Company, died yesterday at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital here. She was 87 years old and lived in West Cornwall.

MOSCOW, July 28 West German efforts to obtain Soviet approval of changes in their projected treaty renouncing the use of force apparently ran into expected Soviet resistance today when the two sides began point-by-point discussion of the document.

CHICAGO, July 28 (AP) Mayor Daley told a news conference today: "Monday's concert was held to provide entertainment for young people. The hope, the belief, was that they would govern themselves. How can we achieve a condition in which young people will discipline themselves?"
ATHENS July 28 (UPI) Mrs. Aristotle S. Onassis observed her 41st birthday today on the Island of Skorpios, and as a present her husband ordered construction of a yacht, to be named Jacqueline.
An unidentified man was repeatedly and fatally stabbed near a Bowery hotel early yesterday morning as he tried to elude a neighborhood youth who had accosted him, the police said.

The appointment last week of four trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company by Federal District Judge John P. Fullam in Philadelphia was formally ratified yesterday by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
Stock prices closed slightly higher on balance yesterday after another session of fence sitting.
GENEVA, July 28 The United Nations took a decisive step today toward the creation of a world peace corps to assist the poorer nations toward economic development.
MOSCOW, July 28 The Soviet Union today announced the appointment of Nikolai N. Rodionov, a regional Communist party official, as a Deputy Foreign Minister.

One of the oldest issues in American history the degree of independence of the central bank from Presidential authority is heading for a new round. Its outcome may have a crucial impact on the future course of the economy and on the political fortunes of the Republican Party. The re-erner

After teetering indecisively on the fence Monday, stocks on the American Stock Exchange took a hop forward yesterday. The exchange's index gained 0.07 points to close at 20.41. Advances outnumbered declines by 404 to 334.

The bandwagon theory of trading worked vigorously yesterday in two leading commodities. Some traders jumped aboard fast-rolling silver and others were taking a not-sopleasant leap out of soybeans, either to conserve their profits or to cut their losses.
GREENPORT, L.I., July 28 Edwin H. King, a retired farmer and former Suffolk County Republican committeeman, died today at Eastern Long Island Hospital. He wash 79 years old and lived in Orient.

LONDON, July 28 American Ballet Theater las night opened a two-week season at the Royal Opera House, Covent Grarden. This was the company's fifth Covent Garden appearance since 1946, but its first in 14 years.
YONKERS, July 28 Except for a special few, things are going so badly for trainers of harness horses that most have had to sell a yacht, snowmobile or other bric-a-brac to carry on.

Peggy Lee was given the royal treatment Monday night at the Schaefer Music Festival in Central Park. August Heckscher, Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs, was there to welcome the singer. The Thad Jones-Mel Lewis band was recruited to accompany her along with eight strings and three guitars plus an additional percussionist, or- ganist, tuba and French horn.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, July 28 The first thing to be said in favor of Rudi Van Dantzig's staging of Prokofiev's "Romeo and Juliet" for the Netherlands National Ballet is that it is original.

SEOUL, South Korea, July 28 South Korean fighter planes sank a 50-ton North Korean speedboat, believed to have been used to put Communist agents ashore, early today off the cast coast, the Defense Ministry announced.
The second fire in as many days delayed Penn Central riders last night.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., July 28 Westchester rallied in afternoon singles matches today to tie New Jersey for the Stoddard Cup in the 39th annual triangular matches that also involve amateurs from the Long Island Golf Association.

Three major oil companies the Gulf Oil Corporation, the Cities Service Company and the Getty Oil Company issued midyear reports yesterday, all showing a drop in earnings. Among the reasons they cited were rising operating costs, the effects of rubber and trucking industry strikes, increased taxes and depressed prices.

The organizers of last week's international tournament in Deauville went to great trouble to insure worldwide participation in their invitational pair championship. The eight pairs included one from France, one from Great Britain, two from Italy, two from the United States, one from the Republic of China, and a cosmopolitan partnership of movie star Omar Sharif playing with a French expert.

WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) The Justice Department today filed a proposed settlement requiring the Atlantic Richfield Company to sell within three years 2,500 former Sinclair Oil Corporation gasoline stations in the South and West.

From the tops of its skyscrapers to the sweltering depths of its sprawling subway system, the city absorbed the impact yesterday of renewed cutbacks in electrical power from the crippled Con Edison system.

Shortly after "Company" opened, Dean Jones, playing the lead role of the bachelor Robert, became ill. His standby, Larry Kert, filled in and subsequently took over the role. Robert now belongs to Kert not just contractually.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (AP) A tough new consumer protection bill that would allow individuals to band together in "class action" 'suits was approved today by the Senate Commerce Committee.
WASHINGTON, July 28 The House refused today to make any changes in its seniority system, by which members move into positions of power solely through length of service.
WASHINGTON, July 28 (UPI) The House Ways and Means Committee voted formally today to hold President Nixon to the oil import quota system in effect since 1959.
C. Ernest Smith, a former Municipal Court judge and State Senator, died after a long illness yesterday at Staten Island Hospital. He lived at 260 Benedict Road, Staten Island.

LONDON, July 27 (AP) When you are Coutts bank, and all the English kings and queens have been your customers since George III, it comes as frightful news that a road is going to be run through your vault.
Merck Co. and the National Starch and Chemical Corporation announced last night preliminary agreement on a merger plan that would involve stock valued at about $189-million.
The Weyerhaeuser Company, a major producer of pulp paperboard and containers, had record sales but lower earnings in the second quarter and first half of this year, it reported yesterday.

LANSING, Mich., July 28 (AP) Gov. William G. Milliken has signed a law that permits anyone to file suit to protect the air, water and other nat- ural resources. Not even the state is immune from court action.
The memento on the bookcase in Mayor Lindsay's City Hall office could be a reminder that politics sometimes estrange bedfellows.
The New York lets and the Long Island Bulls will meet n a "controlled scrimmage game" on Saturday night if the management-labor dispute in pro football is settled by then.

The stock market may have bottomed out, but the pessimism lingers on. It is very difficult to generate excitement in a market that produces so little volume that brokerage houses continue to operate in the red.
Mary Pickford has donated 50 of the many short films that were made for the pioneer Biograph company here to the American Film Institute Collection in the Library of Congress.

United States controls on direct investments abroad have not brought any improvement in the American balance of payments, George Ball, former Under Secretary of State and Ambassador to the United Nations, said here yesterday.

What is a relay motor race? It is a participant sport, popular in England, that has been imported for some years to the Lime Rock Park road course in western Connecticut, where Jim Haynes, a promoter, is happy to try anything. A five-hour relay will be run Saturday, Sept. 5,
AUSTIN, Tex., July 28 (UPI) The Justice Department said today it would file suit to integrate 39 Texas school districts within 10 days unless the districts submitted to Federal guidelines.

This week, with the resumption of bilateral negotiations between Bonn and Moscow, Europe finds itself well launched on the diplomatic search for a new future. This future seems postulated on the assumption of declining American influence in its western half and the somewhat less warranted hope of declining Soviet influence in its eastern half.
The Professional Football Players Association can relax because the young woman who has been holding the football for Pete Gogolak, the Giants' kicker, doesn't want to play professionally.

The Norfolk Western Railway, whose stock has been one of the hardest hit of the rail issues in recent weeks, yesterday cut its dividend to $1.25 a share for the September quarter from the $1.50 a share it paid in March and June.

HOUSTON, July 28 Leaders of this city's Black Coalition accused the police today of deliberately creating a situation "to draw fire" last Sunday night that resulted in the death of Carl Hampton, a 21-year-old black activist here. Mr. Hampton was killed in a three-hour gun battle with the authorities, the police say.

ROCKVILLE, Md., July 28 (AP) Jane Bastanchury, the defending champion, was beaten today in 19 holes in the first round of the women's amateur Trans-Mississippi golf championship by Mrs. Richard Canney of nearby Centreville, Va.

JERSEY CITY, July 28 Joseph P. Schneider, founder and president of Schneider, Allen, Walsh, Inc., a New York advertising agency, died Sunday, after a brief illness, at Christ Hospital. He was 66 years old and lived at 93 Fairview Avenue.

Lawson H. Brown, a Brooklyn civic leader from the 1920's through the 1950's, who campaigned vigorously for improved public facilities in the borough, died yesterday in Hamden, Conn. He was 82 years old.

A lucky thing happened to Stanley Provus during his two years as a Peace Corps volunteer in Ethiopia. He didn't have a supervisor. The result is a small new industry for the African country and more colorful fashion for the Western world.

Congress and the American people are nearing a fundamental decision on transportation policy revolving about the Highway Trust Fund, which is scheduled to go out of existence on Sept. 30, 1972. The Nixon Administration has asked Congress to extend it for another four years, and House and Senate committees have begun hearings.
WASHINGTON, July 28 The Department of Defense reversed today a decision to sell a surplus quantity of dieldrin, a controversial pesticide.

Stanley R. Jaffe, who joined Paramount Pictures last October as executive vice president, has been appointed president of the motion picture and tele vision company, a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc.

Jacob H, Blitzer, former executive vice president and director of Lightolier, Inc., died Sunday at the Dewitt Nursing Home on East 79th Street following a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 111 East 56th Street and in Palm Beach, Fla.

WASHINGTON, July 28 The President's panel on the Defense Department, which spent a year studying the Pentagon for a report issued today, had as its chairman Gilbert W. Fitzhugh, chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.

The city's Department of Air Resources reported air pollution levels as unsatisfactory yesterday as a stagnant air system continued to hang over the area. The situation was expected to continue through today.

WASHINGTON, July 28 The Federal Communications Commission gave its approval today to the sale of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's teletypewriter exchange (or TWX) system to the Western Union Corporation.
A police sergeant in the Bronx and two firemen in Brooklyn were injured yesterday as a result of attempts to close illegally opened fire hydrants on city streets.

Meritus made an early lead stand up against the closing rush of Teddy's True to win the featured sprint at Aqueduct yesterday by a neck. The finish close as it was, was satisfactory to the favorite players in the crowd of 25,601. They made Meritus, who campaigns for James Cox Brady, the favorite at even money in the six-furlong event for older fillies.

WASHINGTON, July 28 A Presidential commission recommended today a radical reorganization of the Defense Department including the removal of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from involvement in military operations and a number of other steps designed to achieve more efficiency and save money in weapons procurement.

WASHINGTON, July 28 A Presidential commission recommended today a radical reorganization of the Defense Department including the removal of the Joint Chiefs of Staff from involvement in military operations and a number of other steps designed to achieve more efficiency and save money in weapons procurement.

OTTAWA, July 28 (AP) The House of Commons Finance Committee was informed today that Bobby Orr of the National Hockey League, a superstar of the Boston Bruins, spent more than $15,000 a year sending autographed pictures to his fans.

NOROTON, Conn., July 28 The defending champion Noroton Yacht Club crew, skippered by David Campbeli, led the way through the qualifying series of the 47th annual junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound today, when the final three preliminary races were held in lightning glass sloops on the sound off the Noroton club.

New Yorkers wriggled through an electric power crisis yesterday the hottest day of the year aided by voltage reductions throughout eastern New York State and three hours of voluntary cutbacks in power consumption.

Miss Irene Ingrid Helene von Dorrer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wolfgang von Dorrer of Bonn and Stuttgart, West Germany, was married in Stuttgart on Saturday to James. Leslie Hildebrand 3d, of Chardon, Ohio. The Rev. Rederick Schneeberg, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Schloss Solitude.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 28 (AP) A criminal court judge who sent several convicted terrorists to jail was kidnapped today by youths who identified themselves as Tupamaros, members of an urban guerrilla organization.

There have been more serious accidents on the New York subways in the last 10 years than on any other major subway system in the world; in the last year there have been more accident injuries here than on any other subway system.

RIDGECREST, N.C. The early morning clouds hung low over the Blue Ridge Mountains, and the only sound was the soft rustling of leaves heavy with dew. Suddenly, at 7 o'clock, the silence was broken by a carillon playing "Adestes Fideles."
Twenty-five "votemobiles" will start roaming the city Saturday in search of unregistered voters as part of the annual summer registration drive, the Board of Elections said yesterday.

A hearing will be held Aug. 11 by the National Labor Relations Board here on a petition filed by editorial workers of Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, seeking to be represented in collective bargaining by the United Automobile Workers.

Gilbert Wright Fitzhugh, the board chairman of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, keeps a small wooden triangle on his desk in New York. It is engraved with a thought that he believes is "pretty good": "Are you here with the solution or are you part of the problem?" ...
WASHINGTON, July 28 Congressional committees approved three different bills affecting the securities industry today, but a fourth hit an immediate snag in the Senate Banking Committee.

NEW HAVEN, July 28 Warren Kimbro testified today that he was told for the first time that Alex Rackley was to be killed only instants before a pistol was placed in his hand and he was given the order to pull the trigger.

While the Consolidated Edison Company was struggling to meet its power demands yesterday, the giant utility released its first-half earnings report, which showed sizable declines in net income despite higher operating revenues.
A cab driver was shot in the face early yesterday in the first shooting since the police started driving decoy cabs 10 days ago in an effort to cut down on attacks upon taxi drivers.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 28 (AP) President Nixon, a White House source said today, has signed into law a bill providing antitrust law exemptions for joint commercial operating agreements between newspapers in 22 cities.
The conviction of George Whitmore Jr. for attempted rape and assault on a Brooklyn practical nurse was affirmed unanimously yesterday by the Appellate Division, Second Department.

GENEVA, July 28 A preparatory committee will meet here from Aug. 3 to Aug. 7 to prepare the draft text of a new international grains agreement, a spokesman for the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development said today.
LONDON, July 28 "oh! Calcutta!" opened here last night to disappointing remarks from critics, the public and local officials.
