Confronted with an acute shortage of campaign funds, Arthur J. Goldberg has canceled virtually all his public appearances next week to devote almost full time to raising money for his DemocraticLiberal gubernatorial drive.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) The House sent to the Senate by voice vote today an $18billion appropriation bill providing $541-million more than President Nixon asked.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association will investigate reports of racial and religious discrimination at various invitation tournaments in its Middle Atlantic section, Alastair B. Martin, the association president, said yesterday.
LEWISBURG, Pa., July 28 The acting warden of Northeastern Federal Penitentiary denied today that the Rev. Philip Berrigan was being held in an isolated cell.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 29 (AP) President Nixon, repeating his assertion that Congress has been slow to act on anticrime legislation, signed today the controversial District of Columbia crime control bill.

William M. Webb of Haverford, Pa., and Mrs. Arthur M. Parker of Charleston, S.C., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Frazier Webb, to John Williams Sanford 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Jr. of Cooperstown, N.Y., and Provincetown, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

One of the best known kennels in Venezuela carries the McCool's prefix, which doesn't exactly have a Hispanic ring to it. "I was at the American Kennel Club to register my kennel," said Mrs. William Haas. "I guess my English wasn't too good and the clerk couldn't under

WASHINGTON, July 29 Frederick R. Livingston, the chairman of President Nixon's emergency board on the railroad firemen's dispute, said to day that his extended effort to mediate a settlement was on the verge of collapse.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 29 President Nixon has, for the time being, ruled out any request for new taxes or tax increases when he presents his budget for the fiscal year 1972 to Congress early next year, informed sources disclosed today.
Stock prices in London closed higher yesterday on news that union delegates had voted to end the national dock strike.

Mayor Lindsay, declaring that air pollution had reached crisis levels here, put the city on an alert yesterday that could ultimately mean steps as drastic as banning private automobiles from congested parts of the city.

There has been a trend lately for companies to buy their own shares at today's cheap market prices. However, that doesn't necessarily make the same shares a good additional buy for current stockholders or even for initial investment.
WASHINGTON, July 29 For every 1,000 jobs in manufacturing industries, eight were vacant last May, according to a survey made public today by the Department of Labor.

Through the polluted haze that for days has hung over East Coast cities from New York to Atlanta, nothing is clear but a timely warning. Urban areas are getting perilously close to the point where they may have to choose between the internal combustion engine and breathable air. That Tokyo should be undergoing the same harrowing ordeal in the same week demonstrates that the problem is worldwide and not even primarily an American phenomenon.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., July 29 Seven agencies of the State of Alabama have been ordered by a Federal Court to stop discriminating against Negroes in their hiring practices.

After 40 years in the money market, the last 14 of them as the top financial officer of the nation's largest steel company, Robert C. Tyson stepped down yesterday. As he made the move, he offered several acute observations on steel, money and men.

Doctors at Lincoln Hospital yesterday sidestepped the question of possible mass resignations because of alleged intimidation and harassment by militants who moved into the hospital July 14. They voted instead to work with members of the militant group to resolve the problems at Lincoln Hospital.

JACKSON, Miss., July 29 The Hinds County grand jury said today that law officers "had a right and were justified" in shooting into a Jackson State College girls' dormitory during a campus disorder last May.
With smarting eyes and raw throats, New Yorkers went about their business yesterday under a six-day-old blanket of stagnant smog.

A history professor at New York University and a former teaching aide there were arrested yesterday following their indictment on charges of threatening to destroy a computer installation if the university would not give them $100,000 to provide bail for a Black Panther here.
MEXICO CITY, July 29 (UPI) Mexico announced today that she had notified Cuba that commercial air traffic between the two countries would cease next year.

Dr. Max Reiss, who founded and directed the neuroendocrine research unit at the Willowbrook (S.I.) State School for the mentally retarded, died Monday of an embolism at Wolfeboro, N.H., while on vacation. He was 70 years old and lived at 350 Richmond Terrace, New Brighton, S.I.

Some 2,600 passengers on two liners docking at Hudson River piers yesterday were delayed about four hours while 135 United States Customs agents conducted an unannounced, intensive search for contraband narcotics.

CAIRO, July 29 A leading official of the Palestinian commando movement flew here today for urgent consultations on President Gamal Abdel Nasser's tentative moves toward a settlement with Israel and the suspension yesterday by the Cairo radio of broadcasts by the Palestinians.
QUANGTRI COMBAT BASE, South Vietnam, July 28 "We planted $17 worth of flowers out there and what have we got one damn zinnia!"
State and local agencies from New York and New Jersey endorsed proposals yesterday to raise the purity standards for waterways in the metropolitan area.
PRINCETON, N.J., July 29 Public confidence in President Nixon is at its highest level in five months, the Gallup Poll reported today.

GENEVA, July 29 A Japanese who was arrested two weeks ago on suspicion of having stolen manufacturing secrets of three prominent Swiss watch companies has been released on bond, a spokesman for the Justice and Police Ministry said in Berne today.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The current practice of restricting a woman's weight gain during pregnancy may be contributing to the nation's high infant mortality rate, a report from the National Research Council suggests.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) H. Neil Garson, secretary of the Interstate Commerce Commission, who has been accused by a Congressional subcommittee of altering check stubs, was suspended today by George M. Stafford, chairman of the commission.

The city's Human Resources Administrator ordered a local antipoverty agency yesterday to "take immediate action" in the case of a youth counselor who is accused of having drawn a 45-caliber revolver on four policemen Monday night while allegedly trying to crash a Central Park concert.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The Army will move two trainloads of small rockets filled with the lethal nerve gas GB through the South to be dumped into the Atlantic Ocean, Representative Cornelius Gallagher said today.

NEW DELHI, July 29 (AP) Prime Minister Indira Gandhi survived a no-confidence motion in Parliament today by 241 votes to 134 after angrily rejecting accusations that she was a dictator and had made India a satellite of the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy said today that his department strongly opposed any general searches of library records to find out who had read specific books. But he said it would allow its agents to investigate what books a specific suspect had checked out.

WASHINGTON July 29 The two Federal agencies responsible for stamping out illegal narcotics trafficking agreed today to stop fighting each other and to concentrate on their main enemy at home and abroad.

WASHINGTON, July 29 House and Senate conferees reached tentative agreement today on a final version of the post office reorganization bill, including a section that paves the way for an increase in most postal rates by next spring.
LONDON, July 29 (AP) Bowes Egan, a law lecturer and adviser to Bernadette Devlin, was charged in court today with having plotted a tear gas attack on the House of Commons last week.
OSWEGO, N.Y., July 29 (AP) Mrs. Louise Hosmer Culkin, widow of Representative Francis E. Culkin, died today in Oswego Hospital. She was 92 years old and had been an invalid several years.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) The Civil Aeronautics Board ruled today that current domestic air fares would remain in effect until Oct. 15 while new lawful rates are being established.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Representative Leonard Farbstein, Democrat of Manhattan, said today he would ask the Federal Communications Commission to investigate pressures from food advertisers against news coverage of consumer issues.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The chairmen of the House and Senate Banking Committees introduced legislation today to establish a National Development Bank that could provide financing for both business and state and local governments.

In strategy that will test the unity of the National Football League Players Association during the labor impasse, the club owners will open their training camps tonight at 6 o'clock to any experienced players who wish to report.
JERUSALEM, July 29 When he became immersed in the intricacies of Middle Eastern politics, former Secretary of State Dean Rusk used to say, "These governments are too weak to be wise."

OCEANPORT, N.J., July 29 (AP) Woodcrest's Encarnado moved from well off a rapid pace, set by Predominio and favored Top Bid, to win the $16,150 Midsummer Hurdles Handicap at Monmouth Park today. Atrevido was second and Predominio third.

In rising volume, the stocks on the American Stock Exchange moved up yesterday by 0.04 to 20.45, as measured by the exchange's index. Volume rose to 2,827,190 from 2,637,910 on Tuesday. Advances outnumbered declines, 424 to 344.
WASHINGTON, July 29 A Presidential commission's manyfaceted plan for a major overhaul of the Pentagon, announced yesterday, was greeted warily and with almost stony silence on Capitol Hill today.
The appointment of C.N. (Nick) Anderson, the president of the Cunard Line of North America, as managing director of H.E. Moss Co., Ltd., of London was announced yesterday.
Once, when Warner LeRoy went to buy seats for a Broadway show, the ticket seller glared at him. "Aren't you the owner of Maxwell's Plum?"

The Lefrak Organization, one of the world's largest builders, gained approval yesterday of a plan to construct a public housing project in Brooklyn, then sell it to the city's Housing Authority for rental to lowincome families.

El Museo del Barrio, the city's first museum of Puerto Rican culture, has no building, no collection, no guards. And right now, all its belongings are stashed in cardboard boxes, awaiting a move to another site from its present headquarters in P.S. 125 at 425 West 123d Street.
Each month, when the moon orbits closest to earth, its scarred and pitted crust bulges 20 to 30 inches, cracks and shifts and quakes for nearly an hour.

PRINCE RUPERT, British Columbia, July 29 (Canadian Press) a ferryboat, with 342 persons aboard, ran aground on West Kinahan Island early today and oil spilling from her ruptured tanks threatened to pollute the harbor of this north coastal British Columbia port.
TEL AVIV, July 29 (Reuters) Israeli jets attacked three Arab guerrilla bases in Jordan today and hit Egyptian military targets along the Suez Canal, a military spokesman said.

WOR-TV, Channel 9, will have a daily, half-hour, prime time newscast beginning this fall. The independent station, owned by R.K.O. General, has been the city's only outlet without an evening news program.
The Long Island Lighting Company was fined $1,000 yesterday for polluting Long Island Sound.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The Justice Department is investigating to determine who originated the rumor that the Nixon Administration was contemplating canceling the 1972 elections and repealing the Bill of Rights.
DES MOINES, Iowa, July 29 (AP) An Iowa Supreme Court justice issued an injunction yesterday barring a proposed rock festival at tiny Wadena in northeast Iowa.
The oil industry continued yesterday to churn out earnings news, but none of it was good.

WASHINGTON, July 29 Sargent Shriver, who helped lead the attack on poverty in the mid-1960's criticized the Nixon Administration today for failing to support voluntary efforts to combat poverty in this country

Every day may not be ladies' day at J. Walter Thompson, but yesterday must have been. Four of the gals were raised to the purple of the vice presidency, bringing the total number of female officers in the world's largest agency to 12.
MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., Thursday, July 30 The owner of the Powder Ridge Ski Area told thousands of youths here last night that the three-day rock festival advertised for this weekend could not be held.
WASHINGTON, July 29 The Treasury today presented holders of $5.6-billion of maturing securities with a three-part offering having interest rates a little lower than in the last big refunding.
SALEM, Ore., July 29 Gov. Tom McCall announced today that Oregon would file suit in the Supreme Court in a few days opposing the lower. ing of the voting age to 18.
MADRID, July 29 Madrid's subway system, which normally has 1.5 million passengers a day, half of the city's population, was shut down today by a strike of its 3,800 workers.

After a seven-hour inspection tour yesterday of the city's three shelters for homeless children, Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said he found many conditions "dreadful" and "inadequate" and added that the shelters were "seriously overcrowded." He promised to continue his investigation until the situation was ameliorated.
United Utilities, Inc., reported yesterday a decline of 8 per cent in first-half earnings. Paul H. Henson, president, attributed the drop to higher costs of interest, labor and materials.
"Black Journal," National Educational Television's monthly program about black Americans, announced yesterday that it would establish a permanent bureau in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia.

Morris A. Schapiro, the nation's leading dealer in bank securities and long a sharp critic of the New York Stock Exchange, went to court yesterday to force the Securities and Exchange Commission to divulge the contents of a longsecret S.E.C. staff report on trading by Big Board members off the floor of the exchange.

LOS ANGELES, July 29 Linda Kasabian, the chief state witness in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson, said today that the hippie cult leader himself led a second murder expedition the night after his fol lowers had killed five persons.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) A former vice chairman of the Penn Central Company hinted today at dissension in the executive suite but insisted it was mostly outside economic forces that caused the railroad to file for reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws.
Michael J. Maye, president of the Uniformed Firefighters Association, criticized the Penn Central Company yesterday for using its own personnel to combat fires on railroad property.
STOCKHOLM, July 29 (AP) Dane Korica of Yugoslavia scored a surprise victory over Frank Shorter and Ken Moore of the United States in the 5,000-meter run tonight.

WASHINGTON, June 29 The Senate settled down today to a prolonged military debate, with Senator Barry Goldwater charging that "left-wing political elements" were engaged in "an organized effort to downgrade and weaken the defense posture of this nation."
LONDON, July 29 Leaders of Britain's striking dock workers called off their nationwide strike today, after tying up 40 ports for two weeks.

BORDEAUX, France, July 27 Jacques Chaban-Delmas worked hard all last week running the affairs of France as Premier. Early Saturday he left Paris in a government executive aircraft, and then for more than nine hours whirled through this southwestern port city in his capacity as Mayor.

WASHINGTON, July 29 One of the most important facts of American political life, just eighteen months after the Nixon Administration took office, is that it is now the defender of the war in Vietnam while the Democratic party has all but officially swung into opposition to it.
WASHINGTON, July 29 Mortgage prices rose at this week's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association disclosed yesterday.
As the credit markets awaited the terms of the Treasury's $6.45-billion financing plan, most bond prices and interest rates showed little change yesterday, and trading activity slackened.
Pan American World Airways, Inc., has held merger discussions with "two or three" carriers, according to its president, Najeeb E. Halaby.
A prose version of the forthcoming film "The Master" by James Drought will be sold for a dollar in the lobbies of movie houses where it will be shown.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 29 (UPI) Cliff Richey, the topseeded American, fought off a challenge by Ray Ruffels of Australia today to advance in the men's singles of the $50,000 national clay court tennis tournament.
The head of Mayor Lindsay's commission to investigate possible police corruption said yesterday that District Attorneys were inhibited in their efforts to investigate the police.

An Army helicopter taking three seriously burned civilian employes of the United States Military Academy from West Point to the St. Albans Naval Hospital in Queens yesterday was forced by bad weather to land on Baker Field, the Columbia University football field at the tip of Manhattan.

Over the last two years, as the independent-media-buying services started to become a topic in the business with their promises of betterbuying-through-bargaining, an interesting onlooker has been Jerome Bess, ad man turned broadcaster turned ad man.

At a tumultuous public meeting last night that broke up in a general melee, the community school board of District 23 in Brooklyn, which includes the former Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration district, officially named Mrs. Nellie R. Duncan as district superintendent.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) George Meany president of the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations, urged Congress today to increase the minimum wage to $2 an hour from the present $1.60.
Bill Melton has gone to bat five consecutive times without striking out.

WASHINGTON, July 29 Most of the Democratic Representatives from New York have sought Arthur J. Goldberg's help in getting Representative Richard Max McCarthy back in the race for his House seat in Erie County.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, July 29 For the three years since the Arab-Israeli war of 1967 the Arab world has been able to achieve only a minimum of unity. Now, as a result of the acceptance by the United Arab Republic and Jordan of the United States proposal for a settlement of the Middle East

Ready-to-wear is rapidly replacing perfume as the most marketable by-product of the French couture. Even the couture houses admit that the number of women who are willing and able to spend the time and money for made-to-order clothes is diminishing. Picking up amusing clothes in a boutique has its own status and charm, even for women who don't flinch from spending as much for an elaborate dress as they do for a simple automobile.
BUFFALO, July 29 Miss Mary Ann Frauenheim and Dr. Mark Edward McGovern will be married here Sept. 19 in St. Benedict's Roman Catholic Church.

CHARLESTON, W.Va., July 29 Miss Margaret Rutherfoord Feild, who is studying for a master's degree in education at the University of Virginia, will be married to William Theodore Kresge Jr. of New York, a graduate of the University of Virginia School of Law.

It was easier to get a telephone installed in the metropolitan area in June than it has been for more than a year, but after the phone was installed it usually took longer to make a call, the Public Service Commission reported yesterday.

Although, these two books differ enormously in accomplishment, they begin with the same premise: that policemen lie. In "People vs. Blutcher," the lying has to do with shakedowns, false arrest and brutality. In "The Crime of Martin Sostre," the lying has to do with political persecution, the planting of evidence and brutality. That some policemen take bribes is a fact known to every reader of this newspaper.
YONKERS, July 29 Wanted! Modest apartment in southern Westchester County for harness horse driver from Delaware who thinks he can strike it rich here.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 29 The California State Supreme Court today affirmed an appeals court finding that Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther minister of defense, should have a new trial.

Some deceptive plays by the declarer are easily diagnosed by alert defenders. Others, such as the one played in the diagramed deal, have a good chance of success unless the opponents are quite expert.
NEW HAVEN, July 28 Eight black teen-agers were discussing the Black Panthers' trial being held just down the street from their classroom here on the humid Yale University campus today.
FORT DIX, N.J., July 29 (UPI) One soldier was killed and 13 were injured this afternoon when lightning struck a group of privates receiving basic training here.
MOSCOW, July 29 Chingiz Aitmatov, a popular writer, has aroused a literary controversy by having his latest story end with the suicide of its hero, a 7-year-old boy.
WILLIMANTIC, Conn., July 29 For the second time in three weeks thousands of fish have been found dead in the Shetucket River, the State Board of Fisheries and Game reported today.
Preparations are under way for the distribution of eight prize-winning, student-made short films chosen from more than 150 international entries in Esquire magazine's first College Film Festival.

A 20-year-old Brooklyn man was arrested last night at Kennedy International Airport by New York City and Port Authority police when he attempted to claim two steamer trunks filled, the police said, with 66 kilograms (140 pounds) of marijuana valued at $50,000.

HARTFORD, July 29 (UPI) A Superior Court jury returned a verdict of not guilty today in the trial of former city policeman, Anthony Lombardi, accused of manslaughter in the shooting of a 19-year-old youth he was chasing after an alleged traffic violation.

WASHINGTON, July 29 Well-placed informants reported today that Communist China took the initiative in asking an Italian manufacturer to use American engines and spare parts in a shipment of trucks for China.

LONDON, July 29 Anyone from the American theater who does not feel a man-sized stab of envy when faced with Britain's National Theater is too noble for this life. This organization, apparently opulent, self-evidently splendid, is a model to the English-speaking world, but a model that unfortunately only its rival English twin, the Royal Shakespeare Company, can match. If only Joe Papp and his New York Shakespearean colleagues had their advantages!
Carol Channing is returning to Broadway as the star of "Four on a Garden," a comedy by Abe Burrows, who also will direct.

NEW HAVEN, July 29 The jury in the trial of Lonnie McLucas listened today to a tape recording in which the defendant could be heard, softly but unmistakably, confessing to having fired a shot into Alex Rackley.
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 The threat of military intervention in Chilean politics, real or imaginary, has become a factor that could affect the decision on the next President.
Philip Morris, Inc., announced yesterday it had agreed to acquire all of the remaining 47 per cent of the shares outstanding of the Miller Brewing Company.

The Federal Home Loan Bank Board, which regulates the $167-billion savings and loan industry, proposed yesterday a general tightening of its rules covering conflicts of interest at the 4,400 associations under its supervision.
TEHERAN, Iran, Thursday, July 30, (Reuters) An earthquake early today shook the northeastern Iran province of Khurasan where more than 10,000 people died two years ago in a violent quake.

Lowell M. Birrell, a lawyer and former financier who once amassed a fortune, fled the country when he was being investigated for stock fraud and came back to face the charges in 1964, was sentenced yesterday to two years in jail.
BAYONNE, N.J., July 29 Russell Golding, a Bayonne fire captain, died yesterday while vacationing at Silver Lake. He was 51 years old and lived at 130 West 57th Street here.
LOS ANGELES, July 29 (UPI) A $2-million suit was filed in Federal court today against Charles Manson and four of his followers charging the wrongful death of Voityck Frykowski.

President Nixon's news conference today, President Thieu's radio-television address tomorrow and Ambassador Bruce's projected arrival in Paris Monday could open a new phase in the efforts to negotiate a political settlement of the Vietnam war. Mr. Thieu will clarify his proposals on a cease-fire in Vietnam, which presumably could be laid on the table in Paris next Thursday.

"Right now it's not raining," said Herbert Allen, immediately after the running of the $28,300 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct yesterday. Actually, it was coming down, but Allen's colt, the 4-year-old Distinctive, had just turned in a crackling performance in winning the six-furlong dash.

Earl Wild, dressed as if for a stroll along a resort boardwalk, took a brisk turn through Rachmaninoff's Rhapsody on a Theme of Paganini on Tuesday night in Central Park. The prematurely white-haired pianist, appearing as soloist with the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Sixten Ehrling, gave an efficient, highly fluent performance whose broad lines and sharp contrasts suited the outdoor, amplified setting.
LONDON, July 29 Britain formally recognized the republican Government of Yemen today.

The national master and theoretician Alex Kevitz, many-time champion of the Manhattan Chess Club and originator of the Kevitz Opening, outwitted master Louis Levy of Newark during a Reti Opening in the current masters' tournament at the club's quarters.

A memorial service for Gordon McIntire, an international distributor of encyclopedias, art books and visual aids, was held yesterday in Rome, where he lived for 18 years. He died of a heart attack earlier this week in New Delhi while on vacation. He was 59 years old.
BONN, July 29 Economics Minister Karl Schiller issued a stern warning today against proposed limitations by the United States on imports of textiles and shoes.
DELANO, Calif., July 29 Farm workers and table grape growers signed an agreement in this dusty rural town today that both sides said would bring a "new day" to American agriculture.

WASHINGTON, July 29 The heartening improvement in the wholesale price index in recent months was reversed in July as farm products and processed foods began to go up again, the Labor Department reported today.

Nantucket Island's second annual billfish (in this case, swordfish and blue and white marlin) tournament will be held Aug. 10 to 14, according to the sponsoring organization, the Nantucket Angler's Club.
CHICAGO, July 29 The National Football League Players Association accepted tonight the challenge of the club owners and indicated in a statement its 1,200 members were on strike.
The American Electric Power Company announced plans yesterday to raise about $100-million through the sale in late September of 4 million new common shares.
Donald Clement, a 29-yearold actor who had been appearing as Cowboy in "The Boys in the Band" off Broadway, died of electrocution Tuesday, in an accident in his apartment at 19 East 74th Street.
MOSCOW, July 29 (AP) The foreign ministers of the Soviet Union and West Germany met today for two and a half hours on treaty negotiations.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (UPI) From now on the Mafia, or Cosa Nostra, may very well be described as "an organized crime syndicate," Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today.

CHESTER, N.H., July 29 Dr. Faith Preston, founding president of White Pines College here, plans to be married to Winthrop Wadleigh, senior partner of the Manchester law firm of Wadleigh Starr, Peters, Dunn Kohls.
PARIS, July 29 (AP) Jewish community leaders here said today that 200 Jews remained in the United Arab Republic after the recent release from prison and transfer to France of 80 Jews.
BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 29 Dr. Otakar Machotka, professor of sociology at the State University of New York at Binghamton, died of cancer today at his home here. He was 70 years old.
SYRACUSE, July 29 (AP) A 20-year-old girl who worked as a cocktail waitress in a "fox" costume contends she was discharged after two months because the boss considered her too flat-chested.

ALBANY, July 29 Governor Rockefeller urged Mayor Lindsay, Gov. William T. Cahill of New Jersey and two public bodies in New York State today to settle powerline disputes quickly. Such disputes, he said, are "seriously delaying" Consolidated Edison's ability to bring new electric power into New York City.

An international panel of scientists, writers and philosophers will meet next month in Aspen, Colo., to ponder the impact that technology has upon culture and to recommend ways of helping improve man's environment.
CHICAGO, July 29 (UPI) The Chicago Cubs acquired Joe Pepitone on waivers today from the Houston Astros for $20,000.
LONDON, July 29 Sir John Barbirolli, the internationally renowned conductor, died in London today. He was 70 years old.
In what was described by one broker as "very, very active trading," soybean prices continued to slump yesterday, following their recent sharp declines.

GENEVA, July 29 The International Committee of the Red Cross said today that its representatives who visited the Con Son prison in South Vietnam failed to learn of the existence of the so-called tiger cages.
Showers on another 90-degree day came to the aid of New York City's beleaguered electric power supply yesterday as hot and humid weather elsewhere reduced supplies
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, July 29 Vietnamese Communist forces have driven Cambodian Government troops from Kirirom, the hilltop resort that has been the scene of fighting for three weeks.
ANAHEIM, Calif., July 29 The Yankees swept the threegame series from California tonight by defeating the Angels, 8-3, as Jack Aker finished up the sloppy game by pitching four scoreless innings.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 29 Ben Hogan visited New York today to attend an unveiling in his honor. Then the diminutive Texan returned to the Westchester Country Club for a last-minute tune-up before the start tomorrow of the $250,000 Westchester Classic.

When 21-year-old Randese Owen and her sister, Barbara, 20, decided to go into business last January with their mother's backing, they planned to sell hand-tailored suits from England for women and some accessories for men.
Prices on the New York Stock Exchange continued their push yesterday toward the 740 support level before backing off slightly in the afternoon.

What do the spots on a giraffe's neck, the wrinkles in the snout of a black rhinoceros, the shape of an elephant's ear and the human fingerprint have in common? They are all, in varying degrees of reliability, ways of distinguishing one member of a species from another.

The stock of Computer Sciences a company that, like many of its rivals, has had setbacks in the computer software and leasing business led the list of active stocks on the Big Board yesterday on massive volume sparked by a startling half-million share trade.

"Big Allis," the million-kilowatt Consolidated Edison generator whose breakdown was a major factor in the city's power crisis, is likely to be out of service until late fall instead of just through the summer, as had been predicted earlier.

WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) The Democratic national chairman, Lawrence F. O'Brien, told party reformers today that the way to win the youth vote was to strive for peace, focus on pressing domestic issues and avoid another convention like the one in 1968.
WASHINGTON, July 29 Suburban areas of Connecticut, Massachusetts and New Hampshire increased dramatically in population in the nineteen-sixties, while New England cities continued to decline.
The city, blocked by legal action from putting unit pricing into effect by administrative regulation, will try to do it by legislation.

DANANG, South Vietnam, July 29 (AP) A crowd of angry South Vietnamese surrounded a truck carrying six United States Marines and held it for almost 10 hours until American officials paid nearly $2,500 as compensation for a boy killed by the vehicle, reliable sources said today.

Schedule Today through Sunday. 18 holes daily. Sudden death follows end of Sunday play in event of tie for first place. Starting field of 158. Low 70 scorers and ties and those within 10 strokes of leader after second round continue for third and fourth rounds. Purse $250,000. First prize, $50,000.

NANTUCKET, Mass., July 29 George Lewis's Breeze lost a 16th place in Class Three today, when a protest filed by Arnold C. Gay's Babe, which placed 12th, was sustained at a hearing aboard the race committee yacht, Incredible.

TAMSUI, Taiwan, July 29 The Presbyterian Church in Taiwan has voted to withdraw from the World Council of Churches on the ground that the ecumenical organization has undermined the interests of Nationalist China by supporting efforts to conciliate Peking. The action was taken this week at the church's annual general assembly at this old port city on the northern coast.
WASHINGTON, July 29 (AP) Bus drivers asked today how they could enforce a ban on smoking in intercity buses if the Government imposed it. They are drivers, not policemen, they said.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 29 Dr. and Mrs. Louis Gillman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diane Joy Gillman, to James Charney. Mr. Charney, son of Dr. and Mrs. I. Richard Schwartz of Hewlett Harbor, L.I., changed his surname. The couple will be married next month.
SAN CLEMENTE Calif., July 29 President Nixon will confer with President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz of Mexico on Aug. 20 and 21, the White House announced today.
Although he would shudder at the description of himself as a "power broker," that is just what Tom Griffin is.
Powered by 175,000 kilowatts from Con Edison, the subway system rumbled through the afternoon at its normal pace yesterday.
Bobby Bonds hit two home runs two innings and two hours apart at Shea Stadium yesterday as the San Francisco Giants defeated the New York Mets on a muddy track, 4-2.

A seven-hour session that ended yesterday morning between Rick Barry's lawyers and the owner of the team he wants to leave, the Washington Caps, apparently wound up in defeat for the 26-yearold basketball star.

RUMSON, N.J., July 29 Mrs. Walter Cooperstein of Glen Oaks staged a strong finish today and increased her lead to 13 strokes after two rounds of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association 54-hole Jersey Shore medal play championship.

HAVERFORD, Pa. The Rev. Karl G. Kumm of Atlantic Highlands, N.J., a Haverford College alumnus, class of '25, raised his hand at the conclusion of the philosophy lecture in Stokes Hall and asked for clarification of a point made by the professor, Dr. Asoka Gangadean.

More than 300 residents of Ramapo filed suit in Federal Court here yesterday in an attempt to block the construction of a low-income housing project mainly for the elderly in their Rockland County town.

ROME, July 29 Pope Paul VI is planning to issue a special message to youth on the dangers of drug abuse, a subject on which President Nixon's special envoy to the Vatican, Henry Cabot Lodge, held long and detailed talks during his first official visit to Rome.

PHOENIX, Ariz., July 29 (AP) The General Motors Corporation says that its $50,000 test sale of pollution control kits for pre-1968 automobiles here was so poor that it will take a long look before attempting to market the kits nationally.
TOKYO, July 30 (Reuters) Hydron International, Inc., of the United States will set up a joint company in Japan next month with the Nippon Sheet Glass Company, the Japanese company announced today.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (Reuters) Net income of Federal Reserve member banks rose to a record $3.45-billion in 1969 from $2.96-billion in 1968, the Federal Reserve reported today.
The Board of Education is investigating reports that students in certain schools are being promoted without having achieved proper credit, simply to get them out of their particular school.

NORTH BENNINGTON, Vt., July 30 Stanley Edgar Hyman, literary critic, author and professor of literature at Bennington College, died last night apparently of a heart attack. He was 51 years old. His first wife, Shirley Jackson, the novelist and short story writer, died in 1965.

Although the city's new rent control law goes into effect tomorrow, city officials have advised tenants to ignore for the time Being any rent increases their landlords may ask of them under the statute.

On July 31, 1963, the world was startled to hear Peking denounce Moscow for initialing a nuclear test-ban treaty and thus having "betrayed the peoples of the Socialist camp" by a move most capitals regarded as an encouraging step toward sanity.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 30 Preferential treatment is part of the reward for stardom and respectable starting times invariably are allotted to the name performers in any golf tournament. The dawn patrol is usually manned by eager kids who don't mind getting their feet wet in the morning dew. But the entire field for the Westchester Classic got whacked in the ears by alarm clocks for early starting times, half today and the other half tomorrow.

When Dr. Ernest Leroy Boyer's family first learned he was being considered for the job of chancellor of the State University of New York, some of his four children had initial doubts about the position.
ALBANY, July 30 Governor Rockefeller said today that four of eight companies found to have been discharging mercury into state waters had ceased that form of pollution.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 30 Five professional golfers crowded into the openinground lead in the $250,000 Westchester Classic today. But the tourney lost Ben Hogan, who withdrew after a 78 with a painful knee, and Lee Trevino, a former United States Open champion, who failed to appear at the starting tee on time.
The help-wanted advertising index in June dropped to 175 per cent of the 1957-59 average, a decline of 5 points compared with May and 53 points under the level of advertising in June, 1969.
MELBOURNE, Australia, July 30 (AP) Sir Wilfrid Kent Hughes, one of Australia's most colorful members of Parliament and a leading sports figure, died today at his home. He was 75 years old.

The Rev. C. Herbert Oliver, chairman of the defunct governing board of the Ocean HillBrownsville demonstration school district, and 11 other persons were arrested last night and charged with trespassing in the board's administrative offices.
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after a day of narrow price changes in less active trading.

WASHINGTON, July 30 The Federal Communications Commission today renewed the license of a Florida radio station that had admitted over-billing its advertisers by nearly $42,000 between mid-1966 and the end of 1968.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) Dan A. Kimball, a World War I pilot with Jimmy Doolittle, who went on to become Secretary of the Navy in the Truman Administration, died today at the age of 74.

MILWAUKEE, July 30 Roy White packed his new silver and purple scarf but left his mother-in-law's chocolate cake behind him in the clubhouse. He wasn't sure whether the batting slump was going or staying.
The city continued yesterday the alert it called to deal with the air pollution crisis but, as levels of contamination dropped, it relaxed some restrictions on the use of incinerators.

WASHINGTON, July 30 John W.Gardner, chairman of the National Urban Coalition, is organizing a national citizens lobby whose goals will include reshaping government and party politics at all levels to make the system work.
HEWLETT NECK, L.I., July 30 Mr. and Mrs. William Floyd Haneman have announced that their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Prentiss Haneman, and Carl J. Stinchcomb of New York plan to marry in October.
WASHINGTON, July 30 The National Transporation Safety Board said today that it expected to complete early next year a study of safety problems of mass-transit systems.
Nineteen persons, all residents of a psyychiatric aftercare center for former mental patients, collapsed yesterday, as the result of what an official of the institution said might be group hysteria.

The most urgent task for Elliot L. Richardson in his new job as Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare is to pilot through Congress the Nixon Administration's complex welfare reform bill. When he became Secretary, the House had already acted favorably but the bill was in deep trouble in the Senate Finance Committee.

MOSCOW, July 30 The talks between West German and Soviet officials have reached a crucial stage, with the Bonn Government spokesman today saying that difficulties have arisen in the four-day negotiations for a treaty renouncing the use of force.
Miss Catherine Maria Soussloff, a sophomore at Bryn Mawr, and John Heywood Edison Sloane, a junior at Haverford, plan to marry next month.
As the field swung into the stretch in the fourth race at Aqueduct yesterday, a realist said, "Looks like the kid's got another winner."

ST. PAUL, July 30 (AP) Minnesota's Attorney General, Douglas Head, has filed suit against three banks in St. Cloud and Rochester, Minn., and Omaha, alleging that they are violating Minnesota's 8 per cent usury law in a credit card operation.

WASHINGTON, July 30 Although the wars in Asia and the Middle East are getting most of the public attention here, the managers of American foreign policy are casting wary glances at Moscow these days to monitor what they think may be an even more fateful diplomatic exercise the effort of the Soviet Union and West Germany to reach a new understanding about the future of Cen tral Europe.

William E. Humphreys, executive vice president of Lord Taylor, has been named president and chief executive officer of the Abercrombie Fitch Company effective Sept. 1. He succeeds Earle K. Angstadt Jr., who has resigned as chairman, president and chief executive officer of the sporting goods chain based in Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, July 30 A bipartisan coalition in the Senate agreed today upon strategy for a fight to prevent the Nixon Administration from expanding the Safeguard antimissile system.
Prices on the London stock exchange staged a solid advance across the board in moderate trading. The impetus for the advance came from the settelment of the British dock strike.
The Penn Central has agreed to notify the Fire Department immediately whenever there is trouble on the line that could produce a fire, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, July 30 The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit was asked today to reverse the convictions of all defendents in the Chicago conspiracy trial because of recently disclosed electronic surveillance of Bobby G. Seale.

GENEVA, July 30 Highlevel trade officials of the world's major industrial powers met here informally tonight as they prepared for two days of talks aimed at heading off a slide back into protectionism.
The American Stock Exchange announced yesterday a 70 per cent decline in net income coupled with a drop in over-all share volume of 36 per cent for the first half of 1970.

The box-office treasurer at "Oh Calcutta!", now playing at the Eden Theater, 187 Second Avenue, was ordered suspended for 11 months yesterday following charges of having exacted "ice" or payments over the listed price for tickets to the Off Broadway hit.

Paul Horgan, a shy, scholarly author whose reminiscences about the Southwest have won him many literary honors but relatively few dollars, stands to realize at least $250,000 with his latest novel. This will be a welcome gift for Mr. Horgan, who celebrates his 67th birthday tomorrow.
MADRID, July 30 The subways resumed operation here this morning after the system's 3,800 workers returned to their jobs rather than face being drafted into the army.
LOS ANGELES, July 30 (Reuters) A temperamental microphone caused a delay tonight in the start of President Nixon's nationally televised news conference.

The confidence of students and blacks in the impartiality of the law cannot have been increased by the latest denial of justice in Mississippi. A county grand jury investigating the killing of two Negro youths at Jackson State College last May by local police officers and state highway patrolmen has concluded that the officers "had a right and were justified."

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended Dean Ruffell Burwell, the principal stockholder of the Meyerson Company and a director of Winfield Underwriters, Inc., both of San Francisco, from the securities business for nine months. Harry Meyerson was suspended for 60 days.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) Samuel Clark Waugh, former head of the Export-Import Bank and an official of the State Department, died early today after a short illness. He was 80 years old.

The Rev. Dr. Charles D. Trexler, who served as an Army chaplain in both World Wars, died Tuesday in Physicians Hospital, Jackson Heights, Queens. He was 86 years old and lived at 35-20 77th Street, Jackson Heights.

The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it was negotiating for a two-year line of credit of "up to $100million" in Eurodollars (dollars on deposit abroad), to be provided by an international syndicate of banks headed by Manufacturers Hanover Ltd., in London, the merchant banking subsidiary of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, New York.

Despite another day of heat and humidity, New Yorkers reduced their demands for electricity yesterday and the Consolidated Edison Company, which has been trying to meet power demands despite the loss of two major generators, praised the "wonderful cooperation."
Monetary expansion proceeded at a moderate pace the last few weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.

ROME, July 30 The Swiss priest and theologian, Hans Kung, one of the most outspoken liberal thinkers in the Roman Catholic Church, declared today that new rules meant to facilitate mixed marriages between Catholics and non-Catholics were actually evasive and backward.
The city reported a $44-million loss in stock transfer tax receipts yesterday in the Finance Administration's final report for 1969-70.
In a Bronx office, a secretary and her employer discussed the difference between "smart" and "shrewd."

The United States peace initiative has posed a severe challenge to leadership on both sides of the ArabIsraeli conflict, as was to be expected. It is always easier to rally people with emotional rhetoric for military confrontation than to lead them with reason to political accommodation, especially in a region with the bitter historical memories and deep-rooted suspicions that prevail in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) The East Room of the White House, where the Presidential family's formal social events are held, has been repainted for the first time since 1965.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) A group of Senators made an effort today to stir national indignation over treatment of United States prisoners of war, whom they termed the "forgotten men", of the Vietnam war.
The new 7 per cent notes offered by the Treasury in its current $9.2-billion financing operation quickly rose in price as they started to trade yesterday.

MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., Friday, July 31 Roads leading to the Powder Ridge ski area were clogged last night and early today with young people making their way on foot to the 300-acre resort where a rock festival had been scheduled to start today.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 30 Tim McCann, a defensive tackle, was the only holdover to accept the New York Giants' invitation to attend training camp today. The other Giant regulars will meet tomorrow to decide whether they should heed the strike call of the National Football League Players Association.
State Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved yesterday to bar the Port Authority from allegedly discharging "enormous quantities of jet airplane fuel and oil" into Jamaica Bay at Kennedy Airport.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 30 None of the 41 experienced players on the New York Jets' roster reported today, in accordance with the National Football League Players Association's strike. But Weeb Ewbank disclosed that an unidentified member of his team is on the way.

Parke, Davis, Co. the Detroit-based pharmaceutical manufacturer, in a matter of moments late yesterday afternoon announced the rejection of one would-be suitor and an agreement in principle to combine forces with another.
Jonel Perlea, a Rumanianborn conductor who taught at the Manhattan School of Music for 18 years died Wednesday of cancer at his home here. He was 69 years old.
WELLINGTON, New Zealand, July 30 New Zealand's international airline, Air New Zealand, Ltd., intends to buy at least three DC-10 longrange jets for delivery in 1973 and 1974.

George Szell, conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra since 1946, died last night in Hanna House of University Hospital in Cleveland, where he had been under treatment since June 16, He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 30 A group of 71 Senators today publicly endorsed a firm Administration position on the Middle East, asserting that the Soviet Union should be warned of the dangers of provoking the United States.
What once seemed to be one of the most reliable clocks in the universe has been acting up again.

Labor Secretary James D. Hodgson, backed up by six other Government officials, yesterday outlined for an audience of businessmen steps being taken by the Administration to improve the operation of the Federal equal employment opportunity programs.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 Charles M. Manson and three of his followers planned still another murder the night two Los Angeles residents were killed, but the hippies were thwarted at the last minute, a key prosecution witness testified today.

The Union Pacific Corporation, which owns 93 per cent of the Union Pacific Railroad Company, reported yesterday second-quarter consolidated net income of $18,126,000, equal to 86 cents a share, virtually unchanged from last year.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) In the midst of a controversy over the nutritional value of breakfast cereals, the Government is moving ahead with a proposed regulation that would remove from the market the cereals a nutrition crusader called the best available.
OCEANPORT, N.J., July 30 Gen. Ulysses S. Grant tore up his program in disgust today muttering, "I had Tenny."

"Nonsense," "out of date," "a male put-on." With these and other rebuttals, endocrinologists, psychiatrists and practitioners of industrial medicine contradicted a physician's recent assertions that "physical and psychological inhibitants," particularly the "raging hormonal influences" of the menstrual cycle and menopause, limit women's potential in the executive spheres of business and politics.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Friday, July 31 (Reuters) A civilian was shot to death during street battles between Roman Catholic rioters and British troops early today.
The Miller Brewing Company has come up with a nice and fairly inexpensive direct-mail advertising campaign. And they have few fears that it will be copied by a competitor.

Most of the 100-man complement of firemen in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn called in sick last night, it was reported early today, in protest against the suspension of three of their number Wednesday night for their refusal to ride on unprotected fire trucks that had been assaulted by bricks and bottles.

NEW HAVEN, July 30 A detective who interrogated Lonnie McLucas three weeks after the Alex Rackley slaying testified today at Mr. McLucas's trial that the defendant was ready then to appear before a Senate committee that was investigating the Black Panther party.

Governor Rockefeller's office said yesterday that the New York State Council on the Arts had authorized an additional $50,000 to the New York Shakespeare Festvial. The sum is in addition to the $100,000 committed to the festival by the Council last month.
TEHERAN, Iran, July 30 (AP) More than 100 bodies have been pulled from the ruins after scores of villages in northeast Iran were struck early today by a powerful earthquake.
PARIS, July 30 Philip C. Habib ended his tenure as the ranking American at the Vietnam peace talks by telling the enemy today the negotiations "can be successful" if not misused for propaganda.
TRENTON, July 30 The New Jersey Insurance Department announced today that the bad drivers and others in the so-called "assigned-risk pool" could expect additional auto insurance coverage by Oct. 1.
AREA A What John Falkiewicz of Surf City, N.J., calls "the best fishing in quite a few years in Barnegat Bay" has netted pleasing catches of kingfish, blues, flounder and a few weakfish.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., July 30 A case of alleged murder on an Arctic ice island, with possibly international legal complications, unfolded here late this afternoon as a Mexican-born American citizen was charged with the crime.

CHICAGO, July 30 In announcing here today that the pro football players were "officially" on strike, John Mackey said firmly and defiantly that he did not expect any of the players to report to the team training camps.
GALLUP, N.M. Business has never been better and the future has never been bleaker for traditional Indian handicrafts.

TEL AVIV, July 30 The second-largest group in Israel's Government voted today to quit the Cabinet if the Cabinet chooses even limited acceptance of the United States peace plan for the Middle East. BEIRUT, Lebanon,July 30 Two minor Arab groups broke the unity of the Palestinians today by rejecting criticism of President Gamal Abdel Nasser and asserting that the Egyptian President's acceptance of the United States plan for Middle East peace was a clever move.
Steven Ross came to the Parke-Bernet Galleries on East 84th Street yesterday hoping "to pick up a used computer cheap, something under $10."
NOROTON, Conn., July 30 The Seawanhaka Corinthian Yacht Club crew from Oyster Bay, L.I., captained by Terry Neff, won the 47th annual junior sailing championship of Long Island Sound today.
Is it posible that Robert W. Haack went from the major leagues to the minors when he gave up the presidency of the National Association of Securities Dealers to head the New York Stock Exchange?

In the second-floor fur-auction room of the New York Auction Company on West 26th Street, a shaft of sunlight focused on light dust hovering on row after row of empty seats. Not too many years ago, those seats were occupied by frantic bidders seeking to acquire the best mink or other furs for robes for Pope John or for coats for the Duchess of Windsor and Mrs. Jacqueline Kennedy.
A 72-foot iron-hulled steam tug built in 1899 in Sorel, Quebec, joined the historic fleet at the South Street Seaport Museum yesterday.

BANGKOK, Thailand, July 30 Thailand is undergoing an intensive re-examination of her foreign policy as a result of President Nixon's policy of lowering the American profile in Asia. The most acute expression of Thailand's reappraisal is the debate that has been going on here over whether Thailand should send ground troops to Cambodia.
CHICAGO, July 30 Negotiable bonds worth $6,050,000 disappeared last March, presumably while being transported from New York City to Chicago, and no trace of them has been found.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 30 If Ben Hogan was disgruntled over being treated like a Sunday golfer on a municipal course, his displeasure was as nothing compared to the unhappiness of thousands of spectators who missed much of his round in the opening of the Westchester Golf Classic.
MUTTONTOWN, L.I., July 30 Miss Susan Robin Shapiro and Steven Douglas Levkoff were married tonight at the Muttontown Country Club by Rabbi Jerome Davidson, who was assisted by Cantor Robert Harmon.
Life in New York City this week seems almost too much for man to bear.

The Jones and Laughlin Steel Corporation, which had sustained a loss and omitted the dividend on its common stock in the first three months of 1970, reported yesterday in Pittsburgh that it had earned a small profit less than a cent a share in the second quarter.

MADRID, July 30--The United States has agreed to make 36 used F-4 Phantom jet fighter-bombers available to Spain as part payment for a new five-year agreement allowing American forces to use three bases here.

WASHINGTON, July 30 President Nixon tonight sought to assure Israel that she can accept the United States proposal for a limited cease-fire in the Middle East "without fear that by entering negotiations her position may be compromised or jeopardized in that period."

A Federal grand jury indicted three former special agents of the Internal Revenue Service yesterday, bringing to 10 the number here who have been charged with bribery in a two-year investigation called Project S.

BRASILIA The sun takes a long time to set in the immense, clear sky. When it does, it leaves Brasilia pretty much alone except for the shirring and clicking of insects in the short, twisted trees and in the cracks in the dry earth.

PARIS, July 30 Mrs. Marianne O'Brien Reynolds, the former wife of Richard J. Reynolds, the tobacco heir, was wed to Lee Meyers, a public relations executive, in a private ceremony in Monte Carlo, Monaco, today.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) -House Banking Committee investigators have uncovered evidence pointing to "a national scandal of the most sordid type" in the administration of programs to help low income persons buy homes, the committee chairman said today.

There are few auditoriums of unselfconscious splendor left in New York, and Radio City Music Hall is unique, not only among movie theaters but among all other performing-arts houses. Currently, in its lush embrace, Carmen Rojas and Paco Ruiz have joined their Flamenco troupe to the resident ballet company and the Rockettes in a Latin stage show.
MOSCOW, July 30 The Communist party newspaper Pravda today denounced Arab critics of the Egyptian decision to accept the latest American initiative for a Middle East settlement.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., July 30 (AP) Jean Paul Bradshaw, Springfield lawyer, once a Republican candidate for governor, died today at St. John's Hospital in Springfield. He was 64 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 30 (AP) The controversial Alaska oil pipeline project is undergoing a management shake-up in an effort to end a series of legal entanglements and bureaucratic delays that have set it back indefinitely.

MILLBURN, N.J., July 30 Francis A. Tetaz, former national foils champion and president of the Tetaz Jewelry Company in Newark for 50 years, died yesterday at his home. He was 89 years old and lived at 745 Ridgewood Road. He retired in 1965.
OTTAWA, July 30 (Reuters) The Canadian Government has "no plans at the moment" to return the dollar to a fixed exchange rate, a Finance 'Ministry spokesman said today.

The power shortages bedeviling this city in recent days provide a reminder that adequate electricity for all communities and the nation's needs can no longer be taken for granted. Moreover, there is every reason to suppose that present problems will grow increasingly acute over the passing years as the population rises and as ever more difficult compromises must be sought between growing power demands and the environmental damage caused by hydrocarbon and nuclear fuels.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 30 President Nguyen Van Thieu said tonight that a "residual force" of about 50,000 American troops would be required in South Vietnam after 1973 to "guarantee the peace."
Stefan Andres, a German novelist and poet, died in Rome on June 29 of complications following surgery. He was 64 years old and had been living in Rome since 1961.

Neither Senator Charles L. Goodell nor Representative Richard L. Ottinger, his Democratic opponent, even stepped into the ring yesterday, but their campaign managers sparred furiously for advantage on the eve of an upcoming endorsement.

World sugar prices slumped yesterday in very heavy volume after a report issued by F.O. Licht, the European statistical service. The report, construed by traders as bearish, sharply increased estimates of world sugar supplies above a previous forecast made in April.

Twenty young painters and sculptors of "exceptional talent" have been nominated-by the National Council on the Arts to receive fellowships of $7,500 each. Drawn from every, region in the country, they constitute the first group of artists to receive individual grants under the direction of Nancy Hanks, who became council chairman in September.

A consultant has been hired to do a study of the Sanitation Department although there is a city office specifically charged with doing the same sort of study, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 30 Peter Zinman's Wee Ken and Michele McEvoy's Amabette won the two junior working hunter championships by forging to the front in the final classes today at the Orange County horse show.
WASHINGTON, July 30 The Treasury Department formally submitted to Congress today its long-planned legislation to tax lead additives in gasoline and to speed the collection of estate and gift taxes.
WASHINGTON, July 30 The Army disclosed today that seven Southern states would be crossed when two trainloads of deadly nerve gas are transported to the sea for disposal next month.
Three hundred people, including many newspaper associates, attended a funeral service yesterday for Mrs. Helen Rodgers Reid, former publisher of The New York Herald Tribune.
Many qualified observers think that Benito Garozzo of Rome is the world's greatest bridge player, and nobody would deny him a place among the top three.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges this week issued reports on changes in stock ownership of major shareholders, directors and officers of listed companies. The reports included the following:

LONDON, July 30 Alcoholism among Britain's teen-agers is developing into a medical and social problem that surpasses narcotics addiction, a detailed medical report on alcoholism has warned the British public.

The trustee of the Central Railroad of New Jersey told the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday that the carrier now faced the possibility "that it will have to cease operations in December, possibly before that date," unless it received financial assistance.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he intended to establish a separate Department of Early Childhood Services within the Human Resources Administration to administer all city programs for young children.
Ladies and gentlemen, we've had a slight delay because the audio in the room I hope that all of you will ask your questions quite loudly.

The former executive director of the Claremont Neighborhood Centers in the Bronx was indicted yesterday on 67 charges of grand larceny and forgery in connection with the alleged embezzlement of $46,000 from the center over the last year.
INDIANAPOLIS, July 30 (AP) The first and third seeded foreign men were eliminated from the national clay courts tourney in today's third-round singles.
HARRISON, N.Y., July 30 The Westchester Golf Classic has raised $911,000 in three years for the benefit of six hospitals in Westchester County.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., July 30 (AP) Claud Allister, an actor with a long career in this country and in his native England, died here Sunday in a hospital after a long illness. He was 76 years old.

Dr. Ernest L. Boyer, a 42year-old educational administrator and expert on speech and hearing disorders, was appointed yesterday as the new chancellor of the State University of New York, the largest such system in the country.

The Philadelphia Electric Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday gains in operating revenue and net income for the first half and 12 months ended June 30. The report placed total operating revenues at $250,455,000 for the first half, up from $217,202,000 a year before. Net income rose to $35,917,000, or $1.02 a share, from the $34,178,000, or $1.08 a share on fewer shares, reported for the six months ended June 30, 1969.
WASHINGTON, July 30 The exchange of weapons for foreign bases is considered an unusual practice, a Pentagon spokesman said, although he would not confirm the transfer of F-4 phantom jets to Spain.
PARIS, July 30 (AP) The Metro has started giving free rides to save money.

Miss Leigh Catlin, a senior nursing student at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston, was married here yesterday afternoon to Wayne G. Quasha, a 1970 Harvard graduate who will enter the Business School there in the fall.
DETROIT, July 30. (AP) The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it was recalling more than 10,000 Dodge, trucks for inspection and repair if necessary of possible brake defects.

EAST HAMPTON L.I., July 30 The "Three Philip Roth Stories," which the Yale Repertory Company has chosen to dramatize as the current chapter in its summer season of Story Theater at the John Drew Theater, are firmly entrenched in their Jewish milieu. To remind us that the plays are about Jews in America, the stage is set with one backdrop: a huge American flag with a Star of David in the center.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 30 (AP) The police said today they were considering obtaining search warrants for strongholds where they believe persons who fired at policemen last night might have hidden weapons.
Steve Hargan missed a nohitter by only four outs last night, and one would expect the Cleveland pitcher to be upset that he didn't get it.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 30 Dick Siderowf, a 33year-old stockbroker from Westport, Conn., took aim toward a third successive Metropolitan Golf Association Amateur championship today despite a bad start and a heavy rainstorm that soaked the Upper Montclair Country Club course.

A group of Italian-Americans picketed The New York Times's West Side Plant in the Lincoln Center area of Manhattan for five and a half-hours yesterday morning, protesting the use of Italian "labels" for a section of organized crime.

FREEPORT, L.I., July 30 Rouvime Poliakoff, a former professor of engineering and retired vice president of the Seamless Products Company in New York, died today at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx. He was 90 years old and lived at 15 Wilshire Court.
The muggy, noxious air hovering over New York City has rekindled concern about the disease-producing capacity of the many chemicals that man has introduced into his environment.

WASHINGTON, July 30 The Federal Power Commission announced today its intention to review and probably revoke the price ceiling that has been in effect for a year and a half on natural gas produced in southern Louisiana. About three-quarters of all the natural gas that is used in New York State and City comes from this area.
Manuel F. Rothberg has been elected president and chief exexcutive officer of Beck Industries, Inc., a diversified retailing company.

TEL AVIV, July 30 Israel reported today that four Egyptian MIG-21 fighter planes were shot down in dogfights this afternoon when they tried to intercept Israeli jets on a bombing mission in the Suez Canal area.
UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 30 Miss Anne Patrice La Bonte and Jacque Alan Neff will be married Aug. 21 in Bay Head.

The Association of National Advertisers, whose member companies place an estimated three-quarters of the country's national advertising, has disclosed the formation of a new committee whose deliberations could have far-reaching effects on the agency side of the business.

HADLEY'S HARBOR, Mass., July 30 When the New York Yacht Club crews reached the tide-torn waters between here and Wood's Hole on a run from Nantucket and the committee had completed its mathematics, this was found to be a fine day for racing form. The yachts that had established themselves as favorites by successes in two earlier events remained at or near the top.
One unfortunate occurrence connected with the rise of jazz rock is the tendency of performing groups to be cast in the mold of the successful Blood, Sweat and Tears.
President Nixon was in San Clemente at the Western White House, where he appointed Rolf Eliassen as a member of the General Advisory Committee to the Atomic Energy Commission.
CAIRO, July 30 The ordeals of war with Israel may not yet be over for the Egyptians, but already the gloom of last winter's blackout has disappeared from downtown Cairo.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, July 31 (AP) The United States command announced yesterday that 77 Americans were killed in action in South Vietnam in the week ended Saturday, 11 more than the week before. However, it said the number of American combat dead in the last four weeks, 276, was the lowest in four years.

The world's biggest icebreaker, the key performer in the pioneering expedition last summer through the Arctic waters of the Northwest Passage, is returning to its relatively humdrum career as a plodding supertanker.

LOS ANGELES, July 30 In an indirect criticism of the recent Heard report on campus unrest, President Nixon said tonight that it was unfair to put the entire blame for student disorders on the national Government.

George Szell on the podium exuded confidence, power and mastery. No professional musician ever disputed his sheer mastery of the craft of conducting. There were those who called him arrogant, and there were others who accused his interpretations of being somewhat pedantic.
There are more than 120 shopping days left before Christmas, but for anyone who wants to do some early reading about Santa Claus the place to go is to Columbia University.

CLEVELAND, July 30--The identities of four groups and three men who had been classed as "enemies" of law enforcement" by Benjamin O. Davis Jr. when he resigned Monday as Cleveland's safety director have been disclosed by Mayor Carl B. Stokes.
LISBON, July 30 Portugal's austere former dictator, Dr. Antonio de Oliveira Salazar, was buried today in a simple country cemetery near Santa Comba Dao, where he was born 81 years ago.

A benefit art exhibition including works of water-color, drybrush and tempera by Charles Colombo and David Hanna opens at the Southampton, L.I., Art Gallery tonight. The two-week run, ending Aug. 14, will raise money for the art scholarship fund of the Nyack Preparatory School in Southampton.

While Casey Stengel, their indefatigable manager emeritus, was merrily celebrating his 80th birthday yesterday in Glendale, Calif., the New York Mets less heroic types after completing 100 of the 162 games of their current season enjoyed a day of rest.
"Mad King George" is one of the butts of history, so little admired or liked that even his lunacy hasn't attracted much sympathy. Now two London psychiatrists,...
WASHINGTON, July 30 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume in the year. earlier week.

PATERSON, N.J. July 30 Joseph Matzner, publisher of the Daily newspaper Wayne Today; was sentenced today to two days in jail on a contempt of court judgment based on a July 19 editorial in his paper. The sentence was stayed pending appeal.

WASHINGTON, July 30 A study conducted in several communities across the country indicates that 90 per cent of the three to five-year-olds in families with annual incomes of $5000 or less watch the educational television program "Sesame Street," according to Joan Ganz Cooney, president of the Children's Television Workshop.
The bodies of three young men were found in the charred wreckage of an automobile early yesterday morning in South Ozone Park, Queens. Each had been shot in the head.
The owners of the 26 teams in the National Football League opened their training camps to their striking players at 6 o'clock last night, but few of the 1,200 professionals broke ranks to attend.

WASHINGTON, July 30 Members of a House subcommittee investigating the operations of the Smithsonian Institution today criticized plans for the construction and operation of the Joseph H. Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden. Several suggested that Congress take a second look at the design of the garden.
LONDON, July 30 (AP) The Rolling Stones parted company today with the group's American manager, Allen Klein, who also manages the Beatles.
WASHINGTON, July 30 (UPI) Attorney General John N. Mitchell and Senator Edward M. Kennedy disagreed politely today over whether the crime rate was rising or declining under the Nixon Administration.

A lieutenant described by the Manhattan District Attorney's office as the first policeman here to admit to a grand jury that he had taken bribes was arrested yesterday after his indictment for perjury and criminal contempt.

HONG KONG, July 30 Communist China today announced the release of George Watt, a 41-year-old British engineer accused of spying and detained in Lanchow since September, 1967. A report by Hsinhua, the Chinese press agency, said he would be deported.
The fourth of 13 black Panthers facing trial here on bomb conspiracy charges was released on $50,000 bond yesterday.

Alda's, 332 East 86th Street, 288-6335. If there is a tremendous sameness about 99 per cent of all the Italian menus in Manhattan, the fault lies to a large part with the public. Americans, by and large, comfort themselves with spaghetti with meat sauce, meat balls or tomato sauce, veal Parmigiana, chicken cacciatore and nothing more adventurous gener ally than fettucini all'Alfredo.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange inched upward yesterday as volume slipped. The exchange's index closed at 20.48, up 0.03 for the day.
Turn-of-the-century American pottery and porcelain are proving ever more attractive to a growing group of antiques collectors.
"I haven't seen more than eight tapewatchers in here at one time in more than a year, or ever since the market started its decline."

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31 President Nguyen Van Thieu declared tonight that South Vietnam's conditions for peace were unchanged and ruled out any coalition government with the Communists except one that might result from free, internationally supervised elections.

The Silent Majority Mobilization Committee, which describes itself as a nonpartisan middle-of-the-road organization, added Attorney Louis J. Lefkowitz yesterday to the list of candidates it is supporting for statewide office.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31 Just when it appeared that rain and fog would stamp out the New York Yacht Club's cruise from Hadley's Harbor, Mass., to Newport this morning, the sun emerged to allow 77 yachts to complete the 29-mile trip.
The stark sight of oil drilling rigs etched above oceans and bays around the world may soon be a picture from the past.
"And so, for the last time, good luck and good night, Chet,"
Census takers in the city are encountering serious difficulties in poverty areas, and the count is lagging far behind other sections.

Four hours after bench warrants were issued for their arrest, members of the defunct governing board of the Ocean Hill-Brownsville demonstration school district returned yesterday to a Brooklyn courtroom that they had quit in what the judge called a contemptuous act.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (UPI) A Presidential emergency board said today that it would submit next week its recommendations for settling the 11-year dispute over the use of firemen on diesel engines.

MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., July 31 A popular rock balladeer and two professional bands performed at the Powder Ridge ski area last night, but a state's attorney said it was "not quite clear" whether they had violated a court order prohibiting a rock festival here this weekend.

The American Stock Exchange index of prices inched ahead yesterday to close at 20.50 up 0.02 in a day that was marked by volume of 2,186,490 shares. This compared with trading of 1,916,405 shares on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, July 31 Overriding Administration protests, the House voted today to give President Nixon stand-by authority to impose wage, price and rent controls.

LONDON, July 31 (UPI) Buckingham Palace said today that British magazine dealers had decided to withhold distribution of the current Ladies' Home Journal, in which an article suggests that the marriage of Princess Margaret and the Earl of Snowdon is an unhappy one.

The San Francisco-based Bank of America, the nation's largest bank, plans to open an international banking subsidiary in Chicago. If the Federal Reserve Board approves the proposal, it would mark the first time that an American bank from outside Illinois has set up shop in the rich industrial heartland that surrounds the Windy City.
The Continental Can Company announced yesterday a price increase averaging $10 a ton on all grades of combination boxboard, effective Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, July 31 In their effort to counter speculation that the allies are preparing to make new concessions in the Vietnam talks, both President Nixon and President Nguyen Van Thieu of South Vietnam have indicated in the last 24 hours how little they expect from the next phase of...

WASHINGTON, July 31 A group of liberal Democratic members of the House urged President Nixon today to counter foreign actions in the trade field that "violate our international trading rights" in order to head off protectionist trade legislation.

AMMAN, Jordan, July 31 Yasir Arafat, the leader of Al Fatah and the Central Committee of the Palestinian commando movement, told a cheering crowd of 25,000 people here today that the movement was dedicated to the liberation of all of Palestine, to the rejection of the United States peace plan and to all other compromise solutions with Israel.
VALHALLA, N.Y., July 31 "The campaign is really not going to get started until after Labor Day," Governor Rockefeller told a reporter after landing at the Orange County Airport yesterday afternoon.
American Export Isbrandtsen Lines has named Joseph G. Barkan as president. He will succeed Manuel Diaz, who is relinquishing the post.

After some rather stormy negotiations with several diamond dealers and one brief skirmish in Federal District Court, the Government has completed the first major sale of industrial diamonds from its strategic stockpile in more than eight years.
Directors of Computer Applications, Inc., and Volt Information Sciences, Inc., agreed in principle yesterday to a merger of the two companies.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) Preliminary tests show that substantial amounts of lead and arsenic are being poured into Louisiana's waterways, according to Federal water quality officials.

President Medici has finally condemned Brazil's "death squads" and promised to bring them to swift, severe justice. It was the first time the military regime had even conceded the existence of the vigilante groups, believed to consist mostly of off-duty policemen, who have been accused of murdering 500 to 1,000 persons in the last six years.

The Tidal Handicap, with a four-horse entry representing the Cragwood Stable listed as the overwhelming 3-5 favorite, will feature the getaway day card at Aqueduct today. From Monday through Aug. 29, the thoroughbred sport will shift upstate to Saratoga.
WASHINGTON, July 31 Manufacturers' inventories declined $150-million in June, returning to the April level, the Commerce Department reported today.
