WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The Pentagon says it is confident that its plan to transport deadly nerve gas hundreds of miles by rail and sink it at sea next month is safe, but it plans to stockpile a life-saying antidote at hospitals along the ways just in case.

TEL AVIV, July 31 (Reuters) Israeli jets today attacked Jordanian Army targets in northern Jordan in retaliation for guerrilla shelling of the Tel Katzir and Shaar Hagolan sectors of Israel, a military spokesman reported.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 31 President Nixon today hailed Israel's acceptance of the United States proposal for a 90-day cease-fire in the Middle East, but he warned that no one should "underestimate the difficulties that lie ahead."

SANTA ROSA, N.M., July 31 (UPI) Louis E. Lomax, a nationally known black writer who was working on a threevolume history of the Negro, died in an automobile crash, the state police said today. He was 47 years old and lived in Baldwin Harbor, L.I.

MUSCAT, July 31 The new ruler of Muscat and Oman declared today that he was willing to cooperate with other rulers of the Persian Gulf area in forming the proposed Federation of Gulf Emirates, which would consist of nine sheikdoms.

All the victories in this book of short stories and there are some are small ones. People do cope, they do come through. They patch up a family crisis, reconcile a child to the remarriage of her mother, secure the husband and security they desire, accept the fact that they are their father's sons.
TATESHINA, Japan, July 31 (UPI) The President of Japan's Toyota Motor Company has had a $445,000 shrine constructed for the repose of the souls of people killed in Toyota cars.

MOSCOW, July 31 West German sources today revealed details of Foreign Minister Walter Scheel's tactics in seeking Soviet approval of a provision supporting the principle of a unified Germany in the treaty now being negotiated here.
WASHINGTON, July 31 A chemistry research fellow at Harvard University was granted a patent this week for compounds that are said to provide the anti-inflammatory...
LONDON, July 31 Peter Thomas, considered a moderate, was appointed chairman of the Conservative party today by Prime Minister Health.

The Accounting Principles Board, wracked by internal dissension and heavy pressure from the business community, formally adopted yesterday a compromise set of rules to govern corporate merger accounting.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, July 31 The chief United States adviser to the Uruguayan police force and the Brazilian consul were kidnapped by Marxist guerrillas here today. Two other American officials were injured in an unsuccessful kidnapping attempt.
LOS ANGELES, July 31 The key prosecution witness in the murder trial of Charles M. Mansion said today that she once regarded the bearded hippie leader as a "messiah" and as "another Jesus Christ."
CHICAGO, July 31 Judge Julius J. Hoffman of Federal District Court accepted in a sealed envelope today the Government logs of electronic eavesdropping on Bobby G. Seale, Black Panther party chairman.

The Justice Department has turned down the sale of the Budd Company's railroad division to the General Electric Company, and G.E. says it plans to set up production of electric rapid-transit cars on its own.

JACKSON, Miss., July 31 (UPI) Mayor Russell C. Davis said tonight that criticism by a grand jury of his action, during the violence at Jackson State College, in which two Negro Youths were killed, was an "unwarranted personal attack" encouraged by persons who wanted "to destroy me."

FARGO, N.D. July 31 A Federal grand jury in Fargo today indicted the First Western State Bank of Minot, N.D., and six prominent state Democrats charging that bank funds had been illegally used to make political contributions.

LONDON, July 31 Michael Frayn, the newspaper satirist, television playwright and novelist, has succeeded in every form he has touched, perhaps we were expecting too much of his debut in the theater. There is nothing terribly wrong with "The Two of Us," a twohanded quartet of marital sketches at the Garrick Theater on the model of Neil Simon's "Plaza Suite"; but you do leave the theater feeling that practically anyone could have written it.

Miss Elizabeth Jane Bryden, a teacher in the Edinburgh school system, was married in Trinity Church in her native Lockerbie, Scotland, yesterday afternoon to Robert A. Cuddihy, a student at the University of Edinburgh. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. John Fletcher of the Church of Scotland.

Stock prices rallied in early trading yesterday, following news of Israel's acceptance of United States proposals for Middle East peace talks, but the strength failed to hold and the market lapsed into the mixed pattern that has characterized most trading this week.

HOUSTON, July 31 Five days after a gun battle between policemen and black youths along Dowling Street, there is much disagreement between police reports and accounts of black residents as to just what happened.

LONDON, July 31 A pair of golden eagles has successfully nested and hatched offspring in England for the first time in more than a century, the Royal Society for the protection of Birds announced today.
LITCHFIELD, Conn., July 31 Nils Hogner, an artist and illustrator died yesterday. He was 72 years old and lived at Hemlock Farm.

CHICAGO, July 31 The Kansas City Chiefs, the National Football League champions, polished off the College All-Stars, 24-3, tonight following only five days of practice and then disbanded to join the strike of N.F.L. against the owners.

SOFIA, Bulgaria, July 31 (AP) In spite of unabated atheist propaganda, Bulgaria's Orthodox Church, observing its 1,100th anniversary this year, is undergoing a seeming renaissance. Doubt and dissent may mar many other Christian churches, but Bulgarian Orthodox leaders report that faith is becoming firmer.
London stocks scored a solid advance in active trading yesterday.
The mammoth tankers now being built are too big for most of the world's ports. With their deep draft, they often have to moor far offshore when taking on or discharging their cargo.

TEL AVIV, July 31 The Israeli Cabinet decided tonight to accept the United States formula for a limited cease-fire and the opening of peace talks with the United Arab Republic. The vote was 17 to 6, and the dissenting ministers all from the hard-line Gahal faction are now expected to withdraw from the Government partnership.

A former top sales official of I.O.S., Ltd., the ailing international mutual fund and insurance complex, disclosed yesterday that he has set up a rival company that would join with other former Investors Overseas Services personnel in the financial services business.
WASHINGTON, July 31 A Government safety official said today that his agency had found "serious" defects in three buses operated by the Tedesco Bus Company, Inc., of Jersey City.
Saying that air pollution had dropped to substantially lower levels, Mayor Lindsay yesterday canceled the alert condition that he had declared on Wednesday.
The United Federation of Teachers announced yesterday that it had reached agreement with the Board of Education on a contract covering the 4,000 paraprofessionals represented by the union.

When Mr. and Mrs. Edward Fenton of Huntington, L.I., celebrated their 35th wedding anniversary recently, the former Maria Gambarelli and her husband gave a poolside party for 100 friends and relatives.

Larry Grathwohl, a 22-yearold Cincinnati man who is under indictment for being part of an alleged nationwide bombing conspiracy by the radical Weathermen, some of whom suspect him of being an undercover police agent, had an additional warrant for his arrest issued against him yesterday for bailjumping.

MANHASSET, L. I., July 31--Owen Ely, who retired last year as a specialist in public utilities for Loeb Rhoades Co., brokers of New York, died yesterday in St. Francis Hospital, Roslyn. He was 80 years old and lived at Munsey Park.
Charles E. Gillham, associate editor of Field Stream magazine, died Tuesday in a St. Louis hospital. He was 72 years old and lived in Edwardsville, Ill.

WASHINGTON, July 31 The Army disclosed today that it had demoted a brigadier general and stripped him of a Distinguished Service Medal "because he failed to maintain a high degree of personal and professional integrity."
SALISBURY, N.C., July 31 A bishop of the African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church invited all white Chris tians today to save their souls by joining a black church.

Concern by players over possible reprisals and concern by club owners over the loss of exhibition-game income next weekend developed yesterday as an insignificant number of experienced performers entered National Football League training camps.
BELFAST, Northern Island, Saturday, Aug. 1 (Reuters) Sniper bullets sounded in Belfast at dawn today as British troops clashed with rioters for the second time in four hours.
WASHINGTON, July 31 (AP) The Government charged the Armco Steel Corporation today with using illegal reciprocalpurchase arrangements with suppliers and customers.
THE PLAINS, Va., July 31 Joseph Minot Mulford, senior partner from 1930 to 1935 of the former J.M. Mulford Co., New York investment bankers, died today. He was 80 years old and lived here.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., July 31 Jim Hudson, one of the New York Jets' stalwart performers, in their Super Bowl victory, followed Harry Theofiledes, a quarterback candidate, into the team's training camp tonight at Hofstra University.

NEW HAVEN, July 31 The jury in the Lonnie McLucas trial heard a New Haven detective say today that the order to kill Alex Rackley was relayed by a member of the central committee of the Black Panther party, Landon Williams.

LONDON, July 31 (AP) A two-engined aircraft piloted by Prince Charles with his father, Prince Philip, and a flying instructor aboard, narrowly escaped colliding with a small plane, it was announced today.

MILWAUKEE, July 31 Seemingly baffled for six innings, during which they were shut out with only two hits, the New York Yankee struck wth fury in the seventh tonight to score all their runs in a 7-3 victory over the Milwaukee Brewers.

WASHINGTON July 31 (AP) H. Neil Garson, whose expense accounts have come under the scrutiny of Government investigators, said today he intended to resign his $30,000-a-year job as secretary of the Interstate Commerce Commission.
American exporters have begun to respond favorably to a Nixon Administration effort to encourage the use of United States-flag merchant ships, according to Federal and Maritime industry leaders.

CAZENOVIA, N.Y., July 31 Jacob Edward Eckel, retired president of the Eckels-Nye Steel Company of Syracuse and the Jersey Shore Steel Company of Jersey Shore, Pa., died Wednesday at, the State University Hospital in Syracuse. He was 76 years old.

Vietnamization, like the proverbial cat, seems to have atleast nine lives, about five of which have already been lived. Vietnamization was tried first by the French nearly 20 years ago. On May 10, 1970, General Henri Navarre, formerly commander of the French forces in Indochina, said: "Vietnamization is an old idea. It was the basis of my own plan when I was sent to Indochina in 1952."
MASSAPEQUA, L.I., July 31 M. Rudolph Preuss, a lawyer with offices in Hempstead and a leader in community activities, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 45 Club Drive. His age was 63.
Arthur Mermin, a partner in the New York law firm of Cahill, Gordon, Sonnett, Reindel Ohl died Tuesday of a stroke at his home, 4475 Douglas Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 49 years old.

The Penn Central announced yesterday that its leased line, the Cleveland Pittsburgh Railroad, would not pay the dividends due Sept. 1 on its 7 per cent guaranteed and 4 per cent special guaranteed betterment stock. It said the omission was because of the uncertainty of its making continued rental payments to the C., which it operates under lease.

ST. LOUIS, July 31 (AP) Jimmy Conzelman, who was coach of the Chicago Cardinals' football team and had been a member of professional football's Hall of Fame since 1964, died today after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, July 31 Senator Mike Mansfield predicted today that Congress would cut appropriations by a net of $5-billion this session, but he did not mention numerous other Congressional actions and inactions on spending and revenue that threaten to add billions of dollars to the budget deficit.
"Was this the record?" Bob Lemon asked that ques- tion last night after his Kansas City Royals lost to Baltimore, 3-1.

The New York Shakespeare Festival yesterday rescinded the Aug. 9 closing notice of "The Wars of the Roses" in Central Park and extended its run through Aug. 22 because the New York State Council on the Arts has decided to contribute to the festival $50,000 more than originally expected.

HONG KONG, July 30 The resumption of technological studies at university level in Communist China has been spurred by the launching of a new Maoist type of higher education at Tsinghua University in Peking, the country's foremost school for science and engineering.

COLORADO SPRINGS, July 31 The marriage of Miss Heather Cogswell to Second Lieut. William A. Palmer, U.S.A., took place in the Episcopal Chapel of Our Saviour here today. The Rev. James Burnette performed the ceremony.
CLEVELAND, July 31 (AP) A private funeral service was held this afternoon for George Szell, music director of the Cleveland Orchestra, who died last night at the age of 73.
MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 31 Pinnacle came through under pressure today and won the intermediate jumper championship at the Orange County Horse Show with 11 points.

AIRMONT, N.Y., July 30 "Let's face it, when you put a project in my backyard, I'm going to be skeptical," said Mrs. Marvin Rosenfeld as she stood watching her children play on the lush green lawn that reaches back to a thicket behind her home here.

In the midst of the latest electrical power crisis, Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, is opposing a major expansion of the Astoria, Queens, plant of the Consolidated Edi- son Company, contending that it would significantly increase air pollution.

There have been singers in the past who have served as leaders of jazz groups. But none have been as integral a part of the group as Leon Thomas who appeared with his septet Thursday night at the Museum of Modern Art.
A union that ordered United Parcel Service drivers off the job Thursday was fined $25,000 a day yesterday for refusing to obey a court's instructions to get the men back to work.

MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., July 31 "I'm here because my people are here," said a New Haven student, lowering a knapsack and then gazing upon a vista of multicolored tents, flags, motorcycles, trees and tanned bodies.

Henry Coddington Meyer 3d, who retired several years ago as a partner in the engineering firm of Meyer, Strong Jones, 230 Park Avenue, died yesterday in Martha's Vineyard (Mass.) Hospital. He was 70 years old, lived in Tequesta, Fla., and was spending the summer at Edgartown, Mass.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, July 31 Lieut. Gen. Do Cao Tri, commander of South Vietnam's Ill Corps tactical zone, around Saigon, denied today that he had made remarks critical of Thai military forces, attributed to him in an article in The New York Times on July 19.

Reacting to Lindsay adminstration charges that Controller Abraham D. Beame was "playing Clubhouse politics" in the controversy over city consultants, Mr. Beame hurled the same charge at the administration yesterday.

Again this summer as last summer, the New York City Board of Elections is conducting a neighborhood voter registration drive, this year by widespread use of "votemobiles" which, cruising through local communities, will seek out the many potential voters who have never before been placed on the registration rolls. The "votemobiles" begin a trial run today with full-scale operations scheduled for next week.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 31 It is not the grandest of music festivals, this 10-day series that started here officially last night and unofficially the night before. But it is in many ways the most endearing, with the most unusual repertory in the most glamorous setting.

The biggest change in tournament schedules in the last two decades has been caused by the remarkable popularity of Swiss Team contests, in which short head-to-head matches are played but no team is eliminated.

HARTFORD, July 31 This city of 155,000 people, plagued by three days of rioting by Negroes and Puerto Ricans, was declared in a state of emergency today and placed under a curfew lasting from 9 P.M. to 5 A.M.
LISBON, July 31 Joao Lopes Soares, an indomitable democrat and educator, died here today at the age of 91, four days after his lifelong...
A Federal judge, in a preliminary action, turned down yesterday an attack on the X rating of movies that exclude children under 17.
AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, July 27 The French authorities have been trying to keep the younger generation cool this summer by banning several pop music festivals in the South of France.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., July 31 Mr. and Mrs. Will N. Robins have announced the engagement of their niece, Miss Maura W. Gaffney, to Lieut. (j.g.) Raymond C. Lynch, U.S.N.R., son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip of Cedarhurst, L.I. Miss Gaffney is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Maurice L. Gaffney, also of Cedarhurst. A September wedding is planned.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., July 31 (AP) Regents of the University of Texas at Austin voted tonight to split the College of Arts and Sciences into three parts.
A California producer of electronic measuring instruments was the only company this week to sell its stock to the public for the first time, according to a weekly survey of new-issue underwriters.
Joseph R. Fiore, 44 years old, of 25-20 38th Street, Astoria, Queens, was sentenced to 20 years in prison yesterday as a wholesaler of heroin.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 31 Most spectators come here to cheer the big-name superstars, but there is always a small group of fans who, with fingers crossed, root for one of their local favorites to hit that $50,000 jackpot.
If anybody needed convincing that racing's 2-year-old division lacked a standout, the line-up for today's $136,370 Sapling Stakes should end the debate.

NEW BEDFORD, Mass., July 31 (AP) Nineteen blacks were arrested today in what the police said was the city's Black Panther headquarters. The arrests followed three nights of disturbances and sniper fire in the South and West End sections.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 31 A 41-year-old man who volunteered his services here to "cool" racial disturbances last week and whose advice led in large measure to the imposition of a state of emergency and two nights of curfew was arrested this morning on charges of impersonating a policeman and carrying a concealed weapon during that period.

INDIANAPOLIS, July 31 (AP) Cliff Richey, the top-seeded United States player, defeated Fred McMillan of South Africa, 7-5, 3-6, 8-6, in the quarterfinals of the $50,000 national clay court tennis tournament today.
WASHINGTON, July 31 The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week ended July 28.
VIENTIANE, Laos, July 31 (Reuters) A special envoy of the Pathet Lao arrived in Vientiane today in an effort to arrange negotiations with the Laotian Premier, Prince Souvanna Phouma.
Just three years ago, a youthful chemical engineer named Robert Norman Rickles took the witness stand here before the state's Air Pollution Control Board.

Israel's acceptance of United States peace proposals, previously endorsed by Egypt and Jordan, clears the way for the most intensive effort to negotiate a lasting settlement in the Middle East since the establishment of the Jewish state 22 years ago.

HARRISON, N.Y., July 31 Caught in a late rainstorm, John Miller, a slim, 23-year-old California professional, scored a 67 today and finished as the 36-hole leader in the $250,000 Westchester Golf Classic with an aggregate of 136.
Two lawyers and a merchant seamen were arrested here yesterday, accused of soliciting legal business in the corridors of the Manhattan Criminal Courts Building.

SEA CLIFF, L.I., July 31 Todd Field of the Port Washington Yacht Club won in his Lightning Class division and his younger sister, Bonnie, captured her Blue Jay Midget division honors today as 145 boats sailed in the Junior Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound open regatta on Hempstead Harbor.

YARMOUTHPORT, Mass., July 31 Joseph B. Maclean, vice president and actuary of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York from 1941 to 1947 and consulting actuary until his retirement in 1950, died Wednesday. He was 81 years old and lived here.
Four firemen were injured, none seriously, while battling a two-alarm fire in a Brooklyn synagogue early this morning.
After its sharp decline on Thursday, the world sugar futures market regained a little equilibrium yesterday. Trading slowed from a near record 6,344 contracts to 1,400 contracts.
Stanley Drew Beard, a former director of Lederle Laboratories, died yesterday in Nyack (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 88 North Main Street, Pearl River, N.Y.

WASHINGTON, July 31 Opponents of the Safeguard antimissile system contended today in the Senate that the Defense Department had conceded that the system, as designed, would not effectively protect Minuteman missiles against a Soviet attack.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., July 31 (AP) Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra opened their fifth summer season at Saratoga Performing Arts Center last night joined by the trio of Isaac Stern, violinist, Eugene Istomin, pianist, and Leonard Rose, cellist.

CHATHAM, N.J., July 31 (UPI) The police seized black powder, explosive chemicals and instructions on how to make both explosives and drugs and arrested four young men in raids on four houses in this Morris County community.

WASHINGTON, July 31, (Reuters) Informed sources said today that the executive board of the International Monetary Fund has formally decided to continue to press Canada to return to a fixed exchange parity for the Canadian dollar as soon as possible.

Long years of patient labor in the vineyards of trade union organization, nonviolent protest and national boycott have at last resulted in a historic contract between the grape pickers and grape growers in California. "We are overjoyed that peace has come to the valley," said the owner of a vineyard in San Joaquin. "All grapes will be sweet grapes again," said Cesar Chavez, the leader of the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee.

New York City's electric power safety margin widened slightly yesterday thanks to continuing conservation efforts and some increase in supply from outside the city as the work week ended for most people.

WILLIAMSON, N.Y., July 31 At least four persons were killed and 20 injured tonight when a stock car speeding out of control at more than 100 miles an hour vaulted a restraining wall and slammed into a grandstand.

Mrs. Fridolyn Fleisher of New York, a great granddaughter of the late Ellis A. Gimbel, a founder of Gimbel Brothers, was married here yesterday afternoon to Milton J. Stamos of New York, owner of the Riviera Florist here. The civil ceremony took place at the Municipal Building.

Five squatters in two nearly vacant six-story tenements opposite the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Morningside Heights, chosen to speak for the 54 families that occupied apartments in the buildings on July 25, appealed to the owners yesterday to stop demolition of adjacent buildings.

WASHINGTON, July 31 United States and Soviet negotiators at the talks in Vienna on the limitation of strategic arms have intensified their discussions with the apparent objective of ending the current phase by mid-August.
Three Housing Authority high-rise apartment buildings were left without elevator service last night as some 200 elevator mechanics in city facilities began a wildcat walkout.
Scarves are in. So are beads and belts. But gloves? As a status symbol, even as a sign of gentility, they've lost their standing. At best, they're worn to keep the hands warm.
WASHINGTON, July 31 Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson said today that the Government would set employment goals for women in some Federal contract work to eliminate discrimination because of sex.

Five brothers and sisters who had been separated since they first entered the city's overcrowded facilities for abandoned and neglected children were reunited yesterday as they and 13 other youngsters were transferred to facilities run by voluntary agencies.
CALISTOGA, Calif. Robert Louis Stevenson described Jacob Schram's winery in his book, "The Silverado Squatters," after he had paid a visit here in 1880.

The nation's largest all-line insurer, the Aetna Life and Casualty Company, reported yesterday that net income, including realized capital gains, rose to $34.5-million, or $1.30 a share, in the first haf from $28.1-million, or $1.05 a share, in the year-earlier period.
CINCINNATI, July 31 Dr. Howard D. Fabing, a former president of the American Academy of Neurology and of the Society of Biological Psychiatry, died here Wednesday at his home. He was 62 years old.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., July 31 The White House press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, qualified somewhat today President Nixon's statement last night at a news conference that the number of Federal officials sent to Southern schools this fall would be governed by requests from the Southern school districts.
HONG KONG, July 31 Communist China, marking the 43d anniversary of its army's founding, accused the Soviet Union today of massing troops near the Chinese border.

"I have a fear," said Paul Martha of the Pittsburgh Steelers several years ago, "that someday my boy and I will be watching a pro football game on television, and after the first quarter one of the teams will walk off the field because of a working grievance against management."
SANTIAGO, Chile, July 24 A Chilean politician chatting with friends on a downtown corner paused to cough and looked up into the haze where snow-capped mountain peaks should have been visible.

Fifth Avenue Coach Lines, Inc., and its subsidiary, Surface Transit, Inc., indicated yesterday that they had agreed on a settlement with the City of New York to fix compensation for the condemnation acquisition by the city in 1962 of the bus service system and operations of the two companies.

Policemen in helicopters covering a 50-mile route from Long Island to lower Manhattan guided colleagues in cars yesterday to $85,000 in hijacked meat and the arrest of five men allegedly involved in the crime.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., July 31 Although a move to report to training camp developed today among some Giant regulars, Fran Tarkenton contended that the "overwhelming majority" of the players had decided not to report.
The Mets, for the first time since July 11, are back in first place in the Eastern Division of the National League.

The Western Electric Company was awarded yesterday a $232-million prime contract for development of the Army's Safeguard ballistic missile system. Senator George Murphy, Republican of Califronia, said that $75-million was committed by the Army to cover the Aug. 1-Sept. 15 period and the balance would be funded in increments.

GREAT NECK, L.I., July 31 Miss Susan Lois Forman and Robert Dana Pickman, candidates for M.A. degrees at C.W. Post College of Long Island University in Brookville, plan to be married on Aug. 16 in the Great Hall at the college.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N.J., July 31 Rain played havoc with the Metropolitan Golf Association's 68th amateur championship today.

The F.W. Woolworth Company achieved a 14 per cent increase in sales for the first six months this year, but earnings declined 6.1 per cent, reflecting higher operating costs, according to the midyear report issued yesterday by the nation's largest variety chain.
Dr. Irving Smiley, who retired in 1956 as director of gynecology at Bronx Hospital, died yesterday at his apartment in the Mayflower Hotel, Central Park West and 61st Street. His age was 82.

Show tune buffs are split down the middle on this one. While many prefer the wit and sophistication of Lorenz Hart's lyrics, just as many fancy the more sentimental approach of Richard Rodgers' later partner, Oscar Hammerstein.

But one envelope caught his attention: the return address read "Cruising Club of America."

THE 1970 census will show that the United States has a population somewhat in excess of 205 million, an increase of about 25 million since the last census was taken in 1960. This will hardly come as a revelation, for sample surveys taken by the Bureau of the Census since the last complete count provide an accurate annual record of broad changes in the American population.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 1 (AP) Starting next year, according to a new decree, all the country's movie theaters must show Brazilian films 112 days a year, or double the quota imposed now by the National Cinema Institute.

CRANFORD, N.J., Aug. 1 Miss Carolyn Anne La Corte, daughter of Mrs. Nicholas St. John La Corte of Cranford and the late Mr. La Corte, was married here this morning to William Robert Finnegan 3d, son of Dr. and Mrs. William R. Finnegan, also of Cranford.

SNOWDOUN, Ala., Aug. 1 The predominantly Negro National Democratic Party of Alabama met in the woods of a green lakeside in Southern Alabama today to nominate a black candidate to oppose George C. Wallace for Governor in November.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 1 A blaze reportedly started by fire bombs wrecked two five-story buildings early today in a business area here near where riots ravaged a three-block section of the predominantly Negro West Side several weeks ago.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 1 Bwamazon Farm's Well Man ered extended a winning streak to five today by winning the $55,750 Minuteman Handicap at Liberty Bell Park by eight lengths over J.I.B. Farm's Rollicking. The favored Silent Screen finished last in the field of six 3-year-olds.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 1 William Persons Gwinn, chairman of the United Aircraft Corporation, and Mrs. Rachel Coleman Witman, widow of John H. Witman and owner of John H. A reception followed at the Beach Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 The National Research Council issued guidelines today designed to protect blood plasma donors from careless laboratory procedures that spread hepatitis and provoke other problems.

JERUSALEM Aug. 2 While the talk in world capitals was of the possibility of peace in the Middle East, Israeli and Arab forces have clashed on three fronts since yes- terday. Israeli jets today attacked Egyptian positions along the Suez Canal and staged what were described as retaliatory raids against army positions in Jordan, and Israeli artillery has attacked guerrilla positions in southern Lebanon.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 2 There is a land where the stock market has been rising and taxes are going to fall, where the balance of payments is massively favorable and the gross national product is felt to be growing almost explosively.

OTTAWA, Aug. 2 Canada has made substantial gains on its gigantic wheat surplus during the crop year now closing. However, before the new crop begins to come in she still has one billion bushels to dispose of.

CENTERPORT, L.I., Aug. 2 Paul Capron of Sea Cliff, L.I., added a fifth place today to a pair of sccond-place finishes to win the First District Novice Star Class championship.

ROME, Aug. 2 Pope Paul VI offered a defense today of the Roman Curia, the central administration of the Roman Catholic Church, which has been under heavy attack as being a bastion of conservatism in an institution requiring reform. The Curia has been internationalized and to some extent liberalized by the Pope.

WATERFORD, Conn., Aug. 2 Wole Soyinka began writing "Madmen and Specialists" secretly in prison in Nigeria, where he was confined because of his stand on the Biafran War. Last month he finished the play in artistic sanctuary at the Eugene O'Neill Center, and last night, with his own actors from the University of Ibadan, he staged its world premiere in the O'Neill Center's outdoor amphitheater.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 2 (UPI) The wife of a manufacturing company executive was kidnapped and released 19 hours later after her husband paid the abductors $10,000 in ransom, the, police reported last night.

England, Aug. 2 Although in London the Royal Shakespeare Company ranges far and wide over world drama, both classic and contemporary, its Memorial Theater in Stratford-upon-Avon, is kept as a sacred shrine to Shakespeare.
