The performance gave him four triumphs and a fourthplace finish, with a 12th place showing in the second contest of the series being used as a throw-out race.

CLEARFIELD, Utah, Aug. 2-D Dormitory is neat and airy, painted blue and brown. Its low cost and varnished wood closets help give the wartime built warehouse and its neighboring Job Corps structures a quasimilitary air.
Douglas Grant, a dimpled 11-year-old with darting eyes, has a public face. You might see him almost anywhere on the stage, on television or movie screens or tending a newsstand near West 34th Street.

CAIRO, Aug. 2 President Gamal Abdel Nasser today sharply criticized the hard-line attitude of Iraq against Cairo's acceptance of the United States proposals toward a peaceful settlement of the conflict with Israel.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Aug. 2 Miss Elaine Ruth Friedman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Friedman, was married at her parents' home here yesterday afternoon to Eric A. Stone, a research scientist in psychiatry at the New York University Medical Center. The ceremony was performed by the bride's cousin, Rabbi Paul Teicher.

The following is a supplementary list of over-the-counter stocks prepared by the National Association of Securities Dealers. It consists of securities less widely held or those that, for other reasons, do not appear on the daily Overthe-Counter list. The range shown reflects prices at which securities could have been sold (bid) or bought (asked) last Friday.

The International Utilities Corporation and the Pacific Intermountain Express Company announced yesterday that they had held discussions concerning the possible acquisition of Pacific by International.

Attacks of muscle weakness in many patients with a rare genetic disease called periodic paralysis can now be relieved and prevented with a drug that physicians have used for 20 years to treat commoner conditions, according to a team of researchers at the National Institutes of Health.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 Ruth Alexandria Phillips, a novelist, newspaperwoman and artist, died of cancer yesterday at Rogers Memorial Hospital here. She was 68 years old.

A field of 70 teams, including many players with national reputations, was led into the final session of the Greater New York Bridge Association's Swiss Team tournament at the New York Hilton last night by the foursome of William Passell of Hartsdale. N.Y., Dave Strasberg of Rockville Centre, L.I., and Peter Leventritt and Stan Turecki of New York.

Mayor Lindsay's power committee split, 3 to 2, yesterday, with a majority proposing to let the Consolidated Edison Company go ahead with a controversial plan to expand its electric plant in Astoria, Queens provided that the expanded facilities burned only natural gas.

YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif. The crowds of vacationers are pouring into Yosemite again this summer, but here and elsewhere across the country there is a discernible difference from previous years: The visitors are spending less.
HOUSTON, Aug. 2 (AP) Bob Gibson limited Houston to four hits, struck out 10 and singled in the decisive run today to pace the St. Louis Cardinals to a 3-2 victory over the Astros.

An island near Tampa Bay, in Florida, has been leased for $1 a year by the National Audubon Society to provide a sanctuary for white ibises displaced by the new congestion of brown pelicans on their old nearby site.

ROME, Aug. 2 Premier-designate Emilio Colombo ended his first week of political consultations today and indicated that he had made progress toward forming a new center-left coalition cabinet. But a spokesman for one of the four parties with which Mr. Colombo has been negotiating said the fourweek-old government crisis was as far from settlement as ever.

GALVESTON, Tex., Aug. 2 (UPI) Hurricane Celia, its peak winds slightly diminished, advanced steadily toward a major Southern population center today. The showery fringes of the storm moved inland across parts of Louisiana and Texas.

A settlement of the most serious strike in the history of American sports appeared possible early today as the 26 National Football League club owners huddled in the offices of Commissioner Pete Rozelle.

PULLMAN, Wash., Aug. 2 (AP) Dick Nelson of Ashtabula, Ohio, a University of Kentucky star, won the marathon today, closing event of a threeweek Olympic distance runners' training camp at Washington State University.
INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 2 (AP) Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex., captured the national clay court tennis championship today by beating Stan Smith of Pasadena, Calif., 6-2, 10-8, 3-6, 6-1.

Women's liberation took a long kick forward yesterday, Twenty-six young women from France and Italy played soccer long a man's game at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, before 4,500 fans, who paid $4 apiece for a show worth the money.
In August, when candidates turn to vacations, the attention of many politicians turns to the internal feuding that plagues almost every major campaign.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2 (UPI) Tony Taylor greeted Mike Davison, relief pitcher, with a grand slam homer with none out in the ninth inning today to give the Philadelphia Phillies a 7-6 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
Mr. Congreve passed on in 1729, but Dr. Milstein is still very much alive and living in a plant-filled apartment in Long Island City, Queens.

HILVERSUM, The Netherlands, Aug. 2 (AP) Tom Okker of the Netherlands won the Dutch open tennis championship today by defeating second-seeded Roger Taylor of Britain, 4-6, 6-0, 6-1, 6-3, in the final. Okker earned $3,000, Taylor $1,300.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 2 (UPI) Bobby Tolan's two-out single off Juan Pizzaro in the 11th inning drove in Ty Cline and gave the Cincinnati Reds a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 2 (UPI) A $63.5-million "automation" fund to pay off West Coast dock workers unemployed by technology is near bankruptcy.
DETROIT, Aug. 2 (AP) Home runs by Harm on Killebrew and Tony Oliva paced the Minnesota Twins to a 4-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.

LA PIOLINE, France, Aug. 2 A rash of fires in town dumps has spurred French authorities to try to cope better with one of western Europe's most apparent environmental problems: the mounting masses of litter that scar the countryside.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2 (Reuters) Millions of dollars worth of American fuel is being stolen in Southeast Asia because a new system designed to prevent thefts was never put into effect, two Democratic Senators charged today.

Following are excerpts from the majority report of Mayor Lindsay's Interdepartmental Committee on Public Utilities recommending that Consolidated Edison enlarge its Astoria plant and from the cornmittee's minority report opposing expansion of the plant:
HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 2 A group of Bruce Crampton fans flew in from Grand Bahama and later had to motor a few miles in search of a club in their efforts to encourage the 34-year-old professional.

If the name of Margaret Anderson is known to this generation at all, it is surely as editor of The Little Review, the magazine that flourished between 1914 and 1929, publishing those who were then the avant-garde writers. Its most memorable years were just after World War I when it published Joyce's "Ulysses" in installments...

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 2 A 24-year-old white civil rights law clerk and a young black woman from a poor rural south Mississippi county were married here today, toppling a legal barrier against interracial marriage that had been on the books for more than 100 years. It was believed to be the first such wedding in Mississippi.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 2 Sammy Cahn, the songwriter ("High Hopes," "All the Way," "Love and Marriage," and "The Second Time Around"), and Mrs. Tita Basile Curtis, an actress turned fashion coordinator, were married here this afternoon by Superior Court Judge Joseph Wapner at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Burton...
The American Broadcasting Company is looking for four "concerned corporations" that are willing to cosponsor a new television series next year and to pay almost $2.5-million each for the privilege.
TORONTO, Aug. 3 (Canadian Press) Three of the four seeded players including two Americans advanced in senior men's singles today as play opened in the Canadian closedtennis championships.

The horrors of the atomic destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki 25 years ago were shown for 16 minutes last night on the network of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting (Channel 13). The film, made by Japanese cameramen, was classified as secret for 20 years but in the last two years had been widely shown on foreign television systems and over 400 prints have been sold.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Without naming him, the State Department suggested today that Senator J.W. Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, had disclosed confidential information about a proposed new base agreement with Spain.

Three city-bound Penn Central commuter trains had to be evacuated in the tunnel under Park Avenue near 72d Street last night after they were trapped because of a smoky third-rail fire. No one was injured.
KALAMAZOO, Mich., Aug. 3 (AP) Two ranking players were upset today in the second round of 16-and-under singles of the national junior and boys tennis championships.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Aug. 3 (UPI) A California Senate subcommittee said today that the Communist party had taken over the Black Panthers and was using them as "shock troops on the front line of the revolution."

SHEFFIELD, England, Aug. 3 Few thing in ballet seem more difficult that the entertainment of children. A few children presumably like any kind of ballet, but most dislike both complicated stories and pure dancing and have a dangerously short attention span.
Government bond prices declined slightly yesterday as the Treasury began its $6.45-billion refinancing to pay off securities that come due Aug. 15.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 3 Thomas J. Delaney, Commissioner of Public Safety here, and Mrs. Delaney have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Veronica Andrea Delaney to James Kearney, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Kearney of Brooklyn, New York.

MOSCOW, Aug. 3 An important Bonn official expressed strong optimism today about the chances for a favorable outcome of the Soviet-West German treaty negotiations, which have entered their second week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Representative David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, charged today that Government supervision of nursing homes was "grossly ineffective" despite the fact that tax dollars paid for almost three quarters of the care the homes provide.
Consolidated Edison said yesterday that it was working around the clock on its disabled million-kilowatt generator at Ravenswood, Queens, but that it still had not found the source of the problem.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Aug. 3 Three thousand people marched today in the funeral cortege of a 19-year-old youth shot dead by a British Army marksman during rioting here early Friday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (Reuters) The Senate ap proved today a bill raising the interest rate for Series E Savings Bonds from 5 to 5.5 per cent.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 3 Eugene H. Nickerson, who will not seek re-election after serving three terms of three years each as Nassau County Executive, plans to return to the practice of law next year.
RAPID CITY, S.D. The American Indian is adopting the white man's ways in art as well as in life.
MIDDLEFIELD, Conn., Aug. 3 (UPI) About 1,000 young people stayed behind today near here to clean up the debris of 30,000 who gathered for the Powder Ridge Rock Festival that never was.

The Swiss team tournament that ended Sunday night at the New York Hiton was won by Peter Leventritt and Stan Turecki of New York, Bill Passell of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Dave Strasberg of Rockville Centre, L.I. They achieved the rare feat of leading throughout the event, heading a strong field of 70 teams with a final score of 173 victory points of a possible 240.
Except for a few occasions, Dangerous Dan McGinn has been more dangerous to the Montreal Expos this season than to the teams he pitches against.
STONY POINT, N.Y., Aug. 3 The mothball fleet of gray troopships, submarine tenders and radar vessels anchored in the Hudson River here since the end of World War II is being phased out.

OTTAWA, Aug. 3 The recent success of the Alaskan Eskimos in getting their aboriginal rights recognized by the United States Senate has raised the hopes of the 12,000 Eskimos in Canada that they will be able to win over an obstinate Government in Ottawa.

Activities. The President flew from his San Clemente, Calif., home to Washington, D.C., with a stop in Denver for a meeting with representatives of the state planning agencies of the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 3 (Reuters) President Joseph D. Mobutu of the Congo arrived here today for a 12-day visit to the United States, which will include discussions of foreign aid and African affairs.

Exports of steel from the United States soared by 138 per cent in the first half of 1970, compared with those of the 1969 period, while imports dropped 17.7 per cent, the American Iron and Steel Institute said yesterday in Washington.

MOUNT PLEASANT, N.Y., Aug. 3 A chartered bus carrying 36 passengers most of them children between 7 and 12 years old to an upstate camp crashed into a car and a tree today after its brakes apparently failed at an intersection.
If the concert on Sunday evening at the Forest Hills tennis stadium was any indication, Janis Joplin finally has a backup band worthy of her.
JOHANNESBURG South Africa's policy of apartheid, long attacked on ideological grounds, is at last beginning to give way on economic grounds.

A recent series of attacks on policemen has pointed up one continuing problem there is aparently very little that the Police Department here can do about assaults by crowds on patrolmen making arrests.

PETERBORO, N.H., Aug. 3 (AP) Dr. Richard Ford, Massachusetts state pathologist and medical examiner for the Southern District of Suffolk County, Mass., since 1959, died today of a self-inflicted gunshot wound in the head. He was 55 years old.
A leading authority on virus infections suspects that the vaccine against rubella, or German measles, as presently administered may eventually do more harm than good.

Ilka Suarez, whose shop is on 60th Street near Second Avenue, says she does not do custom, but she does make knits to measure. She's a little particular about what those measurements are, though. They should be no more than a size 12, and while Miss Suarez will take on a 14 now and then she thinks no woman should let herself get bigger than that what she really

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass. Aug. 3 Miss Jane Helen Canter, who is completing studies in city planning at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, and Robert Hugh Loeffler, a magna cum laude graduate of Harvard, where he was president and editor of the yearbook, will be married in September.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Petitions intended to lead to an early constitutional test of the vote for 18-year-olds were filed with the Supreme Court today by Oregon and Texas.
Sidewalk garden tubs on midtown Broadway are posing a special problem of environmental pollution.

Teachers aides and other paraprofessional school employes approved a three-year contract with the Board of Education yesterday that grants them a 140 per cent weekly wage increase plus substantial fringe benefits.

The American Natural Gas Company and subsidiaries have reported operating revenues of $553,469,570 for the 12 months ended June 30. This was up from $503,162,093 a year earlier. Net income rose to $54,304,358, or $3.48 a share, from $47,442,890, or $3.06 a share.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 3 John Papandon, a lawyer who lives in Oakdale, L.I., was sentenced to five months in jail today for his part in an Islip land scandal.
Residents of two East Harlem blocks twice threw rubbish and discarded furniture into the street yesterday, then set it afire to protest what they said was a lack of garbage collection in the area.
Government bonds moved strongly forward yesterday on the London stock market with long-term issues showing special strength.

The insecticide DDT causes mutations in rat genes, a Food and Drug Administration geneticist has reported. This is the first time that DDT has been found to cause mutations in an intact mammalian system.
COWES, England, Aug. 3 (Reuters) Prime Minister Heath tonight won a 24-mile yacht race off the Isle of Wight against competitors who included Princess Anne, the daughter of Queen Elizabeth II.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 The political world needs a new vocabulary to deal with the various stages of incipient candidacy for President between the time when a man is merely mentioned and late 1971, at the earlier, when he will have announced.

PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 3 A 58-page indictment was filed here today against 20 black Africans who appeared in court charged with terrorist activities intended to overthrow the South African Government.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 3 India and East Germany have agreed to form consular ties, Swaran Singh the External Affairs Minister, announced today in Parliament.

BUFFALO, Aug. 3 (UPI) Senator Charles E. Goodell acknowledged today that he lacked the "full support" of his Republican Congressional colleagues from New York but said he could win re-election without their help by running on his record as an independent.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 3 (UPI) The defense asked that charges against Charles Manson and other defendants in the Sharon Tate murder case be dismissed on the ground that remarks earlier today by President Nixon about their guilt had made a fair trial impossible.
The wives of two Staten Island legislators dangled their legs over the bow of a cabin cruiser Sunday afternoon landing their husbands in hot water.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, Aug. 3 (UPI) Capt. James Pollack, master of a British Columbian ferry that was in a collision yesterday with a Soviet freighter at Active Pass, west of Vancouver, said today he had been unable to make contact with the freighter on an emergency radio channel before the collision.
MLAMI, Aug. 3 (AP) Conditional, beaten in his last two starts, galloped to an eightlength victory today at Tropical Park.
The City's Department of Consumer Affairs has pasted two "condemned" stickers on a scale used to weigh draftees at the Armed Forces Induction Center on Whitehall Street.

On second viewing, "Performance," which opened yesterday at the Trans-Lux East, seems less pretentiously formidable and more cleverly amusing than on first viewing, and although I'm not sure I want to see it a third time, at least not right away, twice seems an entirely reasonable and even rewarding schedule.
SEARCHLIGHT, Nev., Aug. 3 (UPI) Ten persons were killed today when a Navy antisubmarine warfare plane exploded in flight during a lightning storm 10 miles northwest of this small desert community.
BOSTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Twenty-four members of the Kennedy family rode the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy into port today as the ship arrived for her first Boston visit.

The chairman of Mayor Lindsay's power committee expressed hope yesterday that the "four years' lead time" needed to build a new electric power plant in Astoria, Queens, should be enough to allow "breakthroughs" on pollution controls with Federal help.
REHOVOT, Israel, Aug. 3 American Jewish and Israeli scholars debated today the question of the dominance of the Orthodox religious Establishment in Israel.

The breezes stirred over New York City yesterday; the sun was out and the air could be breathed without choking, in welcome contrast to last week"s unhealthy smog. But only the breezes have stirred. Underlying conditions remain much the same and, because they do, the smog may return. Other dangers, as yesterday's subway and Penn Central mishaps prove, also linger.
BERLIN, Aug. 3 Dr. Otto Warburg, the Nobel Prize-winning biochemist and leader in cancer research, died in a West Berlin hospital Saturday. He was 86 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration said today that a scientific study had shown that mouthwash products did not kill bad breath, combat colds or cure sore throats.

Five Brooklyn Civil Court judges resigned yesterday to pave the way for their nomination go the State Supreme Court and to give Brooklyn Democratic and Republican leaders the opportunity to nominate their Civil Court successors this year rather than next.
Governor Rockefeller, campaigning for re-election, said yesterday that the addiction problem in the state had grown much bigger than he had expected four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Ken O'Donnell, in an article in Life magazine, has shed interesting but not conclusive light on two matters of large historical importance how John F. Kennedy came to choose Lyndon B. Johnson as his running mate in 1960, and whether Mr. Kennedy, had he lived, would have pursued the war in Vietnam to the extent that Mr. Johnson ultimately did.

The King Resources Company of Denver, which was reported to be under mounting financial pressure after its unsuccessful attempt to take over Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., reported yesterday that it had succeeded in refinancing its short-term debt.
Will the public be served by the rise in brokerage fees now under consideration for smaller trades? Merrill Chapman thinks not.
A 14-year-old youth was stabbed to death in Chinatown last night as a result of what the police said was apparently friction between Chinese youth gangs.
A gun-detection instrument to foil potential hijackers was in operation at Kennedy International Airport Sunday when an armed man, who later commandeered a Boeing 747 to Havana, boarded the plane.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Leaders of a move to impeach Associate Justice William O. Douglas said today that an investigation being conducted by a special House judiciary subcommittee was a "whitewash" and a "travesty."

In the 1950's, when nitrate-based detergents were introduced, they produced huge quantities of suds which were not readily broken down. They bubbled up in the nation's lakes and streams and found their way into reservoirs. Dismayed housewives saw detergent suds coming out of their kitchen taps.

George Foreman, the 21-yearold heavyweight boxer who won an Olympic gold medal in 1968 and turned professional 13 months ago, will face the most formidable opponent of his career tonight when he squares off against George Chuvalo in a 10-round bout at Madison Square Garden.
AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France, Aug. 3 (AP) France's first open-air pop-music festival went silent at dawn today, with the promoters left with a deficit estimated at $200,000.

A 34-year-old man allegedly shot his wife and mother-inlaw and then fled with his 4month-old daughter late last night in Staten Island. The two women were in critical condition at Staten Island Hospital.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 3 The Stamford yacht club crew, with Ellen Watts at the helm, held a 4-point lead in the qualifying series of the 29th Long Island Sound girls championship regatta today after the first four races were sailed in Lightning Class sloops off Norwalk Yacht Club. After a fifth race tomorrow, the leading five crews in the field of 17 will sail a five-race final roundrobin series, rotating the 19foot centerboard yachts.

After 22 consecutive hours of negotiations mediated by Commissioner Pete Rozelle, the National Football League Club owners and players settled their labor dispute yesterday in an unhappy but relieved atmosphere.

DETROIT, Aug. 3 The American Motors Corporation today reported a loss of $14.1million, or 57 cents a share, for the June quarter, the third quarter in the auto maker's fiscal year. This brought the nine-month loss to $39.8-million, or $1.62 a share. The loss figures do not include taxcredit benefits. A loss in the fiscal fourth quarter, ending Sept. 30, also is expected.

MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 3 John Swan of the Babylon Yacht Club opened defense of the Picken Trophy, symbolic of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's midget sailing title, in an impressive manner today. Swan captured the opening race of the sevenrace round-robin series, then finishet second in the next three events.
The Mod Age is bringing increased profits to many business catering to the youth market.
Seven of the 12 doctors who walked out of Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx two weeks ago have resigned, a hospital spokesman said yesterday.
The American Stock Exchange took its first beating in nine sessions yesterday as declines outnumbered advances by more than a two-to-one ratio in very slow trading.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug.3 Charles Ansel Mooers, director emeritus of the University of Tennessee Agricultural Experiment Station and nationally known as an agronomist, died at a nursing home yesterday. He was 100 years old.

SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 3 (AP) Thomas Koch of Brazil scored a technical victory today over Spain's No. 1 tennis star, Manuel Santana, and salvaged Brazil's lone triumph in the Davis Cup interzone semifinals.

A Teamsters' strike against the United Parcel Service spread to a portion of New Jersey yesterday as some drivers at the company's Secaucus, N.J., terminal walked off the job in sympathy with Local 804, in New York.

A Board of Elections official announced plans yesterday to eliminate 16,000 election inspector jobs by the end of the year. The jobs have traditionally been given to housewives and elderly citizens as a form of political patronage.

WOODBURY, L.I., Aug. 3 A "Country Rock Bar-BQ," the sixth annual fair sponsored by the Friends of Waldemar to raise money for the Cancer Research Foundation will be held on the grounds of the Woodbury Institute on Sunday.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 3 The cafeteria manager at C.W. Post College wanted to know how many players would be on hand for dinner tonight.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) The House overwhelmingly approved today a bill that would outlaw the mailing of unsolicited salacious advertising.
Stock prices dropped sharply yesterday, led by the blue-chip issues that were among the market's best gainers last month.

BERNE Traveling through Eastern Europe as a cultural ambassador, John Updike, the novelist, wandered one evening into an apartment building in Prague. He chatted with a friendly, middle-aged Czechoslovak named Vavro Oravec, who spoke passable English and as he talked began drawing Mr. Updike.
TRENTON, Aug. 3 The first known infestation in this country of a rare aphid that attacks asparagus has been reported here.

ABOARD THE U.S.S: OBSERVATION ISLAND, at Sea, Aug. 3 A Russian tracking ship stood three miles off today as the United States nuclear submarine James Madison successfully completed the first underwater firing of a Poseidon missile.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) The Senate passed a bill today to create a corporationstyle United States Postal Service that would take over management of the nation's mails. It also provides an 8 per cent postal pay rise.
Fidel Castro got his first look at a Boeing 747 the other day when a Pan American airliner was diverted to Havana by a hijacker.

More than 500 subway passengers, some described as panicky, rushed from a West Side IRT local train that was involved in a minor accident yesterday two days after a passenger died and 50 others were injured in another accident. In yesterday's incident two women suffered from smoke inhalation after the train stopped with a startling popping noise halfway out of the West 86th Street station and emitted a cloud of smoke.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, July 29 Mai is not a goodlooking woman, in the eyes of some Vietnamese men, for her shoulders are too big and the bottoms of her heels are not pink or soft. There are still calluses on her hands, although the frosted pink fingernails are long and curved now.
Fidel Castro has unveiled a devastating picture of Cuba's economic troubles. As he himself acknowledged, the warnings of foreign observers about the inadequacy of his sugar program have come true.

EUTAW, Ala. Mrs. Eddie Coleman Powell, 65 years old, sat for a long time on the dilapidated porch of her four-room shack and looked into the rainy afternoon and talked slowly about poverty and getting her son Richard out of jail.
PARIS, Aug. 3 The chairs are gone where Oscar Wilde was sitting when he thought he saw an angel on the Avenue de I'Opera.

The International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., achieved record sales and earnings in this year's second quarter and first half, primarily because of higher prices for nickel and copper, the company reported yesterday.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 3 The Right Rev. Frederick B. Wolf, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Maine, and Mrs. Wolf of Portland and Heath, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Clare Wolf, to John Nigel Frederick Pepper, son of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Pepper of East Orange, N.J.
Miss Patricia Herring, a magazine and television model here, and James D. Hittle, Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Manpower and Reserve Affairs, plan to be married next month.

YONKERS, Aug. 3 (AP) The ashes of Hugh Francis Redmond, former Yonkers resident who was held in a Communist Chinese jail for 19 years until his death several months ago, were buried today in the family plot in Oakland Cemetery.
The Realty Equities Corporation of New York announced yesterday that it expects a loss of between $3.8-million and $8.7-million after tax credits in the fiscal year ending next March 31.

The Internal Revenue Service has reached the conclusion that the hundreds of books that come a reviewer's way a huge proportion of them unbidden, unwanted and unread are a form of income and should be taxed as such.

The Dodge index of construction-contract value jumped to 186 in June from 170 in May owing to a sharp increase in "nonbuilding" contracts for highway, utility, dam and military installations, projects, the F.W. Dodge division of the McGraw-Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.
MIAMI, Aug. 3 Frank E. (Lank) Leonard, creator of the comic strip "Mickey Finn," died at Jackson Memorial Hospital yesterday. He was 74 years old and lived in Miami Shores.
CAIRO, Aug. 3 A military spokesman said that an Israeli supersonic Phantom fighterbomber was shot down today over the Suez Canal town of Ismailia and the two crewmen were captured.
The appointment of Dr. Assad Kotaite as chief executive officer of the International Civil Aviation Organization (I.C.A.O.) has been announced by the group's governing council.

Stanley Furness has been elected president and a director of Herbert Arthur Morris Advertising, Inc., in a reorganization move announced by Arthur Abravanel, chairman of the agency's board of directors. Mr. Furness replaces Morris Brodis, who died recently.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (AP) Preliminary air pollution rankings for 1970 list Stuebenville, Ohio, as the dirtiest city of the United States and New York City as the most foulded with corrosive oxides.

CAIRO, Aug. 3 A conference of the so-called Arab confrontation countries scheduled to open in Libya today has been postponed as a result of a rift among the Arabs over efforts toward a peaceful settlement with Israel.

LONDON, Aug. 3 The British Government announced today that it would help two independent airline operators to amalgamate and go into competition with the state-owned airlines. It said it wanted such a "second force" airline to be in operation next summer on "major international routes."

LYNBROOK, L.I., Aug. 3 State Senator Norman F. Lent, chairman of Senate Health Committee, charged today that the state's water quality standards were "no longer adequate or relevant to safeguarding human health."
BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 3 East Side Drive, an outsider in the field, captured the first junior jumper class today as the Sussex County horse show opened a six-day run.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 3 Welcoming back old, wellheeled friends, Herb Shaw greeted the train from New York that unloaded 800 fans at Monmouth Park today.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 3 The Westchester girls' tennis team defeated Long Island, six matches to three, at Bronxville Field Club today, winning all three doubles after dividing the singles events in the opening round of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's annual junior Wightman Cup matches.

The Chicago Cubs, who have had a history of retreating in the face of the enemy, were back in town last night for their midsummer skirmish with the New York Mets. But this time, before a crowd of 50,669 persons in Shea Stadium, it was the Mets who gave ground.
PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 3 Walter G. Seely, a lawyer who had been in practice here since 1924, died at his home here yesterday. He was 76 years old.
NAPLES, Fla., Aug. 3 Harold D. Shattuck, a former executive of the Schrafft's restaurant chain, and a son of its founder, died in the Naples Community Hospital today. He was 80 years old.

Dinah Shore, once a reigning singer of evening television, began a daily morning program for women at 10 o'clock yesterday on the National Broadcasting Company's network. If she accomplishes half of what she says she hopes to do in coming weeks, it may not be necessary to watch other shows.

Prime Minister Chichester-Clark stood up once again to extremists in his Unionist party by banning public parades and demonstrations in Northern Ireland for six months. Three days later, however, his order was flouted by Orangemen in a County Tyrone village while troops and police stood by. A disciple of the Protestant fanatic, the Rev. Ian Paisley, told a crowd of 2,000: "Remember this day the day we broke the ban."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 3 Secretary General Thant took the first step today toward new peace efforts in the Middle East, conferring on the United States cease-fire proposal with Secretary of State William P. Rogers and Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, Mr. Thant's special envoy in the Middle East.

All through the night the impasse remained. Many of the National Football League clubowners, weary after more than 12 hours of debate, napped in the Commissioner's private office on the 13th floor at 410 Park Avenue. Some flopped on the couch or in chairs, others sprawled on the beige carpet.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 3 (AP) Gov. James A. Rhodes announced today the state would direct a special grand jury inquiry into disorders at Kent State University last May.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 3 No Back Talk, owned by the High Rising Farm and ridden by Eddie Maple, won the Flash Stakes, the feature race of Saratoga's opening today, by 1 lengths. Boone the Great of the favored entry was second and Alfred G. Vanderbilt's Dundee Marmalada, also part of an entry, ran third.

Rollins, Inc., disclosed yesterday plans to repurchase for $22.5-million a $2.5-million note it issued to the Prudential Insurance Company of America in 1964 in connection with the purchase of the Orkin Exterminating Company.

TENAFLY, N.J., Aug. 3 The marriage of Miss Susan Helen Minkoff, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Minkoff of New York, to David French Feingold, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham D. Feingold of Brooklyn, took place here this morning. Leonard Karp, Leader of the American Ethical Union, performed the ceremony at his home.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 President Nixon asserted today that Charles Manson, a hippie cultist now on trial in California, "was guilty, directly or indirectly, of eight murders without reason."
Bob Hayes, star receiver of the Dallas Cowboys, is no longer a reluctant pro football warrior. He had a sudden change of mind yesterday after the players' strike was settled.

FAR HILLS, N.J., Aug. 3 Miss Elizabeth Macy Jones, a photographer for The Boston Globe, and Frank Landt Dennis Jr., a correspondent with The Christian Science Monitor's bureau in New York, plan to be married on Sept. 19.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Aug. 3 Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill won the medal in the 48th annual Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association championship tournament by two strokes today by scoring a 78 at the Bedford Golf and Tennis Club.
GENEVA, Aug. 3 The United States today submitted a plan for the internationalization of the ocean floor to the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of the Seabed.
The sharp decline in stock prices on the New York and American Stock Exchanges cast a shadow over trading in silver futures yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 The Administration's candor or lack of it in explaining its Vietnam troop withdrawal policies has become an issue in former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey's campaign for a Senate seat from Minnesota.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Five members of the Supreme Court have voluntarily filed declarations of their income from off-the-bench activities.
The city's biggest retailers, after becoming accustomed to a reluctant consumer during the year's first six months, experienced their worst month of the year in July.

The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation reported yesterday sharply lower earnings for the second quarter and the first half of 1970. But the company said it was "making progress" toward restructuring two military programs that would permit a solution of major contract differences with the Federal Government.

As part of a planned fourday demonstration in connection with the 25th anniversary of the atomic bombing of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, about 20 persons took part in a "live out" yesterday at the headquartersof the Atomic Energy Commission here.

BONN, Aug. 3 The West German research ship Meteor has returned from a North At lantic expedition with test results indicating that carbon monoxide concentrations at a depth of a fathom or two were 10 to 30 times greater than the normal content of the gas in the earth's atmosphere.

A booming local economy, which though slowing in growth is employing more people here each month, apparently is the prime cause of the inflation that is afflicting New Yorkers with greater severity than other urban Americans.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 3 Heavy fighting in the provincial capital of Kompong Thom entered its second day this morning as Vietcong and North Vietnamese troops pressed their apparent objective of occupying the town, 80, miles north of Pnompenh.

Participants in any of the three August bluefin tuna tournaments in Cape Cod waters will have an excellent chance of surpassing the world record rod-and-reel catch, officials of the Cape Cod Tuna Club, sponsor of one of the events, believe.

OXNARD, Calif. "Our food is not hot, just pleasantly spicy." Mrs. John Ramirez said as she prepared enchiladas, young cactus shoots, sopa seca or Spanish rice, and pinto beans in the kitchen of her ranch home here, 40 miles north of Los Angeles in lemon grove country.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 3 (AP) An Israeli warplane was shot down over Egyptian territory today during an Israeli attack on surface-to-air missile bases in the central sector of the Suez Canal, the military command announced, A spokesman said the plane had been hit by ground fire "maybe a missile."
LONDON, Aug. 3 (AP) Harold Wilson will receive almost $250,000 for the inside story of his six years as Prime Minister, The Sun reported today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Treasury bill rates rose at today's auction compared with last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

When winter storms freeze switches on the Long Island Railroad tracks, when highly touted new cars break down, when subway trains collide, when passengers are trapped in smoky fires, when fares go up and tolls fail to go down, when anyone is late...

In the long, lonely hours of early morning, Times Square changes. It ceases for a while to play its practiced role as glamour girl of the Western world. Predawn visitors see it in what amounts to its cold cream and curlers.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 3 "Sudden-death" landed in big-time tennis today amid the same kind of organized protest cries that greeted another shot fired 20 miles up the road two centuries ago.
VIENTIANE, Loas, Aug. 2 (UPI) A representative of the pro-Communist Pathet Lao forces handed new peace proposals to Premier Souvanna Phouma today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Joseph C. Swidler, chairman of the New York State Public Service Commission, suggested today that a 1 per cent Federal tax be imposed on all electric bills to finance research to make the technology of producing energy more compatible with environmental needs.
PARIS, Aug. 3 Jean Desses, a dominant figure of Paris high fashion for two decades, died yesterday in Greece after a long illness and was buried there today. He was 65 years old.

Governor Rockefeller, in one of the strongest antipollution statements he has made so far, said yesterday he thought people were "ready to slow down the pace of economic progress to protect the environment."
"Most wives watch football in self-defense" said Mrs. Lucille Waite of Chicago, but Mrs. Monie Pallats, an Atlanta housewife, plans to play offense.
ALBANY, Aug. 3 Governor Rockefeller today said he has directed his Secretary of State to prepare for voting registration this year of all persons between the ages of 18 and 21.
DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 3 Richard Ferriccio Bemporad died yesterday at his home, 8 Driftway Lane. His age was 80.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Walton Trafford Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kate Carroll Trafford, a senior at Skidmore, to the Rev. Andrew Donnan Smith, curate of Trinity Episcopal Church in Hartford.

HEMPSTEAD L.I., Aug. 3 Dave Herman didn't know all of the details of the agreement between the National Football League Players Association and the owners when he reported to Hofstra for the first New York Jets regular camp today but he was sure everything was in order.
HARTFORD, Aug. 3 City officials lifted a 9 P.M.-to5 A.M. curfew today but a state of emergency continued in this state capital after six days of street disorders.

TEL AVIV, Tuesday, Aug. 4 Premier Golda Meir's Government of National Unity broke up early this morning, when, by a vote of 117 to 112, the Central Committee of the Gahal faction, a nationalist right-wing group, decided to withdraw its six ministers in protest against the Cabinet's acceptance of the United States Middle-East peace initiative.
Merck Co. and the National Starch and Chemical Corporation announced the termination last night of merger negotiations between the two companies by mutual agreement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Yes, it was true. Chet Huntley had retired at a sacrifice of potential future gross income of (perhaps) millions. At the peak of celebritude Chet Huntley had retired.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 3 Hurricane Celia struck the Texas Gulf Coast today with 145-mile-an-hour winds and drenching rain, severely damaging this resort city and virtually destroying several towns on Corpus Christi Bay.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (Reuters) Output per man-hour rose by a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.1 per cent in the second quarter, the Bu reau of Labor Statistics said today.
DURANGO, Mexico, Aug. 3 (AP) Radioactive pieces of a United States research rocket that went awry on a test flight July 11 have been found in a Mexican meadow, military authorities reported today.
Mayor Lindsay dedicated a new $1.9-million station for the 109th Precinct yesterday in Flushing, Queens.

CHICAGO, Aug. 3 George Meany, president of the A.F.L.C.I.O., said today that what he called the Nixon Administration's "game plan" for overcoming inflation was not working and he warned that a further rise in unemployment was likely.
DENVER, Aug. 3 Following is the official transcript of President Nixon's remarks to the press in the Federal Office Building here today:

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 3 (AP) The Government refused today to give a "yes" or "no" to a leftist guerrilla demand that all political prisoners be released as ransom for two kidnapped foreign officials.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 (UPI) House farm leaders abruptly called off floor action on a new farm bill today. They said they wanted President's Nixon assurance that he would fight efforts to lower a committe-approved limit on annual farm payments.

Directors of the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation have approved a cost-cutting program in an effort to reduce operating expenses by $11-million a year by the end of this year, Darryl F. Zanuck, chairman, and Richard D. Zanuck, president, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 Army witnesses told Congress today that lethal nerve gas had been leaking from many of the rockets scheduled to be dumped into the Atlantic this month.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 3 (UPI) All eight seeded players advanced to the second round in the men's United States national amateur clay-court championships at the Tennis Club of Rochester.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 A divided Open Market Committee voted in early May, on the heels of the Cambodian campaign and general uncertainty in the money markets, to aim at a somewhat faster pace of growth in the money supply. The Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee also decided at its meeting of May 5, to give its agent in the Government securities markets more leeway than usual.

It was D for Deadline Day at Bonwit Teller yesterday, and most of the female employes in the public eye bowed to the store's request that they wear the midi-length skirt. Some did so against their wishes and did not hesitate to say so.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 3 Just when it appeared that Manager Ralph Houk had put together the pieces that are the Yankees for a sustained move toward first place along came a stubborn stand by Milwaukee yesterday to slow the New Yorkers momentum.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Aug. 3 Massive busing of students to achieve desegregation in Charlotte-Mecklenburg County public schools will be required according to an order handed down here today by Federal District Judge James B. McMillan.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 3 (UPI) Maj. Frank Green of the Air Force tallied an 891 out of a possible 900 points in the four .22-caliber matches today to take the lead in the national pistol championships.
The Chrysler Corporation announced yesterday that it had tentatively increased prices of 1971-model trucks by an average of $98, or 3.8 per cent, over similarly equipped 1970 models.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 3 A fight has broken out within the Senate Banking and Currency Committee over a bill to combat tax evasion, stock fraud and other forms of white collar crime committed under the cover of secret Swiss bank accounts.

Few players are acknowledged to be in the top flight in both rubber bridge and tournament play. One member of that elite group is Jeremy Flint, an Englishman who made a great impact on this side of the Atlantic in 1966. He played with Peter Pender of San Francisco for a nine-month period, and they finished in the top two places in the McKenney Trophy contest, which depends on master points won in tournaments.

The United Parcel Service prepared to resume deliveries in northern New Jersey yesterday after members of Teamster Local 177, which struck the company's Secaucus terminal Monday, agreed to return to work with an assurance they could wear American flag pins on their uniforms.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 Austin Brown, a former partner in Dean Witter Co., the brokerage house, died here Saturday. He was 73 years old, and lived in Walnut Creek, Calif.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The director of the supersonic transport program conceded today that there were two major uncertainties about the potential atmospheric effects of supersonic airliner operations.

In the wake of its third fire within a week, the Penn Central announced yesterday that all trains using Grand Central Terminal were scheduled to have two-way radios for quick communication installed by November.

The latest in education and training equipment, much of it plugged in and faintly humming, was put on display yesterday at the sixth annual American Management Association conference on education and training.

Senator Eugene J. McCarthy gave his endorsement yesterday to Arthur J. Goldberg, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, and Representative Richard L. Ottinger, Democratic candidate for United States Senator.

Southern University of Louisiana and North Carolina Agricultural and Technical College, two football powerhouses among predominantly black schools, will meet in the third annual invitation game at Yankee Stadium Friday night, Sept. 11.
The Anaconda Company reported yesterday a sharp drop in earnings for the quarter and six months ended June 30, reflecting nationalization of Chilean copper properties and lower sales and revenues.

Commonwealth United Overseas, N.V., the foreign financing arm of the Commonwealth United Corporation, the onceglamourous mini-conglomerate that has been trying to make a corporate comeback, failed this week to make an interest payment of $862,500 on a $30-million bond issue sold in Europe, the trustee for the issue said yesterday.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 4 (UPI) Francis Higginson, a warrant officer in the Marines, scored 887 out of 900 points today, won the center-fire title and moved into first place in the national pistol championships with a two-day total of 1,775 points.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug 4 Sidney K. Lawrence, a lawyer for the State Department of Labor, died of cancer yesterday at White Plains Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived here and in Chappaquiddick, Mass.

Even though Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Nogueira of Plymouth, Mass., have six children of their own, they are having two young guests this summer, instead of one, at their ranch home overlooking Plymouth Harbor.
ROME, Aug. 4 Italy's four center-left parties agreed separately tonight to revive their coalition, which has ruled the country for the last seven years.

CAIRO, Aug. 5 Despite the clamor of Arab extremists against the United States initiative, there were indications here today that the Egyptian leadership would not allow itself to be intimidated into refusal.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 4 Ambassador Jarring held the first round of talks today in the new drive for a settlement in the Middle East.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 (UPI) The number of alienated young people is much greater than most people believe, and a "speed-up" of the educational system will be a prime need as their numbers grow, a Presidential commission was told today.
If coal and gas production lose ground at a time when the nation's energy requirements are soaring, what's to fill the gap?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Ever since President Jefferson announced that Aaron Burr was guilty of treason in the Gen. James Wilkinson conspiracy case (he was later acquitted), Presidents of the United States have been in trouble over careless or ill-considered public remarks.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The White House insisted today that United States aircraft were flying only "interdiction" missions against enemy forces in Cambodia.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 4 Crosby T. Smith, who retired as vice president of the First National City Bank in 1965, died today at the Yale New Haven Hospital. He was 64 years old, and lived on West Road in New Canaan.

The new union contract covering paraprofessionals in the public school system ranks among the most significant steps ever taken in this city to overcome poverty and to build more cooperative relations between the ghetto areas and the schools.

How can the city's Environmental Protection Administration say the projected new electric power plant at Astoria, Queens, would increase air pollution while Consolidated Edison contends pollution would be decreased?
Robert L. Park, an examiner for the Civil Aeronautics Board, recommended yesterday in Washington the board's approval of the merger of Northeast Airlines into Northwest Airlines.
WEST POINT, Miss., Aug. 4 A Negro ran second in a special election here today for Mayor. A runoff between the two leading candidates is slated for Aug. 18.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 4 (AP) Senator Stuart Symington easily defeated four political unknowns in the Democratic primary today to win renomination for a fourth term, and State Attorney General John C. Danforth captured the Republican senatorial spot.

The strategy of the Federal Reserve System for controlling inflation calls for holding the rate of growth in total demand for goods and services below the economy's over-all growth potential through the end of 1971, an official spokesman for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York said here yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Maynard B. Barnes, a former Foreign Service officer, died at his home in Georgetown, Sunday. He was 72 years old.
DETROIT, Wednesday, Aug. 5 Mrs. George Romney scored an apparent primary election victory yesterday in her bid to become the Republican Senate candidate from Michigan.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 The Ford Motor Company said today that it was developing an ignition system connected to its auto lap belts that would prevent a car from starting unless the belts, a safety device, were fastened.
The United States Steel Corporation on Oct. 1 will increase the price of tin mill products, widely used in the canning of food and beverages.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 4 The improved Cleveland Indians, again demonstrating they were very much at home in their tailored "mini-park," gave the Yankees a hostile welcome tonight as they posted a 6-1 victory in the opener of a two-game series.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 4 (AP) President Alfredo Ovando Candia received the resignation of his Cabinet today after three weeks of political crisis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Sweeping authority for President Nixon to suspend in the national interest any quotas set up by the pending trade bill has won preliminary committee agreement, informed persons said today.
BUFFALO, Aug. 4 (AP) William Sadler of suburban Hamburg, a Republican Assemblyman from 1951 to 1964, died at his home yesterday at the age of 79.
The California-Western States Life Insurance Company announced yesterday in Sacramento that it had elected Harold S. Hook, 38 years old, as its president.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 (AP) A $3-billion antitrust suit was filed today in United States District Court charging five major Chicago banks with conspiracy to fix the price of consumer credit in Illinois.

LISBON, Aug. 4 The Portuguese opposition leader, Mario Soares, has been forced into exile once again. The authorities gave him eight hours to get out of the country, to which he had returned for his father's funeral, or face arrest.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 4 City officials charged, and a Federal official confirmed today, that Syracuse had been named one of the 10 dirtiest cities in the nation on the basis of readings from a single measuring device set up 25 yards from a highway construction project.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The Agriculture Department informed the Shell Oil Corporation today that it will cancel registration in 30 days for the concern's household pesticide, No Pest Strip, if the label is not changed.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The Quaker Oats Company, using the same system employed by a nutritionist who criticized the breakfast-cereal industry two weeks ago, offered its own listing today to rebut the critic's contentions that most of the cereals were low in nutritional value.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 4 Communist soldiers reportedly captured Robert S. Anson, a 25-year-old reporter for Time magazine, as he was driving alone late yesterday afternoon in the Cambodian countryside 34 miles north of Pnompenh.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4 The Fourth Estate Stable's Free Press won his second straight race at Liberty Bell Race Track today by defeating Mrs. W.R. Harris's 9-5 favorite, Tillquest, by a nose in the feature race.
LONDON, Wednesday, Aug. 5 The Daily Telegraph reported today that a British naval patrol that has been enforcing trade sanctions against Rhodesia will be ended shortly.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The Senate voted unanimously today to put an end to the longstanding and politically popular practice of permitting members of Congress to announce the award of defense contracts.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The Senate Banking and Currency Committee passed today a bill designed to stop the affluent from using secret Swiss bank accounts to commit tax evasion, stock frauds and other white collar crimes.
At least two managers in the National League's Eastern Division feel the St. Louis Cardinals still can win the title in the National League's Eastern Division.
Garbage collection is being reduced from a schedule of three times a week to twice a week for thousands of families in many sections of the city.
ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 4 Astute political footwork and martial law seem to have stabilized, at least for the moment, the position of Premier Suleyman Demirel.
Nolan Ryan, who may be the most spectacular part-time employe in baseball, pitched the New York Mets to a 4-0 victory over the Chicago Cubs yesterday before 42,786 persons in Shea Stadium.
A random sampling of the men who operate and maintain the city's subways shows that they say that the system is safe, despite shoddy equipment, too-short training programs and a lack of manpower.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of Brooklyn, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said today that he would continue his investigation of Justice William O. Douglas but would not respond to some Congressional critics who had called the inquiry a farce."

The Midsummer Serenades of Lincoln Center, operating this time under the cutesy title of "A Mostly Mozart Festival," opened its August series Monday night in Philharmonic Hall. The opening program lived up to its title.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 4 (AP) Sharp fighting was reported today in the Mekong Delta 42 miles southwest of Saigon, where Government troops said they had killed 44 enemy soldiers in a day-long battle.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) American sources say an aerial clash between Soviet and Israeli pilots was disclosed to the Israeli Knesset (Parliament) on July 27 but was hushed up by the Israeli Government.
ALBANY, Aug. 4 The State Education Commissioner has ruled that a woman teacher may continue to wear a bikini bathing suit while giving swimming instructions to junior high school boys.

TOKYO, Aug. 4 Within the next several weeks, Japan will start sharing in the control of many of the military bases the United States operates in the country, according to the minister in charge of Japanese defense.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 4 (UPI) Charles H. Kendrick, civic leader and former head of the Schlage Lock Company, died last night. He was 93 years old.

Robert Angelus caught a plane last night for Akron, Ohio, so he could be on tap early tomorrow for the opening of the American Golf Classic. But he's not a professional on the tour his 10 handicap is not quite good enough nor is he merely a devoted fan of the sport.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 4 Judge Harold M. Mulvey denied today a defense request that he bar George Sams Jr. from testifying in the Lonnie McLucas trial on the ground that Sams was insane.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The breakfast cereal industry defended itself today against charges that two-thirds of its products are nutritionally deficient.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 4 The latest chapter in a tragic story that began with the death of 12 persons in a Yonkers fire in 1965 began to unfold in a courtroom here last week.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Israeli planes were in action throughout the morning against Egyptian military objectives along the Suez Canal, an army spokesman said.
LONDON, Aug. 4 (AP) Britain's monetary reserves rose by $4.8-million in July, the first full month under the new Conservative Government, the Treasury announced today.

NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 4 (Agence France-Presse) East and Central African foreign ministers from four Commonwealth states met here today for three hours to work out "a common front" on the possible resumption of arms sales to South Africa by Britain.

President Alfredo Ovando Candia of Bolivia seems to be at the point where he must choose between the conservative military elements that supported his rise to power and the leftist-reformist forces whose rhetoric he often employs. After his Cabinet resigned yesterday, General Ovando insisted that he would maintain "a national leftist line."

When the Senate considers putting up an additional $290 million for the supersonic transport plane, it will have before it the warning of a scientific study group bluntly recommending that the entire program be delayed until scientists can determine the probable effect of the SST on the world's atmosphere.

A program to train young Harlem residents, even those with "mild" police records, to take Police Department entrance examinations was announced yesterday by the Harlem-East Harlem Model Cities Office.
ROCHESTER, Aug. 4 (AP) Dick Stockton of Garden City, L.I., advanced to the third round of the United States claycourt championship today, but Steve Turner of New York was eliminated.
ALBANY, Aug. 4 Governor Rockefeller today ordered the State Department of Health to scour the country for a substance to uncover hepatitis germs in blood used for transfusions.
TOKYO, Aug. 4 (UPI) The Japanese Cabinet today issued a regulation requiring all factories dumping large amounts of waste into rivers to register with the Government.

PARIS, Aug. 4 Qualified military sources predicted today that France's nuclear production team would be able to provide hydrogen bombs for French forces by 1972, or at least three years earlier than official Government forecasts have indicated.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 President Nixon's comment on Charles Manson yesterday has given the White House the jitters, aroused the legal fraternity, and has Manson's lawyers demanding a mistrial. But what fascinates observers here is what the episode tells about Mr. Nixon's mood and behavior,...

For years the Under Secretary of State has been the day-in, day-out manager of the bulk of United states foreign policy business and the diplomatic establishment that carries it out. For nearly two months that job has been vacant.
An independent consulting concern has recommended expanding the city's More Effective Schools program, a controversial effort to improve the education of children from disadvantaged homes.
CHICAGO, Aug. 4 The executive council of the A.F.L.C.I.O. accused Attorney General John N. Mitchell today of seeking to silence the American trade union movement for purely political purposes.

NEWPORT. R.I., Aug. 4 Miss Anne Fairchild Pendleton Bowler and Montgomery Meigs Smith were married here this afternoon. The ceremony was performed by Canon Lockett F. Ballard in Trinity Episcopal Church, where the bride's great-greatgrandparents were married in 1750.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 4 Premier Golda Meir spelled out a firm Israeli position today for proposed peace talks with the United Arab Republic, but declared that Israel's acceptance of the United States peace initiative was unconditional.

QUINCY, Mass., Aug. 4 (AP) Marshall E. Turnbaugh of York Beach, Me., a pioneer Navy and civilian developer of nuclear submarine and surface ship power plants, died last night at his apartment, apparently of a heart attack. He was 54 years old.
Ted Black, a former band leader and music company executive, died at the Lutheran Medical Center in Brooklyn on Friday of a heart attack. He was 70 years old and lived at 9511 Shore Road, Brooklyn.
DUBROVNIK, Yugoslavia, Aug. 4 There are a few Eupean music and drama festivals that can match Dubrovnik for the sheer beauty and excitement of its settings, but none that can surpass it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Senator J.W. Fulbright said today that the balance in American Government would be effectively destroyed unless Congress could command automatic access to network television the same access that the President now enjoys by informal courtesy of the broadcasting industry.

ROME, Aug. 4 (AP) A 35year-old housewife, childless for 11 years of marriage, gave birth today to sextuplets. The three boys and three girls were put into incubators and doctors said all appeared in good condition.

BROOKVILLE, L.I. Aug. 4 "We're football players, not negotiators," said Greg Larson, the player representative of the New York Giants. "We're glad to be playing. This way, we can release our emotions."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Consumer installment credit rose a seasonally adjusted $441million in June, somewhat above the $415-million May increase, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
BORDEAUX, France, Aug. 4 (Reuters) A tornado battered the coast of southwest France today, killing at least 9 persons and injuring 20, with 11 persons reported missing.

The heads of two of the city's superagencies clashed yesterday over the proposed Astoria electric plant one holding it necessary to assure power reliability for a goal of creating 300,000 jobs in a decade, the other charging it would create an "asthma alley."
LONDON, Aug. 4 The Grand Palais was packed once. By 8 o'clock, the audience had swarmed through the mirrored lobby and was sitting noisily in the red plush seats.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 4 (AP) Paul Brown, coach and general manager of the Cincinnati Bengals, criticized today the National Football League commissioner, Pete Rozelle, for granting negotiators for the Players Association additional time to report to their teams.

ALGIERS, Aug. 4 (AP) Sonatrach, the Algerian national petroleum company, and the Phillips Petroleum Company said today that agreement had been reached on the indemnity to be paid to Phillips for the nationalization of its Algerian holdings.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) A new ceremonial entrance to the west wing of the White House was used today for the first time when President Nixon greeted General Mobutu.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 4 Richard F. Selig, chairman of the board and president of Piser Furniture Company, at Third Avenue and 150th Street in the Bronx, died of a heart attack Sunday at White Plains Hospital. He was 61 years old and lived in Mamaroneck.
Citing recent accidents in which three subway riders died, the Democratic majority leadership of the City Council announced plans yesterday for a special investigation of subway safety.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 4 An investigation by the Internal Revenue Service of Victor Frenkil, chief executive of Baltimore Contractors, Inc., was disclosed today in papers filed in Federal Court here.

PARIS, Aug. 4 Almost a year after France acknowledged her critical financial condition by devaluing the franc, the Government has virtually lifted exchange controls for individuals as one sign of recovery.

ASPEN, Colo. The coming superpower is not China but Japan which, by late this century or early next one, will possess the largest gross national product in the world. Such is the considered opinion of Herman Kahn, futurologist and director of the Hudson Institute, in his forthcoming book, "The Emerging Japanese Superstate; Challenge and Response" (Prentice-Hall, publishers).

PARIS, Wednesday, Aug. 5 (Reuters) The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that the rate of growth of the Canadian economy next year would probably be well below its potential and that undevelopment could rise to about 6 per cent by December. The 21-nation organization was reporting on the outlook for the Canadian economy during the next 12 months.
Stock prices moved lower in moderate trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

The Board of Elections is scheduled to consider today a proposal to eliminate 16,000 election inspector jobs during voter registration periods. Three of the four board members indicated yesterday that they would support the proposed cut.
