MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 4 Cris de Murias of the Babylon Yacht Culb finished the series with a flourish today in capturing the Picken Trophy emblematic of the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's medget sailing championship. De Murias was the winner of the final event of the sevenrace series. That gave him three first places.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) The president and the secretary-treasurer of the United Mine Workers District 5 were indicted today on charges of conspiracy and the filing of false expense vouchers and financial reports.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 4 The first sign that something is wrong shows up a full 50 miles north of here at a little farm town called Refugio.

More than 1,000 people each donated a pint of blood yesterday at the seventh annual Actors Fund Blood Donor Day at the Imperial and Golden Theaters on West 45th Street. Each donor received two tickets to a Broadway or Off Broadway show.

SAN FRANCISCO Just as brides register for china and glass at Tiffany's, out here they register at WilliamsSonoma for pots and pans. And cooks amateur and professional, including such experts as James Beard send in orders by mail from around the world for kitchen utensils they can't find elsewhere.
GENEVA, Aug. 4 (Reuters) France and Britain today suggested two alternatives to a United States proposal for exploiting mineral resources of international seabeds.
INDEPENDENCE, Mo., Aug. 4 (AP) Former President Harry S. Truman, making one of his rare public appearances, voted today in Missouri's primary election.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) AAMCO Automatic Transmissions, Inc., denied today Federal Trade Commission charges that it had forced holders of its franchises to engage in deceptive trade practices.

LONDON, Aug. 4 In the first scene of Christopher Hampton's "The Philanthropist" at the Royal Court Theater, a boy blows his brains out against the back wall. In the second we learn that the entire British cabinet has been machinegunned down in the House of Commons.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. Billy Walker Jr. strode back and forth under his tent, a hand microphone close to his mouth, his face dripping with perspiration and his voice hoarse from two solid hours of singing and preaching.
TOPEKA, Kan., Aug. 4 (AP) Attorney General Kent Frizzell won the Republican nomination for Governor in today's primary.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Circumstantial evidence has persuaded some United States officials that Soviet pilots engaged in aerial combat against Israeli planes in the Suez Canal region last Thursday, but other officials regard the evi- dence as too flimsy for such a judgment.

Problems with their players are far from over for the pro football owners. They now must negotiate individual contracts with more than 300 of the 1,200 seasoned professionals who are in training camp but unsigned.
SAVANNAH, Ga., Aug. 4 (UPI) Wayne Ray of Galveston, Tex., outlasted a group of marksmen to win the world 26-gauge skeet-shooting championship at the Forest City Gun Club today.

Michael Hall Thomas, president of Cartier, Inc., the jewelers, and Mrs. Jeanne Beaupre McGowan of Fort Worth were married at his apartment here on Sunday. Criminal Court Judge Milton Shalleck performed the ceremony.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Military personnel who recently served in Cambodia would be entitled to the special tax benefits received by service personnel in combat areas, under a proposed change in tax regulations announced today by the Treasury Department.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The Senate approved today an appropriation bill $541-million higher than President Nixon's budget request. There were indications that Mr. Nixon would ...

TRENTON, Aug. 4 State officials, announcing a new drive to eliminate foul odors over northern New Jersey's industrial heartland, charged nine industrial giants today with contributing to air pollution.

Two summers ago it was virtually unheard of. Last summer it was mainly confined to the Bethesda Fountain, the East Village and Washington Square Park. But now, as anybody who has been out walking on a warm summer day can plainly see, the braless look has established a beachhead in Manhattan.
The world's largest auto insurer, the State Farm Mutual Automobile Insurance Company, reported yesterday a substantial improvement in auto insurance business but an over-all loss on investments.

Features from France, Italy, West Germany, Great Britain, Brazil, Sweden and India are among the first 10 movies selected for showing at the eighth annual New York Film festival. It will be held Sept. 10 to 20 under the auspices of the Film Society of Lincoln Center at Philharmonic Hall, with some screenings scheduled for Alice Tully Hall. The festival's special events program will continue through Sept. 30.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Supreme Court Justice William O. Douglas filed a public report of his off-the-bench activities today, disclosing that he received $20,568.10 in the first six months of this year from his lectures, articles and books.
DALLAS, Aug. 4 (UPI) The Earth Resources Company said it has a "firm commitment" for an $8-million term loan to finance its Nacimiento copper mine in New Mexico.
The American Stock Exchange ended on the fence yesterday after stepped-up buying in the afternoon erased earlier losses.
Just when it appears that there is nothing else that could possibly take a designer signature, along comes Saks Fifth Avenue with a group of signed designs in needlepoint pillows.

DETROIT, Aug. 4 (AP) The Chevrolet Division of the General Motors Corporation has announced the recall of about 3,300 1970 Chevrolet station wagons to replace a possibly defective load rest attachment in the bumper jack.

Mrs. Randolph Franklin Hall of Southampton, L.I., and Henry Anthony Barclay of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mrs. Susan LeFevre Barclay Gaines, to Stephen Ely. He is the son of Mrs. Sterling Ely of Washington and Provincetown, Mass., and the late Mr. Ely.

Irish International Airlines (Aer Lingus) has come to a parting of the ways with Lennen Newell, Inc. Tom Kennedy, director of public relations and advertising for the airline, said that the decision, "reached with real regret," was based on a conflict of interest with another current Lennen Newell airlines client World Airlines.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 President Nixon welcomed President Joseph D. Mobutu of the Congo to the White House today for a conversation that lasted almost two hours.

A Westchester man, formerly executive vice president of the Realty Equities Corporation, was fined $10,000 yesterday for having sold a note to a Boston financier in violation of the "kickback" section of the Investment Company Act.

New York's apartment squeeze has forced the Department of Social Services to house 40 per cent more welfare clients this summer in hotels, often at premium rates, a spokesman for the department said yesterday.
Frank's Restaurant a gathering place for politicians, city officials, businessmen and visitors to Harlem is for sale.
Another member of a group of Oklahoma businessmen who lent securities to bolster the capital of Hayden, Stone, Inc., has withdrawn the securities and substituted cash.
A former Queens College lecturer in biology, described by a Federal prosecutor as "a major supplier of marijuana" on that campus, was held in $24,000 bail yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (UPI) President Nixon made it known today that he preferred a limit of no less than $55,000 a crop annually on Government subsidies to farmers, and the House soon afterward began debate on a previously stalled farm bill.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 4 Native Partner, the experienced stakes performer owned by Ralph Wilson, waged a splendid stretch drive to win the feature event on today's Saratoga program.
"I think," says Myron Cohen, "an ideal subway system is one that is safe, reliable, cool in the summer and warm in the winter, quiet and not uncomfortably crowded."

Mrs. Jane Gutman Sachs, who was active in a number of charitable organizations, died of heart failure Monday night at her home, 875 Park Avenue, after a year's illness. She was 57 years old and was the wife of Henry N. Sachs, an insurance executive.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Senate action on President Nixon's controversial welfare reform program will be delayed still further, almost certainly until after the fall election and possibly until next year.

Speaking extemporaneously on important issues can be a dangerous practice for any President, as President Nixon proved Monday with his assertion that one of the defendants in the Sharon Tate murder case "was guilty, directly or indirectly, of eight murders without reason."

MOSCOW, Aug. 4 West German sources said today that Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union had assured Foreign Minister Walter Scheel that the Kremlin recognized the principle of eventual unification of Germany by peaceful means.
BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 4 It was a cool, clear evening, but Clark Graebner seldom has been hotter.

Valentine E. Macy Jr., philanthropist and former president of the Macy newspapers in Westchester and Rockland Counties, now part of the Gannett chain, died yesterday in his apartment at 115 East 67th Street. He was 72 years old and maintained his main residence in East Hampton, L.I.
The bond market ambled along yesterday, trying to get a better idea where it is headed.

As Bowery residents scattered out of the line of gunfire, a battle between a narcotics detective and a suspected drug dealer ended with both men shot and a bystander nicked in the leg by a bullet yesterday afternoon.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 4 While the New York Jets slowly put together their roster today, Joe Namath, their star quarterback, wasn't to be found at the training camp and his whereabouts remained a mystery to the club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Two former Federal officials said today that they foresaw in the South widespread defiance of integration, flourishing private segregated schools for whites, increasing resegregation and violence as the result of desegregation policies of the Nixon Administration.
A Self-help Sanitation Service got under way in the South Bronx yesterday with city officials voicing optimism and community residents, hired as sanitation aides, complaining of a lack of equipment.
The Witco Chemical Corporation said yesterday it would phase out its operations at Franklin, Pa.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 The Maritime Administration opened bids today on ships anchored in the Hudson River in a mothball fleet that is being phased out this year.
YONKERS, Aug. 4 With 234 driving victories already in hand this year, the national driving champion, Herve Filion of Canada is well on his way to top his record of 407 winners recorded last year.
Yesterday was the sort of summer day that one rememhers from childhood, but it wasn't just nostalgia: It really was a nearly perfect specimen of the way a summer day ought to be.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 4 High on a hilltop, with breathtaking views of both Jerusalem and Bethlehem, is the headquarters of the United Nations Truce Supervision Organization.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 4, Miss Anne Louise Drake, a buyer of radio and television time with Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, the advertising agency in New York, and Richard Stephan Koffey, a lawyer with Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer Wood, New York law firm, will be married here Sept. 27.
BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 5 Chantilly scored 15 points and won the small pony hunter championship tonight at the Sussex County Horse Show. That have Sindy Paul a one, two finish.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 5 Premier Muammar el-Qaddafi returned tonight from a futile effort to heal the breach between Iraq and the United Arab Republic over the United States plan for a settlement with Israel.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 4 Charles M. Manson held up before the jury today a newspaper with the headline "Manson Guilty, Nixon Declares" and forced a halt in testimony at the Tate murder trial.
Borough President Abe Stark of Brooklyn, the senior member of the Board of Estimate, is expected to resign within the next month because of failing health.

A Brooklyn burglary victim said yesterday that he had caught a suspect, taken him by the arm to a police station and they had been told by a detective that the suspect could not be arrested because "this is the wrong precinct."

The three national television networks released yesterday a study reporting that they could save from 25 to 35 per cent in the cost of distributing their programs either by means of a domestic satellite system or by a specialized microwave relay system on the ground. They now use the facilities of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 4 (Reuters) Following is the text of Israel's reply to the American proposal for peace in the Middle East, as forwarded to Washington today:

ROCKFORD, Ill., Aug. 4 (AP) The Sundstrand Corporation announced today it planned to enter the automatic truck transmission field and said it would build a manufacturing plant in Ames, Iowa, for a new hydromechanical unit.

Theodore Rosenberg, the 17year old judge's son whose father arranged a special arraignment for him and three friends after their arrest last June on drug charges, was accepted for counseling yesterday by the city's Youth Counsel Bureau.
John W.A. Kelley, a lawyer for nearly 65 years, died yesterday in his home at 155 East 76th Street. He was 90 years old.
Jesse S. Moore, who ran the shop-at-home service division at Gimbel's, died yesterday at his home in Scarsdale. He was 73 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 Senator Edmund S. Muskie suggested today that proposed regulations on oil spills drawn by the Department of the Interior could enable spillers to circumvent the intent of Congress and possibly escape penalties.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) A distributor of books on explosives and guerrilla warfare told a Senate panel today that he felt no more responsible for their misue than General Motors should if its cars were used by terrorists on the way to bombings.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 4 (AP) The Cambodian command reported today that its troops drove hundreds of North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers out of the provincial capital Kompong Thom yesterday after three days of fighting.

MOUNT PLEASANT, N.Y., Aug. 4 A warrant was issued today for the arrest of the driver whose bus carrying 36 children and camp counselors crashed Sunday. The police said the driver had given a false name.

There was only one successful buyer at the Government's weekly silver auction yesterday. It turned out to be a persistent British firm, Sharps-Pixley Co. of London, a large buyer over a period of time.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 4 (AP) Gov. Claude R. Kirk, Jr. of Florida said today that he would seek a court injunction if necessary to stop the Army from dumping obsolete nerve gas rockets into the Atlantic Ocean some 280 miles off Cape Kennedy.
Working their way out of an early decline, stock prices closed mixed yesterday in another session of relatively slow trading.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 4 They called her "Rain Enchanteur" as they hovered around the paddock area, four and five deep, trying to get a look at Reine Enchanteur, the world's most expensive filly who was making her first start today at Monmouth Park.

OSLO, Aug. 5 (AP) Ron Clarke of Australia finished sixth in the 10,000-meter race at the Bislet meet tonight, but the world record-holder was given a warm and sentimental farewell by 13,500 spectators.

Former Deputy Chief Charles J. Freeman, who had been president of the Uniformed Fire Officers Association, died yesterday in St. Luke's Hospital of lung cancer. He was 60 years old and lived at 1635 Plymouth Avenue, the Bronx.

Like the municipal transportation system it will investigate, New York's City Council has arrived late in assuming its responsibility. Now that three passengers have been killed in a rash of recent subway accidents, scores injured and thousands inconvenienced, the Council will roll out its investigative powers and begin an overdue inquiry.
While 500 guests slept early yesterday morning, three armed men spent more than an hour rubbing 17 strongboxes and a small safe in the lobby of the Regency Hotel.

Moore-McCormack Lines announced yesterday that it would sell its four newest freighters forming the "Seabridge" class to American Export Isbrandtsen Lines for $38.4-million. The sale has been approved by the boards of both companies but is subject to execution of a final contract and the final approval of the Maritime Administration.
NASHVILLE, Aug. 5 Tennessee voters, possibly a million of them, will select tomorrow their Democratic and Republican nominees for Governor, United States Senator and a host of other offices.
Gretel II, Australia's wouldbe America's Cup challenger, is scheduled to leave Philadelphia tonight for Providence, R.I., aboard the freighter New York Star.
LOS ALAMOS, N.M., Aug. 5 The fences are down now around the secret atomic city gone for 13 years and the old guardhouse on the road from Santa Fe has been turned into a restaurant.

A soft-spoken baldish 31year-old man in colorful hippie garb drove to the exclusive Four Seasons restaurant yesterday afternoon in a white horsedrawn carriage and proceeded to distribute money in the form of bills in varied denominations, coins and personal checks to passers-by, customers at the bar and employes.

BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 5 Act I, who has developed into one of the divisional stars this year, captured the first open jumper class at the Sussex County horse show today, defeating four rivals in a jumpoff.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 Mr. and Mrs. John Erwin Hollis have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Slocumb Davis Hollis, to Edward Lee Perry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Dean Perry of Shaker Heights and Mill Pond Plantation in Thomasville, Ga.

LEE, Mass., Aug. 5 The First Chamber Dance Company, founded in the early 1960's to bring technically strong classical ballet to smaller communities, is entering the seventies by adding substantial choreographic weight of its repertory.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The President's chief adviser on the environment gave a cautious endorsement today to the Army's plan to dispose of 12,540 rockets containing nerve gas by dumping them into the Atlantic Ocean.
Sugar futures, which dropped sharply a week ago on news of larger-than-expected world sugar production, moved up strongly yesterday to recover most of the loss.
BEL AIR, Calif., Aug 5 Miss Karen Therese Connelly and William C. Donovan will be married Aug. 29 in St. Paul's Roman Catholic Church in Westwood.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 The Ford Motor Company announced today that it was tentatively raising 1971 car and truck prices by more than 5 per cent. This will be the sharpest price increase in recent years, if it holds.
A small Philadelphia manufacturer of burglar alarms has found yet another legal way to cut into the oncesacrosanct territory of the telephone company.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y. Rose Fama's cooking, an acquaintance said recently, falls into the category of the superb, "Her husband, Michael," the friend added, "makes a hearty and excellent dry white wine in their cellar, and he uses not a hand crank but a machine of his own devising for pressing the grapes.

Dr. Percy Wells Bidwell, former director of studies of the Council on Foreign Relations and author of books on foreign trade policy, died Tuesday at his home, 3030 Park Avenue, Bridgeport, Conn. He was 82 years old and formerly lived in Hartsdale, N.Y.

Mayor and Mrs. Lindsay were hosts to 160 wounded Vietnam veterans yesterday at a lawn party at Gracie Mansion the first reception Mr. Lindsay has given Vietnam veterans in his four and one half years as Mayor.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The presidents of the three commercial television networks said today they would consider new, voluntary means of balancing their coverage of Congress and the President possibly including grants of prime evening time in which Congress could pick its spokesmen, issues and format.
OAKLAND, Aug. 5 Huey P. Newton, the Black Panther minister of defense who was found guilty of shooting an Oakland policeman nearly two years ago, was released from prison today.

State Controller Arthur Levitt recommended yesterday that the city consider maintaining apartments for temporarily housing welfare clients who have been made homeless by fires and other disasters. He said the city could save "substantial" sums by doing so instead of putting them up in hotels.
A West Point senior has asked the Army for a discharge as a conscientious objector, the first such request to have been made by a student at the United States Military Academy.

A piano recital in which Ravel's "Hommage a Haydn" balanced "Blues for Art Tatum," a Scarlatti sonata followed "Tea for Two," and "St. James Infirmary" was cheek by jowl with a Chopin polonaise was given Tuesday evening at the Library and Museum of Lincoln Center.
LIMA, Ohio, Thursday, Aug. 6 A black woman was shot to death by the police last night, touching off a wave of violence that led to the cordoning off of a 12-block area on the Negro Near South Side.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 5 Frances Carter, the 21-year-old secretary of the local Black Panther chapter, was set free today after a 15-month legal battle for bail and against a contempt order.

MOUNT PLEASANT N.Y. Aug, 5 The vice president of a transit company whose bus crashed Monday, injuring 14 camp-bound children and a counselor, was arrested today on charges of allowing an un- licensed operator to drive the bus.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 5 Edward Robinson Jr., a retired Supreme Court Justice in Nassau County, L.I., died in a hospital here yesterday. He was 70 years old and had moved here from Oyster Bay, L.I., after his retirement two years ago.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 5 One of Premier Lon Nol's closest advisers said today that the Cambodian Government could last only six months more without important military and economic aid, principally from the United States.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) For the 20th consecutive month, more people redeemed United States Savings Bonds than purchased them, according to Treasury Department figures published today.
Miss Mary Claudel Lallande, an associate editor of Glamour magazine, and Clinton Jansen Kendrick, who is with the Stuyvesant Asset Management Corporation here, plan to be married in October.
An $11-million low-income housing rehabilitation project one of the largest in the city's history was started in Harlem yesterday in a joint venture by black and white contractors.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 5 (Reuters) The conference of the so-called Arab confrontation countries opened here today after a two-day delay during which Premier Muammar el-Qaddafi of Libya tried unsuccessfully to persuade the Iraqis to end their boycott of the meeting.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 5 (UPI) The youngest member of the Presidential Commission on Student Unrest has a commission of his own to keep the investigation honest.
STAMFORD, Conn. Ranan Lurie has no intention of becoming an interior decorator. On the other hand, he wonders if there won't be problems for buyers of his unusual paintings if he doesn't.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Aug. 5 For the first time at any unit of the State university, a professional theatrical company, made up solely of graduates, is in residence on the campus of Nassau Community College.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 We went to the seashore and saw the strange things Americans do there. One evening in a luminous foggy twilight, for example, there were several Americans standing at the ocean's edge holding long sticks.
PARIS, Aug. 5 (UPI) The Chase Manhattan Corporation of New York has become the first American banking concern to win a listing on the Paris Bourse, people in financial circles reported today.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 5 (Reuters) In accepting the American Middle East peace proposal, Jordan has insisted that Israel accept the principle of withdrawal from all Arab territories occupied in the 1967 war, it was announced here today. The reply to the United States proposal also insisted that the full rights of the Palestinian people, approved by United Nations resolutions, be recognized as a safeguard for peace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The chairman of a special House subcommittee considering the impeachment of Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court contended today that its preliminary inquiry was being obstructed by the refusal of federal agencies to supply necessary information.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5-Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, told the Senate today that the United States must expand the Safeguard antiballistic missile system to counter an "alarming increase" in the Soviet strategic threat.
Some 7,000 industrial films will be produced this year, with the dollar volume of those made by independent companies estimated at somewhat more than $135million.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Dr. Jean Mayer, the nutritionist, called on the Federal Government today to monitor television advertising directed at children when it pertains to their health and nutrition.
The bill under which the Federal Government more than doubled last year's appropriation for the National Endowment for the Arts has begun producing its first major fruit.
A Long Island Railroad spokesman said yesterday that a residue of a weed killing spray that remained on the tracks was the apparent cause of a train accident in Long Beach, on July 7.
Governor Rockefeller issued the first interest-free loan yesterday under a new state program to prevent decay or abandonment of structurally sound apartment buildings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 A California Congressman declared today that President Nixon's comments on the murder trial of Charles M. Manson, while "wrong," had been "relatively unimportant news" and that the press had acted "irresponsibly" in reporting them.
A man suspected of being a drug dealer died yesterday fol- lowing a gun battle with policemen on Third Street in the East Village Tuesday.

A new surfing area in Far Rockaway between Beach 49th and 50th Streets will be opened tomorrow at 1:30 P.M., in ceremonies highlighted by a "shoot-the-waves" demonstration to rock music, City Recreation Commissioner Joseph W. Halper has announced.
Stock prices advanced in moderate trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 5 Tworun homers by Thurman Munson and Bobby Murcer off Sam McDowell in the fifth inning led the New York Yankees to a 7-3 victory tonight over the Cleveland Indians.

CLERMONT FERRAND, France, Aug. 5 (AP) Lucien Lamoureux, who was Finance Minister when France fell to the Germans in 1940, died today after a heart attack at his home in the village of Creuzier-le-Vieux. He was 82 years old.

TRENTON, Aug. 5 Edgar H. Smith, who has been on Death Row longer than any other condemned man in American penal history, lost another legal battle to escape the electric chair today when a Federal judge refused to strike down the confession that led to Smith's conviction of murder 13 years ago.

Under strong pressure from Puerto Rican community leaders in the South Bronx, the city formally started to clear the site yesterday for a new medical and mental health center to replace the dilapidated Lincoln Hospital, founded in 1839.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The United States will field its fourth negotiating team in two years at the Paris talks with North Vietnam tomorrow, with only slender hope that it can break the deadlock in the foreseeable future.
Suggestions by city officials that Consolidated Edison build plants outside the city to provide more power drew strong opposition yesterday from the suburbs.

Community representatives in four of the slum areas where the Sanitation Department said it collected garbage five and six times a week reported yesterday that the pickups were sporadic and occurred about twice a week.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 5-The Noroton Yacht Club crew, captained by Susie Crimmins, survived a disqualification in the first of today's three races off Norwalk Yacht Club and won the Long Island Sound girls' championship regatta.
Lincoln Center's Mid-Summer Serenades have other fish to fry than Mozart this summer, as the Philharmonic Hall series carefully suggests by its subtitle, "A Mostly Mozart Festival." There was, for

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The United States is sounding out Israel and the United Arab Republic On arrangements for each side to police the other's observance of the proposed 90day cease-fire in the Middle East, rather than rely primarily on United Nations truce observers.
GENEVA, Aug. 5 (UPI) Bernard Cornfeld, founder of Investors Overseas Services, was told today he could meet with its board of directors tomorrow to outline his plan for the company's recovery.
Leading retail chains reported yesterday increased sales in July over the like year-earlier month.

LONDON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Imports of low-priced American electronics components were viewed today as threatening the British industry. The chief executive of one of the big companies in the field said the danger was that American concerns might win total control of parts of the British market.
The Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation announced yesterday cost-reduction measures including executive salary cuts and a 9 per cent reduction in the work force.

MOSCOW, Aug. 5 The Soviet Union said today that it would do "everything within its power" to aid in the search for an equitable political settlement of the conflict between... Arabs and Israelis in the Middle East.
OUTSIDE SKOUN, Cambodia, Aug. 5 (AP) Seven American planes gave direct air support to Cambodian ground troops here today.

Mrs. Rheinfrank Bell of New York and Frank Suydam Ball of Perrysburg, Ohio, and Palm Beach, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katharine Fuller Bell, to John Francis Ryan Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Ryan of Brightwaters, L.I.
James Campbell Lewis, retired vice president of research for E.R. Squibb Sons, Inc., died Tuesday in Claremont, N.H. He was 82 years old and lived in Cornish, N.H.

Along the leisurely avenues and the shaded side streets of the Upper East Side, clusters of small shops display their expensive temptations. But these days the window-shopper who wants to look more closely, or maybe buy, is likely to find the shop door locked and the proprietor wary.

Mrs. Ricki Hunter and Dr. Stephen Goodyear, a psychiatrist she met on the telephone when she was working as an operator for his answering service, were married yesterday afternoon in a civil ceremony at the Municipal Building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (UPI) Fifteen states filed suit in the Supreme Court today to force the four major automobile manufacturers to equip cars with better pollution control equipment and to provide pollution-free engines "at the earliest feasible date."

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 5 (AP) A team of United States Transportation Department investigators has found safety defects in 10 of the 15 buses owned by the company that provided the bus that crashed in Allentown, Pa., killing seven children.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 5 (UPI) The Mayor of Corpus Christi, the largest city battered by Hurricane Celia, assumed emergency police powers today to stop "profiteering" and get the devastated city back on its feet.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Abe Fortas, former Associate Jus- tice of the Supreme Court, registered recently as a Congressional lobbyist.
Luke Walker hasn't had any trouble getting to the ball park at the right time recently, and sometimes that means trouble for the opposing team.

Mrs. Bertram J.L. Ainsworth of Fairfield, Conn., and Dr. John Spotswood Hoes of Cooperstown and Rome, N.Y., have made known here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Wiggins Hoes, to Peter James Cohen. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Perry Cohen of Highland Park, Ill.
LISBON, Aug. 5 The Portuguese police are reported to have arrested a former army chaplain in what appears to be a continuing crackdown on critics of the colonial wars.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Aug. 5 (Agence France Presse) The Roman Catholic Church in Rhodesia has issued a pamphlet indicating that it is considering softening its attitude toward the Land Tenure Act, which regulates racial segregation.
BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 5 Morris L. Rosenberg, sports editor of the Bayonne Times since 1924, died today in Greenville Hospital, Jersey City. He was 69 years old and lived at 143 West 34th Street here.
RAWALPINDI, Pakistan, Thursday, Aug. 6 (Reuters) A Fokker Friendship aircraft of Pakistan International Airlines crashed soon after take-off today, killing 30 people.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The Commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration accused the drug industry today of shirking its responsibilities by not helping to prevent abuse of amphetamines.

NEWARK, Aug. 5 The Newark Housing Council, a community organization created two years ago to oversee the renewal and rehabilitation of the city's strife-torn and decayed Central Ward, made public today a comprehensive development plan for the first phase of the task.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 5 The New York Mets sailed serenely through all sorts of potential difficulties today and wound up with a 5-3 victory tonight over the St. Louis Cardinals, making a good beginning for a difficult and important 13-game trip, which will take them to Pittsburgh, Cincinnati and Atlanta.

Randolph E. Brown, who retired in 1959 as first vice president and director of the American Surety Company of New York, later the Transamerica Corporation, died Sunday in South Egremont, Mass. He was 72 years old and also lived in Tenafly, N.J.
DETROIT, Aug. 5 Once more into the breach go Detroit's auto makers with a new line of mini-cars aimed at stemming the million-a-year flood of imported automobiles.

The S.S. Kresge Company, Detroit, which transformed itself in the last eight years from just another variety-store company into one that also includes the country's largest discountstore chain, is continuing to pursue the retail industry's most aggressive expansion program.

Charles Tanqueray Co., Ltd., of London, the producer of Tanqueray Gin, has been granted use of its bottle as a trademark by the United States Patent Office. The bottle is a replica of an old-time London fireplug in dark green with a bright red seal containing the letter T in script.

Prodded into discussing his indecision regarding his football future, Joe Namath answered criticism last night from Al Atkinson and Gerry Philbin, two of his teammates, and explained his absence from the New York Jets' training camp.

Drug charges against Howard C. Samuels, son of the industrialist who ran unsuccessfully this year for the Democratic nomination for Governor, were dismissed here yesterday on the recommendation of the youth's court-appointed counselor.

The Hartford Fire Insurance Company, now owned by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, reported yesterday that net operating income in the second quarter had risen almost 29 per cent to $12.7-million, or 59 cents a share, from $9.9-million, or 46 cents a share, in the year-earlier period.

CHICAGO, Aug. 5 Plans for an expanded drive to win collective bargaining rights for farm workers throughout the nation were jointly announced today by the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations and by the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 5 The State Department announced today that the United States and Spain would sign a new agreement tomorrow providing for continuing American use of military bases in Spain.

Tenneco, Inc., the conglomerate based in Houston, achieved record revenues in this year's second quarter and first half, but rising operating costs, strikes and poor results in two divisions reduced earnings by more than 20 per cent.
DETROIT, Aug. 5 (AP) United States auto makers produced 453,804 vehicles in July, up from 433,002 during the year-earlier month.

Mrs. Lynwood (Peg) Walton of Mount Holly, N.J., is the bench show chairman of the largest one-day outdoor show in the East Trenton. Six years ago, when she became chairman, Trenton had an entry of 2,060. Last May, it had 3,615.
New York State deer hunters may obtain party permit application forms the first of next month, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.
ALBANY, Aug. 5 The major bus company in the AlbanyTroy area is planning to discontinue operations.

DETROIT, Aug. 5 Mrs. George Romney won a narrow victory in yesterday's Michigan primary election and will be the Republican candidate for the United States Senate seat held by the Democratic incumbent, Philip A. Hart.
A strike of Teamster Local 804 against the United Parcel Service moved into its sixth day yesterday as a meeting between the company and the union broke up with no resolution of the issues.

The Commonwealth United Corporation, whose overseas financing arm failed this week to make a required interest payment of $862,500 on a bond issue sold abroad, is in default on two other bond issues sold domestically, the trustee for the bonds said yesterday. Interest on a third issue sold domestically is also overdue, the trustee said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) Fewer than half of the 48 states that do not allow 18year-olds to vote have indicated that they will comply with the lower voting age in the new Federal Voting Rights Act, Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today.

Federal Judge John P. Fullam ordered yesterday nine banks to restore $4.5-million of deposits of the Penn Central Transportation Company, which the banks had taken to offset loans and other debts owed them by the railroad.

BONN, Aug. 5-Following strong opposition by both officers and soldiers, Defense Minister Helmet Schmidt today revoked a reform intended to democratize etiquette in the armed forces by banning the use of "Herr" (Mister) when addressing higher ranks.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 5 Tony Jacklin will seek another American golf title as well as lots of prize money in the next four tournaments on the pro tour. The 26-year-old English professional who returned home last June with the United States Open championship outlined his plans today for further golfing gold and glory.
"Summer Festival for Peace," a 12-hour rock music festival sponsored by "Peace Incorporated," will be presented at Shea Stadium today from 10 A.M. to 10 P.M.

On the floor of the lobby of Madison Square Garden a man jerked and twisted and moaned while guards argued whether he should be carted off in a wheelchair or a stretcher. Policemen formed a circle and pushed passersby away. "C'mon, keep moving," one said, "it's just a fit," and the crowd streaming out of the arena shrugged and moved on. They had already seen their accident.
A spokesman at the Armed Forces Induction Center at 39 Whitehall Street stressed yesterday that it was "unlikely" that anyone had heen inducted into service because of an inaccurate weighing scale.
With an attack on the absence of Joe Namath from the New York Jets' training camp, Al Atkinson, their dependable middle linebacker, announced his retirement yesterday from pro football.
The mounting activity among chess buffs these days in the San Francisco Bay area is stimulated by the performances of two indomitable spirits.

Citizens for Clean Air, a civic group, and former Bronx Borough President Herman Badillo urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to block the controversial new Consolidated Edison electric power project for Astoria, Queens, as a likely air polluter.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 5 Superior Court Judge Charles H. Older refused again today to declare a mistrial in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson and three young women co-defendants.

Dr. and Mrs. Hans A. Hartmann of New York have announced the engagement of Dr. Hartmann's daughter, Miss Karen Kohler Hartmann, to Robert Allen Hoffman. He is the sun of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Hoffman of Mequon, Wis. The couple plan to be married in January.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The pesky fire ant, which ranges over nine Southern states, may be a nuisance but the insecticide used to curb it poses a public health hazard, an environmental group charged today.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Aug. 5 Mrs. Thomas J. Hory of Winged Foot, the defender, reached the semifinal round of the 48th annual Women's Westchester-andFairfield Golf Association championship at Bedford Golf and Tennis Club today by rallying for a 1-up victory over Mrs. Allan V. Becker, Westchester Country Club.

HYANNIS PORT, Mass., Aug. 5 Robert F. Kennedy Jr., second oldest son of the late Sen- ator, and Robert Sargent Shriver 3d, son of the former United States Ambassador to France, are scheduled to appear in Juvenile Court tomorrow on charges of possessing marijuana.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 5 (Reuters) Left-wing guerrillas said today that they would accept nothing less than the release of all political prisoners before they granted freedom to a kidnapped American official and a Brazilian diplomat.

WARENDORF, West Germany, Aug. 5 (AP) Peter Kelemen took the individual title and led a strong Hungarian team to the modern world pentathlon team championship today. The United States team finished fourth.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange drifted aimlessly yesterday and finished almost unchanged in stepped-up trading.

The last time we talked to Super Bear he was worried that the nation might be headed for another 1929. That was in mid-April when the Dow-Jones industrial average had already been battered down to 772.

An entire generation has been born and has grown to maturity since the atom bombing of Hiroshima just 25 years ago today yet the shock waves set off by that event still reverberate around the world. At Hiroshima and a few days later at Nagasaki the world received unforgettable glimpses of the disastrous perspectives modern military technology has opened up for all life on this planet.

The Lindsay administration seems determined to insure that no section of the city will ever qualify as really clean. That is the only conclusion we can draw from the Sanitation Department's announcement that garbage collection for families living in small homes will be cut back from three times a week to two.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 5 Resembling a $125-a-week exercise boy, Bill Hartack, the $100,000-a-year jockey, galloped Tyrant an eighth of a mile at Monmouth Park today.
Two 17-year-old youths were held last night in the slaying of a 14-year-old earlier this week that the police said had resulted from knife fights between members of two Chinese youth gangs.
Extending the concept of pedestrian shopping malls, Mayor Lindsay yesterday broadened the closing of main avenues to vehicular traffic in various parts of the city.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 5 If it hadn't been for that strike by the football players, Ed Baker's life would be a lot more simple today.

PARIS, Aug. 5 A 14-yearold schoolboy flew 12,000 miles first class from Sydney to Paris last weekend with only 10 cents in his pocket. He said today that he had got on the jetliner by running through customs after a family and shouting: "Papa! Papa! Wait for me!"
Eight panels, depicting scenes in Hiroshima after the first atomic bombing 25 years ago today, will be seen for the first time in the United States beginning Oct. 15 at the New School Art Center.

The South African economy is paying a steep price for its policy of racial apartheid. The nation is suffering from a labor shortage that feeds inflation, a foreign-trade deficit, a decline in investment in plant and equipment, a drag in its economic growth, and a fall in the stock market.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 5 Optimism that a limited truce may be reached between the neutralist Government and the Communist-led forces is greater here now than it has been in recent months.

Charges that a 22-year-old Brooklyn man had sold narcotics were dismissed yesterday after District Attorney Eugene Gold disclosed that the defendant could not have said the things a police agent said he did since the defendant is virtually mute.
Herb Adderley, a cornerback for the Green Bay Packers, joined Lance Alworth, the San Diego Chargers' wide receiver, in pro football retirement yesterday.

ALBANY, Aug. 5 State tax receipts for the first four months of the current fiscal year have not reflected the anticipated 10 per cent revenue increase predicted by Governor Rockefeller's budget makers.
A new and apparently unique joint venture in the asset management field was announced yesterday by Marine Midland Banks, Inc., and the Dreyfus Corporation, a pioneer in the mutual fund industry.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 5 Samuel B. Mosher, who founded the Signal Oil and Gas Company in 1922 and built it into a giant conglomerate with interests in air freight, aerospace, real estate, broadcasting and athletic teams, died yesterday at his home. He was 77.

The Nixon Administration will compound old errors and commit ominous new ones by signing today in non-treaty form the so-called "Agreement of Friendship and Cooperation Between the United States and Spain." It is obvious in the first place that the signing was advanced because of growing opposition on Capitol Hill to the form and content of the agreement.

Arthur J. Goldberg charged yesterday that the city subway system "has the worst accident record of any major system in the world." He blamed Governor Rockefeller for "neglect" of mass-transit facilities.
The National Distillers and Chemical Corporation said yesterday it had filed an antitrust suit seeking more than $150million in damages against two West German companies and one American corporation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 Administration sources reiterated today that the United States would not use American ground troops in Cambodia to save the anti-Communist regime of Premier Lon Nol and would not raise the level of the war there.

OTTAWA, Aug. 5 (Canadian Press) Canadian foreign exchange reserves rose $110.6- million during July to reach an unprecedented $4.44-billion at the end of the month, the Finance Department reported today.

NEWPORT, R.L. Aug. 5 The weather has turned benign, and everyone at the Newport Music Festival is now able to pursue in comfort the goals of this two-year-old institution the investigation of forgotten 19th-century music.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 5 About $85-million in Tennessee Valley Authority power revenues will be required for payments to the United States Treasury during the fiscal year that began July 1, an increase of more than $12-million over last year's payments, the TVA announced today.

The American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., created a separate division yesterday to develop frequency-modulation radio as a medium stressing progressive rock music and offering talk-in shows for those interested in today's modern life style.
Alexander Robert Munro, a public relations man and former president and board chairman of Knickerbocker Hospital, died Tuesday in his home at 325 Riverside Drive at the age of 85.
The variable-interest-rate mortgage, which has been designed to help lending institutions adapt more readily to changes in the money market, has been the subject of increasing attention.
FRANKFURT, West Germany, Aug. 5 (AP) West Germany's gold and convertible currency reserves rose in the week ended July 31 by $406-million, to $8.38-billion, the central bank reported today.
The first New York International Art Show, which opened last Friday at the Coliseum, came under scrutiny yesterday from some of the exhibitors and from Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The Commerce Department reported today that consumers had stepped up their buying plans for houses for the next six months.

Israel's formal acceptance of United States peace proposals and Premier Golda Meir's concurrent comments in the Knesset add momentum to what must become an irreversible movement toward settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.

SALISBURY, N.C., Aug. 5 In the chapel of the First Methodist Church hare tonight. Miss Deborah Adrienne Cline a June graduate of St. Mary's School in Raleigh, was married to Thomas Austin Finch 3d, who is a junior at Princeton University. The Rev. D. Edwin Bailey performed the ceremony.
Tournament bridge enthusiasts will be criss-crossing the United States today and tomorrow. Some will no doubt pass each other unwittingly in airport terminals.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 A Senate committee rejected today several major manpower training proposals made by president Nixon and included in a bill a program of public service jobs that the Administration has resisted.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 5 Westchester retained the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association's Junior Wightman Cup today by defeating New Jersey, 6 matches to 3, at Bronxville Field Club in the final round of the annual girls' triangular competition.

Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Gallagher of Brooklyn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eileen Patrice Gallagher, to John Carver Vining Jr., son of Mrs. John C. Vining of Philadelphia and Cannes, France and the late Mr. Vining. A wedding in December is planned.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 5 If the name Ray Ruffels does not exactly ring a bell in your Australian tennis catalogue, you are not alone. Ray Ruffels is the Aussie nobody knows.

BRISTOL, Conn., Aug. 5 This city of 57,000, landscaped by the Industrial Revolution into gray chimneys and red-bricked factories, is caught in the slack of the nation's economy.

Domestic Air Express, Inc., an international air and surface forwarding company, said yesterday that it expects to report a loss of about $1.6-million for 1969, subject to final review and certification by its accountants.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 (AP) Fears that erotic films, books and magazines are aggravating sex crimes and corrupting the morals of youth are unfounded, a draft report of the President's Commission on Pornography says.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass. Aug 5 (AP) About 300 dissidents stoned automobiles and buses tonight, made targets of firefighters and erected a barricade near Harvard Square, but were driven off by police using tear gas.

LONDON, Aug. 5 The Thomson Organization, publisher of The Times of London, announced "an internal financial arrangement" today to protect the viability of the 185-year-old daily paper, which lost about $4-million last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 5 The House voted today to limit subsidy payments to any one farm to $55,000 a year for each of three crops wheat, cotton and feed grains.

Investment bankers are again experimenting with lower yields on high grade bonds. Their efforts yesterday were highly successful with taxexempt bonds and not so successful with corporate bonds.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 5 (AP) All the seeded singles players survived today's round of the United States amateur clay courts tennis championship, despite a few close calls.

TOKYO, Aug. 5 A leftleaning historian is locked in a protracted legal battle with Japan's Education Ministry over whether it has the right to disapprove the contents of high school textbooks.

Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it will introduce a new credit card, effective Sept. l, to be known as the Take Off card.

LONDON, Aug. 5 Neville Blond, a textile industrialist who was patron of the Royal Court Theater, died here yesterday at the age of 74.

George J. Miller was having a nerve-racking time trying to speed the recovery of intact tiny fossils from the La Brea tar pits in Los Angeles. At last, he made a few inquiries and came up with a solution that is proving to be a boon to paleontology.
