The Bethlehem Steel Corporation yesterday announced that effective Oct. 1 it will increase prices on tinplate and tin-free sheet steel used by the can industries by 65 cents per base box.

It is now almost six years since the student rebellion began in this country. In that time very few colleges and universities-perhaps none-have developed a specific, coherent strategy for coping with it. The usual pattern is for incidents to develop willy-nilly. Student rebels press their assault. The administra-
LONDON, Aug. 6 (AP) Britain has informed the United States of mounting concern about American plans to dispose of lethal nerve gas in the Atlantic Ocean, the Foreign Office announced today.

PRETORIA, South Africa-"We're moving in the opposite direction from the rest of the world," declared Dr. William Nkomo, a widely respected civic leader of South Africa's black community. "Our people are being increasingly robbed of their rights and the racial inequities are more and more entrenched."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 6 (AP) Mando Ramos of Long Beach, Calif., former lightweight champion, his face a gory mess of blood from the third round on, battered his way back into the 135-pound division title picture tonight by gaining a split 10-round decision over Sugar Ramos of Mexico city before a crowd of 10,000 at Olympic Auditorium.

LOS ALAMOS, N.M., Aug. 6 More than 100 rain-soaked demonstrators marked the 25th anniversary of the destruction of Hiroshima today by planting a locust tree at the laboratory where the first atomic bomb was created.

The skyscraper fire that claimed the lives of two workmen and injured dozens of others high in one of New York City's glistening office towers requires the thorough investigation promised by Mayor Lindsay and Acting Buildings Commissioner Ferro.
A 38-year-old detective was acquitted yesterday of perjury charges arising out of a grand jury investigation into alleged protection payoffs to the police by numbers racketeers.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 6 The engagement of Miss Sara Katherine Harman to Ralph Lyman Harding 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harding Jr., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Harman Jr. A winter wedding is planned.

BOSTON, Aug. 6-The Spingold Knockout Team Championship will attract most attention at the American Contract Bridge League's Summer Nationals, which begin here tomorrow afternoon, for this event will help determine American representation in the 1971 World Championship.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 6 Premier Souvanna Phouma said in an interview today that he was more optimistic about the possibility of peace talks with his half-brother, Prince Souphanouvong, leader of the Pathet Lao.
The creative director of J. Walter Thompson's London branch spent some time yesterday with the colonists at the home office and regaled them with stories about advertising, British style.

ROME, Aug. 6 The 32nd Cabinet since the fall of Fascism in 1943 took charge in Italy tonight, but both the composition of the four-party Government and its announced policies appeared nearly identical to those of its predecessor.

WASHINGTON Aug. 6 The Federal Government's enforcement of a new health and safety law for the nation's underground coal mines was condemned today before a Senate subcommittee as "a mockery and a fraud."
It was another dreary session yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as prices moved lower in quiet trading.
Should the Chrysler Corporation pay a dividend at a time when the company has reported losses and has had to comb the nation's banks and financial capitals of Europe for working capital?

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 With a thinly disguised attack on his Democratic opponent, Senator Charles E. Goodell proposed today a $25,000 limit on the amount of money a candidate can spend on his own behalf for nomination or election to Congress.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 5 A trial balloon for an annual "state of the judiciary" address to Congress by the Chief Justice will be launched here on Monday when Warren E. Burger will deliver a nationally televised speech before the American Bar Association convention.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 The Nixon Administration rebuffed Senator Russell B. Long, the influential Senate Finance committee chairman, today on two major suggested revisions in the pending welfare reform program.
The question of control over cable television in New York City is heading for a showdown decision by the Federal Communications Commission.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Aug. 6--A five-man board of colonels and majors conducted a four and-a-half hour hearing today on the request of a cadet at the United States Military Academy here for a discharge as a conscientious objector.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) A six-cent stamp honoring former President Dwight D. Eisenhower was presented to his widow today in White House ceremonies.

Starting Tuesday, you may pay anything from a cent to a C-note to get into the Cloisters, the Metropolitan Museum's medieval outpost in Fort Tryon Park, but you must pay something. The sliding-scale entrance fee is part of an experimental "discretionary admission" policy that has already been in effect for four weeks for special exhibitions at the museum's main building on Fifth Avenue.

"I'll take the three-button vested suit, the double-breasted overcoat, and the Hamilton Beach electric mixer, too!" said a customer with a gleam in his eye yesterday at a Weber Heilbroner men's store here.
Despite temperatures that rose to a high of 85 degrees at 1:45 P.M. yesterday, Consolidated Edison eased through another summer day with power reserves that a spokesman described as adequate.
Mrs. Jean Paaswell Bailinson of New York has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Ann E. Bailinson, to Jerome Alan Kleinman. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Kleinman of Beachwood, Ohio.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. Aug. 6 Princess Roycraft, the favorite, and Hunnemania, a hesitantly backed contestant, shared the divisions of the Test Stakes today. Larry Adams steered Princess Roycraft and Eddie Belmonte guided Hunnemania in the respective divisions of the seven-furlong sprint for 3-year-old fillies.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6-A Senate subcommittee's inquiry into the quality and advertising of dry breakfast cereals is over but Government and private efforts to get the cereal industry to improve its products and to reform its advertising are not.
The National Transportation Safety Board yesterday denied Representative Richard L. Ottinger's assertion that it was investigating last Saturday's subway accident.

Striding toward the subway the other day, a copy of "Future Shock," title outward, under my arm. I was hailed by a construction worker hanging around a new department store going up in my neighborhood. "Hey!" he called, "Future shock now I gotta read that." He may have ethnocentrically assumed the book is about some forthcoming.

WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Aug. 6 Mrs. Orme Crawford has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Dianne Marie Crawford, to William Pope Anderson 5th, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Grenville Anderson of Sherborn. The wedding is planned for May.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, the House minority leader, took issue today with a contention by the chairman of a special subcommittee considering the impeachment of Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court that its investigation has been hobbled by a lack of cooperation from Federal agencies.
Robert H. Finch, a counselor to President Nixon, has agreed to portray himself in a segment of the National Broadcasting Company's TV adventure series "The Name of the Game."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 A high-flying reconnaissance plane is cruising over 26 American cities this summer, taking photographs to help develop an early warning system for urban change.

Former State Supreme Court Justice James Vincent Keogh, who asked for a Federal Court order to set aside his 1962 conviction for accepting bribes in connection with the sentencing of a defendant, was turned down by Judge Edward Weinfeld.
NASHVILLE, Friday, Aug. 7 Senator Albert Gore, the silverhaired liberal who describes himself as "the prime target of the Southern strategy," won renomination yesterday for a fourth term.
PLANDOME, L.I, Aug.6 Miss Pamela Ann Messerschmitt and Peter Yearsley Bennett plan to be married next May in Manhasset.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) The Federal Clean Air Agency conceded today that its preliminary ranking of American cities for two types of air pollution had been based on information from a single sampler for each pollutant in each city.
HIRAM, Ohio, Aug. 6 Homer Jones, late of the New York Giants and now of the Cleveland Browns, said today that he never could understand why he was made out to be "a dumb fool" back in New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 Clyde C. Hall, former public information director of the National Science Foundation, died yesterday of a heart attack on a Maryland golf course. He was 68 years old.

A nine-year-old city plan that permits black students to transfer to predominantly white schools to achieve racial integration has fallen short of its goal because of the departure of whites from the school system, a Board of Education report said yesterday.
The city's $1-a-year official greeter got a $20,000-a-year assistant yesterday.
MOSCOW, Aug. 6 The Soviet Union tonight announced an outbreak of cholera in the region of Astrakhan, a city in the Volga River delta 60 miles from the Caspian Sea.

LONDON, Aug. 6 George Brown, deputy leader of the parliamentary Labor party until he lost his House of Commons seat in the June election and a former Foreign Secretary, has been elevated to the peerage and will sit in the House of Lords.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 6 (AP) A statement from leftist urban guerrillas today set a deadline for midnight tomorrow for the release of Uruguay's political prisoners.

Second place in the American League's Eastern Division, which seems about the best the Yankees can hope for as the season enters its final eight weeks, was the stake last night as New York and the Detroit Tigers split a double-header before 22,434 fans at Yankee Stadium.

The market for tax-exempt bonds continued to surge ahead yesterday as large banks, insurance companies, individual investors and Wall Street professionals purchased large amounts of securities in the belief that interest rates are headed still lower.
CHICAGO, Aug. 6 Walter Kennedy, commissioner of the National Basketball Association, said today that merger with the American Basketball Association could not be accomplished until next year.
A Manhattan housewife, just back from Florida with a deep sun tan, decided her medium-blond hair was too dark for her skin and wanted to have it lightened.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 You can hardly tune in the evening news these days without hearing the low grumble of Senator Fulbright's voice. To hear him tell it, the world is in a terrible pickle, the State and Defense Departments are leading us to unimaginable disasters and the poor old Senate is helpless to save the Republic.
High and deep in the empty balcony, a speck of sunlight gleamed through a window of Madison Square Garden and died against the orange plastic seats.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 A key Senator has warned the securities industry that the insurance legislation the industry urgently wants may receive no further Congressional consideration unless the New York Stock Exchange provides more information about the brokerage firms that are currently in financial difficulty.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 6-The Vanguard National Bank, one of the first fully integrated banks in the state, has received a provisional charter from the Controller of the Currency, the bank announced today.

WASHINGTON, Aug 6 Secretary of State William P. Rogers informed a House subcommittee today that the Soviet Union had shown increased interst recently in United Nations peace-keeping operations. He voiced the hope that Moscow would relax its past opposition to supporting them financially.

Miss Harriet Blacker, director of publicity for Coward-McCann. Inc., publishers, was married here yesterday to Roland Algrant, who is executive vice president of Feffer Simons, Inc., publishers' representatives. The ceremony, performed by Justice Arthur Markewich of the Supreme Court, Appellate Division, in his chambers, was witnessed by Mrs. Bertram Shapiro, sister of the bride, and Dr. John Zabriskie.

An investor has charged that he lost $150,000 because the New York Stock Exchange was negligent and careless in its supervision of Baerwald DeBoer, a member firm that failed and went into liquidation.

The Department of Justice charged yesterday that Samuel J. Lefrak, one of the nation's leading builders, and the Lefrak Organization had practiced racial discrimination in the renting of 21,000 apartments in 150 buildings in Brooklyn and Queens.

David Bruce began his Vietnam peace mission in Paris yesterday voicing hope "that we can avoid propaganda and harsh language and settle down to businesslike discussion of the issues." It was a short-lived hope so far as the 78th session of these fateful negotiations was concerned.
Anyone who thinks today's youth unimaginative or filled with ennui should drop by Scarabocchio, a boutique that opened at 344 East 72d Street recently.

ALBANY, Aug. 6 A protest by two prisoners over being ordered into solitary confinement has resulted in an order from a Federal judge that the New York prison system must formalize its disciplinary rules. One of the two, who said he had been thrown naked into a "strip" cell at Clinton State Prison, Dannemora, also won a $1,500 cash judgment.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 6 Grover G. (Buddy) Delp was in unusual company at Monmouth Park today he didn't have a winner. He saddled three horses, and the best he could do was a fourth place with his wife's filly, Honzie, in the sixth race.

BUFFALO, Aug. 6 The marriage of Dr. Jane Fay Pascale, clinical assistant professor of pathology at the Medical School of the State University of New York at Buffalo, to Dr. Joseph H. Kite Jr. took place here today. The Rev. Richard Harrington performed the ceremony in Trinity United Methodist Church, where the bridegroom, associate professor of microbiology at the medical school, is the lay leader.
A bar owner in the midtown area where police payoffs are suspected of being made conceded yesterday that such practices were "a sore spot" for those involved in dispensing alcoholic beverages.

TRIPOLI, Libya, Aug. 6 Five Arab countries ended a conference today that was officially described as having improved military cooperation in the war against Israel and as having ignored the effort now under way to negotiate a settlement under a 90-day cease-fire.

"Ordinarily, this does not represent the way to solve problems," Milton Musicus, the Municipal Services Administrator, said yesterday of the increasingly heated public debate between top Lindsay administration officials over a projected power plant in Astoria, Queens.
ROME, Aug. 6 Prince Carlo Pacelli, a nephew of Pope Pius XII and for many years a legal adviser to the Vatican City administration, died here today of a heart ailment. He was 66 years old.
Delaney Bonnie and Friends, a joyous soul-rockgospel ensemble, played a long concert Wednesday evening at Wollman Rink in Central Park.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 6 (Reuters) South Vietnamese war veterans prevented the destruction of their shantytown dwellings today with a violent attack on a Government office and self-inflicted wounds.

The three alarm fire Wednesday night in the upper floors of One New York Plaza, a brand-new showcase office tower in the financial district, forced three New York Stock Exchange firms yesterday to take emergency measures to stay in business and caused the Chase Manhattan Bank to fall behind schedule in clearing checks.

LIMA, Ohio, Friday, Aug. 7 National Guardsmen patrolled the relatively calm streets of this mid-Ohio city this morning after the fatal shooting of a black woman by white policemen Wednesday afternoon touched off a night of racial violence.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 Police expenditures of questionable value in the reduction of crime consume most of the funds made available to states under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968, according to a study by the National Urban Coalition.
CARTERET, N.J., Aug. 5 Seven persons were injured, one critically, when an explosion and fire ravaged an tanker being loaded with gasoline here.

The banners that hung over the bleachers at Shea Stadium yesterday were peace signs as about 20,000 young people listened, clapped and danced to the resounding beat of rock music in a 12-hour "festival for peace."
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 6 Many men have translated the Bible, Kenneth N. Taylor has paraphrased it all 66 books in the Protestant text.

R.J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., the nation's largest cigarette manufacturer, announced plans yesterday to diversify into the oil business by agreeing to acquire the American Independent Oil Company for an undisclosed amount of cash.

YONKERS, Aug. 6 The $25,160 Hudson Filly Trot, a stakes event that has been turned into "just another race" because the public will not be permitted to wager on the outcome, is the nominal feature of tomorrow night's harness racing card at Yonkers Raceway.

LONDON, Aug. 6 Alan Ayckbourn is known as a virtuoso in cross-purpose comedy, and the set for his new play, "How the Other Half Loves," at the Lyric Theater, confronts you like a piece of juggling apparatus.

In proposing a new international regime for the seabed, President Nixon expressed apprehension about "the ecological hazards of unregulated use of the oceans and seabeds." This laudable concern unfortunately finds no adequate reflection in the Army's plan to dump 418 concrete "coffins" containing leaky nerve gas rockets into the sea off Florida.

PURCHASE, N.Y. The first full-time students are still more than a year away, the first faculty member has yet to be hired, and of an eventual two dozen buildings, three are holes in the ground, one is a steel skeleton, and the others are only blueprints.
ALBANY, Aug. 6 (UPI) The State Narcotic Addiction Control Commission has approved grants of $3,690,391 to help finance New York City's battle against drug abuse, Governor Rockefeller announced today.
BROOKVILLE, L.I, Aug. 6 Only two days before their first exhibition game, the Giants were without an experienced center today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 (UPI) Chet Huntley, the former newscaster, has told President Nixon he is sorry and "terribly embarrassed" about remarks attributed to him in a recent issue of Life magazine.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird reiterated today the Nixon Administration's contention that American planes were not giving close air support to Cambodian troops despite eyewitness press reports to the contrary.

DETROIT, Aug. 6 Mrs. Beverly Kritzman Killingsworth, wife of Dr. Charles C. Killingsworth, University Professor of labor and industrial relations at Michigan State University and a member of the National Manpower Task Force, died of cancer yesterday. She was 49 years old and lived in Okemos, Mich.

Investigation Commissioner Robert K. Ruskin asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to send three New York City policemen to jail until they satisfactorily answer questions about a list they allegedly used to collect systematic payoffs from Manhattan businesses.

AREA A Heavy seaweed has tangled surfcasting action along some of the New Jersey beaches, but boats are taking blues and school tuna. From Asbury Park to Sea Bright, charter boats working two or three miles offshore are doing best of all, with trolling for blues up to 12 pounds described as "terrific." Point Pleasant reports good quantities of blues and some fluke. Near Manasquan, the headboats are scoring well on diamond jigs.
Stock prices drifted downward yesterday as trading activity continued to hover around the lowest levels of the year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 Senate and House negotiators agreed today to give President Nixon stand-by authority he has said he would not use to impose wage, price and rent controls.

The Royal Dutch-Shell Group of companies achieved record sales and earnings in the second quarter, reflecting a firming of prices in European markets, according to the midyear report issued yesterday.
A group of Oriental-American actors yesterday picketed the offices of Herman Levin, the theatrical producer, at 424 Madison Avenue, charging discrimination in casting his forthcoming new musical.
LONDON, Aug. 6 Air Chief Marshal Sir Richard E.C. Peirse who headed the Bomber Command of the Royal Air Force from 1940 to 1942, died yesterday. He was 77 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 The House gave final Congressional approval today to a bill to turn the 181-year-old Post Office Department over to an independent Government agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 Following are the texts of the section dealing with cooperation in defense matters in the agreement signed today by the United States and Spain earlier sections deal with other forms of cooperation and of a letter by Secretary of State Rogers to the Spanish Foreign Minister, Gregorio Lopez Bravo, in regard to military assistance:

PARIS, Aug. 6 The new chief American negotiator attended his first session of the peace talks on Vietnam today and proposed a renewed effort at settlement of the war. But the Communist side declared at this 78th meeting that he had nothing new to offer.
For most of this season, the San Francisco Giants and the Pittsburgh Pirates have been pitching-paupers. Suddenly, however, their pitchers are making them wealthy.
Tony Giammalva of White Plains and John McEnroe of Douglaston, Queens, won singles titles yesterday in Metropolitan boys' tennis.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 6. The United States shoe industry asserted today that, contrary to widespread belief, import quotas on footwear would have only an "insignificant effect" in raising the price of shoes to the consumer.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 6 A Presidential emergency board recommended today that the 33-year-old dispute over use of firemen in railroad locomotives be settled by creating a new job classification.
OTTAWA, Aug. 7 The Canadian Government announced today it would continue paying subsidies to highcost gold producers for another two and one-half years.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 7 Urban guerrillas who are threatening to kill a United States adviser and a Brazilian consul they kidnapped a week ago seized another United States adviser today.

Ferronics, Inc., a Fairport, N.Y., producer of magnetic materials used in the electronics industry, sold its shares publicly for the first time this week. Investors quickly bid them up to a handsome premium.

The President of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association yesterday denounced an Investigation Department move to send three policemen to jail until they testify more fully about their alleged involvement in the collection of payoffs from Manhattan businessmen.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 7 The Chief Justice of the United States, Warren E. Burger, told the chief justices of the states today that "unseemly, outrageous episodes" in courtrooms and overly long trials were "undermining some of the public confidence in the entire system."

For the fourth consecutive summer, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, presented by Miriam Colon, will give a series of free performances in both English and Spanish in parks and playgrounds in Manhattan, the Bronx, Brooklyn and Queens.

Special to The New York Times BRANCHVILLE, N.J., Aug. 7 Frank Chapot, the United States Equestrian Team star, rode Corn Planter to victory in the preliminary jumper class today at the Sussex County horse show.
LANSING, Mich., Aug. 7 A "truth pollution" bill passed the State Legislature today as Michigan continued to react to mercury contamination of bordering Great Lakes waters.
Paul A. Gorman, chairman and president of the Penn Central Company and its railroad-operating subsidiary, the Penn Central Transportation Company, is quitting his $250,000-a-year job on Tuesday.
The Treasury Department announced yesterday the results of its multibillion-dollar August financing operation, which noted the Government $1.9 billion in additional debt.

MIAMI, Aug. 7 Cuba and Chile have signed an agreement to exchange television programs. It is believed to be the first of its type between Havana and a Latin-American country since the Organization of American States imposed economic and diplomatic sanctions against the Government of Fidel Castro in 1964.

Casey Stengel, who managed the New York Mets when the "Amazins" were earning their descriptive adjective by dropping balls all over the field, came to City Hall yesterday and among other things defended longhaired athletes.

The Lomas Nettleton Financial Corporation of Dallas, the nation's largest mortgage banker, announced yesterday that it agreed in principle to acquire all of the stock of three mortgage servicing subsidiaries of the U.I.P. Corporation, Milwaukee.

Keeping cool in the city requires some imagination and, for those who would avoid the obvious, a bit of capital. One of the off-beat ways that is becoming increasingly popular is swimming, skyscraper style.
Robert L. Gibson, formerly a vice president of the General Electric Company, has been elected a director of the Rogers Corporation.

Mr. and Mrs. E. Allen Dennison of Riverdale, the Bronx, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Mansfield Dennison, to Colin Louis Melville Smith of Cambridge, Mass. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. Melville Smith of Leamington Spa, England. A wedding next month is planned.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Aug. 7 Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Braslow have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carol Braslow, to Herbert Edward Richter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert H. Richter of Boston. The wedding is set for Nov. 29.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 A New York electronics engineer believes he has just the thing for apartment house tenants who want to receive frequency modulation stereo broadcast but whose landlords forbid outdoor antennas.
Six bus routes will be changed today and on the three following Saturdays because of the closing of Lexington Avenue and Eighth Street as experimental pedestrian malls.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The Navy, in a continuing drive to meet Administration budget cuts, announced today that it would retire 55 ships in the next six months.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The wholesale price index, on the basis of complete figures, rose six-tenths of one percent in July, the Labor Department reported today.

The hum of air-conditioners and splashing of campus fountains have replaced the crackling of bullhorns and strident shouting of student political rallies. The bustle of class changes has given way to the relaxed strolling of suntanned students.
The supervisor of the Queens Zoo charged yesterday it was the "benighted stepchild" of the Parks Department where animals sometimes sicken and die because of power failures.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The Federal Communications Commission turned down an appeal today for equal radio time by a woman whose opponent for a House seat runs a radio talk show in New York City.

FULLERTON, Calif., Aug. 7 (UPI) Roger Brown, a 10-year National Football League player who played defensive tackle last season at 285 pounds, reported to the Los Angeles Rams' training camp last night weighing 350.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8, (AP) The nation's scheduled airlines asked the Customs Bureau today to make effective as soon as possible its proposed tighter security measures in the handling of international air cargo.
OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 7 Dust Commander snatched a mouthful of hay this morning and chewed it furiously, going back for more before he was finished.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 7 Miss Elizabeth Brown Edgerton and Timothy J. Cullen will be married here Sept. 12 at the home of the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm J. Edgerton Jr., who have announced the engagement of the couple.
Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz moved yesterday against the New York International Art Show, which opened July 31 at the Coliseum, and its executive director, Richard A. Lersch.

ANNISTON, Ala., Aug. 7 (UPI) The loading of two trains with 12,540 nerve gas rockets, destined for disposal in the Atlantic Ocean, was completed today in preparation for a slow, cautious trip that will involve helicopters, special communications cars and caged rabbits.

A sleepy stock market burst to life for a brief period yesterday afternoon in response to the announcement of a 90-day cease-fire in the Middle East. Trading was heavy during the upsurge and the New York Stock exchange's ticker tape at times lagged behind transactions.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 7 Twenty-three years ago, a Jesuit priest teaching at a Roman Catholic boys' school in Bogota that the Colombian political elite traditionally attended was lecturing a lazy pupil on his lack of a sense of life's tragedy. "For example," the priest said, as ...

ARLINGTON, Va., Aug. 7 Eugene Epperson Barnett, a leading figure in the Young Men's Christian Association for more than 40 years, died today at Arlington Hospital after a fall at his home. He was 82 years old.

CHICAGO, Aug. 7 Federal Judge Julius J. Hoffman ruled today that logs of electronic surveillance of Bobby G. Seale, chairman of the Black Panther party, should be turned over to the United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.

OAKLAND, N.J. "It looked like a 17-century lumber yard thousands of feet of ancient lumber stacked everywhere on the floor," recalled Sidney Kingsley as he spoke of the elaborately carved paneled room that he has been puzzling and laboring over for six years.

Michael J. Salamo, an assistant professor of English and former public relations director for Brooklyn College, died Thursday of a heart attack in Methodist Hospital. He was 55 years old and had lived in Brooklyn all his life.

The German-born basso of Russian descent, Ivan Rebroff, took over the stage of Philharmonic Hall on Thursday night. He changed costumes, he bantered with the audience, he raised the lid of the piano for his accompanist, he discussed the songs, and he made himself throughly at home. Indeed, he did everything but sing well.

MIAMI, Aug. 7 (UPI) Dozens of engineers and mechanics swarmed over an Eastern Airlines DC-8 today, trying to learn what caused two malfunctions in which all four of the plane's jet engines lost power simultaneously.

Still suffering the effects of a recent automobile accident, Muddy Waters was leaning on a crutch as he limped onto the performing area in the garden of the Museum of Modern Art on Thursday night. The blues singer sat down stiffly in a chair and took his guitar in his lap. From then on, everything rocked his seven-piece blues band, the enthusiastic ...
ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 7 (AP) A toll collector on the New Jersey Turnpike saved the life of a 10-month-old baby today after she turned blue and stopped breathing in her parents' car here.

DALLAS, Aug. 7 (UPI) George Andrie, the Dallas Cowboys' 6-foot-6-inch 250-pound defensive end, announced his retirement today in an emotional statement that said he would not "compromise my principles" in order to settle a contract dispute with the Cowboys.
The cease-fire between the United Arab Republic and Israel that went into effect last night is the fourth-Middle Eastern truce in the 22 years of Israel's existence.
A state grant of $150,000 for the Saratoga Performing Arts Center was announced last night.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 7 (AP) Carlo Demetz, Italy's skiing sculptor, won Australia's top skiing event the Wills International Cup at Thredbo today.

SONOMA, Calif. August Sebastiani represents the second generation of European vignerons who started the wine business in California, and he still prefers eating such Italian delicacies as capretto, which is kid, chicken feet soup and batter-fried zucchini blossoms.

If governing New York City is one of the world's hardest jobs, Robert F. Wagner may have undertaken the next-hardest in accepting appointment from Governor Rockefeller to rewrite the state's home-rule powers for local governments. The passionate longing of cities, counties, villages and even school boards to govern themselves with less interference and dictation from Albany has been a political issue for a hundred years, more or less.

One man was killed and his daughter and four other persons seriously injured last night when a taxi went out of control at Central Park West and 81st Street and plowed into a crowd leaving a canceled Shakespeare in the Park performance.

In addition to its other problems, the Transit Authority had to cope this week with complaints from irate BMT riders who got on a Manhattan-bound D train in Brooklyn Thursday morning and wound up an hour later back in Brooklyn.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Aug. 7 Two antipoverty officials, a lawyer and a caseworker, were arrested today on trespass charges after they refused an order to leave a migrant farmworkers camp that they were trying to inspect.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 7 (AP) Three battalions of Cambodians trained by the United States Special Forces today reinforced Government troops besieging the crossroads town of Skoun 40 miles northeast of Pnompenh.

BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said today it had filed suit in United States District Court charging a British shoe products manufacturer and its American agent with infringement of Goodyear's Neolite trademark.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 7 Secretary General Thant announced today that the Jarring mission for peace in the Middle East "is now reactivated."
The United Presbyterian Church has agreed to invest more than $100,000 in a factory in Seoul, Korea, that makes artificial limbs.

Howard E. Reinheimer, a leading specialist in theater and copyright law, died yesterday in Lenox Hill Hospital, after a short illness. He was 71 years old and lived at 35 East 76th Street. He also had homes in Beverly Hills, Calif., and Sun Valley, Idaho.

CAIRO, Aug. 7 The United Arab Republic agreed today to reinstate the cease-fire along the Suez Canal. It linked the agreement to Israeli acceptance of a timetable for withdrawal from the lands seized in the war of June, 1967.
BOSTON, Aug. 7 The Summer National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League opened here today with attention focused on the Master Mixed Team Championship.
Large parts of New York City and an area of New Jersey stretching from northern Hoboken to the North Bergen area was covered with a blanket of swamp gas for several hours early today.
Columbia University announced today the appointment of Elie Abel, dean of the university's Graduate School of Journalism, as Godfrey Lowell Cabot Professor of Journalism at the school.
American country furniture at its best is shown in the newly opened exhibition of work by the cabinetmaking Dunlap family of New Hampshire at the Currier Gallery of Art in Manchester.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Thwarted by Congress in attempts to require stronger health warnings on packages of cigarettes, the Federal Trade Commission has moved to require disclosure in cigarette advertising of tar and nicotine content.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 7 (AP) Gretel II, Australia's contender for the America's Cup next month arrived here today aboard the freighter New York Star, completing a 14,000-mile, two-month journey from Sydney.

An Australian official said here yesterday that his Government "definitely didn't like but couldn't do a great deal about" the stock-market gyrations that have followed the mining boom of the last decade.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 At Chrysler's Mound Road engine plant here they are trying green stamps. At the General Motors plant in Lordstown, Ohio, they are trying robots. The aim is the same: To cut costs, improve quality and raise productivity.
After a fire is out, but often before the fire fighters have left the scene, the city's fire marshals move in on the ruin.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 7 Premier Golda Meir expressed hope tonight that the ceasefire with the United Arab Republic would spread to other fighting fronts and that the truce would have no limit in time.

Returns in the Tennessee primary indicate that Senator Alhert Gore faces a difficult campaign for reelection in November. In the Democratic voting, Mr. Gore won only narrowly over a conservative who was making his first statewide race. On the Republican side, William E. The extraordinary rapidity with which Egypt and Israel have put their standstill cease-fire into effect contributes to the growing hope that both sides have finally decided to make a serious effort to negotiate a settlement.
COXSACKIE, N.Y., Aug. 7 William E. Brady, Greene County Assemblyman from 1939 to 1962 and former director of the Brady Funeral Home here, died Wednseday. His age was 80.

It was just the thing for the jaded investor with a penchant for something different. The offer took the form of an ad in the commercial notices section of a Sunday issue of The New York Times. It was placed by an Englishman and it said, in effect: "For sale: Lord of the Manor titles, $2,400 ( 1,000) and up."

Co-ordination between the Economic Development Administration and the city's other major agencies is supposed to be the keynote of Operation Main Street, Mayor Lindsay's effort to rehabilitate 15 marginal shopping areas here.

The Subway Supervisors Association said yesterday that additional serious accidents were likely on the lines because of a shortage of experienced personnel and an alleged de-emphasis of equipment maintenance by transit officials.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 7 (AP) Elsie Hill, leader in the fight for woman suffrage in the United States, who once went to jail for her beliefs, died last night in her home after a heart attack. She was 86 years old.

Grove Press has accepted, at least technically, a labor arbitrator's ruling ordering the avant-garde publishing house to rehire, with full back pay, four women dismissed last April during a dispute over union organizing.

IONNINA, Greece, Aug. 7 (AP) The Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia qualified two boats today for the finals in the world junior rowing championships, giving the United States four entries for tomorrow's title events.

Ted Abernathy has earned his livelihood throwing a baseball since 1952. He dosen't do it in the orthodox way, though, Instead, he throws it underhand. Some call it submarining. Abernathy calls it, "coming straight under."

BROOKLINE, Mass., Aug. 7 Hobbled by a growth on the back of his left foot and "mentally tired" from too much tennis, Arthur Ashe was crushed, 6-1, 6-4, by Tony Roche today in a quarterfinal round match of the $50,000 United States professional championships.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 7 In a television commercial that is being broadcast frequently in Nigeria these days, a young couple approach a Government office to get a license. Apprehensively, they speculate in whispers: Will they have to bribe anyone?

CAIRO, Aug. 7 In a farewell communique, for the time being at least, Cairo's military spokesman reported tonight that Egyptian artillery had opened fire along the length of the Suez Canal against Israeli positions in the Sinai Peninsula.

SYOSSET, L.I., Aug. 7 Mrs. Julia Feininger, widow of Lyonel Feininger, the artist, died at Syosset Hospital today after a long illness. She was 89 years old and lived until a year ago at 235 East 22d Street in New York City. Her husband died in 1956.
Abe Stark, longing for "some rest and solitude," said yesterday that he would retire as Brooklyn Borough President on Sept. 8.
Firemen cleared a six-story apartment building in the Bronx last night after a three-alarm fire engulfed a paint factory at Jackson Avenue and 142d Street.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Louis E. Wyman 2d, 19year-old son of Representative Louis C. Wyman, Republican of New Hampshire, is being held at the Montgomery County Detention Center on a celong charge of possion of marijuana, the police said today.
A man and two women were arrested on the West Side early yesterday morning in a raid on what the police described as a narcotics factory.
Still playing follow the leader, the silver futures market took a jump yesterday in pursuit of the stock market. Stock prices spurted ahead on news of the cease-fire between Israeli and Arab forces.
A brief mid-afternoon upswing enabled most issues to end in the plus column by a narrow margin yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 Interior Department officials told a Senate subcommittee today that the harsh criticism and protest strikes that have marked their management of a new Federal law to protect the health and safety of coal miners had resulted from a "communication gap" that had left them "badly misunderstood."
LONDON, Aug. 7 (Reuters) Albert Finney, the British actor, married Anouk Aimee, the French actress, here today.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 7 (AP) The European Economic Community urged member nations today to increase efforts to relieve the community's labor shortage.
AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 7 J. Edgar Hoover and the Knight newspapers' editorial chairman, John S. Knight, traded sharp rebukes in letters published today on the front page of The Beacon Journal.

GENEVA, Aug. 7 Bernard Cornfeld today told the new management of the Investors Overseas Services mutual fund empire that he founded that it had the alternative of restoring him to an executive role or ousting him in a proxy fight.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) President Nixon said today that he was sending the former astronaut Frank Borman on a mission abroad to try to seek the release of United States prisoners of war in Southeast Asia and obtain humane treatment for those who remain in enemy hands.
Stock prices in London moved in a narrow range with fractional changes on both sides of the previous day's level.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia has ruled that apartment landlords have a responsibility to help protect their tenants from crime.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The Treasury Department revoked today a special shipping privilege that Congressional critics had asserted would produce a "multimillion-dollar windfall" for a tanker concern once headed by Peter M. Flanigan, White House aide.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 7 Eighteen persons were arraigned today on breach of the peace charges after a night of rioting in two of the city's lowincome housing projects.

SANTA FE, N.M., Aug. 7 (AP) The New Mexico Health and Social Services Department said today that the Philmont Scout Ranch in northeast New Mexico has been quarantined because the death of a young Boy Scout yesterday may have resulted from a communicable disease.
The city's first attempt to register voters in a summer campaign from vote-mobiles got under way in Harlem yesterday with an endorsement from City Council President Sanford D. Garelik.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The current round of AmericanSoviet negotiations on limiting strategic arms will end with the cautiously optimistic forecast that future sessions could reach an eventual agreement, informed diplomatic sources said today.

There may, of course, be some value in having highflying reconnaissance planes manned by crews from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration circling over metropolitan areas to snap pictures, as the Federal Government now plans to do. Its plans also call for having this task done by space satellites.

NEWTON, Mass., Aug. 8 (AP) Jane Bastanchury, the former national intercollegiate champion, and Mrs. Paul Dye set the tempo today as the United States took a 5 -3 lead over the British at the halfway mark of the 16th Curtis Cup golf matches.
GREEN BAY, Wis., Aug. 7 Here they come, ready or not.
A policeman reported that 745 bags of heroin were stolen from between his feet yesterday in a Criminal Court room in Manhattan while he was waiting to present them as evidence.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Aug. 7 Col. George Wilton Bennett, U.S.A.F., and Mrs. Bennett have announced plans for the Aug. 30 marriage of their daughter, Miss Donna Lee Bennett, to Lieut. Stanley Richard Seltzer, U.S.A.F., son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley L. Seltzer of New York.
About 150 black Transit Authority policemen demonstrated outside the authority's headquarters at 370 Jay Street, Brooklyn, yesterday to protest alleged discrimination against black employes.

An early-morning raid by Federal law-enforcement authorities yesterday halted what they described as a $100,000a-night gambling operation allegedly run by a member of the Mafia family of Carlo Gambino.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 7 The New York Mets fell farther off the pace than at any time since the first day of summer by losing to the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight, 6-1, before a crowd of 37,556 in Three Rivers Stadium.
Toby Hardwick, a former saxophonist with Duke Ellington's band, died Wednesday in Washington. He was 66 years old.

BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 7 Seven skippers maintained their undefeated status as the Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's Race Week championship series resumed off here today. The final two races of the series will be sailed tomorrow and Sunday.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Aug. 7 Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill, the medalist with a 78, rallied to win the 48th annual Women's WestchesterFairfield Golf Association championship on the last hole today. She defeated Mrs. M. Stuart Roesler of Stanwich, 1 up, in a 36-hole match at Bedford Golf and Tennis Club.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The Army is reverting to a preVietnam war policy that will allow a large number of college graduates in the Reserve Officer Training Corps to spend only three to six months on active duty instead of two years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 A cease-fire went into effect tonight on the Egyptian-Israeli front along the Suez Canal, and the preliminary phase of a new round of negotiations on peace in the Middle East was under way at the United Nations.

We have just been informed by the Governments of the United Arab Republic and Israel of their acceptance of the United States proposal for a standstill cease-fire to come into effect at 2200 hours Greenwich Mean Time today, Friday, Aug. 7.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 7 The Whitney Stakes will occupy the feature spot today on the first Saturday card of the current Saratoga meeting. Although it is to have only its 43d running, comparatively young in this venerable land of the thoroughbred, it is one of the most important events in the caldendar, and this year's entry list attests to that popularity.

Governor Rockefeller and Lieut. Gov. Malcolm Wilson, who have been elected three times on the Republican line alone, have agreed to accept a second line offered them by the Civil Service-Independents party.

A young New York City patrolman and his wife were arrested yesterday in their Brooklyn home, where members of a narcotics squad raiding party allegedly found mariujana, a hypodermic needle and heroin, which the police said the couple "attempted to sell."
SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug. 7 (AP) "You take all the pictures you want. We are the revolutionaries," a gunman told Jim Kean, waving two revolvers in the photographer's face.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The Justice Department filed suits today against the State of Texas and 26 school districts, seeking to compel desegregation for the coming school year in the last large group of holdouts not already under litigation.
ATLANTA, Aug. 8 (UPI) Pam Barnett shot a threeunder-par 70 today and took a two-stroke lead in the opening round of the 54-hole Lady Carling open.

Samuel Weinberg, who retired recently as president of the investment securities firm of S. Weinberg, Grossman Co., Inc., 40 Exchange Place, died yesterday in Parkway Hospital, Forest Hills, Queens, after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 70-31 108th Street, Forest Hills.

CANTON, Ohio, Aug. 7 The National Football League's six weeks of preseason games begin here tomorrow afternoon with the annual Pro Football Hall of Fame contest in Fawcett Stadium, the local high school facility.

Two persons drowned and three others were rescued from the choppy Atlantic Ocean yesterday as their cabin cruiser foundered and sank while being towed by a Coast Guard cutter 31 miles southeast of Cape May, N.J.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 7 Misael Pastrana Borrero, 46 years old, was sworn in tonight as the President of this fourth most populous Latin-American republic.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 7 Weeb Ewbank, the New York Jets' general manager and coach, expressed interest today in Joe Kapp, now in exile from the Minnesota Vikings, but not at Kapp's reported $1.25-million demand for a five-year contract.

NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 7 Metropolitan Transportation Authority officials, under heavy fire recently for their supervision of the New York City subways and the Long Island Railroad, are able to smile when they talk about their most recent acquisition, a general-aviation airport near this city.
YONKERS, Aug. 7 Chalk players among the 26,308 fans who attended Yonkers Raceway tonight owed management a vote of thanks for having made the Hudson Filly Trot a nonbetting race.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 7 Joe Lapchick, the longtime basketball coach, was convalescing from a heart condition today. He is the sports coordinator for Kutsher's Country Club here.

BERLIN, Aug. 7 Eastern European countries have begun to lease manpower and machines to West Germany's expanding building industry in a new form of East-West cooperation that appears to bring profits to both sides.

Mrs. E. Frothingham Lombard of Cambridge, Mass., and Percival H. Lombard of Shirley, Mass., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Eugenia Frothingham Lombard of Glen Ellyn, Ill., to H. Scot Monaghan. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Monaghan of Wheaton, Ill.
Merger negotiations between Dean Witter Co. and Paine, Webber, Jackson Curtis were called off yesterday.

The fighting between Israel and her Arab neighbors stopped late yesterday as an American-proposed cease-fire went into effect. Washington officials said Jordan, Syria and Lebanon would observe the 90-day cease-fire as well as Egypt. Israel and Egypt are to police each other's lines to make sure no military gain results from the halt in hostilities. [Page 1, Columns 5-8; Text. P. 2.]

Fifteen organizations of the Astoria, Long Island City and Ravenswood communities in North Queens that oppose the Consolidated Edison Company's plans to expand its Astoria power plant joined yesterday in a petition to the Board of Estimate for public hearings on the project.

In New York, dealers call the items "cultural antiques"; in northern California, the favorite word is "collectables," in Dallas, "new antiques." In Memphis, Tenn., and Madison, Wis., they simply call the stuff junk but they spell it, with verbal pinkie extended, j-u-n-q-u-e.

BARRIO BANUBO, the Philippines When Miss Salama Engkong and Salud Tino were married in this Mindanao village of 450 Moslems, an all-day gala temporarily turned the drab collection of houses into a hamlet filled with song.
Mrs. Helen Rogers Reid, former president of The New York Herald Tribune, who died in her Fifth Avenue home July 27 at the age of 87, bequeathed $200,000 to her alma mater, Barnard College.

In the suspense thriller league, Stanley Ellin is a 400 hitter. (For those who watch only yacht races and hurling matches, that 400 percentile denotes a performer of more than superior ability.) His novels and short stories have been international successes and have won him a clutch of Edgar Allan Poe awards. They have been translated, dramatized on television and made into motion pictures.

TOKYO, Aug. 7 (AP) Prince Norodom Sihanouk's exile government in Peking has warned foreign newsmen covering the war in Cambodia that unless they obtain its permission, it will not be responsible for their safety. It asserted that its rebel army controlled the whole country.
RICHMOND, Aug. 7 (UPI) Amid tight security, a Federal judge began hearing arguments today on a second school desegregation plan submitted by Virginia's capital city.
Fifteen Detroit Tigers reached base on seven hits and eight walks last night at Yankee Stadium, but only one found his way across home plate.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) The Selective Service System is already drafting men with lottery numbers up to 195, but it now suspects a lower number would have sufficed.

The Justice Department's case against Samuel J. Lefrak, of the nation's leading builders, for allegedly discriminating against blacks in renting apartments, is apparently based largely on investigative work done by the New York Urban League's Operation Open City, a fair-housing organization financed by the Federal antipoverty program.

AKRON, Ohio, Aug. 7 Tom Shaw hurried home to Portland, Ore., for advice last week, after missing the cut in the Westchester Classic, to consult with his golf teacher. This afternoon the 27-year-old blond scored a 66 and tied for the 36-hole lead at 136 with George Archer in the $150,000 American Golf Classic.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 7 William Titon, for many years Macy's master taster, died at his home here yesterday, at 72 Skyline Drive. He had retired last year, and was 90 years old.

DETROIT, Aug. 7 (AP) With model changeover in full swing, United States automobile production declined this week as auto makers scheduled 18,083 assemblies, down from 31,420 last week and 22,084 in the year-earlier period.

President Nixon now has on his desk two big money bills which he must sign on veto. One is the $18-billion bill for various Federal agencies. It would authorize spending $541 million more than Mr. Nixon requested, with the extra money going for urban renewal, water and sewer programs, and veterans' hospitals. The other bill provides $4.4 billion for education $453 million above the Administration budget request.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 7 Linda Kasabian, her face contorted from crying as she was being shown a series of bloody photographs at the murder trial of Charles M. Manson today, turned suddenly to the hippie leader and three young members of his band and asked, "How could you do that?"
Sharply lower earnings were reported yesterday by the LTV Aerospace Corporation for the quarter and six months ended June 30.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 7 Thousands of youths bound for a rock music festival near Toronto have been refused entry into Canada at border crossings here and elsewhere because they could not produce enough money to support themselves during their stay.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 7 Arab commando spokesmen said tonight that they would not observe the Middle East cease-fire and would work to undermine it.
The National Football League exhibition season gets under way today with many stars scheduled to be on the sidelines.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) New evidence of increasing concentrations of lead in the atmosphere ascribed mostly to gasoline additives was reported today by two California scientists. They said the situation might cause global health hazards if unchecked.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 7 (AP) The South Vietnamese Government announced stricter visa requirements for Americans today. The move was believed aimed at keeping out antiwar groups and other persons the Government regards as potential troublemakers or undesirables.

LIMA, Ohio, Aug. 7 (AP) National Guardsmen, policemen and firemen remained on alert today in an effort to check further outbreaks of firebombings and other vandalism in this racially troubled, industrial city.
LONDON, Aug. 7 One of Britain's most endearing heroines, Anna Leonowens, was toppled off her pedestal tonight.

The McLean Trucking Company, one of the largest in its industry, has projected earnings for the year ending June 30, 1971, of $6,733,000, or $4.84 a share, up from $3,783,030, or $2.72 a share, in fiscal 1970.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 7 Amman was subdued but tense tonight as the first report came, by radio, that a Middle Eastern cease-fire had been agreed upon and would come into force tonight.

WESTBURY, L.I, Aug. 7 Miss Susan Mary Byrne, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F.X. Byrne, was married in St. Brigid's Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon to John Francis Picciano, a lawyer with the Justice Department in Miami.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (UPI) The International Union of Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers called a nationwide boycott against RCA Corporation products today after contract negotiations broke off in the 10th week of a strike.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 7 George Sams Jr. testified today that he had an argument with Bobby G. Seale the day he arrived in Oakland, Calif., to enlist as a Black Panther.

West Germany and the Soviet Union have taken a long first step toward a fruitful new era for Europe. The draft initialed in Moscow yesterday is not a substitute for a definitive peace treaty formally ending World War II. It can serve, however, as an interim settlement on which a more satisfactory East-West relationship can be built in Europe one that could lead, in turn, to genuine rapprochement and peace.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The Nixon Administration's first "inflation alert," issued today, identified several recent price increases, some accompanied by large wage increases, that it said had been important in raising the price level. It pointed no finger of blame, however.

Dr. Ludwig Schwarzschild, a dermatologist and professor, died in a hospital in the Netherlands last Monday, after suffering a heart attack while on vacation. He was 71 years old and lived at 200 West 86th Street.

EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 7 J. Sidney Johnson, a market consultant for food manufacturers, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, while swimming at the Devon Yacht Club. He was 80 years old and lived at 26 Courseview Road.
American Smelting Refining Co., for the second time in a month, announced yesterday a price reduction in lead. The new price, effective immediately, is 15 cents a pound.
Harland Sanders, founder of the Kentucky Fried Chicken Corporation, and two other directors of the franchise organization, have resigned from the board.

MOSCOW, Aug. 7 Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko of the Soviet Union and Walter Scheel, the West German Foreign Minister, ended 12 days of negotiations today by initialing a treaty both sides hope will lead to improved West German-Soviet and East-West relations.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 (AP) Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic national chairman, has accused Vice President Agnew of making an "attack on me designed purposely as a smear filled with characteristic innuendo and insinuation."

BOSTON, Aug. 7 (AP) A no-fault auto insurance reform bill cleared the last major legislative hurdle early today and Aetna Casualty and Surety Company, the state's third largest insurer of motor vehicles promptly ordered its agents not to sell any new policies in the state.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 7 The nation's unemployment rate rose in July, again touching the 5 per cent mark, which it had also reached in May.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 7 Mrs. Zimmerman Douglas has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Isabelle Frothingham Douglas, to Robert Sidney O'Hara Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Hara of Old Lyme, Conn. The wedding is planned for next month.

MIAMI, Aug. 8 (AP) The Tartan Stables' heavily favored Willmar took the lead approaching the half-mile pole today and staved off a bid by Papago to win the Dr. Fager Stakes by a length at Tropical Park. The race was named for the Tartan Stables' great horse, now in stud.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 8 Miss Eileen Mary Denari, a former buyer for Saks Fifth Avenue in New York, and James J. Ludwig, a vice president of the company and manager of its San Francisco store, were married here this afternoon at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell Jelline. The ceremony was performed by Family Court Judge Alvin R. Ruskin, former Mayor of New Rochelle.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 8 (UPI) Tony Perez batted in six runs with two homers and a single today as the Cincinnati Reds hit five home runs to trounce the Los Angeles Dodgers, 10-5.

The saga of the Shaggy Hank took a turn toward a happy ending yesterday when Hank McGraw, 27-year-old career minor leaguer, was traded by Eugene, Ore., to Honolulu in the Pacific Coast League, still unshorn.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 8 (AP) The impression that the United States has enjoyed a large and persistent trade surplus with Latin America during the last decade is in correct. John R. Petty, As sistant Treasury Secretary for International Affairs, said here this week.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 8 (AP) John W. Moffett, vice president and advertising director of the Minneapolis Star and Tribune Company, died here today after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 8 Miss Nancy Jane Lomenzo, daughter of John P. Lomenzo, New York Secretary of State, and Mrs. Lomenzo, was married here this morning to Peter Edward Muller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Muller Jr. Msgr. Leslie G. Whalen performed the ceremony at a nuptial mass in Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church.

Nearly all the policemen regularly assigned to the Central Park Precinct have signed a petition calling for the removal from the precinct of a patrolman who has accused the Police Department of harassing him because he has long hair.
"We're people in a hurry," Jeanette Henry explains when describing the ambitious plans of San Francisco's newly founded American Indian Educational Publishers.
MAUD, Ky. Aug. 8 (AP) When the state said it could not afford to build a $17,000 detour while a bridge was being replaced, the people of Maud built their own $563.02 version.
Stroh's Brewery in Detroit has embarked on a crusade. It wants, an executive said, "to bring young people back to beer."

Lew Hoad, the 35-year-old Australian coach of the Spanish Davis Cup team, will be among the sentimental favorites competing in the $160,000 United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills, Sept. 2 through 13.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Aug. 8 Fred Schmid of Marblehead, Mass., sailing Big Beauty, won the first race of the Rhodes-19 Class East Coast championship of Larchmont Yacht Club today. Only one of three scheduled races, began after a threehour wait for sufficient air, was completed in a light southeasterly breeze on Long Island Sound. The series ends tomorrow.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 8 (AP) Sally Sheffer of the Philadelphia Aquatic Club gained her second Eastern diving championship today as she won the one-meter board title with 379.95 points at Kelly Pool in Fairmount Park.
KALAMZOO, Mich., Aug. 8 (AP) The favorites in both age divisions were upset today in semifinals of the national junior and boys tennis championships.

ALBANY, Aug. 8 Miss Grace Cantine Tebbutt and Stephen Christopher Meigher 3d, were married here this afternoon in St. Peter's Episcopal Church by the Rev. Dr. Laman Bruner.

CAIRO President Nasser's charisma, still strong in much of the Arab world despite seemingly endless intrigues, setbacks and challenges, is facing what may be its ultimate test amid the clamor of Arab extremists against his move toward a peaceful settlement with Israel.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Aug. 8 Miss Susan Jean Shipley, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morgan Bowman Shipley Jr., was married in St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church here today to James Russell Downey Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Downey of McLean, Va.

Miss Maureen Jane Fitzgerald and Dennis James Murray, who baked the bread used fof communion at the nuptial mass, were married in St. Benedict's Roman Catholic Church in the Bronx yesterday afternoon.

ATTLEBORO, Mass., Aug. 8 In the Evangelical Covenant Church here today Miss Gretchen Elsa Lundgren, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Arnold Lundgren of Attleboro and Falmouth, was married to Alexander Ingersoll Lewis 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Ingersoll Lewis Jr. of Grosse Pointe, Mich.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 On Monday, for the first time, the House of Representatives is expected to vote on a constitutional amendment that would prohibit any form of discrimination on the basis of sex.

WESTON, Conn., Aug. 8 Barefoot beneath a maple tree outside the bridegroom's farm house here, Miss Susan Elizabeth Lardner, daughter of the late John Lardner, a writer, and herself a staff writer for The New Yorker, was married this aftenoon to Fred Hellerman. WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 Marc Splaver, a May graduate of American University, has been named the school's sports information director.

A decade ago, the New York University basketball coach, Lou Rossini, visited Schenectady, N.Y., to see Barry Kramer, then one of the top schoolboy prospects in the nation. Kramer was starring for Linton High School.

BERKELEY, Calil. After more than five years of Labor, the university reform movement has brought forth mountains of committee reports but only little actual change. This is the essence of a report by the Carnegie Commission on Higher Education, made public here last week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8 (AP) Representative John A. Blatnik says that if Hiawatha came back to see Minnesota's Land of the Skyblue Waters, "he would be sickened at what we have done to them" in a century of pollution.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 8 (UPI) The Internal Revenue Service has notified the promoters of the abortive Powder Ridge Festival that they owe $200,000 in Federal corporate income taxes.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 8 Robert A. Bloomfield brought Chalet d'Ete home 7 minutes 33 seconds inside the time limit today to give the Shields Class an official race on Long Island Sound in the Orienta Yacht Club's 64th annual regatta.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 8 Mrs. Josephine Reeves and Michael S. Dingee of Old Greenwich, were married here this afternoon in the Round Hill Community Church by the Rev. Jurjen J. Hoomans, the assistant pastor.

FIERY RUN, Va., Aug. 8 In this lovely corner of Virginia, men are changing their ideas about the land not much but some. A generation ago, they plowed the foothills of the Blue Ridge to plant corn and the gully-washing rains carried the red earth down the Rappahannock River to the sea.

Tens of thousands of Americans are deaf, blind, handicapped by defective hearts or mentally retarded because their mothers, during early pregnancy (sometimes without even knowing it), experienced a mild ailment known as rubella, or German measles.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 8 (UPI) An inspection of all of Baltimore's 43 nursing homes for possible cases of salmonella poisoning began today following a report of a possible salmonella-related death at a third nursing home in the city.

Mary Stewart's latest is a long-distance ramble through fifth century Britain right up to the accouchement of Ygraine, the mother of King Arthur. The party responsible for bringing together Ygraine and Uther Pendragon, Arthur's dad, is Merlin the magician, who needs all his wizardry for this caper, since Ygraine has a jealous husband with a private army.

The season's first goldenrod is in bloom and, unhappily, so is the ragweed. The two plants, one a beautiful plume of sun-bright blossoms, the other a nondescript head of tiny greenish flowers whose only distinction is their allergenic pollen, often grow side by side. The botanical name of goldenrod is Solidago, which means "to heal" or "to matte whole." The ragweed's botanical name is Ambrosia, which must be either irony or a grim joke.

Kenneth Rogoff of Rochester, who is 17 years old, retained his crown by winning first place in the recent United States Junior Chess Championship at the Hotel McAlpin in New York. RYE, N.Y., Aug. 9 James W. Sykes sailed Dixie to a Shields Class victory over Robert A. Bloomfield and his Chalet d'Ete in the last 100 yards today during the season's 25th Yacht Racing Association championship regatta. The Greenhaven Yacht Club staged the races in light and shifting breezes that were full of holes.

Noncommercial television specifically WGBH-TV in Boston takes the measure of commercial TV in the coverage of at least one sport tennis. Reports and pictures of the United States Professional Tennis Championships at Brookline, Mass., were thoroughly professional and a sustained treat for tennis buffs. They were seen yesterday and on Saturday over Channel 13 via the Eastern Educational Television network.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 (AP) Amid elaborate safety and security precautions, the Army has completed loading lethal nerve gas aboard trains in Anniston; Ala., and Richmond, Ky. It will send the trains through the South tomorrow toward a disposal in the Atlantic.

BABYLON, L. I., Aug. 9 The Great South Bay Yacht Racing Association's race week championship came to a close today with only three skippers completing the five-race series undefeated. They are Marc MacDonell among the Cape Cod's, Bryce Suydam in the Sun Fish Class open division and Joe Pfingst in the Signe-T Class open division.

Emilio Colombo has succeeded in ending Italy's month-long Cabinet crisis. With luck, his Government Italy's 32d since the fall of Mussolini will get the necessary votes of confidence in Parliament this week, in time for the politicians to flee Rome for the annual Ferragosto holiday.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 9 Dr. Stuart R. Brinkley Jr., physicist and authority on combustion and detonation processes, died Friday at his summer home in South Bristol, Me. He was 54 years old.
DOVER, Del., Aug. 9 (UPI) Jim Paschal of High Point, N.C., driving a 1970 Javelin won the Blue Hen 200 at Dover Downs International Speedway today. His average speed was 102,462 miles an hour.

SUEZ, United Arab Republic, Aug. 9 Egyptian troops in this war-shattered town were vigilant and wary today as the cease-fire with Israeli forces a few hundred yards away neared the end of its second day. No shooting incidents were reported.
SAN DIEGO, Aug. 9 (UPI) Solo home runs by Ed Spiezio and Nate Colbert marked San Diego's 11-hit attack today as the Padres beat the Atlanta Braves, 4-2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Senator Jacob K. Javits raised the possibility today that United States and Soviet troops might be used to help police the cease-fire in the Sinai Penninsula.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Aug. 9 Within 24 hours of taking office, President Misael Pastrana Borrero said he favors speeding the drawing up of "rules of the game" for private foreign investment in Colombia. These rules may then apply throughout the Latin American Free Trade Association, he said.

And just about all of them, says the manufacturer and the publisher, were serious.
PARIS, Aug. 9 The French Government has suspended the construction of one multimillion dollar project while the fate of a second remains in doubt.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9 (UPI) Jerry Reuss pitched a two-hitter to give the St. Louis Cardinals a 4-0 victory today after the Montreal Expos won the first game, 7-6. Bobby Wine's double with the bases-loaded capped a four-run seventh inning rally in the opener.
An intense, behind-the-scenes battle is shaping up over a key provision in the bill to regulate one-bank holding companies, which is currently awaiting action by the Senate.
Barcelona of Ecudor and Deportivo Call of Colombia, two of the strongest soccer teams in South America, battled to a 1-1 tie at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island yesterday before 7,980 fans.

A fire in a diesel-electric locomotive sent thick clouds of smoke into Grand Central Terminal yesterday forcing the evacuation of 20 people from the lobby of the Biltmore Hotel, which is directly above part of the terminal.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug, 9 Midnight Flight, owned and ridden by Pat Gibson of Huntington, L. I., won the amateurowner hunter championship at the Brookville Horse Show today. In the process, he beat War Count, who had been undefeated on Long Island this year.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 9 (AP) A Marine and a civilian posted scores of 1,599 out of a possible 1,600 today at the end of the first day of individual shooting in the national small bore rifle prone championships.
Racing will open at two New Jersey tracks today on the heels of a record-setting season at Monmouth Park.

The new local school boards and the Board of Education will meet today in an attempt to resolve the first severe controversy between them since decentralization began in earnest in the city on July 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9 Some public schools that are desegregating in the South are running into trouble from an unexpected source their insurance companies. Some have had their rates raised, some have had coverage reduced and some have had their policies canceled entirely.

GENEVA, Aug. 9 Bernard Cornfeld announced today that he had taken action to force the calling of a special shareholders' meeting that would restore him to control of the Investors Overseas Services mutual-fund complex that he founded 14 years ago. The bearded former Brooklyn College student, who will be 43 years old this month, was deposed in May by a boardroom revolt.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 9 Francis P. Beattie's Luders-16 Class sloop, Galure; William E. Hegarty's and Richard B. Nye's Soling, Nebulous, and John E. Muhfeld's Quincy Adams 7, Ajax, won slow 6.4-mile races today when half of the 60 starters in the Rocky Point Club's regatta failed to finish because a light easterly breeze died.

ALAMOGORDO, N.M., Aug. 6 Last October, when the Ernest Lee Huckleby family butchered a hog, stored the meat in their freezer and began eating it at meals, the cuts of pork on their plates resembled any others. They looked the same, smelled the same and tasted the same.
William Robert Miller, who wrote on Christian thought and philosophy, died yesterday after a heart attack in his home at 134-19 166th Place in Jamaica, Queens. He was 43 years old.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 10 The pleas of oil-purchasing companies for more oil were heeded today when the Texas Railroad Commission increased August production by 88,750 barrels a day, lifting the allowed flows of wells to 70 per cent of their production capabilities.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Agriculture Department forecast today the 1970 cotton crop at 11,078,900 bales, a 10 per cent increase from last year's output of slightly more than 10 million bales.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 10 Two unscheduled performers at the Ann Arbor Blues Festival yesterday Junior Wells, the harmonica player and singer, and Johnny Winter, the guitarist and singer proved to be just what the audience had been waiting for.

The New York Stock Exchange said yesterday that it was making a "routine" check of the possibility that some of its members might be in financial trouble as a result of the insolvency of the Eatontown National Bank.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Aug. 10 Dr. Alexander Gode, a prominent translator and lexicographer, died of cancer early this morning at Northern Westchester Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at Finney Farm in Croton-on-Hudson.
STATELINE, Nev., Aug. 10 (AP) Joe Frazier, the world heavyweight boxing champion, will give Bob Foster, the light heavyweight title-holder, a shot at his crown, Frazier's manager said today.

DUBLIN, Aug. 10 (UPI) Kipchoge Keino of Kenya, drawing on reserves of finishing speed, burst past Frank Murphy of Ireland tonight to win the Billy Morton Memorial mile in 3:59.2 at an international meeting.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 10 (UPI) Ronald O. West of Zanesville, Ohio; fired three. straight perfect scores today and took the lead in the national small bore rifle matches. He had a seven-match total of 2,798 points out of a possible 2,800.

The man who set up his own agency a couple of months ago and decided to limit accounts to "socially renovative" products and public issues got to talking yesterday about the role of such advertising and its relationship to the agency world.
SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 10 A lavish large-scale production of Verdi's "Otello," conducted and staged by Herbert von Karajan, was greeted enthusiastically tonight in the Large Festspielhaus.
EAST HAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 10 East Hampton is fortunate in having not one, but two first-rate serious theaters in residence this summer.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange continued to drop yesterday in the slowest trading in almost four years.
Deputy Commissioner Benjamin Ward, a Police Department trial officer, ordered the lawyer for a suspended detective ejected from the trial room yesterday and threatened him with arrest.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 (AP) Fighting between North and South Vietnamese forces was reported today in the mountains near an abandoned United States artillery base named Ripcord in the northern part of South Vietnam. More than 1,000 enemy soldiers were believed to be massing for an attack on a South Vietnamese base.

The top Federal air-pollutioncontrol official said yesterday that it would be "imprudent" to allow expansion of Consolidated Edison's plant in Astoria, Queens, because of the contamination that it would add to the city's air.
The liquidation of another major brokerage house was announced yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange, which said a liquidator had been appointed in the failure of Dempsey-Tegeler Co.

Long strides have been made in public awareness of the environmental crisis and in Government programs to cope with it in the five years since President Johnson summoned a White House conference on the coyly named subject, natural beauty. One proof of progress is that there is now in the Office of the President a three-man Council on Environmental Quality modeled on the Council of Economic Advisers.
LONDON, Aug. 10 In a quick response to public protests, the Post Office announced today that it would take another look at a new system of listing names in British telephone books.
New York's subway cars are giving five states in the union some unasked-for publicity, because the Transit Authority's painting program lags.

Thousands of dead menhaden, one of the most plentiful and commercially valuable fish of the Atlantic Coast, were found yesterday washed up on beaches bordering Long Island Sound, from Orchard Beach to Port Washington.
Pierre Salinger has been named deputy chairman of the board of directors of Gramco U.K., Ltd., with its headquarters in London.

MILTON, Mass., Aug. 10 Dr. and Mrs. Robert Mitchell Putnam have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail Putnam, to Robert Emmet, son of Mrs. Richard Stockton Emmet of Glen Head, L.I., and the late Mr. Emmet and a descendant of Thomas Addis Emmet, brother of Robert Emmet, the Irish patriot.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 10 (AP) A Federal judge ordered the Corpus Christi School District today not to make major repairs of damage from Hurricane Celia.
