OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 10 If the nation's Governors are competent as political pundits, 1970 is not destined to be a year of sweeping Republican gains.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 10 Undeterred by light failure that delayed the start of the game half an hour, and aided by nine walks and two errors in the first four innings, the New York Mets defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 10-2, tonight as Tom Seaver pitched a six-hitter for his 17th victory.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 With the nation not yet through its summer power shortages, the chairman of the Federal Power Commission warned today that further shortages were possible next winter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 President Nixon sent Congress today the first White House report on the "state of the nation's environment." The document gave an exhaustive analysis of the ecological problems facing the country but offered few new proposals for solving them.

Betty Furness, who was President Lyndon B. Johnson's special assistant for consumer affairs, was named yesterday as chairman and executive director of the newly formed State Consumer Protection Board.

MUSCAT, Aug. 10 Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman, who overthrew his father's rule 18 days ago, yesterday changed the name of his country, invited exiles to return, inveighed against Communism and announced a long list of reforms and development plans.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 The House of Representatives, by the overwhelming vote of 350 to 15, passed today a constitutional amendment prohibiting discrimination on the basis of sex.

ROME, Aug. 10. Premier Emilio Colombo, making a formal appeal for a parliamentary vote of confidence for his four-day-old coalition Government, promised today that he would not devalue the lira but would take prompt fiscal measure to stimulate production and contain domestic demand.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 10 Frederick B. Lacey, the United States Attorney for New Jersey, said today that he would begin presenting evidence to a grand jury tomorrow in the case of the Eatontown National Bank, which was closed Saturday.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 (AP) The General Motors Corporation has announced the recall of about 16,500 medium-duty trucks and school buses for correction of possible brake defects.
Bill Paultz, a rookie 6-foot11-inch center was acquired by the New York Nets yesterday from the Virginia Squires for an undisclosed amount of cash and a draft choice.
LONDON, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Just two weeks after the end of a costly national dock strike, the Port of London Authority today announced increases up to 27.5 per cent in port charges.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 During a balance of payments crisis a few years ago, Representative Martha W. Griffiths startled the Under Secretary of the Treasury, Robert V. Roosa, when she asked sweetly: "Tell me, Mr. Roosa, why do we have to have gold in the first place?".
Harry Heltzer has been named chairman and chief executive officer, 3M Company, succeeding Bert S. Cross who is retiring Raymond H. Herzog succeeds Mr. Heltzer as president.

DELMAR, Calif. Aug. 10 (AP) Bill Shoemaker, who became the second jockey in history to win 6,000 races in a career last Saturday, rode four winners, including Daryl's Joy in the feature race at Del Mar today.

Even so, the gross offensiveness and latent risks of the scheme suggest what a mess the nation has got itself into.
United Air Lines, Inc., announced yesterday it had filed with the Civil Aeronautics Board for authority to increase its fares by 5 per cent, effective Oct. 15.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (.AP) Sixteen Republicans in the House proposed today the virtual removal of the Reserve Officer Training Corps from college campuses to improve the program and help cool volatile student antimilitarism.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Michael W. Strauss, commissioner of the United States Bureau of Reclamation in the Truman Administration and a strong advocate of public power and irrigation projects, died yesterday of a heart attack in Chamberlain, Me., where he was visiting a friend. He was 73 years old.
Shipments of mobile homes declined slightly during June from the level a year earlier, the Mobile Homes Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Aug. 10 The Ford Motor Company plans to build 400,000 Pintos its new minicar in the coming model year, setting the stage for a fierce fight between Ford, Chevrolet and Volkswagen for the smallcar market.
BILBAO, Spain, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Two stationmasters were arrested today after a collision of two trains caused the deaths of 33 persons and injured 136.

BUFFALO, Aug. 10 (AP) Good students, leaders of high school clubs and student councils, athletes, musicians and prom queens the 20 New York State students killed in a plane crash in Peru yesterday were mourned and praised today by their families, friends and teachers.

BONN, Aug. 10--The two leaders of the Christian Democratic Union told Chancellor Willy Brandt today that their conservative parliamentary Opposition was against his plan to sign a nonaggression treaty with the Soviet Union in Moscow on Wednesday.

MOSCOW, Aug 10 (AP) A cholera epidemic that broke out in Soviet Central Asia appeared to be spreading in the European part of the Soviet Union. Travel was restricted to cities as far north as the Ukraine and warning signs sprouted in Moscow's fruit and vegetable markets.
A new superintendent of Brooklyn's Community School District 13 was appointed last night and promptly issued a challenge to the citywide Board of Education.

Two legislative proposals designed to stimulate apartment house construction' were denounced as wasteful by landlords yesterday but praised as crucial by the city's housing chief, who pleaded for early passage.

After 11 months of almost constant traveling, Duke Ellington has settled down at the Rainbow Grill for what has become an annual fiveweek visit. WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) The Radio Corporation of America and the International Union of Electrical Workers reached a tentative agreement today to end a 10-week strike affecting some l2,000 workers at 14 plant locations.

For the second time in a month, the St. Joe Minerals Corporation said yesterday that it would cut the price of lead "reluctantly." Once again, St. Joe was following a move, which it called "unjustified," that was initiated by the American Smelting and Refining Company.

BERLIN, Aug. 10 Walter Ulbricht, the East German head of state, has appealed to some North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries and nonaligned Western states to grant diplomatic recognition to East Germany in view of the "basically new situation" in Europe growing out of the Soviet-West German accord.

HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 10 Harold B. Dorsey, founder and board chairman of the Argus Research Corporation, an influential advisory service for brokerage firms, mutual funds and banks, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home here. He was 70 years old.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Ave. Aug. 10 (AP) Gene Scott of New York, Tom Leonard of Los Angeles and Charles Owens of Tuscaloosa, Ala., led the seeded players into the second round of the United States grass court amateur tennis championships today. A field of 64 began play today at the Meadow club.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that during the first six months of the year it had spent more than ever before and more than any other corporation to improve and expand service.

Senator Charles E. Goodell called for increased appropriations for prison reform yesterday while his Democratic opponent. Representative Richard L. Ottinger called for new programs to reduce unemployment.

Institutional investors particularly mutual funds tended to make the shares of smaller, relatively spectaculative companies more volatile during the last decade but in general did little to improve the efficiency of the stock market in allocating capital to areas of the economy that need it most, a major academic analysis concluded yesterday.

BOSTON, Aug. 10 Pairs from New England and Florida led the field into the second semifinal of the life master pair championship at the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals at the Boston Sheraton today, with three New York partnerships in close pursuit.

Some 60,000 gallons of gasoline that accidentally spilled early yesterday from a Texaco tanker into the Kill Van Kull and spread over a four-mile area was virtually cleaned up by midday, the Texaco company reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 White House sources said today that President Nixon had decided not to veto the $4.4billion education appropriation bill that is $453-million above his budget request.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 10 (Reuters) Itzhak Rubin, Israel's Ambassador to the United States, left today to return to Washington.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 10 Alex Webster made the big switch today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 10 President Jorge Pacheco Areco's decision not to yield to the demands of terrorist guerrillas, which prompted their murder of an American hostage yesterday, was entirely consistent with his record as a roughand-tumble politician while chief executive of this small nation.

BOSTON, Aug. 10--A record attendance of 307 chess players competed in the opening session of the 71st annual United States Open Championship in the Parker House here last night. The event is a round Swiss system.
Weakness in the stock market yesterday had a subduing effect on some commodity futures, both as to volume and to price.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
Hayward Keniston, former dean of the University of Michigan College of Literature, Science and the Arts, died yesterday at a nursing home in Yarmouth, Nova Scotia. He was 87 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 10 Senate Republican leaders expressed confidence today that on a crucial vote Wednesday the Senate would approve, by a two-vote margin, an Administration proposal to expand the Safeguard antiballistic-missile system.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 9 A case that may produce a landmark decision on the disposal of radioactive wastes has been set for trial on Oct. 5 by a Federal District Court here.
McSorley's Old Ale House opened its doors to women yesterday for the first time in its 116-year history and within two hours had its first coed fight.

ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 10 Charging that the state's $1billion "pure waters" bond issue had not eliminated water pollution, Arthur J. Goldberg declared today that at least $1.5-billion more in state aid, in addition to unspecified Federal aid, would be necessary to cleanse the state's waters.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 10 (UPI) Rick Monday got four hits and drove in two runs today to pace the Oakland Athletics to a 7-3 victory, their third in a row over the Minnesota Twins.

Gatorade and Energade are now being joined by Olympade in the ranks of thirst quenchers geared particularly, but not exclusively, for the athletic set. But only Olympade offers this super-special exclusive: use of the red, white and blue interlinking-ring trademark of the United States Olympic Committee.

SAN RAFAEL, Calif., Aug 10 (UPI) The first shots in a gun battle that killed a judge and three men holding him hostage were fired by the kidnappers, the police said today, and a San Quentin prison guard took what the police said was "reasonable, action" in returning the fire.

WASHINGTON Mrs. Edward M. Kennedy's dressmaker ... the wife of David Lloyd Kreeger, the philanthropist ... the wife of Robert S. McNamara, president of the World Bank ... the wife of Senator Karl E. Mundt ... the wife of Richard M. Helms, director of the Central Intelligence Agency almost anyone in Washington Who goes out a lot eventually drops in at the G Street Remnant Shop to see what's available.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 10 (AP) Sharon Walsh, the defending champion from San Rafael, Calif., defeated Daryl Gralka of Houston, Tex., 6-2, 6-0, today in the second round of the United States girls' 18and-under grass court tennis championship at the Philadelphia Cricket Club.

Miss Charlotte Diana Smith and Bruce Alan Crane plan to be married on Aug. 28. Their engagement has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. Edward W. Smith of New York, parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry D. Crane of Plymouth, N.H.
A teamster strike against she United Parcel Service, started by a dispute over the wearing of various lapel buttons, was ended last night, a union spokesman announced.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 10 Henry N. Flynt, a lawyer who helped spearhead the preservation of Old Deerfield, Mass., as a New England village of the 1700's, died today at his summer home in Bay Head, N.J. Here, he lived at 547 North Street. He was 77 years old.
Twelve Democratic and two Republican Senators have accepted an offer of free time on noncommercial television to express their opposition to President Nixon's policies on the Indochina war.

The people walking on Third Avenue near East 21st Street the other morning could hardly believe their eyes. Those were women who were lugging furniture out of an apartment building and loading it onto a truck.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 10 Mayor Thomas J. Whelan ordered the deployment of extra police tonight in a downtown neighborhood that was the scene of a rock-throwing and bottle-throwing involving 200 people last night and early today.

Eighteen stations across the country, including Channel 9 (WOR) in New York, will telecast the Adios Stake from The Meadows harness track in Meadow Lands, Pa., on Saturday night. This will mark the first live network offering of a harness race.
State Supreme Court Justice Irving L. Levey died yesterday while vacationing in Montecatini, Italy. He was 71 years old and lived at 200 East End Avenue.
LONDON, Aug. 10 The tangled drama of Brian Lea, a minor British diplomatic official in Uganda, has taken another turn before a fascinated public audience and an embarrassed Government.

OSSINING, N.Y., Aug 10 Sylvester L. Vigilante, the retired chief of the New York Public Library's American History Room in the Fifth Avenue building, died here last night. He was 79 years old and had homes here and in Moretown, Vt.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10 (UPI) Gretel II, the Australian challenger in the America's Cup races, was launched today and prepared for her first tests afloat since being damaged in an unloading accident.

HOUSTON, Aug. 10 (AP) Jim Bouton, the author of "Ball Four," 'the controversial baseball book, retired as a player today, saying he had lost his knuckleball pitch and didn't want to drag his family through the minor league life.
Fortune magazine said yesterday that in its reference in its August issue to accounting practices of the Penn Central Company it had been in error in some instances.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 10 (UPI) Eight Marine Corps reservists who refused to get military-style haircuts were sentenced yesterday to forfeiture of pay and reduction in rank.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 10--The body of Dan A. Mitrione, chief United States police adviser to Uruguay, was found today in an automobile parked in a Montevideo street 11 days after he was kidnapped by urban guerrillas.
Corporate and Treasury bonds declined in price yesterday as the investment banking community prepared to handle this week's huge volume of new fixed-income securities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) President Nixon signed today a bill extending unemployment insurance coverage to 4.7 million more workers and said that it would cushion the move from a wartime to a peacetime economy.
Six leading retail chains reported yesterday increased sales in July over the yearearlier month.
A 16-year-old boy who wants to be a doctor took a step yesterday in that direction. He was a guinea pig.

"Ever since I can remember, I've been hearing that Broadway musicals are dead," said Richard Rodgers. And with that he sat back and watched the beginning of rehearsals for "Two by Two," his musical version of Clif-' ford Odets's "The Flowering Peach," starring Danny Kaye as Noah. The show is scheduled to open at the Imperial Theater on Oct. 29.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Aug. 10 (Reuters) A Cambodian diplomat and a group of Cambodian students seized their embassy here today on behalf of the Peking-based exile government of Prince Norodom Sihanouk.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 10 (AP) Claiborne Farm's Title and W. C. Partee's I'm for Mama made it a two-horse race and dominated the $20,000 added Silver Anniversary Stakes at Atlantic City today.
Stock prices in London were irregular yesterday in quiet dealings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10 (AP) United States and Soviet negotiators have reached tentative agreement to expand commercial airline service between the two nations, but diplomatic sources report that the United States has rejected a Soviet bid to permit transcontinental flights over both nations.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 10 (AP)--Joe Lapchick, one of basketball's Original Celtics, who spent 50 years in the sport as a player and coach, died today at Hamilton Avenue Hospital, where he was taken last week after having suffered a heart attack. He was 70 years old.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 10 (AP) The U.S. command acknowledged today for the first time that Cambodians were flying aboard observation planes piloted by Americans to help spot targets for bombing strikes in Cambodia.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 10 The expectation is growing here that indirect ArabIsraeli negotiations on the substance of a Middle Eastern peace settlement will get under way at the United Nations within a week.
MARSTRAND, Sweden, Aug. 11 (AP) Tommy Blackaller of San Francisco won the third race in the world Star Class yachting championship today.
LONDON, Aug. 11 (Reuters) The British Post Office tonight bowed to a volley of criticism and withdrew its latest brain child telephone directories that do not list names alphabetically.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 11 The body of Dan A. Mitrione, an American hostage who was slain by terrorists, was flown to the United States tonight, accompanied by his widow and their nine children.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 11 (AP) The Army, reinforced by a Federal court decision, moved today to resume its efforts to court-martial Sgt. Esequiel Torres, one of the 12 soldiers charged in the alleged massacre at Songmy, South Vietnam.

MOSCOW, Aug. 11-Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany arrived here today for the signing tomorrow of a treaty with the Soviet Union aimed at improving relations between the two countries and over-all East-West relations.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission proposed restrictions today on advertisements for insect and weed killers, including the posting of a prominent health warning.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) A Senate Public Works subcommitee is close to approving legislation that would set a national deadline for meeting uniform air quality standards.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 11 (UPI) Six Suffolk County youths were arrested today on charges of raping a Manhattan teen-ager outside Agwam Park here last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The State Department announced today that Uruguay planned to erect a memorial in Montevideo to Dan A. Mitrione, the American slain by Uruguayan terrorists, and to name a street there after him.

United Parcel workers, wearing American Flag emblems in their lapels, returned to their jobs throughout the metropolitan area yesterday, ending a two-week dispute over the wearing of lapel buttons that had disrupted service.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 11 An appeal in strong terms for the lives of two hostages held by terrorists in Uruguay was issued by Secretary General Thant today.

BLOCK ISLAND, R.I., Aug. 11- The Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, the fugitive priest convicted of destroying draft records to protest the war in Vietnam, was arrested today by a dozen agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation who waited in the bushes around a private house and posed as bird watchers.

A new toll collection system to speed traffic and cut labor costs will go into effect at 2 A.M. today on nine Hudson River Bridges and tunnels and three crossings between Staten Island and New Jersey.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 11 (AP) David Rose 3d, an Army Reserve captain from Woodbury, L.I., did not lose a point today and moved into the lead in the race for the national small-bore rifle prone championship with a three-day score of 4,796 points of a possible 4,800.
MOSCOW, Aug. 11 (UPI) Nikolai R. Erdman, a wellknown playwright of the twenties whom Stalin sent into exile in Siberia in 1935, died yesterday. He was 68 years old.

An agency has to throw itself into the work of a client to know what's going on and that goes for a volunteer account too. So when McCann-Erickson took on the job of developing better understanding for the Detroit Police Department, its representatives began riding the prowl cars to get a feel of the policeman's job.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 11 The President's Commission on Campus Unrest apparently was stymied today in its attempt to learn exactly what happened at Jackson State College the night of May 14 when two students were killed and 12 others wounded by law enforcement officers firing shotguns.

John M. King, the Denver oil man who gained world prominence in his unsuccessful bid to gain control of Investors Overseas Services, surprised the financial world yesterday by disclosing that he would step down as chairman of the Colorado Corporation an oil development company he largely owns.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 A $5-million Senate bill to provide for exchange visits for 1,000 political leaders of the United States and Soviet Union over the next five years ran into resistance today in a House foreign affairs subcommittee.

Richard F. Gamble has been elected division president of United Aircraft's Hamilton Standard division. Edmund V. Marshall has been named to succeed Mr. Gamble as executive vice president, Hamilton Standard.
Jim Bunning became the second pitcher in major league history to win 100 games in each league but the Philadelphia fans had to listen to the 6-5 victory last night over the Houston Astros on radio.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 A psychologist described today as "rigged" the findings of a Presidential panel investigating the relationship of pornography to antisocial behavior.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 11 For the second season in a row the Giants appeared to have struck it rich with their first draft choice. Jim Files, the country boy from the University of Oklahoma, has everyone in the C. W. Post training camp satisfied with his work at middle linebacker.

Escorted by fireboats, helicopters and a Chinese junk, the hulk of the Wavertree, a once proud and graceful three-masted sailing ship, arrived yesterday at the South Street Seaport Museum, where she will be restored as the major exhibit.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company asked Judge John P. Fullam of the Federal District Court in Philadelphia yesterday to authorize them to continue paying interest and meeting the maturity installments of more than $1-billion of equipment obligations.
Stock prices in London drifted lower in slow trading yesterday.

PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 11 The defending champion, Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Essex County, led the way into the second round of the New Jersey women's amateur golf championship today by defeating Mrs. Richard Newman of Green Brook, 6 and 5, over the par 74, 5,761-yard Plainfield Country Club Course.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 11 William F. Luddy, the Westchester County Democratic chairman, announced today that he was returning a third of the contributions to his campaign for re-election because he didn't need the money after all.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 11 (AP) The Getty Oil Company said today it was making a major organizational realignment.
OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 11 One thing is indisputable: This is the most secure Governors' conference ever.

ALBANY, Aug. 11 The Public Service Commission ruled today that the Penn Central could not "restructure" rates on its New Haven line, partly because some of the proposals called for 100 per cent increases.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 11 Bobby Fischer, the 28-year-old former United States champion, won his seventh consecutive international chess tournament last night by clinching first place in the Buenos Aires international, with three rounds to go.

BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 6 The growing association of the priestly cassock with revolutionary violence has become a concern of crisis proportions to both the Roman Catholic Church and the Argentine Government.

A petition with 1,000 signatures protesting Columbia University's plan to install an atomic reactor on its campus near 120th Street and Amsterdam Avenue was presented yesterday to Deputy Mayor Timothy W. Costello.

The New York City Ballet will present 18 ballets from the repertory in a special two-week season at the State Theater from Tuesday evening, Aug. 25, through Sunday afternoon, Sept. 6.

After his flight was delayed for two hours because of a bomb threat, Chancellor Willy Brandt of West Germany arrived in Moscow yesterday to sign a nonaggression and cooperation treaty between his country and the Soviet Union. Mr. Brandt was greeted at the airport by Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, who will sign the treaty for the Soviet Union, (Page 1, Column 4; Text, P. 2.)

SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 11 (UPI) Cesar Chavez, leader of the California farm workers' union, began a hunger strike today and sought his own arrest in a dispute with the teamsters' union and Salinas Valley growers.

Norton Simon, Inc., a consolidation of the Canada Dry Corporation, Hunt Foods Industries, Inc., and the McCall Corporation since mid-1968 showed almost a 17 per cent increase in earnings for both the quarter and the fiscal year ended June 30, with annual sales exceeding the billiondollar mark.

A 1970 low for I.B.M., downward drifting prices, slow volume, a lack of bids for stock by institutions. That was the story of the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

Four members of the City Council plan to introduce a resolution committing the city to withholding the portion of Federal taxes that go toward financing the Vietnam war, Councilman Donald R. Mames said yesterday. The taxes would be a portion of those the city withholds from the pay of its employes.

It is early morning on the Brooklyn Bridge. The harbor glistens, and overhead thick white clouds are suspended as though giants had splattered spoonfuls of whipped cream against the light blue sky. Far in the distance an airplane's jetstream unfolds behind the Statue of Liberty and, for a startling moment, it seems as though the lady's torch is smoking.

MANHASSET, L.I., Aug. 11 James Dee, Ridgewood Country Club, who won from Mark Lettman, Huntington Country Club, 4 and 3, will meet Tod Pike, Rye Golf Club, in one semifinal of the Metropolitan Golf Association boys' championship tomorrow at the Deepdale Golf Club course. Michael Occi, Orange Avenue Junior High School, will meet Gary Carlson, Knoll Golf Club, in the other semifinal.

A Federal judge ordered the Army yesterday not to take any further steps to dismiss a West Point cadet from the United States Military Academy until a court can pass on his attempt to get a discharge as a conscientious objector.

MERRIMACK, N.H., Aug. 11?Mr. and Mrs. Willard I. Jebb have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Jebb, to Pfc. Harry Remington Tether, U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Willard L. Tether of Bronxville, N.Y. A wedding in the autumn is planned.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11- The House moved today to cut campaign costs and control television's impact on politics by limiting the expenditures that candidates may make on broadcast advertising.

Many Portuguese hoped the recent death of Antonio de Oliveira Salazar would free his successor, Marcello Caetano, to lead Portugal into more liberal and enlightened policies at home and abroad. But Mario Soares, leader of the banned democratic Socialist opposition, always doubted that Premier Caetano would use his escape from the Salazar shadow in such positive ways.
PARIS, Aug. 11 The French Communist party has asked Chancellor Willy Brandt to lift the 14-year-old legal ban on the Communist party in West Germany.

Strong opposition was voiced yesterday before the Landmarks Preservation Commission over the Metropolitan Museum of Art's proposed expansion into Central Park.

Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., a major investment banking concern, reported yesterday that its earnings before taxes were $752,894 in the six months ended June 30. A year earlier it had a $164,481 loss.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 11 (AP) South Vietnamese troops supported by United States planes, battled today to repulse enemy soldiers threatening an artillery and patrol camp near Laos.

A Long Island group filed suit yesterday to block a Suffolk County highway construction program that it said would contaminate two wildlife preserves and kill fish and marsh birds.

Prisoners rioted yesterday afternoon and into the night at the Manhattan House of Deten tion for men, holding three guards as hostages until they reached an agreement with the city that jail conditions would be investigated and a report would be made public within three weeks.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 (UPI) All the contenders for the America's Cup were in the water together for the first time today, but they picked a bad day for it.

TRENTON, Aug. 11?Maj. Gen. James F. Cantwell, the former chief of the New Jersey National Guard and the current president of the National Guard Association of the United States, was indicted today on charges of having used state employes to make additions to and improvements on his home.
BERLIN, Aug. 11 East Germany today endorsed to the Soviet-West German treaty, calling the conclusion of the pact "good news."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) The Agriculture Department estimated today that this year's corn crop would be 4,692,864,000 bushels, a 3 per cent increase over last year's 4,577,864,000 bushels but a 3 per cent decline from its July forecast. DONCASTER, England, Aug. 11 (Reuters) A decision will be made Friday on whether to run Nijinsky in the St. Leger, last of the major English races, on Sept. 12.

WILLOUGHBY, Ohio, Aug. 11 Mr. and Mrs. Edward Lewis Meister have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Katharine Elizabeth Meister, to William Christian Miller 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Miller of Englewood, N.J.
The best conductors create a sense of design in music. Hearing them one feels a mind at work, shaping, balancing, setting details in place in a grand, developing structure.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11- The House Ways and Means Committee approved today a major revision of the nation's foreign trade laws, with provisions that would lead to import restrictions on shoes, textiles and almost certainly some other products.

"Don't tell me popcorn grows on trees!" exclaimed Chris Warme, a 9-year-old Fresh Air Fund camper from the Bronx, as she and four of her cabinmates walked among the tall stalks of corn on Sharpe Reservation's model farm.
MEXICO CITY, Aug. 11- President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz proposed today legislation that could kill the present system of quick divorces in Ciudad Juarez that is used by many New York residents.

BONN, Aug. 11 Two morning newspapers of the conservative publisher Axel Springer published today the text of the Soviet-West German treaty, which is to be signed in Moscow tomorrow and has not been officially made public.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11- President Nixon, in an action that caught much of Congress and even some of the White House staff by surprise, vetoed two large appropriations bills today. He said that they provided $1 billion more than his original requests and would therefore be inflationary.
COLOGNE, West Germany, Aug. 11 (AP) Americans won seven events five in men's competition and two in women's at a track and field meet before 20,000 spectators tonight.

The name of Judge Irving R. Kaufman, one of the breakfast speakers yesterday at the annual convention of the American Bar Association in St. Louis, was a headline if not a household word in April, 1951, when he imposed the first peacetime death sentences for espionage in ...

OLD LYME, Conn., Aug. 11 In the Congregational Church here at noon today, Miss Carol Andrews Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Waldo C.M. Johnston of Old Lyme and Cooperstown, N.Y., was married to Amos Galpin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Galpin of New Haven and Branford.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The Securities and Exchange Commission today petitioned the Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia for a rehearing of the case involving the right of shareholders in a company to have public policy questions put before stockholder meetings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 The United Transportation Union and the National Railway Labor Conference agreed today to resume negotiations Aug. 25 in their long dispute over the use of firemen in diesel locomotives.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 (AP) New guidelines on subpoenaing newsmen and their files are part of a Nixon Administration policy to "make the press a whipping boy," Senator Birch Bayh, Democrat of Indiana, said today.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 When you play with explosives, you are allowed only one slip, and Jim McAndrew, pitching for the New York Mets, made his tonight on his sixth pitch to Cincinnati's Tony Perez in the second inning of an 8-1 defeat.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Aug. 11 The British Army moved reinforcements into Ulster's second city toright and prepared to seal it off all day tomorrow, when militant Protestants are scheduled to demonstrate.
RYE, N. Y., Aug. 11 Louise Bruce of La Mesa, Calif., won the 36-hole net qualifying medal in the 22d annual United States Golf Association junior girls' championship today.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Aug. 11 A remotely controlled oceanfloor crawler has completed engineering tests off the coast here and will begin this fall exploring the geology of nearby undersea canyons.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 11 (UPI) Maurice Stokes, former professional basketball star who died in April after having been crippled since 1958 by a brain disease, left $91,431 of his $194,862 estate to St. Francis College in Loretto, Pa.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11 (AP) A rifle and pistol used in the fatal escape attempt by three convicts at San Rafael last week were originally purchased by Angela Davis, the Communist instructor, The San Francisco Examiner reported today.

When the 700-foot containership American Astronaut sails from Port Newark on Sept. 10 for San Francisco, Honolulu, Hong Kong, Kobe and Yokohama, it will be a new departure for United States Lines in more than one sense.

A five-foot-long cardboard tube filled with stones was hurled through the windshield of a northbound Penn Central train in the Bronx yesterday afternoon, cutting the 52-yearold engineer about the eyes.
"Hmmmmm, how about 'Bud's Duds?'" mused the press agent, thinking up catchy phrases for his client's new line of men's wear. "Or maybe, 'From Knicks to Knits.'"

FONTANA, Wis., Aug. 11 Roy D. Chapin Jr., the chairman of the American Motors Corporation, predicted tonight that the rising demand for small cars would enable the automobile industry to sell half a million more cars in 1971 and bring it out of its present slump.

CALDWELL, N.J., Aug. 11 Milton S. Coe, formerly second vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, died yesterday in Mountainside Hospital, Montclair. His age was 68 and his home was at 512 Bloomfield Avenue.
VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 8 Qualified Laotian and American sources assert that Government troops will mount no major offensive during this rainy season, contrary to the usual pattern of the war.
Subway foremen said yesterday that because of the design of new air-conditioned cars on the IND line, blind persons had fallen through unprotected gaps to the tracks on two occasions since last fall.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 11 Fourteen poor families that moved into former military barracks buildings at Mitchel Field will get Nassau County permits this week to legalize their action, at least in the eyes of the county's Democratic administration.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 11 Ben Hogan's comeback bid failed today. Because of a painful knee, the recurrence of an old ailment, Hogan was forced to withdraw from the Professional Golfers' Association championship that begins here Thursday.

U.S. Plywood-Champion Papers, Inc., announced yesterday that its board of directors had agreed in principle to acquire Roberts Consolidated Industries, Inc., through an exchange of stock worth about $13.5-million.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 11 Twenty-five prisoners who were awaiting trial escaped today from the Monroe County Penitentiary here by chipping through an 18-inch thick cell block wall with spoons, the police said.

CAIRO, Aug.11-The United Arab Republic's chief delegate to the United Nations, with instructions to stand firm on demands for Israeli withdrawal, flies to New York tomorrow to begin talks aimed at achieving a settlement of the Middle East conflict.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Aug. 11 The 38th New Jersey State Golf Association four-ball match-play championship opened today at the Essex County Country Club with a major upset.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 11 Walter Clinton Bennett, former chairman of the Phelps Dodge Refining Corporation, a subsidiary of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, died at his home here today. He was 87 years old.

TRENTON, Aug. 11 (AP) State Labor Commissioner Charles Serraino ordered an investigation today into charges by Federal antipoverty officials that squalid conditions still prevailed in migrant labor camps of South Jersey.
Football fans will be able to take a special train to New Haven for the Giant-Jet game Aug. 23, the Penn Central Railroad said yesterday.

The St. Regis Paper Company announced yesterday price increases, effective Oct. 1, in kraft paper, paperboard and packaging products. The price of corrugated containers will be raised by 8 per cent, and the price of unbleached kraft linerboard used in the manufacture of corrugated containers will be raised $5.00 a ton to $125 a ton.

BOSTON, Aug. 11 A pair from New York and a pair from Buffalo shared the lead going into the final session of the Life Master pair championship here tonight at the American Contract Bridge League's summer nationals.

Mrs. Eleanor Homes Norton, the city's Commissioner of Human Rights, issued a statement yesterday calling reports that one woman "was subjected to unusual harassment" by the management and patrons of McSorley's Old Ale House "very disturbing."
LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 11 (AP) Citation, the last horse to win racing's Triple Crownthe Kentucky Derby, Preakness and Belmont Stakes died Saturday at Calumet Farm at the age of 25.

QUIDNET, Mass., Aug. 11 Miss Andrea Mantell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murray Mantell of Miami, was married this afternoon to John Frederick Seidel, son of Dr. and Mrs. Reginald F. Seidel of Englewood, N.J. Charles Clark Coffin, Clerk of the Town of Nantucket, performed the ceremony at the Seidels summer home here.
The bond market bulldozed its way into a huge volume of new financing yesterday, and it succeeded in moving an impressively large amount of it.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 A former Federal civil rights official today blamed actions of public officials for de facto school segregation in the North, and urged the Federal Government to press for integration with equal vigor everywhere.

Assemblyman Samuel D. Wright, in his well-timed warning to obstructionists in Ocean Hill-Brownsville, left no doubt that the local community school board intends to open all the schools in the embattled Brooklyn district on schedule. As the duly elected chairman of the local board, he speaks with the full authority of a community representative and an official in the decentralized system.

Wall Street had its paperwork explosion in 1967-68 and we all know what that led to back-office snafus, shortened trading hours and many administrative foul-ups that continued until the current market decline.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 11 (Reuters) The Cambodian Government today maintained silence on the seizure of its embassy in Prague by proSihanouk elements.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 11 Israeli military analysts said today they had detected no material change in the pattern of routine attacks from Palestinian guerrillas since the ceasefire between Israel and the United Arab Republic began Friday night.
Once again Sharps Pixley Co., the British bullion dealer, was the one and only successful bidder at the United States Government's weekly silver auction yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11? The latest dance has emerged not from rock-oriented youth but from their elders: It is the walking-on-eggs toe dance around that touchy question that some have dubbed the "population bomb."

The appearance of Senators opposed to President Nixon's Indochina war policies was fixed yesterday for 9 P.M. on Monday, Aug. 24, under the offer of National Educational Television to grant the doves free time on noncommercial television. The Senators are paying the production cost of the program, which will be carried locally by Channel 13.

Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday that a "corrections crisis" here demanded that the state provide facilities for sentenced prisoners and that the courts clear up the backlog of prisoners awaiting trial.

President Nixon has vetoed two big Federal appropriation bills for education, housing and other domestic functions on the ground that they exceeded his budget request by nearly a billion dollars. Mr. Nixon maintained that if he were to sign the bills, he would be saying "yes" to a higher cost of living, higher interest rates and higher taxes.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 Senator Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, took steps today to make sure that the equal rights amendment would not be buried in the Senate Judiciary Committee.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11 (AP) Two Senators, fearing a rash of pleas for Federal funds to bail out cash-stricken Government contractors, sought today to draw legal boundaries around the Lockheed Corporation's plea for $200-million in interim financing to complete the C-5 supertransport program.
PLAINFIELD, N. J., Aug. 11 (AP) A pre-dawn drug raid, conducted by the state and local police in three counties, resulted today in the arrest of 46 persons.

LONDON, Aug. 11 Few things can be harder to achieve in contemporary drama than the sex comedy. Today we all know what comedy is; but, in our increasingly permissive society, we are naturally a little doubtful about things that may be too near the truth to be funny.

The guidelines laid down by Attorney General Mitchell to limit Federal subpoenas for newsmen as witnesses in criminal cases reflect a welcome, if belated, recognition of the dangers inherent in any governmental intrusion on the news-gathering process.
MINEOLA, L. I., Aug. 11 The Nassau Commission on Human Rights has filed its first criminal charges against a person accused of housing discrimination in the seven-year history of the commission.

YONKERS, Aug. 11 The owners of only eight of the 39 colts eligible for the 16th annual Yonkers Futurity Trot, to be contested at Yonkers Raceway Friday night, saw fit this morning to make the $2,000 starting payments on behalf of their respective charges.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 11 Ambassador Jarring was understood today to have urged Israel, the United Arab Republic and Jordan to provide speedy replies to his inquiries about arrangements for the start of Arab-Israeli talks on a peace settlement.
Ralph Houk's uptown co-op, otherwise known as the New York Yankees, accepted contributions from all sides yesterday to defeat the Chicago White Sox, 7-1, at Yankee Stadium.

NEW MILFORD, Conn., Aug. 11 Harold P. Herman, former presiding supervisor of the Town of Hempstead, L.I., died on Sunday at his summer home here, apparently of a heart attack. He was 68 years old and lived also at 34 Hamilton Place, Garden City, L.I.

LONDON, Aug. 11 The great American Disaster has struck London. Berkeley coeds, Boston hippies and even the British stand on Fulham Road to push into the tiny, wood-paneled restaurant that offers. Great American Milkshakes, Great American Apple Pie and, of course, the Great American Hamburger.

DENVILLE, N. J., Aug. 11 One of the first and once one of the biggest of the space age companies, Reaction Motors, will be nothing by tomorrow night except a string of empty plants and a few abandoned concrete test stands where giant rocket engines used to flare and roar, shaking foundations for miles around at all hours of the day and night.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 11 (AP) Cornelius C. Moore, lawyer, banker, philanthropist and longtime power in Democratic circles, died today at his home here. He was 85 years old.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Aug. 11 Arthur J. Goldberg, the sophisticated urban lawyer, hiked four miles into the Adirondack Mountains near here this evening "to find out if there's anything left to the wilderness in New York State."

Miss Julia Kahn, daughter of Mrs. George E. Sands of New York and the late Elliott M. Kahn, was married here yesterday afternoon to Martin Shubik, a professor of economics of organization at Yale Univer sity. The Rev. Dr. Ronald Sobel of Temple Emanu-El performed the ceremony at the Plaza.
The world has begun to enter the United States has already been thrust into "the transition state between two ages."

KARAMEH, Jordan, Aug. 10 Even in the scaring sun, with dust on his shirt and his skin after a long morning in the fields of the Jordan Valley, the farmhand named Khalil had strength to vent his wrath.

Representative Richard L. Ottinger, the Democratic candidate for United States Senator, has leased a landmark as his campaign headquarters, the Villard Houses at Madison Avenue between 50th and 51st Streets.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 11 The soldiers have been dominating world events for the last few years, but the diplomats are stirring again. They are always in the awkward position of having to anticipate the future, to foresee the coming age, but they are beginning to think they can at least talk about the world beyond the present wars.
OSAGE BEACH, Mo., Aug. 11 Governor Rockefeller said today that he would not invite President Nixon or Vice President Agnew to New York State to help him in his re-election campaign this fall.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 11?Bruce Hoblitzell Sr., Mayor of Louisville from 1957 to 1961, died today at the age of 83.

The National Radio Company, a producer of communications equipment based in Melrose, Mass., announced yesterday that it had filed a petition under Chapter XI of the Bankruptcy. Act in Federal Court in Boston. The company gets about half its business from the Government.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 11 Former Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey made a strong plea today for liberals to identify themselves with the "law and order issue" by making it clear that they were opposed to violence and disruption by the right or the left.
"I should have stayed home." This comment by a broker summarized the performance of the American Stock Exchange yesterday as prices continued to ease in slightly stepped-up trading.
Michael J. Lacopo, an assistant vice president of the American Electric Power System, died yesterday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 61 years old and lived in Amherst, Mass.

OMAHA, Aug. 11 A district court judge, ruling in a case involving a contractor who is accused of shooting at an offduty policeman, held today that Nebraska's new self-defense act was unconstitutional.

Officials of Walston Co. and Hayden, Stone, Inc., issued a statement yesterday that said steps leading toward the previously announced consolidation of the two firms Sept. 4 were "proceeding according to plan." There had been rumors that the negotiations had encountered difficulties.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Aug. 11 A leading health physicist who is a pioneer in radiation protection research told an international gathering of atomic energy experts today that he opposed the installation of nuclear power plants in or near large urban areas.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 11 A sparkling debut by Fairs Fair, a full sister to the redoubtable Arts and Letters, thrilled her owner, Paul Mellon, and other race-goers in the crowd of 15,602 at Saratoga today. Overcoming an awkward start is a six-furlong sprint that attracted a dozen maiden 2year-old fillies, Fairs Fair came out of the pack in the stretch to score by six lengths over the runner-up, Love Locked Out.

Miss Linda Carol Rees, secretary to Michael Butler, the producer of "Hair," and David Frederick Wallace, one of the publicity men for the rock musical, plan to marry on Oct. 10. The wedding will take place in St. Mary's Chapel at the Episcopal Cathedral of SS. Peter and Paul in Washington.

JERSEY CITY, Aug. 11 The police ordered an extra detail to patrol tonight the scene of a rock-throwing and bottlethrowing rampage, although the area, except for minor incidents, remained calm last night.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa The organizers said it was South Africa's first black debutante ball, and it was billed, of course, as "the ball of the year."

Leading environmentalists and medical authorities joined forces yesterday to oppose the expansion of Consolidated Edi son's power plant in Astoria, Queens, on the ground that it would add intolerable levels of air pollution.

At a time when one quarterback (Joe Kapp) won't play unless he receives more pay, when another (Joe Namath) doesn't know if he wants to play and a third (Rick Norton) is dropped because he can't play well enough, Terry Bradshaw comes through on a positive note.

J. Schotte, president of the Eatontown (N. J.) National Bank, was arrested today and charged with "misapplication" of $5-million through the issuance of cashier's checks to stock brokerage firms in New Jersey and New York.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 11 The prosecution rested its case this afternoon against Lonnie McLucas, a Black Panther party member who has been on trial here in connection with the killing last year of Alex Rackley.
BONN, Aug. 11 The bomb threat that delayed the takeoff of Chancellor Brandt's plane was telephoned at 1.05 P.M. to the air traffic safety center at Bonn airport.
SYOSSET, L.I., Aug. 11 Minturn deSuzzara Verdi, a retired lawyer, died yesterday in Huntington Hospital of a heart attack. He would have been 83 years old tomorrow.

Two American economists predicted yesterday that Japan's inflation would intensify during this decade and force the nation to reduce her economic growth rate to below the level projected in the new six-year plan.

Greece's military regime announces that it will release 500 political prisoners, held since the 1967 coup. It will also restore passports to 500 political leaders, forbidden until now to leave the country. These moves are commendable, even if there was never a valid reason to detain or restrict many of these individuals in the first place.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 12-- Iraq denounced the United Arab Republic in unusually harsh terms today and Syria reaffirmed her doctrine that guerrilla warfare was the only way "to put an end to the Zionist and imperialist aggression against the Arabs."

Two infantry clerks hit the deck at 6 o'clock yesterday morning at Fort Dix, N.J., put on their suntan uniforms and, like thousands of other reservists across the country, spent a long day as civilian soldiers on two weeks of summer training.

Senator Charles E. Goodell and Representative Richard L. Ottinger campaigned here in the warm sunshine yesterday, touching on the issues of crime, subways, misuse of public funds and the high cost of living.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 12 (AP)--President Eduardo Frei today signed into law a bill to nationalize $1.6-million worth of stock that the Boise Cascade Corporation of the United States holds in the largest privately owned electric power company in Chile.

The Securities and Exchange Commission has entered the case involving the Eatontown National Bank to determine what impact, if any, the New Jersey bank's failure may have had on Wal Street. The bank's president has been charged with misapplying $5-million in funds.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- The United States is assessing Israeli intelligence reports that Soviet low-altitude missiles were installed on the Egyptianheld side of the Suez Canal four hours after the Middle East cease-fire began last Friday night.

More than 110 cases of viral meningitis, a nonfatal disease of the nervous system, have been reported this year by public and private health officials. The city Department of Health said that the total probably represented the largest number of cases reported at one time since the department first began keeping figures on the disease in 1959.
PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 12-- A survey of world leaders finds the overwhelming majority holding the opinion that life is "improving" for most people in the world, the Gallup Poll reported today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 12--President Nguyen Van Thieu said today that only South Vietnam and Thailand could send troops to help Cambodia and that the time to do so was now.

Unilever, N.V., and Unilever, Ltd., the twin companies that control about 500 companies including the United States giant, the Lever Brothers Company, registered record sales and earnings on a combined basis for the second quarter quarter and first half of this year, according to the company's midyear report issued yesterday.
Four Yale undergraduate women staged a sit-in in a "male-only" section of the Yale Club lobby yesterday, as 10 policemen and six bellhops looked on in mild amusement at the outnumbered band.

FORT MCPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 12 (AP)--A military judge rejected today constitutional challenges to a military trial for Sgt. Esequiel Torres, one of 12 soldiers charged with slaying South Vietnamese civilians at Songmy in 1968.

GENEVA, Aug. 12--The two sides fighting for control of Investors Overseas Services said today they would like to see a halt to the war that could destroy the already badly battered mutual fund empire.

LONDONDERRY, Northern Ireland, Aug. 12--Protestant and Roman Catholic extremists fought with British soldiers in scattered clashes, but the army succeeded in staving off a repetition of the wild riots that exploded here a year ago today.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 12-- The District Attorney's office here is investigating a business office in the Town of Greenburgh that, according to District Attorney Carl A. Vergari, operated as a "clearing house for sex and filth."
The signing of the treaty between the Soviet Union and the Federal Republic of Germany is an important moment in our postwar history.
LONG LAKE, N.Y., Aug. 12 --Arthur J. Goldberg learned about the Adirondack Forest Preserves the hard way today.

The police raided what they described as an after-hours club at 247 West 46th Street, near Eighth Avenue, early yesterday. They arrested 66 persons and confiscated quantities of drugs, liquor, and gambling materials.
Governor Rockefeller and Mayor Lindsay called upon each other yesterday to solve the crisis in the city's jails.
The latest Government soybean-production estimates excited some vigorous speculative buying yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Prices zoomed about 7 cents a bushel, an unusually share rise.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 12 --The Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan began serving today a threeyear prison sentence that he had avoided for four months.
PLAINVIEW, L.I.--"I wouldn't want my wife to work if it meant our kids would be wandering around the streets until she got home."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12--In an effort to dramatize his repeated pledges to cooperate with the South on school desegregation this fall, President Nixon will fly to New Orleans on Friday for an unusual private meeting with members of seven state advisory committees on public education.

Walter K. Levy has been promoted to vice president, operations and selling services of Bonwit Teller, a subsidiary of Genesco, Inc., it was announced yesterday by William M. Fine, president of Bonwit Teller.

BONN, Aug. 12--The other day Gerhard Schroder, the conservative who served in every West Germany Government from 1953 to 1969, described the style of Chancellor Willy Brandt's Administration as "too loud and too ostentatious."

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 12 --Mrs. A. Sherburne Hart of Essex County continued to set the pace in the 45th New Jersey women's amateur championship today by defeating Mrs. Henry Doubilet of Hollywood, 5 and 3, at the Plainfield Country Club.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 12--Jack Nicklaus clicked off a 64 today in his final tune-up for tomorrow's start of the Professional Golfers' Association championship. His six-under-par burst over the Southern Hills Country Club course firmly established him as the favorite in the tourney he last won in 1963.

John J. De Lury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, charged yesterday that more than 200 new sanitation trucks scheduled for immediate service here were sitting idle in Jersey City because they had been improperly assembled.

DETROIT, Aug. 12--The bank-empire dreams of Donald H. Parsons, Detroit lawyer-financier, were shattered today when he tendered his resignation as chairman of the Bank of the Commonwealth here and indicated that he might sell his stock interests.

From out of the Tombs has come an urgent plea for decency and change of the corrections and court system that equals in straightforward eloquence what many studies by attorneys and judicial organizations have been saying about criminal cases for years.
HAMBURG, Germany, Aug. 12 (UPI)--Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia and Ilie Nastase of Rumania scored easy victories today in the West German tennis championships.

DETROIT Aug. 12 (AP)-- Joe Louis, former world heavyweight champion, remained in Denver, afflicted with an emotional disorder, but his spirit was in Detroit tonight, where about 8,000 persons came to pay tribute to one of their city's most revered heros.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- --Three members of Congress from areas that produce natural gas announced plans today to introduce legislation that would stop the Federal Government from regulating the prices that owners of gas wells can charge.

ATLANTA, Aug. 12 (AP)-- The Coca-Cola Company announced today that it had established new job classifications and granted wage increases averaging 23 per cent to about 300 workers employed in the company's citrus groves in Florida.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug 12 --The Willow Bank Y.C. crew from Cazenovia, N.Y., captained by David Penfield and representing the Central New York Yacht Racing Association, won the Area B semifinal series of the North American junior sailing championship by one-half point off Riverside Y.C. today.

BOSTON, Aug. 12--Two New York experts, Michael Moss and Paul Heitner, captured the Life Master Pair Championship here last night and became strong candidates to represent the United States in the next world pair championship. Moss is a past winner of the mixed team championship, but the victory in the summer national tournament being played at the Boston Sheraton was his first major pair title. It was the first national event Heitner has won.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 12--Angel Cordero, the Puerto Rican riding star, took care of both ends of the Bernard Baruch Handicap today in record-breaking time. The 1 1-16-mile stakes on the turf had drawn so many entries that it was conducted in two divisions.
AMHERST, N.Y., Aug. 12-- Governor Rockefeller urged today the development of community leadership and "total community involvement" in the fight against narcotics addiction.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Military and industrial leaders got together here today to honor Representative L. Mendel Rivers, the South Carolina Democrat who is chairman of the House Armed Services Committee and one of the defense establishment's foremost advocates.

DENVER, Aug. 12 (Reuters)-- George W. Mitchell, a member of the Federal Reserve Board, said today that present monetary policy issues were weighted toward the timing of economic stimulus and not the maintainance of anti-inflationary restraint.
Oscar de la Renta strolled into Bonwit Teller yesterday morning as the showing of his first blouse collection was under way and looked aghast.

HARTFORD, Aug. 12--Connecticut's two Republican members of the House of Representatives won their party's nomination for Governor and United States Senator by wide margins today in the first statewide primary election in history here.

A major battle is developing between the Government and the savings-and-loan industry over the right of millions of depositors in mutual, saverowned institutions to have a greater voice in the management of their associations.

HARVEY'S LAKE, Pa--It is a restaurant with a sophisticated, impressively professional kitchen. Guests dine there on snails bourguignonne, on fillet of beef bearnaise and on breast of chicken cooked a blanc with a sauce made of pate de foie and cream.
CAIRO, Aug. 12--A suspension of all but military censorship was promised today for foreign newsmen in the United Arab Republic by Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, the Minister of National Guidance.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 12--The name on the scoreboard was familiar. So was the shot, stocky figure bouncing round the court, running down every ball within reach, scrambling for each point as if it were the last. So were the scores: 6-4, 6-2, McKinley.

The New York State Public Employment Relations Board suspended yesterday the dues deduction privilege of four locals of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employes because of a strike in November, 1968, at four state mental hospitals.

DETROIT, Aug. 12--New-car sales in early August fell 4 per cent from a year ago with dealers reporting sales of 148,577 American-type cars against 155,439 a year ago. The industry's early August sales rate was the lowest for the period since 1963.

Bernard Zuckerman, the international master and former champion of the Manhattan Chess Club, captured first place in the recent Manhattan masters invitation tournament without the loss of a game. In this fiveround Swiss event, which attracted 16 of the strongest players in the metropolifour games and drew one, scoring, 4 - .
Miss Linda Westall Paine and David Lawrence Langston, graduate students at Columbia University, will be married next month.
The annual Pereseids meteor shower reached its peak over New York just before midnight last night, but the shooting stars were obsecured by smog.
DEDHAM, Mass., Aug. 12-- Charles B. Crockett, who retired as chairman of the board of Harper-Atlantic Sales, Inc., in 1965, died yesterday in Boston. He was 70 years old and lived here.

SUNNY POINT MILITARY TERMINAL, N.C., Aug. 12-- Col. John Osick said today that if the courts enjoined the Army from dumping its shipment of deadly nerve gas in the ocean the court would have to tell the Army how to dispose of the cargo.
The experimental pedestrian malls on Lexington Avenue and Eighth Street will continue this Saturday, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.
HOMER, La., Aug. 8--Calvin Willis turned off the alarm clock and lay back in bed. It was 5 A.M., an hour and a half before daylight.

TORONTO, Aug. 12 (UPI)-- Pancho Gonzales, fatigued by his overnight flight from Los Angeles relied on his powerful service today to turn back a determined John Sharpe from Toronto, 11-9, 6-4, in first round play at the $23,200 Rothmans Canadian open championships.
A State Senator and a court officers' association joined here yesterday in urging greater courtroom security to prevent a repetition of the slaying last Friday of a San Rafael, Calif., judge.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 12-- King Hussein of Jordan said today that despite the opposition of the Palestinian commandos, a majority of his subjects would support "a just and durable peace" as defined by the United Nations Security Council resolution on the Middle East of Nov. 22, 1967.

"The best hope for the development of a new audience for opera among young people is to develop a species of anti-opera," said Peter Herman Adler, who has been preoccupied with the art in a major part of his 70 years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP)--A striking decline in birth rates during the late nineteen-sixties will mean 100 million fewer Americans in the year 2000 than previously projected, the Census Bureau said today.
"Let's not kid ourselves," said the president of the prison guard's union yesterday. "We're not correcting, anybody in there."

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 12--Chief of Police Ralph C. Petrone today asked the State Attorney General to investigate "political interference" from City Hall that he said was causing "a very serious breakdown in the morale of the city's policemen" and creating "situations" that threaten the city's safety.
CAIRO, Aug. 12--The United Arab Republic is ready for a peaceful settlement with Israel but not a formal peace treaty, Cairo's leading policy spokesman, Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, declared today.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 12 (AP)--Taking command at the half-mile pole under Mike Hole, Brookfield Farm's Imasuper charged to a five-length triumph in today's Decathlon Purse at six furlongs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Total inventories held by manufacturing and trading companies rose by $350-million in June, although manufacturers reduced their stocks during the month for the first time since September, 1967.
A 15-year-old girl was seriously wounded last night by shotgun pellets fired from a passing automobile while she was sitting on a stoop in Brooklyn.
PARIS, Aug. 12--Maurice Frere, Belgian banker and economist, died yesterday in Turkey, according to word received in Brussels tonight. He was 80 years old.
The New York and American Stock Exchanges have issued their reports on changes in stockholdings by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed corporations. The lists include the following:

LAS VEGAS, Aug. 12--Price competition in the oil industry is practically non-existent because of the concentration of most of the market in the hands of few large companies, an official of the Federal Trade Commission said today.

It takes a bit of doing to turn Philharmonic Hall into a chamber, as that word is understood by music listeners, but it can be done. The Boston Symphony Chamber Players--five firstdesk men from the orchestra, in this instance--found the problem surmountable on Tuesday night, when they appeared in Lincoln Center's "A Mostly Mozart Festival."

Ida Oppenheimer, a retired social worker who helped organize the Lower East Side Community Council in the 1920's and later headed the Jewish Vacation Association of the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies, died yesterday in her home at 235 West 22d Street. She was 74 years old.

HALKIRK, Scotland, Aug. 12--Heavy clouds sometimes obscured the sun, but the air was clear as we moved in a long line up the hill over heather, sedge and sphagnum moss and far below us the Thurso River gleamed in its green valley.
It was more of the same yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as prices continued to slump and volume dropped to its lowest level in almost four years.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 12 (UPI)--The defense rested its case today without bringing John Norman Collins to the stand to testify at his murder trial in the slaying of an 18year-old coed.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 12--Both Jordan and the United Arab Republic have informed Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring that they would prefer starting substantive political discussions on a Middle Eastern settlement in New York at the ambassadorial level, diplomatic sources reported today.
The theory that the addition of jazz horns can extend the scope of a rock group was placed in somewhat blurred perspective Tuesday night at the Village Gate by a new group called Dreams.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that Melvyn S. Klein had been appointed vice president for marketing and planning in the exchange's Stock Clearing Corporation. The position is new.

SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 12 (UPI)--Cesar Chavez, leader of a union of farm workers, signed an accord today with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, ending a jurisdictional dispute over which union would represent the nation's agricultural workers.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 12--Jerry Lepre and Tom Berberian of Forest Hill, two-time winners of the New Jersey State Golf Association's fourball match play championship, led the way into the semifinals of this year's event at the Essex County Country Club.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) --The House passed and sent to President Nixon today a bill authorizing an increase in the interest rate on Series E savings bonds to 5 per cent from 5 per cent.
LAS VEGAS, N.M., Aug. 12 --Murder charges were filed here today against four men accused of slaying a 25-yearold New Yorker described by authorities as a resident of a hippie commune.

The Kings Lafayette Bank, a $200-million Brooklyn-based institution, and the Republic National Bank of New York, with assets of $177-million, are holding "very preliminary" merger discussions, they disclosed yesterday.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 12 (AP)--David Ross 3d, a captain in the Army Reserves from Woodbury, L.I., smashed the national match record today to win the national small-bore rifle prone championship with a four-day score of 6,396 points of a possible 6,400.

Showing dogs is a family project with the Richard Howes. The very name of the kennel at Westfield, N.J. --Clariho--is an acronym formed by the first letters of the names of the four children--Charles, Laurie, Ricky and Holly.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (UPI) --President Nixon signed legislation today raising payments to disabled veterans by about 11 per cent, even though it exceeded his request by $218million. He said he would offset the excess by making reductions in four other Federal programs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- After eight months of buttonselling and fund-raising concerts, including a performance on the White House lawn, the District of Columbia Youth Orchestra will be flying across the Atlantic tomorrow to St. Moritz, Switzerland.

Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the 39-year-old lawyer who has represented Connecticut's Fourth Congressional District since 1968 and yesterday became the Republican candidate for the United States Senate, began his political career in the Connecticut General Assembly.
CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 12-- The industrial complex at Durgapur in West Bengal was paralyzed today by a strike by 50,000 workers belonging to unions led by Communists.
Courtland Smith, a former motion-picture executive, died Sunday at the ranch of his daughter, Mrs. John Barnes Mull, in Santa Fe, N.M. His age was 86.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug 12-- John Mandia, a former dancer with the New York City Ballet, died of a heart attack here yesterday. He was 45 years old and lived at 176 East 95th Street in New York.
SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 12 (AP)--The Rev. Paul J. Harney, chancellor of the University of San Francisco, died yesterday at the Montecito Jesuit retreat here. He was 60 years old.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 12--Gary Gentry, giving the New York Mets exactly the kind of strong pitching they had been hoping for, defeated the powerful Cincinnati Reds, 2-1, tonight, holding them to four hits.

A $39-million loan by the New York City Employes Retirement Fund to the builder of the new Department of Transportation headquarters in Washington has been held up indefinitely because the official who authorized it is now under indictment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- The Senate handed the Nixon Administration a major legislative victory today by defeating a proposal to prevent the expansion of the Safeguard missile defense system.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 12-- Military censorship has been in effect in Israel since the formation of the state in 1948. It is said to concern "only military information affecting the security of the state." Israeli as well as foreign correspondents fall under the regulations.

Brand, Grumet Seigel, Inc., a brokerage house that has been losing money in recent months, is negotiating a consolidation with Thomson McKinnon, Auchincloss, Inc., a concern that has been acquiring other houses aggressively during the bear market.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 12-- The second member of the Jersey City Black Panther party awaiting a possible retrial on charges of machinegunning a police station here has been freed in bail.
ATHENS, Thursday, Aug. 13 (Reuters)--The Greek Government today released seven Arabs sentenced to various prison terms for terrorist activities in Greece.

Leaders of two transit groups involved in defending workers against charges of negligence contend that many of the charges are brought by the Transit Authority to mask equipment failures caused by maintenance neglect.

Miles W. Kirkpatrick, nominated by President Nixon as new chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, displays commendable civic spirit in his willingness to leave the critics in the grandstand and show what he can do on the playing field.
Scripps-Howard Newspapers said yesterday that it had completed the purchase of the San Juan (P.R.), Star from Cowles Communications for $9,750,000 in cash.
The bond market, after moving rather confidently toward lower interest rates Tuesday, found the going a little tougher yesterday.

The Legal Aid Society has prepared a suit charging that conditions in the Manhattan House of Detention are so shocking that they violate the constitutional bar against cruel and unusual punishment, Legal Aid lawyers and other sources said yesterday.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 12--Billy Schneider of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club, sailing Captain America, and Chip Cusick of Norwalk Shore and Country Club, at the tiller of Psych, won Lightning Class races on Long Island Sound off the Belle Haven Club today as the Junior Yacht Racing Association's annual race week began.

SEATTLE, Aug. 12 (UPI)-- Western Airlines officials disclosed today that they paid $25,000 in cash to a man who had told them that he had put a bomb on an airliner and had set it to go off when the plane descended to 10,000 feet.
For the first time since The Trouble, Joe Namath spoke yesterday to his coach, Weeb Ewbank.

Consolidated Edison Company repairmen were repairing a transformer in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn early this morning after a fire caused scattered power interruptions. Power failures were reported in a nine-square-block area.
BOSTON, Aug. 12--By a process of elimination, 19 players remain who have swept through the first three games victoriously in the 71st annual United States Open Championship at the Parker House here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- A strong circumstantial case that hepatitis, the sometimes fatal liver disease, is one of the hidden costs of environmental pollution and could become more widespread was presented today to the Third International Congress on Food Science and Technology.

The following, therefore, is directed to all worried mothers, wherever you may be:

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 12--Norman I. Stone of Great Neck and Mrs. Harvey Poliakoff of Rockville Centre have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Ellen Stone, to Douglas Hugh Yoblon. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin M. Yoblon of Searington.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 12 (AP)--The chairman of the largest steel maker in the United States predicted today that world steel production would reach one billion net tons by 1980.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12-- Submerging its skepticism about the Soviet Union's intentions, the United States today extended its official blessing to the Soviet-West German treaty.

Representative Thomas J. Meskill, who won yesterday's primary election to become the Republican candidate for Governor of Connecticut, has represented the state's Sixth Congressional District since 1966, when he emerged from the off-year elections to become the party's major officeholder in the state.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 12--In its monthly statistical survey, the Executive Commission of the European Common Market said today that wages in the six member countries are rising at an unprecedented rate. This, together with a continuing expansion of demand, causes the price climate to remain unfavorable.
Stock prices moved generally lower in London yesterday in a continuation of the recent dull trading trend.
BURLINGTON, Wis., Aug. 12--American Motors emphasized small, sporty cars at the unveiling of its 1971 models today. They will be in dealers' showrooms on Oct. 6.

William H. Moore, executive vice president-operations of the Southern Railway System, has been picked as president and chief executive officer of the Penn Central Trans portation Company. SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 12--Miss Louise Basch and Christopher George Purslow, who met in the summer of 1965 on a dig at Fishbourne, near Chichester, England, were married here today.

Alfred J. Mayer, an investment banker and a security analyst, died Tuesday of a heart attack at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 1215 Fifth Avenue. His summer home was at Montauk Point, L.I.

SAINT-JEAN-DE-LUZ, France, Aug. 12 (UPI)--Mrs. Marie-Antoinette Chaban-Delmas, wife of Premier, Jacques ChabanDelmas, was killed today in an automobile accident near this resort town in southwestern France.

CARLISLE, Pa., Aug. 12-- Speaking of Vince Lombardi, Bill Austin said today, "At least I know I can yell as loud as he can." Austin is in the unenviable position of being Lombardi's successor as head coach of the Washington Redskins.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12 (AP) --Dean L. Schedler, a World War II reporter for The Associated Press, died here today after a long illness. He was 55 years old.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 12--Premier Golda Meir, facing Opposition demands that Israel withdraw from diplomatic efforts toward a peace settlement, insisted today that Israeli negotiators would concede nothing in advance but that they would not state preconditions for peace talks with the Arab states.

One-way toll collections went into effect yesterday on 12 Hudson River and New YorkNew Jersey bridges and tunnels, causing moments of anger and confusion among car and truck drivers that led to delays of up to an hour during the morning rush.

ATLANTA, Aug. 13 (AP) Promoters said today that the way was virtually clear for a Joe Frazier-Cassius Clay heavyweight title fight in Atlanta, but Frazier's manager immediately branded the statement as nonsense.

An 18-year-old foster child from Queens who won a tuition scholarship to the State University of New York at Buffalo has been awarded $2,500 a year from a private organization so that she can live in an oncampus dormitory instead of boardine in a new foster home.

Unionized lifeguards at the Palisades Interstate Park and Taconic Park Commission's lakes and pools announced last night they would go on strike at 8 A.M. Saturday in a bid to gain wage parity with Long Island State Park Commission lifeguards.

The United States Lines, which has drawn more than a half-billion dollars in Federal operating subsidies in the last three decades, is about to go off Uncle Sam's welfare rolls.
