WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 The Federal Communications Commission said today that President Nixon had made such extensive use of television to defend his conduct of the war in Indochina that the networks must now give opponents a chance to present critical replies on prime time.
The new-issue market where the shares of companies that had never had public owners are offered and traded drifted lower in quiet trading this week.

"The essence of the New Federalism," President Nixon explained to the nation's Governors gathered at their annual convention last year, "is to help regain control of our national destiny by returning a greater share of control to state and local governments and to the people."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 14 Although many of the 1.5 million Palestinians outside Israeli control stand to gain from a settlement in the Middle East, not one prominent Palestinian has spoken out publicly in favor of an agreement.

FALLS CHURCH, Va., Aug. 14 Lieut Col. Richard J. Flynn Jr., U.S.M.C., retired, and Mrs. Flynn has announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane Flynn to Peter P. Jones. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. J. Carleton Jones of Baltimore.

BOSTON, Aug. 14 Lubomil Kavalek, a grandmaster of Washington and a former chess champion of Czechoslovakia, and John Grefe of Oakland, Calif., won their games in the fifth round of the 71st annual United States Open Championship last night to become the only competitors with five straight victories.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 California, leading a surge of population growth in the Pacific states, was officially listed for the first time today as the nation's most populous state, displacing New York by about 250,000 persons.
MOSCOW, Aug. 14 Vano Ilych Muradeli, a Soviet composer and music official who during the Stalin era was sharply attacked for "formalistic" writing, died today, in Moscow. His age was 62.

EATONTOWN, N. J., Aug. 14 The buildings and property of the insolvent Eatontown National Bank were sold here today for nearly $2-million to two other Monmouth County banks that will open tomorrow to Eatontown depositors.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 13 Sister Juanita Shealey, dressed in a long brown and yellow dashiki, took a sip of wine from a silver chalice, then passed the chalice to the nun standing directly behind her.
A small explosive device was found yesterday in the men's room in the basement of the American Museum of Natural History at 79th Street and Central Park West.

TOKYO Twenty-five years after Japan surrendered to the victorious allies, her leaders are engaged in an effort to strengthen an army, navy and air force with weapons, designed to protect only the islands of Japan herself, that do not include nuclear bombs.

TORONTO, Aug. 14 After conferring with Federal and provincial authorities, the Gulf Oil Corporation officially committed itself today to produce uranium at its Rabbit Lake property in North Sasketchewan.

OCEANPORT, N.J., Aug. 14 The races for the junior working hunter and junior jumper championships were tightened considerably at the Monmouth County Horse Show today so much, in fact, that the final class in each section will determine the titleholders.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 High United States officials, chary of concluding that the Egyptians violated the Middle East standstill cease-fire by moving missles toward the Suez Canal, see political motives behind Israel's publicizing of charges of such a violation.
The Transit Authority said yesterday that it was making a vigorous effort to repair broken air-conditioning equipment on the city's buses following complaints by many riders.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 14 A military tribunal today found two brothers guilty of spreading Communist propaganda through their Chinese-language newspaper in Manila and sentenced them to detention in a reformatory for political re-education.

A study to determine more precisely when heart attacks and strokes will occur in likely victims was announced yesterday by the New York University Medical Center and the John A. Hartford Foundation. The foundation has made a $149,640 grant to support the project.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 14 Anti-Government leaflets were scattered by small explosive devices in major South African cities last night.
Seventeen New York policemen-including one: captain, two sergeants and five detectives are facing departmental charges of moonlighting without permission for a private investigating concern.

City welfare officials estimated yesterday that 775,000 adults and children among the working poor would be eligible for the city's new food stamp program, in addition to most of the 1.1 million people who receive welfare aid.

It was a hectic day correspondence to clear up, frequent telephone interruptions, visitors stopping by as Cyril D. Tyson finished his last day yesterday as Commissioner of the city's Manpower and Career Development Agency.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 Senator Birch Bayh said today that President Nixon could make "all the difference in the world" in winning final Congressional approval for direct election of the President if he wanted to exert his influence.

BETHESDA, Md., Aug. 14 Col. George J. McNally, retired, chief of the White House communications system, died Tuesday after a heart attack at the National Naval Medical Center here. He was 64 years old.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 14 The buddy system has been helping children who are hard of hearing to live normal lives with children who do not have that handicap.
English Regency and early Victorian furniture are getting to be as important as the standard 18th-century models in the shops where high fashion antique furniture is featured.

The New York Yankees, who must be feeding Jake Gibbs catnip up there in the Bronx, defeated the Kansas City Royals, 3-2, last night when Gibbs hit the fourth pitch of the 10th inning into the right-field seats.

VIENNA, Aug. 14 The United States and the Soviet Union concluded the Vienna phase of the strategic arms limitation talks on a hopeful but inconclusive note today and agreed to resume negotiations in Helsinki on Nov. 2.

YONKERS, Aug. 14 A $12 rubber bit, which snapped in Marlu Pride's mouth, causing the 2-5 favorite to go off stride at the start of the Yonkers Futurity Trot, probably cost the colt's owner, August Portanova, the winner's share of $64,062 at the $106,770 classic tonight at Yonkers Raceway.

PARIS, Aug. 14 (AP) France, which first recognized Henry Miller's literary voice, has banned a movie, taken from one of his books, that Customs officials in New York have found acceptable for distribution.

TORONTO, Aug. 14 Whereas France under President Charles de Gaulle regarded a strong franc with pride and Prime Minister Harold Wilson sought to win re-election on the recovery of the British pound, Canada finds that its robust dollar is a headache.
A news item from Pittsburgh reported that a tight shoulder muscle had forced Dock Ellis to miss his scheduled pitching turn last night against the San Diego Padres.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 14 (UPI) The Democratic candidate for State Attorney General Adam Walinsky, called flag desecration laws "utter nonsense" today and said he would take a dim view of enforcing them if he is elected in November.

MAMARONECK, N. Y., Aug. 14 Christened with two bottles of dirty water from the Hudson River and Long Island Sound, the Miss Westchester, a 16 -foot Boston Whaler, was officially commissioned here this afternoon as Westchester County's floating pollution laboratory.
FORT BENNING, Ga., Aug. 14 (UPI) The court-martial of First Lieut. William L. Calley Jr., charged with murdering 102 Vietnamese civilians at Songmy in 1968, was postponed indefinitely today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 A space agency official has invented a stationary communications satellite whose broadcasts can be focused on a specific area of irregular shape.

Hundreds of young people accompanied by officials from the city and suburbs marched up the Avenue of the Americas to a Central Park rally yesterday to dramatize the problem of drug abuse. But after the rock music and speeches by politicians faded, black speakers rose to denounce the demonstration as a "racist sellout."

The stock market staged a modest advance yesterday to post its first gain in a downward week. Trading remained relatively slow at 7.85 million shares as advances outpaced declines by a narrow margin on the New York Stock Exchange.

SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, Aug. 15 President Chung Hee Park said today that South Korea would be willing to take "epochal and more realistic measures" toward the peaceful reunification of Korea if North Korea renounced the use of force.
LONDON, Aug. 14 Caches of bombs and explosives believed destined for Ulster have been uncovered by the London police in two days of raids in the southwestern part of the city.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 14 The Jordanian military command reported two Israeli air raids and a shelling attack across the Jordan River today. It said that a soldier had been killed and seven soldiers and a civilian wounded.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 A Federal district judge let the Government go ahead today with its plan to sink 418 concrete containers holding lethal nerve gas rockets in the Atlantic Ocean 240 miles off the coast of Florida.
PARIS, Aug. 14 France has applauded the new Soviet-West German treaty but not without a few worried thoughts about the political and economic future in Europe.

ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 14 Frank A. Tedesco, president of the Tedesco Bus Company in Bayonne, N.J., and his garage supervisor were formally charged with seven counts of involuntary manslaughter today before Justice of the Peace Richard J. LeVan of East Macungie, five miles southwest of here.

A group of tenants from the Bushwick section of Brooklyn ended a three-day sit-in at an office of the city's Housing and Development Administration yesterday after a meeting with Deputy Administrator Robert G. Hazen.
The Fortune Store, a nonprofit shop in Greenwich Village run by ex-convicts with merchandise made by ex-convicts, was burglarized yesterday.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 14 While the other America's Cup defense candidates remained out of the water, Heritage went to sea today to test a brand new sail plan.
SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 14 His name is Haroon Rahim, he is 20 years old, dark, trim, handsome, and the most exciting product to reach this country from Pakistan since the first shipment of jute.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 14 President Nixon flew here today to reassure the South that he was at once firm and reasonable in his approach to the next big round of school desegregation this fall.

BUTTE, Mont. Citizens of this century-old copper center are thinking of moving their town off what has been called "the richest hill on earth" to make way for a huge open pit mine that each year seems to chew its way closer to traditional business district.

Because city narcotics agency officials "were not fully aware" of the provisions of a contract they signed with the state, New York City stands to lose more than $1-million, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.

Miss Barbara Ann Sloin and Jonathan Robert Moore, graduate students at the University of Michigan, plan to be married in the fall.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended narrowly mixed yesterday in quiet trading.

LOS ANGELES, AUG. 14 (AP) Jim Henry of University of Indiana and Capt. Micki King of the Air Force and Long Beach, Calif., successfully defended their National Amateur Athletic Union diving titles tonight.
Al Atkinson, the middle-linebacker who retired 10 days ago with a verbal attack on Joe Namath's absence from training camp, will rejoin the New York Jets.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14 Personality successfully met a determined challenge from Loud in the Jim Dandy stakes today and won the $30,050 one-mile event by a head. The eighth running of the stakes for 3-year-olds drew a field of eight, but it really developed into a duel between Mrs. Ethel D. Jacobs's formidable campaigner and William Haggin Perry's runner-up. In third place, three lengths behind the winner, came George D. Widener's Plymouth.

FALMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 14 Miss Nancy Jane Bergmann, an elementary-school teacher in Garland, Tex., and Michael Vance Killough, a lawyer in Dallas, were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Richard S. Crowell performed the ceremony in St. Barnabas Episcopal Church.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 14 Hollis Stacy of Savannah, Ga., and Janet Aulisi of West Caldwell, N.J., will meet in the final round of the 22d annual United States Golf Association junior girls' golf championship tomorrow.

Hot and muggy weather pushed the power demand in New York City and Westchester County to near the summer's peak yesterday and forced Consolidated Edison and five other utilities in the eastern part of the state to reduce voltage 5 per cent and to appeal to large users to reduce their consumption of electricity.

City Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath yesterday inspected a deteriorated cell block at the Ossining Correctional Facility Sing Sing Prison and said he would move city prisoners there as soon as the state turned it over.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission has temporarily suspended Martin J. Joel Jr., doing business as Martin J. Joel Co., a New York brokerdealer, after finding violation of Federal securities law.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14 A police detective was critically wounded in a new outbreak of sniper fire that ranged over a six-block area in the Negro South Side for more than an hour last night and early this morning. WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission said today it asked for and received a Federal court injunction against a Dallas company and its Florida subsidiary after alleging that they touted their stock and issued a misleading press release.
MARSTRAND, Sweden, Aug. 14 (AP) William E. Buchan, a 36-year-old building contractor from Mercer Island, Wash., won the world Star Class yachting championship today.
TORONTO, Aug. 14 (Canadian Press) Top-seeded Rod Laver and second-seeded Andres Gimeno won their matches tonight and advanced to the semifinals in the $23,000 Canadian open tennis championships.

The House has voted to override President Nixon's veto of the $4.4-billion education bill but has upheld his veto of the $18-billion money bill for housing and other programs. Neither vote was surprising. In fact, Mr. Nixon's initial-decision had been to sign the education bill because it was so clear that he would be overridden; the conventional political wisdom is that a President should husband his prestige and not waste it on lost issues.

CHICAGO, Aug. 15 (AP)-- Two men identified by the police as members of a Negro street gang were charged today with conspiracy to murder a policeman who was critically wounded in an ambush Thursday night.

With Julius Rudel conducting and with solo contributions by Hans Richter-Haaser, the German pianist, and Theodore Weis, trumpeter of the New York Chamber Orchestra, the "Mostly Mozart Festival" concert at Philharmonic Hall on Friday night offered an agreeable mix of works by Mozart and Haydn.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- Tough new laws and regulations are being proposed and accepted in many states to combat a national increase in terror bombings.

WASHINGTON--In a survey of "world leaders," Dr. Gallup has found that an overwhelming majority of them believe that "life for most people in the world is improving." A lot of Americans, who hadn't known, should be relieved to hear this.

SQUARE carpet tiles that can be pasted down with a special adhesive, or with a double-faced adhesive tape, have been available for some time now --but one company has recently introduced a new innovation--carpet tiles that come in a Moorish-shaped outline, instead of in squares.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 15--An International gathering of scientists and businessmen concerned with atomic energy in effect told an increasingly hostile public this week that it would have to choose between air-conditioners, dishwashers, television sets and garbage disposals on the one hand and, on the other, greater responsibility for the effects-- notably environmental pollution--of increased power demands.

IRBID, Jordan, Aug. 15--The Israeli Air Force struck an already ruined and deserted Jordanian Army headquarters here yesterday in what appeared to be a warning attack.

RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 15 (AP)--Jim Paschal, impervious to the mud, drove his 1970 Javelin to a seven-lap victory in the second annual NASCAR Grand American Casey 200 today at the North Carolina State Fairgrounds track last night.

SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 11 --Mrs. Patricia Steward still glows over the red-carpet treatment that she and her husband, Lester, received when they arrived from Arizona a few weeks ago to teach in a rural Australian town.

TULSA, Okla., Aug. 15--The 1970 winner of the Professional Golfers Association championship to be decided here will have the shortest reign in the game's history. He will be a champion for only six months.
Charles W. Engelhard, the former bomber pilot whose world includes platinum, diplomacy and thoroughbred horses, syndicated his unbeaten 3-yearold colt, Nijinsky, yesterday for a record $5.44-million.
SYDNEY, Aug. 15--Garbage piled up in Sydney streets today aftter 1,600 municipal employes struck for more pay.

Gunnar Myrdal, the Swedish political economist, and his wife Alva, Sweden's highest disarmament official and an expert in population problems, have been chosen as recipients of West Germany's Peace Prize for 1970.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, Aug. 15--Systematic assassination of young political radicals by Dominican security forces has been going on for several weeks here as President Joaquin Balaguer prepares to begin a second fouryear term tomorrow.
SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 15-- The current move toward collective political action on the nation's college campuses "is an invitation to educational disaster," Dr. Sidney Hook warned tonight.

Two objectives are vital to reform of the nation's military high command. One is to improve the quality of the Pentagon's military advice to the Secretary of Defense and the President. The other, equally important, is to provide the Secretary with an independent capability for evaluating that advice.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 (AP)--The Federal Aviation Administration says it is trying to track down some 48,000 small aircraft.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 9-- An ambitious program for a unified Arab offensive against Israel has suffered a crippling setback as a result of President Gamal Abdel Nasser's acceptance last month of the United States peace initiative in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- When Marion Edey was a political science major at Reed College in Oregon, she wrote her senior thesis on the Federal Wildlife Service, concluding that it was exterminating coyotes and other predators because of pressure from sheep ranchers and, in the process, upsetting the ecology in the West.

The rowing championships of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen will have an international flavor next weekend on the Cooper River course at Collingswood, N.J. West Germany, New Zealand, Australia and Canada have entered crews.

BOSTON, Aug. 15--New England recently suffered its second Naval cutback in two months, with the Boston Naval Shipyard announcement of a layoff of 1,400 workers at the end of 1970.

PARIS, Aug. 15--Half the world's schoolchildren either do not get a seventh-grade education or repeat one to three grades along the way, according to a survey carried out by the Nnited Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 15-- The economic committee of the Democratic Policy Council said today that President Nixon's veto of education and housing spending bills "simply has no economic justification" as a needed measure against inflation.
UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., Aug. 15--Scientists have found it economically feasible to use the peels and cores of apples and potatoes and the skins and seeds of grapes and tomatoes as cattle feed.

A 180-pound St. Bernard, Polar Blue Samaritan von Barri, more familiarly known as Grizzly Bear, from Denali, Alaska, is the dog hero of the year. On Wednesday, his owners, Mr. and Mrs. David Gratias, will receive the Ken-L Ration gold medal that is awarded annually to the hero.

The city's Board of Education will have to find at least $15-million in new funds, most of it for federally aided education programs for underprivileged children or face a drastic cutback in such activities in a majority of the 31 local school districts this fall.

The police filed a formal complaint yesterday against a Bronx man who, they say, put a single-engine plane through some wild maneuvers over Manhattan on Friday night. The complaint was made to the Federal Aviation Administration because two New York City police helicopter pilots found that they had no jurisdiction over the light plane when they followed it to Teterboro Airport in New Jersey.

An African professor of religion told a group of 50 American teachers of African studies here last week that the popular image of a witch doctor--a man clothed in terrifying garments and masks, exorcising sick people, casting spells and forecasting the future--was an invention of foreign writers.
An off-duty patrolman accused of pistol-whipping a man in a brawl outside a Queens bar was arrested on a charge of felonious assault early yesterday and was suspended from the force.

LOS ANGELES. DANIEL BERRIGAN, S.J., the ecu menical pimpernel of the peace movement, was present in Los Angeles last week--in voice and spirit if not in underground flesh. His play, "The Trial of the Catonsville Nine," was performed with grace and fire by New Theater for Now at the Mark Taper Forum, the brain of the Music Center theatrical complex.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 15 --Miss Mary Louise Gilbert and Scott Hale Reiniger Jr., seniors at Rollins College, were married here today. The ceremony in St. Peter's Episcopal Church was performed by Canon Sydney R. Peters, assisted by the Rev. Allen J. Edmiston.

ITHACA, N.Y., Aug. 15-- Miss Rebecca MacMillan Fox, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Whiting Fox, was married at her parents' home here this morning to Thomas Jerome Leach, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Wilbur Cleon Leach of New York. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Sheldon Flory, Episcopal chaplain of Brown University, a close friend of the bridegroom's family.

EASTON, Md., Aug. 15--A 4-year-old Maltese, Ch. Pendleton's Jewel, owned by Mr. and Mrs. Norman White of Youngstown, Ohio, was named best of 1,005 dogs at the Talbot Kennel Club's show on the grounds of the Elks Club today.

MANY lawns are invaded by weeds such as annual bluegrass (Poa annua) which the common selective herbicides will not con trol. Others have been destroyed by insects or disease. If these are the reasons why a new lawn is planned, consider the use of a soil fumigant. Many of the problems can be reduced if the soil is sterilized before seed is planted or sod laid.

The desire of many renters of office space for parking facilities inside new office buildings is presenting builders with the need to make hard and costly business decisions and some planners in city government with the sense that city regulations may need revision.

SAIGON. SOUTH VIETNAM doesn't have Nielsen ratings for its fledgling television industry. But a letter from the Saigon Electric Company does identify the number one program. The letter, on file at THVN, the Saigon station, complains that every Friday night, all the television sets tuned to the weekly Chinese opera show are overloading the city's circuits.

ST. LOUIS--Being the Attorney General has always entailed so many headaches that it obviously irks John N. Mitchell that he has one that didn't trouble any of his predecessors--the controversy over the subpoenaing of newsmen's notes.
NEW CANAAN, Conn., Aug. 15--The marriage of Miss Claudia Whitney, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Oliver Hills Whitney of Brooklyn Heights, New York, to Guenter Frankenberg took place here today.

TACOMA, Wash., Aug. 15-- The most acute of the many crises that have erupted from Tacoma's polarized City Council since last November is shaping up for Monday and Tuesday over a movement to recall five of its nine members from office.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 15-- Eight children, four to 14 years old, went swimming in a portable pool at St. Clair Village, a housing development here, and later apparently developed a mild form of meningitis. As a result, the Allegheny County Health Department closed all nine of the city's portable swimming pools this week.

ESSEX, Conn.--From the townhouse district on Manhattan's East Side through the outer boroughs and the nearby suburbs into the spacious exurban reaches 100 miles and more from Times Square, the market in home sales is uniformly sluggish.

CAIRO--President Nasser has long been convinced that the United States holds the key to a nonmilitary Middle East settlement because of its political and economic influence over Israel and its role as Israel's principal arms supplier. KULUSUK, Greenland--The Eskimo children are a deep suntanned color with bright pink cheeks and large dark, Oriental eyes. Both my children are blond and very fair, and soon the Eskimo youngsters become curiously aggressive, touching them, tugging gently at their pale hair. My son asks what to do. I suggest he touch them in return. Within moments everyone is grinning broadly --an unexpected discovery of warmth in such a cold place.

It would do better to realize that the Penn Central signals the need for a real reorganization--reorganizing the whole structure of the industry, not just changing numbers on balance sheets.

"MR. BERNARD, please check at the Trans World Airlines information counter in the departure lounge." The summons resonated from the loudspeakers in London Airport at about 3 o'clock one recent afternoon. HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 15 (Agence France-Presse)--Despite the war, Hanoi's newspapers devote much of their space to sports, literature, painting and food.

LONDON, Aug. 16 The police used "snatch squads" and other new techniques to curb youth rampages at soccer games yesterday, but juvenile violence and vandalism occurred throughout Britain.

Less than a month after publication, "Sexual Politics" by Kate Millett, a manifesto of the new feminism, has sold upward of 15,000 copies and is in its fourth printing. The paperback rights have been sold for $75,000. It is also a Book-of-the-Month Club alternate selection for November.

WATKINS GLEN, N.Y. Aug. 16 A Chevrolet Camaro, driven by Vic Elford of England, won Camaro's second TransAmerican race of the season today. About 40 minutes of the two-hour endurance event were run in treacherously wet conditions that came with a rain shower.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 16, (Reuters) Yasir Arafat, leader of Al Fatah commando organization, pledged today that any Middle East peace settlement would be foiled by guerrilla force.
A wildcat strike by nightshift workers disrupted Western Union facilities here early today.

The New York State Department of Motor Vehicles is "all set to go" this winter on a new program to stop city scofflaws from renewing their auto license registrations, a spokesman said yesterday.

Mayor Lindsay announced approval yesterday of an $11.6million design contract for the long-awaited Second Avenue subway.

Britain's Conservative Government has finally accepted clear responsibility for carrying out reforms and enforcing equality in Northern Ireland even if this should require abolition of home rule in that volatile province. The bond market, which has been spending August assessing the June-July drop in interest rates, will have a quiet week to ruminate. Then it will have to get busy.

LONDON In England they have this curious day. It is called Sunday, but it is not to be confused with the day Americans call Sunday. The American Sunday, to cite one distinction, is only 72 hours long, while the English Sunday is of variable length, though never shorter than 257 hours.
Eastern and Western railroads reached agreement in Chicago yesterday to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission for authority to increase their freight rates by 15 per cent.
HONG KONG, Aug. 17 Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China is expected to make an extensive tour abroad this year that will take him to the Middle East, Africa and Europe.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 17 The New York Giants, smarting from a last-minute defeat at the hands of the San Diego Chargers Saturday night, reported back to camp at C.W. Post College this afternoon and had what amounted to a second straight day off.
CAPE HATTERAS, N.C., Aug. 17 (UPI) A severe tropical depression moved up the Eastearn Seaboard today, washing ashore a body and damaging several resort towns.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 17 A thunderous explosion early to- day ripped the old Federal Office Building, headquarters for military inductions in the Minneapolis area.
White Consolidated Industries, Inc., and the White Motor Company, two large industrial companies based is Cleveland, announced yesterday that they had agreed in principle to merge.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17 "When you get into the final trials," George Hinman said today, "I find that almost every thing the boat did before is usually forgotten."

PARIS, Aug. 17 (Reuters) The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in a survey of the Japanese economy, said today that, even if a high rate of economic growth was maintained, Japan's current balance-of-payments surplus would probably be between $2-billion and $2.5-billion in 1970, with a further increase in the first half of next year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Vice President Agnew charged today that a Senate proposal for a fixed withdrawal of Amer- ican troops from South Vietnam was "a blueprint for the first defeat in the history of the United States."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 American-Israeli relations were more strained tonight than at any time since mid-June, when the United States started its initiative for a Middle East cease-fire and a new round of Arab-Israeli negotiations.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 17 Miss Rose Ella King, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W.L.G. King, was married here Saturday to John Youie Woodruff, of Edison, N.J., associate director of the New Jersey Residential Manpower Center at Camp Kilmer, N.J., and former Olympic 800-meter track champion. The Rev. Paul Beattie performed the ceremony in All Souls Unitarian Church.
BUFFALO, Aug. 17 A Buffalo youth died early today in an explosion and fire in a vacant cottage on the city's East Side, and his brother was found 15 minutes later suffering from severe burns.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Senator Philip A. Hart asked the Federal Trade Commission today to investigate the gasoline industry for possible violations of the antitrust laws in a half-dozen areas.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Senate defeated today, 43 to 22, legislation that would have required the Pentagon to tell Congress whether it was following the new "fly-beforeyou-buy" policy.
The 13-foot high iron gate to the garden of the Museum of Modern Art was swung open last night on creaking hinges to welcome the public in a new program of free evening admission.
GENEVA Aug. 17 (UPI) The World Health Organization said today that there were no indications that a cholera outbreak was spreading westward from the Soviet Union.
On June 29, 1964, Nikita S. Khrushchev, then the Soviet Premier, wrote a warm tribute to the memory of an American with whom he had engaged in several battles of will.
The bond market yesterday failed to pass a key test, and interest rates moved decisively higher.

By late August even the most dedicated members of the fruit-only-for-dessert group would welcome something from the oven. The recipes that follow offer three distinctively different style desserts that would even tempt calorie counters.

In a recent speech to a group of law students, State Senator John R. Dunne contended that 5 per cent of the state corrections budget was spent on rehabilitating prisoners, while 95 per cent was spent "to keep men behind bars."
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 17 Suleiman Franjieh, Lebanon's new President, is depicted by acquaintances as a model Middle Eastern country gentleman.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 17 Israel has decided to release two prominent Algerians taken off a British airliner in transit through Lydda airport last Friday, according to informed sources here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 17 (AP) The United States mission in Vietnam, in a move aimed at encouraging civilian advisers to serve here, has quietly dropped the five-year-old prohibition against the advisers bringing their wives to Vietnam.

An old scandal has resurfaced on Capitol Hill. Two years ago, this newspaper reported that the major automobile companies were leasing luxury cars to influential members of the House and Senate at a nominal charge. Now, two reporters for United Press International have again examined this curious practice and come up with fresh details. Familiarity has not made the practice less contemptible.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The Nixon Administration has abandoned all consideration of shifting oil import controls from quotas to tariffs, it was dis- closed today.
WARSAW, Aug 17 Stefan Cardinal Wyszynski, the Roman Catholic primate of Poland, said here last night that personal sacrifices were needed if the Polish nation was to survive.
Leon Fleisher, once America's most respected young pianist, a former prodigy who made his debut at age 7, will walk out on the stage of Philharmonic Hall for another debut next Monday.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 17 Joe Namath the actor again became Joe Namath the football player tonight when he walked out of the Jets' team physician's office and was cleared to return to the team tomorrow.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 17 Foreign Minister Abba Eban charged today that the United Arab Republic and the Soviet Union were continuing to construct missile sites and to deploy weapons close to the Suez Canal.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 17 "Americans Go Home," the posters say in Vietnamese.
CHICAGO, Aug. 17 (AP) She Is Gorgeous won Arlington Park's $30,100 Majorette Stakes for 2-year-old fillies today before a crowd of 13,264.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 17 Once you have coached Bill Russell and have won as many championships because of him as did Arnold (Red) Auerbach, it's difficult to let the past fade away.

Dr. Frederick D. Lascoff, owner of a Yorkville pharmacy that specializes in rare drugs and old-time remedies, died yesterday in Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived at 125 East 72d Street.

In two working days last week the Agriculture Department mailed out $2.1 billion in checks to farms for complying with Government acreage allotments that limit the output of cotton, feed grains and wheat.

STONY BROOK, L.I., Aug. 17 Jim T. Smith of Hempstead posted a 39, 37 76 to lead the scoring in the Long Island Senior Golf Association tournament today at the St. George's Golf and Country Club, Par for the 6,208-yard course is 34 36 70.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Two months after Dr. James E. Allen Jr. was dismissed as United States Commissioner of Education, the seed that he planted for a national reading program has begun to take root.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 17 The door stays open and the children are free to come and go as they please. Mostly they come and stay, and about 50 of them have spent almost every weekday this summer painting, modeling and building in a former florist shop here that has become a community art workshop.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., 17 Mr. and Mrs. Fletcher Wakefield Hartshorn have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Prudence Elwell Hartshorn, to Louis Farthing Ryan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Anthony Ryan of Richmond. The couple plan to be married here on Sept. 5.

Jim Hannan, despite an academic career that included studies at Notre Dame, the University of Pennsylvania, Fairleigh Dickinson and New York University on the way to a master's degree in economics, didn't seem very smart three years ago.

When two Volkswagen drivers pass each other at night, they blink their lights as a sign of recognition. When two owners of Louis Vuitton luggage cross paths at an airport, they nod discreetly for the same reason. And when two women wearing a Lacoste dress meet at a party, they recognize each other as sisters under the skin rather than as immediate enemies.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. disclosed a substitute today for the proposed constitutional amendment approved by the House a week ago to guarantee equal rights for women.

Axelrod Co., a member firm of the New York Stock Exchange and a specialist on the American Stock Exchange, will become the second publicly owned Big Board member in history as a result of a merger disclosed yesterday.
The election of Richard T. Norton as president of Global Terminal and Container Services, Inc., was announced yesterday.
SARATOGA, Aug. 17 (AP) Fasig Tipton Company, Inc., sold 88 horses of racing age in its sales ring at Saratoga today for a total of $621,800.

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Aug. 17 (UPI) Despite Sheriff Ed Stack's plea to "cool it," Negroes set fire, to several buildings in Broward County tonight and resumed their rockthrowing sprees. Sheriff Stack made his appeal today after widespread sniping, firebomb- ing and looting over the weekend.
Arthur J. Goldberg called on Governor Rockefeller yesterday to agree to limit campaign spending for television and radio even before a proposed Federal limitation takes effect
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, has established a community college in Israel, the first of its kind there.

ATLANTA, Aug. 17 (UPI) African doctors who charged racism at the Center for Disease Control went looking for new quarters today, bolstered by an increase in their daily living allowance from the State Department.
MOSCOW, Aug. 17, (Reuters) A dissident intellectual arrested nearly a year ago has been released and the case against him has been dropped sources close to dissidents said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 17 (UPI) Ken Stabler, a rookie for three years who finally is getting a crack at a pro quarterback's job, threw three second-half touchdown passes tonight to carry the Oakland Raiders to a 30-19 victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in a National Football League preseason game.
The Yankees won New York's annual meeting of the baseball clans last night by bombing the Mets, 9-4, with the same fiendish delight the Mets used to take when their fortunes were reversed.

Nearly 300 New York City policemen will be wearing new shoulder patches during the next month in an experiment designed to eliminate confusion in distinguishing them from other city and private law-enforcement agents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 The United States brought suit today in the Supreme Court against Arizona and Idaho, asking the Court to uphold the constitutionality of the new Federal statute that grants the vote to 18-year-olds and outlaws literacy and residency requirements of more than 30 days for voting.

DUESSELDORF, Germany Aug. 17. (AP) Christian Kuhnke needed only two minutes to complete a 6-3, 6-3, 7-5 victory over Manuel Orantes of Spain today and send West Germany into the Davis Cup challenge round against the United States, the defenders, in Cleveland on Aug. 29 through 31.

SAN MIGUELITO, Panama, Aug. 17 Over 50 per cent of the 28,000 eligible voters in this special district cast ballots for local-government leaders yesterday in Panama's first official election since the military seized power in a coup d'etat in October, 1968.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 Senator Sam J. Ervin Jr. proposed today a substitute for the pending equal rights amendment that would specifically exempt women from compulsory military service and also insure the continued validity of most other laws that treat men and women differently.
Prices and volume continued to drop yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in the slowest trading in more than three years.

DETROIT, Aug. 17 The Bank of the Commonwealth in Detroit, the flagship of a chain of banks once dominated by Donald H. Parsons' investor group, announced today that common stock dividends would be eliminated for the rest of the year.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 17 The Minister of the Economy, Suleiman Franjieh, was chosen by Parliament today to be President of Lebanon by a onevote margin on the third ballot, after which tumult erupted on the floor of the house.

VIENTIANE, Laos, Aug. 17 (Agence France-Presse) Talks between Government representatives and an envoy from the Communist-led Pathet Lao have reached a stalemate, according to the envoy, Prince Tiao Souk Vongsak.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 President Nixon, who is trying to improve his political image among Negro voters, is also preparing to replace Walter E. Washington, the black Mayor of the District of Columbia.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 17 Contemporary music, outside the academic cloisters to which it has been condemned by the culture industry in this country, is generally to be found, when at all, on its back and breathing heavily.
Steel production in the week ended Saturday rose by 1.4 per cent, compared to output in the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 17 (Reuters) The Nigerian Government said today that it would not use its new powers indiscriminately to punish public officials for anti-Government acts between Jan. 15, 1966, and the end of the Nigerian civil war last Jan. 15.

NARRAGANSETT, R.I., Aug. 17 (AP) The defending champion, Mrs. Betty Rosenquist Pratt of Maitland, Fla., led the advance of seeded players today through the opening round of the national senior women's tennis championships on the Point Judith Country Club's grass courts.

Miss Emily Elizabeth Wadhams and Marshall Canfield Webb, whose fathers were classmates at Yale and who knew each other vaguely as children, were married on Saturday, a year after they bumped into each other in Europe.

To the great number of Americans who bought and read his biographies and other books, Andre Maurois must have seemed the quintessential French writer: stylish, rational, aphoristic, balanced, without excesses, humane and withal very genuine.

Louis H. Rubenstein, former president of the Infants Home of Brooklyn and founder and president of Le Mont Clothing and Driggs Pants Company, men's clothing manufacturing concerns, died at Mount Sinai Hospital yesterday after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 275 Central Park West.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission censured today Schweickart Co., a New York broker-dealer, for violations of the financial-reporting and record-keeping provisions of the Federal securities laws.
NEWARK, Aug. 17 (AP) A 5-foot-6-inch civilian is finding that although he had what it took to win a Bronze Star in Vietnam, he does not have what it takes to become a Newark policeman.
An 8-year-old 'boy's left hand was severed yesterday after he fell beneath the wheels of a northbound IND A train in Brooklyn, the Transit Authority reported.

The bodies of 14 of 49 teenagers killed in a plane crash on Aug. 9 in Peru were sent yesterday from Kennedy International Airport to their home communities or other airports, airline officials said.
ALBANY, Aug. 17 One night last winter in the relaxed atmosphere of a dinner here, Governor Rockefeller accepted a phrase that had been leveled at him as criticism by Democratic politicians.

RICHMOND, Aug. 17 (AP) Federal District Judge Robert R. Merhige Jr. approved an interim desegregation plan of operation today for Richmond's schools that he described as not a unitary system, but the beginning of the end of a dual system.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 17 Secretary General Thant's special representative for the Middle East, Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, continued today to press for preliminary agreements that would allow peace talks to begin.

The president of a Wall Street security company that employed off-duty policemen to make investigations, take fingerprints and write reports said yesterday that he believed that the moonlighting charges brought against the men last week were a "great injustice."

LONDON, Aug. 17 The British Government, worried about the increasing use of barbiturates with intravenous injections, has asked treatment centers and local police offices for details on the extent of misuse.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug 17 Despite thunderstorms that stopped play for 15 minutes this morning and for 25 minutes in mid-afternoon the first qualifying round of the 70th annual United States Women's Amateur golf, championship was completed today.

SARASOTA, Fla., Aug. 17 Wallace L. Minto, an engineer and scientist who invented a nonpolluting, Freon-powered ergine, announced today that he had signed a multimilliondollar contract for its mass production and use in Datsun automobiles manufactured in Japan.

Fritz T. Sprandel, 26 years old, of Allentown, Pa., left by canoe from Staten Island yesterday, headed for Los Angeles by way of the Panama Canal.

ASMARA, Ethiopia, Aug. 14 Since the rains came six weeks ago there has been a decline in rebel activity here in Eritrea, Ethiopia's northernmost province, but the area remains troubled.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 17 Simon H. Fabian, former president of the Stanley Warner Corporation, the motion picture theater concern that became a conglomerate, died at White Plains Hospital yesterday after suffering smoke inhalation from a fire in his summer residence here. WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 A Federal court was asked today to bar Congressional attempts to block a voluntary busing program that has transported black elementary school students from downtown Washington to a white community in the Maryland suburbs.

TORONTO, Aug. 17 (Canadian Press) Mrs. Margaret Court of Australia defeated Rosemary Casals of San Francisco, 6-8, 6-4, 6-4, tonight to win the women's singles title at the Canadian open tennis championships. Mrs. Court received $800 and the loser $400.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 17 Christ's Episcopal Church was the setting here last Saturday for the marriage of Miss Sarah Meade Parker, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Stevenson Parker, to Alan Houghton McCord, who is with the art department at McCann-Erickson, Inc., the advertising agency in New York.

Stock prices eased yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrial average slipped 1.78 points to finish at 709.06 after being down more than 4 points in early-afternoon trading.

LONDON Aug. 17 (UPI) Brazil said today that she would stand fast in her dispute with the United States over instant-coffee prices.
