"Its ability to get and keep expert people to run its programs is inadequate." Another study by the Institute of Public Administration also recommended handsome salary increases for all top municipal administrators.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 17 Yasir Arafat, the main Arab commando chief, met with Iraqi leaders in Baghdad yesterday after saying in Amman that his men would turn Jordan into "another Hanoi" and that any Middle East peace would be "foiled by our gun barrels."
JOHNSON CITY, Tenn., Aug. 17 (AP) John Small, the Atlanta Falcons No. 1 draft choice from The Citadel, was shifted from linebacker to defensive tackle today by Coach Norm Van Brocklin.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (Reuters) A Silver Users Association report said today that present world silver stocks, plus future production, will be adequate to meet industrial needs for 10 to 15 years.

LONDON, Aug. 17 A bomb that the police thought had been set by members of the Irish Republican Army or their sympathizers seriously injured a young couple here last night as they carried it from a movie.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 17 (AP) The survey listed the following other New York City metropolitan water systems as potentially hazardous:
FALLS VILLAGE, Conn., Aug. 17 William C. Michel, retired executive vice president of 20th Century-Fox, died today. He was 75 years old and lived on Belden Street.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 17 (AP) B-52 bombers struck the northern quarter of South Vietnam today in an attempt to thwart what some allied officers said might be a bid enemy offensive.
WASHINGTON, Aug, 17 (UPI)?The House Government Operations. Committee said today that the Federal Government failed to provide adequate training for most of its 50,000 investigators.
It was a day to remember yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as all grain futures rose to limit highs, propelled by the threat of a serious blight to the nation's corn crop.

Muhammad Ali, who as Cassius Clay once held the world heavyweight title, will move in Federal Court this morning against the State Athletic Commission's request to dismiss his suit for a license to box.
A grant of $35,000 to the New York Dance Festival by the New York State Council on the Arts was announced by Governor Rockefeller yesterday.

Two brief work stoppages in the communications industry ended yesterday with employes returning to their jobs at both Western Union and the longlines division of the American Telephone and Telegraph company.
MONTREAL, Aug. 18 (AP) An Air France jet carrying 174 passengers from Montreal to Paris was diverted to New York's Kennedy International Airport early today after one of its engines caught fire.

Five black inmates of the Manhattan Men's House of Detention were escorted from their cells to a legislative hearing yesterday and testified that a major cause of the disorders there last week was the beating of a black prisoner by white guards.

Members of the Correction Officers Benevolent Association demanded last night that they be allowed to go through the city jails section by section to repair broken locks on cell doors, return inmates to their cells and search for contraband and homemade weapons.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 After 15 months of debate within the Administration, the White House will send the Geneva Protocol of 1925 to the Senate tomorrow for approval.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 18 Someone involved with the Giants-Jets football game finally admitted that this contest at Yale Bowl Sunday was "more than just an exhibition game." It was Alex Webster, coach of the Giants, who said he wanted to win this game more than he wants to win most games.
THANHMY, South Vietnam In June this small community was only a dark smudge on the earth after a Vietcong massacre.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 A panel of Spanish-speaking educators said today that past programs and policies for providing equal education for Spanish American children were a fraud. The educators questioned integration as a solution.
DEDHAM, Mass., Aug. 18 Hardwick Moseley, a retired director of the Houghton Mifflin Company, publishers, died in a nursing home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 69 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Hitler once considered attacking Britain with nerve gas exactly like the GB gas that the United States dumped in the Atlantic today, according to Joseph Borkin, a Washington lawyer and publicist who is writing a book about the develovment of nerve gas.

WASHINGTON, Aug.18 The United States informed Israel today that it could not conclude that there had been a serious enough Egyptian violation of the Middle East cease-fire to warrant any further delay in Arab-Israeli negotiations, and urged Israel to proceed with the talks, officials reported.

NORTH TONAWANDA, N.Y., Aug. 18 Arthur J. Goldberg said today that he thought Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird had made "a very bad mistake in dismissing Israel's intelligence reports" of violations of the cease-fire in the Middle East.
CHEYENNE, Wyo., Aug. 18, (AP) Senator Gale McGee, a backer of United States policy in Vietnam, defeated a peace candidate i the Democratic primary today to win renomination to a third term.

The latest example of diversification by agencies took place yesterday when Young Rubicam said that it had made an offer to acquire some assets and operations of the J.K. Gill Company. Gill owns 11 stores in Oregon and Washington that sell books, gifts, art supplies and office equipment.

ATTICA, N.Y., Aug. 18 Twenty-six prisoners who were leaders in a three-day work stoppage last month at the At- tica Correctional Facility have been transferred to other penal institutions, and about 50 men have been disciplined by the loss of time off for good behavior, Superintendent Vincent R. Mancusi said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. l8 The Justice Department endorsed today, a senate bill that would authorize the assignment of persons on parole or probation to community treatment centers run by the Bureau of Prisons.
Miss Nancy Hill and John M. Darcy, who met at the State University, at Stony Brook, L.I, where they are doctoral students in psychobiology, will marry Aug. 29.
The private banking firm of Brown Bros., Harriman Co. was identified yesterday as the victim of a $1.56-million theft of Treasury bills.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The White House praised Walter E. Washington today and said that President Nixon had no plans to replace him as Mayor of the District of Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) Federal experts reported today that a new type of corn blight had spread from Texas to Florida in the South and up to Minnesota and Wisconsin in the North. But it said it was too early to estimate the potential damage to the nation's $5-billion corn crop.
Zsa Zsa Gabor was robbed at gunpoint early this morning of jewels whose value she estimated at $625,000, the police said.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Mrs. Elizabeth Becker Farmer, a news producer here for the Columbia Broadcasting System, was married this noon to John Midgley, Washington correspondent of The Economist of London. The Rev. Walter Fauntroy performed the ceremony at the New Bethel Baptist Church.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 18 A nationwide campaign to prohibit state courts from issuing injunctions against strikes by public employes where public safety is not involved was begun here today by the American Federation of Teachers.

The Mostly Mozart concert series at Philharmonic Hall this month has become quite a testing ground for relatively unknown and relatively young conductors. Monday night it was the turn of Sergiu Comissiona, born in 1928 in Rumania and now conductor of the Baltimore Symphony, to show New York audiences what he can do with the crack New York Chamber Orchestra.
At 2:30 last Monday afternoon, after seven months of detention, Julio Senidez was released from the Tombs when his family put up $150 bail.

BRANFORD, Conn., Aug. 18 Hubert M. Greist Jr., former president of the Greist Manufacturing Division of the Mite Corporation, died here yesterday. He was 59 years old and lived at 21 Island View Avenue. He was with the family company from 1934 until his retirement in 1968.

The Most Rev. Helder Camara is called the "Red Bishop" because he fights for social justice in Brazil's impoverished northeast, criticizes military dictatorships in his own and other countries, and often supports radical reform causes in Latin America.

MOSCOW, Aug. 18 The Soviet Union today dismissed as "fabrications" Israeli charges that the United Arab Republic had violated the Middle East cease-fire by moving Soviet missile installations near the Suez Canal.
LONDON, Aug. 18 A continuing tanker boom with 700 per cent profits on some voyages and a shipbuilding spree by Communist China are buoying the Baltic Exchange.
MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 18 William O. Beach, deputy manager of Brown Brothers Harriman Co., New York bankers, died in a hospital here today. He was 64 years old and lived in Valley Stream.

Dr. and Mrs. Robert Hawthorne Wylie of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Alexandra Pearson Wylie, to Norbert A. Considine 3d, a 1969 graduate of the University of Pennsylvania, where his fiancee was graduated this year. The wedding is planned for next month.

ABOARD U.S.S. HARTLEY, in the Atlantic, Aug.18 The obsolete Liberty ship LeBaron Russell Briggs and her controversial cargo of nerve gas sank in 16,000 feet of water today 283 miles east of the Florida coast.

Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm yesterday. The strength of the market was apparently spurred by the U.S. Federal Reserve Board's credit easing action in freeing $350-million of bank reserves.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 18 (AP) North Vietnamese troops were staid to have attacked a South Vietnamese force near a fire base 27 miles west of Hue today, but heavy rains reduced ground action elsewhere in South Vietnam's northernmost provinces.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Following are excerpts from the text of Senator Mark O. Hatfield's floor speech today replying to Vice President Agnew:
"Oh, my God," a woman shrieked. "It's Governor Rockefeller."

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 18 The unpredictable Joe Namath, an absentee from the Jets' first 11 training days and two exhibition games, rejoined his teammates this afternoon but still was expressing uncertainty about his football future.

LENOX, Mass., Aug. 18 In the last half dozen years there has been no more significant development in music than the appearance of imposing numbers of young performers who are both willing and able to play new works whose difficulties would have been beyond the reach of renowned virtuosos a generation ago.

In 1940, Henry R. Luce wrote that "if John Kennedy is characteristic of the younger generation and I believe he is many of us would be happy to have the destinies of this Republic handed over to his generation at once."

WESTBURY, L.I., Aug. 18 Roosevelt Raceway's synthetic rubber surface, over which standardbreds turned in seven sub-2-minute miles during the recent harness racing meeting, was given its first test by thoroughbreds today. With numerous officials from various tracks on hand, about 25 "flat" horses jogged, galloped and breezed.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 18 Martha Wilkinson of Whittier, Calif., won the qualifying medal in the 70th United States women's amateur golf championship today by adding a one-over-par 75 to a first-round 75 for 150.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 For many months now, the Nixon Administration has been debating privately the best way to make the South Vietnamese take over the defense of their country and speed up the withdrawal of the American expeditionary force. Should the Saigon regime be assured of Washington's support indefinitely, or should it be told, publicly or privately, that the American troops would be called home by a certain date?

BRUSSELS, Aug. 18 A European security conference involving the North Atlantic alliance, the Warsaw Pact nations and neutral countries is regarded as quite likely in 1971 by authoritative sources in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
BERLIN, Aug. 18 Bonn announced today it would provide no public funds for a gathering in West Berlin next month of the associations of those expelled from Germany's former eastern provinces.

Fashion may still be in a state of flux about hemlines but there is no uncertainty about hats. They are back and there's scarcely a designer of ready-to-wear who isn't stressing their importance. One of the nicest things about the current millinery revival is that there is almost no "wrong" shape. There are, however, shapes that are more right than others.
The New York Mets turned into the homestretch last night, with 42 games to go, by socking the Houston Astros, 7-1, before 36,496 persons in Shea Stadium.

YONKERS, Aug. 18 Ted Gibbons, Larry Mallar and Carl Miller will handle the racing secretary duties at Yonkers Raceway until Ed Parker recovers from an automobile accident which hospitalized Park and his wife, and in which the Parker's 3-year-old son, Michael was killed yesterday morning.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 18 (AP) Thousands of people lined up today for shots in this city's worst diphtheria outbreak in a decade as two new cases were confirmed, raising the total to 22 for this month and 52 since Jan. 1.

The coordinators of next week's Women's Strike for Equality announced plans yesterday for nationwide demonstrations ranging from "babyins" to marches and rallies to dramatize their goal of achieving "the unfinished business of our equality."

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug 18 The nine-point "sudden death" tie-breaker, receiving its first test on grass in the Pennsylvania lawn tennis championships, decided a thrilling threeset match today between Haroon Rahim of Pakistan, the United States amateur grasscourt champion, and Tom Gorman of Seattle.

Negotiators for the city's four major daily newspapers and the Newspaper Deliverers Union continued their bargaining sessions yesterday in an effort to reach an agreement that would avert a strike threatened for tonight.
BONN, Aug. 18 The West German government has postponed its final approval of two nuclear power projects that were originally scheduled to get under way this year.

PARIS, Aug. 18 (Reuters) Banking sources here described the Reserve's moves as economically wise. But they foresaw little reaction ensuing either way on Wall Street and only minor adjustments resulting in prevailing United States and Eurodollar interest rates.

The Olin Corporation, one of many chemical companies that have been accused of contaminating the environment, announced yesterday that it had developed an instrument that can automatically detect and measure minute amounts of mercury in air or water at a rapid pace.
A grim Mayor Lindsay spent an hour yesterday morning walking through several rundown blocks of East Harlem.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 18 (AP) Robert Selph Henry, author, historian and retired railway executive, died today. He was 80 years old.

"Divisions in society" between rich and poor, young and old, white and black and the elite and non-elite are at the top of a list of major problem areas for the United States for the nineteen-seventies and nineteen-eighties, according to a National Industrial Conference Board survey released yesterday.

A five-week tribute to the directorial career of George Cukor will be presented starting Aug. 27 at the Museum of Modern Art. The program of 22 films starts with the 1930 film "The Royal Family of Broadway," which Mr. Cukor co-directed, and goes to "The Chapman Report" (1963). The following year Mr. Cukor won an Oscar for "My Fair Lady."

Cassius Clay's lawyers told a Federal judge yesterday that more than 90 convicted felons, whose crimes ranged from embezzlement to rape and murder, had been licensed to box in recent years by the New York State Athletic Commission, which suspended Clay after he refused to be inducted into the armed services.

Do you reach for the pile of mail your postman has brought, thinking eagerly of letters from family and friends, of an invitation to join some pleasurable or profitable venture, or perhaps a tax refund? And do you find all too often that what you have instead is a collection of gaudy and unwanted sales pitches for everything from Florida real estate to cut-rate tomatoes featured at the local supermarket?

POMPANO BEACH, Fla., Aug. 18 After four nights of racial violence, black citizens in Broward County, Fla., presented the Pompano Beach City Commission today with a list of demands, one of which called for the prosecution of a white policeman who shot and kiled a Negro Saturday night.

It would have been easy for Jim Plunkett: the money could have bought a new house for his mother and sister in the suburbs, an engagement ring for Gini, his girl, and a new car to replace the blue '66 Chevy that sometimes stalls on the freeways.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) The latest moves by the Federal Reserve are regarded as neutral by American banks here. However, they have prompted speculation that the recent suspension of ceilings on 30-89-day large certificates Continued on Page 58, Column 3.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 The two youngest teams ever to reach the final of the Spingold knockout team championship met today in the top event in the American Contract Bridge League's summer national tournament at the Boston Sheraton Hotel.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 18 Describing Lonnie McLucas as "my man" or "as you would say, my boyfriend," a young woman in the Black Panther party testified at his trial today that he wept after the murder of Alex Rackley.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 Grandmaster Bent Larsen of Denmark retained the lead after the eighth round of the annual United States Open Chess Championship by splitting the point with Robert Byrne, a grandmaster of Indianapolis, at the Parker House here last night.

Miss Stephanie Bradford Hoar, who is with the Conservation Foundation in Washington, and Thomas Paul Einstein, director of business affairs for A.B.C. International Television here, plan to be married in the fall.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 18 Henry Ford 2d assailed today "irresponsible demands and uninformed criticism" in the air pollution and auto safety fields and said the changes needed in cars "will not come one moment sooner because of deadlines which command the impossible."
What went up came down yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as grain futures contracts dropped sharply following Monday's across-the-board limit advance.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 18 Thousands of young "street people," wearing faded blue jeans and long hair, low on money and looking for others like themselves, have come to Harvard Square this summer. They are confronting the Cambridge community with a challenge to its liberal ideals.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate overrode today President Nixon's veto of a $4.4-billion education appropriation bill:

NEWARK, Aug. 18 Mrs. Betty Kennedy, vice president of the defunct Eatontown (N.J.) National Bank, testified for an hour today before a Federal grand jury here investigating the affairs of the bank. The bank was closed and seized by the Government on Aug. 8 after losses that might exceed $5-million were discovered by bank examiners.

For eight years Frank Langella has been working steadily off Broadway, at Lincoln Center and in regional theaters. Even without ever appearing on Broadway, he is recognized at the age of 30 as one of America's finest young stage actors.

Pierre Boulez, principal guest conductor of the Cleveland Orchestra through the 1971-72 season, has been named to serve as the orchestra's music adviser through that period. The orchestra's musical director, George Szell, died last month.
LONDON, Aug. 18 A rash of explosions and discoveries of arms caches have generated a bomb scare that is keeping the police busy and providing the popular newspapers with big headlines.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Aug. 18 (UPI) Bob Ross, originator and producer of the television series "Mayberry R.F.D.," died last night of a heart attack.
HONG KONG, Aug. 18 (Reuters) The pro-Communist Pathet Lao leader, Prince Souphanouvong, has accused the Laotian Government of Premier Souvanna Phouma of introducing South Vietnamese troops into Laos.

From the time Russell E. McKelvey hit the major leagues' first home run with the bases loaded for Indianapolis in 1878, the subject has proved to be among the most glamorous statistics in the record book, including Lou Gehrig's 23 career grand slams, Ernie Banks's five in a season, Jim Northrup's three in a week and Jim Gentile's two in the first two innings.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) Despite efforts begun three years ago to recruit more blacks, the Navy officer corps remains a virtual lily-white organization, with Negroes accounting for less than 1 per cent of the Navy's 80,000 officers.

Conflict of interest. The very term has a troublesome connotation. No one, it would seem, can be expected to serve effectively interests that are opposing. But at the same time, it is clear that overlapping and possibly conflicting relationships are commonplace throughout American business.

WASHINGTON, Aug.18 Dean Burch, chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, emphasized today that the agency's order requiring the television networks to give prime-time exposure to critics of the Administration's policy in Vietnam was not a grant of "equal time" to match President Nixon's appearances.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Senate passed today with brief debate and no record vote legislation tightening the provisions of the corporate takeover law. That law, passed in 1968, requires disclosures of the identities and intentions of those who acquire 10 per cent of the stock of publicly held corporations.
Miss Ellen Martha Carlstein, a lawyer with Cadwalader, Wickersham Taft here, and Stephen Harold Roth, a lawyer with Clapp Eisenberg in Newark, plan to be married Aug. 30.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The Senate today decisively overrode President Nixon's veto of the $4.4-billion education appropriation bill, completing enactment of the measure despite White House disapproval.

MIDDLETOWN, R.I., Aug. 18 Comdr. Sherwoode A. Taffinder, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Taffinder have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Terry Anne Taffinder, to Christopher Heathcote Robinson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis C. Robinson of London. The wedding will take place here Oct. 3 in the chapel of St. George's School.

Unable to put on their Powder Ridge Rock Festival in Middlefield, Conn., last month, the producers have scheduled a concert to be held next Tuesday in the Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium in Washington.
SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 18, (UPI) Eddie Fisher, the singer, filed a petition of bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court.

CHICAGO, Aug. 18 (AP) Charles Edward Bey, second in command of a Negro street gang, turned himself in to the authorities today, and the police continued their hunt for three other gang members wanted for questioning in the sniper slaying of a Chicago detective.

John A. Gaynor leaned out of the subway car, hoping that somehow the men and women trying to push their way into the train from the platform would finally let the doors close on the Times Square-Grand Central shuttle.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 18 A series of meetings of the Organization of African Unity got under way today, with Nigeria participating for the first time in two years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) Former Welfare Secretary John W. Gardner formally initiated today a nationwide, nonpartisan political movement called Common Cause, which he says will be a citizens' lobby to force action on reform of the political system and solution of national problems.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., Aug. 18 A little old woman in the dining room asked, "Are you really Pete Maravich?"
Westchester County officials said yesterday that water that was called "potentially hazardous" in a nationwide Federal survey made public Monday had been cleared up and was safe for drinking.
McCann-Erickson has nabbed a big one, its biggest since it acquired the Buick account in 1958 and about the largest piece of new business taken on by any agency in many a moon.
The City Investing Company showed a sharp increase in profits in the second quarter and a more moderate advance for the half year, the report showed yesterday.
A four-alarm fire, which burned out of control for more than three hours, ruined 11 stores and a banquet hall in a block-long section of Roosevelt Avenue in Woodside, Queens, yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) The Federal Trade Commission ruled today that all watches comprised of 50 percent or more foreign-made parts must be labeled of foreign origin.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 18 As efforts continued to get Middle Eastern peace talks under way, Secretary General Thant warned all United Nations members today that unless more money was forthcoming for Arab-refugee aid, the refugees would present added problems.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) Asserting he was "shocked and disappointed" by President Nixon's decision to retain the present oil-import quota system, Senator Edward M. Kennedy said today he will hold Senate hearings on the decision "at the earliest opportunity."
Toll collectors at five bridges and two tunnels in the city abruptly walked off their jobs last night, surprising both their supervisors and their own union leaders.

It is possible, it seems, to go faster by going slower. Sunday's Yankee 400 stockcar race at Michigan International Speedway proved the point as Charlie Glotzbach raced the 400 miles at an average speed of 148 miles an hour, 5 m.p.h. faster than the previous record.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 A Senate Appropriations subcommittee was reported today to have cut $3.7-million from funds for the Geneva-based International Labor Organization.

TRENTON, Aug. 18 The deputy chairman of the Republican National Committee ridiculed today as a "great revelation" the public disclosure by Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr. last May that he once had had a drinking problem.

BELLMORE, L.I., Aug. 18 Miss Doris Hustedt, a cum laude graduate of Harpur College, was married here this evening to Richard W. Kessler, a Colgate University graduate who is attending the University of Pennsylvania Law School.

PEKING, Aug. 18 (Agence France-Presse) The man whom many Japanese consider their country's "private ambassador to China," Kinkazu Saionji, left here today to return to Japan by way of Canton and Hong Kong after living here for 12 years, trying to improve relations between Japan and Communist China.

The troubles of the 715-foot liner Caribia, now illegally berthed between two piers at the edge of the Upper West Side, were compounded yesterday when harbor pilots sued the ship for an unpaid pilotage bill.
QUITO, Ecuador, Aug. 18 Sweeping and revolutionary economic reforms have been approved by the Government in conjunction with its devaluation of the surce from 18 to 25 to the dollar last Sunday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 18 Beniamino Benvenuto Bufano, the largely "misunderstood" Italian artist who wandered like a medieval gnome through the 20th century creating titanic sculptures of stone and steel, was found dead in his workshop here today. He was 72 years old.
HARTFORD, Aug. 18--Connecticut Democrats will go to the polls tomorrow in the party's first statewide primary election to select a candidate for the United States Senate.
The United States Gypsum Company announced yesterday it had sold 4,974,179 ordinary shares of its holdings in BPB Industries, Ltd., London, producers of building materials.
The New York Stock Exchange announced yesterday that its board of governors had suspended Charles Plohn Co. and the First Devonshire Corporation because they were in unsafe financial condition.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 18 The mileage on the flashy red convertible in the bull pen went up tonight, but Yankee spirits dipped as Minnesota edged New York 8-7, on Jim Holt's pinch-hit, two-run single in the ninth inning.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 18 Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt met the Mayor of Saratoga, Sarto Smaldone, after the running of the feature race on today's card. The race was a six-furlong fillies-and-mares purse named the Saratoga Springs and it was Vanderbilt's happy task to accept the victory trophy from the Mayor.

A 76-year-old Polish immigrant who said he had lost "about 250 relatives" in World War II was arrested on a charge of trying to murder two vice consults in the West German Consulate at 460 Park Avenue, near 57th Street, yesterday.

The squatters who occupied Ellis Island for 13 days this summer have been given permission to return to the island and turn it into a rehabilitation center for 2,500 nar- cotics addicts, former convicts and their families.
The Metropolitan Transportation Authority announced the appointment of a three-man panel of foreign transit experts yesterday to try to improve New York's subway system.
An association representing student governments at colleges in the State University has been formed to try to avert campus violence.
State Senator John Richard Dunne had no sooner arrived on Cape Cod last week for his first vacation in two years when rioting erupted among prisoners at the Tombs.

BERLIN, Aug. 18 Ernst Lemmer, co-founder of the Christian Democratic Union after World War II, and a ranking politician in the earlier years of the Bonn Republic, died here today following an operation for a stomach ailment. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (UPI) A former Marine sergeant told a Senate subcommittee today that his objections to marijuana smoking so infuriated men under his command in Vietnam that one tried to murder him with a hand grenade.
GENEVA, Aug. 18 Charles C. Parlin, a Wall Street lawyer, today became the first layman to be elected President of the World Methodist Council since it was formed in 1881.

TOKYO, Aug. 18. The Bolshoi Opera Company of Moscow will open a four-week engagement at the Metropolitan Opera House in Lincoln Center, New York, next April 15, Sol Hurok announced here today. It will be the 532member company's first visit to the United States.
There were 109.3 per cent more narcotics arrests in the city last June than in June, 1969, Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday.

LONDON, Aug. 18 (AP) Consumer coffee nations agreed in principle today with the International Coffee Trade on setting a 58-million-bag quota for 1970-71 coffee year at a meeting of the International Coffee Agreement.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Members of the North Atlantic alliance remain eager for the United States to maintain present troop levels indefinitely in Western Europe.
Mrs. Ernest Byfield Jr., a prominent society woman and the wife of an advertising executive, died yesterday at her home. She was in her 50's and lived at 930 Park Avenue.
ROME, Aug. 18 An eightpoint decree, approved by Pope Paul VI last June but still not officially published here, relaxes outdated restrictions on some 1,250,000 Roman Catholic nuns and monks.

Coal mining remains a dangerous and bloody trade. One hundred and one men lost their lives in the mines in the first six months of this year. Unless safety procedures are radically improved, it is only a matter of time until there is another disaster in which scores of men will die.
Widespread malnutrition among old people living here without friends or relatives and fearing to leave their rooms was reported yesterday at a legislative hearing.
Price increases affecting important consumer items were announced yesterday by a number of companies.
GENEVA, Aug. 18 Bernard Cornfield, fighting to regain a major voice in the Investors Overseas Services mutual fund complex he founded, intends to fly to New York tomorrow.
The Federal Reserve's decision to cut reserve requirements against savings deposits lowered interest rates sharply on short-term funds employed to finance public housing and state projects.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 18 President Chung Hee Park's overture for a peaceful reunification of Korea in a speech last Saturday has led to lively public discussion on a question that few South Koreans dared to debate openly in the past.

American Metal Climax, Inc., announced yesterday that its Ayrshire Coal Company division had signed a $500-million agreement with the Public Service Company of Indiana calling for Ayrshire to supply 80 million tons of coal to the utility over a 30-year period.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 17 Citing dozens of health-code violations in migrant camps in a threecounty area near here, Adam Walinsky today demanded that the stage empanel a special grand jury to "seek out the private citizens and public officials who violate the laws which protect the migrant workers."

PARIS, Aug. 18 France has nearly quadrupled her force of narcotics agents covering the Mediterranean coastal region and Corsica in the last month, and plans to add more in the fall. These are the principal areas for refining drugs from Turkey and other Middle Eastern regions and transshipment to the United States.
HARTFORD, Aug. 18 Efrain Gonzalez, a 26-year-old Puerto Rican who was fatally shot during recent North End riots, "probably" was slain by a police weapon, according to Police Chief Thomas J. Vaughan.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. Aug. 18 The Ford Motor Company still is considering doing business in the Soviet Union, but Moscow has not responded to Ford inquiries, Henry Ford 2d, the company chairman, said today.

Summertime, and this year the living's not so easy for college students. With tuition, room and board fees soaring, an ever-increasing number need summer jobs to help pay their expenses, but with the economy in the doldrums, there are fewer jobs to be had.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 18 (Agence France-Presse) In the presence of a delegation from the American Black Panther party led by Eldridge Cleaver, North Vietnam celebrated an "international day of solidarity with the black people of the United States" today.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 18 Linda Kasabian said today on the witness stand that her testimony was her "repentance" for the slaying of Sharon Tate, the actress, and six other persons last August.
ROME, Aug. 18 Italy's summer campaign against narcotics users is sending long-haired young foreigners fleeing from a country they once found completely hospitable.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug 18 All Elizabeth patrolmen and members of the department's auto squad were ordered today to keep a sharp lookout for one particular stolen car. The car belongs to their chief, Michael D. Roy.
The American Stock Exchange yesterday turned in its best performance in three weeks as most prices rose in stepped-up trading.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (AP) Miss Angela Davis, avowed Communist and former instructor at the University of California at Los Angeles, was named today to the F.B.I.'s list of 10 most-wanted fugitives.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 18 Lebanese officials reported today that an Israeli force crossed into southern Lebanon early in the day and blew up three houses.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 18 (Agence France-Presse) In the presence of a delegation from the American Black Panther party led by Eldridge Cleaver, North Vietnam celebrated an "international day of solidarity with the black people of the United States" today.
TUCSON, Ariz., Aug. 18 (UPI) Dr. J. Byron McCormick, former president of the University of Arizona, died yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital here. He was 75 years old.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 18 Heritage seems to be a much faster boat now than she was last month.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 18 Communist forces ambushed a Government food convoy bound for Pnompenh yesterday and made off with "a rather important number of truckloads" of rice, the Cambodian command said today.

A raid by six members of the police auto squad yesterday morning on a Brooklyn auto wrecking yard resulted in the finding of 10 stolen autos and the recovery of $150,000 in auto parts that the police believe were from more than 100 stolen and dismantled cars.

Ward B. Chamberlin Jr., who played a key role in setting up the Corporation for Public Broadcasting, after Congress authorized creation of the body to advance noncommercial radio and television, will become executive vice president of the Educational Broadcasting Corporation, operator of Channel 13.

As the old Liberty ship sinks to the ocean floor off Florida carrying its cargo of 67 tons of nerve gas, one of the most extraordinary stories of human ignorance, arrogance and confused blundering comes to an end. Code-named by the Pentagon as Operation Chase ("cut holes and sink 'em"), it might better have been called Operation Bungle.

Diphtheria, which has reached so-called epidemic proportions in San Antonio, Tex., this week, is a childhood disease that used to kill thousands of American youngsters each year. Now it affects only a few hundred each year and only rarely kills.

BOSTON, Aug. 18 (AP) A Federal judge ruled today that Fidelity Fund, Inc., an investment company with assets exceeding $800-million, did not violate the law in its pre-1969 practice of placing its portfolio brokerage business with stockbrokers who split their commissions with other brokers also selling shares of the fund.
Former Controller Mario A. Procaccino, the unsuccessful Democratic candidate for Mayor of New York last year, assailed Arthur J. Goldberg as a "political hypocrite" yesterday.
NORTH PROVIDENCE, R.I., Aug. 18(AP) Florie DeSimone, father of Attorney General Herbert F. DeSimone, died early today at Zambarano State Hospital. He was 76 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 The head of the draft board in Dubuque, Iowa, came to Washington today to support legislation that, its sponsors say, would do away with the draft.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex. Aug. 18 (AP) The commanding general of Lackland Air Force Base said today that a public information officer who decided a photo should be slashed from 10,000 copies of the base newspaper had been reprimanded.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 18 (UPI) Iraq has placed her 12,000 troops in Jordan at the disposal of the Palestinian guerrilla movement, the Baghdad radio said today, commenting on talks in Baghdad between the guerrilla leader, Yasir Arafat and Iraqi officials.
BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 18 David Holmden of the Niagara Sailing Club was the leader after two races today in the Raven Class national sailing championship.

CANBERRA, Australia, Aug. 18 (Reuters) The Government said today that it would withdraw a battalion of troops from South Vietnam, but would offer Saigon a direct grant of 3.3 million Australian dollars (about $3.6-million) as "defense aid."
DUBLIN, Aug. 18 Two Americans were among four persons killed near here today in a collision between a biplane and a helicopter during filming of a dogfight in the movie "Zeppelin."
MOSCOW, Aug. 18 Two thousand Moscow Jews dem- onstrated last weekend that there still is an audience here for Yiddish theater.
The stock market, feeding on some morsels of good news for a change, bounded ahead yesterday in brisk trading.

An Administration-created haze hangs over the vote the Senate will take today on the Brooke amendment. The White House, in opposing the amendment, is still leaning on the chief argument it used last week to defeat moves to suspend expansion of the Safeguard ABM system beyond its present two Minuteman sites. But that argument has no real pertinency to the Brooke amendment.

No doubt people, like George Christian and Louis Heren, who weathered the direct blasts of Lyndon B. Johnson's personality, will not soon forget him. (Mr. Heren tells the archetypal Johnson story in his description of how the former President once made extensive use of Heren's knee and lower thigh to illustrate a comparison of the Vietcong "to a young man trying to seduce a girl.")
Can an attractive young woman and a computer find happiness in the stock market? In the case of Penny Kaniclides and her Sigma 7 computer, the answer would appear to be a definite "yes."
Firemen were forced to walk up 46 flights of stairs last night to combat a fire in the Astor Plaza building in Times Square.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 Stung by an accusation that they would sponsor the United States' first military defeat, counter-attacking Senators asserted today that Vice President Agnew might be undermining constitutional government.

The Police Department defended itself yesterday against charges by Mayor Lindsay that it had failed to handle properly the violent skirmishes last May between construction workers and students protesting the United States involvement in Cambodia.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 18 (Reuters) Representative Wright Patman, chairman of the House Banking Committee, today called yesterday's announcement by the Federal Reserve Board of a cut in reserve requirements highly misleading concerning its effects on the housing market.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 19 As the Yankees' chartered bus, swaying from side to side, approached Metropolitan Stadium tonight, Ralph Houk turned to no one in particular and asked.

The office of Manhattan District Attorney Frank S. Hogan is investigating charges that "hoodlums" have beaten employes of the New York Playboy Club in a demand for concessions' from the club's management and woman attendants the Playboy bunnies a spokesman for Mr. Hogan said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Federal Power Commission, for the second time in five years, has authorized the Consolidated Edison Company to build a controversial pumped-storage hydroelectric power project at Storm King Mountain on the Hudson River near Cornwall, N.Y.
Mr. and Mrs. David Israel of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Willa Harriet Israel, to Alan Paul Feinbaum, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Feinbaum of Franklin Square, L.I.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The United States today gave the Soviet Union evidence, which it said was "not conclusive," that Egyptian missile batteries moved closer to the Suez Canal after the Middle East truce began Aug. 7. But it did not charge Cairo with a truce violation or request the withdrawal of any missiles.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Justice Department announced today that, subject to certain conditions, it would permit the General Electric Company to go ahead with its plan to sell its computer-manufacturing business to a new company controlled by Honeywell, Inc.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 19 (Reuters) Companies in the European Economic Community are incapable of competing with giant American corporations under present conditions, its executive commission warned today.

The business of Hayden, Stone, Inc., a major brokerage house in financial distress, will be divided between Cogan, Berlind, Weill Levitt, Inc., and Walston Co., Inc., under the terms of an agreement disclosed yesterday.

The Triborough Bridge and Tunnel Authority last night invoked the Taylor Law, which bans strikes by government employes, in an effort to end a wildcat strike by 547 toll collectors at its five bridges and two tunnels in the city.
LIVERPOOL, N.Y., Aug. 19 Governor Rockefeller estimated today that it would cost $4.2billion to rid the state's waterways of municipal and industrial waste.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 19 (AP) The Israeli command said its planes attacked Arab guerrilla bases in Lebanon today. It was the second Israeli incursion into Lebanon reported in as many days and the third in five days.

In the early years of the 21st century, so the historians will claim, there appeared in North America a number of secret radical organizations dedicated to the suppression of women. The most violent of them all was The Florence League. Members of The Florence League never traveled in groups of less than 11, and always wore helmets like those worn by professional football players before that game was banned.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 19 Lonnie McLucas testified today that he had fired a shot into the body of Alex Rackley because he believed him to be already dead and feared ending up "in the same position Rackley was in."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The White House today named John N. Irwin 2d, a prominent New York lawyer and former Assistant Secretary of Defense under the Eisenhower Administration, to be Under Secretary of State.

Short-interest positions change on Aug. 14 were 10.2 earlier, the exchange reported short-interest positions on last Friday amounted to 20,075,218 shares, an increase of 1,855,998 shares from the revised July figure of 18,219,220 shares.
ALBANY, Aug. 19 (UPI) Gas suppliers warned today of higher home heating bills for millions of New Yorkers if the State Public Service Commission ordered a cutback on sales to new customers.
Corn called the tune yesterday in commodity trading, driving futures prices upward in active but orderly trading.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 19 An undisguised protest at sea and a thinly-veiled protest ashore that was overruled enlivened the America's Cup scene today.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 Grandmaster Bent Larsen of Denmark drew his ninth-round game with the New York star and defending champion, Pal Benko, in the United States Open Chess Championship at the Parker House here last night.
SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 19 (AP) Dave Stockton makes his first start as the new Professional Golfers' Association champion tomorrow as one of the favorites in the $160,000 Avco Golf Classic.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 18 The crackle of small arms fired aimlessly into the night, the digging of shelters in the refugee camps and the wary movement of Jordanian troops girding the city all seem to foreshadow another tragic episode in the history of the Palestinians.

CALCUTTA, India, Aug. 19 Kanu Sanyal, the most important leader in West Bengal's Naxalite movement, and 29 other Maoist extremists were arrested today near Siliguri in the Darjeeling district. Arms and ammunition were reported to have been seized.
About 16,000 teen-agers members of the Luther League of the American Lutheran Church opened the first working session of a six-day convention at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

When a client-agency relationship continues uninterruptedly for 50 years, you've got to notice it. And today one of these relationships will be officially noticed at a luncheon in the Hemisphere Club atop the Time and Life Building.

The State Public Service Commission has urged Mayor Lindsay to approve the Consolidated Edison power plant expansion in Astoria. But at the same time the Commissioner of the State Environmental Conservation Department, Henry Diamond, has said that "the proposed plant would seriously jeopardize plans to meet air quality standards."
Mayor Lindsay announced the appointment yesterday of Sidney J. Goldner as director of the Neighborhood Action Program in East Flatbush in Brooklyn.
BONN, Aug. 19 A Soviet vessel believed to be equipped with electronic surveillance gear is lying capsized in the North Sea in the vicinity of maneuvers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

YONKERS, Aug. 19 Most harness racing observers are in agreement that the difference between Columbia George and Most Happy Fella, clearly this season's outstanding 3-year-old pacers, is indeed small. Each colt has the blood line, speed, stamina and gameness that make a champion. In seven meetings this year, Most Happy Fella enjoys a 4-3 advantage over Columbia George.

Imagine the original New York Mets in all their inept splendor, but without the charm, and you'll have a fair impression of how the Mets performed at Shea Stadium yesterday in a 9-4 loss to the Houston Astros.

MELVILLE, L.I., Aug. 19 Mrs. Melvin Smoley of Melville and Dr. Jules Roistacher of New York and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jill Robin Roistacher, to Charles B. Butman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Simon Butman of Lynn, Mass. The wedding is planned for Sept. 5 at the St. Regis-Sheraton in New York.

The trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company were ordered yesterday by Federal Judge John P. Fullam in Philadelphia to affirm their liability for some $1.3-billion of secured equipment obligations trust certificates, conditional sales agreements and leases the railroad has outstanding.
CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Aug. 19 (AP) John Bellanca, an aviation pioneer who began manufacturing airplanes in 1919, died here yesterday after a long illness, at the age of 84.
The Transit Authority announced yesterday that it had suspended a subway motorman for running his southbound IRT local through a red signal just below 103d Street on Tuesday morning.

Governor Rockefeller announced yesterday the appointment of Herbert B. Halberg, former Commissioner of Marine and Aviation in Mayor Lindsay's administration, as special New York City field coordinator for the Governor's bid for re-election.
With different parts of the credit markets moving in different directions, the August reassessment of interest-rate levels continued yesterday in an atmosphere rife with rumors.
YONKERS, Aug. 19 (AP) Harrison Cameron Cornell, an independent radio and television newsman, who made training films for the Navy, died today at a hospital here. He was 52 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Ford Motor Company is recalling 85,000 police cars for correction of a possible safety defect.

"All he wants to do is go yummie yummie at the pretty girls," scolded a plump, sixtyish woman about her grandson. The 12-year-old voyeur grinned. The pretty "girls" lined up in the broiling sun on the Boardwalk at Coney Island yesterday weren't exactly teenagers.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 19 (AP) John Norman Collins was convicted today of first-degree murder in the slaying of Karen Sue Beineman, an 18-year-old freshman at Eastern Michigan University.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 19 The United States' allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, led by West Germany, have been working since spring on a finance-assistance program that would keep United States forces in Europe or at least limit the number of troops withdrawn.

PHILADELPHIA Last year, William and June Noble drove several thousand miles alone in a small Mercedes Benz on a cook-out trip in South America. And only a month ago they returned from a round-trip 7,000-mile camping expedition to Mexico with four children in a Volkswagen bus. They dined, they said, simply but elegantly and well with a minimum of equipment.

Zsa Zsa Gabor, the actress who was robbed at gunpoint of jewels valued at more than $600,000 early yesterday morning, did not appear in yesterday's matinee performance of "Forty Carats" at the Morosco Theatre.
DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 19 Martha Wilkinson of Whittier, Calif., the medalist, won two matches today in the United States women's amateur golf championship at the Wee Burn Country Club.

AUSTIN, Tex., Aug. 19 Responding again to mounting demand for low-priced domestic crude oil, the Texas Railroad Commission today increased the market-demand proration factor for Texas wells in September from 70 to 79.9 per cent of the wells' calculated ability to produce.
ROME, Aug. 19 If everybody in Rome did as the Romans do, there would not be anybody in Rome.

WOODLOWN, Md., Aug. 19 (AP) The chairman of the United States Civil Rights Commission charged today that federal and local governments and the majority of citizens were not serious about equal opportunities for minority groups.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 President Nixon urged the Senate today to approve the 45year-old Geneva protocol banning the first use of chemical and biological weapons in war.
Luis Aparicio and his Chicago White Sox teammates were guilty of overkill yesterday as a record-equaling 11-run ninth inning gave them a 13-5 victory over the Red Sox at Boston.

Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and its subsidiaries, reported yesterday a decline in second-quarter net income to $16,383,000 from $16,692,000 in the like 1969 period ended July 4. Net income for the first six months ended July 4 totaled $30,222,000 and was exactly even with last year's figure.

COLLINGSWOOD, N. J., Aug. 19 With oarsmen from West Germany, Australia, New Zealand and Canada on the scene since yesterday, all appeared in readiness today for the start of the national rowing championships.
ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J., Aug. 19 (AP) The Corn Industrial Division of C.P.C. International, Inc., said today it was immediately raising its corn syrup and starch prices.

The General Dynamics Corporation, the conglomerate with a big but faltering stake in the country's aerospace program, announced yesterday a reorganization of its defense and space operations to "permit a more rapid and effective response to government requirements."

HALKIRK, Scotland Oystercatchers flew low over the river and alighted on a gravel bar below us, plovers wheeled above grazing sheep and cattle in the green fields; a kestrel rode a thermal over a stone-capped hill across the water, and brown trout rose in the pool below us.
BROOKVILLE, I.I., Aug. 19 Fred Dryer thinks the training season is too long. He'd limit it to two weeks of drills and three weeks of exhibitions and then he'd open the gates and start the season.
The Bronx police arrested a 9-year-old boy last night and charged him with beating his 5-year-old playmate into unconsciousness with a bottle during an argument.

HARTFORD, Aug. 19 The Rev. Joseph D. Duffey, the boyish-looking chairman of the Americans for Democratic Action, won a convincing victory tonight in the Democratic primary election for United States Senator from Connecticut.

GREAT NECK, L.I., Aug. 19 Mr. and Mrs. Harold B. Streem have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jane Streem, to Harris Joel Rakov, son of Mrs. Hyman Rakov of New York and the late Mr. Rakov. The wedding is planned for Nov. 21.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 The national outdoor swimming championships for men and women begin tomorrow. The four-day meet may be the best ever and surely will be the most mod.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 19 (AP) Dr. William Campbell Binkley, scholar on Texas history, died here today. He was 81 years old.

LONDON, Aug. 19 Everyone knows, of course, that the United States has had a Vice President for years, but how many of us are aware that England once had a Vice King and might still have one today but for the notoriously short temper of Henry VIII?

The city charged yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company was not trying hard enough to recover for its customers the money the company says it was overcharged over a 10-year period by 13 contractors who admitted rigging their bids on construction work.

A shareholder suit against Fidelity Fund, Inc., which was exonerated Tuesday of improperly conducting portfolio transactions over a three-year period, will be appealed, the head of the plaintiff's law firm disclosed late yesterday.
LONDON, Aug. 19 The Court of Appeal today upheld prison and reformatory sentences for six Cambridge students who took part in a riotous protest in February against the Greek Government.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 19 Executioner of the October House Farm killed the opposition in the Sanford Stakes today. Given a frontrunning ride by Jacinto Vasquez, Executioner scampered to a six-length victory in the sixfurlong sprint, covering the course in the near-record time of 1:09 2-5, and returned $6.60 for $2.
LONDON, Aug. 19 An independent audit has produced figures showing the profits and assets for Pergamon Press in 1968 far below those in the company's audited accounts for that year.

VENICE, Italy, Aug. 19 The 31st International Film Festival, which opened here tonight, is short on celebrities, protest and even entries, and the presentation of three films made especially for Italian television is seen as a sign of the direction in which the underfinanced local industry is heading.
GENEVA, Aug. 19 (AP) In a last-minute change of plans, Bernard Cornfeld said today he hoped to reach a reconciliation with Sir Eric Wyndham White in Geneva instead of New York.

WARSAW, Aug. 19 (UPI) Pawel Jasienica, a writer and historian who was singled out by Premier Wladyslaw Gomulka as an instigator of the Polish student riots in March of 1968, died today, the Polish press agency said. He was 61 years old.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Aug. 19 The South African Government loosened its apartheid rules slightly today to allow members of the Chinese community of Port Elizabeth to continue to share sports facilities and attend places of entertainment reserved for whites.
New York City had to pay more than twice as much for temporary borrowing last year than ever before, Controller Abraham D. Beame said yesterday.
HARTFORD, Aug. 19 The Rev. Joseph Daniel Duffey, who won the Democratic primary for the United States Senate tonight, was thought of as the "peace candidate" when he started campaigning last fall.

Sales and earnings of Bendix Corporation will be down substantially for the fiscal year ending Sept. 30, according to a proxy statement mailed to stockholders announcing a special meeting for voting on a proposed merger with American Forest Products Corporation.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 19 Informants close to the throne said today that King Hussein had begun a campaign to calm irate commando leaders while trying to persuade their followers to accept an eventual peaceful settlement of the ArabIsraeli dispute.

Two years after the invasion that ended Czechoslovakia's sovereignty, the Kafkaesque situation in which Czechs and Slovaks alike now find themselves is grimly summarized in the Prague "joke" that theirs is the most neutral country in the world: It does not even intervene in its own internal affairs.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange were firm yesterday, although they finished below the day's best levels.
The American Stock Exchange made its second consecutive advance yesterday as advances outnumbered declines by a narrow margin in slow trading.

In the old days, back around 1968, news of a merger proposal where there was a fairly wide differential in the prices of the stocks involved was bound to produce all kinds of fireworks on Wall Street.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Aug. 19 Miss Elizabeth Ann Gamble plans to be married Sept. 4 in St. Louis to Terry Thomas O'Connor, a special agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, from which his father, Carl O'Connor of St. Louis, Mo., retired as a special agent after 20 years of service. The future bride's father, Joseph H. Gamble, is an F.B.I. special agent in charge of the Internal Security Division in New York.

ROSELLE PARK, N.J., Aug. 19 Clifford C. Knerr, treasurer of the Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers, who spent some 50 years in shipbuilding and ship repair, died yesterday in Rahway Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 402 Locust Street.
An idyllic stretch of the Volga River, rich in historical and cultural associations, is threatened with pollution by a proposed oil refinery, according to a Soviet newspaper received here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Attorney General John N. Mitchell said today that shifting school desegregation decisions had made "yo-yo's" out of some students in the South, and he expressed the hope that the Supreme Court would not impose "racial balance" requirements during the coming school year.

The boarded-up stores on 207th Street east of Broadway, forlorn as the tattered campaign posters and fading graffiti on their fronts, give mute testimony to how some neighborhood merchants have found it difficult to hang on in the face of population shifts and competition from the big shopping centers.

Promoters of the canceled Powder Ridge Rock Festival, who announced Tuesday that they would present a new concert in Washington on Aug. 25, learned yesterday that they have been denied use of the Robert F. Kennedy Stadium there.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 19 Bob Carmichael of Australia, seeded second, gained the quarterfinal round of the 71st Pennsylvania tennis championship by defeating left-handed Joaquin Loyo Mayo, of the Mexican Davis Cup team, 6 7, 6 3, 6 4, before a near capacity crowd today on the Merion Cricket Club grass courts.

CHESHIRE, Conn., Aug. 19 An October wedding is planned here by Miss Louise Dorsey Hemingway and Francis Harbert Statton, who is in charge of advertising and public relations for the General American Development Corporation, a land development company is San Francisco.

LAS VEGAS, Aug. 19 A new small Comet, a dressedup version of the Ford Motor Company's successful Maverick, will be sold by Ford's Lincoln-Mercury dealers for 1971. The car will be in dealer showrooms on Sept. 11.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Nixon Administration plans to renew pressure on Congress to produce some action on its dormant proposal to share Federal tax revenue with the states.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Aug. 19 Mr. and Mrs. John Erwin Steinback have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Whelan Steinback, to Robert Henry Hodge Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Hodge of Kansas City, Mo. An October wedding is planned.

The president of the Newspaper Deliverers Union announced a few minutes after midnight last night that the union and the city's four major newspapers had reached agreement in principle and that a threatened strike had been averted.
MIAMI, Aug. 19 Premier Fidel Castro has appointed Capt. Serafin Fernandez Roddiguez as Cuba's Domestic Trade Minister, normally a civilian post.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 19 (UPI) Arthur Ashe, Bob Lutz, Cliff Richey and Stan Smith will make up the United States Davis Cup team that will face the team from West Germany here Aug. 29 to 31.

Eugene O'Neill's early sea plays, three of which are being revived by the Masterworks Laboratory Theater under the title "Three Plays of the Sea," are autobiographical, but not, like his last plays, subjectively autobiographical.

A State Supreme Court justice ordered George F. McGrath, City Commissioner of Correction, to appear in his court if prisoners in two of the city's houses of detention continue their court boycott, which went into its third day yesterday.
Customs agents seized more than $1-million worth of LSD yesterday and arrested a 26year-old Manhattan man who they said was a "key figure" in the smuggling of illegal hallucinogenic drugs.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP) The Attorney General's office and a consumers group from New York City asked the State Agriculture Department today to outlaw the use of such fanciful names as London broil and California roast on meat cuts sold in stores.
CENTRAL ISLIP, L.I., Thursday, Aug. 20 The predominantly black Carleton Park section of this mid-island community held a tenuous grip on calm yesterday following a night of gunfire across barricades.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 19 Public approval of President Nixon's performance has slipped to the level recorded in mid-June, prior to the withdrawal of United States troops from Cambodia, the Gallup Poll reported today.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 19 San Antonio's diphtheria epidemic, which has hit hardest in a Mexican-American residential area, may not be completely checked until next spring, health officials said today.
