BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 19 Bill Pagels finished first and third today and took over the lead in a series to determine the Raven Class national champion. The skipper from Sayville, L.I., who is the defending titleholder, leads Robert Kirtland of Port Washington, L.I., by 2 points.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 19 (UPI) State and Federal inspectors checked 15 charter buses on the New Jersey Turnpike last week and found 10 of them to have safety defects.
ALBANY, Aug. 19 (AP) The State Health Department ordered today the chlorination of all public water supply systems in the state that use ground water as their source.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Aug. 19 (AP) A jetliner bound for San Juan was hijacked today to Cuba by three men two brandishing hand grenades and one armed with a gun passengers said when they arrived here after a 14-hour flight by way of Havana.

NEWARK, Aug. 19 The assistant cashier of a bank that last week purchased a branch office of the insolvent Eatontown National Bank was arrested today and charged with the misapplication of $125,000 of his bank's funds.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 19 Linda Kasabian, in her 18th day on the witness stand, completed her testimony here today by professing still to love Charles M. Manson "as I do all mankind."
The New York and American Stock Exchanges have issued their reports on changes in stockholdings by major stockholders, directors and officers of listed corporations. The lists include the following:

YONKERS, August 19 A driver for the Club Transit, Inc., bus lines was repeatedly stabbed tonight, the police said, by a passenger who became enraged when the driver of the exact-fare bus refused to change a quarter for him.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 19 Kent Foster of Cincinnati held a 4 -point lead for the 25th anniversary. Thistle Class national championship today after four races had been completed in the week-long regatta being sailed on Long Island Sound off Cedar Point Yacht Club. Two races remain in the series.

BOSTON, Aug. 19 A team of five players who are prominent in New York tournaments captured the Spingold knockout team title in the American Contract Bridge league's summer nationals at the Boston Sheraton Hotel early today. They did it by defeating the world champion Dallas Aces.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J. Aug. 19 Parents, businessmen and community workers shaken by the death of a star high school basketball player here this week, apparently from an acute heroin reaction met today with the administrator of Englewood Hospital to ask for beds there for the treatment of addicts.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 19 Longhairs won a victory here today when the American Federation of Teachers voted at its national convention to support a student's choice of his own "dress and grooming."

KENT, Ohio, Aug. 19 The elders talked of a minority of troublemakers, of better communications, of non-lethal weaponry and of the problems of large universities as the President's Commission on Campus Unrest opened hearings here today, and the young spoke of guns and death.
MOSCOW, Aug. 19 The Soviet Union's East European allies arrived here today for a summit meeting of the Warsaw Pact, the Soviet bloc's defense alliance.

LONDON, Aug. 19 Shortly after a group of mentally retarded women gave birth, their infant children were given intensive training programs at the University of Wisconsin. By the age of 3, the children began to read and learn arithmetic.

A Mozart work for two pianos that in all likelihood has not been played here before turned up in the Tuesday night program of the Mostly Mozart Festival at Philharmonic Hall. It was a Larghetto and Allegro in E flat, rediscovered by Gerhard Croll and published in 1964.

Dr. Julie Meyer Frank, emeritus associate professor of sociology and economics at the New School's Graduate Faculty of Political and Social Science, died Tuesday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. She was 73 years old and lived at 80 Seaman Avenue.
Stuyvesant Town has asked the city for permission to raise rents by more than half to $56.61 a room.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) Following is the 53-45 rollcall vote by which the Senate rejected today an amendment by Senator Edward W. Brooke. Republican of Massachusetts, to limit expansion of the Safeguard antiballistic-missile system:
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 19 Arthur J. Goldberg urged the state today to ban commercial fishing in lakes and streams "that are consistently above dangerous levels of mercury contamination."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) The Rev. Dr. Frederick Brown Harris, who served for 24 years, a record, as chaplain of the Senate, died yesterday. He was 87 years old.

The-Metropolitan Museum, which seems to be finding more and more ways of extending its hospitality to the performing arts, provided a marvelous setting Tuesday night for a splendid concert of sacred and secular music by the Berkshire Boy Choir. The concert was given in the Medieval Sculpture Hall, with the chorus of boys and men ranged on risers placed in front of the magnificent Spanish choir screen installed in the hall several years ago.

SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 16 Music and "The Sound of Music" dominate Salzburg, and Mozart and Julie Andrews, to say nothing of Herbert von Karajan, are its deities. The visitor to Salzburg will never fail to be reminded of Mozart.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) The Government filed suits against New Hampshire and North Carolina in lower Federal courts today to provide a further test of the constitutionality of a law extending the right to vote to 18-yearolds.
OSSINING, N.Y., Aug. 19 Ferdie Catropa, a 17-year-old senior at Notre Dame High School of Bridegport, Conn., won the Westchester Golf Association's 47th annual junior championship today.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 19 The first death sentences against Arab guerrillas were imposed by an Israeli military court in Nablus this morning, but a few hours later the military governor commuted the sentences to life imprisonment.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Senator Charles E. Goodell opened a drive today to show New York Republicans that he is not a party renegade.
SYDNEY, Australia, Aug. 19 The first Australian to head a major automobile manufacturing company in this country has been appointed by the Ford Motor Company.
PORT HARCOURT, Nigeria, Aug. 14 Joseph, a 34-yearold Ibo, finally summoned sufficient courage the other day to return to Port Harcourt, where he had worked as a welder before the Nigerian civil war.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Commerce Department, in a new midyear assessment of the economy, forecast today a "renewed upswing" in the rest of 1970 and in 1971.

Anna E. Lawson, who retired in 1951 as principal of the former Julia Ward Howe Junior High School for Girls, 212 West 120th Street, died Monday in Skaneateles, N.Y., where she lived. She would have been 89 years old Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) The Government began today its first enforcement action against a contractor for failing to comply with the socalled Philadelphia Plan aimed at training Negroes and other minority workers for construction jobs.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Thursday, (UPI) Aug. 20 A military spokesman said that a force estimated at 3,000 North Vietnamese regulars launched a heavy attack early today against the outer defenses of Pnompenh. He said casualties had been heavy on both sides.

A sequel to one of the most bizarre courtroom episodes ever enacted will begin Monday in South Africa. Twenty Africans, five of them women, will go on trial in Pretoria, charged with terrorist activities aimed at overthrowing the white minority Government.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug. 19 (AP) The Monmouth County Board of Freeholders said yesterday that it would not allow citizens to speak at its public meetings if they did not take part in flag ceremonies at the beginning of each session.

A story made no less disquieting by its dreary familiarity is unfolding in the legislative hearings on the Tombs. The inquiry by State Senator John R. Dunne into conditions in the troubled Manhattan House of Detention has exposed far more than custodial brutality and terrible overcrowding.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (UPI) Masked and unidentified to insure anonymity before television cameras, former servicemen testified today of neartragedy resulting from the use of marijuana and other drugs in the United States, Vietnam and Korea.
PAWLING, N.Y., Aug. 19 (UPI) A flying instructor and student were killed yesterday when their trainer plane plummeted to earth near the Connecticut state line here.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The World Bank reported today record lending activity and record earnings in the fiscal year ended last June 30.

The case of the first West Point cadet who has ever sought to be discharged from the Army as a conscientious objector was argued in Federal Court yesterday, and Judge Marvin E. Frankel told authorities not to move to dismiss him from the United States Military Academy while he considers the case.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 19 Coach Weeb Ewbank made it clear today that just because Joe Namath has finally joined the Jets, fans who have paid $7 a ticket to see the Jets play the Giants in Yale Bowl Sunday should count it a "bonus" if they see Namath in action.
The dilapidated frame house by the junkyard in East Flatbush is as swaybacked as Barney Google's horse and even older, and it has had many a near miss with the bulldozer.

WASHINGTON, Aug.19 The new blue car cruising in northwest Washington carried no printed legend but had seven large red lights on its roof, an extra radio antenna and a special license plate. Inside were two officers wearing sunglasses and with gold braid on the right shoulder of their white shirts. I
The Brittany is a dog of paradoxes. He's a spaniel, but looks like a small setter. He's the only member of the spaniel family that doesn't flush his game he points it.

To New Yorkers, William Zeckendorf, his sudden fall from financial grace notwithstanding, will always be Mr. Real Estate. He was supersalesman, faster than a speeding foreclosure, borrowing millions with a simple handshake, able to leap from sale to leaseback and back again.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Aug. 19 Three organizations that are aiding migratory farm workers in southern New Jersey urged Gov. William T. Cahill today to end what they said was apathy by the state toward the "miserable destiny" of the laborers.

Representatives of five candidates for Governor and the United States Senate met yesterday to discuss a voluntary limitation on radio and television campaign spending, but Governor Rockefeller's campaign manager, R. Burdell Bixby, refused to attend.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 19 (AP) A rally of 1,000 persons in Civic Center today to support Angela Davis, the black militant, and defendants in two other murder cases led to clashes of demonstrators and the police.

The House Ways and Means Committee has formally approved, by a vote of 17 to 7, a trade bill that would impose import quotas on textiles, shoes, oil and, in all probability, a long list of other products. If adopted and signed, this bill would represent a giant step back to protectionism for the United States.

SINGAPORE, Aug. 19 Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew canceled an official visit to Malaysia two hours before his scheduled departure today because of a controversy over police treatment of three long-haired Malaysian youths.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Dr. Lee A. DuBridge resigned today as science adviser to President Nixon and was replaced by a computer specialist 23 years his junior, Dr. Edward E. David Jr. of Sum mit, N.J. Dr. DuBridge, who is 68 years old, told a news conference at the White House that he wanted to retire because "for a long time I've had a horror of remaining in any job beyond reasonable retirement age."
One of the most instructive games of the recent Buenos Aires International, won by Bobby Fischer, the United States ace, was the Petroff Defense, Fischer against Florin Gheorghiu of Rumania.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (Reuters) Navy tests indicate that the dumping of 418 vaults of nerve gas in the Atlantic apparently caused no widespread contamination in the area, Defense Department officials said today.
Les Ballets Africains, Guinea's national folk ensemble, which has paid several visits to this country since 1959, came back to town last night at the City Center.

BUFFALO, Aug. 19 The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People announced today that it planned to file a suit to stop all state and Federal construction in the Buffalo area until alleged racial discrimination was eliminated from the building trades here.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 19 (UPI) Marine Warrant Officer Robert L. Goller of Keyser, W. Va., continued his torrid shooting today and took a six-point lead in the national high power rifle championships.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 A subcommittee of Congress's Joint Economic Committee said today that the supersonic transport should be shelved because of hidden cost burdens to both the Government and consumers and because of imponderable hazards to the environment.
If you have bills to pay, you probably do as most people do: you let them pile up until the middle or the end of the month.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 19 Israel made public tonight photographs of what was described as an Egyptian missile build-up on the western bank of the Suez Canal that started a few hours before the Middle Eastern ceasefire and military standstill.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Hadassah, the women's Zionist organization of America, today adopted a 1970 71 budget of $12.5-million for the support of its social service and medical institutions in Israel and for programs in this country.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., Aug. 19 (UPI) Britain's second Skynet military communications satellite rode an American rocket into an accurate orbit today.

STORRS, Conn., Aug. 18 Hundreds of puppets from three continents have gathered here this week at the University of Connecticut for what the university office described as "a rather unlikely event" an international congress of puppets.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 (AP) Worldwide shortages and skyrocketing prices for fuel oil have hit American utility companies so hard that the result could be across-the-board utility rate increases for the... utility rate increases for the nation's consumers, a high Nixon Administration official has said.

On his experience in both diplomacy and administration, John N. Irwin 2d is well qualified to be Under Secretary of State, one of the most challenging secondlevel jobs in Washington. As Assistant Secretary of Defense in the Eisenhower Administration, he was deeply involved in international negotiation on military alliances, arms control and disarmament.

On a typical night about 10 years ago, Dr. Thomas William Matthew, then director of the department of neurosurgery at the Coney Island Hospital, was racing to the hospital from his home in Harlem to perform an emergency operation.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Internal Revenue Service announced today that 11 white private schools in Mississippi were being removed from a list of those eligible to receive taxdeductible contributions.

With a view to receiving the advice and consent of the Senate to ratification, I transmit herewith the protocol for the prohibition of the use in war of asphyxiating, poisonous or other gases, and of bacteriological methods of warfare, Signed at Geneva June 17, 1925. I transmit also the report by the Secretary of State which sets forth the understandings and the proposed reservation of the United States with respect to the protocol.

Mrs. Joseph Kopechne, mother of the girl killed in an auto accident with Senator Edward M. Kennedy, said yesterday that the conclusion of Judge James A. Boyle that Mr. Kennedy had not told the whole truth left "a bad taste in our mouths, and we absolutely reject it." Judge Boyle presided at the inquest.

Leading officials of the Men's House of Detention in Manhattan expressed strong endorsement yesterday of the grievances being pressed by inmates, adding details of their own but denying there was widespread brutality by guards.
The stock market, fueled by the oil group, advanced yesterday for the second session in a row. Prior to its current upswing, the market had declined in five of the last six trading days.
Whitney M. Young Jr., executive director of the National Urban League, yesterday called the record of the Nixon Administration uneven, indecisive and flabby.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 19 (UPI) The police shot and killed a Negro today and arrested 19 persons on riot charges, capping four nights of racial violence that has spread to four South Florida cities.

Flying Tiger Line, Inc., announced yesterday that, as a result of its recent tender offer to acquire 700,000 shares of the common stock of the North American Car Corporation it now owned 45 per cent of the railroad-car leasing company's 3,238,000 outstanding common shares.

ALBANY, Aug. 19 Governor Rockefeller and Representative Richard L. Ottinger, the Democratic candidate for the Senate, were apparently assured second lines on the ballot today when independent parties filed petitions on their behalf.
FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 19 (AP) The Army announced today it was dropping charges against S. Sgt. Kenneth L. Hodges, one of 12 men charged in the killings at Songmy.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 19 Allied officials here say that South Vietnamese ground forces have made a surprisingly good showing in their current offensive against North Vietnamese base areas in the country's northernmost provinces.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 Despite misgivings, the Consumer Federation of America will neither endorse nor oppose President Nixon's choice of Miles W. Kirkpatrick for the chairmanship of the Federal Trade Commission.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19 The Senate today defeated by 53 to 45 the third and apparently final challenge this year to the Administration-sponsored Safeguard antiballistic-missile system.

Roy Jefferson, one of they best pass receivers in football, was traded by the Pittsburgh Steelers yesterday to the Baltimore Colts for Willie Richardson and a high future draft choice. Richardson also is a wide receiver.
Newspapers deliverers and stereotypers reached tentative agreements yesterday on new contracts with newspaper publishers here.

President Nixon deserves two cheers at most for finally sending to the Senate his request for approval of the Geneva Protocol of 1925, which seeks to ban chemical and biological warfare. It is bad enough that nine months of intramural wrangling followed the original announcement of the Administration's intention at the United Nations last November.

President Nixon has gone well outside the main channel of the American scientific establishment in selecting Dr. Edward E. David Jr. to succeed Dr. Lee A. DuBridge as the President's science adviser. Dr. DuBridge is one of the most prestigious elder statesmen of American science; Dr. David, an electrical engineer for the Bell Telephone Laboratories, is so little known outside his specialized field that he is not even included in Who's Who.

To nobody's surprise, the Federal Power Commission, which in 1965 approved Consolidated Edison's proposed electric power plant at Storm King Mountain, has reviewed its work and found it good. The commission's primary function, after all, is to license the production of power; its interest in the environmental aspects of the project was largely the product of a United States Court of Appeals decision setting aside the original license and ordering further consideration.
PEKING, Aug. 20 The news was all over town the Chinese table-tennis team trounced the North Koreans, who are considered the No. 2 power in world table tennis.

ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 20 (AP) Thomas W. Rearden's Bubble Case took the lead at the start and went on to score an upset today in the Kislak Purse at Atlantic City Race Course, defeating six fillies in a six-furlong allowance race.

Jaroslav Drobny, a former Czechoslovak Wimbledon winner who now lives in London, helped Britain take a 2-0 lead over Mexico in the international senior tennis team eliminations for the Stevens Cup at the West Side Tennis Club in Forest Hills, Queens, yesterday.

Dr. Natalie Joffe Moir, anthropologist and lecturer at the New York University School of Continuing Education, died Wednesday of a liver ailment at Knickerbocker Hospital. She was 55 years old and lived at 209 West 104th Street.
Four youths were arrested yesterday morning on charges of invading a Board of Education vocational center in Brooklyn, smashing equipment and throwing bricks at teachers and students there.
A Harlem playground received an old jet plane yesterday from the Air Force.

New York is in danger of losing "millions of dollars" in state and Federal aid because census takers seem to be missing many city residents, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday. "My guess is we are going to be seriously undercounted in New York," the Mayor said during a City Hall news conference.

When Ghana returned to parliamentary democracy last September, cynics thought they detected in the creation of a Presidential Commission a vehicle for dominating the civilian Government or even for future reimposition of army-police rule. The Commission was composed of two Army officers and the head of the National Police. It was to function for three years in place of a President, unless the National Assembly decided otherwise.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 The Senate voted today to bar the United States from paying larger allowances to allied troops in Vietnam than it pays to American soldiers.

United States Attorney Whitney North Seymour Jr., who has expanded his staff to record size and is worried about the security of his office in a time of bomb scares and threats of violence, is spending $131,000 to refurbish the office and close it off from the general public.

Dr. Josef S. Smul, an Internist for 59 years here until his retirement last March and a specialist in gastroenterology, died of a heart attack in Ellenville, N. Y., Wednesday, while on vacation. His age was 88.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary announced yesterday that police protection for foreign government interests here would be cut nearly in half, starting at midnight tonight.

An assortment of difficulties headed by a water-main break that caused a five-and-a-halfhour disruption of service on the BMT Canarsie line, plagued the subway and commuter railroad lines here yesterday.

Life was simple, money wasn't so tight and taxes didn't take as big a bite in 1916 when Nathan Handwerker opened his first food stand in Coney Island and underpriced his competition 50 per cent by offering a 5cent hot dog.
Gyrations in grain futures continued at a frenetic pace on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.
A 36-year-old woman corrections officer was shot and seriously wounded with her own revolver early yesterday during a struggle with a mugger in the foyer of her apartment building.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 20 Vice President Agnew made a personal attack tonight on Lawrence F. O'Brien, the Democratic National chairman, in making an argument that the Democratic party would spend the nation into bankruptcy and socialism.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 20 Martha Wilkinson, a 21-yearold player from Whittier, Calif., ed three other Curbs Cup teammates into the semifinal round today of the 70th annual United States Golf Association women's amateur championship.

The New York State Conservation Council, whose affiliated organizations have more than 350,000 members, objected yesterday to the attempt by two Democratic candidates for statewide office to get a second line on the ballot under the name of the Conservation party.
HIGHLAND PARK, Ill., Aug. 20 (AP) Lester G. Porter, president of Borg-Warner Corporation from 1961 until he retired in 1968, collapsed and died yesterday while playing golf. He was 67 years old.

LEE, Mass., Aug. 20 Barely more than a year old, the Dance (Theater of Harlem, founded and directed by Arthur Mitchell of the New York City Ballet, revealed itself this week at the Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival here as one of dance's most promising ventures.
Rezoning to prevent contruction of skyscraper apartaents on many side streets on he Upper East Side was approved 18 to 4 by the Board of estimate yesterday.

BINGHAMTON, Aug. 20 A preferential ballot, in which a voter lists candidates in the order of his choice rather than simply checking the one he likes the most, was urged today for New York elections on behalf of Mayor Lindsay.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 20 Mrs. Judith Anne Goldhill Heller, a landscape architect, was killed in an auto accident here yesterday. She was 42 years old and lived at 151 Central Park West, New York, and in East Hampton.

The headquarters office of Hayden, Stone, Inc., a throwback to another era in Manhattan's financial district, will be abandoned as a result of the brokerage concern's consolidation with Cogan, Berlind, Weill Levitt.

A Staten Island savings and loan association has moved to convert its charter to that of a savings bank, becoming the first to take advantage of legislation effective in July, 1969, permitting such a move.

The postal strike is having its expected carryover in moves by unions in other Federal agencies to drop strike prohibitions from their constitutions. The American Federation of Government Employes, representing more than'a half-million Federal workers, is the latest dropper of the ban.

Directors of the Loctite Corporation approved yesterday in principle the acquisition of assets of International Sealants, S. A., Panama, including its five operating subsidiaries, for about $21.2-million in stock and cash.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Aug. 20 (UPI)--Rod Laver defeated Roger Taylor, 6-4, 7-5, tonight in a first-round singles match of the $22,500 Colonial National invitation tennis tournament.
By a one-point margin, John Newcombe leads Rod Layer, his fellow Australian, in the race for the Martini Rossi tennis player of the year award.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 20 The magistrate sat in the shade of an ancient tree, his shirt and shoes off for comfort. The police superintendent sat with him, as did several other Government officials all waiting in the heavy silence of the scorching afternoon.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Aug. 20 The Suffolk County Lebisla ture is expected to pass a law barring the sale of certain detergents within the county because of potential danger to the water supply, the chairmen of two legislative committees said today.
LONDON, Aug. 20 British Overseas Airways Corporation, the profitable, state-owned airline, served notice today that it wanted a larger share of the lucrative North Atlantic business.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Aug. 20 Dr. Eric M. Matsner, an obstetrician and gynecologist who was active in birthcontrol organizations, died o a heart ailment yesterday ink a hospital here. He was 73 years old and moved recently from Santa Monica.

PARIS, Aug. 20 After attending two sessions of what he called a renewed effort to reach a Vietnam settlement, David K. E. Bruce, the new chief American negotiator at the peace talks here, stayed away today from the 80th plenary meeting.

LUXEMBOURG, Aug. 20 (AP) -The Luxembourg Commercial Court declared bankrupt yesterday Four Seasons Overseas, N.V., the financing subsidiary of Four Seasons Nursing Centers of America, Inc, which has filed a bankruptcy reorganization petition in the United States.

WATCH HILL, R.I., Aug. 20 Miss Wendel Gilbert Browne was married in the Watch Hill Chapel this afternoon to Donald Havens Jr., a partner in the New York real estate firm of Havens, Baxter Associates. Thirty-five guests attended the Episcopal ceremony performed by the Rev. Alexander Ogilvy and the reception that followed at Channel Mark, summer home here of Mrs. Gilbert Goodwin Browne, mother of the bride.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Aug. 20 Mrs. Ogden Phipps made a return to the winner's circle today after the running of the Saratoga Steeplechase Handicap. Her 6-year-old, Top Bid, won the $18,100 feature went on the card, an achievement that was appreciated by the players who backed the favorites in the crowd of 15,458.

YAWGOO VALLEY, R. I., Aug. 20 Reorganization of naval forces in the Atlantic Fleet has jammed more sailors and their families into southern Rhode Island than the area can house and many wives and children are paying the price.
The Bronx Zoo has carried out a face-lifting job on the Palisades in New Jersey to help reproduce a habitat for birds

LONDON, Aug. 20 Princess Margaret celebrates her 40th birthday tomorrow, a moody woman struggling to intertwine the traditions of monarchy with the ebullient style of upper-class Britain.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Aug. 20 Secretary General Thant opened a conference of international educators here today and asked them to establish among their students "a new allegiance" to the international community as a whole.

NEW HAVEN, Aug 20 Lonnie McLucas conceded under cross-examination today that he had believed himself to be carrying out orders authorized by the Black Panther party on the night Alex Rackley was murdered.

State Senator Roy M. Goodman charged yesterday that he had found "a chamber of horrors involving scandalous neglect, lax code enforcement and questionable financial accounting practices" in 18 proprietary nursing homes here.

The Great Hall on Ellis Island will be refurbished and turned into a massive monument to the 16 million immigrants who passed through there, Dr. Thomas W. Matthew, president of the National Economic Growth and Reconstruction Organization, announced yesterday.
BERKELEY, Calif., Aug. 20 Ronald T. Tsukamoto, a Japanese-American rookie on the Berkeley police force, was shot dead by an unknown gunman this morning as he wrote out a traffic ticket.

COLLINGSWOOD, N. J., Aug. 20-Eight determined oarsmen who have been working out of the Vesper Boat Club of Philadelphia for the last six weeks and Jim Dietz, the New York Athletic Club star with the build of a basketball player, shared opening honors at the national rowing championships today.

The Public Service Electric and Gas Company announced plans yesterady to raise more than $70-million with the sale of 3,270,422 additional common shares ho stockholders. The Newark utility plans to offer stock to holders on record as of Sept. 16 on a 1-for-10 basis.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 20-The Yankees won their final game in Minnesota this season, 4-3, tonight, but Fritz Peterson suffered for the second night in a row.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 20 (AP)-William H. Moore, the new president and chief executive officer of the Penn Central Transportation Company, gained court approval today for a five-year contract that will pay him $165,000 annually to run the United States' biggest railroad.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Miles W. Kirkpatrick, President Nixon's nominee to be chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, said today that both he and the commission itself were "dedicated to the consumer interest" and that, therefore, he saw no need for creating a special consumer counsel within the agency.
GENEVA. Aug. 20 Iceland suggested today an international conference to draw up a treaty preventing pollution of the marine environment.

Two television cameramen were injured slightly yesterday in a brawl between union and nonunion camera crews in the offices of Correction Commissinner George F. McGrath in the Criminal Courts Building, 100 Centre Street.

The Cincinnati Reds, the meanest hitters in baseball, will open a four-game series in Shea Stadium tonight against the Mets, who are in no mood these days for Big Red Machines, little green machines or any machine that has hit 165 home runs in 125 games.

WEST CALDWELL, N. J., Aug. 20 Miss Virginia Beth Puder, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Puder of South Orange, was married here this evening to Michael D. Harris of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harris of Buffalo. Rabbis Eli E. Pilchik and Barry H. Greene performed the ceremony at the Mountain Ridge Country Club.
The two-day advance on the American Stock Exchange ended yesterday as prices finished mixed in very quiet trading.
ST. PAUL, Aug. 20 (AP) William Hamm Jr., a brewery executive who was once held for $100,000 ransom by the Karpis-Barker gang, died today. He was 87 Years old.

In his first specific proposals for televised debates, James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for United States Senator, said yesterday that he would seek a series of statewide forums, rather than regional ones, to prevent candidates from tailoring their views by geographic area.

BONN, Aug. 20 Authorities of the Roman Catholic Church and the Evangelical Church said in a statement today that increasing numbers of people were withdrawing from they churches following the Federal Government's introduction of a 10 per cent surcharge on income taxes last month.

YONKERS, Aug. 20 At 7:15 o'clock tomorrow night, 10 sophomores will go postward in the $26,660 Bronx Filly Pace at Yonkers Raceway. It will be a one-mile event on which there will be no wagering mainly because of a fourply entry involving the stables of Billy Haughton and Del Cameron.

"The Unembarrassed Muse," a survey of the popular arts in America, is the first volume of Dial Press's ambitious bicentennial history of America. Its author, Russel Nye, professor of English at Michigan State University, is a prodigious scavenger of the trivial past. Reading his book is like spending an afternoon in a country antique store.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 A series of armed forces surveys presented to Congress today shows that about three out of 10 servicemen interviewed have used marijuana or other drugs.

BABYLON, L.L, Aug. 20 Bill Pagels of the Wet Pants Association captured his second national sailing championship within a week and won his second straight Raven Class series crown today. Pagels was the winner of the Blue Jay Class nationals last weekend.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20--A Senate subcommitte has approved an air pollution bill that would halt sales of new cars on Jan. 1, 1975, if they did not eliminate 90 per cent of the exhaust contaminants allowed in 1970 cars.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug. 20 Eric Patterson, farm superintendent and associate professor of agriculture at the State University in Farmingdale, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home on the campus here. He was 69 years old.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 20-Jamie McCreary of the Larchmont Yacht Club, with three victories in the five-race championship division, was awarded the Long Island Sound Junior Yacht Racing Association midget sailing crown today.

A Federal air pollution scientist said last night that the increase in just one noxious gas from the proposed addition to Consolidated Edison's plant in Astoria, Queens, would result in an increase in respiratory disease that he estimated would cost society $250,000 to $750,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Freight traffic on United States railroads arid intercity truck tonnage in the week ended Aug. 15 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Secretary of the Treasury David M. Kennedy conceded officially today what was already generally known that the deficit in the Federal Budget in the current fiscal year would be probably larger than the latest official estimate of $1.3-billion, made in May.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Aug. 20 After five nights of racial disorder, the white people in this sunny city are beginning to worry about its causes as well as its effects.

PINK HILL, N. C., Aug. 19 After he planted his nine acres of tobacco this spring, Clarence Lee Boyette came to a store here to buy pesticides. He wanted something to kill the worms that can riddle tobacco leaves something like DDT, which he had used for more years than he could recollect.
Governor Rockefeiler announced two appointments yesterday to fill a Supreme Court vacancy and the other to fill the new position of executive assistant to the Governor.

TOULON, France, Aug. 20 (AP) A French submarine and a South African submarine collided on the surface tonight off Toulon in the Mediterranean. Four sailors were killed on the French vessel, the French Navy said. Two seamen were reported missing.
SAIGON South Vietnam, Aug. 20 (Reuters) President Nguyen Van Thieu announced a shakeup tonight in the South Vietnamese military high command.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 20--Senator Joseph D. Tydings of Maryland, a young, liberal Democrat with a reputation as a tough former prosecutor of errant Congressmen and as a crusader for public disclosure of elected officials' financial date, has been accused by Life magazine of failing to meet his own standards of ethical conduct in managing his personal fortune.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Aug. 20 -Zambia, which has a gross national product of about $1-billion and is hard pressed for funds, is spending more than $14-million to build a hall and other facilities for a five-day conference of members of the so-called third, world bloc.

Stokes Jr. of Lenox, Mass. The Rev. Jerome Kaufman, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Passavant Memorial Hospital here.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20 Liberal Senators of both parties proposed changes today in President Nixon's welfare reform program, still firmly lodged in the Senate Finance Committee.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., Aug. 20--Inflation and government demands for safety and pollution equipment could drive up the price of Detroit's new minicars by 35 to 50 per cent in only five years, Lee Iacocca, a president of the Ford Motor Company, warned today.

SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 20 Dan Sikes enjoyed the change in weather as the pro golf tour moved into New England today. YORK, England, Aug. 20 (AP)--American-owned Mill Reef scored a 10-length victory today in the six-furlong Gimcrack Stakes for 2-year-olds, a race first run in 1846.
"The best yield of real-estate tax levies in four years" 95.8 per cent of the total amount due-was collected by New York City last year, Finance Administrator Richard Lewisohn said yesterday.

One of the most interesting symbols of America today is Joe Namath, the quarterback of the New York football Jets. Joe is not only in tune with the rebellious attitude of the young, but he doubles it. He defies both the people who hate play-boys and the people who hate bully-boys. He is something special: a long-haired hard-hat, the anti-hero of the sports world.

RAISING alpines to perfection is something of an art and no one has a surer hand with these choice (if demanding) plants than Eleanor Brinckerhoff. Her Georgetown, Conn. rock garden has become a mecca for alpine enthusiasts who come to see...

A daughter was born to Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Tsai Jr. of New York and Greenwich, Conn., on July 24 at the Harkness Pavilion. Mrs. Tsai is the former Miss Marlyn Chase. Her husband is president of the Tsai Management Research Corporation. The child has been named Veronica Lee.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 22 (UPI)--Cincinnati Milacron, Inc. has received an order for 237 of its recently introduced minicomputers from the Eldorado Electrodata Corporation, Concord, Calif.

WAYNE, Pa., Aug. 22-- Miss Martha Gale Sanson, daughter of Mrs. M. DeWitt Samson, of Bryn Mawr and Henry Bright Sanson of West Hartford, Conn., was married here this afternoon to Alan Lynn Antik, son of Mrs. M. Clark Antik and Alain Anatole Antik, both of Los Angeles.
LIHUE, Kauai, Hawaii, Aug. 22 (AP)--Hawaiian historians have called on the state to police commercial helicopter flights into remote areas of the islands to curb the looting of ancient temple sites.

BEIRUT, Lebanon--Drowning out beggars' cries and the purr of limousines, the sound of gunfire spread across Beirut last week. It was not trigger-happy Arab commandos, but jubilant Lebanese: Lebanon had just chosen an improbable new President for this sybaritic old capital --and thereby given a small but possibly important nudge to the movement of events in the Middle East.

MADE of heavy gauge, auto-body steel, a home utility cart recently put on the market is equipped with two large (14-inch) ball bearing wheels to simplify pushing it when heavily loaded, and to permit easy rolling over...

MILFORD, N.J., Aug. 22-- In the First Presbyterian Church of Milford today, Miss Margo Harder, a descendant of Alfred Vail, inventor and partner of Samuel F.B. Morse, was married to Richard Michael Lawless, who heads R.M. Lawless Real Estate, Inc., in Norwood, Mass.
Since last fall, college football's coaching ranks have undergone all sorts of changes-- placid and otherwise.

Dr. Oscar E. Goldstein, a specialist in internal medicine at 150 Boulevard, Passaic, N.J., died yesterday in Memorial Hos pital. His age was 53.

Most Americans take it for granted that water from the household tap is as safe and wholesome as homemade pie. That assumption should no longer be made, according to a nationwide study on the quality and safety of community ...

CAIRO, Aug 22 (Reuters)-- Thirteen persons including two children were killed and 54 injured today when a car of an Aswan-to-Cairo express train overturned in Tamouh, a village south of here, the Middle East News Agency reported.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 22-- John Parks turned up the huge foot at the end of the long, long leg and pointed to the new halfsole on his shoe.

The men's field for the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis championship was completed yesterday when Steve Turner of New York, Richard Russell of Jamaica, B.W.I., Brian Gottfried of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Jean-Loup Rouyer of France won qualifying matches.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Aug. 23 (AP) Denis Hulme, leading all the way, scored his third straight victory in the 1970 Can-Am series today by easily winning the Buckeye Can-Am road race over the Mid-Ohio Sports Car course near here.

GREENPORT, L.I., Aug. 23 Fire of undetermined origin that lasted throughout the night destroyed a fish processing plant here. There was no official estimate of damage, but Police Chief Robert Walden predicted that the loss would run into hundreds of thousands of dollars.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 23 High winds, big seas and heavy morning rain all subsided by starting time for the Yacht Racing Association regatta on Long Island Sound this afternoon.
The city's Commissioner of Air Resources said yesterday that the controversial Consolidated Edison power plant approved by Mayor Lindsay on Saturday might never be built.
A fireman who is a former state weight-lifting champion ran from his West Side firehouse Saturday night andcaptured a 6-foot-4-inch, 240pound mugging suspect.

The chairman of the State Committee on Crime and Correction called on the city yesterday to release immediately the defendants accused of nonviolent misdemeanors who had not been able to post bail. He estimated that a total of 2,000 to 2,500 in this category were being held in city detention facilities.

Howard J. Samuels, the chairman of the city's offtrack betting corporation, said yesterday that his agency was studying the feasibility of seeking legislative approval to enable the legal parlors to take bets on other sports besides horse racing.
ODESSA, Del., Aug. 23 (UPI) An off-duty Delaware trooper was wounded early today by a shotgun blast fired through the closed front door of the State Police office here.

LONDON, Aug. 23 The restlessly growing women's liberation movement in Europe, which is attracting workingclass mothers and young radicals, has stirred trade unions and governments in its drive for equal pay, equal jobs and equal rights.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 23 (UPI) Eddie Leon's two-run double in the eighth inning snapped a 6-6 deadlock today and gave the Cleveland Indians an 8-6 victory over the Oakland Athletics and a sweep of their three-game series.

In the course of nearly nine soggy hours at Shea Stadium yesterday, the New York Mets split a double-header with the Cincinnati Reds while a remarkably patient crowd of 43,712 sat through rain delays, got one full dose of ninth-inning satisfaction and got a glimpse of a major star in the making.

The show known as "Like It Is," a production of WABCTV, had an unusual concept yesterday afternoon, something that came within minutes of personalizing the agonies of the drug scene with exceptional force. Unfortunately, it then veered from its goal and diluted what started out as a compassionate tribute to one of the station's assistant producers.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 23 Joseph M. Regan, a retired vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co., New York realestate brokers, died at his home here yesterday. He was 72 years old.

SUNBURY, Pa., Aug. 23 Miss Ellen Beth Weis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sigfried Weis, was married this afternoon to Lieut. Joseph Ira Goldstein, U.S.N., son of Mrs. Manuel Lande of Roosevelt, N.J., and the late Paul Goldstein. Rabbi Norman Intrator performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Figures that the New York Stock Exchange itself has provided to Congress are raising serious questions here about the adequacy of the exchange's special trust fund to insure customers of all brokerage houses that are failing against losses.

SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 23 Heavy rains forced postponement today of the fourth round of the $160,000 Avco Golf Classic. The Pleasant Valley Country Club course was declared unplayable at 1:45 P.M., after several greens were inundated from the steady downpour.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23 When a stranger offered several Jet's players a short ride in his car from their motel rooms to the team bus during today's noontime downpour, two who accepted were Joe Namath and Al Atkinson, the team's philosophical rivals.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 23 (Reuters) The police today foiled an attempt by left-wing demonstrators to seize Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's farm near here.

The Government's latest report on the high cost of living shows things drifting as they have been for the last three months. Inflation is still cutting the value of the dollar at the rate of roughly a nickel a year. But, when seasonal factors are taken into account, the upsurge in prices may be easing a trifle.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (UPI) Jerry May singled off Bill Sudakis's glove at third base to drive in Roberto Clemente from second base with two out in the top of the 16th inning Saturday night to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 2-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 23 James B. Moore Jr.'s Lure won over 10 Resolute Class sloops today as 41 boats braved driving rain in the Cow Bay Area, Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound competition.

TOKYO, Aug. 23 The Japan Communist party, once considered an adjunct of Moscow or Peking or both, has created an image of itself as an "independent" party busily soliciting voter support on down-to-earth issues such as housing, sewerage and pollution.
LONDON, Aug. 23 The Trades Union Congress warned a restless rank and file today against indiscriminate walkouts that might hurt organized labor as a whole.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 George Carroll Buzby, chairman and chief executive officer of the Chilton Company, a business-magazine and bookpublishing concern, died yesterday at his home. He was 73 years old.

MANILA "Beauty is vain," the author of Proverbs observed 2,400 years or so ago. Just how universal is this rather waspish judgment can be confirmed by visiting with women of the national minorities, or tribal groups, in the Philippines.
BRUSSELS, Aug. 23 Belgium's Union Miniere Company, whose assets were nationalized by the Congolese Government in December, 1966, is preparing a comeback in the Congo.

LEAWOOD, Kan., Aug. 23 (UPI) Kathy Ahern, equalling Donna Caponi's second-round record-breaking 5-under-par 67, marked her first tournament victory in four years as she shot a 211 to win the $20,000 Southgate open invitation tournament today.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Monday, Aug. 24 A Cambodian military spokesman said today that allied air strikes had killed 500 North Vietnamese and Vietcong soldiers in a sanctuary along the border with South Vietnam.

Henry Ford the Elder described his first gasoline buggy as "something of a nuisance, for it made a racket and scared horses." Its descendants make 75 per cent of the racket in our major cities and scare a lot more people than their forerunner ever did horses.
SPARTA, N.J., Aug. 23 Winsomore captured his fourth championship in 10 starts in his first year in the ring when he won the regular working hunter title today at the Homestead Stables horse show.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 23 A heavy downpour an hour before playing time today forced a one-day postponement of the final-round match between Ray Ruffels of Australia and Jaime Fillol of Chile for the 71st Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship. The match will be played at 1 P.M. tomorrow at the Merion Cricket Club.

ATHENS, Aug. 23. (Reuters) The Government today rejected a charge that a public prosecutor was hounding the Greek shipowner Stavros Niarchos over allegations that he fatally injured his wife, Eugenie.
FARMINGDALE, L.I., Aug. 23 The police are investigating the slaying of an electronics company executive who was found dead at his office desk here last night by his wife.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 Less than three weeks ago, after he had won a not particularly well pitched game against Cleveland, Fritz Peterson of the Yankees said: "At least I've gotten my luck back. It's better for me to be lucky than to be good."

Two decades ago almost all of America's top-ranked players, and the vast majority of expert players in other parts of the world, were satisfied with natural bidding methods and a minimum of conventions. Now the picture has changed completely: most of the contenders for world championship titles play complex methods that require careful study by their opponents.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23 "I never look down at a victory," Fran Tarkenton said today. "Also, I never take any future meaning out of a victory. We won today. That's good. That's what it means. We won today." This was positive thinking in the Tarkenton vein, as positive as any Giant could be after the narrow escape of a 28-24 victory over the Jets in the transplanted Battle of New York.
GILBERTVILLE, Pa. A 2year-old bulldog, Ch. Westfield Flying Colors, was judged best in show over 910 other dogs today at the 22d annual Perkiomen Valley Kennel Club event.

Timothy Wayne, 22 years old, the son of David Wayne, the actor, was reported missing while on a camping trip near the town of Yellow Knife, in the Northwest Territory, Canada, his father reported yesterday.

New York City's proportion of people on the welfare rolls far exceeds the ratio in most urban centers, according to comparisons offered in the latest episode of a running dispute between city officials and the Center for New York City Affairs of the New School for Social Research.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 (AP) The Federal Aviation Administration has withdrawn its plan to require airlines to provide smoke-protection hoods for emergency use by passengers.

SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 23 (AP) Some 3,000 members of Cesar Chavez's United Farm Workers Organizing Committee voted today to strike at least 27 vegetable ranches tomorrow in a jurisdictional dispute in the fertile Salinas Valley.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. Seldom has any man so naturally and totally embodied the image of the discreet, self-effacing, almost invisible diplomat as Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, under whose auspices long-awaited negotiations on the Middle East are expected to open soon.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 23 (AP) Al Unser of Albuquerque, N.M., easily captured the Tony Bettenhausen 200 here today, finishing more than three laps ahead of the field in a record time of 1 hour 44 minutes 59 seconds.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 More than 1,600 drama teachers and students assembled here today for the opening session of the American Educational Theater Association's annual convention.
The first big rainstorm of August swept over the city yesterday, leaving streets and highways awash in low-lying areas but bringing relief from the heat and nourishment to parched lawns and trees.
Samuel L. Rockower, who retired in 1965 as a teacher of mechanical drawing, at the Aviation Trades School in Long Island City, Queens, died Saturday in Miami, where he lived. His age was 70.

HONG KONG, Aug. 23 (AP) The most Rev. James Edward Walsh, the Roman Catholic bishop who was freed July 10 by the Chinese Communists after 12 years in a Shanghai prison left Hong Kong tonight for Rome. He is scheduled to meet Pope Paul VI on Tuesday.
Miss Evelyn Tkach and Andrew S. Novins were married here yesterday afternoon at Temple Shaaray Tefila. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Phillip Schechter.

ATLANTA, Aug. 23 During the next three weeks, in a showdown with the Federal Government and the courts, 543 school districts in 11 states of the South are scheduled to desegregate fully for the first time. The will of the white Southerner to accept orderly social change will be tested as never before, and trouble is expected in several places.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 23 Sterling E. Watts of the Greenwich Cove Racing Association, who sailed Huck to a second and two first places when the regatta began on Long Island Sound yesterday, became the Rhodes-18 Class national champion today at Rocky Point Club.

PARIS The most surprising best seller of the season has been Edgar Rice Burroughs. The first four volumes of the new edition of Tarzan's adventures have each sold 100,000 copies. As there are 22 volumes to go, one may easily surmise the editor's elation.

ST. JAMES, L.I., Aug., Aug. 23 Harry deLeyer rode Dutch Lady to the regular working hunter championship of 15 points today at the raindrenched Mills Pond Horse Show. The event was held at Hollandia Farms.

ROME, Aug. 23 Three militant advocates of Italy's pending divorce bill finished their 15th day of a public fast in front of the Senate building here today, having lost one companion yesterday while gaining four others in the southern city of Bari.
TALLADEGA, Ala., Aug. 23 (UPI) Young Pete Hamilton seized an early lead and charged to victory today in the Talladega 500 stock-car classic at a brisk speed of 158.517 miles an hour.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23 Harry Theofiledes, the shortest Jet quarterback, emerged as the tallest in stature of the four in attendance at today's 28-24 loss to the Giants.

CHICAGO, Aug. 23 Environmental protection groups in the Lake Michigan area are trying to force the setting of tough new standards to protect the lake from hot water that will be dumped into it by nuclear power plants now under construction along the shoreline.

Bobby Fischer's victory in the 18-man international round-robin tournament at Buenos Aires continues to stir interest in the chess world. Fischer clinched his victory as early as the 14th round, something unusual in a tournament boasting the caliber of players in the Buenos Aires field.

Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, attacked yesterday, Mayor Lindsay's approval of an addition to an electric power plant in Astoria, Queens, and said he would seek to rescind approval if elected Governor.

CAP-HAITIEN, Haiti, Aug. 19-A search for the lost wreck of the Santa Maria, the ship from which Columbus first saw America, is centered on a corai formation that looks hauntingly like a sunken vessel below the luminous blue-green waters here.

The Northern Division title of the North American Soccer League will not be decided until next Sunday, the last day of the regular season, as both contenders, the Kansas City Spurs and the Rochester Lancers, failed to win in yesterday's games. The Spurs bowed to the St. Louis Stars, 2-1, while the Lancers tied the Washington Darts, 2-2.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Aug. 23 Tests of archeological samples excavated from a site in south central Ceylon have indicated that the area was settled by a people of the late Stone Age about 10,000 years ago.

GREAT BARRINGTON, Mass, Aug. 23 Jane Esther Henderson's 4-year-old West Highland white terrier, Ch. De-Go Hubert, topped the 1,165-dog field at today's Great Barrington Kennel Club show at the Butternut Basin.

The General Electric computer components business that Honeywell, Inc., proposes to acquire, last year operated in the black for the first time since the General Electric Company entered the computer field early in the nineteen sixties.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) Bob Johnson pitched a twohitter and Bob Oliver clouted a two-run triple in the seventh inning today as the Kansas City Royals topped the Boston Red Sox 4-3.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP) Roberto Clemente smacked three singles, a double and a home run for his second straight five-hit spree as the Pittsburgh Pirates unleashed a 23-hit barrage today and trounced the Los Angeles Dodgers, 11-0, behind Steve Blass's four-hitter.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 23 The New York Giants staggered to a 4-point victory over the Jets in the Yale Bowl today, winning, 28-24. A three-touchdown rally in the final period was not enough for the Jets to overcome their early errors, which helped the Giants to a 28-0 lead after only 15 minutes 47 seconds of play.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 The Amateur Athletic Union's national outdoor swimming championships ended tonight with some of the fastest and closest races ever. Almost incidentally, John Kinsella, Mark Spitz and Gary Hall broke world records.
TOKYO, Aug. 23 (AP) A leader in the United States women's liberation movement advised all women in Asia today to "gather force and seize power."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The first National Convention of Black Lay Catholics concluded this afternoon after adopting a statement accusing the church of failing to respond to the needs of blacks.

CAIRO, Aug. 23 (Reuters) The United Arab Republic and Iran have agreed to end a 10year rupture in diplomatic relations and re-establish them at the ambassadorial level, Foreign Ministry officials aid here today.

Adam Walinsky, the Democratic candidate for Attorney General, yesterday challenged Louis J. Lefkowitz, the incumbent, tot a series of 10 television debates.

OTTAWA, Aug. 23 Secretary General Thant of the United Nations told a congress of World Federalists tonight that mankind must soon solve its problems of rising population, increasing pollution and a "multiplied capacity of destruction" or perish.

Miss Margaret Esme Simon, daughter of Dr. Carol T. Simon of New York and George M. Simon of Albany, was married here yesterday to Brian Leslie Berger, son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Berger of Elizabeth, N.J.

Slightly more than a year ago, John F. Small, a black advertising man, formed his own agency that was designed from the start to operate as a full-line shop rather than as one concentrating on the ethnic market.

MOSCOW, Aug. 23 (Reuters) Aleksander Ginzburg, a dis sident intellectual sentenced in 1968 for anti-Soviet activities, has been moved from a labor camp to the apparently stricter conditions of a prison, it was learned here today.

AGANA, Guam, Aug. 23 Vice President Agnew warned today that it would be impossible for United States combat troops to pull out of South Vietnam if the Communists overthrew the Government of Premier Lon Nol and took over Cambodia.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 (UPI) Frank Johnson's basesloaded pinch-hit single in the ninth inning today drove in two runs that gave the San Francisco Giants a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Cubs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 A dispute almost as old as the Constitution is moving to the forefront of the controversy over the call to impeach Justice William O. Douglas because of his off-the-bench activities.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 23 William Carlson, president of the Carlson Foundation, which has contributed to universities, hospitals and other institutions here, died today at his home. He was 84 years old.

The State Department of Taxation and Finance said yesterday that state residents returning from abroad, beginning Sept. 1, could bring in only one quart of liquor free of state taxes instead of the gallon previously allowed.

The American Embassy in Moscow has properly protested to the Soviet Foreign Ministry against secret police treatment of some American tourists. The crude behavior of the K.G.B. toward the Americans involved must raise questions for other Americans contemplating visits to the Soviet Union.

The $170-billion savings and loan industry, which is the largest single supplier of funds for home mortgages, is facing its most basic structural reform in more than a generation and it is not at all happy about the prospect.

Insurance on cars and homes is increasingly difficult to buy in many areas, but more than 2,500 employes of the University of Pennsylvania from janitors and secretaries to nurses and professors are not only getting all the coverage they want on the payroll deduction plan but are also receiving an average 15 per cent group discount in the bargain.
