GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 23 Wally Corwin of the American Yacht Club of Rye, N.Y., won the 420 Class junior-national sailing championship today. The young skipper who is 13 Years old had his cousin, Garry Corwin 3d, 12, as mate.
A year ago, Mayor Lindsay, rejected by his own party, was fighting for political survival in the mayoral election.

GENEVA, Aug. 23 The Soviet Union has submitted a surprise proposal to the United Nations Committee on the Peaceful Uses of the Seabed under which "all military uses" of the seabed outside national jurisdiction would be prohibited.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Senator J.W. Fulbright suggested today that the United Nations might create an international police force to enforce a negotiated settlement of the Arab-Israeli conflict.
New York City's sidewalk litter baskets are now being stolen as so-called camp art objects, after decades of being filched by well-muscled householders for home refuse.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 23 Major yachting developments are expected here tomorrow when the America's Cup trials resume on two fronts.
PARIS, Aug. 23 Alain Clement, a French television technician, arrived here today tired and emaciated after a month and a half of captivity in Cambodia.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 23 A booby trap on a water tap killed an Israeli Arab this morning. The man, a forty-five-year-old father of nine, had been working in Dovev, an Israeli village some 150 yards from the Lebanese border.
BOSTON, Aug. 23 (UPI) The legislature passed without opposition tonight a compromise bill to modify the nation's first no-fault auto insurance law.
CAIRO, Aug. 23 King Hussein today ended talks with President Nasser on strategy against Israel and returned to Amman. The talks were surrounded by tight secrecy, and no communique was issued.

Steve Gerrie wears a welltrimmed mustache, works as an accountant in a Wall Street brokerage and lives with his lover in a neat but threadbare apartment in the West Village here. His roommate, Jack Waluska, is a former welfare case worker now studying for a master's degree in sociology.

Interest rates unquestionably will move downward this week. This unhedged prophecy was voiced by a large number of investment bankers and credit market observers late last week as they reviewed the period just ending and surveyed the outlook.

MUSCAT, Oman, Aug. 19 Sultan Qabus bin Said of Oman said today that he would offer an amnesty to the guerrillas in the southern province of Dhofar and "let bygones be bygones" in hopes of ending their warfare.
The building superintendent is a person of extraordinary power.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 23 Dr. Paul Duncan McGehee of 4 Durham Road, a psychiatrist and psychoanalyst, died today in Phelps Memorial Hospital, Tarrytown, after a brief illness. His age was 53.
A portrait of the New York policeman, showing that there has been an increase in unskilled workers joining the force, has emerged from studies drawn together in a federally financed report.

Bobby Phillips of Baltimore capped the four-day national amateur bicycle championships which ended yesterday, with a victory in the 10-mile event on the rain-slicked Kissena track in Flushing, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 A Senate subcommittee said today that the United States had turned over to Japan the responsibility for defending herself against conventional military attack.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 23 Israel broke ground today for her second oil refinery. It will rise at Ashdod on the Mediterranean Coast, 10 miles north of the terminal of the ElathAshkelon Pipeline.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 23 A left-wing Arab commando organization, As Saiqah, has demanded that King Hussein's Government release eight of its members who it said were imprisoned here.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 23 Miss Nancy Lynn Fisher, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Fisher, was married this afternoon to Robert Englander, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Englander of Kew Gardens, Queens. Rabbi Joel Zion of Temple Israel performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents. He was assisted by Cantor David Benedict.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 23 (AP) Frank Howard and Del Unser hit three-run homers and Dick Bosnian hurled a sixhitter as the Washington Senators routed the Minnesota Twins, 11-1, today.

A 195-pound, off-duty fireman carried a 235-pound, 85year-old crippled man down a ladder from the third floor of a burning Bronx apartment building early yesterday while other elderly tenants in the same apartment were guided to safety by another fireman.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The Nixon administration has come up with a new strategy for getting its policies across to the American public: reaching out to metropolitan newspaper editors and regional television executives throughout the land.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., Aug. 23 A pre-noon cloudburst followed by an afternoon thunder and lightning storm proved no deterrent today as the National rowing championships were completed on the wind-blownCooper River.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Aug. 23 (UPI) Thirty-nine elderly persons were injured today when a chartered bus carrying them to a religious shrine ran off a wet road and crashed.

KENT, Ohio "The Kerner Commission said a very beautiful thing," a black student named Robert S. Pickett told the President's Commission on Campus Unrest last week, "which you guys could probably say, too."
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 23 The shootout at the Marin County Courthouse did not grow out of a simple, illconceived plan to free three convicts, some investigators now privately concede.

The old Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth, a success for 28 years on the North Atlantic but a failure as a tourist attraction in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., since her retirement in 1968, will be sold at auction there on Sept. 9 and 10.
With almost all the new make-up collections attached to the names of well-known beauties, Mrs. Jay Oringer of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Mrs. Norman Muller of Manhattan decided it was time for a change.

The Federal Reserve Board, caught with an embarrassing error in the announcement of its decision to require a reserve against commercial paper sold by bank holding companies, is making a special effort to inform bankers that such unsecured notes sold with a maturity of less than 30 days will carry a reserve of up to 17 per cent, and not the 5 per cent implied by the initial statement.
MIAMI, Aug. 23 Premier Fidel Castro warned tonight of an invasion of any country that allows itself to become a base for an expedition by exiles against Cuba.

WASHINGTON, Aug, 23 For the second time this year, sponsors of nonprofit housing are disturbed by indications that the Nixon Administration may impose what they consider to be repressive restrictions on their efforts to build homes for the poor.
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 23 Steel users are buying cautiously.

DETROIT , Aug. 23 (UPI) Tom Timmerman came in with the bases loaded and nobody out in the ninth inning today and preserved Mickey Lolich's two-hit performance by retiring the Milwaukee Brewers without a run and the Detroit Tigers triumphed, 1-0.
Senator Charles E. Goodell announced yesterday that he would hold a hearing Aug. 31 to focus attention on the need for Federal action to increase employment on Long Island.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 23 "We have a way of saving our controversies and differences for the off season," ob serves Alec Lyle, Cape May's chronicler and sage-in-resi dence. "We talk them out in the winter. It shortens the wait for spring."

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 23 (AP) Jose Cardenal, who had already driven in three runs, poked a two-run single to cap a ninthinning St. Louis rally today and gvie the Cardinals an 8-7 victory over the San Diego Padres.
TOKYO, Aug. 23 (UPI) Xuan Thuy, North Vietnam's chief delegate to the Vietnam peace talks, left Hanoi last Wednesday for Paris, Hanoi's Vietnam News Agency said today in a broadcast monitored here.

TOKYO, Aug. 23 (UPI) Hiroshi Kobayashi of Japan, world junior lightweight champion, retained his World Boxing Association title tonight by scoring a unanimous 15-round decision over Antonio Amaya of Panama.
Don Shula, the Miami Dolphins' football coach, is glad he heeded the call to 'come on down."

TAIPEI, Taiwan, Aug. 23 Spurred by a forester, the Government is moving to preserve Taiwan's endangered wildlife. The Cabinet recently approved a list of 20 species to be protected from hunting and began considering a second group of 27.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission announced the designation yesterday of an area around the MorrisJumel Mansion in upper Manhattan as a historic district.
PETERBORO, N.H., Aug. 23 Eudora Welty today received the Edward MacDowell Medal.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 23 (AP) Franklin S. Payne, publisher of The Los Angeles Examiner, from 1955 to 1962, died today of leukemia. He was 74 years old.

The Federal Communications Commission's landmark interpretation of the fairness doctrine holding that it can be applied even to the President of the United States on such an overriding issue of controversy as the Vietnam war is a logical and mature extension of a principle that goes to the heart of licensed broadcasting in this country.

El Al Flight Capt., Oded Abarbanell, flying the same Boeing 707 in which he was hijacked to Algeria two years ago, had another close call early today, landing at Kennedy International Airport on two badly worn nose-gear tires.

ROME, Aug. 23 A system that enabled Roman Catholic convents to pay high fees to bring poor and often unqualified peasant girls from the Indian state of Kerala to understaffed institutions in Europe has been suspended, the Vatican said late tonight. The Vatican denied published charges that many such girls had been maltreated and forced to do menial work after their arrival.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 23 Miss Ellen Sue Simonoff, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Simonoff of New Orleans, was married here today to Daniel Abraham Picard, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jean-Jacques Picard of Stamford. The ceremony was performed at the Congregation Agudath Sholom by Rabbi Joseph E. Ehrenkrantz.

AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 22 College applicants, while better prepared today in a strict academic sense, are no more sophisticated about higher education than they used to be, according to Eugene S. Wilson, who is often called the "dean of college admissions deans."

JERUSALEM, Aug. 23 Israel's Cabinet today named Foreign Minister Abba Eban as this country's chief delegate to proposed peace talks on the Middle East. Yosef Tekoah, the nation's representative at the United Nations, was named alternate delegate.
ALBANY, Aug. 23 Governor Rockefeller announced today state approval of a $14.4-million grant to New York City for construction and rehabilitation of 65,000 lowincome and middle-income apartments.
The Lutheran Church, the third largest Protestant denomination in the United States, announced yesterday that it lost 16,058 members during 1969.
International Investors Group announced yesterday the purchase of 12 shopping centers in the United States at a combined price of $44,250,000.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The Rev. Louis Francis Hartman, a Redemptorist educator and Bible authority, who was professor of Semitic languages and former head of the department at the Catholic University of America, died yesterday of a heart ailment. He was 69 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended Aug. 22.

England took a 2-0 lead over Canada in Stevens Cup senior tennis competition yesterday at the River Club. The matches were moved indoors when heavy rains made the West Side Tennis Club courts in Forest Hills, Queens, unplayable.
BABYLON, L.I., Aug. 23 A $20-million program to expand parking at Jones Beach and Robert Moses State Park was announced today by the Long Island State Park Commission.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 23 (UPI) Michigan Democrats endorsed today the concept of granting amnesty to all persons who have dodged the draft by either going to jail or leaving the country. The party's state convention passed the resolution less than 12 hours after it had passed another one calling for an immediate ceasefire in Indochina and removal of all American forces by Christmas.

PARIS, Aug. 23 The Ford Motor Company has become involved in French politics as the result of an announcement yesterday by the Mayor's office in Bordeaux that the American concern had bought land in the area to build a factory.

FORT PIERCE, Fla., Aug. 23 (AP) A soldier killed in Vietnam, who was rejected by a cemetery because he was black, was given military and religious honors at an armory today and then carried to a mortuary.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 23 (UPI) Deron Johnson drove in three runs today with a single and his 24th homer of the season to lead the Philadelphia Phillies to a 4-0 victory over the Houston Astros.

BALTIMORE, Aug 23 (UPI) Paul Blair singled home Mark Belanger from second base with the winning run in the ninth inning today to give the Baltimore Orioles a 6-5 victory over the California Angels and Mike Cuellar registered his 19th victory of the season.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 23 The men and women who, among other things, organize conventions will have their own convention here this week, and there will be a somewhat new slant.

MIAMI, Aug. 23 (UPI) Tropical depression Dorothy, deflated after causing floods on the French Island of Martinique, meandered into the western Caribbean Sea today. Forecasters warned that it could reintensify.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 23 Communist forces in Cambodia today released Robert S. Anson, a Time magazine reporter, after having held him in the countryside since his capture Aug. 3.

The Federal Reserve Board has approved applications of New York City's two largest banks The First National City Bank and the Chase Manhattan Bank to open international banking subsidiaries in Los Angeles, the two institutions announced.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 23 They came as Southern belles and Confederate generals, as Topsies and Evas and the girls of the Atlanta bordellos. There was a Ku Klux Klansman in a permanent-press sheet. There were any number of wounded soldiers in ink-spattered bandages, an occasional Union Officer and a few who seemed vaguely Napoleonic. Those who hadn't been able to concoct costumes came as themselves and announced that they were poor, white trash.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 24 Miss Donna Gail Mallin, a teacher at the Bramble Primary School in Madisonville, and Kenneth John Weinberg, a marketing executive with the Procter Gamble Company, will marry Sept. 19.
Two elderly women were shot yesterday for no apparent reason in the hardware store they own in the Fort Greene Section of Brooklyn.

These three volumes represent the first appearance in English of two contemporary Brazilian writers of some reputation in their home country. Except that both fill out our knowledge of the poorer and lessappetizing side of Brazilian life, they have on the basis of these books little in common. Jose Veiga is a writer of wider range, greater complexity and with a larger reach.

ATHENS, Aug. 24 (AP) A magistrate in Piraeus today received the Stavros S. Niarchos file in which a prosecutor asked that the Greek shipowner be indicted for having caused "lethal injuries" to his wife.
By now, dating by computer is old hat. But eating by computer?

A motion picture theater, housed in a geodesic dome, will open on Sept. 11 in Dayton, Ohio, the first luxury, first-run cinema to be built in a Negro neighborhood by the Walter Reade Organization, Inc. The organization operates 77 theaters in 11 states and Washington.

With the extent of the cornblight problem now the big question, trading on the Chicago Board of Trade slowed somewhat yesterday although the disease continued as the prime topic of conversation in the pits.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 24 Mr. and Mrs. Russell Newman Carhart have announced the engage- ment of their daughter, Miss Susan Elizabeth Carhart, to Peter Dwight Bluhm, son of Mrs. Heinz Bluhm of New Haven and of Wilton, N.H. and Mr. Bluhm of Chestnut Hill, Mass.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 (UPI) Joe Pepitone belted his 19th home run of the season with a man on base in the fourth inning tonight and the Chicago Cubs went on to post a 4-2 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers. Ferguson Jenkins registered his 16th victory.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 24 Cliff Drysdale of South Africa broke service only one time, but that was enough in a straight-set victory over the United States No. 1 junior, Roscoe Tanner, today in first-round play of the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis tournament at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

Stock prices boomed yesterday in the second straight session with dramatic gains. The Dow-Jones industrial average, moving upward steadily on heavy volume, closed at 759.58 with an upswing of 14.17 points.

An explosive device placed outside a suite of law offices shattered a waiting room and blew in a dozen doors yesterday afternoon on the 15th floor of an office building at 15 Park Row, across from City Hall in Lower Manhattan. The explosion caused no injuries.
Following are selected excerpts from sections of the New American Bible compared with the earlier translation in the Douay Version. The 23d Psalm is numbered 22 in the Douay Version.

Britain earned the right to challenge the defending United States team in the international senior tennis team competition for the Stevens Cup yesterday. The British won the clinching doubles match from Canada and took a 3-0 lead in the elimination final.
GALLIFA, Spain In the hills 30 miles above Barcelona, work is being completed on a 30-ton mural designed by Joan Miro and fashioned by Spain's master ceramist, Josep Llorens Artigas.
Sales of domestic passenger cars in the United States slumped 4.4 per cent during the middle 10 days of August, from the 1969 period, the four major auto manufacturers reported yesterday.

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 24 (UPI) Lance Alworth, an all-pro flanker, has returned to the San Diego Chargers' training camp but his contract dispute with the National Football League team is not over, according to his lawyer, Don Augustine.

PHUOCVINH, South Vietnam, Aug. 22 This war sounds different from the others. It has the usual snaps of rifle fire and booms of artillery at varying intervals, but above these is a cacophony of whirrs and putts provided by this war's jeep the helicopter.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 Rumors that spread in this capital after an announcement 18 days ago that cholera had broken out in southern Russia have begun to wane.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 24 The center of Santiago was blanketed with tear gas for most of the day today, as the police sought to halt violence associated with the Chilean presidential election campaign. Many shops, banks and business establishments were evacuated because of the gas.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Aug. 24 Louise Homer Stires, a former singer and the wife of the Rev. Ernest Van R. Stires, died yesterday at Glens Falls Hospital. She was 74 years old and had homes in Bolton Landing and in Sea Island, Ga.
James F. Donnelly, a lawyer who specialized in litigation and appellate practice for 68 years, died Friday in Dublin. He was 93 years old and lived in Park Ridge, N.J.

MIAMI, Aug. 24 (AP) A suit supported by the Federal Government was filed in United States District Court today, seeking to force an all-white cemetery in Fort Pierce, Fla., to allow the burial of a black soldier killed in Vietnam.
MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 24 Thomas H. Spain, retired director of advertising for Public Service Electric and Gas Company of Newark, died here yesterday. He was 74 years old.
HAUPPAUGE, L.I., Aug. 24 A man accused of importing weapons and drugs into the troubled Carleton Park section of Central Islip was banned today from Suffolk County pending his trial here Sept. 4.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 A leading Nixon Administration spokesman on trade matters made a bitter attack today on import quotas and said the Administration does not really want even quotas on textiles, which it has endorsed.
Air travelers by the thousands are by passing New York because of the harrowing traffic jams and congestion at Kennedy International Airport.
LONDON, Aug. 24 Five submachine guns and 5,000 rounds of ammunition were discovered today in the baggage checkroom of the Hilton Hotel on Park Lane here.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 24 Israeli security officials interrogating two Algerian citizens taken off a flight from the Far East to Europe 10 days ago identified one of the detainees tonight as a senior official in the Algerian security agency.

No Senator has more conspicuously urged United States disengagement in Southeast Asia than J.W. Fulbright. That stand, plus his influence as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, has focused world attention on Mr. Fulbright's surprise proposals for settling the Arab-Israeli conflict in the Middle East.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 American swimming is healthier than ever, especially among the men. The women, though not as good as the men, remain the best in the world.

In what may be an omen of a colorful campaign to come, a Manhattan Republican Congressional candidate delivered to his opponent yesterday the customary debate challenge and a hardly customary dozen red roses.
MOUNTAIN VIEW , Ark. They were about halfway through the regular Friday night "musical" on the courthouse lawn.

SUTTON, Mass., Aug. 23 Billy Casper sat in his motel room yesterday when the final round was washed out and played gin rummy. Under sunny skies today, Casper shot a 69 and won the Avco golf tournament by three strokes with an 11-under-par total of 277.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (AP) The Senate voted today to cut off funds for the International Labor Organization but to keep on financing the Subversive Activities Control Board.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 24 Senator Joseph D. Tydings of Maryland today characterized the publication by Life magazine of an article accusing him of using his public position for private gain as an act of high political vengeance. He said the article was planted in the magazine by "high White House sources" seeking his defeat.

LENOX, Mass. Aug. 24 To lead a grand-scale performance of the Berlioz Requiem, a conductor must be not only a good musician but also a frustrated generalissimo, a bit of a charlatan, a lay bishop and a logistics expert.

Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic Liberal candidate for Governor, labeled the Spofford juvenile detention center in the Bronx yesterday "the Tombs for children" and proposed a five-point overhaul in the state's program for dealing with youthful offenders.

Five of the nine members of the Selective Service System's Youth Advisory Committee here resigned yesterday to protest the Nixon Administration's policies on youth in general and the military draft in particular.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The United States is directing its diplomacy in the Middle East toward extending the Arab-Israeli truce beyond its present 90-day duration to improve the changes for reaching a peace settlement in the negotiations starting tomorrow at the United Nations.
CAIRO, Aug. 24 Mohammed Hassanein Heykal, Minister of National Guidance, accused, Israel today of violating the cease-fire-by building fortifications and military roads in the Suez Canal zone.
New York City's relief rolls have undergone their sharpest monthly rise since March, 1969, in what welfare officials say may be a reflection of national economic difficulties.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug 24 Stephen Leroy Angell, a realty executive and official village historian of Scarsdale, died Saturday in a Greenwich, Conn., nursing home after an illness of two months. He was 92 years old.

SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 24 (AP) California's "salad bowl" producer of half the nation's lettuce, strawberries, artichokes and broccoli was hit by a field workers' strike today in a fight over union jurisdiction.
CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 (UPI) The mother of one of the four students killed by National Guardsmen at Kent State University filed a $4-million damage suit today in Federal District Court.

BUCHANAN, N.Y., Aug. 24 An 18-year-old girl allegedly found with a suitcase containing dynamite, blasting, caps, primer cord, a homemade bomb, fireworks and a switchblade knife, was arrested last night in Peekskill, the State Police here reported.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) A minority group within the House Ways and Means Committee today branded a pending trade bill setting import quotas as restrictive, illtimed and provincial.

ALBANY, Aug. 24 Dr. Alan R. Hinman, a former official of the United States Public Health Service, who headed the investigation into a mercury-poisoning case involving an Alamogordo, N.M., family last December, will direct New York State's research into poisons in the environment.

OMAHA, Aug. 24 (AP) Fifteen young black men, including leaders of the militant National Committee to Combat Fascism, have been charged or arrested in the booby-trap bombing that killed a white policeman here a week ago.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Roman Catholics will get a new translation of the Bible in modern English next month to replace the Douay Version in use for 220 years, a team of its editors announced here today.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Aug. 24 Ray Ruffels of Australia won the last 9 points of the match to take the 71st Pennsylvania lawn tennis championship, 6-2, 7-6, 6-3, from Jaime Fillol of Chile today at the Merion Cricket Club.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (AP) Peter Sellers married the stepdaughter of a British lord today.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 24 (UPI) Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia opened a conference of African foreign ministers today with a keynote speech deploring Britain's decision to consider resuming arms shipments to South Africa.
VIRGINIA BEACH, Va. They wait, and often they weep. Especially when they see a Navy jet flying overhead.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 With the stock market collapsing and other financial markets jittery, the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee decided on May 26 to concentrate for a while on keeping financial conditions calm rather than achieving a "target" growth of the money supply, it was disclosed today.

An arbitrator decided yesterday in a dispute between the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and employes in its long-lines department to uphold the company's contractual right to grant $6.5-million in pay increases to employes not receiving top rates.
ALBANY, Aug. 24 The Conservative party has lodged formal challenges to the Conservation party and the Courage party, both of which plan to field candidates for the November election.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 24 (AP) The University of Wisconsin physics scholar who died today when a bomb destroyed a building that had attracted antiwar protests was described by his father as a "good teacher" who would have listened to dissidents.

GENEVA, Aug. 24 (AP) In vestors Overseas Services has delayed a formal solicitation of proxies in the hope of reaching an accommodation with Bernard Cornfeld, who says he already has enough proxies to control the company, a spokesman for the mutual-fund organization said today.

Miss Jaqueline Turner Bond of New York, a vice president of the Dormer Advisory Corporation, was married here yesterday to Dr. Charles Robert Dunbar, an orthopedic surgeon of Manhasset, L.I. The ceremony in the Library Suite at the St. RegisSheraton was performed by Family Court Judge Joseph D. Caputo.

The sharp rise in nighttime robberies at gasoline stations has brought a revolutionary shake-up in high crime areas. Many dealers are refusing to make change after 10 or 11 P.M. Customers are being forced to use either credit cards or to present the exact amount of cash.

Larry Grathwohl, a 23-yearold Cincinnati man who was one of 13 radical Weathermen indicted in Detroit last month on a charge of plotting to bomb public buildings across the country, forfeited a $7,500 bond yesterday for jumping bail on another charge.

The state legislative hearings last week into disorders at the Manhattan House of Detention for Men were denounced yesterday by the Fortune Society, a group devoted to prisoner rehabilitation, as an exercise in politics that had raised false hopes among inmates.
PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 24 The trial of 20 black Africans charged with activities aimed at the violent overthrow of the South African Government opened here today.
NEWARK, Aug. 24 (AP) New Jersey dissolved today its longstanding ban against liquor and beer sales on Election Day.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24 No matter which one wins the right to challenge for the America's Cup, Gretel II and France already have achieved a major breakthrough.
DEL MAR, Calif., Aug. 24 (UPI) Kfar Tov, under the guidance of Bill Shoemaker, led all the way today and won the $16,275 De Anza Stakes for 2-year-olds at Del Mar Race Course.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Pentagon officials announced today a test program requiring architectual and engineering companies to submit competitive proposals for military contracts.
Another roadblock has been put in the path of the merger plans of the Norfolk Western and Chesapeake Ohio railroads.

Public hearings on the controversial expansion of the Consolidated Edison Company's Astoria plant were requested before the Board of Estimate and the City Council yesterday, and at least one hearing before another panel was already scheduled.

Miss Leslie Meakin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eric N. Meakin of Beverly, Mass., and George. H. Priggen 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Priggen Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the United Nations Church Center. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Carl Soule, a Methodist minister.
EDISON, N.J., Aug. 24 (UPI) Twenty-three golfers, eight of them under par, qualified today for the remaining berths in the Dow Jones open, which begins Thursday at the Upper Montclair Country Club.

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 24 Durwood Knowles of Nassau, The Bahamas, who was the Star Class world champion in 1947 and Olympic gold medalist in 1964, won the first race today of the Star Class North American championship sailing series in Rockport, Mass.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 24 (AP) Turning back eight rivals, under good handling by Michael Hole, the L.E.M. Stable's Ahira won by half-alength in the Hamilton Purse at the Atlantic City Race Course today.

Sacrifices in the bidding are commonplace, but sacrifices during the defense of a hand are quite rare. A spectacular example of the sacrifice of a sure trump trick occurred on the diagramed deal played recently.

Concern about Tommie Agee's left knee, which was X-rayed last night at Roosevelt Hospital, added to the worries of the New York Mets yesterday. No firm diagnosis will be available until today when the Mets open a three-game series with the Atlanta Braves at Shea Stadium at 8 P.M.
The Armstrong Cork Company announced yesterday that it would raise prices by about 2 to 4 per cent on selected lines of resilient floor tile, effective Nov. 1.

Five years after a dynamite blast destroyed Muslim Mosque 7 in Harlem following the assassination of Malcolm X, a new building, topped with a dome and a revolving star and crescent, stands on the site. Beneath these symbols of the universal flag of Islam, Muslim ministers, educators and merchants are quietly working toward developing everything they say "a nation needs to be successful."

Manuel Yellen, one of the top salesmen in the tobacco field, has retired as chairman and chief executive officer of the Lorillard Company and as vice chairman of Loew's Theatres, Inc., the parent company of Lorillard, it was announced yesterday.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 Israel complained to the United Nations today over alleged Egyption violation of the cease-fire agreement provisions for treatment of prisoners of war, charging the United Arab Republic with violating the 1949 Geneva Convention.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Tuesday, Aug. 25 (AP) A military spokesman said an enemy force estimated at five battaions launched an attack nine miles northeast of Pnompenh last night, but the spokesman said it had been driven back.
MOSCOW, Aug. 24 The Soviet Union, aided by good weather, appears headed toward bumper harvests in virtually every agricultural sector this year, Western specialists said today.

Patrolman John Bal, who contends that his long hair and ideas for police reform have irked his superiors, pleaded not guilty yesterday to departmental charges of insubordination and unnecessarily conversing with civilians. The 24-yearold policeman was ordered to reappear Oct. 8 at Police Headquarters for trial on the charges.

YELLOWKNIFE, Northwest Territories, Aug. 24 (UPI) The Royal Canadian Mounted Police said today that a weeklong search for Timothy Wayne, 22-year-old son of David Wayne, the actor, and young Wayne's companion had been unsuccessful.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) A bipartisan group of 41 members of Congress sent President Nixon a letter today urging that the United States take all steps necessary to prevent violations of the cease-fire in the Suez Canal area. They warned of an even more dangerous situation arising if either side used the time to build military installations.
The Empire Standardbred Sale at Madison Square Garden Oct. 19 will depart from sales custom and offer an opportunity for the public to attend and bid for the yearlings to be sold at auction.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 23 (AP) Two colleges were placed on one-year probation and two others were reprimanded by the National Collegiate Athletic Association today.

PARIS, Aug. 24 John Haven Ferguson, former United States Ambassador to Morocco and a prominent lawyer in Washington and Paris, died today while vacationing with his wife near the southern Provencal town of Gordes. He was 55 years old.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 24 Israeli officials offered their first cautious reaction today to the proposals of Senator Fulbright, welcoming any international security guarantees, but only after completion of a "peace arrangement" with the Arab states.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Mayor Lindsay went before the Senate Finance Committee today to urge a complete Federal take-over of welfare costs and administration by 1976, but he also spent part of his time discussing why New York City's streets were so dirty.

The Consolidated Foods Corporation in the fiscal year ended June 27 set records in sales and earnings for the 15th consecutive year, William A. Buzick Jr., chairman reported yesterday from Chicago headquarters.
Burglars escaped with $250,000 to $500,000 in United States and foreign currency over the last weekend after cutting through a safe in the office of Perera Company, Inc., at 29 Broadway.

A new air-conditioned express bus service between the Bronx and Manhattan was started yesterday. The service is being maintained Mondays through Fridays between the Parkchester section of the Bronx and midtown Manhattan.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 24 (UPI) The 24th annual Little League World Series, dominated for the last three years by Far East teams, opens tomorrow with Chiaya, Taiwan playing Chinandega, Nicaragua, and Campbell, Calif., meeting Nashville, Tenn.

LTV Electrosystems, Inc., the publicly owned subsidiary of Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., announced yesterday it had reached an agreement in principle to acquire the major portion of the assets and business of the Melpar division of American Standard, Inc.
BETTYHILL, Scotland Unseen, overhead, curlews cried in the soft night as the incoming tide moved up the mouth of the River Naver in northern Scotland.

PARIS, Aug. 24 Tomorrow is the 700th anniversary of the death of King Louis IX, better known as St. Louis, and today the occasion brought his most prominent living descendant, Henri, Count of Paris, pretender to the French throne, out of political retirement to plead for justice and unity in France.
Activities. The President was at the Western White House in San Clemente, Calif.
The N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund has filed a suit charging John Mullins Sons, Inc., a major Brooklyn furniture chain, with violations of the Federal Truth-In-Lending Law.

Dr. Roald N. Grant, a surgeon and vice president in charge of professional education for the American Cancer Society, collapsed and died, apparently of a heart attack, on a bus in Manhattan yesterday. He was 58 years old and lived at 315 Avenue C.

WASHINGTON, Aug 24 (UPI) The Labor Department said today that working time lost because of strikes in July amounted to 0.28 per cent of total working hours in private industry. It was a decline from 0.31 per cent in June and an increase from 0.27 per cent in July, 1969.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 24 If West Germany is successful in its first Davis Cup challenge round this weekend, the German team of Christian Kuhnke and Wilhelm Bungert will have done it with less practice at the site of the series than any challenger in recent history.

On the eve of the announced strike of aroused womanhood for feminine rights, Mayor Lindsay has signed executive orders formally banning discrimination on the basis of sex or age in city employment and in the execution of contracts work for the city.

The mother of Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav author who was imprisoned for writing against the Communist party, has appealed to President Tito to be allowed to visit her daughter and grandchild in the United States.
Two more stock brokerage houses disclosed merger plans yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 24 Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring said today that he would open the long-awaited Middle East peace talks here tomorrow with the chief United Nations delegates of Israel, Jordan and the United Arab Republic.
MIAMI, Aug. 24 (AP) Favored Crew Chief caught Copious in the last 70 yards and won the feature race at Tropical Park today, drawing away to score by 1 lengths.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 24 Mayor Hugh C. Curran invited Mayor Lindsay of New York to visit this city today to see if the streets were cleaner than New York's.

COLLINGSWOOD, N.J., Aug. 24 The University of Washington's four-oared crew with coxswain qualified today to represent the United States in the world rowing championships at St. Catharines, Ontario, next week by scoring a 1 -length victory over the New Haven Rowing Club.

Hearings to be held this week in Sun Valley, Idaho, will go far to determine whether the country will have its 37th National Park or a gaping open-pit mine yielding molybdenum that will not even be needed for decades to come.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 24 A meeting of seven black athletes, the Syracuse University football coach, Ben Schwartzwalder; Chancellor John Corbally, and the Onondaga Human Rights Commission is scheduled for tomorrow to discuss recommendations for ending a dispute between the players and the coach.
BERLIN, Aug. 24 (UPI) A brawl between dozens of Negro and white soldiers took place in a United States Army barracks in West Berlin last Thursday, an Army spokesman reported today.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 24 Dr. Rema Lapouse, professor of community and preventive medicine and psychiatry at New York Medical College, died at her home here yesterday after a long illness. She was 55 years old and the wife of Dr. Milton Terris, professor and chairman of the department of community and preventive medicine at the college.
WARSAW, Aug. 24 A new Chinese Communist Ambassador to Warsaw, Yao Kuang, arrived here tonight, restoring top-level diplomatic representation in the Polish capital for the first time since 1967.

Harry Pesin is president of a small New York ad agency and a man who decided that he'd rather live in California. So he pulled up stakes a couple of months ago, moved into a home in La Jolla and now runs his shop long-distance style.
The city's Site Selection Board approved yesterday a site in the Civic Center area near City Hall for a proposed 30-story combined high school and New York Telephone Company facility.
SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 24 Vice President Agnew pledged today that the Nixon Administration would provide funds to modernize South Korea's 600,000-man armed forces.

CAIRO, Aug. 24 One of the most exciting modern archeological attractions in Egypt, the funerary solar boat of the Pharaoh Cheops, was reported today to be deteriorating rapidly as a result of exposure to humidity and temperature changes.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 24 (AP) The Tupamaro guerrilla group broke a silence of 13 days by announcing today that its two foreign hostages were in good health and had not been "sentenced."

The cowardly bomb attack on the University of Wisconsin's Mathematics Research Center, which killed a thirty-year-old research assistant, the father of three children, is murder compounded because it was committed on a university campus. The university's chancellor, H. Edwin Young, rightly terms it "an unspeakable crime."
Service on the BMT Fourth Avenue line in Brooklyn was disrupted for an hour and a half early yesterday by a bomb scare.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 24 Shuvee, Mrs. Whitney Stone's champion filly, came through with a thrilling success in the $49,100 Diana Handicap today. The 1 1/8-mile event for fillies and mares attracted a field of 12 contestants and Shuvee scored a nose victory over Reginald N. Webster's Dark Emerald. Four langths farther back in third place came Native Partner of the Oxford Stable.
A public hearing on the first modular, or partly pre-fabricated, housing in the city will be held by the City Planning Commission on Sept. 9.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 24 Arab commandos and proEgyptian Lebanese skirmished in the streets of Sidon today. At least two persons were killed and five wounded.

JACKSON, Wyo. This tourist-swollen frontier-flavored town, which shares one of the world's most scenic valleys Jackson Hole with Grand Teton National Park, has turned into a lively summertime theater center.
BONN, Aug, 24 The West German Government said today that it was seeking an agreement with Moscow for construction of a giant truck factort in the Soviet Union.
Plans for the first tire plant in the Congo (Kinshasa) a $16-million venture were announced yesterday by the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.
Morris B. Abram, former president of Brandeis University, yesterday was named board chairman of the United Negro College Fund.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 24 A not-so-funny thing kept happening to the Kansas City Royals this season they kept losing to Baltimore and New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 Treasury bill rates declined sharply at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
LONDON, Aug. 24 (Reuters) Laurence Olivier has a thrombosis and will make no stage appearances for the next two or three months.

NEWARK, Aug. 24 (AP) A Freehold, N.J., man went into Federal Court here Monday seeking the right to speak at meetings of the Monmouth County Board of Freeholders despite his recent refusal to salute the flag at a Freeholder's meeting.
Prices closed higher on the London stock market yesterday despite forecasts of economic difficulties for Britain.
Prices and volume turned in their best gains in almost three months yesterday on the American Stock Exchange as the list advanced in active trading.

LONDON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Exporting and importing member nations, of the International Coffee Agreement failed today to resolve sharp differences over the amount of coffee to be released to the world market in 1970-71.

Radio station WMCA, which has a 20-year tradition of emphasizing popular music, announced yesterday that it was adopting the format of accepting telephone calls from listeners on an almost full-time basis, starting Sept. 21. Most recently the station has been dividing the day between rock music and talking with listeners.

TRENTON, Aug. 24 State Attorney General George F. Kugler Jr. announced today that his office was considering legislation that would empower New Jersey to regulate rock festivals instead of simply geting court orders to ban them.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 24 Edward E. Bontems, president of the Eastern States Bankcard Association, Inc., of 110 East 59th Street, New York, died of an acute asthma attack in United Hospital here yesterday. He was 49 years old.
KHARTOUM, the Sudan, Aug. 24 (Reuters) Abdullah Khalil, who was Prime Minister from 1956 until the November, 1958, coup d'etat led by Gen. Ibraham Abboud, died here yesterday at the age of 78.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 The Nixon Administration is mapping plans for a multimillion-dollar economic assistance program for Cambodia, informed sources said today.

ASPEN, Colo., Many youths may consider businessmen hopeless Philistines, but every summer a small corps of the country's top executives retreats to this remote Rocky Mountain resort to ponder such matters as whether Socrates should have taken the hemlock or whether Captain Vere should have executed Billy Budd.

FORT BENNING, Ga., Aug. 24 (UPI) Defense attorneys sought today the disclosure of what they termed key and classified information that might shed further light on the alleged massacre at Songmy in 1968 and the secretive Operation Phoenix.
RYE, N.Y., Aug. 24 The Westchester Cotillion will take place for the 32d year Sept. 4 at the Shenorock Shore Club here. There are 26 debutantes, 20 fewer than at last year's cotillion.
Henry R. Silverman, general partner in Oppenheimer and Co., has been named a director, president and chief executive officer of the ITI Corporation, a New York-based diversified industrial firm.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 24 An explosion that the police said was caused by a bomb ripped through the Army Mathematics Research Center on the University of Wisconsin campus early today, killing a graduate student and injuring four other persons.

NEW DELHI, Aug. 24 (UPI) A Foreign Office spokesman said today that the Indian Government would investigate allegations that as many as 2,000 girls from Kerala state had been recruited for fees to European convents.

WESTFALL TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 24 Wiliam E. Palmer, vice president and national sales manager of the Fawcett Printing Corporation, which has its sales headquarters in New York, died Saturday of a heart attack at his home here. He was 63 years old and also lived at 413 East 50th Street in New York.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 24 In recent months, bumper stickers have been appearing on cars in Maryland bearing the inscription "Don't Be a Bearer of Ill Tydings."

BOSTON, Aug. 24 (UPI) Gov. Francis W. Sargent today signed a major modification of the nation's first no-fault auto insurance law designed to meet insurance industry objections to a provision for automatic policy renewals.
Prices rose sharply yesterday throughout the money and capital markets.

SAN DIEGO, Aug. 24 (UPI) Dick Post, a halfback, cracked 14 yards off left tackle for a touchdown with 3 minutes 20 seconds left to give the San Diego Chargers a 14-9 comefrom-behind victory over the Chicago Bears tonight in a National Fotball League preseason game.
LONDON, Aug. 24 Shutdowns in the long-troubled British motor industry spread today, with at least 28,000 of the 470,000 workers laid off or staying away from the job.
ROME, Aug. 24 (AP) The Most Rev. James E. Walsh was reunited today with two sisters who last saw him in 1948 when he went to China on a missionary tour that ended with 12 years imprisonment there.
WOODS HOLE, Mass., Aug. 24 Tom Lehrer, the singing mathematician, began the afternoon with a rendition of "So Long Mom, I'm Off to Drop the Bomb."
An off-duty patrolman moonlighting as a cab driver was shot in the back last night in Harlem when he tried to resist two holdup men, the police said.
CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 24 (UPI) The Marine Corps team captured the National Trophy rifle team match today, beating the United States Navy team by two points in the final day of competition.

PRAGUE, Aug. 24 (Reutets) The police held 6,217 persons and seized 263 rifles, pistol, submachine guns and other weapons in the days preceding last Friday's anniversary of the 1968 Warsaw Pact invasion, it was reported here today.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 24 Charlie Morgan's golden dream to defend the America's Cup came to an end today.
Alcuin W. Lehman, former president of the Advertising Research Foundation, Inc., died of a heart ailment Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived at 159 East 70th Street.
Production of steel in the week ended Saturday totaled 2,434,000 tons, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

New York Supreme Court Justice Francis J. Bloustein has ordered the General Host Corporation to show cause on Sept. 14 why its shareholder's meeting, held on Aug. 13 in Seattle, should not be annulled and actions taken there be set aside and a new meeting ordered.
Stock prices retained their momentum yesterday, rising sharply along a broad front for the second day.

KENILWORTH, Ill., Aug. 24 Mr. and Mrs. Keith Kindred have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kathleen Kindred, to Walter Fischer Connor of Chicago and Darien, Conn. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Hayden Connor of Darien. The wedding is planned for October.

Mayor Lindsay's urgent appeal to every New Yorker to make sure that he has been counted in the 1970 census is of importance for reasons that go far beyond civic pride. An undercount could cause the city to lose state and Federal revenues it badly needs to improve essential services.
Construction was resumed in New Jersey yesterday pending efforts to resolve a contract dispute that had led to a strike and a lockout.

A Brooklyn businessman sued the New York Telephone Company for $330-million yesterday, charging that his beauticians' supply concern in Bedford-Stuyvesant had been "irreparably injured" by poor telephone service.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 24 Mrs. Anne-Marie Rasmussen Rockefeller, whose marriage to Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller's son Steven ended in divorce last June, will be married to Robert W. Krogstad of Maple Bluff, a Madison suburb, before the end of the year.

PNOMPEPIH, Cambodia, Aug. 24 The municipal government of Pnompenh has issued an emergency appeal to residents to begin raising some of their own food in the city to thwart "the enemy threat to strangle the capital."

The Saturday morning cartoons on the networks were stripped of much of their violence last year, but criticism of the cereal and toy advertisements still abounds, and the broadcasters are touchy about suggestions that they might incorporate a still greater measure of substance to go along with the escapism. The popularity of "Sesame Street" illustrated perhaps most vividly that the omnipotent tube could be a constructive boon to the younger generation.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 24 The Los Angeles County coroner used line drawings today to depict for a jury the number and location of the repeated wounds inflicted on Sharon Tate and four other persons who were slain last August.

That fellow mentioned here last Wednesday who is looking for a job in advertising and wearing a sandwich board listing his attributes and experience was on Madison Avenue yesterday. His name is Fred Ebner, he's a Manhattanite and he was formerly with the display department of Robert Hall Clothes.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Aug. 24 (UPI) More than 45,000 students went to school today in the midst of a diphtheria epidemic that found most of the city's 648,000 residents unprotected.

CHICAGO, Aug. 24 (AP) Forty-two vehicles in the Clean Air Car Race rolled westward today toward Toronto, Ont., and the end of the first leg of a 3,600-mile cross-country run from Cambridge, Mass., to Pasadena, Calif.

MONTREAL, Aug. 24 (UPI) George Stone pitched a threehitter and the Atlanta Braves scored five unearned runs in the seventh inning tonight to defeat Montreal, 6-0, ending the Expos winning streak at five games.
WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., Aug. 24 (UPI) The data-processing division of Honeywell, Inc., has laid off 229 manufacturing employes at two plants in Massachusetts.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 24 (UPI) Orval E. Faubus, six times the Governor of Arkansas, faces seven other candidates tomorrow in the Democratic gubernatorial primary. Gov. Winthrop Rockefeller faces three opponents in the Republican race.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 24 (UPI) President Nixon met today with the four top Government economists and agreed with them that the nation's badly overheated economy had been cooled without prompting a recession.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 24 A Bronxville, N.Y., fatherand-son team won the parent- and-child event during the Class Day program at the 71st annual Grand American Trapshooting tournament today.
HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 24 (Agence France-Prese) Eldridge Cleaver in a speech here has denounced what he described as President Nixon's doctrine of "making Asians fight Asians."

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 24 Fritz Peterson knows it would cost him heavily sort of along the line of an eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth. Except this would be a steak for a steak and a show for a show.

The largest single program in the five-year history of the National Endowment for the Arts a total of $1,680,000 to 34 symphony orchestras throughout the country has begun. A second round of grants, bringing the orchestra program to about $3-million, will be disclosed later, said Nancy Hanks, chairman of the Endowment.

LONDON, Aug. 24 Who should we run into outside Madame Tussaud's but Harry, the well-known expatriate? Harry, you may recall, is the excessively conscientious semanticist who left America because he did not, in any sense of the word that satisfied his respect for verbal precision, love it.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 23 Under an unpublicized military aid program in Southeast Asia, the United States has provided nearly $80-million in arms and other military goods and services to Burma since 1958.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 24 The Giants returned to camp this afternoon, still wondering why they fall apart in the second half every week. The development of Lee White and George Nock as dependable running backs and pass-blockers appears to have decreased the New York Jets need for Bill Mathis in the approaching season.
Two multiple-alarm fires in the Bronx early yesterday routed a number of families from their apartments and resulted in an injury to a woman and a fireman.

If all Presidential trips abroad could accomplish as much in short order as Mr. Nixon's 28-hour visit to Mexico, the case for personal diplomacy at the highest level would be unanswerable. Actually, the ground had been laboriously prepared for the agreement designed to resolve remaining boundary disputes between the United States and Mexico and to set up machinery for heading off such quarrels in the future.

Congress and the public are beginning to wonder whether a credibility gap has developed with the New York Stock Exchange. There is growing speculation, in fact, that this may be the reason for the leaking of private exchange correspondence by Congressional sources.
MIAMI, Tuesday, Aug. 25 (AP) A commercial jetliner with 86 persons aboard was hijacked to Cuba yesterday by a man who said a bomb was aboard.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 24 Further withdrawals of United States troops from Thailand, now under discussion, may exceed 6,000 men, Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman said today.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 24 The Tennessee Valley Authority disclosed today that it planned to build a third large nuclear power plant. The disclosure indicated that, with troubles over coal supplies, T.V.A. was giving more thought to nuclear power production.

NAPANOCH, N.Y., Aug. 24 Several hundred inmates at the Eastern New York Correctional Facility here refused for nine hours today to return to their cells in a protest against what they called inadequate medical treatment.
Capital appropriations for improvement of manufacturing plant and equipment are "poised for an upturn" in the third quarter, the National Industrial Conference Board said yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 25 A dispute involving race was injected today into the election campaign in which Dr. Max Rafferty is trying to win a term as State Superintendent of Public Instruction against the challenge of Wilson Riles. The effect was to emphasize for California voters that Mr. Riles is a Negro.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25 Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Chandley Burke of Buffalo and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Burke's daughter, Mrs. Jeanne Vallely Lang, to James Suydam Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Suydam of New York.

ATLANTA, Aug. 25 (AP) A state senator who is promoting a fight between Cassius Clay and Joe Frazier said today he was "confident" the bout would take place Oct. 26, but Frazier's manager maintained no fight was contemplated.

The American preoccupation with youth culture and inability to face death realistically have led the medical profession to neglect the emotional needs of the dying patient and his family, four doctors have concluded in a report.

SARASOTA, Fla., Aug. 25 The Yanmar Diesel Company of Osaka, one of Japan's largest manufacturing companies, was reported today to have signed a contract to produce a large model of Wallace L. Minto's nonpolluting, Freon-powered engine for use in boats, tractors and auxiliary power plants.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 Angelenos are turning cast for advice on how to make their downtown grow in an orderly fashion.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Aug. 26 (Reuters) An express train traveling at full speed struck a bus, killing seven American airmen and injuring four others at a railroad crossing near Bangkok's Don Muang airport, police sources said today. The bus was taking the airmen to their headquarters from the airport 15 miles north of Bangkok last ...

Mrs. Miriam W. Hassell of 32 Edgewood Road, Hartsdale, N.Y., a classicist who had taught Greek and Latin at Hunter College, died Monday night at Memorial Hospital of cancer. She was 52 years old and the wife of Donald R. Hassel, a vice president of the ManufacturersHanover Trust company.
STOCKHOLM, Aug. 25 (AP) A young American who said he defected from the Marines and fought for the Vietcong arrived in Stockholm with a North Vietnamese passport today and asked for political asylum.

The Penn Central Company's directors elected yesterday Gaylord P. Harnwell to the position of chairman, president and chief executive officer of the holding company. He succeeds Paul A. Gorman, who resigned on Aug. 11.
BARCELONA, Spain, Aug. 15 Any city of 1.8 million inhabitants that manages to keep 60,000 trees along its streets must be doing something right.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 25 Miss Stacey Lee Schneer, a senior at Jackson College of Tufts University, was married here today to David Harold Lee, a 1969 graduate of Tufts. The ceremony at the Fenway Golf Club was performed by Rabbi Paul M. Steinberg, dean of the School of Sacred Music at the Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion in New York.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 25 For most of Tom Gorman's tennis life, instructors kept telling him, the serve was the biggest, most important stroke in the sport. Hold your serve in every game, they stressed, and you cannot lose.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 United States foreign trade showed a booming surplus of exports over imports in July for the second month in a row, the Commerce Department reported today.
Mayor Lindsay, in a move apparently directed at the Police Department, has ordered all heads of city agencies to obey an anticorruption order he originally issued 15 months ago.

BUFFALO, Aug. 25 Thomas P. Flaherty, the DemocraticLiberal candidate for Representative Richard D. McCarthy's Congressional seat, said yesterday that he would stay in the race even though Mr. McCarthy has decided to run for re-election as an independent.

Assemblyman George A. Cincotta, Democrat of Brooklyn announced his candidacy yesterday for his party's nomination for Borough President, to succeed Abe Stark, whose resignation becomes effective Sept. 8.
Welfare rolls in Long Island showed an accelerating rise yesterday, attributed in part to economic difficulties, as was the sharp June surge reported in New York City for June.
SYRACUSE, Aug. 25--Dr. Douglas G. Haring, professor emeritus of anthropology at Syracuse University, died today after a long illness. He was 76 years old.
Price moves announced late Monday by the Cannon Mills Company were followed yesterday by other manufacturers of sheets.

Detectives raided a group of three stores in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn yesterday afternoon and recovered merchandise stolen from piers and in truck hijackings that was valued at more than $500,000, the police said.

Lincoln Hospital in the South Bronx said yesterday that it was terminating its obstetrical and gynecological services because 24 of 28 physicians in the department had walked off their posts in a dispute involving community groups.

Dr. Harry R. Epstein a physician who had practiced in Brooklyn for 30 years before moving to Mahwah, N.J., seven years ago, died of Hodgkin's disease yesterday at Methodist Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 71 years old.
NEWBURGH, N.Y., Aug. 25 Arthur J. Goldberg accused Governor Rockefeller today of having permitted the Hudson River to become "a cesspool."

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 25 While the final arguments were put before the jury in the trial of Lonnie McLucas, a rally in support of the Black Panther defendant attracted 500 people to the Town Green, across the street from the Superior Court Building.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Air Force acknowledged today that it had discarded a plan to put several hundred Minuteman intercontinental missiles into new silos blasted out of solid granite. The plan was determined to be too costly.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 Apparently moving to assure his major creditors that he can meet his loan commitments, Donald H. Parsons met today with representatives of 17 major banks at his office in nearby Birmingham.

Someone appears to have stolen the Glenn Miller orchestra's bus. According to the police at the West 35th Street station, the bus, along with more than $50,000 worth of instruments, arrangements and uniforms, was taken from the Short Line bus garage, 39th Street and 11th Avenue, late Monday or early yesterday. They said the bus had "Glenn Miller Orchestra" painted on both sides and the band's theme, "In the Mood," on the front.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Aug. 25 Leonard Vieth, a former underwater systems development engineer at Bell Laboratories in Whippany, died yesterday at Morristown General Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived on Round Top Road, Bernardsville.

LOWER MACUNGIE, Pa., Aug. 25 Soapy matter wafted into the air by a factory in a copper-recovery operation may have contributed to a bus crash near here that killed seven children, defense lawyers argued today at a preliminary hearing into the accident.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 25 Dr. William Masters and Mrs. Virginia Johnson, the sex researchers, have been sued for $750,000 on the ground that they used the plaintiff's wife to give sexual treatment to two men patients.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 25--Foreign Minister Abba Eban moved today to answer Opposition criticism in the Knesset by disclosing that Ambassador Tekoah had been instructed to raise the question of violations of the cease-fire at his meeting today with Dr. Jarring.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 25 (Agence France-Presse) Most of the defense forces of Pnompenh were reported to have been shipped across the flood-swollen Mekong River today to oppose a suspected heavy concentration of North Vietnamese and Vietcong troops.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 25 The New York Jets sat around the Hofstra fieldhouse today watching films of Sunday's game between the Jets and the Giants.
Inmates set small fires and participated in disorders at the Bronx House of Detention for Men last night.
The board of directors of the Pacific Intermountain Express Company accepted yesterday a previously announced offer by the International Utilities Corporation to acquire the company.

Six persons, all of them apparently bystanders, were wounded in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn last night in an exchange of gunfire between two narcotics squad detectives and two alleged drug pushers.

Mrs. Margaret Wistar Frantz Myers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Gibson Frantz of Princeton, N.J., was married in a civil ceremony in Juarez, Mexico, yesterday to Thomas Dutton Wellington, a New York lawyer. He is the son of Mrs. Herbert Galbraith Wellington of New York and Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mr. Wellington, an investment banker and a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange.
LONDON, Aug. 25 (Reuters) --Two British convents tonight defended the practice of paying expenses for Indian girls to join them as novices.

SOUTH DARTMOUTH, Mass., Aug. 25 Frank K. Heyniger, a director of the Lawrenceville School, Lawrenceville, N.J., land a teaching member of its history department, died yesterday at his summer home here. He was 53 years old.
Service on the Canarsie line of the BMT subway was halted for half an hour during the rush hour last night after the Transit Authority received a tip that a bomb had been placed on a train.

SEOUL, South Korea Wednesday, Aug. 26--Vice President Agnew inspected allied defense positions south of the Korean demilitarized zone this morning after learning how tough the South Koreans can be at the bargaining table.
LAKEWOOD, Colo. They are called agents, not policemen, and all of them, including the men directing traffic, wear Navy blue blazers and gray flannel trousers.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 25 The first concerted diplomatic effort in more than two decades to bring a formal peace settlement to the Middle East opened at the United Nations today amid guarded expressions of optimism by all the parties.

The New Jersey Bridge Association has an unusual asset often referred to as "The Three Barbaras." They are, in alphabetical order, Barbara Birnholz and Barbara Rappaport, both of East Orange, and Barbara Tepper of Livingston.
To her neighbors, Mrs. Maria Cappelli is something of a wonder.

WIESBADEN, West Germany, Aug. 25 (Reuters) West Germany's foreign trade surplus rose to 1.99-billion marks in July from 1.13-billion in June this year and 1.65-billion in July last year, the Federal Statistical Office said today.

The stock market absorbed some heavy profit taking yesterday but rallied late in the session to close slightly higher on some key indicators. Blue-chip stocks leveled off while glamour issues continued to soar.

CAIRO, Aug. 25 A cultural official assured Egyptians today that restorative treatment of the deteriorating solar boat of Cheops would be completed in three months and that the craft would then be moved to a special air-conditioned museum.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Chief Justice Warren E. Burger said today the Supreme Court would hear arguments on the 18-year-old vote case on Oct. 19.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 25 Seven black Syracuse University football players were undecided tonight on whether to sign a sixpoint statement, an action that would reinstate them to the squad. They have until tomorrow, the start of practice, to sign.
COLLEGE PARK, Md., Aug. 25 (AP) A Government entomologist urged scientists to explore possibilities for creating lethal epidemics today among insects by using baits spiked with germs.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) An air traffic controller, mistaking one plane for another on his radar scope, unwittingly sent a twin-engine aircraft with five occupants into the mountainous area in California where it crashed, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.

Leon Fleisher, winner of prizes, teacher of pianists, more recently a left-handed pianist because of trouble with his right hand, now can add conducting to his accomplishments. If he makes a career of it, he will not be the first pianist in history who left the keyboard for the podium.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 25 Miss Sandra Elizabeth Pierce, a granddaughter of the late Albert J. King, founder and first president of Ferncliff Cemetery and Mausoleum in Westchester, will be married to Kevin Francis Macmanus of White Plains. The ceremony will take place on Nov. 7 in St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in New York.

A 15-year old youth angered over a family argument early yesterday morning, poured kerosene over himself and ignited it, the police said.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., Aug. 25 (AP) The late Joseph P. Kennedy, former Ambassador and father of a President and two United States senators, left a will bequeathing the bulk of his vast estate to a foundation for the mentally retarded, named for a fourth son who was killed in World War II.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 25 (AP) President Nixon issued a Labor Day salute to America's working men and women today and announced that he would give a dinner and hold an outdoor torchlight military ceremony at the White House on Labor Day Sept. 7, in honor of labor leaders.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25--The Nixon Administration has concluded it would be a needless gamble with the national security to cut military spending next year much below the ...
Sanford D. Garelik, president of the City Council, called yesterday for a public hearing before the City Council on the expansion plans of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.
Sometime this fall, the nation's largest banks are almost certain to take action to lower the interest rate they charge their biggest and most creditworthy corporate customers.

State judicial officials said yesterday that the summertime schedule in which 11 of the 34 criminal parts of State Supreme Court here are closed for vacations was the only arrangement possible because of staff limitations in the District Attorney's offices and the Legal Aid Society.
LONDON, Aug. 25 A New Yorker and two Lebanese are facing charges here after being arrested at the London Hilton Hotel when the police turned up a cache of arms and ammunition there.

OCEAN CITY, N. J., Aug. 25 (AP)--An engine aboard a sightseeing speedboat with 117 persons aboard exploded in Great Egg Harbor Bay tonight but only one person was hospitalized. Twenty-three other passengers were treated and released at Shore Memorial Hospital.
The Wings of Man will be flapping furiously on weekends this fall in an effort to attract greater business dur- ing the traditionally slow not, months for the big domestic corp carrier.

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 25 Durward Knowles of Nassau, Bahamas, who won the opening race yesterday for the Star Class North American championship, moved a step closer to the title today, when he triumphed in the second event.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 25 With the America's Cup stage to themselves today, Intrepid and Valiant slugged it out for the third time in this final series to pick a Cup defender. Intrepid won by 3 minutes 24 seconds under almost ideal conditions and took a 2-1 lead in victories.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Aug. 25 (Reuters) About 30 people were injured, three of them by police bullets, in a seven-hour battle between policemen and hippies in the heart of Amsterdam last night.
CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 25 Almost every big name in golf was on hand today at the Upper Montclair Country Club as practice for the richest tournament ever held the $300,000 Dow Jones open continued.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Dr. Edgar F. Berman denied tonight that he had ever told a Democratic party group that women were inferior, but he opened a new attack on what he called the "irrational women's libs."

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 25 (AP) Ralph Cornett of Sykesville, Md., won the champion of champions event at the 71st annual Grand American trapshooting tournament today by breaking 100 straight targets in a delayed shootoff.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 25 Getting the jump on her rivals at the start, Title carried the colors of the Claiborne Farm to victory in the feature race at the Spa today. A field of seven competed in the six-furlong sprint for older fillies and mares, and Title, under the riding of Jorge Velasquez registered the triumph in 1:10 3-5.
The Census Bureau reported the population of Queens yesterday as 1,964,147, representing an increase of 154,569, or 8.5 per cent, since 1960.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 25 Rod Laver and Ken Rosewall were the center of attraction, as expected, in the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis tournament today, but 19-year-old Dickie Stockton of Garden City, L.I., stole the show at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

While the Lindsay administration has virtually stopped building vest-pocket parks, some East Side residents are trying to revive one that they first created five years ago a narrow, shaded alley off Lexington Avenue that ultimately succumbed to the ravages of vandalism and litter.
MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (UPI) Nikita S. Khrushchev was declared completely recovered today from a heart ailment after having been kept hospitalized for nearly three months, members of his family said.

Both White House and State Department insist that Vice President Agnew did not change Administration policy on Cambodia when he said: "We're going to do everything we can to help the Lon Nol Government." But, when coupled with his implication that a Communist takeover in Cambodia would make it impossible to withdraw American troops from Vietnam, that assertion certainly bears scant resemblance to what Administration leaders have said before.
YONKERS, Aug. 25 Arthur J. Doran, United States District Court referee in bankruptcy, died today at St. Joseph's Hospital after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 264 Palisade Avenue.
