The Board of Elections reported yesterday that it had received enough petition signatures to designate Representative Adam Clayton Powell as an independent candidate for re-election.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 25 A band of about 50 Israeli extremists of the so-called Greater Israel Movement tried today to establish an illegal Jewish settlement in the Arab village of Battir in the occupied area on the west bank of the Jordan River. The village was a Jewish stronghold of Biblical times. After two hours they were ejected by an Israeli Army patrol.
The police arrested a Good Humor vender in the Bronx yesterday who they said doubled as a heroin dealer and a bookmaker.

The S.S. Kresge Company realized a 23.5 per cent increase in earnings in the second quarter on a sales gain of 15.6 per cent over the previous year, while the half-year profit was up 17.6 per cent with sales 18.8 per cent higher, the midyear report from Detroit headquarters disclosed yesterday.

The Metropolitan Opera is hastening now toward its rendezvous with its openingnight audience, 20 days hence. Its 86th season opens at 8 P.M. on Monday, Sept. 14, at Lincoln Center in what one official identified as the earliest start in the company's history.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI)--A witness testified at a Senate hearing today that there were more all-white and all-black schools now than in 1954, largely because of housing discrimination. He said there was no real difference between segregation in the North and South.

OSSINING, N.Y., Aug. 25 Fifty-five prisoners from two New York City jails arrived at the Ossining Correctional Facility here today, the first contingent of nearly 700 who will be transferred here to relieve overcrowding in the city's prison system.
GRAZ, Austria, Aug. 25 (AP) Dr. Hermann Knaus, whose gynecological studies led, with the work of others, to the rhythm method of birth control, died of a heart attack Sunday. He was 77 years old.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 25 (AP) The Minnesota Twins announced tonight during a game against the Boston Red Sox that a bomb threat had been received and 17,697 persons watching the game in Metropolitan Stadium were ordered to evacuate the park.

The traditional organizations that for decades have championed women's rights to vote to work, to be educated and to serve their communities are facing a challenge from a movement that many consider bizarre, alien and totally unacceptable.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) Senator George S. McGovern disputed today reports that Senate liberals were obstructing the Nixon Administration's welfare reform bill. But he urged several revisions, including one for full Federal control.
PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 25 Eighty-four per cent of Americans say they would vote for a woman for Congress if she were qualified for the job, according to the latest Gallup Poll.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 25 (UPI) Walt Blum piloted Valdo, an 11-1 outsider, to a photo finish victory over Dot Ed's Bluesky today in the feature race at Atlantic City.

The road to losing pennants is paved with wasted opportunities, and the New York Mets unwrapped some massive paying blocks last night before 48,561 spectators at Shea Stadium as they lost to the Atlanta Braves, 7-6.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Treasury Department, in a move designed to encourage people to keep savings bonds until they mature, today added a one half of 1 per cent "bonus" on bonds held five years or more. The increase brings the interest rate on Series E and H bonds to 5 per cent, the maximum allowed under a new law President Nixon signed in San Clemente, Calif., last night.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Senate, imposing a limitation of six hours on debate today scheduled for next Tuesday a vote on its controversial "amendment to end the war."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Interior Department which instigated lawsuits seeking immediate and total elimination of mercury discharges now says small discharges may be permitted if they prove harmless.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 25 (AP) Nicaragua scored twice in the top of the final sixth inning today, then held off a late rally to topple the defending champion, Taiwan, 3-2, in the opening game of the Little League World Series. Sesco Paz, who pitched for Nicaragua, fanned 12.

Senator Joseph Tydings of Maryland is an outstandingly able and progressive legislator who has shown much courage and independence in his six years in the Senate. He is one of only fourteen Senators who has made public any report on his personal finances.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 25--Lonnie McLucas was characterized today by his own attorney as "that shnook" and by the prosecutor as "Mr. Ready Willing and Able" in final arguments before the jury at the end of his 10-week trial in Superior Court here.
MOSCOW, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Soviet Union today concluded an agreement with Peru granting credits worth $30-million for the purchase of Soviet machinery.

MOUNT VISION, N.Y., Aug. 25 (AP) Timothy D. Dow, 27 years old, son of former Representative John Dow of Grandview in Rockland County, was found dead today in a house belonging to his sister in this community near Oneonta.
BOSTON, Aug. 25 (AP) New England television viewers who watched the Red Sox-Twins game tonight had a birdseye view of the bomb scare.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Edwin L. Wisherd, who had retired last Oct. 27 as chief of the photographic laboratories of the National Geographic Magazine, collapsed and died on a visit to the society's offices yesterday. His age was 69.
Some of the fun returned to Fun City last night when the New York City Ballet popped up for its first summer season at the New York State Theater.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 25 (AP) Sergei Prokofiev's opera "The Fiery Angel" brought a capacity opening-night audience to its feet yesterday despite its controversial chorus of three actresses playing bare-bosomed nuns.

Transit authorities from London and Toronto began an investigation of the subway system here yesterday with a ride on the IRT line, interviews with transit employes and a request for accident and maintance statistics from the Transit Authority.
TOKYO Aug. 25 (UPI) The Japanese Government approved today recommendations for liberalizing foreign investment in 323 industries, thus opening 80 per cent of Japan's markets to foreign investment.

Activities. At the Western White House President Nixon designated Sept. 13 as the beginning of National Hispanic Heritage Week and called for special ceremonies to celebrate the contribution of the Spanish to the nation's culture.
On a night of extra-inning games, a bomb threat, and ninth-inning heroics, Dave McNally plodded along to his 20th victory of the season as the Orioles whipped the Oakland A's, 5-l, at Baltimore.
LONDON, Aug. 25. (AP) The British pound dropped to an 11-month low on the foreign exchange market today, but the close at $2.3837 was above the danger point that would threaten another devaluation.

The radical left-wing student movement is collapsing into fragmented, embittered, competing organizations, according to a survey of 50 colleges and universities by the League for Industrial Democracy.

Leonard Bernstein left for an 18-day tour of Japan with the New York Philharmonic yesterday, his 52nd birthday. To mark the occasion, a cake was presented to the conductor by Pan American World Airways in its VIP Lounge at Kennedy International Airport.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass. Police Chief William Obanhein, "Officer Obie" in the movie "Alice's Restaurant," stood in the middle of Main Street directing traffic. As the cars crawled slowly through town, he commented, "Traffic is off almost 50 per cent this summer."

The historic importance of the Arab-Israeli negotiations just begun at the United Nations extends far beyond the regional conflict that Ambassador Jarring seeks to mediate. Nowhere else in the world is there so much danger that the superpowers could be drawn into a confrontation neither of them wants.
MADISON, Wis., Aug. 25 Bomb experts sifted through rubble today for clues to an explosion at the Army Mathematics Research Cnter on the University of Wisconsin campus early yesterday.

That hardiest of cold warriors, George Meany of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., has stampeded the United States Senate into a cut-off of funds for the International Labor Organization. The offense of that body, which only last year received the Nobel Peace Prize amid vast acclaim from Mr. Meany and his associates, has been to appoint a Russian as one of the I.L.O.'s five Assistant Directors.
The American Stock Exchange scored its third consecutive advance yesterday as an afternoon rally put most issues into the plus column in active trading.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Aug. 25 It was a tale of two quarter backs, Dick Shiner and Bob Davis, in the New York Giants football camp today at C.W Post College.
Isidor Kaplan, a textile manufacturer, died yesterday after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived at the Essex House.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Wednesday, Aug. 26 Former Gov. Orval E. Faubus ran up a wide lead over seven opponents in the Democratic primary for Governor yesterday, but he will have to face either Dale Bumpers, a Charleston lawyer, or Attorney General Joe Purcell in a runoff Sept. 8.

Cholera, which has brought travel restrictions to the southern resort area of the Soviet Union, is a severe, often fatal intestinal infection most often spread through contaminated water supplies and treated with intravenous fluids and antibiotics.

RECIFE, Brazil, Aug. 25--The Roman Catholic bishops and priests of Maranhao state in northeastern Brazil have asserted that a young Brazilian priest was tortured by the police to force him to incriminate himself and the work of the church there.
FALL RIVER, Mass. Angie Khoury kept her sewing machine going at a steady clip as she talked about how happy her 3-year-old son Jimmy was in the day care center across the street.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Aug. 25 (AP)--Stockholders of A. J. Industries met today and adjourned for 24 hours to give accountants time to finish their job of counting and verifying proxy statements.

Department stores all over the world are suffering a declining share of the growing consumer market because they are not making shopping either pleasurable or sufficiently exciting, according to the deputy chairman of Harrods, Ltd., of London.
PARIS, Aug. 25 (AP) Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed Cambodian leader, said in an interview published here today that two-thirds of Cambodia was in the hands of his supporters.
Miss Lisa Elliot Schnall, a senior at Pembroke College, and MacRae Lampland Ross, a 1970 graduate of Brown University, will be married in All Souls Unitarian Church here on Sept. 12.

Channel 13, New York's educational television station, announced its fall evening schedule yesterday in conjunction with National Educational Television. The season, which begins Monday, Oct. 5, will include new documentary, news, dramatic and cultural programs, among these a 13-week art series produced by the British Broadcasting Corporation entitled "Civilisation."

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Capitol office of Representative Olin E. Teague, Democrat of Texas has been advertised for several days over a Washington radio station as a sales contact for a health spa operated by H.L. Hunt, the Texas oil millionaire.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (AP) The Senate Banking Committee approved a bill today giving a priority under the Small Business Act to loans sought for development or use of pollution-control equipment.

DETROIT, Aug. 25 Ford Ballantyne Jr., a director of the Wyandotte Chemicals Corporation and vice president and general manager of its chemical specialties group, died here yesterday. He was 54 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last month's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Mortgage prices were essentially unchanged in this week's auction, the Federal National Mortgage Association announced today.
ATHENS, Aug. 25 (AP) The chief Athens coroner said today that Mrs. Stavros S. Niarchos wrote a note just before she took an overdose of barbiturates last May 4.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 25 (UPI) Five Tupamaros guerrillas, members of the organization that is holding an American and a Brazilian as hostages, raided a radio station here today, set off a bomb and fled.

Allstate Insurance Companies reported yesterday that it sustained an underwriting loss on property and liability insurance of $9.3-million in the first half of 1970, compared with an underwriting loss of $5.1-million a year earlier.
Four revivals were announced yesterday for the new season of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

"Myers Liggett?" is the headline of the ad but fear not, Liggett Myers, Inc. is not changing its well known corporate name. It does want the financial community to know, however, that 54 per cent of its sales are in nontobacco products and hence it is running its first corporate adver tising campaign.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, Aug. 26 (Reuters) A Boeing 707 of the British Overseas Airways Corporation dived 2,000 feet over the South China Sea yesterday to avoid three approaching United States warplanes.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 25 The Los Angeles County Coroner testified today that Sharon Tate was suspended by a rope as she was dying.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 (UPI) The Soviet Union has quietly ended its airlift of relief supplies to Peruvian earthquake victims after delivering 21 of the promised 65 planeloads.
Four revivals were announced yesterday for the new season of the Lincoln Center Repertory Company at the Vivian Beaumont Theater.

"Myers Liggett?" is the headline of the ad but fear not, Liggett Myers, Inc. is not changing its well known corporate name. It does want the financial community to know, however, that 54 per cent of its sales are in nontobacco products and hence it is running its first corporate adver tising campaign.
BERLIN, Aug. 25 (Reuters) President Gustav Heinemann of West Germany arrived here today in a United States Air Force plane despite protests rom East Germany.

Welfare reform, so desperately needed, has become something of a political waltz in Washington with the Nixon Administration leading, Congress following lamely and the real necessity for forward movement all but lost in the shuffle. In taking "key forward steps," as Mayor Lindsay described them in testimony before the Senate Finance Committee, the Administration has also taken some "serious backward steps." As a result, the impact of proposed reforms has been considerably diluted.
Yields on high-grade tax-exempt state bonds moved down to a new level yesterday, the lowest in a year and as much as 1 per centage points below the peak reached late in May.

A 30-year-old former city employe has been arrested and charged with impersonating former Human Resources Administrator Mitchell I. Ginsberg or Ginsberg aides to cash $6,000 in stolen or forged checks.

Dr. Belle E. Jacobson, founder and director of the Phonocardiography Laboratory at Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center, the Bronx, died there yesterday after a brief illness. She was 70 years old and lived at 10 Lawrence Park Crescent, Bronxville.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger denied today petitions by four Southern school districts for a delay in school desegregation orders until the Supreme Court rules on the issue of school busing.

LONDON, Aug. 25--Short of seeing Judge Julius Hoffman reenact his famous role in the film of the Chicago conspiracy trial--a film its defendants are hoping to make--one could not ask for better casting than William Burroughs who presided at the one-night performance here of John Burgess's verbatim documentary "Chicago/Conspiracy" at the Open Space Theater.
The London stock market eased slightly yesterday as early gains were lost on a lack of follow-through.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 25 Mayor Lindsay told the National Municipal League today that "there could be a decent environment if Washington decided to change its priorities."
Mr. and Mrs. Dean McCarthy held a family council before they deceided to invite two Fresh Air Fund youngsters to their home in Westport, Conn., this summer.

Ellis E. Erdman, chairman of Trans National Communications, Inc., the New York-based miniconglomerate in the sports and leisure field, issued a statement yesterday seeking to bring shareholders up to date on several lawsuits in which the company is involved.

TICONDEROGA, N.Y., Aug. 25 Governor Rockefeller said today that Senator Charles E. Goodell faced a difficult election campaign because of his strong criticism of President Nixon 's conduct of the war in Vietnam.

Assemblyman Vito P. Battista called yesterday for a "full-scale" inquiry by the State Investigation Commission of the condemnation of 69 homes in the Corona section of Queens to build an athletic field and high school.

With the city's blessing in the form of a proclamation designating today Equality for Women Day, the organizers of the Women's Strike for Equality exuberantly announced final plans yesterday for demonstrations that they said would bring "thousands" to their parade down Fifth Avenue.

Two researchers using psychedelic sounds, lights, pictures and other devices have concluded that ordinary people can have profound religious experiences like those of the great Eastern and Western mystics, without the use of drugs.

KANSAS CITY, Aug. 25 A jubilant ovation from Kansas City fans in the ninth inning turned into a dejected silence tonight when Jim Lyttle singled in the run that gave the Yankees a 2-1 victory over the Royals.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 25 Discarding normal political and ideological alliances, the Senate rejected today a measure advertised by some of its supporters as the "amendment to end the draft."

Most investors have a hazy impression that something evil can befall them when the brokerage house they deal with goes under. But unless they have actually been caught in a collapse, they have no clear idea of their liabilities.

CHICHESTER, England, Aug. 25 Every festival has its troubles, but this year Sir John Clements, director of the Chichester Festival, must have felt like some Old Testament Job beset with boils. The only play to go off without a hitch was Robert Bolt's "Vivat! Vivat Regina!" which I reviewed a few weeks ago.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON, Aug. 25--The police investigating two bombings in this quiet riverfront village--one involving the home of the chief of police--said today that they believed the incidents were the work of a local band of youths and not political radicals.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 25 About 300 villagers from southern Lebanon descended on this capital today demanding Government protection against Israeli attacks. One villager said: "If the Government does not give us protection, we will bring the war to Beirut."

WASHINGTON The boss is away but the official mice are not playing in Washington. They are worrying about the endless frustrations of Vietnam, not so much about the military situation, but about the consequences of what they regard as their growing successes in Southeast Asia.

Two thousand slum youngsters swayed, sang, cheered and sometimes booed yesterday as they watched their contemporaries give a rock and soul concert under the pleasant skies in the band shell area of Central Park.

ATLANTA, Aug. 25 An unmarried Navy enlisted woman whose stillborn child was fathered by an enlisted sailor has filed suit against the United States Navy. She charges that its subsequent decision to dismiss her from service because of terminated pregnancy was based on a double sexual standard and was therefore, a violation of her constitutional rights.

Corn, along with other grains, advanced yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after dropping the day before in a continuation of the furor created by the disclosure of the corn blight in the Middle West last week.

Weeden Co., a brokerage house that specializes in over-the-counter trading in listed securities, the so-called third market, scored a sharp turnaround in profits in the first half of 1970, posting a net income of $1,646,472 in contrast to a net loss of $1,779,928 in the 1969 period.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 25 (Reuters) The Indian Government has asked the British Broadcasting Corporation to end its its operations in India by Saturday, authoritative sources said here today.

SAN CLEMENTE, Aug. 25 For the third consecutive day, a remark by Vice President Agnew that the United States would "do everything" to insure the survival of the Lon Nol regime in Cambodia touched off debate and questioning here today. The confusion created by that comment was only partly resolved.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 25 Mr. and Mrs. William Merrill Barstow Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Lorraine Lyle Barstow, to Francis Walton Love, son of Dr. and Mrs. Freeman Love of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for Oct. 31.

JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 25 Mrs. Albert Bower of Pelham and Mrs. Thomas Hory of Winged Foot took a one-stroke lead today in the first round of the second annual Barbara S. Kirkland Memorial 36-hole Pinehurst golf championship.
HALKIRK, SCOTLAND Cloud shadows raced over the moors as we climbed slowly to a hilltop loch, Airidh Leathaid, where richly marked brown trout awaited us.
METHUEN, Mass., Aug. 26 Teddy Kennedy is running against a number.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 26 Shooting erupted between Arab commandos and the Jordanian police in the heart of Amman today while the guerrillas were preparing for tomorrow's meeting of the Palestinian National Council.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 27 (AP) A big United States Army helicopter carrying about 25 persons was shot down yesterday and fell into an American position, the United States command said today. Initial reports said two Americans had been killed, seven had been wounded and 30 were missing.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 26 The killers of Sharon Tate and four other persons at her home last August apparently used the actress's blood to paint the word "pig" on the front door of her Benedict Canyon mansion, a jury was told today.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP) President Nixon talked with two fellow golfers today Cardinal Cooke of New York and Lawrence Welk, the orchestra leader.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 26 (UPI) American artillerymen shelled a United States unit by mistake killing two G.I.'s and a Vietcong soldier who had defected, the United States command said today.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 26 Authoritative White House sources have declared that the United States is prepared to join the Soviet Union in a twonation peace-keeping force to maintain a settlement of the Middle East conflict.

An unhappy blend of lagging sales, rising expenses and increasing inventory shortages partially attributed to heavy pilferage has inflicted heavy damage on department-store profits in the second quarter.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) The Senate Banking Committee tentatively approved today a program of Federal insurance against burglary and theft in high-crime areas where rates are excessive or policies are unobtainable.
PLAINFIELD, N.J., Aug. 26 George G. Winspear, a chemcal engineer who served the rubber industry 25 years, died yesterday at his home, 1415 Martine Avenue, after a short illness. He was 66 years old.
NEW HAVEN, Aug. 26 A jury of 10 whites and two blacks began its deliberation today in the trial of Lonnie McLucas, but retired for the evening without reaching a verdict.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 26 Bob Carmichael, the Australian now representing France, and Dickie Stockton, a last-minute replacement, scored big upsets as the field was completed today for the quarterfinals in the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis championships at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

Life insurance companies are not exactly broadcasting it, but when you pay for coverage by the month you may be charged as much as 16 per cent more for the same insurance than if you had paid for it by the year.

CAIRO, Aug. 26 Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian commando leader, conferred with President Gamal Abdel Nasser again today, following a threehour meeting last night, to discuss the Palestinian movement in the context of present efforts for a political settlement with Israel by the United Arab Republic and Jordan.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Aug. 26 (UPI) Attorneys for a young soldier charged with the murder of South Vietnamese civilians asked today that legal proceedings against their client be moved from "this antiseptic courtroom" to Mylai 4. The hamlet is in the village of Songmy, Vietnam, where the alleged massacre occurred on March 16, 1968.

The outbreak of pesticide poisonings in the North Carolina tobacco fields, including several deaths, has led the United States Department of Agriculture to accelerate its search for safer alternatives to parathion, the highly toxic chemical now being used.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 26 Lord Caradon, the former British representative at the United Nations, arrived here from London today to try to save a South Korean graduate of Cambridge University who has been sentenced to death on charges of having spied for North Korea.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 26 Mayor Lindsay to the contrary, this city is almost immaculate by comparison with New York City.

New York City Ballet never does anything by halves. In the spring, no fewer than three principal male dancers were hired, and just before the summer season two leading female dancers were injured, insuring a plethora of interesting castings.
Fifty years ago today, Bainbridge Colby, Secretary of State of the United States, certified that the 19th Amendment had become valid as part of the Constitution.

BASS RIVER, Mass., Aug. 26 Frederick E. King, senior partner in the New York law firm of King O'Conor, died here Saturday, apparently of a heart attack. He was 76 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.
CAMP PENDLETON, Calif., Aug. 26 (AP) Guards in the Marine Correctional Center quelled a four-hour melee, officially termed "a race riot," early today.
BURLINGTON, Mass., Aug. 26 A fire bomb was hurled into the town's temporary police station last night, and the wooden structure was heavily damaged.
The corporate bond market yesterday shook off the doubts it harbored in mid-August.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 26 Three women, wearing colored paper badges on their blouses that proclaimed "Eve Power" and "self-support," struck a strong, joyous, blow for liberation today by walloping the high-powered males in sailing competition. The occasion was the beginning of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's 38th race week and the successful revolutionaries were the winners in the Resolute Class.
Although weeding out continued at the Jets' camp yesterday, Coach Weeb Ewbank still was confronted by a tangled quarterback situation.
NEW DELHI, Aug. 26 Foreign Minister Swaran Singh announced in Parliament today that the Government had ordered an inquiry into the reported sale of Indian girls to West European convents.
Stock prices moved ahead slightly yesterday on brisk volume as the market continued to consolidate its recent spectacular advance.

The director of psychiatry of the city's Correction Department announced her resignation yesterday, charging that the department's mental health program for its 12,000 inmates was "disgracefully inadequate" and impervious to attempts to improve it.

A group of parents in the old Intermediate School 201 Demonstration School District in Harlem and in District Five, into which I.S. 201 was merged under the State Education Act, petitioned the central Board of Education yesterday to suspend or remove the newly elected board of the enlarged district.

The principal theoretician of the women's liberation movement is a 35-year-old former Barnard instructor who lives in a Bowery loft. She swears, one friend says, "like a gunnery sergeant," and stands to make $100,000 from a book on how tough it

Billie Jean King, the country's most successful woman athletic star, says she is never offended by people who tell her she plays tennis just like a man. But she has become increasingly irritated by people who ask her when she's going to settle down and attend to a home and family.

For the vast majority of women, yesterday was a day simply to go about one's business whether that meant going to a job, attending a Broadway matinee, having one's hair done or washing the baby's diapers.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 26 The Israeli Chief of Staff has signed orders for the detention of two Algerian citizens seized Aug. 14 when a British airliner in which they were flying from the Far East to Europe landed in Lydda.

Two prisoners who said they returned $4-million worth of stolen jewels last fall in return for a promise of early parole now want the gems back because they say the "deal" they thought they had made with state law-enforcement authorities hadn't worked out.

The presiding justices of the Appellate Divisions of State Supreme Court who have jurisdiction in the New York metropolitan area said yesterday that officials had no administrative authority to implement a suggestion that defendants charged with nonviolent misdemeanors be released pending trial.

Sammy Reshevsky of Spring Valley, N.Y., has proved again and most emphatically that he is a hard man to beat. During the recent tournament in Buenos Aires, Reshevsky finished in a tie for fourth place, scoring 10 -6 , without one loss.
The United States is planining to use its most advanced aerial reconnaissance system to monitor continuously the ceasefire in the Middle East.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 (AP) The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today a 10 per cent increase in the price of a ticket on 22 railroads, including the financially troubled Penn Central, which stands to gain $3.3-million in additional revenues.

The Firestone Tire Rubber Company reported yesterday a drop of 27.6 per cent in earnings for the third fiscal quarter ended July 31 and a 17.3 per cent decline for the nine months, despite record sales achieved in both periods.

Whoever said that when you've seen one ice revue you've seen them all also has to figure out how to set Shakespeare to skates. And the family crowd that came to the opening of the 26th "Holiday on Ice" last night at Madison Square Garden obviously didn't miss the Bard.
BOSTON Just at 2 P.M. a flatbed truck parks in the shade on a deadend street near the heart of the city and is quickly transformed into a stage on which 10 lively young people perform a rock musical.

FORTTICONDEROGA, N.Y., Aug. 26 The 18th-century cannons boomed, the bagpipes skirled, the flags fluttered and the uniforms provided a panoply of patriotic color as John H.G. Pell, president of the Fort Ticonderoga Corporation, officiated yesterday at ceremonies commemorating the 150th anniversary of the purchase of the fort and garrison grounds by William Ferris Pell, his great-great-great-grandfather.

Celebrating the 50th anniversary of American women's right to vote and the start of a new crusade for equality a crowd of more than 10,000 people, mostly women of all ages, occupations and viewpoints, marched down Fifth Avenue to an enthusiastic rally in Bryant Park last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The American Educational Theater Association, ending its 34th annual convention today, sought to make itself responsive to current issues by changing its bylaws to enfranchise all members, especially students, and to guarantee equal job consideration for women members.

The Leasco Data Processirig Corporation announced yesterday it would continue to pursue its bid for control of Pergamon Press, Ltd., the British publishing concern, despite the latter's reported loss in 1968 and for the first nine months of 1969.
SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 26 President Park, apparently reassured by Vice President Agnew, has softened his stiff position on the United States plan to reduce its forces in Korea.

Chile is heading for a Presidential election certain to put a heavy strain on one of the few remaining democratic systems in Latin America. The outcome could be something without precedent anywhere in the world: the election by democratic, constitutional process of a Marxist, nominated by the Communists and his own even more extreme Socialist party.
"Look at the dragon!" little children shouted as a 30-footlong papier-mache beastie crept down Henry Street yesterday in a parade that signaled the start of the third annual Lower East Side Festival.

CHARLEVILLE MEZIERES, France, Aug. 26 Huge bulldozers continued today to level prairie land a few miles outside this northern city of 60,000 people. But the factory for which they had been preparing the land will be built 400 miles to the southwest, a fact that has created a furor in France.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. Aug. 26 (AP) The captain of a Greek tanker owned by Aristotle Onassis has been charged with failing to report an oil spill in Tampa Bay last week, state officials said today. It was the first arrest under Florida's 1970 Oil Spillage Act.

Mayor Lindsay and Senator Ribicoff got into a wrangle at a Senate hearing this week over whether New York or Bridgeport had dirtier streets. No New Yorker will be surprised to learn that on-the-spot inspection indicates that a "filthy street" contest between this city and Bridgeport is no contest at all Bridgeport's streets are immaculate by comparison with those here.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 26 (UPI) Three persons died and seven others were injured, one critically in a two-car clash at 12:41 A.M. today here at Jerusalem and Holly Avenues.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Supporters of an amendment seeking equal rights for women began today a full-fledged lobbying campaign on Capitol Hill.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 26 City officials here announced plans today for a New York concern to embark on a $10-million industrial development project that would include expansion of the New Haven port which is now the third busiest in New England.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 A Senate subcommittee heard testimony today that the health of Americans has been more seriously endangered by lead, cadmium and other toxic metals in the environment than by the widely publicized threat from pesticides.
Placard-toting females paraded up and down Wall Street yesterday, calling for women's liberation. It was all part of the Women's Strike for Equality.

An international heroin- smuggling ring whose business exceeded half a billion dollars a year in street sales has been smashed with the arrest of two Americans in Europe, the Federal Government announced yesterday.
"The White House Murder Case" and "Dick and Jane," by Jules Feiffer (Grove, $4.50). Two plays in book form.

A move by Commissioner of Investigation Robert K. Ruskin to force three New York policemen to testify, about an alleged payoff list was likened in State Supreme Court yesterday "to taking a prisoner in a station house and beating his head with a rubber pipe."

PARIS, Aug. 26 Xuan Thuy, Hanoi's chief delegate at the Vietnam peace negotiations, returned here today after a threemonth absence and appeared open to suggestions for a renewal of secret talks with the United States.

Parks Commissioner August Heckscher charged yesterday that a plan to expand Kennedy International Airport into Jamaica Bay "would destroy the city's last nature frontier," fail to solve airlines' problems, wreck the bay's famed wildlife refuge and "doom" the proposed Gateway National Rec reation Area.
AMHERST, Mass., Aug. 26 Brian Dowling is one of those college football stars who has found the professional ranks hard to crack.
The New York Telephone Company has called in a 48year-old, executive vice president of the parent American Telephone and Telegraph Company to help solve its problems.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 26 Ambassador Tekoah conferred today with Foreign Minister Abba Eban about tactics for the indirect peace talks with the United Arab Republic and Jordan. Foreign Ministry officials said that Mr. Tekoah would probably not return to New York before the weekend, but his precise plans would be decided through in the 22-year-old Arab- Israeli conflict, even before the cease-fire, deadline expires Nov. 5.
A fire reportedly of suspicious origin ruined part of British Overseas Airway's Corporation's new $56-million terminal at Kennedy International Airport yesterday morning.

J. Ralph Alderfer is a beagler. He has had beagles for 37 years. "I was 5 years old when my father gave me a dog," he recalled. "When I was 12, I had three and was running them in sanctioned trials against professional handlers. I have had some...

Betty Friedan was 20 minutes late for her first scheduled appearance in connection with the Women's Strike for Equality yesterday morning because of a lastminute emergency appointment with her hairdresser.

Chain store sales in July, based on figures from 28 companies, indicate a gain of 7.9 per cent for the month. For the year to date, the retail operators with multiple stores are 8.3 per cent ahead of the level for the corresponding 1969 period.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., Aug. 26 Harry E. Seaman, a supervisor in the engineering-information department at Bell Laboratories in Murray Hill, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital. He was 47 years old and lived at 292 Timberline Road, Mountainside.

KANSAS CITY, Aug, 26 The Yankee detachment of the 389th Training Regiment, only five days removed from Fort Dix, overcame the dubious base-running tactics of some of their barracks mates and led New York to a 3-0 victory over Kansas City tonight.
Traders interested in taking profits brought wide price swings into the major commodity futures pits on the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 United States international monetary reserves declined by $263-million in July as foreign currency holdings took anther large drop.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The Senate defeated today two more amendments to the military procurement bill that it has been wrestling with for five weeks.
Stanley S. Palmer, a commercial printer and a prominent bridge player, died Tuesday after an accident at his business premises. He was 43 years old and lived in Roslyn, L.I.

There is general agreement that Lincoln Hospital is a medical disaster area in urgent need of reclamation. In this period of doctor shortage when many alternative jobs are available, it requires physicians with special dedication to the needs of the disadvantaged to be willing to work under the handicaps that hinder their every step at Lincoln.

CHICAGO, Aug. 26 (AP) Two tear gas grenades were thrown into a crowded downtown theater last night, stopping a performance of a Soviet dance troupe and sending patrons choking and gagging toward the exits.
ANCHORAGE, Aug 26 (UPI) Gov. Keith Miller won the Republican gubernatorial nomination yesterday.

THUNDER BAY, Ontario It's not like the boom of 1966-67, when Russian bread was being baked with Canadian wheat, but the flow of grain through the tall, cylindrical terminals here at the head of the Great Lakes has picked up appreciably this year.
AMSTERDAM, Aug.26 Hippies battled with the police for the third consecutive night tonight protesting a ban on their sleeping in Dam Square.

JERICHO, L.I., Aug. 26 Mrs. Gordon McGrath of Piping Rock and her sister, Mrs. Justine Cushing of Meadow Brook, won the second annual Barbara S. Kirkland Memorial 36-hole Pinehurst golf championship today.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (Reuters) After being under pressure for most of the day, the English pound made a big rally on the foreign exchange market here tonight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, Aug. 27 Vice President Agnew told President Chung Hee Park of South Korea yesterday, before traveling on to Taiwan and South Vietnam, that all American troops would be withdrawn from South Korea when that country's armed forces were fully modernized perhaps in five years or more.

Women employes and members of the top editorial management at Newsweek exchanged verbal bouquets yesterday morning as they came together to sign a pledge by the magazine to accelerate its recruitment and promotion of women.

Although knocked out after giving up 14 hits and five runs, Jim Merritt became the first Cincinnati left-hander in 45 years to reach the 20game plateau last night as the Reds scored a 6-5 victory over the Phillies at Philadelphia.
OSSINING, N.Y., Aug. 26 A work stoppage by 85 bus drivers in a union jurisdictional dispute halted Westchester Coach Company service today on the western side of Westchester County.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Proceedings began today that could lead to import restrictions against products of the European Common Market countries on the ground the market is discriminating against United States exports of citrus fruits.
VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 26 (AP) Four titles in clay-target championships were decided today during shooting at the 71st Grand American trapshooting tournament

Raphael R. Murphy, who retired in 1953 as a city magistrate, after 23 years on the bench, died Tuesday in St. Elizabeth's Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived at 5410 Netherland Avenue, Riverdale, the Bronx.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Aug. 26 A 21-year-old Groton woman was given a 30day contempt of court jail sentence this morning after she stripped naked in front of Circuit Court Judge George E. Kinmonth

New York's largest commercial banks are expecting operating difficulties at the beginning of next week, when 350,000 to 400,000 families will receive their first authorizations to purchase food stamps as the city starts its participation in the antipoverty pro gram.
The London stock market rallied in late trading yesterday after dipping in an earlier rash of selling.

RHINEBECK, N.Y., Aug. 26 Nancy Baroody of Lakeville, Conn., scored a double today when she rode Friar Tuck and Shenandoah Flintstone to pony hunter championships at the Dutchess County Fair horse show.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 26 (Reuters) Three more cases of cholera were diagnosed in Jerusalem today, bringing to 14 the number of cases reported here since the outbreak of the illness six days ago.
Gov. Linwood Holton of Virginia appealed yesterday for support of public schools this fall. He did so as more desegregation came to scattered Southern school districts for the first time.

ROME, Aug. 26 (UPI) The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano today accused the world press of sensationalism in its handling of allegations that Indian priests had sold impoverished peasant girls to West European convents that are short of recruits.

The New York Mets played Tuesday night's game in reverse at Shea Stadium last night and lost again. Taking a 7-1 lead into the seventh inning, they saw their margin shrink to 7-6 going into the ninth, and they were finally beaten, 9-7, when a two-run homer by Hank Aaron off Gary Gentry gave the Atlanta Braves the lead.

PARIS, Aug. 26 Paris and Algiers have avoided an open break over Algeria's oil policy and, it was announced today, will open high-level talks in Algiers tomorrow to lay the basis for future cooperation.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 26 Dr. Irving Grenadier, an orthodontist with offices here and in the Bronx, died today of a heart attack at his home, 77 Spier Road, His age was 58.
Every day, more and more New Yorkers, dressed as in a Ruritanian operetta, with merry peasants and gypsies dash for cabs on Park Avenue or flounce down subway stairs. The older and richer...

State Supreme Court Justice Arnold G. Fraiman signed a restraining order at 11 o'clock last night barring community groups from "interfering with patient care and medical services" at Lincoln Hospital.

Corrective measures have been taken in an attempt to avoid a repetition of factors that caused a woman to die and 50 other persons to be overcome by smoke as the aftermath to an electrical fire on Aug. 1 in the IRT Lexington Avenue subway tunnel near the Bowling Green station.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26 Secretary General Thant reported today that the United Nations budget for 1971, under inflationary pressures, would be a record despite bigpower warnings that increases must be halted.
The New York bridge scene was deprived of one of its most enthusiastic and popular personalities when Stanley Palmer of Roslyn, L.I., died Tuesday following an accident.
SINGAPORE, Aug. 26 The Government announced today its intention to terminate its aviation landing rights agreement with Britain when it expires in 12 months.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary, in a major reorganization of the Police Department, ordered yesterday the establishment of special new anticorruption teams in each of the department's major units.

LONDON, Aug. 26 Down to the National Portrait Gallery to see the new painting of Princess Margaret which is causing the great controversy. Well, the press says there is a great controversy, but the British public is not stampeding the gallery this morning with portraitslashing devices. There are exactly eight of us in the presence of the controversial canvas; and all are breathing normally.

NORWICH, N.Y., Aug. 26 Trying to induce local communities to tackle the narcotics problem, Governor Rbckefeller disclosed today that he had called on local officials to develop narcotics control programs or face the loss of existing state aid for health and mental health programs.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that the Soviet Union had conducted first tests of warheads on its principal intercontinental ballistic missile, the SS-11.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 26 Carlton S. Proctor, a retired consulting engineer, who was a leading designer and supervisor of construction of substructures of buildings, dams and bridges, died yesterday in Lawrence Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived at 21 Northway.

Two policemen were seriously wounded early this morning in what the police said was an apparently unprovoked gunfight in the Springfield Gardens section of queens. One of the policemen's three assailants was killed and another was believed wounded.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Miss Elissa Celeste Spinetta and David Stephen Ruggieri plan to be married Nov. 7 at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Georgetown.

"Inga" is at it again, as "Eugenie." This time the lippy young Swedish actress, Marie Liljedahl, has shifted operations southward to what looks like the Mediterranean coast of Spain, where some dead-eyed parasites spend a weekend house party wallowing in sex and sadism. And that is absolutely all that happens in this atrociously written, directed and performed waste of perfectly good raw film.
WHITE DOG, Ontario, Aug. 20 Norbert Michaud, a large, rawboned man, sat in his kitchen and made small talk with two women and a child.

GENEVA, Aug. 26 Sir Eric Wyndham White, head of Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., and Bernard Cornfeld, former head of the mutual funds concern, tonight had their first meeting since Mr. Cornfeld started his campaign to regain control.
Henry D. Lloyd Jr., a director of The New York Daily News and its parent Tribune Company, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Barrington, R.I. He was 62 years old.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 A coalition of Jackson, Miss., bankers that includes two members of a committee set up by the Nixon Administration to promote support for public schools has granted a $600,000 loan to a group of private segregated schools.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 The National Transportation safety Board reported today that many children were endangered by "inadequate and inefficient" bolting and riveting of school bus bodies.

Chief Justice Warren E. Burger's refusal to grant a delay in the desegregation of four Southern school districts does not mean that the Supreme Court has now committed itself to a policy of mandatory busing. On the contrary, Justice Burger has been emphatic on the need to have the Supreme Court clarify the intent and limits of its 1954 landmark decision.

Assemblyman Vito P. Battista, Republican from Brooklyn met with members of the State Commission of Investiga-, tion for more than an hour and a half yesterday to detail what he alleged, were improprieties in the condemnation of 69 homes in the Corona section of Queens to make way for a new high school and athletic field.

A lawyer for the Chicago Seven said last night that a magazine article just published was the defense's first information that Federal District Judge Julius J. Hoffman may have twice rejected messages from the jury that it was deadlocked.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 26 Gretel II and Intrepid returned from sea today looking very much like the yachts that will battle for the America's Cup.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 26 While everyone was considering whether the new $300,000 Dow Jones open would create another golfing millionaire here this week, a standby pro, Herb Hooper, and Dick Lotz, who had his entire set of clubs stolen a month ago, shared preliminary honors in the proamateur introductory event today with a 66.
They're at the top of their field. Or else they were the first women to crack it. Others have achieved celebrity status because they are married to famous men.

TURIN, Italy, Aug. 26 (AP) the United States, although many of its leading swimmers are competing in Japan, finished one, two in the three men's finals and took second in the two women's events today on the opening day of the sixth World University Games.

Mrs. Beverly Moss Spatt, who as a member of the City Planning Commission has been a constant thorn in the side of the Lindsay administration, was proposed yesterday for the post of Brooklyn Borough President.
SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 26 (UPI) A strike by the United Farm Workers Organizing Committee in the nation's "salad bowl" forced lettuce prices up today by as much as 100 per cent around the country.
It was another bullish day on the American Stock Exchange yesterday as the list turned in its fourth consecutive gain in the heaviest volume in almost three months.
LONDON, Aug. 26 The Foreign Office said tonight that it regretted the decision by the Indian Government to close the offices in New Delhi of the British Broadcasting Corporation.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 26 The Arab commando leadership, which feels a growing sense of isolation in the midst of the current efforts toward a Middle Eastern peace settlement, is attaching increasing importance to the support of ultramilitants around the world.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 George Romney, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, told a Senate committee today that his department would not follow the recommendation of a Presidential panel to withhold Federal funds from suburban communities that bar low-income housing.
WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 26 Miss Esta Jacqueline Milchman and Frederick Alan Rapoport were married this evening in Temple Israel Center by Rabbi Max Gelb.

Arthur J. Goldberg and all other Democrats running for statewide office in the November election issued a statement yesterday calling for "a distinguished and nonpartisan screening panel to interview and approve all candidates" for the State Supreme Court in Manhattan and the Bronx.
PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 26 State and city officials prepared today for an expected confrontation with radical groups that have threatened to disrupt the American Legion's national convention here.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Aug. 26 The World Youth Orchestra, conducted by Erich Leinsdorf, got a standing ovation and was widely acclaimed by Copenhagen's music critics after its first performance here last night.
NORFOLK, Va., Aug. 26 (AP) The city of Norfolk and the automobile heir Walter P. Chrysler Jr. announced today an agreement that will bring Mr. Chrysler's multimillion-dollar art collection here.

ANKARA, Turkey, Aug, 26 The Government has asked the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York to supply details on a hoard of antiquities, including gold said to come from the kingdom of Croesus, that is alleged to be in the museum's basement after having been illegally exported from Turkey.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 A Boeing Company scientist, who had been cited as the author of a report that the supersonic transport would make big changes in the environment, said today that further studies had shown that the atmospheric effects would in fact be negligible.

Edward Lownan, who is a doctor, likes to cook. And he likes to cook for friends. And his friends like what he cooks. Thus, in 1964, he offered to 300 of those friends a highly personal Christmas gift a collection of his recipes.
LONDON, Aug. 25 Bail was refused today for a New Yorker and two Lebanese held here on charges of unlawfully possessing arms that were reportedly destined for the Middle East.
WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 26 (AP) Janice Metcalf of Claremont, Calif., scored the first upset of United States women's amateur grass-court tennis championships today at Wilmington Country Club.
CAIRO, Aug. 26 (Reuters) The Middle East News Agency reported today that a plot against the Sudanese Government was foiled last Thursday.
PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 26 (Agence FrancePresse) The Cambodian Government is to end a press censorship committee formed in March, it was learned here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Led by a sharp drop in farm prices, the Government's wholesale price index declined this month for the first time in two years.

DETROIT, Aug. 26 Sniper attacks, terrorist bombings, shootouts and rising assaults against big-city policemen are causing deep concern among the police about their personal safety and ability to do their job.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Louis E. Wolfson, the financier who finished a term in a Federal prison last January, told a Congressional subcommittee today of "harassment and mental cruelty," "sadistic guards" and other conditions that he said he had found in prison.
SPRINGFIELD, Mo., Aug. 26 (AP) The battle for control of A.J. Industries, Inc., ended today with the management retaining four of seven board seats.
Tomorrow, Scientific American celebrates its 125th anniversary, which isn't too bad a feat in a field as volatile as magazine publishing.

Activities, President Nixon, from the Western White House in San Clemente, Calif., issued a proclamation saluting the 19th Amendment, which gives women the right to vote. He met with Cardinal Cooke and Francis Cardinal McIntyre.
LONDON, Aug. 26 (AP) Consumer nations in the international coffee talks rejected today a Brazilian proposal for a 48-million-bag 1970-71 coffee export quota.
A "significant drop"-in job opportunities for New York City's poor is indicated in analyses of the latest welfare case loads, according to Mayor Lindsay's consultant on welfare reform.
WINTER HAVEN, Fla., Aug. 26 (UPI) George Dare Fleck, a pioneer broadcast industry official and editor of the first broadcasting magazine, died here yesterday. He was 88 years old.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 26 Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations representative for the Middle East, conferred today with Egyptian and Jordanian delegates as the peace talks here went into their second day despite the temporary absence of the Israeli representative.
On Broadway and off Broadway, it is the people who go to the plays. But in New York City in the summer, more and more, it is the plays that go to the people.
WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 26 (AP) Steve O'Neil pitched a no-hitter, the second today, as Wayne, N.J., defeated Valley. field, Quebec, 10-0, in a firstround Little League World Series game.

ROME, Aug. 26 (Reuters) The Most Rev. James Edward Walsh, the American bishop who was released last month after 12 years in a Chinese jail, praised China's Communist Government today for banning all public displays of indecency and immorality.

Time the space of only two short years and a conscientious, purposeful transfer from television to the screen have dealt J.P. Miller's drama, "The People Next Door," a near fatal blow. This is the highly acclaimed story of two neighboring middle-class families almost split wide open by some generation-gap, revelations involving two youngsters. Beamed into the living room, minus frills, from the small home box, it must have been a thunderbolt. Not now.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 26 The engagement of Miss Virginia Roper Fox to the Rev. Joseph Paul Wagenseller, son of Mrs. Wayne M. Wagenseller of Harrisburg, Pa., and the late Rev. Mr. Wagenseller, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Heywood Fox of New Canaan.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 26 A million dollars in fines was imposed on the Chevron Oil Company in United States District Court here today in a case stemming from massive oil pollution of the Gulf of Mexico.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Thursday, Aug. 27 (Reuters) Thailand has begun negotiations with the Saigon Government for the withdrawal of the 12,000 Thai combat troops serving in South Vietnam, Premier Thanom Kittikachorn said today.
Directions for reaching Upper Montclair Country Club, at Clifton, N.J., site of the $300,000 Dow Jones open today through Sunday:

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 26 Indian Harbor Yacht Club of Greenwich, Conn., gained possession of the Everett B. Morris Trophy today when the 48-foot sloop, Carina, the winner of this year's Newport-toBermuda race, placed first in the Beach Point Yacht Club's 14th annual junior overnight race for the junior distance sailing championship of Long Island Sound.

SANDY SPRING, Md., Aug. 26 Allen T. Baldwin, a retired chemical engineer and longtime resident of Montclair, N.J., died here today at Friends House, a Quaker retirement home. He was 84 years old. Mr. Baldwin was the father of Nona Baldwin Brown, Sunday correspondent for The New York Times in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 26 Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird said today that South Korea's request for $3billion in military assistance and equipment over the next five years was neither feasible nor realistic, given the present attitudes of Congress.

The American Stock Exchange yesterday issued its report on changes in stockholdings of major stockholders, directors and officers of listed corporations. The New York Stock Exchange did not issue an insiders report. The American Stock Exchange list includes the following:
Ninety minutes after the Canarsie branch of the First National City Bank in Brooklyn was robbed of $10,000 yesterday morning, three suspects were arrested and all but $1,000 of the money recovered.
The marriage of Miss Elayne Lerner to Elliott Grossbard took place here last night at the Fifth Avenue Synagogue. Rabbis Solomon Scharfman and Baruch Silverstein performed the ceremony.

LONDON, Aug. 26 Although he was the first playwright to put football crowds and student revolutionaries on the British stage, Peter Terson is not primarily a social dramatist: and "Spring-Heeled Jack" at the Jeannetta Cochrane theater, his fourth play written for the National Youth Theater Company, reveals him again as a poet.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 26 Forward Gal, under a persistent ride by Frank Ianelli and aided by a "runout" of a well-backed rival, won the $84,600 Spinaway Stakes today at Saratoga race course.

A spokesman for the taxi industry charged yesterday that assaults this week in Harlem on cab drivers, one of whom was killed, were part of a pattern by which slum-area militants attempt to terrorize drivers in such areas.
"Ballet is a woman," George Balanchine has said. So much for the Women's Lib aspect of last night's opening in Central Park's Delacorte Theater of the free-admission New York Dance Festival.
The Union Carbide Corporation announced yesterday that it planned to raise prices of several low-density polyethylene resins beginning Oct. 1.

Miss Marguerite Trenholm Robb, better known as Trenny Robb, the model, was married last Sunday to Robert Pforzheimer, a former student at New York University. The Rev. Gerry Wrixson performed the Protestant ceremony in the woods on the 20-acre property the bride has rented for two summers in Rio, N.Y., north of Port Jervis.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 27 (AP) The 68 members of the Syracuse University football team, all but two of them white, walked off the practice field today in an apparent symbolic counter-boycott to one staged earlier in the year by suspended black players.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 27 The campaign workers sat around the table at party headquarters. Their leader urged them on and advised that they "concentrate on areas where we have support, and forget the others." On the walls were charts of key voting districts, next to the party's symbol, the Star of Bethlehem.
Honeywell, Inc., decided after lengthy studies that the acquisition of the General Electric Company's computer operations provided it with the best opportunity to expand its share of the market.

SOUTH BYRON, N.Y., Aug. 27 Two railroad tank cars, each carrying 30,000 gallons of a highly volatile and toxic sub stance known as vinyl chloride exploded a few miles from this farming village today when 28 cars of a Penn Central freight train were derailed.
Governor Rockefeller rolled out the red carpet yesterday for Miss Universe Marisol Malaret, who had been Miss Puerto Rico. The Governor's hospitality cost about $15,000 of his own money.

Bob Gibson, almost baseball's forgotten man last spring after suffering a muscle pull, reeled off his seventh straight victory yesterday as the St. Louis Cardinals halted the streaking Giants, 4-1, at San Francisco.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 27 Mrs. Babette Regner Eisenberg, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Sidney L. Regner of New York, was married here this evening to Julian K. Melmed. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Melmed of Stamford, Conn.

Pushed by the problems of day-to-day living here and pulled by the promise of a more satisfying way of life abroad, many of New York's most capable citizens are giving up their jobs, careers, homes and friends to resettle oveseas.
The United States Weather Bureau issued this forecast at 7 P.M. yesterday for New Yorh Harbor, Long Island and nearby coastal waterss
Paul O'Dwyer, a leader of the Reform Democrats in the state, was named New York City campaign manager yesterday for the statewide Democratic ticket headed by Arthur J. Goldberg.
KANSAS CITY, Aug. 27 When Amos Otis saw his former manager, Gil Hodges, at the All-Star Game last month, Hodges wished him luck in his job as center fielder of the Kansas City Royals.
Supreme Court Justice Moses Weinstein ordered the Queens Liberal party yesterday to hold a new election for county chairman.
NEWSPORT, R.I., Aug. 27 Baron Marcel Bich will sail France tomorrow against Gretel II of Australia in the fourth race of their America's cup challenge series.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 27 Mrs. M. Stuart Roesler of Stanwich, Mrs. Harry M. Day of Woodway, Mrs. Carl T. Chadsey Jr. of Round Hill and Mrs. James R. Hand of Sleepy Hollow combined to card a 39, 34-73 today at the Stanwich Club to win the best-ball-offoursomes championship of the women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association by three strokes.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 Dr. Jesse L. Steinfeld, Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, said today that the health effects of mercury, lead, arsenic, cadmium, and other toxic substances in the environment were not a cause for hysteria.

Charles Plohn Co. and the First Devonshire Corporation, two financially troubled brokerage houses that were suspended from membership in the New York Stock Exchange last week, were charged yesterday by the Securities and Exchange Commission with various violations of securities laws.

A California doctor who says he originated the Spiro Agnew watch has filed suits against S. Klein Department Stores, Inc., and a watch company here alleging that they have infringed on his copyright on a caricature of the Vice President by selling their own such watches.

LONDON, Aug. 27 (AP) Consumer nations in the international coffee talks rejected today a proposal to break the deadlock on export quotas for 1970-71 as Brazil angrily denied charges that she was responsible for high world coffee prices.
The stealing of the city's trash baskets from street corners has become so widespread that there are now stretches of 6 to 10 blocks in the heart of Manhattan without a basket.
MOSCOW, Aug. 27 Sergei A. Vinogradov, the Soviet Ambassador to the United Arab Republic, died here today, after a short illness, at the age of 62.

Because of an editing error, an article in the New York Times yesterday incorrectly stated that Secretary of Defense Melvin R. Laird had announced the first tests of warheads on Soviet SS-11 missiles.
JERUSALEM, Aug. 27 Premier Golda Meir said tonight that she would go to New York late in October to join in ceremonies marking the 25th anniversary of the United Nations.

ASMARA, Ethiopia, Aug. 18 "There are no missiles, no nuclear weapons, no heavy artillery and no dangerous explosives of any kind on Kagnew Station," according to a United States Information Service pamphlet distributes here.

Diversification was mainly responsible for the 29 percent profit increase of Swift Co. in the third fiscal quarter ended Aug. 1 and the 31.5 per cent gain realized in the nine-month period, Robert W. Reneker, president of the world's largest meat packing operation, reported yesterday.
The second of two 160-foot-long fountains that flank the new and imposing stone stairway to the main entrance of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, was finally turned on yesterday.

HUSHPUCKENA, Miss. Down Mississippi High way 61, past a HEP-UR-SEF carwash and a billboard brandishing an American flag with the admonition: "Back It, Don't Buck It," a nameless dirt road leads back to the sun-peeled plantation shack where James Earl Miller lives.

The city was accused yesterday of contributing to the "decay, suffering and misery" of thousands of slum residents by delaying for four months the final authorization of a pilot program to train superintendents to work in Harlem tenements.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 The Government's composite index of "leading indicators" of the economy showed last month its first strong rise in more than a year, the Commerce Department reported today. It was another in a recent series of encouraging economic reports, including those on prices, production, interest rates and foreign trade.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 The supersonic transport appeared to lose more support in the Senate today even as the Administration put its star witnesses in favor of the plane before the Transportation Subcommittee of the Appropriations Committee.
ALBANY, Aug. 27 Governor Rockefeller directed state law enforcement agencies today to avoid the use of such words as Mafia and Cosa Nostra when discussing organized crime.

State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh ruled yesterday that a number of pistols, rifles and explosives could be used as evidence in the forthcoming trial of 13 Black Panthers charged here with a conspiracy to bomb public places.
The American Can Company said yesterday that it planned to increase prices on metal tube by 5 per cent beginning with shipments Oct. 1.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 27 Helicopters and planes still arrive daily at a remote corner of Tansonnhut Airfield carrying the bodies of United States soldiers, sailors and airmen.

Miss Karen Y.T. Chang, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry K.C. Chang of Honolulu, will be married in Honolulu this afternoon to David Russell Liu of New York. He is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Arthur Liu of New York and Honolulu.

As the summer began the morning line in Central Park looked good for the daily double of Puccini and Philharmonic but nobody was placing bets on the staying power of King Henry VI and Richard III. Now, as the summer rounds the last turn, New York is winding up with the greatest season of free entertainment in the park's history.

BERLIN, Aug. 27 Highranking officials here and in Bonn said today that East Berlin had been leaking reports to the West that it planned major concessions on Berlin under which the 2.1 million West Berliners could cross the border wall to visit in the East.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Aug. 27 (Reuters) Health ministers from seven Arab countries met here today to coordinate measures to combat the cholera outbreak in the region.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Aug. 27 A Brazilian Army court sentenced 11 persons to prison terms tonight after finding them guilty of taking part in the kidnapping last September of C. Burke Elbrick, then the United States Ambassador.

The Federal Reserve System's gradual push toward an easier credit policy picked up steam during the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed. Money and bank credit both showed an accelerated rate of expansion.

The $100,000 survey of the city subway system by four foreign transit experts, just initiated by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, would inspire greater confidence if the visiting consultants had been more restrained in their initial praise of the system.
PARIS, Aug. 27 The Bank of France lowered its discount rate today from 8 per cent to 7.5 per cent in a move to ease credit restrictions and stimulate the economy.

WELLINGTON, New Zealand, Aug. 27 (Reuters) The New Zealand Government, tonight suffered its first parliamentary defeat in 40 years because two members of the governing National party slept through a roll-call vote.

AREA A Surf fishing has improved tremendously off Long Beach Island. Plenty of weakfish are being taken, starting with the twilight hours and running into the night. Some blues also are being caught. Few kingfish during daylight hours.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Aug. 27 (Agence France-Presse) The Nigerian Chief of Staff, Brig. Hassan Katsina, said yesterday that a number of Nigerian Army officers had been executed in a widesweeping anticorruption drive.
SAIGON, Aug. 27. (AP) Only two Americans were reported today to have survived the crash yesterday of an Army Chinook helicopter carrying 27 infantrymen and a crew of five.

MIAMI, Aug. 27 A Federal District Court here today ordered a cemetery in Fort Pierce to accept for burial the body of a black Vietnam veteran whose coffin had been turned away because of a charter that restricted the cemetery to whites.
Southern railroads believe that the decision by Eastern and Western railroads to seek a 15 per cent freight-rate increase now from the Interstate Commerce Commission is "completely wrong" in timing.

Miss J. Sharon Kelly, daughter of Mrs. Lester J. Kelly of New York and the late Mr. Kelly, was married at the Colony Club last evening to William Martin Kirschner, son of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin Kirschner of Scarsdale, N.Y.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 25 WAR, says the metal disk on the necklace of a gung-ho marine, his face streaked with black and green greasepaint for reconnaissance.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 27 Rod Laver and Mrs. Margaret Smith Court, the top-seeded players in the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis tournament, advanced to the singles semifinals with brilliantly executed victories today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

MOSCOW, Aug. 27 (AP) Foreign Minister Adam Malik of Indonesia announced today that the Soviet Union had agreed to grant his nation 30 years to pay off an $800-million debt incurred by Sukarno when he was President.
The money and capital markets held steady yesterday, resting after their pronounced moves toward higher prices and lower interest rates earlier in the week.

MADISON, Wis., Aug. 27 A self-styled guerrilla group that calls itself the New Year's Gang reportedly claimed responsibility today for setting off the bomb that destroyed the Army Mathematics Research Center at the University of Wisconsin Monday, killing a research student and injuring three other persons.

The new advertising campaign for the Getty Oil Company got under way last month and just this week had its introduction into New York. For those who have been folowing the recently completed change of the company's brand name from Flying A to Getty and the initial commercial showing the name being marched into town, this campaign will provide an understanding of its current approach to the marketplace.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., Aug. 27 Miss Karin Ann Lawrence, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. Lawrence, was married here this afternoon in the garden of her parents' home to Peter Charles Siegfried, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Siegfried of New York and Bayport.

In the seven months since the end of the civil war, Nigeria's Federal Government has handled the formidable problems of national reconciliation and reintegration of the former Biafrans far better than most had expected. Unfortunately, however, it is still addicted, in peace as it was in war, to pronouncements that appear to violate General Gowon's promises of general amnesty and reinstatement of ex-Biafrans in public jobs.

Lieder are sacred to some people, but Eliot Feld can take them lightly or seriously, depending on his own puckish ear. In "Early Songs" he collects a gaggle of Richard Strauss's into a ballet of uneven but nearly always inventive flow. The American Ballet Company presented the work last night on the second program of The New York Dance Festival at the Delacorte Theater in Central Park.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 27 Students have taken increasingly to demonstrating and guerrilla fighting since President Alfredo Ovando Candia eliminated leftists from his Cabinet earlier this month.

The America's Cup literally lacks a bottom. Yachtsmen have been pouring millions into it for a century, the latest being such diverse types as Marcel Bich of France, the ballpoint baron, and Charlie Morgan Jr., a nice guy from Florida who did finish last.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Aug. 28 (AP) Vice President Agnew lauded the South Vietnamese people today for suffering "so much in freedom's cause" and he pledged again that "there will be no lessening" of American support.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Aug. 27 (AP) A marine private took the stand in his own defense today and denied that the 16 Vietnamese women and children he and his patrol killed last Feb. 19 were murdered.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 A bipartisan bill that would create a comprehensive health insurance program for all Americans at an estimated cost of $40-billion a year was introduced in Congress today by 15 Senators.

Rosie the Preacher, a familiar figure in Times Square, was arrested last night and charged with disorderly conduct when she refused a policeman's order to move from the corner of Broadway and 49th Street.
LONDON, Aug. 27 The police announced today that they had seized machine guns, other firearms and explosives in 50 simultaneous raids in the London area and throughout England last night.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 27 Eight "GO VALIANT" stickers appeared on the America's Cup buoy, nine miles at sea today, but once again it was Intrepid that went.
WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 27 Cindy Weiner of Morrisville, Pa., scored an unusual double today when she rode the winners of both the large and small divisions in the national pony hunter championships.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary condemned as "senseless" and "dastardly" yesterday an apparently unprovoked early morning Queens gunfight in which two patrolmen were wounded and one of the assailants was killed.

TEL AVIV, Aug. 27 (Reuters) Two representatives of the International Federation of Airline Pilots' Associations left today after failing to obtain the release of two Algerians taken off a British airliner during a stopover at Lydda 13 days ago.
A junior high school teacher in Indianapolis, Louis B. Russell Jr., gained a historic distinction the other day. He became the first man in history to live for two years with a transplanted heart.
The Duke Power Company announced yesterday that in an effort to guarantee coal supplies for its power plants it has acquired two coal companies and has agreed to joint financing of a third mine.

The city's Correction Commissioner, George F. McGrath, announced yesterday that the population of the Manhattan Men's House of Detention, the Tombs, had been reduced from 1,900 to approximately 1,300 since the riots there two weeks ago.

YONKERS, Aug. 27 Stanley Dancer is taking nothing for granted so far as Most Happy Fella and Saturday night's $102,770 Cane Pace at Yonkers Raceway are concerned. Before Dancer flew to Indianapolis yesterday morning, he took the time to train Most Happy Fella two separate miles at his Egyptian Acres Farm at New Egypt, N.J. They were leisurely trips, the faster one being clocked in 2:20.

The 1971 world team championship for the Bermuda Bowl will be played in Taiwan, and for the first time there will be two teams representing North America.

The legality of the Lindsay administration's granting a $4.6-million management contract without public bidding or a public hearing to the Institute of Public Administration was questioned yesterday by Controller Abraham D. Beame.
Measles, a disease that three years ago was thought to be on the verge of eradication, has begun an ominous climb.

WENATCHEE, Wash., Aug. 27 (AP) A 39,000-acre fire in north-central Washington burned wildly out of control today and a smaller fire threatened residences of about 800 persons as fire fighters strove to contain the blazes.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27 Marguerite A. Salomon, who became famous in the Netherlands for a World War II act of generosity, died Tuesday in Unitarian Universalist Home, where she lived. She was 82 years old.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 27 Walt Patulski wasn't certain what Coach Ara Parseghian would say. His hair wasn't really that long he didn't want to look like a football freak with one of those skin cuts and he felt the sideburns would fill out his 6-foot' 6-inch, 250-pound frame.
TURIN, Italy, Aug. 27 (UPI) The United States swimming team broke four meet records today and picked up eight more medals, five gold, in a dazzling performance at the sixth World University Games.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) The Interior Department proposed today changes in regulations to permit the sale of oil import allocations and licenses.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (Reuters) The Soviet Union protested to the United States today over an incident in Chicago last night in which tear gas grenades exploded during a performance of the Moiseyev Dance Company.
