PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 27 City officials and spokesmen for a war protest group announced today an agreement that will permit two antiwar parades at the time of the American Legion convention here next week.
SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 27 Jerome Sayles Hess, a lawyer who represented the Mexican Government in the United States for more than 50 years, died at his home here today. He was 88 years old.
Nearly 60 demonstrators disrupted the taping of the Merv Griffin Show last night in protest over what they said was not enough use of black jazz musicians on television entertainment shows.
BUENOS AIRES, Aug. 27 A major leader of Argentina's trade union movement was killed by a gunman this morning 100 yards from his home in suburban Blegrano.

Diamonds valued at $232,268 being flown to Japan by Pan American World Airways from Kennedy International Airport in a locked security pouch disappeared Aug. 19, the police were notified yesterday by airline officials.
Dr. Charles C. Adler, professor of history at Hamilton College, died Monday in Moscow after a brief illness. He was 47 years old and lived in Clinton, N.Y.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 Freight traffic on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage last week were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

ROME, Aug. 27 (AP) The Vatican published pictures and interviews today to counter what it described as "an unworthy and scandalous campaign" in the press on allegations that priests in India had sold girls to become nuns in European convents.

Two municipal agencies and the city's local community corporations mobilized forces yesterday in an attempt to head off trouble expected Monday when a new food-stamp program aimed at increasing the poor's food money by 30 per cent goes into effect here.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 27 (AP) Ed Rommel, who rose from a Baltimore sandlot to become a star American League pitcher and later was an umpire, died last night after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (UPI) Head Start and other programs strictly for the poor cause social polarization and backlash because they exclude the middle class, the new Head Start director, Edward F. Zigler, said today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission filed a complaint today in United States district court seeking to enjoin three Alexandria, Va., companies and two individuals for alleged violations of Federal securities laws.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27 Just because John Unitas, Len Dawson and Bill Nelsen were all shipped away to greater glory by the Pittsburgh Steelers, the football fans in the area tend to quiver a little when any former Steeler quarterback comes back to town.

Adam Walinsky, Democratic candidate for State Attorney General, charged yesterday that the Rockefeller administration had filled safety-inspector positions through political referrals from union leaders "supporting Governor Rockefeller's re-election."

WESTON, Vt., Aug. 27 Mrs. Virginia Gibson Bullitt, widow of James B. Bullitt Jr. of Swarthmore, Pa., and Clifford Lewis 3d of Media, Pa., were married here at noon yesterday in the Londonderry Chapel of St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

The Transit Authority reluctantly disclosed yesterday that it did not plan to construct a station at 42d Street on the new Second Avenue subway and that there probably would be only three Manhattan stops north of 57th Street.

FORT WORTH, Aug. 27 (UPI) Marvin Leonard, who built an $835 bankroll into a profitable department store, grubstaked Ben Hogan's first try at pro golf and founded two of the country's top golf courses, died yesterday. He was 75 years old.
Having suffered through a couple of agonizing evenings against the Atlanta Braves, the New York Mets rediscovered the simple formula for victory yesterday in broad daylight at Shea Stadium.
A 100 per cent interest in Manhattan Cable Television has been obtained here by Sterling Communications, Inc., in an exchange of stock and other assets with Time-Life Broadcast, Inc.

Despite a court order served on radical groups at Lincoln Hospital yesterday, the 27 doctors who are boycotting the hospital because of alleged intimidation by the radicals refused to return to their jobs.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 27 A second day of deliberations in the trial of Lonnie McLucas was abruptly halted today when the jury foreman informed Superior Court Judge Harold M. Mulvey that one member of the panel was sick.

Corn, wheat and soybeans futures prices bounded upward yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade after having dropped sharply the day before. The rise did not occur, however, until shortly before midday after an early weak opening due largely to reports of good weather in the growing areas.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 27 Sometimes a caddie dreams of the days when he can outscore the champion he admires most. It was one of those days at the $300,000 Dow Jones open that found Mike Reasor, the ex-bagtoter, leading Arnold Palmer by seven strokes, 66 to 73.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 27 (AP) Repeal of all United Stated laws against pornography for adults, along with the enactment of laws against exposure of children to obscene pictures, were among recommendations reportedly given final approval today by the President's Commission on Pornography.
Share prices drifted generally lower on the London stock market yesterday in dull trading.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 27 Arab commandos, their sympathizers and the Governments of Syria and Iraq called today for continued guerrilla raids on Israel. Amid signs of disarray within the commando movement, they convened here for a council of war.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.
NORTH VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Aug. 26 The wife of the principal of a Brooklyn elementary school was found dead in her bed in her house here early this morning.

HAWORTH, N.J. Aug. 27 For the third year in a row, Amy Lane, 17 years old, of Navesink, N.J., won the 11th annual Maureen Orcutt junior golf trophy at the White Beeches Golf and Country Club today.
The Rev. Edward A. Wallace, Roman Catholic chaplain in both World Wars, died Wednesday at Madonna Residence, 1 Prospect Park West, Brooklyn. He was 85 years old.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 27 The United States command reported today that 52 Americans died in combat in Indochina last week, for the lowest toll in three and a half years.

Allen Stone studied accounting before he decided to become a tennis professional but the 25-year-old Australian doesn't figure to get much of chance at the $160,000 in prize money from the United States Open championships, which begin next Wednesday at the west Side Tennis Club, Forest Hills, Queens.
Whitman Knapp, chairman of the special commission investigating charges of widespread police corruption in New York, called on the public yesterday to report specific cases of police graft.

Shelby M. Harrison, retired consultant in the social sciences and for many years affiliated with the Russell Sage Foundation here, died yesterday in Midtown Hospital. He was 89 years old and lived at 370 Riverside Drive.

DENVER Going West in America these days, one is startled by the power and diversity of the nation. SAG HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 27 Joan Wharton, former letters editor of Newsweek magazine, died of cancer today at her mother's home here. She was 42 years old.

PARIS, Aug. 27 Xuan Thuy, Hanoi's chief delegate to the Vietnam peace talks, who returned here yesterday after a three-month absence, stayed away from today's session of the negotiations.

GENEVA, Aug. 28--The threat of a reduction in American contributions has forced the International Labor Organization to undertake a severe economy program.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28--The October House Farm's entry of Executioner and Pass Catcher--with the former having the sharper edge-- will head the field for the Hopeful tomorrow. The 6 -furlong sprint for 2-year-olds will serve as the feature of the closingday program of the Saratoga meeting, and has attracted a field of eight.

The Food and Drug Administration, in response to the wishes of food manufacturers, has approved the special, continued use in soft drinks of a food additive that the agency declared in January to be "no longer generally recognized as safe for use in food."
Contrary to Representative Byrnes, President Nixon's plan to share Federal revenues with the states is no "gimmick." It is an essential reform if the Federal system is to survive.

BRAUNSCHWEIG, West Germany, Aug. 28--After years of avoiding conflict, Rollei Kamerawerke of Braunschweig has thrown down the gauntlet to its formidable Japanese competitors. At a news conference yesterday, marking the 50th anniversary of Rollei Camera Works' founding, its director, Heinrich Peesel, disclosed that his company would soon start fighting the Japanese with their own principal weapon--low labor costs--by transferring part of its production to Singapore.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (UPI) --The Senate Agriculture Committee approved today a three-year farm support bill, including a $55,000-a-crop limit on subsidies to big farmers growing cotton, wheat and feed grains.

MOSCOW, Aug. 28--Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Communist party leader, gave strong Soviet backing today to the current Middle East peace efforts and called on all sides for "an honest observance" of the 90-day ceasefire agreement.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Aug. 28 (AP)--John Norman Collins publicly proclaimed his innocence for the first time today just before he was sentenced to life imprisonment on a conviction of killing an Eastern Michigan University Coed.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 28-- The Palestinian National Council declared tonight that it categorically rejected the present efforts toward peace in the Middle East.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 28--Miss Linda Hurd Leslie and Hutchinson DuBosque Jr. were married here this afternoon in the outdoor chapel of St. John's Episcopal Church by the Rev. William S. Spilman. A reception was given at the home of the bride's mother, Mrs. Clarissa Leslie of Mill Neck.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP) --The Government moved today to break up what it said was a 17-year-old conspiracy to eliminate competition in the sale of refrigerant gas in violation of the Sherman Antitrust Act.

The first stage in the playoff matches to determine the American representatives in next year's world championship begins today in Phoenix, Ariz. Teams headed by Lew Mathe of Los Angeles and Dr. George Rosenkranz of Mexico City will play a match of 144 deals during the weekend.
Stephanie M. Clark, 19 years old, of Washington, won the Miss Black America beauty pageant at Madison Square Garden last night.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28-- As expected, Gretel II of Australia completed a 4-0 sweep of France today and became the 21st America's Cup challenger.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 28--Israel got its first American bank this month.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 28 (AP)--Two patrolmen, one of them the president of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association here, were arrested tonight and charged with conspiracy and extortion.

William H. Chartener, an economist and a former Assistant Secretary of Commerce in both the Johnson and Nixon Administrations, died yesterday after a heart attack at his home in Port Washington, L.I. He was 45 years old.

GENEVA, Aug, 28--Investors Overseas Services, Ltd., reported today a net loss of $25.86million, including an operating loss of $12.53-million, for the first six months of 1970.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28--Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, the United Nations special representative for the Middle East, held conferences yesterday and today with diplomats from the Big Four powers in connection with his new round of peace efforts.
GENEVA, Aug. 28--After Wilfred Jenks was elected Director General of the International Labor Organization, he was asked what he liked to do when he was not working.

LONDON, Aug. 28-Jonathan Miller is clearly a man of many parts, His talents as satirist, physician, writer and director, have gone far beyond that fringe where we all first found him. The stock market, basking in the glow of improved investor confidence, turned strong again yesterday after three days of consolidating its recent advance. Numerous glamour issues scored multi-point gains.

A giant chimney matching the height of the Empire State Building is being built by the International Nickel Company of Canada in an effort to curb the pollution problem at its Copper Cliff, Ont., smelter complex.
Approval of the merger of Trans Caribbean Airways into American Airlines was recommended yesterday by a Civil Aeronautics Board examiner in Washington.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 28-- An autopsy today determined that Mrs. Joan Holder, 41 years old, who was found dead in bed by her husband in their Valley Stream home yesterday, was asphyxiated and had traces of chloroform in her body.

Trustees of the Penn Central Transportation Company asked the Federal District Court in Philadelphia yesterday to permit them to defer payment of some $45-million in state and local property taxes that have become payable since June 21 or will become due by Dec. 31. The railroad went into reorganization under the Federal bankruptcy laws on June 21.

The note of urgency President Nixon put into his latest plea for swift Senate action on his welfarereform plan is eminently justified. The existing welfare system is a national scandal, and the Administration proposal represents the most imaginative effort in three decades to transform it into something socially useful.
Eight of Syracuse University's 10 black football players were suspended for the season yesterday when they did not appear at the first preseason practice at 9 A.M.
John J. DeLury, president of the Uniformed Sanitationmen's Association, said yesterday that street sweeping by hand was "the only answer to the city's dirty streets."
Eldon R. Clingan, the City Council minority leader, yesterday chastised a fellow Liberal councilman, Alvin Frankenberg of Queens, for "neanderthal attitudes toward the women's equal rights movement."

Robert K. Ruskin, the city's Commissioner of Investigation, said yesterday that nine members of the Police Department had been assigned to his office's investigational staff because of a "substantial" increase in the work volume over the last year.

The first sizable business failure in the current, prolonged slump in retailing was announced yesterday in San Francisco when one of that city's oldest specialty store chains, H. Liebes and Company, filed a Chapter XI petition under the Bankruptcy Act in Federal Court.
At least 10 persons were injured last night when a Penn Central Metroliner from Washington more than three hours behind schedule, hit the back of another train in Pennsylvania Station.

Allan Shelden 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan Shelden 3d of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., died on Tuesday of cancer at the Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 25 years old.

State-guaranteed college education loans are easier to get in the New York metropolitan area than they were at this time last year, bankers say, although some students in New Jersey are having trouble.
A $70,000 grant to help continue a study to improve highways safety has been awarded to Arizona State University by PPG Industries Foundation of Pittsburgh.

Although the proposed Second Avenue subway has certainly been far from an express up to now (its active planning stages began nearly twenty years ago), it may be an express when it finally begins service.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Dr. Richard L. Garwin, a member of the White House Science Advisory Committee, who has persistently challenged the Nixon Administration's supersonic transport program, said today that the test models now being built would cost the Government up to 40 per cent more than the target $1.3-billion. But he said the models would still prove useless in resolving questions about the plane's affect on the environment.

OMAHA, Aug. 28--A 16-yearold member of an offshoot organization of the Black Panther party was arraigned here today on a first degree murder charge and ordered held without bail in the booby-trap killing Aug. 17 of an Omaha policeman.
For the last two years, a total of 300 New Jersey residents have come to New York each weekday for training in an experimental day-care program that has been described as the only one of its kind.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 28--President Nixon agreed today to allow a year of "field 'tests" of the proposed Family Assistance Program before it would go into full operation.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 28 (UPI)--Charles Harvey, a 30year-old salesman from Oskaloosa, Iowa, defeated four other marksmen today in a shootoff and captured the coveted Grand American Handicap at the 71st Grand American trapshoot.

CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 28--At the front gate, there were pickets. Two stumpy middle-aged men, their eyes narrowing in the rising heat, shifted from foot to foot as they chatted with a state trooper. Their placards berated "the establishment," today the Upper Montclair Country Club, for not properly paying its bar and restaurant help.

DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Denny McLain was suspended tonight for up to a month without salary by the Detroit Tigers' general manager, Jim Campbell, for "conduct unbecoming a professional baseball player."
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 28-- Ten dynamite explosions reverberated across La Paz last night in an apparent campaign of guerrilla terrorism.
They may be castigated as male chauvinist pigs, but New York's fashion-liberated men cannot be called sheep when it comes to trouser lengths.

Probably the chief merit of Louis Falco's choreography at this point in his career is the opportunity it affords us to see him and his superbly disciplined company. While it is a modified pleasure, it is not one to be lightly dismissed. Last night at the New York Dance Festival in Central Park's Delacorte Theater, his company offered "Huescape" and "Caviar."
RIVERHEAD, L.I., Aug. 28-- State troopers and members of the Suffolk County District Attorney's office arrested 26 persons late last night and early today in drug raids.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 28-- Terry Bradshaw, golden-haired and enthusiastic and the top draft choice last winter, was the star of the first football game in Three Rivers Stadium tonight, leading the Steelers to a 21-6 victory over the Giants.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- Thailand has informed the United States that she intends to withdraw her 11,000-man force from South Vietnam, the State Department said today.

BERKELEY, Calif.--Lewis Hand Morris, grandson of the late Judge Learned Hand and son of the late Newbold Morris, New York political figure and former City Commissioner of Parks, was found dead in his apartment here yesterday afternoon. He was 26 years old.

TOKYO, Aug. 28 (AP)--The Japanese Government said today it had decided to liberalize import-quota restrictions on 13 items and to raise the ceiling on direct foreign investment abroad by Japanese companies.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Hundreds of travelers have been stranded in London lately by a British Government crackdown on what it has considered illegal charter flights.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, Aug. 29 (AP)--A convoy of American infantrymen was ambushed on a main highway in jungles in the Central Highlands and in nearly 10 hours of fighting 6 were killed and 26 were wounded, the United States command reported today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (Reuters)--The State Department said today that the United States was no longer prohibiting American oil subsidiaries broad from supplying fuel to ships of other nations bound for Communist China.

Arthur J. Goldberg charged yesterday that the "forced disclosure" by the Transit Authority that only six stops were planned for the new Second Avenue subway from 34th to 125th Street was "another indication of the contempt in which the riding public is held by the State Metropolitan Transportation Authority, the T.A.'s parent body."
POONJAR, India, Aug. 26 --The bent old woman with the kindly, seamed face shuffled slowly into the room to greet her grandson and the Western stranger he had brought.

HOPEWELL JUNCTION, N.Y., Aug. 28--This tidy Dutchess County community does not have a serious unemployment problem, a slum or even its own police force. But it has recorded its first teenage death attributed to narcotics.

New and difficult questions are being asked about the obligations of stock exchange members and the evaluation of their memberships as a result of the current wave of brokerage-house collapses on Wall Street.

The White House suggestion that American and Soviet troops might join in United Nations peacekeeping operations in the Middle East, after an ArabIsraeli settlement, is an imaginative contribution to bringing that settlement about.

KINGS POINT, L.I., Aug. 28--The engagement of Miss Suzanne Lynn Grossman to Stephen Arnold Goodman, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Goodman of New York, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin B. Grossman.
The California Angels, driven by Manager Lefty Phillips, continued to make the Minnesota Twins uncomfortable atop the American League's Western Division last night.
About 200 angry taxi drivers massed their vehicles on Second Avenue yesterday afternoon to mourn a colleague who was stabbed to death by holdup men earlier in the week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)--The State of New York asked the United States Supreme Court today to overturn a lower court's decision banning construction of the Hudson River Expressway until Federal approval is obtained for the construction of the dikes and causeway.
RADFORD, Va., Aug. 28 (AP) --The Radford Army Arsena was rocked early today by an explosion that killed two employes, injured four other workers and caused damage estimated at $200,000.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (AP)--The Council of the International Coffee Organization decided today to extend its meetings for 48 hours in a bid to break a deadlock over next year's export quotas.
HONG KONG, Aug. 28 (Reuters)--North Vietnam conceded today that war had heavily damaged its "already very poor and backward" economy but it gave no sign of retreating in the Indochina conflict.

The Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More was the setting here yesterday for the marriage of Miss Kathleen Suzanne McQueen, a senior at Cornell University, to Harry Tipper 3d, a member of the class of '72 at Cornell's School of Architecture. The Rev. John Calhoon performed the ceremony.

Flora Shore, administrative assistant in guidance at Midwood High School, Brooklyn, until her retirement last June, died Aug. 20 in Zurich, Switzerland. She was 69 years old and lived at 75 Henry Street, Brooklyn.
TEL AVIV, Aug. 28--An Israeli spokesman said today that 13 Arab guerrillas were killed during the night as they attempted to penetrate Israel from Lebanon and Jordan.

Because the jazz concerts at MUSE, Bedford Street and Lincoln Plaza in Brooklyn, are played by volunteer groups booked two months in advance, last-minute conflicts between commerce and contributed service are apt to occur. The fortnightly concerts are free.

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug. 28 --Durward Knowles of Nassau lengthened his lead in the North American Star Class championship today by winning the fourth race. The former world and Olympic champion now leads Joseph R. Duplin of Winthrop, Mass., also a former world champion, 207-202.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 (AP)--President Nixon's new National Labor Relations Board chairman, in his first major case, swung the vote today against a union's demand for wage increases from a concern that had illegally refused to bargain.

Former Justice Albert D. Schanzer, who retired from Special Sessions Court here in 1961, died Thursday in Nassau Hospital, Mineola, L.I., after a short illness. He was 80 years old and lived in East Williston, L.I.

The ancient Phoenicians called her the goddess of love. An interracial group of businessmen and women hope she'll be known as the black Est e Lauder and have given her name, Astart , to a new luxury brand of cosmetics "specially designed for the fashionable woman of colour."

Arturo G. Ramirez, a Cuban editor and drama critic who had fled the Castro regime, died yesterday at Jamaica Hospital in Queens, after he had suffered a heart attack in his home at 83-64 Talbot Street, Kew Gardens. He was 62 years old.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28--The Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today the following spot primary prices for the week end Aug. 25, 1970.

Daniel Trotzky, who recently retired as president of Roosevelt School in Stamford, Conn., a preparatory board school, and who was a long-time leader in Jewish community affairs, died Wednesday at his home, 27 West 86th Street. His age was 66.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 28 --Using a king-sized hypodermic syringe, Dr. Kenneth Sterling of Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons drew blood from a thrashing, five-foot shark five miles at sea yesterday and came away with all 10 fingers intact.

As a man with a baby perched on his shoulder greeted Governor Rockefeller at the Franklin County fair in Malone this week, a photographer tried in vain to divert the baby's attention toward the Governor for the inevitable campaign picture.

A seven-foot snake was removed to an A.S.P.C.A. shelter early today after spending several hours locked in a top-flcor bathroom last night, having first beep cornered by a police sergeant who responded to a call by residents of the building at 170 West 108th Street.
VERONA, N.J., Aug. 28-- Dr. Charles Raymond Downs, a chemist and a consulting engineer in the field, died yesterday in a nursing home at Cedar Grove at the age of 82.

Although market conditions improved this week, only one company felt that the time was opportune to try and sell its shares to the public for the first time, according to a weekly survey of new-issue underwriters.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 28--Ken Rosewall of Australia and Bob Carmichael of France advanced to the semifinals of the $25,000 Marlboro open tennis championships today in sharply played matches at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.

WESTHAMPTON BEACH, L.I., Aug 28--Mr. and Mrs. Walter E. Guldi have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Jane Guldi, to David E. McIntyre, son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. McIntyre of Appleton, Wis.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 28--On the 38th floor of the Secretariat building here, a formula first employed on the Island of Rhodes more than two decades ago is in use again in an attempt to bring peace to the Middle East.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Aug. 28--Steve Tannen's heel injury has added to the uncertainty in the New York Jets' defensive backfield.
HOUSTON, Aug. 28 (AP)-- The formation of a new corporation to build and operate the $900-million, 800-mile TransAlaska Pipeline System was announced today.
DETROIT, Aug. 28 (AP)--The tempo of auto production picked up considerably in the nation's auto plants this week as manufacturers stepped up production schedules of 1971 cars.
TURIN, Italy, Aug. 28 (AP)-- American swimmers made a clean sweep of the five gold medals at stake in the World University Games today, bringing their total to 13 in the three-day-old competition.

A North Carolina school scheduled for desegregation was rocked by two explosions early yesterday. Meanwhile attorneys in Virginia and Florida prepared to ask the Supreme Court for stays of integration directives.

BERLIN, Aug. 28--Mayor Klaus Schutz of West Berlin said today that the new SovietWest German pact had for the first time in years created conditions under which improvements for West Berlin "have moved into the range of possibiiity."
Prices turned lower on the London Stock Exchange yesterday as trading slowed down in anticipation of the Bank Holiday Monday.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 28-- Mrs. Peter Bulkeley Langmuir of Milwaukee and East Chop, Martha's Vineyard, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Maria Adams Langmuir, to William Sebring Herrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Beckwith Herrick of Weston, Mass., and East Chop.
GENEVA, Aug. 28--The World Health Organization said today that the failure of some governments to report cholera cases was concealing the spread of the disease through the Middle East into Africa.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 28--Cliff Richey, whose tennis record and reputation have been confirmed on slow clay courts, will make his Davis Cup challenge round debut tomorrow amid much speculation. The question remains: Can Richey conquer a fast asphalt surface and the formidable southpaw serve of Christian Kuhnke?
LIMOGES, France, Aug. 28 (UPI)--Th o Sarapo, the last husband of Edith Piaf, died today after an auto accident in Limoges. Four other persons in his car were injured.
A security guard for the American Broadcasting Company was injured last night when he was struck by an outof-control automobile on the sidewalk in front of the network's studio at 7 West 66th Street.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Oct. 28--Randy Bartholomew in the Etchells-22 Class, Gino Matkovic among the Resolutes, and Pierce McCreary among the Internationals were winners in a Manhasset Bay Yacht Club Race Week regatta that was saved today by a late-blooming southwester that was neither steadfast nor strong, but good enough.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 28--A special sale of yearlings conducted simultaneously at Deauville, France, and the Humphrey S. Finney Pavilion here attracted 150 spectators at this end of the operation yesterday.

The Data Processing Financial General Corporation increased its gross revenues in the fiscal year ended May by 31 per cent, but a net loss of $4,255,593 was incurred in contrast to the net income of $8,175,654, or $2.43 a share, realized in the preceding fiscal year, the company's annual report disclosed yesterday.
A fourth suspect in an international heroin-smuggling ring that authorities said did business exceeding half a billion dollars a year in street sales was seized yesterday by the police in Madrid.
Wedgwood is a name found on a lot more than the decorative pieces, with stark white relief ornament applied to a pale ground, which everyone knows.

The financial difficulties of the King Resources Company of Denver deepened further yesterday as the Delafield Capital Corporation of New York filed suit against the company on charges of default on a $2-million note due more than two weeks ago.
HOUSTON, Aug. 28--Another host from the past of the New York Mets--the pitcher those special practice is beating them--emerged in the strodome tonight and dealt them a painful 2-1 defeat.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 28--President Nguyen Van Thieu handed out the first land titles to peasants today under the land-reform program he signed into law five months ago.
A grand jury yesterday indicted five Bronx men accused of the fire-bombing last month of a house inhabited by a woman and her nine children.

COLUMBUS, Ohio. Aug. 28 (UPI)--Bennett Cooper, 49 years old, superintendent of the State Reformatory at Mansfield, today was appointed Ohio Corrections Commissioner. He becomes the highest ranking Negro prison official in the nation.
BUFFALO, Aug. 28 (AP)-- Horse-riding deputy sheriffs along with colleagues on foot, swept into the Erie County Fairgrounds in suburban Hamburg today and arrested 10 young men on drug charges.
The American Stock Exchange finished higher for the sixth consecutive session yesterday as advances outnumbered declines by more than a two-to-one ratio.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 28--A Los Angeles County deputy medical examiner testified today at the murder trial of Charles M. Manson that Mrs. Rosemary LaBianca had been stabbed 41 times.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 28-- The Treasury announced today a key step in a process that could lead to somewhat higher prices for imported Japanese television sets.
Evans Clark, writer on social issues and economic problems, died yesterday in Nyon, Switzerland. He was 82 years old.
Although profit-taking near the end of the session trimmed the advances somewhat, corn, wheat and soybeans futures prices rose again yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

LEVITTOWN, L.I., Aug. 28 --Miss Barbara Gail Muller, who was graduated cum laude in June from the New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, and Keith W. Rouse, who received a B.F.A. degree in communication arts last year from the institute, will be married Sept. 20 at the First Reformed Church in New Hyde Park.

Dr. Joseph T. English, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, met yesterday with representatives of 27 physicians who are boycotting Lincoln Hospital in a dispute with radical community groups.

ATHENS, Aug. 27--While lawyers for Stavros S. Niarchos prepare a brief answering charges that the multimillionaire shipowner was responsible for the death of his third wife, Eugenie, on May 4, the case and the people involved are taking on political overtones, so that his accusers appear as heroes of the left and his defenders as right-wingers.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 29 Miss Anita Mitchell Schenck was married here this afternoon to Juraj Zednik. The Rev. Dr. Dudley J. Stroup performed the ceremony at the Church of St. James the Less (Episcopal).
HARRISON, N.Y., Aug. 29 Frederick J. Emmerich, retired board chairman of the Allied Chemical and Dye Corporation, died after a heart attack today at his home on Sunny Ridge Road. He was 78 years old.

Mark McFadden will be busy tomorrow, Mark, the 18year-old son of George McFadden, public relations director of the San Francisco 49ers, has been a staff assistant at the team training camp since he was 15. Mark is a hard worker and is popular with the players, except on...
LONDON, Aug. 29 Seemingly carefree Britons began their long Bank Holiday weekend today amid warnings that the nation was heading for a rough time.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Aug. 29 Communist forces across the Mekong River from Pnompenh attacked a small Government encampment at Moat Krasas Krao, five miles from here. The fighting, which was reported to have ended when the enemy withdrew this morning, was the closest yet to the capital.
Tremors of anxiety brought on by a slumping economy are rippling through the architectural profession, traditionally one of the first areas in the building field to feel effects of a recession.

BANGKOK, Thailand According to an old proverb, "After a rainfall, the soil is firm." Thus philosophized Vice President Spiro T. Agnew in one of his airport speeches as he swung through Asia last week. When he said it, at Kimpo Airport in Seoul, South Korea, mud still mottled his green trousers and caked his brown galoshes.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 29 Mrs. Margaret M. Clucas of Greenwich, New York and Guardiaro, Spain, has announced here the engagement of her daughter, Miss Alice Clucas, to Andre Depret of Paris. The wedding is planned for early December in Paris.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Aug. 29 (AP) Larry Gravestock, a sporting-goods dealer in Wichita Falls, Tex., won the over-all championship today at the 71st annual Grand American Trapshooting tournament. He shattered 967 of the 1,000 targets thrown up for him during the competition.
A Bronx patrolman wos shot and critically wounded early today as he approached two men standing on East Tremont Avenue between Belmont and Crotona Avenues in the East Tremont section of the Bronx.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 29, Miss Robin Ann Knight, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James L. Knight, was married here this afternoon to Andrew Bernard Drummond, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard G. Drummond of Darien. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Episcopal Church by the Rev. H. Arthur Lane Jr.

ORADELL, N.J., Aug. 29 This quiet Bergen County town of 9,200 people, five miles north of Hackensack, is divided by circumstances that have affected the commuting, the commerce and the composure of its citizens.
SAN DIEGO, Aug. 29 (Reuters) Craig Stadler, 17 years old, of La Jolla, Calif., won the third annual world junior golf championship today by five strokes.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Aug. 29 Miss Megg Carleton Picoli, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert C. Piccoli, was married here today to Edward Sullivan Hoffman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert L. Hoffman Jr. of Mill Neck. The ceremony was performed in St. John's of Lattingtown by the Rev. Howard M. Lowell, the rector.
Penn State's 1970 freshman football team will play two games a home contest with West Virginia on Oct. 16 and a road game at Pitt on Nov. 7.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 Tens of thousands of Soviet teen-agers reached turning points in their lives this week. They learned whether they had been accepted to the college of their choice or, as in most cases, rejected.

KENNETT SQUARE, Pa., Aug 29 Miss Elizabeth Hannum Dean and Alain Raunay Singer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Singer of Greenville, Del., were married here this afternoon in the Episcopal Church of the Advent by the Rev. Elbert K. St. Claire.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 29 (AP) Rioting broke out today among 7,000 persons at a Mexican-American antiwar rally in East Los Angeles. Demonstrators burned buildings, smashed store windows and injured policemen.

Miss Laraine Harriet Silver, a Columbia Law School student, and Peter Jay Rothenberg, a lawyer with the New York firm of Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton Garrison, were married here last night at the Plaza by the Rev. Dr. David J. Seligson of the Central Synagogue.

Verdi's "La Traviata" and Rossini's "La Cenerentola" will re-enter the New York City Opera's repertory during the second week of its current season at the State Theater. In addition, there will be one debut; Herman Malamood, New York City tenor, will apear in "Madama Butterfly" on Sept. 20. Casts and conductors for the week beginning Sept. 15 follow:

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 29 Gabriella Gonzalez's Shawn finished in a tie for third place in the bonus point stake and the 4 points he collected enabled the aged bay gelding to win the jumper championship today at the concluding session of the two-day Fairfield County Hunt Club horse show.

Charles A. Lindbergh, who was one of America's leading opponents of entry into World War II, still believes that he was right in urging the country to stay out of the conflict. Indeed, he contends that the United States, in the perspective of the last 30 years, lost the war.
MONTREAL, Aug. 29 (AP) Lee May clouted a two-run homer in the 11th inning today, giving the Cincinnati Reds a 4-3 victory over the Montreal Expos.

SUMMIT, N.J., Aug. 29 Miss Barbara McClain Livingston and Robert Frederick Howarth Jr., son of Mrs. Fatig Howarth of Newark, Ohio, and Robert Frederick Howarth of Columbus, Ohio., were married here this afternoon in Calvary Episcopal Church.

ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Aug. 29 Denny Hulme and Peter Revson took the day off today and yet qualified for the first and second starting positions in tomorrow's Road America Can-Am, sixth of the 1970 Canadian-American Challenge Cup series.

The 21 young women to be presented at the Gotham Debutante Ball at the Plaza on Nov. 26, will attend a rehearsal tea in the hotel's Grand Ballroom on Sept. 10. The rehearsal for the annual New York Foundling Hospital benefit is always held the Thursday after Labor Day, before the debutantes go away to school.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The $150-milion United Mine workers Welfare and Retirement Fund, the focus of much of the angry and disruptive controversy swirling around the coal union, said in a financial statement today that it had paid out $196.9-million in the last year, $28-milion more than it had taken in.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Aug. 29 (UPI) An American detective arrived from New Delhi today to help the police investigate the slaying of a 35-year-old Pennsylvania nurse whose body was found in her home last Monday.

Whenever insurance men speak of Louis W. Niggeman, the 54-year-old president of the Fireman's Fund Insurance Company, they invariably link him with stars like John Wayne, Julie Andrews, Gary Cooper and Lassie.

It was moving day at 231 West 58th Street on Friday. But unlike most moving days, this was something special. A bit of memorabilia was leaving New York City the Amateur Athletic Union, which had been a fixture here since it was founded in 1888.

RICHARD FAIRBANKS was the first post- master in America and Winton M. Blount is the last of the more than 60 men who were also postmasters on a higher level. As Postmasters General, they were given their posts by congressional action or by presidential appointment.

ATHENS, Aug. 26 At one point in the course of a bawdy, satiric review playing twice nightly to packed houses in a central Athens park, the actors lean across the footlights to tell the audience in confidential tones: "We did not write this stuff. We are just saying the lines."

ROCKPORT, Mass., Aug.29 Durward Knowles of Nassau won the North American Star Class championship today, finishing third in the last race. It was his lowest finish of the five-race series, during which he won three races and was second in another.
A record total of 20 men have been seeded in singles for the United States Open Tennis Championships.

Sam Boulmetis is proud that his nephew, Tony Black, learned about horsebacking on his own. He did it with little help or advice from his uncle, once one of the outstanding riders in the country and now a steward on the New Jersey-Florida circuit.
WASHINGTON The United States is the only major nation that does not have some type of government-directed national health insurance system.

ROSEGREEN, Ireland, Aug. 29 Nijinsky, the most valuable piece of horseflesh in history and the "horse of the century" according to many European writers, may not race in the United States after all, his trainer says. However, his owner seems inclined to ship the horse to Belmont Park.
Anyone who has lived in a small town or even driven through one surely knows of Rotary, the granddaddy of all service clubs.

The question on the dozen college campuses I visited last April was: "Is the environmental crisis merely a fad?" Not only students were asking; academia reflected the national uncertainty and exacerbation, Congress was swamped with antipollution bills, the Executive grappling with a traumatic reorganization of environmental bureaus, the public reluctantly facing one more category of taxes,...

TWO wars and 100,000 American lives ago, we thought the occu pation of Japan was gleaming like a star in an ugly sky of politics. Goliath had slain David, and now he was redeeming his soul. It was a heyday for nearly a million Americans on and off, lasting from Aug. 28, 1945, when the advance party of 150 men for whom I was interpreter landed,...

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Aug. 29 The marriage of Miss Anne-Marie Barbara Aigner, who is with C.B.S. News in Washington, to Stephen Anthony Rowan, who has been Pentagon correspondent for C.B.S. News, took place here this afternoon.
Many utility executives feel that the Consolidated Edison Company's problems this summer have given the industry a black eye.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29 The seventh-seeded pair of Leonard Prosser and Steve of Leawood, Kan., was extended to a third set in the opening of the 52d United States fatherand-son grass-court tennis doubles championship at the Germantown Cricket Club today.

Max Hendler, a lawyer and the clerk of special term, Part V, of the State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, died yesterday in the Downstate Medical Center, Brooklyn. He was 60 years old and lived at 3060 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.

BAYONNE, N.J., Aug. 29 Msgr, Anthony Tralka, pastor emeritus of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church here, died Thursday. He was 80 years old and had been pastor of the church from 1929 until his retirement two years ago.
A man and woman from Brooklyn were arrested yesterday on charges arising from shooting in the St. George section of Staten Island in which one teen-ager was killed and another wounded.
SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 29 (AP) The National Legislative Conference has urged state legislatures to petition Congress for a constitutional convention on the question of revenue sharing.
LIMA, Peru, Aug. 29 (AP) Peru's military Government has bought all foreign shares and has taken control of the Continental Bank.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 29 Bob Lurtsema is a competent 250-pound defensive lineman with the New York Giants. Like any lineman, he expects to have trouble with opponents who weigh the same as he does, but when he hits a quarterback, he would like to think the man would have the good form to fall down.

WILLIAMSPORT, Pa., Aug. 29 (AP) Thousands of dead fish floated up along 150 miles of the Susquehanna River Saturday, killed by what officials said were massive amounts of mine acid polluting the waters. Workers dumped tons of lime into the river to neutralize the deadly acids. They reported some success.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 29 The Democratic party has a substantial lead over the Republicans among those taking sides in a Gallup Poll as the party "best able to handle the top problem" of the United States.

Dog fanciers from the East, South and Midwest will head for the metropolitan area next weekend for a big triple, during which an entry of 5,543 dogs will compete for ribbons. On Saturday, there will be 1,824 at the 36th annual all-breed event of the Somerset Hills...
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 On the second leg of today's America's Cup trial, three smell planes circled over the competing yachts.
MIAMI, Aug. 29 Air travelers, some bitter over their unhappy experiences at Kennedy International Airport, are discovering Miami as a gateway to Europe.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 29 King Hussein of Jordan, in a television speech tonight, warned Arab commandos that "we shall deal with any attempt to undermine our national unity with whatever means are necessary."

RECIFE, Brazil, Aug. 26 Across the gray backlands of northeastern Brazil 392,000 men and boys are digging ditches, clearing brush and building roads by hand to avoid starving to death with their families.

WESTPORT, Conn., Aug. 29 Miss Elizabeth Wilkes Dore was married at her family's country home here this afternoon to George Webster Adams. The ceremony, written by the couple, was performed outdoors before a large boulder by the Rev. Dr. Donald S. Harrington of the Community Church of New York, Unitarian Universalist.

WASHINGTON Phase II of the United States-Soviet Strategic Arms Limitation Talks (SALT) has ended at Vienna but the missile race continues. Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird announced last week that a new multiple warhead development was observed northwest of Midway Island. The Soviet SS-11 ballistic missile, a liquidfuel version of the American Minuteman, splashed down three warheads in the Pacific.
STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 29 Edward G. Gross, a sports copy editor of The New York Times, died today in the Stamford railroad station, apparently of a heart attack. He was 58 years old.
RABAT, Morocco, Aug. 29 Official figures published today give King Hassan II a majority of over 90 per cent in Morocco's new parliament in voting that ended last night.

TAMPA, Fla., Aug. 29 The novel People Movers at Tampa International Airport, which will shuttle between the central terminal-andparking building and its boarding outposts when the new passenger complex opens Dec. 15, are already being put through their paces.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29 Lyudmila A. Gvishiani, the daughter of Premier Aleksei N. Kosygin, asserts in a book just published that United States policy in Vietnam had its roots in the early American relations with the Soviet State.

Several hundred youths roamed through Greenwich Village streets last night and early this morning after a demonstration by homosexual organizations ended. They smashed windows in at least two stores, set several minor fires and overturned two automobiles.

ROME The Vatican blew its cool last week. More significant than the cause of the uproar press reports that Indian girls were being exploited as novices in European convents was the clamorous denial the church felt it had to issue and reissue, a publicity overkill that made it seem the prelates did "protest too much."

In a mood of resentment and bewilderment landlords are crowding into dingy city offices at 280 Broadway these days to pick up stacks of new rent forms. The landlords are trying to figure out how to do the complex paperwork to get rent increases under the city's new rent control law.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 29 Brilliant weather and moderate winds out of the northwest were enjoyed by everybody involved in the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club Race Week sailing today.

MIAMI, Aug. 29 (AP) The Elias Brothers Farms' Grass Eater took command at the head of the stretch today to win the $5,000 added Singing Tower Stakes at Tropical Park. Feature Attraction was second, followed by War Lady.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Aug. 29 The marriage of Miss Susan Barret Shepardson to Andrew Alexander Lockhart Jr., son of Mr. Lockhart of London and Mrs. Lockhart of Harrow, England, took place in St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon.

GATLINTBURG, Tenn. Great Smoky Mountains National Park, which spans the crest of the Appalachians between Tennessee and North Carolina, has consistently led the nation's 33 national parks in attendance figures. This summer has been no different: In July alone 1.33 million people were counted, and the seven-month total through July 31 was 3.68 million.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 The Supreme Court has set hearings for Oct. 12 in two Southern school desegregation cases that are expected to produce landmark decisions on the extent to which busing can be required to achieve racial integration.

THE Soviet Union, which launched the first unmanned earth satellite on October 4, 1957, and issued a stamp to commemorate the event, and which has issued more than 160 stamps honoring its astronauts and their accomplishments, has added another stamp to the series this one (shown at right, above) is for the flight of Suyoz 9, July 119, 1970. It is inscribed (in Russian) "424 Hours in Orbit Around the Earth."

ARTHUR KOESTLER ("Darkness at Noon," "The Yogi and the Commissar," "The Ghost in the Machine") is 65 this week. In the following interview with him in Paris, the editors of L'Express drew him out on a life spent seeking "a universal explanation, a key to everything" from Communism in the thirties to "harmonizers" for man in the seventies. The translation is by Stanley Hochman.

CAIRO Photographs of a broadly smiling Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian commando leader, on the front pages of newspapers here last week perhaps gave as much insight as a dozen editorials and policy pronouncements into the tactics and objectives of the Egyptian leadership in the "peace exchanges" under way at the United Nations.

The Continental Championship of the Sports Car Club of America will make its first appearance of the season in this part of the country on Labor Day on the 1.53-mile road course of Lime Rock Park in Connecticut. The main event, as usual, will be for Formula A cars the highwing, open-wheel racers with a single seat in an open cockpit...

FALLS CHURCH, Va., Aug. 29 Miss Emily Graham Lay, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Selden Lay Jr., was married in St. James Roman Catholic Church here this afternoon to Paul Ignatius O'Connell, son of Mrs. Valentine George O'Connell of Upper Montclair, N.J., and the late Mr. O'Connell. The Rev. Thomas McArdle performed the ceremony and celebrated the nuptial mass, assisted by the Rev. Maurice Carlton and the Rev. Albert Holtz.
Honeywell, Inc., announced last week the election of C.W. Spangle as senior vice president in charge of the company's computer operations.

WEATHERFORD, Tex., Aug. 29 Miss Glenda Allen Green and Victor Koshkin-Youritzin, who are on the faculty of the art department at Newcomb College of Tulane University, were married here tonight in the garden at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Allen Green, parents of the bride. The Methodist ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Wayne Reynolds, assisted by the Rev. Carl P. Mehaffy.

WARRENTON, Va., Aug. 29 St. John's Roman Catholic Church was the setting here today for the marriage of Miss Madeleine Feroline Perkins Wallach, a June graduate of Goucher College, to John Bernard McKeon, who was graduated with the class of 1970 from Johns Hopkins University.

THE International Piano Library was founded in 1966 to preserve, reproduce and dissemi- nate important historical piano recordings. Building its collection slowly after one or two sizable acquisitions, the IPL seemed a year ago on sure if modest footing. Important recordings were released (available to members only) which were of sufficient interest to warrant reviews in these pages over the years rare recordings of Josef Hofmann, Ferruccio Busoni, Leopold Godowsky.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Aug. 29 (AP) Mr. and Mrs. Charles Robb have moved into a $59,500 home near the University of Virginia, where Mr. Robb will attend law school this fall.

It is hard to say whether this has been one of those explosive summers for roadside wildflowers or whether the drought in some way prompted their profusion. But whatever the reason, the fields and byways have been spectacular for weeks, starting with the white of daisies, and will be for weeks to come, again with white, the clouds of asters.

ON JULY 4, 1970, I participated in the dedication of the Caddie Woodlawn Memorial Park in western Wisconsin. The park is a six-acre tract that was formerly a part of the 160-acre homestead of my great-grandfather, John V. Woodhouse. It is located on State Route 25 about 12 miles south of Menomonie, four miles from Downsville and near the site of what was formerly the town of Dunnville.

ST. LOUIS, 29 Miss Marhere to David C. Reiser, son of garet Ann Lowrey was married Mr. and Mrs. Neil Reiser of Riverdale, the Bronx, New York, this evening at the home of the bride's stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. John G. Goessling.
TURIN, Italy, Aug. 29 (AP) The United States continued to dominate the sixth World University games today winning six gold medals to increase its total to 19.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29 Proudest Roman installed himself as patrician of the thoroughbred world today. Mrs. John A. Morris's Kentucky home-bred won the $130,950 Hopeful, the closing-day feature of the most successful Saratoga meeting in history.
THERE'S quite a mess involved with the stamps of Fujeira, about which we went to some lengths on July 19 when we discussed proliferation of stamp issues.

Dr. Harold Fink, chief pathologist at Coney Island Hospital and clinical professor of pathology at the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, died Friday night in Yale-New Haven Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 1901 Dorchester Road, Brooklyn.
The poisons of pollution are penetrating the Ford Foundation's indoor gardens but the greenery still looks verdant and inviting on a summer day.

The enlightened and enlightening Requiem of Mozart, which for all its brooding and pathetic passages takes a humanistic attitude towards death, ended the final program in the "Mostly Mozart Festival" at Philharmonic Hall on Friday night. (It was repeated last night.) It was given an astonishingly mature reading by Michael Tilson Thomas, the gifted young associate conductor of the Boston Symphony.

It can do no harm to tell it now. At the age of 15, this reviewer fell hopelessly in love with S.J. Perelman. It was from afar, for I was sitting in Jackson (Miss.) High School, in Cicero class. While the others were studying "How long, O Catiline, must we endure your orations?" I was taking in "'Gad, Lucy, You're Magnificent!' Breathed the Great Painter," drawing and caption by...

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Aug. 29 Patrick O'Neal, at the helm of the Shields Class sloop, Theresa; James M. Mertz, with the Etchells-22, Shillalah II, and Mathias J. Burgraf's Eaglet in Class S, were winners of 9.8mile races on Long Island Sound today, They competed in the season's 30th Yacht Racing Association championship regatta.
Today American Hot Rod Association summer national drag racing finals at New York National Speedway, Center Moriches, L.I., postponed from last Sunday, 2 P.M.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sunday, Aug. 30 (AP) Enemy troops attacked a Buddhist orphanage and temple south of Danang today, killing 15 South Vietnamese and wounding 45, a Government spokesman reported. He said that most of the victims had been orphans.

SEOUL, South Korea, Aug. 29 Lord Caradon, the former British representative at the United Nations, left here today after having appealed to the South Korean Government for clemency for a Korean, a University of Cambridge graduate who has been sentenced to death for espionage activity.

RANGOON Three countries in Southeast Asia have tried to remain neutral in the face of Communist expansionism. Laos fell years ago, Cambodia joined her last March. Burma remains, but the pressure on her is mounting.
Wind tunnels, long a tool of aerospace companies, have found their way into a maze of new uses.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 (UPI) A municipal judge who was injured Feb. 2 in a bomb explosion that leveled the Shaker Heights Police and Municipal Court Building has filed a $100,000 damage suit against the company that sold the explosives used in the blast.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 29 Willie Mays Jim Ray Hart and Bobby Bonds slammed home runs as San Francisco wiped out a seven run deficit in the eighth inning and went on to beat the Pittsburgh Pirates today in 10 innings, 10-9. Bonds' two-out single in the 10th was the clincher.
GOING ALL THE WAY, by Dan Wakefield. The sad and funny fumblings of a determined sexual maladroit who teams up with an ace makeout man during one post-Army summer in the depths of Indianapolis.
Two night games, one at home against Paterson State and one on the road against St. Peter's of Jersey City, will be highlights of Fairleigh Dickinson University's 1970 football schedule.

WILMINGTON, Del., Aug. 29 Eliza Pande, a baseline player with a telling looping backhand stroke down the line, won the United States women's amateur grass court tennis championship today by upsetting the topseeded Sharon Walsh, 3-6, 9-7, 6-2, in an allCalifornia final at the Wilmington Country Club.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 29 (AP) Dave McNally, a left-handed pitcher, aided his own cause tonight with three hits, including a bases-loaded double, as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 6 to 1. McNally notched his 21st victory of the season.

Tomaso Buscetta, described as one of the top leaders of the Sicilian Mafia, was captured last week in New York and is being held for deportation by the Federal Immigration and Naturalization Service, officials said yesterday.
Three members of the second place New York Yankees will make a personal appearance at Monticello Raceway on Wednesday.
JERSEY CITY, Aug. 29 The Long Island Bulls, trailing, 10-0, at half-time, rallied to defeat the Jersey Jays, 17-10, in their closing exhibition game tonight before 18,200 fans at Roosevelt Stadium.
Can a power-hitter woman golfer beat one of the top money-winning men professionals?
The Bronx Model Cities program said yesterday that it was seeking applicants for a program leading to appointments to the Fire Department.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y. After the three full-scale wars and incessant border strife that have marked the 22 years of Arab-Israeli relations, the two sides were finally brought together at the United Nations last week to begin the search for peace.
ATLANTA, Aug. 29 The South stands this weekend on the verge of a rendezvous that was ordained by the Supreme Court more than 16 years ago.

WASHINGTON The economic news last week was almost too good to believe. For the first time in the often-trying 19 months of the Nixon Administration, just about everything seemed to go right. This did not mean that the economy was out of the woods umemployment remains high and may go higher, and inflation has by no means ceased. But there was no disputing that the news was brighter:

LONDON, Aug. 28 Two British social scientists who have interviewed political lead- ers in Northern Ireland have concluded that the intervention of the British peace-keeping force there left the Roman Catholic minority isolated and "put an end to all immediate hopes of reform."

One if by Land It may not exactly be one of the enduring mysteries of American life, but it happens between 200 and 300 times in every baseball game and it sets up the ultimate confrontation of the sport: The catcher squats behind home plate and waggles his fingers in a rapid and coded sequence to the pitcher 60 feet away.
Motorists who store their cars in commercial parking lots and garages here will be charged the 6 per cent sales tax beginning Tuesday. The tax is expected to yield $15million a year.
KYOTO, Japan, Aug. 26 Defense against crime "should be an integral part of national planning," a United Nations congress on crime prevention has concluded.
SALEM, N.H., Aug. 29 (AP) B.A. Dario's Great Mystery turned on speed in the stretch today and won the $15,975 White Mountain Handicap before a crowd of 14,274 at Rockingham Park.
Kent State will honor its three American League players prior to the Yankee-Indian game in Cleveland, Sept. 13.

SINCE that time, two and a half years ago, a few things have changed around Hollywood. The Chamber of Commerce of Bridgeport, a city that Mayor Lindsay said last week was as dirty as New York, has sent a letter to Mayor Lindsay suggesting he should have consulted his wife before talking about Bridgeport.

While the hectic and sometimes violent nineteen sixties produced many Negro leaders who gained national prominence, far more who rose to positions of influence in their own communities remain unknown to outsiders.

GREENWICH, Conn., Aug. 29 Sailing into the lead at the start of the final beat, Arthur H. Boultbee won his first Luders-16 Class race today with Bonito. The race was run during the season's 33d championship regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets based eastof-Rye on Long Island Sound.
A strong team of four riders will leave for Toronto tomorrow to defend the United States junior Nations Cup championship on Sept. 6.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 29 (AP) Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, assured President Nixon today that the Senate would consider the Administration's welfare reform plan before it quits this year.

WASHINGTON, Conn., Aug. 29 In St. John's Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Sharon Forester Salembier, daughter of Richard Van Zandt Salembier of Washington and East Booth Bay Harbor, Me., and the late Mrs. Marjorie Forester Salembier, was married to John Russell Cornell. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Cornell of Point O'Woods, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Haig Nargesian performed the ceremony.
FREEHOLD, N.J., Aug.29 Maida Million, driven by Eddie Cobb, won her fourth straight race at Freehold Raceway today when she captured the $10,000 Marlboro feature by a neck.

AUGUSTA, Ga. On they came, moving along Broad Street without attracting much attention, an irregular band of women and children carrying miniature American flags and looking terribly self-conscious as they sang "God Bless America" and "Onward, Christian Soldiers." A boy with a bugle puffed out a squeaky version of "The Star Spangled Banner," and a matron in purple slacks and green sweater led the small group in the Pledge of Allegiance.

WASHINGTON The American way of death has always included a considerable measure of racial segregation. Yet a ripple of indignation spread across the country last week when a black soldier killed in Vietnam was denied burial in a "Caucasian-only" Florida cemetery.

PLANT collecting as a science goes back to the 16th century. It was about 1530 that Luca Ghini of the University of Bologna found that plants dried under pressure and mounted on heavy paper could be preserved almost indefinitely. His methods soon became popular and within a few years had spread throughout Europe.

BOBBY FISCHER of the United States continues his domination of the chess world by winning first place during the recent Second International at Buenos Aires an 18-man round robin. Without losing a game outright, Fischer scored 15-2. He won 13 games and drew four with the grandmasters Miguel Najdorf of Argentina, Enrique Mecking of Brazil, Vassily Smyslov of the Soviet Union and United States champion Sammy Reshevsky.

BOSTON, Aug. 29 Urban universities, swollen by increases in population and para phernalia, are finding themselves in deep conflict with their surrounding communities. In many cases, the communities have been successful in thwarting the schools' search for more space.
GENEVA, Aug. 29 National rivalries have again prevented a United Nations committee from agreeing on the basic principals for the internationalization of the seabed.

The 1970 census is underscoring the two-year-old warning of the National Advisory Commission of Civil Disorders that America is "moving toward two societies, one black, one white separate and unequal."
ATLANTA, Aug. 29 Three of the four leading governorship candidates in the Georgia primaries Sept. 9, all former moderates in Southern terms, have shifted to the right.

LONDON, Aug. 29 What the United States needs is a revival of hypocrisy. The conclusion is inescapable for anyone from the new candid, tellit-like-it-is America who has seen the monumental old hypocrisy of London.
ATLANTIC CITY, Aug. 29 (AP) Audley Farm's Ziba Blue and M.J. Stavola's Apple Princess won the two divisions of today's Pageant Handicap at Atlantilc City.

The National Hockey League this week continued to widen its search for greater recognition, which ultimately will mean greater revenue from the cereals, vitamins, games, watches and other promotional tieins it has been involved with for the last few years.
TOMBSTONE, Ariz., Aug. 29 (UPI) A husband and wife running for Mayor have announced a separation.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Aug. 29 (Agence FrancePresse) The military command circular clearly spelled out the danger for combat troops: be careful when you salvage enemy ammunition, it may be booby-trapped.

EXHIBITS at the American Numismatic Asso- ciation's convention in St. Louis were the richest and most varied ever assembled for this annual show. The spacious Exhibition Hall of the Chase-Park Plaza Hotel served as headquarters for this 79th anniversary event and was the major center of attraction.

FROM Fort Worth, Tex., has come a letter written by Thomas Edward Wall, who says that he is deeply worried and confused about the future of electronic music. What bothers him is the attitude of the general public, which seems to be re ceiving electronic music more as a commercial product than as the serious musical form he believes it to be.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Aug. 29 Miss Constance Ann Dever and Douglas Alan Motz were married here this morning in Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church by the bride's cousin, the Rev. Anthony Wallace, who also co-celebrated the nuptial mass with the Rev. Mario Costa.

PERHAPS it's just the summer doldrums Fun City beginning to pall, literally as well as figuratively but the three shows I've seen over the past two weeks have all failed to interest me, albeit for different reasons. NEW HAVEN When Dr. Joseph Goldstein in 1954 helped draft the Durham Rule, one of the juridical landmarks that broadened the use of insanity defense, he did not dream that one day he would oppose the basic concept of such a defense.

LONDON, Aug. 29 (Reuters) Leeds United defeated Burnley, 3-0, today to register its fifth successive victory and maintain its 2-point lead in the English Soccer League First Division.

DARIEN, Conn., Aug. 29 In St. Luke's Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Anne Van Wyck Crimmins and Anthony Adams Rockwood, students at the University of Denver, were married by the Rev. Dr. Robert N. Back.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 (AP) Roy Foster and Buddy Bradford cracked two homers each today and Sam McDowell won his 19th game, a career high, as the Cleveland Indians trounced the California Angeles, 14-1.
MIAMI, Aug. 29 (AP) The Miami Dolphins broke Baltimore's 11-game preseason winning streak tonight as the former Colt coach, Don Shula, beat his ex-team, 20-13, before a record crowd of 76,712.

All Presidents have the same objective mainly, to win maxi- mum exposure of their views in the best possible light but the techniques they employ are as different as the men themselves.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 29 (AP) In a decision wiping out a 300-year-old practice, a judge has ruled that juveniles may not be held in jail awaiting trials but may be kept in custody of the state Youth Service Board.
THE SUCCESS of Hugh Hefner's television venture, "Playboy After Dark," has set visions of residuals dancing in the heads of other sharp magazine editors and publishers.
LONDON, Aug. 28 (Reuters) Secretarial services are to be provided for the traveling businessmen from Nov. 1, by British United Airways, Britain's largest private airline.

The New York Racing Association's program shifts back to Belmont Park tomorrow, following a successful 24-day meeting at Saratoga. The Belmont Park meeting will run 42 racing days through Oct. 17 and then the final 43 days of the New York season will be at Aqueduct from Oct. 19 through Dec. 7.

HOUSTON, Aug. 29 Completing one of the most disheartening weeks of their entire history and that's saying a lot the New York Mets lost to the Houston Astros today, 9-8, in 10 innings, after taking a one-run lead in the top of the 10th.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Aug. 29 President Rafael Caldera told Venezuelans this week that their Government did not have enough funds to open public primary and secondary schools for the new term on Sept. 15.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29 Faced with a budget deficit of more than $5-million, the Cleveland Board of Education has reduced the hours of more than 2,000 nonteaching employes by at least 20 per cent until Dec. 31.
SEQUOIA NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Aug. 29 (AP) Mount Whitney, the second tallest mountain in the nation, is gaining a dubious reputation as America's highest trash can.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29 Baron Bich's America's Cup challenge went to the guillotine yesterday when he found himself lost in the fog in the fourth race between his France and the Australian boat Gretel II. The Baron was beautifully dressed for the execution and his sartorial elegance prompted Jim Hardy's brother Tom to shout over to the skipper of Gretel II, "Where are your gloves, Jim?" just before the start.
The Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, pastor emeritus of Christ Church, Methodist, died yesterday in his home at 830 Park Avenue.

Sixty candidates for the Williams College football team will report to Coach Larry Catuzzi and his staff today. Included in the group are 25 returning lettermen and 30 sophomores. The team captain is senior Rob Farnham of Brattleboro, Vt., a tackle.

BEDFORD, N.Y., Aug. 29 Miss Brenda Jean Carlson, daughter of Byron A. Carlson of Chappaqua, and the late Mrs. Carlson, and Dr. Thomas Roberts Kinney, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas D. Kinney of Durham, N.C., were married here today by the Rev. Ernest C. Olsen at the Bedford Presbyterian Church.

NEW YORK University's School of Con- tinuing Education is offering a series of courses on film production this fall.
