CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 Think of all the classic mismatches the second LouisSchmeling fight, Roosevelt-Landon, Johnson-Goldwater, Green Bay-Kansas City then add the 1970 Davis Cup challenge round between the United States and West Germany.

The American Stock Exchange is initiating an industrywide communications network that will replace costly systems operated independently by brokers, Ralph S. Saul, president of the exchange, disclosed over the weekend.

CENTER MORICHES, L.I., Aug. 30 Dwayne Ong of Detroit drove his rear-engine Pawnbroker to the A.A.-fuel dragster championship today at the American Hot Rod Association nationals before 18,212 at the National Speedway. It was the first national title for a rear-engine fuel dragster.
LONDON The monocle, which enjoyed its highest vogue in the pages of Victorian novelists, is back in favor here.
PASADENA, Calif., Aug. 30 A 1970 Plymouth sedan powered by liquefied propane gas was first across the finish line tonight in the transcontinental intercollegiate "clean car" race.

Sidney M. Sheldon, a teacher of mechanical drawing and mathematics at Samuel Gompers Vocational and Technical High School, the Bronx, died Saturday in his home at 1025 Gerard Avenue, the Bronx. He was 65 years old.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 30 (AP) Carl Eller, an all-pro defensive end, ended his two-week holdout tonight when he agreed to a 1970 contract with the Minnesota Vikings. Terms of the contract were not disclosed.
KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Aug. 30 (AP) Prince Abdul Rahman, the founder and leader of this country since 1957, announced today that he would retire as Prime Minister on Sept. 21.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Aug. 30 Lee Oldak, a youth from the neighboring Knickerbocker Yacht Club who sailed in the Blue Jay Class, was chosen as the winner tonight of the Black Jack Trophy as the leading helmsman of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club's race week.

PHILADELPHIA, Monday, Aug. 31 Four Philadelphia policemen were shot in a black neighborhood of West Philadelphia over the weekend, one fatally. The three wounded policemen remained in serious condition early today.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The top 10 countries of the Eastern and of the Western Hemispheres sending immigrants to the United States in the fiscal year 1970, which ended last June 30, are listed in the left-hand column below, with preliminary State Department figures.
OAKLAND, Calif., Aug. 30 (AP) The Green Bay Packers raced to a 24-0 first-period lead and went on to trounce the Oakland Raiders, 37-7, in a ragged National Football League preseason game tonight.

RYE, N.Y., Aug. 30 Miss Gail Ann Lauter and Henry Dave Podolsky were married here this afternoon. Rabbi Morris Kertzer performed the ceremony at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert I. Lauter. The bridegroom's parents are Mrs. Reuben Podolsky of Lynn, Mass., and the late Mr. Podolsky.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 30 (UPI) Alex Johnson drove in four runs with a homer and a single today to power the California Angels to a 10-9 victory over the Cleveland Indians. A total of nine homers were hit by the teams, two short of the major league record.

Tournament players using standard methods know how to bid a balanced hand with 21 high-card points: Open two no-trump. The minority who stick with strong twobids and a 22-24 point two no-trump bid have to open one of a suit, a less satisfactory action.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 30 About 1,000 persons turned out today to march through downtown Portland in the widely heralded "Victory to the Vietnamese People" parade and to protest the American Legion national convention in progress here.

BUFFALO, Aug. 30 The Police Department here said today that it would arrest all street venders of the Black Panther newspaper under a 1902 state criminal-anarchy statute now under review by the United States Supreme Court.
The rally in the credit markets gathered momentum last week, and it very likely will continue this week. Bond prices should continue to rise and interest rates should keep working their way lower.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 30 (Agence France-Presse) The Council of Ministers of the Organization of African Unity approved a resolution today that would condemn France, Britain and West Germany for selling or planning to sell arms to South Africa.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 (UPI) Denny McLain has reacted to his second suspension of the season by asking to be traded and blaming the Detroit Tigers' general manager a longtime supporter of McLain for the team's collapse.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Both savings flows and mortgage-lending activity rose sharply in July at savings and loan associations, the Federal Home Loan Bank board reported today.

The Rochester Lancers and the Washington Darts, who both joined the North American Soccer League last year, have triumphed in the Northern and Southern Divisions, respectively, and will meet in a twogame playoff for the league title.

WHITE PLAINS, Aug. 30 Miss Jane L. Heffer, daughter of Mrs. Jacob M. Seiler of New York and Mamaroneck, was married today to Agostino T. Galluzzo, son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Galluzzo of Springfield, Mass. The ceremony, at the White Plains Hotel, was performed by the Rev. Robert Young, chaplain of the Dana Hall School in Wellesley, Mass.

Metromedia, Inc., and a union representing television technicians announced last night that they had reached an agreement to end the 100-dayold strike against WNEW-TV here and WTTG in Washington, D.C.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 30 Billy Haughton, the man from Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., who has driven trotters in 24 heats in 12 Hambletonians without finishing first once, will not get the chance to break through in Wednesday's 45th edition of harness racing's showcase event.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 The pattern of immigration into the United States has been drastically altered by legislation of the mid-nineteen-sixties.
The old question as to whether the New York Stock Exchange is subject to antitrust laws appears to be headed for a court trial in Milwaukee.
HONOLULU, Aug. 30 Vice President Agnew, heading home today from a tour of five Asian nations, said that more than half the Communist combat forces in Cambodia "have been eliminated."

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., Aug. 30 By the time Joe Namath slouched into a huddle tonight for the first time this year, the New York Jets were losing, 21-0, to the Minnesota Vikings. As a result, the situation minimized the significance of the quarterback's return.

TRENTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) Ray Hendrick of Richmond drove his 1969 Camaro to a full lap victory today in the Trenton 200-mile race for modified stock cars and earned $10,400, the biggest auto racing payday of his career.
George Meany, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., says that the Democratic party "has disintegrated" and that trade unionists are no longer as attracted to it as they have been in the past.
TOKYO, Aug. 30 (UPI) Kyodo News Agency said today that Japan would seek to improve her relations with North Vietnam soon in an attempt to bring peace to Indochina.
Thoroughbred racing returns to Belmont Park today with the $25,000 Fall Highweight Handicap at six furlongs heading the opening-day program of the 42-day meeting.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, Aug. 30 Spokesmen for the Arab commando movement said tonight that the Jordanian Army had attacked commando installations in Amman for more than two hours tonight.
CANDIA, Crete, Aug. 30 (Reuters) Five Americans were questioned by the Greek police today after their arrest on drug-smuggling charges after a dramatic air chase across the Mediterranean
PITTSBURGH, Aug. 30 Automobile companies are beginning to place orders for steel to be delivered in October.

DETROIT, Aug. 30 (AP) Bill Freehan, playing his last game before undergoing a back operation, singled to touch off a two-run Detroit rally in the eighth inning today as the Tigers rallied to beat the Oakland Athletics, 6-5.

Only hours after a patrolman in the Bronx was wounded in an apparently unprovoked shotgun assault by two youths, the Police Department issued an order at 3 A.M. yesterday requiring each patrolman walking a beat in the evening and night hours to work "in close proximity" to another policeman.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug 30 "Well done."

There hasn't been much in the way of brokerage house reports on advertising agencies these days, so when one appears, that's news. The investment firm of Sassower, Jacobs Schneider issued one recently with a generally bullish appraisal of the field.
UPPER SALFORD TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 30 Although no official proclamation was made, yesterday at the Philadelphia Folk Festival might have been declared Luther Allison Day.

WASHINGTON It is not easy to hide a B-52. Nor is it possible to conceal as anyone who has flown over the jungles of Vietnam in a helicopter can plainly see the moon-craters caused by each plane's thirtyton bombload. Long after the war is a dying memory, these holes in the landscape of four countries in Southeast Asia will remain as reminders of the American way of life and death.
BALTIMORE, Aug. 30 (AP) Skip Lockwood of the Milwaukee Brewers beat the Baltimore Orioles, 5-2, today with relief help from Ken Sanders and ended his second five-game losing streak of the season.

Senator Charles E. Goodell charged yesterday that his Democratic rival, Richard L. Ottinger, was a late opponent of the war in Vietnam, whereas he said he had "stood alone" last fall in making "the first attempt to legislate an end to the war."
CLIFTON, N.J., Aug. 30 For a moment the ball hesitated at the rim of the cup, then it fell in and Bobby Nichols won the $60,000 first prize today in the $300,000 Dow Jones open golf tournment.
AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 29 Highly placed Jordanian informants said today that 5,000 Iraqi troops have been moved from Syria to Jordan in recent days.
The police seized a suitcase containing 10 pounds of heroin valued at $500,000, and arrested a man and two women in a sixth-story apartment at 581 Timpson Place in the South Bronx last night.
POPLARVILLE, Miss. One day last week, as the high school football team was practicing behind the gymnasium, a group of the town's businessmen gathered to watch.

The Salvation Army announced yesterday that Lieut.Commissioner J. Clyde Cox had been promoted to full commissioner and appointed commander of the organization's 11-state central territory, with headquarters in Chicago.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30 (AP) The Boston Red Sox slammed 22 hits in the first game today and then cashed in on secondgame homers by Rico Petrocelli and Mike Andrews to sweep a double-header from the Chicago White Sox 21-11 and 4-1.
In capturing first place in the recent Buenos Aires international tournament, Bobby Fischer scored 15 points of a possible 17 during the 18-man round-robin.
VENICE, Italy, Aug. 30 (AP) Norman Mailer unveiled his film "Maidstone" at the Venice Film Festival today with the hope of wining major critical acclaim in a field of relatively unapplauded films.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 30 After five days of deliberation the Superior Court jury considering the fate of Lonnie McLucas, the first Black Panther to stand trial in connection with the Alex Rackley slaying, reported itself today to be in disagreement on a verdict.

BAY SHORE, L.I., Aug. 30 Reginald Page of the Stamford Yacht Club paced second in both races today to take the Cottontail Class national sailing championship. Page, in his Wabbitt, had a fourth and two firsts yesterday.

ELKHORN, Wis., Aug. 30 (AP) An underground newspaper editor was convicted of contempt today for refusing to testify before a grand jury investigating the bombing of a University of Wisconsin building last Monday.
DALLAS, Aug. 30 (UPI) Abraham Zapruder, the only person to take motion pictures of the assassination of President Kennedy, died today of cancer at Presbyterian Hospital here. He was 66 years old.
Mayor Lindsay has urged a Senate committee to resist "intensive industry pressure," by accelerating a ban on sales of polluting motor vehicles to 1975, moving the measure up five years from 1980.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30 Baron Marcel Bich, the president of the French Association for the America's Cup, formally accused the International Race Committee today of dishonoring him and his 12-Meter yacht, France, by allowing last Friday's race to continue under illegal conditions.
SOPOT, Poland, Aug. 30 The voice of protest American protest came to Poland last Thursday night as Joan Baez galvanized an audience at the Sopot Folk Song Festival.

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 30 A force of 330 sheriff's deputies patrolled the East Los Angeles Mexican-American community today after an antiwar demonstration erupted into a riot yesterday. The riot caused one death, at least 53 injuries and extensive property damage.

TORONTO In its first significant modification of last November's sweeping taxreform proposals, the Canadian Government has responded sympathetically to complaints from mining companies, an industry that accounts for a lot of jobs and export earnings.

MONTREAL, Aug. 30 (AP) John Boccabella's bases-loaded single capped a three-run rally in the fourth inning today and the Montreal Expos went on to defeat the Cincinnati Reds and their 20-game winner, Jim Merritt, 5-1.

New York City is facing the threat of Federal cuts of more than $4-million in its continuing antipoverty programs, David J. Billings 3d, chairman of the city's Council against Poverty, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ended yesterday.
A wounded prisoner escaped from a fourth-floor room in St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday by turning his wheelchair into a weapon, the police said.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 30 Several, million South Vietnamese elected 30 Senators today in voting marked by terrorist attacks in some areas and charges of fraud in others.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 30 The Israeli Cabinet failed to agree today on an opening negotiating position for the indirect peace talks with the Arab states, amid evidence of a growing split between Premier Golda Meir and Defense Minister Moshe Dayan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Complying with a personal request by Senator Barry Goldwater, the State Department has canceled the appointment of Arthur J. Olsen, a Foreign Service officer, as the new director of the department's office of press relations.

FLORAL PARK, L.I., Aug. 30 The marriage of Miss Mary Jo Cook to Daniel Patrick Santo Pietro, assistant director of Catholic Relief Services in Rio de Janeiro, took place in Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church here today.

Unlike most of the world's population, Americans take it for granted that their farms will produce an abundance of food each year so much so that farmers receive Federal subsidies to produce less than they might. Against this background, it was a shock this month to learn that the nation's corn crop is under attack by a virulent fungus, the Southern corn leaf blight, which may cut total yield by 20 to 50 per cent.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 30 Top Administration officials here at the Presidential compound are, of course, happy with the good news Vice President Agnew is apparently bringing home from his Asian tour.
HOUSTON, Aug. 30 The bewildered New York Mets sank a little deeper, without knowing exactly at the moment how much deeper, as they lost again to the Houston Astros today, 9-5.
An agency for the development of more effective library services for the disadvantaged and handicapped across the country has been established at Columbia University.
WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 30 "It will be a victory for us just to step on the field." That not entirely facetious remark came from Bill Whitton, the head football coach at Holy Cross College.

LONDON, Aug. 30 Along Gerrard Street, the smell of pickled ginger and roast duckling seeps from restaurant doors. The men scurry into stores for afternoon games of fan-tan and mah-jongg. A lilting twang of Chinese rock 'n' roll envelops the downtown street.

Senator Jacob K. Javits assailed the Administration yesterday for not supporting his proposal to create an emergency loan guarantee authority. He accused the White House staff of "misleading" President Nixon on the seriousness of the liquidity problem facing the nation's major corporations.
Supreme Court Justice Charles Margett of Queens has been named administrative judge of the Supreme Court for Queens County, the 11th Judicial District.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., Aug. 30 Miss Jane Wilson Foy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Wilson Foy, was married here today to Joseph William Karaman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Bernard Karaman.

The states of New York and Connecticut will open bids today for the contract to supply 144 new cars for the Penn Central's New Haven commuter division. Optimism was expressed that the long-planned but oftenpostponed bistate take-over of rail commuter service between New York City and New Haven would be consummated within a few weeks.
Help-wanted advertising in July fell to the lowest level since October, 1965, according to the National Industrial Conference Board.

Miss Judith Ellen Seidel, an editor with the Twentieth Century Fund, was married here yesterday to Leon Irwin Jacobson, a lawyer with Paul, Weiss, Goldberg, Rifkind, Wharton Garrison. Rabbi Mark N. Goldman performed the ceremony at the Croydon Hotel.

It could be that the most important political figures in New York during the last couple of months have been Tanya Melich, Paul Schossberg, Daniel Oliver, Alton G. Marshall, Peter Edelman and James D. Griffin.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Aug. 30 Kenneth E. Brigham of Hampton, director of public relations and advertising of the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company of this city, died today at his summer residence in Kitty Hawk, N.C. He was 49 years old.

Yogiraj Sri Swami Satchidananda gently shot the cuffs of his saffron-colored robe and looked out over the several thousand people, hip and straight, gathered on Hart Island in the Bronx for Phoenix House's annual end-ofsummer happening.

SALINAS, Calif., Aug. 30 (UPI) The United Farm Workers Organizing Committee announced tonight the signing of a contract with one of the largest vegetable growers in the Salinas Valley, the first victory in the union's struggle to organize the "salad bowl," which produces 70 per cent of the nation's lettuce.

American Airlines wants to sell more air freight and is turning to local media in four cities to do it. In the past, the big carrier has essentially used national media but it is now starting an experimental program using newspapers and, for the first time, radio spots.

RICHMOND, Aug. 30 Ten years ago, Lucien Doyle Adams, then an assistant superintendent of schools in the Richmond system, came home from services at the Episcopal Church and told his wife he was not feeling well.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 Nicholas Johnson, a member of the Federal Communications Commission, said today that every time the President spoke to the nation on television, the networks should give comparable treatment to opposite views.

The Lancaster Hotel in Manhattan said yesterday that it had to turn the lights and airconditioning off in the gubernatorial campaign headquarters of Arthur J. Goldberg several times during the last four and a half months in order to force the staff to pay at least token rent.

FARMINGTON, Mo., Aug. 30 The First State Bank of Bonne Terre, closed since Aug. 24 because of alleged mismanagement of about $1.5-million in loans, is scheduled to open tomorrow under a new charter awarded to Commerce Bancshares, Inc., of Kansas City.

City Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath said yesterday that rioting three weeks ago by prisoners at the Manhattan Men's House of Detention was not so much a protest against conditions there as "a symptom of our times."

Suggestion for the Labor Day weekend. If you've had enough of parties and sand and mountains, of people and dogs and demonstrations and double-headers ... if you'd like to forget about traffic and packing and the end of summer, find yourself a hammock or an armchair and read "God Is an Englishman," the fifth and newest of R.F.

The Senate will vote tomorrow on the HatfieldMcGovern amendment to set a timetable for ending the war in Vietnam, an objective devoutly wished by millions of Americans. The framers of the measure have labored responsibly and creatively to extend the deadline for withdrawal of American forces and to allow the President flexibility in applying that deadline.

The tide of enforcement is beginning to turn against the parking-ticket scofflaw since responsibility for these cases was shifted July 1 from the city's Criminal Courts to the new Parking Violations Bureau of the Department of Transportation.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., Aug. 30 Miss Susan Etess and Barry Fallick were married here this afternoon at Grossinger's, the resort hotel founded by the bride's grandparents, Mrs. Harry (Jennie) Grossinger and the late Mr. Grossinger.
AGANA, Guam, Aug. 31 (UPI) Vice President Agnew is letting his sideburns grow longer.
Every Sunday for the last two months, a woman editor has pedaled her bicycle between her midtown office and her home in upper Manhattan, traversing the entire length of Riverside Park.

One of the great myths perpetuated by the insurance industry is that if you cannot buy auto insurance in the normal market because of your occupation, poor driving record or outright discrimination you can always turn to the assigned-risk plan, where rates are generally much higher but where coverage is always available.

Activity toys have as many uses as an inventive child's mind can devise, which is usually more than the adult mind can conceive. The most recent addition is called Play-All, three interlocking plastic pieces in orange, green and blue that form a 32-inch wheel, a 75-inch...

PHILADELPHIA As 4 A.M. approaches, the black and Puerto Rican slums are silent, and hundreds of sleepy-eyed men, women and children begin gathering to be taken from the worst parts of this city to what are regarded by many as the worst jobs in southern New Jersey.
The Federal Reserve System's present monetary policy will produce only limited relief from inflation, a new analysis showed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 On the eve of a historic wave of school desegregation in the South, the Nixon Administration was expressing confidence today that it would be carried out without any large-scale resistance or violence.
A new musical era will begin in St. Patrick's Cathedral next Sunday when John Francis Grady, organist of the Metropolitan Opera, will also become organist and musical director at the cathedral.
SALZBURG, Austria, Aug. 30 (AP) Jackie Ickx, the ace Belgian driver, won today's two-heat Formula Two race on the Salzburg Ring, wheeling his BMW to victory ahead of Italy's Vittorio Brambilla.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Aug. 18 "Awake, oh people, awake!" the dark-robed chorus cries. But everyone sleeps on, and only a nervous figure, symbolizing time, continues to move.
About 30 residents of two East 19th Street apartment buildings picketed Columbus Hospital yeterday to protest the hospital's plan to tear down their homes and replace them with a garage.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Aug. 30 A dispute between Bolivian bus, truck and taxi drivers and Indian farmers has left this capital virtually without transportation and cut off from the countryside.

Dr. Agnes M. Hadden Byrnes, emeritus professor of sociology at Hunter College, who founded and became first chairman of its sociology department in 1942, died yesterday in Wickersham Hospital. She was 90 years old and lived in the San Carlos Hotel, 150 East 50th Street.
NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 30 The busing of pupils to achieve school desegregation has become a major issue in four Southern states where important statewide political campaigns are being waged this summer.
Representatives of homosexual organzations charged yesterday that police harassment of homosexuals had been intensified within the last three weeks in the "gay ghettos" of Manhattan.

Leaders of Jewish organizations yesterday assailed assertions by Charles A. Lindbergh that the Roosevelt Administration, pro-British elements and American Jews had forced the United States into World War II a War that he contended American had lost.

MOSCOW, Aug. 30 (Reuthers) The former director of a mechanical repair shop has been sentenced to death in the Georgian Republic for accepting bribes, theft of state property and falsifying returns, according to a local newspaper.

Ken Patton, the city's Economic Development Administrator, said yesterday that he thought that New York City was heading into the slump that has already hit most of the nation, but that with basic business conditions here good he anticipated a quick recovery.

LONDON Female impersonation is an old, if strange, theatrical tradition. It can be seen in the Japanese Kabuki theater; at one time it was the common rule in Indian Kathakali dance, and in the Elizabethan theater all the girls were boys. Here no one not only complained, but no one actually seemed to notice.

LONDON Ulick O'Connor's controversial new biography, "Brendan Behan," uproots more than a few of the sturdy myths, long ago planted by Brendan himself, and ever since dutifully watered or rather, whiskyed by his admirers.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 26 A sea of Chilean flags fluttered over tattered tents and cardboard shelters as some 1,200 indigent families founded a new Marxist community in a field here this week.

RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 23 Rebel forces sponsored by the Chinese Communists have made a border region of northeastern Burma a major battleground, inflicting heavy casualties on Government forces in three battles since May.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., Aug. 30 Miss Marylu Shore and John Lewis Simon, graduate students at Cornell University, were married here this afternoon at the Quaker Ridge Golf Club by Rabbi Arthur Hertzberg.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 30 (UPI) A newly organized group of antiwar graduates of the nation's armed-service academies has opened a drive to convince Americans that "the only honorable peace now is to admit our mistake and get out" of Vietnam.
In these days when professional models have replaced movie stars as pin-up girls, you'd think they'd all be content to let their faces be their fortunes.

Simply no match the Cincinnati Bengals had best avoid the Cleveland Browns, the 1969 Century Division champion of the National Football League. That's what the football fans in Ohio were saying and thinking before Saturday night's preseason game that was billed as the "Buckeye Battle."
Officials at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine began to search for obstetricians willing to work temporarily at Lincoln Hospital yesteday, the sixth day of a boycott there by 27 physicians.
Arthur J. Goldberg promised yesterday that within six months after he took office as Governor every heroin addict who wanted help would get it.

Victor Gotbaum, one of the union leaders supporting Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor, said yesterday that he would urge delegates to the state A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention, opening tomorrow at Kiamesha Lake, to refrain from making an endorsement in the gubernatorial race.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 31 A jury of 10 whites and two blacks convicted Lonnie McLucas today of conspiracy to murder for his role in the Alex Rackley slaying, but they acquitted him on three other charges that carried heavier penalties.
A 92 per cent increase in net earnings in its third quarter was reported yesterday by Wells, Rich, Greene.

Pacific Southeast Airlines, the largest intrastate (California) air carrier in the country, announced yesterday it had signed a letter of intent with the Lockheed Aircraft Corporation to purchase two L-1011 tristar jetliners, with an option for an additional three planes.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 31 Lines of men in American Legion caps marched jauntily through the downtown streets here today, symbolizing the temporary victory of "the system" over political radicals, who had threatened disruption.
The American Stock Exchange just barely managed to post its seventh consecutive gain yesterday as advances outnumbered declines by a slight margin in moderate trading.
The corporate bond market will discover today how much investment appeal there is in a yield of 8.65 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.
The National Broadcasting Company began yesterday an experimental series of on-theair promotions of outstanding programs produced by competing networks.
PARIS, Tuesday, Sept. 1 Francois Mauriac, the Nobel Prize-winning author, died at his home here early today. He was 84 years old.
VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Aug. 31 Ask Wayne Hardin, the new Temple football coach, what time it is and he looks at a watch dial that reads Navy 43 Army 12 where the 12 numerals should be.

TOKYO, Aug. 31 (AP) The Tokyo Stock Exchange today said it was investigating a complaint that the country's four largest securities firms manipulated the share price of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company.
NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 31 George Stegerwald, retired vice president of the Hat Corporation of America, died yesterday in Norwalk Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived at 6 Harbor View Avenue.

SANTA MONICA, Calif., Aug. 31 (AP) Mrs. Agnes Fowler, widow of Gene Fowler, the author, died Friday at her home in Encino from injuries suffered in an automobile accident six months ago. She was 80 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug., 31 Secretary of Commerce Maurice H. Stans termed "a lot of nonsense" today the charge that the trade bill approved by the House Ways and Means Committee would lead to major retaliation by foreign countries against United States exports and even a "trade war."
New Yorkers unable to obtain prompt attention from insurance companies on claims settlements now can turn to the State Insurance Department for help under a new law that goes into effect today.
The Police Department's new "buddy system" for evening and night patrols had its first full tryout yesterday and appeared to have only minimal effects.
BRATTLEBORO, Vt., Aug. 28 Pollution and food processing are bathing man's body with a combination of metals and it is killing him, according to an expert on human physiology.

ATLANTA, Aug. 31 Most of the children of the South quietly returned to school today, many to newly integrated classrooms, in what the Nixon Administration has characterized as a last, sweeping assault in a battle joined 16 years ago.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 (AP) Greg Landry threw two long touchdown passes and scored on a 33-yard run as the Detroit Lions crushed the Philadelphia Eagles, 31-7, in a National Football League preseason game tonight.

Mr. and Mrs. Walker W. Stevenson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sharon Stevenson, to Lieut. (jg.) Charles T. Griffith Jr., U.S.N. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Griffith of Bradford, Pa.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company plans to have a private-line digital data network operating "in late 1973 or early 1974," W.M. Ellinghaus, executive vice president, said here yesterday.
Prices on most foreign stock exchanges moved downward yesterday in light-to-moderate trading.

NEWARK, Del., Aug. 31 Jim Colbert of Levittown, Pa., wanted to be a Penn State quarterback following an impressive career in high school. He went to the Nittany Lions' den three years ago, where there were enough former high school quarterbacks to stock several teams.
ACCRA, Ghana, Aug. 31 (Reuters)-Edward Akufo-Addo, a 64-year-old former Chief Justice, was elected President of Ghana today.
Three men, who, the police said, shot a pusher of "poor quality" narcotics on a Harlem street last night were captured shortly afterward in an exchange of gunfire with policemen.
The 26,000 daily riders on the Penn Central's New Haven commuter service were threatened yesterday with new delays or cutbacks in the much-delayed rehabilitation of their deteriorated railroad.

SILVER SPRING, Md., Aug. 31 Julius L. Goldstein, a prominent New York civil rights lawyer associated with the late Samuel Untermyer in anti-Nazi activities, died yesterday while visiting members of his family here. He was 66 years old and had lived in New York until his retirement two years ago, when he moved to Miami.

The month that ended yesterday was the hottest August in 15 years in New York City, the Weather Bureau said in its preliminary monthly weather summary, with an average temperature 2.6 degrees above normal, and eight days on which temperatures hit 90 degrees or over.

SMITHTOWN, L.I., Aug. 31 The chairman of this town's Republican and Democratic committees exchanged charges today of fraud and forgery in connection with nominating petitions filed by candidates for the Fourth State Assembly District seat.
Mayor Lindsay will give Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff of Connecticut a guided tour of the city's sanitation services on Sept. 21.

The Bethlehem Steel Corporation said yesterday that it had abandoned for the time being its previously announced plan to impose, in effect, a storage charge on tin-mill products that were sold but not shipped out of the Bethlehem mills after two months or more.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., Aug. 31 Carol Mann, a 6-foot3-inch athlete will stroke a golf ball for women's liberation when she meets Doug Sanders for a purse of $2,500 over the Grossinger Country Club course tomorrow.
DETROIT, Aug. 31 The General Motors Corporation announced today the establishment of a "public policy committee" to advise the giant concern on matters that affect the general public.
J.P. Stevens Co., Inc., reported over the weekend severe decliens in net income for the quarter and nine months ended Aug. 1 as consolidated net sales fell below year-earlier levels.

WARSAW, Aug. 31 (Reuters) The new Chinese ambassador to Poland, Yao Kuang, who seems likely to represent Peking at future talks with the United States, presented his credentials today today to President Marian Spychalski.
The re-inspection of all school buses and installation of seat belts before classes start next week was advocated yesterday by Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz.

To begin the distribution of food stamps to the poor and near-poor, as New York City did yesterday, is to enter the Model A stage of assuring national nutritional adequacy. It is an improvement over the Model T, but there is still a long way to go to get a really effective program on the road.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Attorney General John N. Mitchell has ruled that television newsmen cannot be barred from coridors surounding deportation hearings, although they cannot televise the hearings.

ATLANTA, Aug. 31 (UPI) A 150-gallon tank loaded with chlorine split tonight when the truck bearing it down Interstate Highway 20 overturned about 15 miles southeast of Atlanta, spreading fumes that hospitalized at least seven persons.

TUXEDO, N.Y., Aug. 31 Miss Diane Joy Gillman and James Charney were married here this evening in the Rose Garden of the Sterling Forest Gardens. The ceremony was performed before 300 guests by Rabbi Robert Port of Middletown. He was assisted by Rabbi Moshe Goldblum.

Kenneth A. Cox, whose service as a member of the Federal Communications Commission expires today, has declined an offer to become president of the National Citizens Committee for Broadcasting. He will become senior vice president of Microwave Communications, Inc., and join the Washington law firm of Haley, Bader Potts.
A policeman was shot in the arm by an unknown assailant last night while investigating a report that a man with a shotgun had been seen near a Brooklyn yacht club.

The General Electric Company, a pioneer in the radio-television industry, said yesterday it was considering going out of the black-and-white picture tube business because of the impact of imported tubes, mostly from Japan.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The president of the American Sociological Association, Dr. Reinhard Bendix of the University of California, criticized politicians and protesters alike today for turning the nation's universities into "convenient battlegrounds."
Remember the choatic second quarter on Wall Street, when the market averages were falling off the charts and visions of financial Armageddon were carving new lines in financiers' faces?
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 A North Vietnamese film of American prisoners of war attending a Christmas church service was shown here today.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Supreme Court announced today that it would make a broad test of school desegregatlon measures the first order of business when the new Court term begins.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., Aug. 31 Militant Tuscarora and Mohawk Indians demanding the eviction of whites living in trailer parks on the Tuscarora Reservation won a victory in Niagara County Court here today.

NHATRANG, South Vietnam Aug. 31 (AP) A four-day armed siege of a South Vietnamese military hospital by a Vietnam Army doctor accused of killing a hospital administrator ended today when four armored vehicles blasted their way into the hospital compound.

DETROIT, Aug. 31 Volkswagen will attempt to defend its car market in the United States by bringing in two versions of its popular Beetle car this fall, a lower priced, stripped version and a higher powered model called the "Super Bug."
CAIRO, Aug. 31 The fragile hopes held by Cairo that the 90-day cease-fire on the Suez Canal front might lead to a settlement with Israel appear to be fraying rapidly.

In recent decades Vice Presidential travel abroad has often been the diplomatic equivalent of "showing the flag." It has served to reassert American interest in a threatened area or to reassure client states at a nervous moment. But sometimes its purposes have been much more political than diplomatic.

ELIGIBLES: All of the nearly 1.1 million welfare recipients who have cooking facilities are automatically eligible. Persons not receiving welfare aid may apply through special food stamp certification offices if family size and net income meet certain limits for example, not more than $370 monthly income for a family of four.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 Benson Storfer, former president of Parfums Corday, Inc. and Storfer Imports, Inc., importers of perfume, died yesterday in New England Baptist Hospital here. He was 81 years old and lived at 9 Rock Hill Lane in Scarsdale, N.Y., and in Sarasota, Fla.

Negotiations continued yesterday between the city and the physicians who had walked off their posts in Lincoln Hospital as pleas were made to them to resume their duties on promises that their security would not be threatened and that medical services in general would improve.
The other day, Frank Robles locked the door of the furniture store he manages and hurried to the subway. He was on his way to the theater to rehearse for three strenuous hours.

Locally grown zucchini, or courgettes as they are called in France and Britain, are one of the most versatile and delectable of summer vegetables. Here are three casserole dishes based on zucchini that can be put together hours ahead and baked at the last minute.

Reaction ranging from hopeful eagerness to skepticism and even despair was voiced in Harlem yesterday in response to Arthur J. Goldberg's pledge that if elected he would, within six months after taking office, provide treatment for every drub addict seeking it.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 31 Senator Charles E. Goodell announced at a hearing here today on unemployment on Long Island that preliminary steps were being taken to establish a computerized "job bank" for Nassau and Suffolk Counties, similar to ones in operation in Syracuse and Buffalo.
When the New York Jets resume their exhibition schedule against the Saints in New Orleans on Saturday night, Joe Namath will be their starting quarterback.

Sears, Roebuck Co., the country's largest merchadising company, reported profit gains yesterday for the second fiscal quarter and first half, in sharp contrast to an earnings downtrend reported last week by four other major retail chains.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 Anti-Government Buddhists appeared today to have won 10 of the 30 Senate seats contested in yesterday's election.

BRIDGETON, N.J., Aug. 31 Local courts in many southern New Jersey farming communities have been directed to arraign every jailed migrant farm worker before a judge or a magistrate within 24 hours of arrest, even if it means conducting extraordinary court sessions.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Aug. 31 (Reuters) War activity in South Vietnam fell off today after a surge yesterday coinciding with the voting for 30 senators.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 31 (UPI) Men believed to be members of the Tupamaro guerrilla movement opened fire from a speeding car on an army training school in downtown Montevideo today and security guards returned the fire. No one was reported wounded.
SOUTHBRIDGE, Mass., Aug 31 Dr. Everett D. Hawkins, Professor of Economics at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, died in Southbridge Hospital today after a brief illness. He was 64 years old.
Robert M. Fomon, 45 years old, president of E.F. Hutton Co., Inc., was named chief executive officer yesterday of the big brokerage house.

Citing a critical national shortage of fuels and "rapidly escalating" prices, the American Public Power Association urged President Nixon yesterday to impose rationing and price controls on fuel oil and coal.
Newsprint consumption in the nation this July was 721,267 tons, down 1.1 per cent from 729,149 tons in July, 1969, the American Newspaper Publishers Association re- ported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Nixon Administration reported today that the United States was shipping weapons to Israel during the current cease-fire so that "the arms balance does not tip against Israel."
OTTAWA, Aug. 31 (Canadian Press) The Bank of Canada announced tonight a reduction in its bank rate to 6 per cent from 7 per cent, effective tomorrow.

UPPER SALFORD TOWNSHIP, Pa., Aug. 31 An unusual mixture of dances a Nigerian harvest dance, a Morns dance, jigs, reels and a stool dance from Ghana provided the high points of the final day of the Philadelphia Folk Festival, which drew 27,000 people to Old Pool Farm here over the weekend.
Charles S. Mill, who headed the selection committee that selected him president of American Business Press, starts his new job today.

From the ankles up Susan Ross, a 23-year-old assistant commodities trader, looked no different than the other afternoon shoppers strolling on Lexington Avenue near 59th Street the other day. Below the ankles, however, there was a big difference. She was barefoot.

AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 31 The main newspaper of the Palestine commandos voiced defiance of King Hussein's Government today after one of the noisiest nights of skirmishing between commandos and Government troops that this city has heard.
Can a monster created in New York find true happiness in Minneapolis?
PARIS, Aug. 31 Bernard Cornfeld fought his way back today to a place in the management of Investors Overseas Services and the mutual-fund empire he had built.

THE HAGUE, Aug. 31 (AP) A band of Indonesian rebels took over Indonesia's Embassy today after killing a Dutch policeman and threatening a group of hostages, but they surrendered hours later and were taken to jail.

MANHASSET, L. I., Aug. 31 John C. Crawley, a former partner in the New York law firm of Thacher, Proffitt, Prizer, Crawley Wood, died at North Shore Hospital today. He was 78 years old and lived in Port Washington.
Northwest Airlines, Inc., which is seeking to acquire Northeast Airlines, Inc., yesterday reported increased earnings and revenues for the second quarter and first half of this year.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Army has successfully staged an interception of one of its own intercontinental ballistic missiles. The interception, which took place above the atmosphere, tested key elements of the controversia Safeguard antiballistic missile system.

Paul Horgan, the Pulitzer Prize man of letters whose September novel, "Whitewater" has already made him a man of $250,000, is marking the start of his 64th year with a display of literary versatility.
ROME, Aug. 31 (AP) A wealthy Roman marquis shot and killed his wife, her young lover and himself, the police said today.

WALTHAM, Mass. Aug. 31 President John F. Kennedy's conduct at his 1961 summit meeting with Nikitas Khrushchev has been depicted by George F. Kennan as that of a "tongue-tied young man not forceful, with no ideas of his own."

The chairman of the City Council's Committee on Charter and Governmental Operations chided Controller Abraham D. Beame and Council President Sanford D. Garelik yesterday for their opposition to a bill that would exclude the Board of Estimate from its budget-making role.

James MacGregor Burns, a leading scholar of the Administration of Franklin D. Roosevel disagreed yesterday with Charles A. Lindbergh's contentions that the United States had lost World War II and had been led into the war by the Administration, pro-British elements and the Jews.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 Heavily armed Philadelphia police contingents swooped down on three Black Panther party centers at dawn today.
Ta Wee made the return to Belmont Park a most satisfactory one for the 29,334 cus tomers who saw her perform in the $28,300 Fall Highweight Handicap yesterday.

"A bright or witty thought tersely expressed". or "a short poem treating concisely and pointedly of a single thought or event." Those descriptions have been borrowed from the wellknown dance critic, Noah Webster. While they are definitions of the word "epigram" they could apply to the individual sections in "Agon."

LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 Angry leaders of the MexicanAmerican community called for a Federal investigation today into the death Saturday of Ruben Salazar, a columnist for The Los Angeles Times and news director for a Spanishlanguage television station.
Gaunt and shaky after 12 years in jail in China, the Most Rev. James E. Walsh returned to the United States last night and said that his heart "is still in China."
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 A young marine from West Babylon, L.I., who declared in Stockholm last week that he was a defector, was returned to New York today, the Defense Department announced.

NEWPORT, England, Aug. 31 In a chilly dawn drizzle, the Isle of Wight festival ended somberly today with Richie Havens chanting "Hare Krishna" and mobs of motorcyclists and other angry youths ripping down iron fences and smashing lights.
Steel production rose 0.2 per cent, last week from the weekearlier output, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday in Washington.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Bureau of Mines acknowledged today that it had been requiring its safety inspectors to obtain telephoned authority from Washington before exercising a key enforcement provision of the new Federal coal mine safety law, which has come under attack by the mining industry.

Still having difficulty raising campaign funds in his adopted home town, Arthur J. Goldberg is flying to Chicago, his former home town, today to seek outof-state contributions to his campaign for Governor.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) Declining prices for hogs, cattle, potatoes and eggs in the month ended Aug. 15 sent national average farm prices down 3 per cent, the Agriculture Department reported today.
GOLOVIN, Alaska Nothing much happens in Golovin. But then, nothing much ever did.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Aug. 31 This friendly, though arid area of corn, wheat, soybeans, strip coal mines and harness horses was hit briefly but hard by thunder, lightning and a frightening rain storm early this morning.

The Black Dance Union and the Murray Louis Dance Company appeared at the New York Dance Festival for the first time Sunday evening in Central Park's Delacorte Theater. The rain held off long enough for the Black Dance Union to close the program with. "Where To Go?" a jazz dance by Morton Winston. Mr. Winston also choreographed "The Bell Dance," the company's opener.

NEW ORLEANS, Aug. 31 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit turned down today a request to stop the extradition of Charles D. (Tex) Watson of the hippie "family" of Charles M. Manson, accused of killing Sharon Tate, the actress, and six others.
LONDON, Aug. 31 (AP) The International Coffee Organization agreed early today to a 1970-71 export quota, ending a two-day deadlock between representatives from consumer and producer nations.

TRENTON, Aug. 31 Mayor Arthur J. Holland imposed a nighttime curfew here this evening in the wake of a brief courtroom clash this morning between the police and blacks who were identified with the Black Panther party.
The distribution of 3,000 new wire-mesh litter baskets throughout the city's five boroughs will begin tomorrow morning, the Sanitation Department announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) A special House investigation was ordered today into alleged deceptive practices by some magazine subscription salesmen.
The stock market finished yesterday with token declines in key indicators, resting a bit after its spirited rally since mid-August. Volume moved lower.

The Data Processing Financial and General Corporation announced yesterday that it and the International Business Machines Corporation had reached an out-of-court settlement of the antitrust suit filed by it against I.B.M.

GENEVA, Aug. 31 Marcel Naville, president of the International Committee of the Red Cross, criticized both North and South Vietnam today for their attitude toward Red Cross in spection of their prison camps.
Despite the recession, retailers and importers appear to be betting that sales of fancy goods, most of which sell for higher prices than staples, will continue to rise.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., Aug. 31 Jaime Fillol and Patricio Cornejo of Chile upset Rod Laver of Australia and Andres Gimeno of Spain, 3-6, 7-6, 7-6, in the men's doubles final of the Marlboro open tennis championship today at the Orange Lawn Tennis Club.
BONN, Aug. 31 The longtime annoyance of senior officers of the United States Army with one of its major gadflies, The Overseas Weekly, has led to the forced resignation of its editor, Curtis Daniell.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Securities and Exchange Commission authorized today an indefinite continuation of the special brokerage commission surcharge first imposed in April of this year.
LONDON, Aug. 31 National labor officials and industrial leaders stepped up efforts today to settle a wildcat strike of 5,000 workers at a key automobile parts plant.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 A State Department decision to yield to Senator Barry Goldwater and cancel the appointment of a press officer was reported today to have been made with the knowledge and apparently the approval of the White House.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Aug. 31 President Nixon sought to dissociate himself today from a suggestion put forth by one of his senior officials that the United States is prepared to join the Soyiet Union in a peace-keeping force in the Middle East if the crisis there is settled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Franc Howard belted a home run with a man on in the fifth inning tonight to tie Harmon Killebrew for the American League lead with 38 as the Washington Senators defeated the Cleveland Indians, 5-4.

New York City entered the national food stamp program yesterday. Long lines of relief recipients cashed their welfare checks and then bought stamps, but there was apparently little interest thus far by other poor people who could enroll.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Aug. 31 The New Orleans Buccaneers, who changed their name to the Louisiana Bucs during the offseason, will be sold to P.L. Blake, a wealthy real estate dealer from Greenwood, Miss.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Aug. 31 (AP) Byers A. Burlingame, former president of the Studebaker Corporation, died yesterday while vacationing at the family cottage at Rondeau Park, Ontario. He was 70 years old.
John W. O'Connor has been named vice president and manager, Metropolitan New York City Department of the Continental Insurance Companies.
The Rapid-American Corporation, one of the largest conglomerates, is negotiating to acquire the Dunes Hotel, one of Las Vegas's oldest and largest hotel casinos, it was reported here yesterday.
A team of four Los Angeles players headed by Lew Mathe became candidates to represent North America in the 1971 world championship by winning a qualifying match in Phoenix, Ariz., yesterday.
LAKESIDE,, Conn. Aug. 31 Columbia's football coach, Frank Navarro, and his staff greeted 68 candidates, including 20 letter men, at the opening of Columbia's pre-season training camp today.
A ruling yesterday will permit the prosecution to introduce alleged confessions in the trial of 13 Black Panthers charged here with conspiracy, arson and attempted murder.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 31 The New York Mets, looking for help in the home stretch of a troublesome summer, bought Ron Herbel from the San Diego Padres tonight and then helped themselves to an 11-5 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals that moved them within 1 games of the firstplace Pittsburgh Pirates.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 31 Herman Knaust, a founder of Knaust Brothers, Inc., and the K-B Products Corporation, at one time one of the world's largest growers and canners of mushrooms, died in a hospital here yesterday after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in nearby Climax and in Safety Harbor, Fla.

NEW HAVEN, Aug. 31 Had it not been for special rules barring cameras from the courthouse at the Black Panther trials here, a lucky photographer might have snapped Superior Court Judge Harold M. Mulvey being introduced recently to two Panther leaders. Huey P. Newton

A Federal judge, describing Matteawan State Hospital for the criminally insane in Beacon, N.Y., as "a place more likely to drive men mad than to cure the 'insane,'" has ordered the transfer of an 86-year-old man who has been there since 1951.
The women's liberation movement, which has put Pat Palinkas into football, jockeys in thoroughbred racing and grooms in harness racing, came to boxing yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Aug. 31 Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring conferred today with Dr. Mohammed H. el-Zayyat of the United Arab Republic though other leaders in the peace talks are absent.

Whatever the disagreement on some aspects of school busing, there can be no disagreement at all on one aspect: The bus itself must be mechanically perfect. So it comes as another safety shock to learn that dangerous buses will be carrying millions of children to school this year.
The 50-foot-long red banner hanging from the 86th floor of the Empire State Building yesterday afternoon, the one that said "Jack" in large letters, was just a sort of oversized birthday card.

Miss Joan Brewster Garver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Chauncey B. Garver of Oyster Bay, L. I., was married in Juarez, Mexico, last Thursday to John Daniel Downey, a chemical engineer she met on vacation in Aruba. He was with the Parsons Construction Company there. The couple are honeymooning in Bermuda.

MINEOLA, L.I., Aug. 31 A State Supreme Court justice here today swept aside the objections of the village of Garden City to the establishment of a day-care center for welfare children in a UnitarianUniversalist church.
UNION, N.J., Aug. 31 Mrs. Rose Negbaur Epstein, widow of Dr. Harry B. Epstein, a physician, died in a nursing home here yesterday. She had lived until recently in East Orange.

MIAMI, Aug. 31 (AP) A man who the police say blamed Eastern Airlines for the death of his champion Irish wolfhound walked up to an Eastern jet today and chopped 18 holes in its underbelly with an ax, airport officers said.

Gregor Piatigorsky, the cellist, and four conductors Aldo Ceccato, Dean Dixon, Milton Katims and Robert Shaw have been added to the roster of artists who will appear with the New York Philharmonic this season.

MOSCOW, Aug. 31 After two years of caution mixed with hostility, Soviet leaders have altered their foreign-policy emphasis and are again stressing the advantages of peaceful coexistence with the capitalist world.

LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Aug. 31.-The engagement of Miss Dinah Hawkins Day to John Weatherbee Tarbell Jr. has been announced by Miss Day's mother, Mrs. Baldus Day of Locust Valley. Mr. Tarbell is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Tarbell of Brockton, Mass. Miss Day is the daughter also of John Fisher Day of Syosset. An October wedding is planned.
NEWARK, Aug 31 Police Director John L Redden ordered an 'intensive investigation' today into obscene letters and 'hate mail' that has been sent to the homes of policemen of Italian descent.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 The Senate lumbered through five hours of debate today on its "amendment to end the war," preparing to vote on it tomorrow and then go home for a week.
RICHMORID, Aug. 31 Carl Ellington hooked his thumbs into the rear pockets of his faded bluejeans and glanced sideways at the students entering John F. Kennedy High School this morning.

Taxi fleet owners said yesterday that they had been assured by city officials that the activities of the police taxi surveillance unit would be increased in an effort to cut crimes against taxi drivers.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (UPI) The impact of military spending on the nation's economy declined to the lowest point since 1966 in the second quarter of this year, the Commerce Department reported today.
HONOLULU, Aug. 31 Vice President Agnew cut short his planned rest stop here today to fly to the Western White House in San Clemente, Calif.
BROOKVILLE, L. I., Aug. 31 Coach Alex Webster and his staff have learned a lot from the films of the New York Giants' 21-6 loss to Pittsburgh last Friday night.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 Manson's murder trial was interrupted again today when one of his three young women codefendants continued to complain of illness.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 31 (UPI) Such big-name entertainers as Bob Hope, Art Linkletter and George Jessel are "unacceptable" to most of the United States troops now overseas, according to a Government official who books the acts.
LOS ANGELES, Aug. 31 (AP) -At the Western White House the Presidential press secretary, Ronald L. Ziegler, said Mr. Nixon regarded Mr. Salazar's death as "a very tragic thing."

The Connecticut General Life Insurance Company reported yesterday that its affiliate, the Aetna Insurance Company, expects to pay about $7-million in direct claims and an additional $2.5-million in indirect claims as a result of losses from Hurricane Celia.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 31 (AP) Arthur Ashe, hobbled by an old heel injury, fought back from match point in the fourth set today and beat Christian Kuhnke, 6-8, 10-12, 9-7, 13-11, 6-4, to complete a 5-0 sweep of West Germany in the Davis Cup tennis challenge round today.

SOUTHAMPTON, L. I. The delicatessen with the herring and the pickle barrels has disappeared, Pulaski Hall has become almost a village meeting place, the family unit isn't as tightly knit as it once was, and few of the younger generation speak their ancestral tongue. But the Polish community here has not assimilated with the group they still call "Yankees;" it has merely blended.
NEWPORT, R. I., Aug. 31 Boat horns that last night had saluted Intrepid's selection as the America's Cup defender sounded an alarm for the 12- Meter yacht today.
One hundred and three gravestones were found overturned yesterday in Mount Hebron Cemetery on the south side of the Long Island Expressway at Rodman Street in Flushing, Queens.

The engagement of Miss Martha Kendall Stearns to Robert Colvin Patrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Baxter S. Patrick of Middletown, Conn., has been announced here by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Stearns Jr. of Haddam, Conn., and Point O'Woods, Fire Island, N.Y.
After advancing sharply early in the session, soybeans and corn futures dipped markedly on profit taking yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 31 Bobby Riggs of Plandome, L. I., won, 2-6, 6-3, 6-4, from Robert Thompson of Youngstown, Ohio, today, in starting the defense of his United States senior grass court tennis championship at Germantown Cricket club.
Robert Douglas Milne, a lawyer who specialized in international contract law, died here Saturday. He was 40 years old and lived here and in Old Greenwich, Conn.

JERUSALEM, Aug. 31 Israel told the United Nations Truce Supervisory Organization today that her reconnaissance had detected evidence of further deployment of missiles and construction of new launching sites along the entire length of the Egyptian-held bank of the Suez Canal.

New York City hospitals performed more than 11,200 abortions between July 1, when the state's liberalized abortion law went into effect, and Aug. 22, the Health and Hospitals Corporation said yesterday.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Aug. 31 Dr. Francis J. Cronin, a former member of the Elizabeth City Council, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, visiting a son in Stamford, Conn. He was 62 years old and lived at 737 Westminster Avenue.
PARIS, Aug. 31 Premier Jacques Chaban-Delmas opened his campaign today to win a Parliament seat in Bordeaux, of which he is mayor, against Jean-Jacques Servan-Schreiber and eight other opponents.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 31 (UPI) The Milwaukee Bucks were told today they have not picked up Fred Hetzel on waiver after all. SOUTHPORT, Conn., Aug. 31 The Belle Haven Club of Greenwich defeated the Larchmont (N.Y.) Yacht Club, the defending champion, 2 races to 1, off the Pequot Y.C. today in the concluding sailoff for the 18th Long Island Sound Junior Yacht Racing association team championship. The victors won the Malcolm McIntyre trophy.

BOSTON, Aug. 31 (AP) Ray Culp drove in the tie-breaking run with a sixth-inning single and posted his 14th victory tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated the Detroit Tigers, 4-2.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 A young, black Detroit educator was chosen tonight Superintendent of Schools by the District of Columbia Board of Education. He would became the first Negro school superintendent of a major city.

TURIN, Italy, Aug. 31 (AP) The United States won its Second straight game in the final round of the basketball tournament at the World University Games today and strengthened its chances for a gold medal.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 31 (AP) The National Labor Relations Board ruled today that striking unions of one Hearst property cannot legally picket Hearst properties in other cities to apply economic pressure.
BUFFALO, Aug. 31 (AP) A City Court judge dismissed a criminal anarchy charge against the vender of a Black Panther newspaper today on the ground of insufficient evidence.

Mrs. John A. Morris's Proudest Roman winner of the $130,950 Hopeful at Saratoga last Saturday and a top contender for 2-year-old honors, fractured a sesamoid bone in his left foreleg during a gallop yesterday morning at Belmont Park.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Sept. 1 Dr. Ann Tukey, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Bradford Tukey of Woodland and East Lansing, was married here this afternoon to Dr. Michael Jay Harrison, professor of physics at Michigan State University. WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The Administration today dropped its appeal of a Federal Court ruling last year that struck down a law barring Federal employment of a person who asserted the right to strike against the Government.

Erick Van Dillen gave up an athletic grant-in-aid at the University of Southern California last spring for a fling at the fame and fortune of the professional tennis tour.

A winning performance by Fritz Peterson, perfect relief by Lindy McDaniel, home runs by Bobby Murcer and Roy White, four crisp double plays and the New York Yankees put victory No. 75 into their record at Yankee Stadium last night, 4-2, over the Baltimore Orioles.

The White House isn't saying why, and members of the staff are reluctant even to discuss it, but starting this week some of those beautiful bouquets in the Executive Mansion will be artificial.
Several changes in the editorial management of Sports Illustrated were announced yesterday by Hedley Donovan, editor in chief of Time, Inc., which publishes the weekly magazine.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Sept. 1 William, Gaston, who ran unsuccessfully for Congress on the Democratic ticket from the Fourth District in November, 948, died Sunday. He was 74 years old and lived at 463 Valley Road.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Fourteen Senators, including the Democratic and Republican leaders, urged President Nixon today to propose a comprehensive standstill cease-fire for South Vietnam at the stalemated peace talks in Paris

MOSCOW, Sept. 1 (AP) A Soviet survey ship, the Shokalsky, has rescued a stormtossed American schooner that had been adrift in the Indian Ocean for six days, Tass, the official press agency, reported today.
NEW DELHI, Sept. 1 Prime Minister Indira Gandhi staked her Government's future today on legislation to end allowances and other privileges for India's former rulers.

LONDON, Sept. 1 The Labor party's National Executive Committee, in a report today on the defeat in the general election in June, avoided pinning the blame on Harold Wilson, the former Prime Minister, and criticized public-opinion polls.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 1 King Hussein of Jordan escaped an attempt on his life today, the Amman radio reported. The Government station said that the assailants, whom it did not identify, opened fire on the 34year-old monarch's motorcade as he was driving to the Amman airport to meet his daughter Alia. The Princess was returning on a flight from Cairo.

Miss Carole Jill Bayer, daughter of Mrs. Elias Bayer of New York and the late Mr. Bayer, and Andrew L. Sager, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Sager of New York and Deal, N.J., were married here yesterday afternoon in the Regency Hotel by Rabbi Judah Nadich.

GROSSINGER, N.Y., Sept. 1 Can a power-hitting woman golfer beat one of the top money-winning men professionals? That was the question to be answered today when 6foot-3-inch Carol Mann of the Ladies Professional Golf Association played an 18-hole match against Doug Sanders at the Grossinger's Golf Club course.
Almost every investor knows by now that the biggest clout in the stock market is wielded by institutions the mutual funds, bank trusts, pension funds and insurance companies with billions to invest.
The Federal food stamp program drew a larger turnout here yesterday than it did on Monday, the day the national program went into effect in the city, according to officials.
Michael I. Begun, a lawyer, died yesterday at University Hospital of New York University Medical Center. He was 66 years old and lived at 400 East 56th Street.

A rescue team of subway passengers, hastily organized by three transit patrolmen, tipped back a 54-ton subway car last night to free an 11year-old boy whose foot was wedged between the car and the platform at a downtown Brooklyn station.
LONDON, Sept. 1 (Reuters) Lloyds Bank said today that its wholly owned subsidiary, Lloyds Bank Europe, Ltd., would merge with the Bank of London and South America.

The world team championship title was won this year by the United States for the first time since 1954, and the full account of the victory of the Dallas Aces in Stockholm is now available from the American Contract Bridge League, 125 Greenwich Avenue, Greenwich, Conn. 06830.

Reubio Thomas, a group engineering manager at Loral Electronic Systems, a division of the Loral Corporation in the Bronx, died after a long illness Sunday at Harkness Pavilion of the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 49 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 (AP) Tens of thousands of pupils and their teachers got an extended summer vacation today as teacher disputes and money problems delayed school openings in some districts in the St. Louis metropolitan area.
TOKYO, Sept. 1 "Mankind stands in the presence of history."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 High Administration officials said today that the United States was now "satisfied" on the basis of photographic and electronic evidence that the United Arab Republic had violated the standstill cease-fire in the Suez Canal region by moving antiaircraft missile batteries into the truce zone.
ROME, Sept. 1 (AP) The Vatican increased prices for gasoline, liquor, meat and other commodities today with no advance notice.
Mayor Lindsay invited Edward K. Hamilton yesterday to "step up for your execution" and then swore him in as the city's Budget Director.

DU QUOIN, Ill., Sept. 1 The 45th edition of the $143,630 Hambletonian, the trotting classic for 3-year-olds, will be staged tomorrow (weather permitting) over the one-mile oval at the Du Quoin State Fairgrounds.

CINCINNATI, Sept. 1-Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Goodwin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Linda Ruth Goodwin, to Michael Alan Hordell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond L. Hordell of New Rochelle, N.Y.
SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 1 The scene aboard the battleship Missouri 25 years ago seemed designed to emphasize the humiliation of a beaten Japan.

Our daughter has not asked a single question; in fact when I solicitously handed her Mary Breasted's "Oh! Sex Education!" she tried to eat it...
VILLANOVA, Pa., Sept. 1 When taking over a new job there are always dozens of problems, but Lou Ferry has one less as the new head coach at Villanova. He doesn't have to adjust to the environment.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 1 The public schools of this clean bustling city opened yesterday under a new desegregation plan that is a model of what the Nixon Administration supports.

The president of the 125th Street Peddlers Association accused the city yesterday of imposing economic death on Harlem venders if it insisted on enforcing a new regulation increasing fines for-unlicensed sidewalk venders up to $100. The new rule also carries with it a possible 10day jail sentence.

A $60-million loan that the city had agreed to provide as the long-term financing for the 50-story Burlington Building on the Avenue of the Americas between 54th and 55th Streets has been ordered held up indefinitely.
TOKYO, Sept. 1 (UPI) North Korea gave workers a pay raise today.
A 68-year-old man who liked to take late-evening strolls died early this morning after being mugged in the hallway of his Grand Concourse apartment building in the Bronx.
Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary said yesterday that recent armed assaults on policemen here were apparently unconnected incidents without an over-all plot.

GENEVA, Sept. 1 The board of directors of Investors Overseas Services will meet here Thursday to restore the membership of Bernard Cornfeld, the deposed head of I.O.S., and place him on its sevenmember executive committee.

The new Chancellor of the New York City school system spent the first few minutes of his initial day on the job yesterday trying vainly to open the office door that carried his name is new Bold lettering.
OSAKA, Japan, Aug. 30 The New York Philharmonic received a tumultuous welcome from a capacity audience at Osaka Festival Hall this weekend as it opened an 18-day tour of Japan.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 1 Union supporters of Governor Rockefeller face a strong challenge from backers of Arthur J. Goldberg at the State A.F.L.-C.I.O. convention opening at the Concord Hotel here tomorrow.

The H.J. Heinz Company reported yesterday that its net income and sales in the first quarter ended July 29 rose to record levels despite a costly 45-day strike at the company's Canadian production facilities that ended early in July.
The London stock market closed slightly lower yesterday after a steady opening. Trading was extremely light following the extended bank-holiday weekend.

TEL AVIV, Sept. 1 A spokesman here said today that Israeli ground forces demolished buildings in a retaliatory raid across the Lebanese border during the night. The spokesman said that one Israeli soldier had been killed and two injured.

It is rare that an author dashes from a book-signing to the stage of the New York State Theater to dance the doomed herioine of "Swan Lake." Last night, McGraw-Hill's loss was the New York City Ballet's gain as Violete Verdy moved from the translation land of "Giselle" to the resplendent world of the Swan Quen. Miss Verdy drew.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 1 When a football team that has little depth begins to suffer injuries, chances for an outstanding season become buried under bandages and trainers' reports. That's what happened to Rutgers last year when the Scarlet Knights opened the centennial season with one of the best teams in its history.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 1 Fourteen persons seized in police raids on Black Panther party headquarters were denied release today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) The space agency said today that it had added $47.6-million to its contract with a Denver concern for two Viking spacecraft to land on Mars because the unmanned landings were postponed from 1973 to 1975.
MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Sept. 1 James Sweeney, a cocoa broker, died today in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, after a short illness. He was 67 years old and lived here at 82 Peconic drive.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Manufacturers' inventories rose substantially in July after two months of near-stability, the Commerce Department reported today.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 1 Mrs. Agnes Ernst Meyer writer and leader in social service and education, any widow of Eugene Meyer, board chairman of The Washington Post, died this morning at he home here. She was 83 years old and also maintained a residence in Washington.
GENEVA, Sept. 1 The World Health Organization said today that cholera had spread into Guinea, killing 60 persons in the first outbreak of the disease ever reported in Africa south of the Sahara.
BLUE HILL, Me., Sept. 1 Mrs. Renee D. Mallett, widow of Dr. George H. Mallett, died in the Blue Hill Hospital today after a short illness. She was 92 years old.

Two retrospective film programs will be presented in conjunction with forthcoming exhibitions at the New York Cultural Center, 2 Columbus Circle., Starting today, a series of features called "Woman" will illustrate the theme of the Second World Exhibition of Photography on the fourth and fifth floors.

Francois Mauriac was that rare combination, a master storyteller and a master moralist. He wrote about sinners men and women palpably of the flesh and about sin. Thinking of life in such terms may be oldfashioned these days, and Mauriac may therefore put off some readers. But that would be a, pity, for he utilized evil to illuminate virtue; and in so doing he universalized and humanized his profound moral and religious concerns.

DALLAS, Sept. 1 (AP) The Dallas Cowboys took a step to bolster their defensive secondary today by trading a center, Malcolm Walker, and a defensive end, Clarence Williams, to the Green Bay Packers for Herb Adderley, cornerback.

BLYTHEVILLE, Ark., Sept. 1 (AP) This city of about 26,000 people in northeastern Arkan sas was placed under curfew tonight by Mayor Tom A. Little after several incidents las night that resulted in the arres of 29 persons.
VINALHAVEN, Me.-Leaving the everyday pressures behind by escaping to your own island is the stuff dreams are made of, but it's not something that happens too often in real life.
The stock market, keeping a wary eye on automobile-contract negotiations in Detroit, beat an orderly retreat yesterday. Both glamour issues and blue chips gave up ground.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 1 (AP) Nigeria has become reconciled with the four African countries that gave diplomatic rcognition to Biafra.
DALLAS, Sept. 1 (AP) Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc., announced today that it was suspending payment of dividends on its preferred stock to preserve working capital.
The world's first major chess tournament played by computers proved yesterday that masters have little to fear from machines and that not even a million-dollar electronic marvel is blunder proof.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (AP) The Government sued Combustion Engineering, Inc. today seeking divestiture of two subsidiaries whose purchases in 1966 and 1968 allegedly have stifled competition in sales of industrial boilers and pulp-making equipment.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Aug. 31 As a festival center, Edinburgh has learned over the years how to make the least of its disadvantages. It has no opera house and the acoustics of its main concert hall are blurred. It lacks theaters and hotels.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 An urban expert noted for his integrationist views defended today white middle class America's economic reasons for resisting housing integration.
Dr. Joseph J. Smith, whose ouster from Lincoln Hospital was demanded by South Bronx militants, returned to work yesterday after receiving assurances that he would be protected from personal harm.
The recent upswing on the American Stock Exchange ended yesterday as profit taking weakened most issues in light trading.

John H. Baker, vice president in charge of sales and a director of the Todd Shipyards Corporation, died yesterday at his summer home in Southampton, L.I. He was 60 years old and lived at 135 East 83d Street.
