MADIS0N, Wis., Aug. 29 Early on the morning of Aug. 24, David Schuster, a bearded, 28-year-old graduate student in nuclear physics at the University of Wisconsin, was performing the last experiment he needed for his Ph.D. degree, which he hoped to win by this December after three years of painstaking research.

Dr. William J. Ronan, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that public hearings would be held before final plans were approved for the location of stations on the new Second Avenue subway.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Senate majority leader, Mike Mansfield, asked the Senate Post Office Committee today to approve his bill that would require that warning labels, similar to those now on cigarette packages, be placed on mail that might be obscene or offensive.

On the eve of his replacement by Dr. William J. McGill as president of Columbia University, Dr. Andrew W. Cordier issued a farewell message of gratitude this week to the university's 30,000 faculty members, students, administrators and employes.

GENEVA, Sept, 1 The United States and the Soviet Union urged the disarmament conference here today to give prompt approval to their much revised draft treaty to prohibit the installation of nuclear weapons on the seabed outside 12-mile coastal limits.

The American Smelting and Refining Company reduced its price for lead yesterday for the third time in less than two months, but other major producers immediately announced that they would not follow suit.

ELKHART LAKE, Wis., Sept. 1 It was just as well that Sunday's Road America Can-Am here, sixth of the 1970 series of 10 events, ended in a protest over the 13lap penalty against Denis Hulme for restarting his stalled engine with a pushstart.
Nadel Co., a small brokerage firm with memberships on the New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange, said yesterday that it had ceased operations, preparatory to the sale of its business.
The Dravo Corporation of Pittsburgh announced yesterday that it had acquired the Marks Tractor and Equipment Company of Cleveland and several affiliated companies.

"The Emerald Slippers," which opened last night at the Gramercy Arts Theater, is billed as "a fantasy for children of all ages." Since it runs evenings at 7 in addition to weekend matinees, obviously the producer, Henry Testa, is interested in luring some adults into the house.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Social Security Administration moved today to establish stringent flammability standards for carpeting in nursing homes that are certified as extended-care facilities under the Medicare program.

ATHENS, Sept. 1 The Greek Government has abolished its list of banned books and has told bookstores they are free to sell all volumes "so long as they do not contain propaganda against the established constitutional order."

DETROIT, Sept. 1 The automobile industry today offered the United Auto Workers a three-year, contract proposal that would increase wages and fringe benefits about 6 per cent a year.
TURIN, Italy, Sept. 1 (UPI) The United States beat Italy, 95-56, tonight to join the Soviet Union in the basketball final of the sixth World University games.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 1 J. Philip Murphy, who directed the construction of many major bridges in the West died on Sunday while on a business trip in Columbia, S.C. He was 62 years old.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 1 The New York Mets edged back into second place tonight when they outlasted the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-3, in 12 innings and sent Bob Gibson to his first defeat in five weeks.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 1 Two white policemen were indicted today by a Federal grand jury on a charge of violating the civil rights of two Negroes on May 11 when racial violence swept through this city, leaving six Negroes dead, 60 persons injured and $1-million in property damage.
DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UPI) Denny McLain will rejoin the Detroit Tigers Saturday after serving a one-week suspension for dousing two Detroit sports writers with buckets of ice water.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The United States Chamber of Commerce challenged today much of the basic line of reasoning behind the Nixon Administration's welfare reform plan.
A Yonkers businessman who allegedly persuaded young women heroin-addicts to engage in sexual intercourse by posing as a lawyer for Odyssey House was arrested yesterday in Brooklyn.
Mayor Lindsay disputed yesterday the contention of some antipoverty workers that department-store jobs are a dead end.
LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 Susan Denice Atkins, a codefendant in the murder trial of Charles M. Manson, underwent further medical tests today.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 1 About l,000 young people marched through Portland's streets tonight in the second licensed parade by the People's Army Jamboree in three days.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 1 A Federal Government effort to renew deportation proceedings against an alleged Sicilian Mafia "executioner," wanted by the Italian police since 1963, was approved today by a special hearing officer for the United States Immigration and Naturalization Commission.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) Transportation Secretary John A. Volpe proposed today that city traffic congestion be relieved by encouraging greater reliance on buses, with special lanes and even highways reserved for their exclusive use.

SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 1 Vice President Agnew said here today that the Cambodian Government "has at least a fighting chance for survival" as a result of the United States and South Vietnamese assault on Communist border sanctuaries.

Moody's Investors Service, the investment counseling and information subsidiary of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., has encountered a significant roadblock to its plan to sell its right to manage the $30-million Moody's Capital Fund to Vance, Sanders Co., Inc., a big Boston-based mutual fund management and distribution concern.

Earl S. Potter, one of three stewards overseeing thoroughbred racing at Belmont Park, Aqueduct and Saratoga, died Monday night at his racingseason residence in Garden City, L.I. Mr. Potter, who made his home an Pottersville, N.J., was 63 years, old.

Nationwide contracts for all kinds of construction work in July had a total value of $6,177,789,000, just a bit below the July, 1969, total of $6,180,435,000, the F.W. Dodge division of the Mc-GrawHill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.
CHICAGO, Sept. 1-Arthur J. Goldberg traveled to Chicago today to look up some old friends for financial assistance on his New York gubernatorial campaign.

NEW HAVEN Sept. 1 With the conclusion of the Lonnie McLucas trial here on a somewhat ambiguous note a guilty verdict on a charge of conspiracy to murder, with acquittal on three others that carried heavier penalties the state's effort to prove that the leadership of the Black Panther.
ST. PAUL, Sept. 1 (UPI) Three explosions within 38 minutes shook this city's Lower Loop today and injured three persons.
Bronx landlords reported yesterday that an impasse had been reached in their negotiations with apartment-house workers, whose contract expires Sept. 14.
BROOKVILLE, L.I., Sept. 1 Alex Webster didn't yell a lot and he didn't make a lot of threats. All he did was hold a friendly little scrimmage this afternoon.

ASPEN, Colo., Sept. 1 In the last few days, a group of distinguished scientists, economists, historians and philosophers meeting here have reached the melancholy conclusion that modern technology, greedy men and complacent or inefficient governments are debasing human values, ruining the quality of our environment, and threatening the future of a decent and civilized world.
The Penn Central plans to introduce a new "zonal" schedule on its evening New Haven commuter service Sept. 21 that it said would mean more trains, faster service and fewer standees.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 1-Twelve Peace Corpsmen have been evacuated from two areas where Marxist guerrillas have been battling Government forces during the last month.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 1 (AP) A faculty committee has stopped paying Angela Davis, on the ground that it has received no word from her that she intends to lecture in the fall at the University of California at Los Angeles.

James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for United States Senator, described his two opponents yesterday as "white flag" candidates for supporting a Congressional effort to require the withdrawal of all American troops from Indochina by the end of next year.
OMAHA, Sept. 1 Two Nebraska leaders of an offshoot of the Black Panther party have been charged with murder in the Aug. 17 death of Patrolman Larry Minard.

At their training camp in Hempstead, L.I., the Jets will go to work today on their offense, which has been so uneven lately. In the fourth preseason game, against the Saints an New Orleans on Saturday night, Al Woodall will follow Joe Namath at quarterback and, Coach Weeb
The Bicycle Institute of America announced yesterday the adoption of a set of industrywide bicycle safety and performances standards.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The Senate defeated today the Hatfield-McGovern "amendment to end the war."

Booker T. Ervin Jr., a jazz musician and composer who played tenor saxophone with many leading contemporary groups, died Monday in Bellevue Hospital of a kidney ailment. He was 39 years old and lived at 204 East 13th Street.

The sedge is an innocuous looking, grasslike plant of many varities that grows all over South America. Two varieties, however, are potent contraceptives, thought to be used by Indian women for centuries as their "pill."

MOSCOW, Sept. 1-The Soviet Union announced today the restoration of the once-abolished Ministry of Justice as part of a stepped up drive against crime, particularly against graft and embezzlement of state property.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1-Japanese makers of television sets have charged that the Treasury's action last week alleging "dumping" in the United States market was based on "stale price data" going back as long as three years.

The Census Bureau made public yesterday its preliminary count for New York City, giving the 1970 population as 7,771,730, only 10,254 below 1960, despite some earlier unofficial forecasts of a major drop.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The possibility of rationing fuel this winter to keep some small electric utilities running was raised today at a meeting of private power officials with the President's Council of Economic Advisers.
Mery Griffin confirmed yesterday that he is taking his late-night talk show to California.
The bottom appeared to drop out of the rising grain and soybean-futures market yesterday, with all components showing price decreases from the day before on the Chicago Board of Trade.
The Western Electric Company, the manufacturing and supply unit of the Bell System, yesterday announced price increases in certain of its manufactured products that average 2.8 per cent.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Chief Justice Warren E. Burger became embroiled in another controversy over freedom of the press today when a Washington publisher chided him for requiring permission before his State of the Judiciary speech may be reprinted.
The summer's strong swing toward lower interest rates and higher prices for fixed-income securities remained largely intact yesterday in the face of a heavy supply of new notes and bonds for sale.

Three new groups were the features of the program last night at the free-admission New York Dance Festival, now in its second week at Central Park's Delacorte Theater under the auspices of the New York Shakespeare Festival.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Sept. 1 Hoping to take advantage of close local races between Republicans and Democrats, the predominantly black National Democratic Party of Alabama formally qualified a slate of 169 candidates today to run in the Nov. 3 general election. All but nine are Negroes.
The switchboard at Boston's Fenway Park received three telephone calls warning of a bomb in the park last night, but the police bomb squad looked in the wrong place.

Ralph Nader asserted yesterday that the United States would "become a nation of slaves" unless safeguards and human values were integrated "before it's too late" into what he called the unregulated and uncontrolled use of computers.

It looked like anything but a major opera company getting ready for an opening night. Julius Rudel, the New York City Opera's, general director, chatted with John White, the managing director about the relative charms of Vienna, London and Paris.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1 David Miller, manager of the Columbia Broadcasting System bureau here, married Kate Dilworth of Washington in a civil ceremony today.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1-Five helicopters fluttered into a jungle clearing northwest of Saigon several months ago to pick up a platoon of American infantrymen that had been staging ambushes for 10 days.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 1 The Israeli Government today postponed further moves to advance the peace talks with the Arab states until the removal of all Egyptian missiles she says have been newly placed at the Suez Canal.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Early in May, aflame over the allied drive into Cambodia and the deaths at Kent State University, a group of young political activists banded together to lobby for the "amendment to end the war."

FARGO, N.D., Sept. 1 (AP) A Republican maverick, Robert P. McCarney, and Richard Elkin, endorsed by the state party, were locked in a tight battle tonight in the Republican gubernatorial primary for the House in the western district.

The Eastern and Western railroads of the country asked the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday for authority to raise their freight rates across the board by 15 per cent. They proposed that the commission allow them to put an 8 per cent increase into effect on Sept. 15,and a 7 per cent increase on Nov. 1.

CHEROKEE, N.C., Sept. 1 An outdoor drama depicting the white man's expulsion of 19th-century Cherokees from the North Carolina mountains has developed over the last two decades into a major source of funds for programs to enrich the lives of 20th-century Cherokees.
ATLANTA, Sept. 1 (UPI) Cassius Clay promised today that he would produce a "real fight" in his two exhibition matches tomorrow night, but said he needed four more weeks to get in championship form.
Policemen called to assist in an eviction in the Morrisonia section of the Bronx last night said they found four unlicensed guns, one crossbow and two longbows.
KANSAS CITY, Sept. 1 (AP) The film, "A Place in the Sun," which presents highlights in the life of the late Dwight D. Eisenhower, made its debut here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 Miss Julianne Rash and Dr. Robert M. Weir, who is a captain in the United States Public Health Service, will be married here Nov. 1 at the home of the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bryson B. Rash.
William Attwood, the editor in chief of Cowles Communications, Inc., and former United States Ambassador to Guinea and Kenya, was named yesterday as publisher and president of Newsday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 The first national statistical picture of the population emerged from the 1970 census today, and it showed that the nineteen-sixties were a decade of outward movement outward from cities to suburbs and outward to the coastland.
LONDON, Sept. 1 Flying for the first time over populated areas, the supersonic Concorde soared today over an 800-mile-long corridor along the coast of West Scotland, Wales and England.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 1-South Vietnamese troops, reinforced by Americans, reported having killed 56 Vietcong soldiers yesterday in a battle lasting nearly eight hours, 120 miles east-northeast of Saigon.

OTTAWA, Sept. 1 The reduction in the bank interest rate announced last night by the Bank of Canada reflects a shifting of political and economic pressures on the Trudeau Government from a worry over inflation to unemployment that has now racked a peak of 6.7 per cent.
On billboards throughout the Twin Cities area, Joe Kapp smiles. Next to him is the slogan, "Joe Kapp Can't Lose with Instant Interest," a message from a local bank.

RENO, Nev., Sept. 1 (UPI) Senator Howard W. Cannon won renomination today in Nevada's Democratic primary election. William Raggio, a Republican district attorney, rolled up an apparently unbeatable lead against token opposition in the senatorial primary.

Wounding other people's sensibilities never has given George Meany much pause so it is no surprise to find the 76-year-old president of the A.F.L-C.I.O. celebrating the advent of Labor Day with a hatful of harsh words for practically everybody outside labor's own ranks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 A federation of black community organizations in Columbus, Ohio, asked the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to deny license renewals for three local broadcasters on the ground that they had given inadequate coverage to the needs and interests of black listeners.

The engagement of Miss Victoria Smith Schofield to Thomas John Arkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. John J. Arkins of Garden City, L.I., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. William H. Schofield of New York and Jaffrey Center, N.H.

Robert P. Anderson, secretary and director of public information of the Council for Financial Aid to Education, died yesterday in St. Clare's Hospital in Denville, N.J., after a brief illness. He was 57 years old and lived in Smoke Rise, Kinnelon, N.J.

DETROIT, Sept. 1 (UPI) General Motors Corporation asked the owners of 4,400 light trucks today to return them to their dealers for inspection and possible replacement of bolts that could cause the driver to lose control if they broke.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1 (UPI) Reporters covering the Sate Department protested today against the withdrawal of the appointment of a director of the State Department's Office of Press Relations after Senator Barry M. Goldwater had objected to it.
HAMILTON, Mass., Sept. 1 Miss Rose Dimond Cutler and Anthony Allan Ryan, a great-grandson of the late Thomas Fortune Ryan, the financier, will many here Dec. 19.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 2 St. Louis is having its troubles these days. The city has just been advised it fell from the top 10 in population in the census. A cobra escaped from the zoo this week and the New York Mets even beat Bob Gibson the other night.
There are still 3,000 tickets at $4 each left for Saturday's Giant-Eagle football game at Princeton, N.J., according to the New Jersey Jaycees, sponsors of the game.

Mayor Lindsay made public yesterday spot reports from 24 areas in which 311 of 1,808 persons interviewed or 17 per cent said they had not been counted in the Federal census. The same assertion came from 66 of 362 families questioned, or 18 per cent.
Stock prices recovered from a sinking spell at midsession yesterday and managed to close only a shade lower. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange continued to ebb with the dip in prices.
Mrs. Nancy Hadra Pogue and Michael Gourd were married here yesterday afternoon in Christ Methodist Church by the Rev. George Teague.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 World trade continued to boom in the second quarter of this year, the International Mone tary Fund reported today.

TRENTON, Sept. 2 Spokesmen for migrant farm workers in southern New Jersey presented a list of 10 legislative proposals to the Acting Governor today, seeking as key changes in the law a $1.75an-hour-minimum wage and free access to workers' camps by friends, relatives and other visitors.

MANILA, Sept. 2 A state of national emergency was declared by President Ferdinand E. Marcos today as floods brought on by three days of heart rain surged over many parts of Luzon Island, including the Greater Manila area.

ATLANTA, Sept. 2 (UPI) Incensed at the indictment of two Augusta policemen by a Federal grand jury, Gov. Lester G. Maddox sent a letter today to President Nixon accusing the Federal Government of favoring "rioters, looters and burners."

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 2 Yasir Arafat, the principal Arab commando chief, today denounced what he termed ugly aggression by the Jordanian authorities. He spoke a few hours after the authorities had expressed a desire to "strengthen the brotherhood" between the army and the commandos.

ATLANTA, Sept. 2 (UPI) Cassius Clay returned to the ring tonight, breezing through eight exhibition rounds against three heavyweights. The ring appearance was Clay's first in three years, but it marked a breakthrough for the deposed heavyweight champion, who has been rebuffed repeatedly by legal procedures in his bid to start a comeback.

The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) said yesterday that its Libyan affiliates had been ordered to cut oil production by 110,000 barrels a day, or about 15 per cent.

F. Joseph Van Poppelen Jr., has been named group vice president for the systems technology, space and defense systems, defense products, industrial products, graphic equipment, DuMont electron tubes and controls divisions as well as the ElectroMetrics Corporation, a Fairchild Camera and Instrument Corporation subsidiary. M.M. Atalla, named group vice president in charge of research and development while retaining his former divisional responsibilities.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 2 Vice President Agnew, whirling across the country as President Nixon's stand-in, declared here today that the "real peace lobby today is composed of those who maintain the peace, not those who disturb it."

Braniff Airways, Inc., announced yesterday the election of C. Edward Acker, 41 years old, as president and chief operating officer. Harding L. Lawrence who had held the posts continues as chairman and chief executive officer.
Mayor Lindsay asked the Mayor of Bridgeport yesterday to forgive him for suggesting that the Connecticut city was as filthy as New York.

MYRTLE BEACH, S.C., Sept. 2-Miss Judith Elizabeth Reed, who is with Time-Life Books division of Time Inc., in New York, and Lucien Leo Bowman Jr., an investment banker with E.F. Hutton Co., in New York, and the son of Lee Bowman, the actor, will be married Oct. 22 in St. James' Episcopal Church in New York.
An experimental plan to transform part of New York's dowdy old waterfront temporarily into a cultural and recreational playground was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
"The left hand made the difference," said Frank Wright yesterday after the Oxford Stable's Native Partner won the $28,800 Maskette Handicap at Belmont Park.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 A major new entity in the nation's financial and housing markets came into being today.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (AP) The police charged a member of the ruling body of the Black P Stone Nation street gang today with the sniper murder of a Chicago policeman.
A New York State prisoner recently was punished for writing in his diary that he did not like the deputy warden.

The Ford Foundation announced last night grants totaling $500,000 to two institutions for experiments in engaging students' emotions in the learning process, from elementary education to post-graduate college levels.

SPARKS, Neb., Sept. 1 Vernon L. Brill is 38 years old and a part-time garage mechanic, campground operator and insurance salesman. He is also part of a muchrevered but dying American institution the one-room schoolhouse.

DETROIT, Sept. 2 The United Automobile Workers said today that General Motors or the Chrysler Corporation or both would be struck at midnight Sept. 14 if the auto union did not have a new contract by then.
The City University, under considerable pressure from its Faculty Senate, has moved to resolve a tangled, year-long dispute that has opened the university to charges of violating academic freedom.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 1 Theatrically, this seems to be Britain's year for Mary Stuart and Elizabeth Tudor. Not only has there been Robert Bolt's play at Chichester, now about to open in London, "Vivat! Regina!" which lovingly explored the relationship between those royal ladies, but also now in Edinburg both Queens provide the subject matter for a brace of recitals at this year's Edinburgh festivals.

ROME, Sept. 2 A man threw two stones at Pope Paul VI today at the end of the Pontiff's general audience at his Castel Gandolfo summer home. The stones missed the Pope by three feet and hit the wall behind his throne. Vatican officials said he was not immediately aware of the incident.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2 Superior Court Judge Charles H. Older ordered the murder trial of Charles M. Manson to proceed today despite the loud protests of a co-defendant, Susan Denice Atkins, that she was still too ill to appear in court.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) Vince Lombardi, famed foot ball coach, was in a deep coma and near death at Georgetown University Hospital today, the victim of "an extraordinarily virulent form of cancer."

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Sept. 2 Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Hoffman Zeese Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Bonita Gail Zeese, to Dodge Oatwell Dorland. He is the son of Mrs. Joseph Warner Dorland of New York and Southampton, and the late Mr. Dorland, who was president and founder of Wade and Dorland, Inc., an insurance brokerage, and vice president of Davis Dorland, Inc., in New York. A December wedding is planned.

If General Motors shows new concern for automobile safety improvements and anti-pollution devices sooner rather than later, the appointment of five of its own directors to a special public policy committee will be welcomed as an example of corporate responsibility. If the company puts most of its concern into explaining why deadlines for safer, smog-free cars cannot be ... met, the public is likely to dismiss the new G.M. committee as mere window-dressing.

Angry shopkeepers and residents of Greenwich Village, asserting they are suffering from rising crime in the area, demanded yesterday that the city give them more police protection and stop housing single men on welfare in local transient hotels.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The Federal Reserve Board, in an unusual case under the Bank Holding Company Act, approved today the purchase of shares in one British bank by another.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 2 Arthur J. Costigan, a retired vice president in the radiomarine department of the RCA Corporation, died yesterday at the Montclair Nursing Home here. He was 76 years old and formerly lived in Brooklyn.
PARIS, Sept. 2 (UPI) France will honor Francois Mauriac, a Nobel Prize winner and one of the nation's greatest writers, in two funeral services this weekend, a Government spokesman said today.

The marriage of Miss Lois Ellen Gilson, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin I. Gilson of Brooklyn, to Ronald William Kuzon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward M. Kuzon of Longmeadow, Mass., took place here last night in the Versailles Suite of the St. Regis-Sheraton. Rabbi Eugene J. Sack performed the ceremony.

With both floundering after a month of camp, the Jets and Giants have decided that now is the time for all good players to come to the aid of their respective teams.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 2 (UPI) The United States today transferred control of an Army company of 31 UH1 helicopters to South Vietnam's Air Force and turned over responsibility for coastal patrols to the South Vietnamese Navy.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 2 (UPI) Lanny Wadkins, the Southern and Western golf champion from Wake Forest, shot an opening-round threeunder-par 34, 33 67 in the National Amateur today and took the lead by a stroke over Gary Sanders of Southern California.

BUFFALO, Sept. 2 (AP) The Erie County Board of Elections accepted today the nominating petitions of Representative Richard Max McCarthy, a Democrat, who is seeking re-election in November as an independent.

NEW DELHI, Sept. 2 The rajas, India's princely former rulers, lost their battle with the Government today as the lower house of parliament voted to abolish their allowances and other special privileges.

LONDON, Sept. 2 (Reuters) British gold and dollar reserves fell by only 18-million ($43.2-million) last month despite the adverse economic effects of strikes and pressure on the pound, it was announced today.
RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 22 After eight years of military dictatorship, many Burmese fear for the future of their country and the mood among high officials is deeply pessimistic.
RANGOON, Burma, Aug. 22 The Burmese, it is said, were once counted among the most honest people in Asia. No more.
JVC America, Inc., of Maspeth, Queens, announced yesterday the development of what it called the world's first fourchannel phonograph and soundreproducing system.

"Scrooge," a British-made musical version of Charles Dickens's "A Christmas Carol," starring Albert Finney in the title role, will be the Christmas feature at the Radio City Music Hall. The program will include the 38th consecutive presentation of "The Nativity," the theater's seasonal pageant.
The first of seven buoys designed to replace lightships reported for duty off Sandy Hook, N.J. yesterday.

Troubled by excess capacity on competitive flights, Trans World, United and American Airlines have asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to let them make a joint agreement to reduce their flights on fifteen major domestic air routes.

TOMS RIVER, N.J., Sept. 1 If the people of Ocean County weren't shouting "we're No. 1" today it was probably because virtually everyone here has known for years that, on a percentage basis, Ocean is the fastest growing county in the United States.
Paul Crowell saw a long line of Mayors come and go, having covered the administrations of all of them from James J. Walker to Robert F. Wagner during his years on the City Hall beat.
GRANBURY, Tex., Sept. 2 (UPI) Henry Zweifel, for years one of the most powerful Republican leaders in Texas, died Monday in a Stephen Ville hospital. He was 86 years old.

Thirty black and Puerto Rican students and several faculty, members took over the office of the president of the small, Federally financed College for Human Services for eight hours yesterday and demanded her resignation.

WEST HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Sept. 2 The state Commission on Human Rights today ordered the Lakeview Fire Department to admit a black applicant who has been trying to join one of the department's volunteer companies for nine years.

Notice to the conductor on the 7 P.M. to Scarsdale: Don't be concerned about that man you used to see reading Harper's Bazaar who recently switched to True Confessions. It's for business, not pleasure.
NEW BRITAIN, Conn., Sept. 2 (UPI) Four juveniles face van dalism charges in the burning of American flags taken from veterans' graves at Old St. Mary Cemetery here.

After about two-thirds of the correction officers scheduled to work at the Rikers Island reformatory called in sick yesterday, the Correction Department announced that 300 more men would be added to the custodial staffs of the city's penal and detention institutions.

If you have been reading your third-class mail lately, you may have noticed a long manila envelope from a concern in Louisville, Ky., marked prominently in red: "Do Not Destroy . . . Cash Voucher Enclosed."
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 The Soviet Union today marked the 5th anniversary of Japan's capitulation with articles denouncing the United States and warning that militarism was on the rise again in Japan.

SYRACUSE, Sept. A court investigation was ordered today into the case of a 4-yearold boy who died, apparently of a beating, shortly after he bad been taken out of a foster home and returned to his parents.
Prices were increased yesterday on various forms and quantities of caustic soda and chlorine by two major producers.

LONDON, Sept. 2 One field in which the oppression of women has been healthy for the common good is the newspaper column. Here the rule that a woman must be at least twice as good as a competing man to get the job they both want has spared the reading public at least a modicum of twaddle.

SARASOTA, Fla., Sept. 2 Paul Crowell, who retired in 1965 after 36 years as a reporter for The New York Times, most of the time at New York's City Hall, died yesterday of a heart attack while on a visit here. He was 78 years old and lived at 151 West 16th Street, New York.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration canceled two lunar landings today in a move that NASA officials said would cut deeply into the scientific value of the Apollo program.
Miss Marian Blum, publicity director of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York, was married here last evening to Marvin S. Gruber, assistant controller of the First Security Company.

Charles Plohn Co., the battered and embattled brokerage firm suspended last month by the New York Stock Exchange, has been telling its remaining customers to be patient, because it is not really insolvent.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 2 Governor Rockefeller tonight identified seven "major remaining challenges" in the state's Pure Water program and promised fast action to overcome them.

BLAIRSTOWN, N.J., Sept. 2 It's centennial year plus one at Princeton's secluded summer football camp, and while things are not quite as hectic as last season, winning is still the No. 1 topic on the agenda of Jake McCandless, the Tiger coach.

"Ecstasy" is a number of things, one of which is a dance by Lar Lubovitch. Last night at the New York Dance Festival in Central Park's Delacorte Theater, Mr. Lubovitch presented his company in the work for the first time this season.
The Ampex Corporation, which first developed tape recording for the TV industry, announced yesterday a line of miniature tape recorders and playback machines for home or industrial use.
Blood for transfusions, chronically in short supply here during summer vacation months and long holiday weekends, was reported yesterday to be at a desperately low level.

The heroes of this week's school opening in the South were a Republican Governor and a seventeenyear-old Negro high school student. Virginia's Gov. Linwood Holton Jr. personally accompanied his thirteen-year-old daughter to the hitherto all-black John F. Kennedy High School in Richmond; Gregory Thomas, commanding officer of the school's corps of cadets, taking apprehensive white students in tow, told them: "This is now your school, too."

Rick Barry, who has spent more time in court than on the court the last three years, was traded to the New York Nets yesterday by the Virginia Squires for a No. 1 draft choice and an undisclosed amount of cash.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The Federal Bureau of Investigation has begun a nationwide hunt for four young men who have been charged in the bombing of the Army Mathematics Research Center on the University of Wisconsin campus on Aug. 24. The blast killed a graduate student and wounded four other persons.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange ended mostly higher yesterday as an afternoon rally erased most of the earlier losses in slightly stepped-up trading.
Dr. Joseph T. English, president of the city's Health and Hospitals Corporation, announced the appointment of Dr. Michael R. McGarvey as his principal assistant yesterday.

TRUNGTHANH, South Vietnam, Aug. 28 The Street Without Joy is still not much fun, but at least it has begun to stir with village life again. The so-called street actually is a marshy coastal strip of interlocking villages between Quangtri and Hue east of Route 1. Its Several thousand villagers were evacuated in 1967.
Representatives of civic, trade and labor groups met with city administrators yesterday and declared that "no category of job needs to be a dead end."
The Metropolitan Transporta- tion Authority announced yes- terday the appointment of a three-man panel to study per- sonnel records and practices of the City Transit Authority.
RANGOON, Aug. 22 You can still 'ear their paddles chunkin' on the Rangoon River.
Pan American World Airways is weighing the possibil- ity of moving all or part of its administrative operations from New York City to the suburbs.
A Queens bar owned by the former wife Of Willie Mays, the baseball player, was held up last night and her daughter and three other patrons were pistol-whipped by three gun- men.

Senator Charles E. Goodell, who has become increasingly dissatisfied with his own political campaign, announced yesterday that he was replacing his campaign manager, former Deputy Mayor Robert W. Sweet.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 (AP) "Tchaikovsky," a SovietAmerican movie production, opened to the Soviet public tonight after an advertising campaign the likes of which have rarely been seen in the press here.

The King Resources Company, which has been beset with financial problems recently, disclosed yesterday that it had a loss of $15,670,947 in the first half of this year against a profit of $7,134,023, or 38 cents a share, in the similar period of 1969.
TURIN, Italy, Sept. 2 (AP) The Soviet Union won five gold medals for a total of 14 at the World University Games today The American team, which has 19, won none today.

LIMA, Peru, Sept. 1 (Reuters) The Peruvian Government last night acquired a controlling interest in a previously foreign-controled bank, its second such move within a week in a quiet campaign of bank nationalization.

Lindy McDaniel helped to make secure another victory for the New York Yankees yesterday, this one a 3-2 decision credited to Mike Kekich at the expense of Dave McNally, who had already won 21 games for the Baltimore Orioles.

Twelve-year-old Chana Stein crash-landed on the moon, Mrs. Consuelo Milner decided how to improve her mathematics classes and 13-year-old William Gilson made a big impression with his "computer bum" skills.

OSAKA, Japan, Sept. 2 (AP) An American quartet bettered the world record for the women's 400-meter medley relay by seven-tenths of a second today, with a time of 4 minutes 27.4 seconds in a swimming meet.

Angelo A. Simonetti, a Democratic district leader in Manhattan for about 30 years and a senior administrator of the Board of Elections, died yesterday after a short illness at Harkness Pavilion, ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He was in his early seventies and lived at 765 Riverside Drive.

GREENWICH, Conn., Sept. 2 Mr. and Mrs. John F. Dowling Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Claire Dowling, to William Calvin Petty 3d of New York, son of Mr. and Mrs. William C. Petty Jr. of Stonington. The wedding is planned for Nov. 28.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 Teams of Justice Department officials will fan out across the country next month in an effort to convince college students that the Justice Department's policies are not repressive toward criminal suspects or lukewarm on civil rights.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 As widely anticipated, business has again revised downward its plans for investment in plant and equipment this year, the Commerce Department and the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.
PASADENA, Calif., Sept. 2 A 1971 Ford Capri, modified to reduce smog emissions, was declared the over-all winner of the intercollegiate crosscountry "clean car" race to- night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals has upheld the embezzlement conviction of Don C. Silverthorne, now 70 years old, the man who founded the San Francisco National Bank and left it broke 30 months later.

HONG KONG, Thursday, Sept. 3 Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China last night accused the United States of trying to end the fighting in Indochina by "feverishly practicing political deception and contriving peace-talk schemes."
Theodore Kheel, the New York City labor negotiator, is going to Paris today to try to find out if his experience as a professional mediator can be useful in helping the Paris peace talks.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 2 The American Legion's national convention urged Congress today to propose constitutional amendments limiting the authority of the Supreme Court.

LINCOLN, Neb., Sept. 2 (UPI) Guards opened fire today into a cellblock in the maximum security ward at Nebraska State Penitentiary, and a band of 13 convicts quickly freed two guards they had held hostage at knifepoint for almost 20 hours.

UMSASKIS LAKE, Me. A gray dawn and a spit of rain greeted us as we crept from our tents on the second day of our canoe trip on the Allagash Wilderness Waterway, but we had gathered good dry wood the night before and soon had a smoke-blackened pot of coffee boiling merrily.

The Dade Federal Savings and Loan Association, the second largest saving and loan association in the Miami area, yesterday announced it was cutting its prime home mortgage lending rate from 8 per cent to 8 per cent.

Consumer cautiousness, uncertainties about styles, hot weather and the late school openings hit New York retailers hard during August and left them with more than a 5 per cent deficit in sales Volume.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (UPI) The Food and Drug Administration announced today that it would set nutritional guidelines for processed foods ranging from breakfast cereal to frozen dinners.

Public response to a novel telephone service, part of a current art show, "Information," at the Museum of Modern Art, may induce museum officials to retain the service after the show closes on Sept. 20.

ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Sept. 2 (Canadian Press) Oarsmen from the United States did poorly while the East German and Soviet crews dominated the scene today as the world rowing championships began on Twelve Mile Creek, a tributary of nearby Lake Ontario.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 Defense Secretary Melvin R. Laird suggested today that the Government might have to change its policy of establishing research facilities on campuses. He said the step might become necessary because such facilities have become potential targets for student radicals.

Revised counts in six of Connecticut's eight counties were reported yesterday by the Census Bureau in Washington to explain the change from its first report of 2,990,196 residents in the state in 1970 to its latest tally of 2,987,950.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 2 Edward Wallerstein, a former president and chairman of the board of Columbia Records, Inc., died in a nursing home here yesterday. His age was 78.

The Commonwealth United Corporation, a troubled West Coast conglomerate, has stayed off for 18 months payment on more than $50-million in principal and interest of its debts to major domestic and foreign secured lenders.

A company selling half-acre lots on a resort island is returning $450,000 to New York State investors because it did not comply with a state law stipulating the filing of an "offering statement," Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz said yesterday.
Alvin Dark pulled the Sam McDowell shift last night for the second time this season, but unlike the first time, it didn't work. Neither did the Frank Howard shift.

LONDON, Thursday, Sept. 31 (Reuters) Union and management officials today agreed on a formula to end the strike at the G.K.N.-Sankey auto components plant, which has seriously disrupted the British car industry.

Reds flags flew at the United States Open tennis championships yesterday signaling the start of "sudden death," but black flags would have been appropriate to mark the opening-round exit of such favorites as Andres Gimeno and Marty Riessen.

KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., Sept. 2 Arthur J. Goldberg, the Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, made a strong bid today for endorsement by the 1,500 delegates attending the annual convention here of the New York State American Federation of Labor-Congress of Industrial Organizations.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 2 (UPI) The Government barred Malcolm W. Browne, a correspondent of The New York Times, from entering Chile last night on the ground that he had written defamatory articles about the country.

LONDON, Sept. 2 A Nobel Prize-winning chemist tonight urged a strengthening of the academic " lite" and questioned the desirability of traditional mass higher education.
ROCHESTER, Sept. 2 (AP) Vince Turiano, owner of the Towpath Inn, a tavern in downtown Rochester, received two letters from the city this week.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 2 After two and a half months of cold fireboxes and bats in the caboose, Cambodia's national railroads are rolling again up to a point.

Every Tuesday evening since early summer, whenever the skies are fair, the sound of sea chanteys has been rising from the South Street Seaport pier at Fulton Street and the East River.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sept. 2 New Zealand officially opened her doors today to American migrants wishing to come under a subsidized immigration program.

ROME, Sept. 2 The Vatican relaxed today the restrictions that prevented Catholic laymen from taking wine along with bread at communion, giving to local conferences of bishops jurisdition over what was once a major theological controversy.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Sept. 2 Mrs. Marie (Mimi)Harriman Murray, an artist and wife of John F. Murray, an author, died yesterday after a brief illness, at Southampton Hospital. She was 45 years old and lived in Wainscott and at 108 East 82d Street, New York.
DETROIT, Sept. 2 (AP)-Chrysler Corporation announced today it was recalling 1,372 cars for inspection for possible defects.
EUREKA, N.C. Billy E. Pate's house payment is $59 a month.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2 (UPI) Don Gutteridge was released as manager of the Chicago White Sox today at his re- quest.
MOSCOW, Sept. 2 Soviet health officials said today that the cholera outbreak had caused several deaths but that the spead of the disease had been virtually stopped.

Diana Sands, the actress, and her mother were sitting around Miss Sands's West Side apartment one night last June, chatting about their relatives. The talk eventually turned to the actress's nephew, Gary Thomas, who was about to become a father for the first time.
The London stock market continued to decline yesterday as trading remained quiet.

SEATTLE, Sept. 2 (AP) Owners of Western Hockey League clubs have voted today to accept a settlement of more than $800,000 from the National Hockey League in an indemnity dispute over the senior league's takeover of territorial rights in Vancouver, British Columbia.

Jerome Kretchmer, the city's Environmental Protection Administrator, said yesterday that the city was cleaner than it was a month ago and that within 60 days there would be such an improvement that it would be visible all over the city.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 The United States Government urgently searched today for ways to preserve the tenuous ceasefire in the Middle East and to bring about resumption of the Arab-Israeli peace talks. It acted as new American evidence showed that the number of Egyptian missile positions in the truce zone had nearly tripled in the last month.

From New York to the hinterlands of the art world places like Harrisburg, Pa., Dayton, Ohio, and Seattle a market for massproduced "original art" is springing up in the wake of a nationwide boom in art buying.
ATHENS, Sept. 2 A powerful explosion in the parking lot of the United States Embassy here killed two persons today, wrecked three cars and shattered embassy windows.
DETROIT, Sept. 2 The four United States automobile makers reported today a 7 per cent decline in sales of Americantype cars in the final third of August compared with the similar period last year.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 (AP) Safeway Stores, Inc., the nation's second-largest grocery chain, began explaining to customers in four states today how to read the freshness codes on its products.

During the recent 18-man round-robin international at Buenos Aires, three players did not lose a game. The high scorer in this respect was Bobby Fischer of the United States, grandmaster extraordinary and the winner of the event with 13 victories and four draws for a 15-2 score.

Allegra Kent, who has been dancing particularly well in the current summer New York City Ballet season at the State Theater, made her debut in the 'Diamonds" role of George Balanchine's "Jewels" at a special matinee yesterday.

A new season is beginning for the three commercial bridge leagues in the metropolitan area. The biggest of these is the Metropolitan Commercial Bridge League, which will operate on a new plan: teams will be of eight players, instead of 12.

HUNTSVILLE, Ala., Aug. 29 Twenty-five years ago, they were the prize booty of World War II. When they were brought to this country, they became the nucleus of the engineering team that launched the first American satellite and built the Saturn 5 moon rocket.

PANAMA CITY, Sept. 1 Panama has formally notified the United States that three draft treaties drawn up in 1967 to create a new status for the Panama Canal are unacceptable as a basis for resuming negotiations.

ALBANY, Sept. 2 The Public Service Commission announced today that it had authorized the Consolidated Edison Company to increase its residential electric rates next Tuesday by an average of about 4 per cent.
SAN CLEMENTE, Calif., Sept. 2 President Nixon today hailed the relatively smooth desegregation of hundreds of Southern school districts and, in the process, complimented the news media.

Corn and soybean futures prices rose yesterday in a late rally after decreasing in price early in the day following two sessions of declining prices. Wheat, which had been off as much as 1 cent a bushel early in the day, also rallied.
