WASHINGTON, Sept. 2 President Nixon's statement of last March 24 on school desegregation is emerging as an element of the Administration's policy for opening white suburbs to poor blacks.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 2 Authoritative sources said today that the divided Israeli Cabinet had decided, in a compromise, to wait about two weeks to determine whether the United States could fulfill its assurances that the present ceasefire would not bring military advantage to the Egyptians.
District Attorney Burton B. Roberts of the Bronx said yesterday that there was no evidence to support any speculation that a Bronx patrolman shot on Sunday was the victim of a plot or an ambush.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 3 William McMahon, Minister for External Affairs, said in Parliament today that an article in The New York Times asserting that Australian troops in South Vietnam are mercenaries whose costs are paid by the United States was scurrilous and inaccurate.

Five major airlines, which joined forces six months ago in the experimental operation of three suburban airline terminals, or satellite check-in stations, announced yesterday that they would discontinue two of them.

OTTAWA, Sept. 3 (UPI) Ted Green, the Boston Bruins" defenseman, was acquitted today of an assault charge, bringing to an end the first criminal court action against professional hockey players for fighting on the ice.

Several Puerto Rican organizations demonstrated noisily last night at Broadway and Leonard Street as a citywide panel of the Council Against Poverty considered a recommendation that funds for the Puerto Rican Family Institute be cut off on Dec. 31.
ORLANDO, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP) Pat Palinkas, professional football's first woman player, made the Orlando Panthers' roster at the final cutdown today but was immediately suspended for missing practice.

GENEVA, Sept. 3 Bernard Cornfeld, founder of the Investors Overseas Services mutual fund empire, regained his seat on the board of directors today in exchange for his agreement to drop his fight to overthrow the new management.
Tony Roche thought he had the day off. Or he thought that that's what Mike Gibson, the referee at the United States Open tennis championships, told him on Wednesday night.
The restaurants reviewed on this page on Friday are rated four stars to none, based on the relationship of food and service to cost. Credit cards are honored where indicated.
Dramatizing an acute shortage of blood for transfusions in local hospitals, Mayor Lindsay made a 15minute stop at Bellevue Hospital yesterday morning to donate a pint of his own.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Indian occupants of Alcatraz Island rejected today a self-appointed mediator's attempt to win them a fiveyear lease on the former prison site in San Francisco Bay.
TURIN, Italy, Sept. 3 (AP) Wolfgang Nordwig of East Germany cleared 17 feet 11 inches today for a world record in the World University Games. It was the second world mark of the day.

ASPEN, Colo., Sept. 3 In this lovely valley of the Rocky Mountains, the old frontier spirit, believe it or not, still exists. Money from Chicago has turned it into an intellectual and sporting resort, where skiers and professors slide and study, but outside these fashionable seasonable pursuits, Aspen is a community with a life of its own and it is doing things in its own way.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 3 Miss Laura Dean Kramer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dan G. Kramer of Muttontown, was married in two civil ceremonies today to Charles Seymour 3d. He is the son of Prof. and Mrs. Seymour Jr. of New Haven. His grandfather, the late Dr. Seymour, was president of Yale University, where the bridegroom's father is professor of history of art.
The American Stock Exchange turned in a strong performance yesterday as the list advanced steadily throughout the session in active trading.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3 (AP) A leader of an American young people's group touring South Vietnam said today that its members were astounded by the difference between the country's image in the press and the "reality of what we found here."
Of the 13.93 million cases of gin sold in this country last year, 1.43 million were imported, mostly from Eng
Former Mayor Robert F. Wagner endorsed Arthur J. Goldberg for Governor and State Senator Basil A. Paterson for Lieutenant Governor yesterday.

Dr. Joseph Simeon Landa, who retired in 1959 as professor in charge of prosthodontics and cleft-palate rehabilitation at New York University College of Dentistry, died yesterday in Montefiore Hospital, after an illness of five weeks. He was 78 years old and lived at 45 Sutton Place South. His office was at 140 East 54th Street.

Marion Delgado the name chosen by the collective that said it committed the bombing of the Army Mathematics Research Center at the University of Wisconsin is a mythical 5year-old revolutionary boy popularized by the Weatherman faction of Students for a Democratic Society.

It cannot have been easy for Dr. Thomas O. Paine to end his tenure as head of NASA by announcing what amounts to a retreat from the moon well before all hoped-for scientific objectives have been achieved.

Paul D. Weathers, treasurer of Amherst College from 1941 until his retirement in 1964, died yesterday in Jacksonville (Fla.) Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old and since his retirement lived at nearby Ponte Vedra Beach.
Chelsea longshoremen yesterday won the opening skirmish in their fight to prevent the city from turning four idle Hudson River piers into cultural centers.

The Yankee Stadium ground crew received more applause than Horace Clarke last night. But then the crew, in putting the tarpaulin on after the game, covered the infield better than the New York second baseman.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 The National Aeronautics and Space Administration's decision to cancel two more flights to the moon was termed false economy today by three scientists connected with the Apollo program.

Miss Rosanne Novick, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Novick of Clifton, N.J., and Jonathan Cerf, the younger son of Bennett Cerf, the publisher and board chairman of Random House, and Mrs. Cerf, were married on Tuesday at The Columns, the home of the bridegroom's parents in Mount Kisco, N.Y.

BONN, Sept. 3 The view that West German industry is bracing for more lucrative business with the East hardened today as Siemens, the giant electrical company, announced "budding" prospects of a deal with the Soviet Union.

The A.M. Byers Company of Pittsburgh announced yesterday that a plan was under consideration under which the General Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio, would acquire the remaining minority interest in Byers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 The United States appealed to the Soviet Union and the United Arab Republic today to refrain from further violations of the tenuous cease-fire in the Middle East and urged an immediate resumption of the peace talks at the United Nations.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 3 The Cambodian Government moved on several fronts today to document its case against the Communist forces fighting in Cambodia, to underscore its assertions of a neutralist policy and to appeal to world opinion for support.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 (UPI) The State Public Service Commission today blamed the driver, not mechanical failure, for the Aug. 3 bus crash that injured 15 persons in the Westchester County village of Hawthorne.

Bond prices declined rather sharply yesterday as the credit markets paid more attention to this week's buildup in the supply of new issues for sale than to the Commerce Department's report of another downward revision in corporate capital spending plans.

As the New York City Ballet's first summer season at the State Theater draws to a close Sunday, it will have proved again that Violette Verdy is one of New York's most beloved ballerinas. The French-born dancer has needed only to step onstage during the current two-week engagement for the applause to roll in.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) A Federal grand jury has returned two indictments alleging that eight Cleveland area policeman violated the civil rights of a television cameraman and two hospital orderlies in separate incidents.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 3 (AP) Sixty-three Americans were killed in action last week in Vietnam, the United States command announced today, but the total did not include 28 others killed when a helicopter was shot down last Wednesday.

David Sylvan Fine, probably the most militant of the four alleged bombers, was known to his friends as "Buzzy." Now 18 years old, he has said that he has been involved in the radical movement since his early teens.
Stock prices boomed yesterday on sharply higher volume as the trend-setting glamour issues paced the broad advance.

"I have hated you in every hour that has gone by, I hate you so that I would happily give my life for your death, and happily go to my own doom if only I could witness yours, take you with me into the depths. When I let this hate free, I am almost overcome by it, but cannot change this and do not really know it
Two textile industry executives were indicted in the alleged bribery of an Internal Revenue Service agent.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 3 Karleton Lewis Armstrong, one of four young men being sought in connection with the fatal bombing at the University of Wisconsin, was linked by the authorities today to an attempted bombing last Feburary of a power station near Baraboo, Wis.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 3 The Justice Department took action today in Federal court to block a group of white parents in a rural Alabama school district from interfering with court-ordered desegregation there.

The newly organized CARE Women's Committee of Connecticut will sponsor a benefit fashion show and luncheon on Wednesday at the Longshore Club in Westport, Conn. Mrs. J. Donald Kyser is chairman and Mrs. Chester Bowles, wife of the former Ambassador to India, and Mrs. Samar Sen, wife of India's represent ative to the United Nations, are honorary chairmen.

GREAT NECK, L.I, Sept. 3 Miss Judith Elen Bob, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murray M. Bob of St. Albans, queens, was married here this evening at the Town Club to Robert M. Bronstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Bronstein of Merion, Pa. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Eliot Spar.

PENSACOLA, Fla., Sept. 3 (AP) Millions of dead menhaden covered Escambia Bay today as fishermen, their profits dwindling after 52 fish kills in 18 months, demanded an end to industrial pollution in the bay.
Many notables paid tribute yesterday to Vince Lombardi, the pro football coach. Fol lowing are some of the comments:

In the swirling, emotional frenzy that engulfed the Green Bay Packers after their outrageously dramatic victory over the Dallas Cowboys in the final 13 seconds of the 1967 championship playoff, the heroes were interviewed endlessly. No statement struck with more impact than that delivered by Jerry Kramer, whose thunderous block had cleared the path for Bart Starr's winning touchdown.
A West Point senior who had been denied a discharge from the Army as a conscientious objector failed yesterday to get a court order directing the Army to release him, as he wished.

ROSLYN, L.I., Sept. 3 William H. Waiters, who rose from printing apprentice to chief executive officer and chairman of the board of Diamond International Corporation, with annual sales of $500million, died today in St. Francis Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived at 548 Manhasset Woods Road, Manhasset.

GENEVA, Sept. 3 The Soviet Union has informed the World Health Organization that its cholera cases numbered 453. The agency said there were 352 cases in the Astrakhan region, near the Caspian Sea, 63 at Odessa and 38 in Kerch, both on the Black Sea.

LONDON, Sept. 3 (Reuters) The London market price of gold today reached its highest level in nearly a year when speculators from the Middle East and the Far East showed renewed interest in buying the bullion.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, Sept. 4 (AP) Forty disabled South Vietnamese war veterans were barricaded in a Government-owned apartment house today after exchanging gunfire with policemen and soldiers in their campaign for improved benefits from the Government.

LONDON, Friday, Sept. 4 (AP) Soviet aid in the Middle East during the last year has raised the Arab military strength to its highest level since the eve of the war with Israel in June, 1967, the Institute for Strategic Studies said here today.
An experimental group of neutral observers has been organized by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York in an effort to reduce violence at mass demonstrations.
CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (AP) Seven members of the Black P. Stone Nation, a street gang confederation, were indicted today by a Cook County grand jury for the murder Aug. 13 of Detective James A. Alfano.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 The Home Savings and Loan Association, the $3.3-billion institution built by the late Howard Ahmanson, is actively considering becoming a publicly held corporation, according to a report today in The Los Angeles Times. Officials of the company could not be reached for comment.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) Savings bond sales exceeded redemptions by $7-million last month, breaking a string of 20 straight months in which withdrawals topped sales, the Treasury Department reported today.
The Federal Reserve System pressed its policy of monetary expansion during the last two weeks, banking data published yesterday showed.

Dr. Martin Sweig, who was the principal aide of Speaker of the House John W. McCormack until Sweig was charged last year with defrauding the Government; was sentenced yesterday to two and a half years in prison and a $2,000 fine for lying to a grand jury.
A 20-city international tennis series in 1971 with more than $1-million in prize money was announced yesterday by World Championship Tennis of Dallas.
Two dozen physicians who walked off their jobs at Lincoln Hospital on Aug. 25 returned to work yesterday, restoring normal service in the hospital's department of obstetrics and gynecology.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, Sept. 3 (AP) Mrs. Jan O'Malley the defending champion, and her crew from the Mantoloking Yacht Club of New Jersey gained two points today and recaptured the Adams Cup, in the 1970 women's North American sailing championship.

HERON ISLAND, Great Barrier Reef, Australia Australian labor unions have joined with conservationists and other aroused citizens in a campaign to protect the world-renowned Great Barrier Reef from men who drill for oil as well as from hungry coral-eating starfish.
M. K. Argus, a Russian-born writer and journalist, died Monday of lung cancer in his home at 309 East 87th Street. He was 70 years old.

CHERRY HILL, N.J. Sept. 3 (AP) Four young Negroes who had been traveling in a stolen panel truck containing Black Panther party literature were arrested today after a shootout and chase in which a state trooper was slightly wounded.

AREA A Bluefish, weakfish, kingfish and fluke appeared in good supply in the area and crabs were abundant. Dick Meyers at Barnegat, N.J., reported the blues and weaks running well at Harzey Cedar inlet and at the light. Crab catches of two and three bushels were not uncommon. At Brielle, N.J., John Bogan said that excellent catches of bluefish were being made day and night and fishing for school

San Antonio, a city of stark contrasts between air-conditioned affluence and traditionconditioned poverty, is in the grip of the worst diphtheria epidemic in the nation in more than a decade, but few people living there, on either side of the economic tracks, seem to be bothered very much by it all.
The Transport Workers Union demanded yesterday that it be represented on a panel that has been appointed by the Metropolitan Transportation Authoriity to study transit workers' safety records.
The fashions of the seventies are getting some people into hot water.

ALBANY, Sept. 3 The Public Service Commission gave the New York Telephone Company permission today to raise its rates enough to bring in $120.8million in additional revenue a year $16-million more than the commission had said earlier that it would allow the utility.

HANOI, North Vietnam, Sept. 3 (Agence France-Presse) An 11-member delegation from the Black Panthers and the American pacifist movement left here today for Peking and Algeria with 379 letters from United States prisoners of war in North Vietnam.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Sept. 3 Jerry Berger can do about everything expected of a college quarterback, as long as the defensive rush does not consist of extremely tall linemen. The problem is that Berger is only 5-feet-6-inches tall.

CAIRO, Sept. 3 Amid furor in Israel about antiaircraft missiles in the Suez Canal zone and sudden anxiety in Washington about a possible breakdown of its peace initiative, an almost Olympian calm prevails in Cairo.
MANILA. Sept. 3 The United States Government donated $10,000 today to help resettle thousands of slum - dwellers driven from their homes by the three-day floods in Manila and surrounding areas.

LONDON, Sept. 3 A deep mistrust of the British among young blacks here along with an increase in conflict between immigrants and the police was underscored today in studies on racial problems facing Britain.

Manhattan faces the loss of one of its four members of Congress as a result of the new census returns, and the likely solution may be a merger of districts now represented by William F. Ryan and Leonard Farbstein, both Democrats.

Matteo's Indo American Dance Company is a troupe that is Indian in manner and American in its sense of theatrical time. It eschews the longueurs that are the recitative of much Indian dance and concentrates its energies on the more immediately appealing dance passages. Last night, the company appeared for the first time this season at The American Dance Festival in Central Park's Delacorte Theater.

HYANNIS, Mass., Sept. 3 Hugh S. Ferguson, who retired as president of the National Research Corporation of Cambridge in 1965, died here yesterday. He was 69 years old and lived on Main Street in Barnstable.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 3 Arthur J. Goldberg, Democratic-Liberal candidate for Governor, stormed out of the State Fair last night, demanding an apology after being denied use of the main stage at the entrance gates to address the crowd.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) A Federal official who told mine inspectors to check with Washington before shutting down coal mines for uncorrected safety violations acknowledged today that the policy might have encouraged operators to drag their feet on safety, if they had known about it.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The Commerce Department today lifted all restrictions on exporting copper.

Mayor Lindsay urged the Senate yesterday to halt Federal financial support of the supersonic transport (SST) program, calling it a "complete misplacement of national priorities and a disastrous misallocation of national resources."

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Sept. 3 (Reuters) The seventh annual conference of the 41nation Organization of African Unity ended here today with a call to its member states to support the peace bid of Dr. Gunnar V. Jarring, United Nations mediator.
The door chimes rang at Ogilvy Mather yesterday and a pleasant voice was heard to say, "Avon calling."
The London stock market closed ahead yesterday as encouraging corporate reports by leading companies prompted selective buying.

In view of the fortune that Tom Yawkey, the Boston Red Sox owner, is reputed to have paid for players, Reggie Smith is a bargain basment acquisition, who is playing as though he had been labeled with a million-dollar price tag.

EDINBURGH, Scotland, Sept. 1 Britain is fortunate in having many subsidized drama companies, some wellknown some almost unknown, but all of them have a home of their own, a base theater. All of them, that is, except one, for there is the Prospect Theater Company, which is a touring group moving from town to town.
Richard Roud's "chickens" will come to roost in Lincoln Center starting next Thursday, when the Eighth New York Film Festival opens at Philharmonic Hall.
DETROIT, Sept. 3 Two major unions, the Teamsters and the Steelworkers, pledged today a total of $35-million in credits to help build up the strike fund of the United Automobile Workers.
PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 3 Alfred T. Chamie, a Los Angeles lawyer, was elected national commander of the American Legion today in the final session of a four-day convention.

CAPE ST. MARY, Nova Scotia, Sept. 3 (Canadian Press) Premier John Robarts of Ontario landed a 532-pound tuna here today, the second caught during the annual international tuna cup match off the southwest end of Nova Scotia. The Premier hooked the bluefin at 5:30 P.M. and took 2 hours 45 minutes to bring it to gaff.

GENEVA, Sept. 3 The disarmament conference ended its 1970 session today after achieving near unanimity on a draft treaty to prohibit the emplacement of nuclear weapons or launching platforms on the seabed outside the 12-mile limit.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Sept. 3 Austin Straub of the Huntington Country Club and Carl Lohren of North Shore posted par 71's to lead the Long Island qualifying round for the Metropolitan Golf Association open championship at the Glen Head Country Club today.

Mr. and Mrs. Walter J. Fried of New York and East Hampton, L. I., have announced here the engagement of Mrs. Fried's daughter, Miss Ingrid Digby Matsner, to Arthur William Einstein Jr., a partner in the New York advertising firm of Lord, Geller, Federico and Partners.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 3 The rumored revival of the New York Mets suffered a little setback here today when Steve Carlton, an 18-game loser, pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 5-3 victory.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Sept. 31 Miami Beach, which is used to bizarre scenes, had never seen anything quite like it. Eight hundred persons were sprawled out on the floor of the main ballroom of the ornate Deauville Hotel, silently touching each other with their eyes closed.
The Reds, coached by Bernie (Red) Sarachek, defeated the Blues, coached by Lou Carnesecca, 103-89, last night at St. John's in a charity basketball game in which many pro stars competed.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 3 John A. Sexauer, chairman of the board of J.A. Sexauer Manufacturing Company of White Plains, producer of plumbing supplies, died at his home here yesterday after a long illness. He was 89 years old.
PARSIPPANY, N.J., Sept. 3 (AP) "The handle is Hussein and the QTH location is Amman, Jordan," said a voice coming through the loudspeaker of Irving Bersak's ham radio.
GENEVA, Sept. 3 (AP) The World Council of Churches announced today that it would allocate $200,000 to groups that fight racism, including African guerrillas.

Governor Rockefeller called on the Nixon Administration last night to restore the balance of power in the Middle East by supplying Israel immediately with planes and other essential military equipment.

PARIS, Sept. 3 North Vietnam's chief negotiator, Xuan Thuy, ended his nine-month boycott of the Paris peace talks today. But he declared that the United States position had not changed in that time, and he made it plain that the Communist bargaining position had not changed either.
WARSAW, Sept. 3 (AP) John Smith of Los Angeles and Jay Silvester of Spanish Fork, Utah, won the 400-meter run and the discus throw, respectively, at a track and field meet today.

Early in the summer, when brokerage firms seemed to be toppling almost daily, a raft of rumors circulated about Hayden, Stone, Inc., one of Wall Street's most troubled big houses. Some of the scuttlebutt came true, but most of it was not dignified with a response.

A Madison Avenue gallery demanded yesterday that the Police department property clerk give up "valuable works of art" used as evidence in the prosecution of David Stein, art forger, more than four years ago.

SAN JOSE, Calif., Sept. 3 (AP) Bombs went off within an hour of each other last night and early today at the Ford plant at Milpitas near here and at the General Motors plant at Fremont six miles away.

ANDERSON, Ind., Aug. 30 To an outlander, East Central, Indiana looks deceptively rural and Republican. The counties clustered near the Ohio border are flat, sparsely populated and awash with corn fields, their somnolent little farm towns seemingly little changed from the days of James Whitcomb Riley.

EAST LOS ANGELES, Calif., Sept. 3 Earlier this week, hundreds of Mexican-American youths jammed into a sweltering news conference where community leaders were commenting on the riot that rocked East Los Angeles last Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 3 Bobby Riggs, the defending titleholder from Plandome, L.I., and Torsten Johansson of Sweden reached the semifinal round of the 52d United States senior grass court tennis championship today at the Germantown Cricket Club. They will meet Saturday.
Students at the College for Human Services voted yesterday to end their three-week-old strike and return to classes next Tuesday.
The radically inconsistent offenses of the Giants and Jets were on the teams' minds yesterday as they went through final drills for the contests tomorrow.

ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 3 (AP) Criminal proceedings in the aftermath of Cornell University's racial turmoil of April, 1969, came to an end today with the unconditional release of the last three defendants charged after the incident.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 3 The children of welfare families living in barracks buildings at the former Mitchel Air Force Base were ordered admitted to the local public schools today by a State Supreme Court justice.
ATLANTA, Sept. 3 An international Congress of African People opened here today with hundreds of black delegates, mostly young, conterging on the five college campuses of Atlanta University.
SYDNEY, Australia, Sept. 3 The Australian Government announced today that it had changed its policy and would now provide arms for Cambodia, "if necessary."
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 3 Chile votes for a President tomorrow in an election dramatic in uncertainty over who will win and in the danger of violence after the results are known.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 3 Premier Golda Meir today welcomed Washington's acknowledgment of an Egyptian missile build-up in violation of the three-week-old Middle East cease-fire. But she pressed for further United States action to demand that the Soviet Union act to cancel Egypt's new military gains.

CHICAGO, Sept. 3 (UPI) Jim Hickman batted in four runs with a three-run homer and a single today while his Chicago teammate, Billy Williams, was ending a string of 1,117 consecutive games played as the Cubs stopped the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-2, behind the four-hit pitching of Ferguson Jenkins.

The engagement of Miss Frances Lauren Hesterberg to James Hall McDonald, son of Mr. and Mrs. James McDonald of Brooklyn, has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Alexander G. Hesterberg of Brooklyn and Quogue, L.I. A November wedding is planned.

The standstill cease-fire proposal for Vietnam urged on President Nixon by fourteen Senators including prominent "hawks" and "doves" of both parties is far more than a scheme for a military truce. Its importance lies precisely in that it addresses the central issue in the war and in the Paris negotiations, the political issue of who is to govern South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (UPI) The Securities and Exchange Commission has suspended the Miami Beach branch office of H. Hentz Co., a New York broker-dealer, from trading on the over-the-counter market for 30 days beginning Tuesday.
The Union Carbide Corporation indicated yesterday that it would refuse after Oct. 1 to offer discounts from its published prices on the ethanolamine group of industrial chemicals.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 3 King Hussein of Jordan, in a radio speech tonight, appealed for peace between his troops and the Arab commandos here.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 3 (AP) Tom Kite Jr., a 20-yearold University of Texas golfer, took the lead at the halfway point of the 70th United States Amateur golf championship today with a three-under-par 67 that put him three strokes ahead of Steve Melnyk and Gary Cowan.

As widespread sick calls by correction officers at the Rikers Island Reformatory continued for the second day yesterday and spread to the Women's House of Detention, George F. McGrath, the city's Commissioner of Corrections, announced he was withholding the paychecks of the absent workers pending investigation of their professed ailments.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) A labor leader warned today that union construction workers faced rising job losses if they did not give a full day's work for their pay, live up to their contracts and stop "devastating" jurisdictional strikes.

PARIS, Sept. 3 General of the Army Pierre Koenig, one of France's most prestigious military leaders in World War II and a leading champion of French-Israeli friendship, died last night at the American Hospital of Paris in suburban Neuilly, following surgery. He was 71 years old.
Vince Lombardi, the professional football coach who symbolized toughness and dedication in sports, died of intestinal cancer yesterday in Georgetown Hosiptal in Washington. His age was 57.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 3 (UPI) A 16-year-old boy who was arrested last weekend for an assault on a 13-year-old girl, was charged today with murder in the stabbing last February of the teen-age daughter of a Stamford policeman.

New York City's first large regional shopping center opens a week from today in the Mill Basin section of Brooklyn, with big new units of Macy's and Alexander's that look surprisingly similar in appearance.
ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 3 (AP) Six men and a woman were arrested in a hotel here today and charged with possession of a bomb and other offenses.
Robbers escaped with a total of $13,800 yesterday in four apparently unrelated bank and loan association holdups here two in Manhattan and one each in Brooklyn and Queens, according to the police.

A sharp increase in wheat exports sent the futures of this grain up 3 cents a bushel in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange yesterday but profit taking trimmed the advances late in the session.

YONKERS, Sept. 3 Thomas J. Maccabe Sr., who retired in 1946 after 35 years as an actuary with the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, died today in Yonkers Professional Hospital. He was 91 years old and lived at 127 Morsemere Avenue.
The RCA Corporation unveiled yesterday a new and larger time-sharing system for users of computers.

The New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange announced yesterday that they planned to include approximately 850 Amex stocks in the Big Board's Central Certificate Service beginning in November.

"Strikes of public employes can be legislated against but not prevented. When public employes consider their conditions insufferable and a strike the only instrument of action available, they will avail themselves of it."

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 3 The United States delegate, Charles W. Yost, discussed the apparent impasse in Middle East peace talks in hurried calls today on Secretary General Thant and the United Arab Republic delegate Dr. Mohammed H. el-Zayyat.

ONTARIO, Calif., Sept. 3 Thirty-two cars of the 33-car starting field ran through 2 hours of warm-up and practice today, setting the stage for the California 500, the opening event of the Ontario Motor Speedway, 40 miles east of Los Angeles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 For six weeks, Senate critics of military spending tried to hack away at the Pentagon budget. They got nowhere: their challenge to the Safeguard antimissile system, their proposal to restrict payments on the C-5A cargo jet and their move to cut $5-billion from defense outlays
FRANKFURT, West Germany, Sept. 3 (Reuters) The Central Bank said today that West Germany's total monetary reserves rose in the week ended Aug. 31 by 105-million marks to 39.088-billion marks.

No City Controller, Budget Director or Finance Administrator ever had a more detailed understanding of New York City's fiscal problems than Paul Crowell. In the three decades he spent at City Hall as a correspondent for this newspaper, he anticipated the computerized miracles of data storage and retrieval by squirreling away in his own head limitless information about every aspect of municipal affairs.
PARIS, Sept. 3 The Government began today what promises to be a long, and tough struggle to get Frenchmen to stop cheating on their income taxes.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 3 A Los Angeles policeman testified today at the murder trial of Charles M. Manson that the fingerprints of two suspects in the case were found at the home of Sharon Tate, the slain actress.
The city is requesting free time from three major television stations here to rebut commercials asserting that new gasolines are helping to reduce air pollution.
George R. Katz, a leading newspaper representative for 70 years, died Wednesday at his home, 784 Park Avenue. He was 97 years old.
The nation's large chainstore operators achieved gains in sales volume last month and, in most instances, their performance was better than in the preceding month.

FARGO, N.D., Sept. 3 (AP) Richard Elkin, running with his Republican party's endorsement, held an 80-vote margin over Robert P. McCarney today with all precincts reporting in the primary election for North Dakota's western district seat in the United States House of Representatives.
Just before the Labor Day weekend two years ago William J. Casey became president of the newly formed Klemtner Casey ad agency. Yesterday the agency announced that he'd quit.
SUMMERTON, S.C., Sept. 3 It was late in the afternoon and in the classroom at the end of the long, dark hallway, Ruth Richardson was busy scrubbing the desks.

LONDON, Sept. 4 (Reuters)I Cuba has more combat planes than any other country in Latin America and her armed forces are outnumbered only by those of Brazil and Argentina, the Institute of Strategic Studies said today.

To those who knew them at the University of Wisconsin, Karleton Lewis Armstrong, 22 years old, and his brother, Dwight Alan Armstrong, 19, had little in common except a sense of restlessness and a penchant for radical rhetoric.

Joan Kennedy, the wife of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, will make her debut as piano soloist with a symphony orchestra at the Philadelphia Academy of Music on Oct. 13. She will take part in a fundraising concert presented by the Arts Committee for Milton Shapp and Ernest Kline, Democratic candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor of Pennsylvania.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 (AP) The Internal Revenue Service said today that it would "take a hard look" at the tax-exempt foundation set up by Jerry Rubin, the Yippie leader.

For years, fishermen have caught flounders, snappers and eels off the sandy shores of Marine Park, in the southern part of Brooklyn. Lately their fishing lines have hooked into a new kind of catch rusted baby carriages, shopping carts and the stripped, mossy hulks of abandoned automobiles.

The Insurance Information Institute reported yesterday that in June, for the first time in 1970, the nation's entire traffic experience deaths, accidents, injuries and total economic loss had shown an improvement.

Imperial Chemical Industries, Ltd., one of Britain's largest industrial complexes, reported yesterday that earnings in the first half of 1970 fell to $184.5-million from $218.4-million in the year-earlier period. The company blamed higher costs for the profit decline.
DANANG, South Vietnam, Sept. 3 (AP) A United States Marine lieutenant from Los Gatos, Calif., was acquitted today of a charge of having negligently killed a Vietnamese woman with a sniper rifle.

AMMANFORD, Wales Under a vast, hot tin roof, 8,000 people acclaimed the winner of, the National Eisteddfod of Wales crown competition. Bryan Davies, a 37-year-old schoolteacher from Ruabon, Denighshire Wales won the honor with 10 poems about people and places in the Amman valley.

ST. CATHARINES, Ontario, Sept. 3 The United States crews staged a sharp recovery today at the world rowing championships held on the Royal Canadian Henley course here. Five of the six American boats in competition today qualified for further action, four of them for semifinal races on Saturday and one for the finals on Sunday.
Impasse contributed a fine exhibition of courage in rallying at the close to win the 1 1-6-mile turf race that featured the program at Belmont Park yesterday.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 3 For years, the prim, exclusive Union League was a mainstay of elite society in New Haven. It attracted men of wealth and prestige from the most proper New England stock.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Sept. 3 Kentucky said today that it expected to get more than $1.5-million in Federal research grants for the first attempts to improve the landscape-damaging methods of strap mining for coal.

Pan American World Airways, Inc., is planning an offering next month of $81,550,000 of 16-year guaranteed loan certificates to help it finance five. Boeing 747 jetliners it is operating under lease. The certificates will be sold by an underwriting group headed by Lehman Brothers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3 Assets of overseas branches of United States banks surged by 79 per cent to $41.1-billion last year, with the biggest increase coming in London branches, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
The Knickerbocker Championships, the traditional Labor Day weekend tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association, begins today at the New York Hilton.

Senator Charles E. Goodell declared here yesterday that the machinery of criminal justice had broken down in the city and that the so-called Federal Safe Streets Act had not fulfilled its purpose.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 3 Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Gane have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jonna Gane, to Fred Lazarus 4th, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lazarus 3d of Cincinnati.

YONKERS, Sept. 3 Seven pacers will go postward tomorrow night in a $25,000 invitation, with Rum Customer the 5-2 favorite. Billy Haughton will drive the 5-year-old, owned by Louis and Connie Mancuso, and will leave from the No. 5 slot.

CHESTNUT HILL, Mass., Sept. 3 Depth on both offense and defense, powerful running backs, a corps of talented receivers and the best quarterback in the East in Frank (Red) Harris give Boston College the potential for its best football campaign in recent seasons.
The American Stock Exchange halted trading yesterday in the shares of Unexcelled, Inc., a maker of meatpacking machinery and operator of discount stores.

Leo Frederick Burt, 6 feet 4 inches tall and weighing 185 pounds, was No. 4 oar on the University of Wisconsin junior varsity crew. And when he wasn't rowing, he was writing about his favorite sport for The Daily Cardinal, the University of Wisconsin's student newspaper.
Luther P. Gales, who lost his job as a Housing Authority policeman last April 18 because he wore a beard, filed suit yesterday for reinstatement and back pay.

CORONADO, Calif., Sept. 3 President Nixon today welcomed the Mexican President, Gustavo Diaz Ordaz, to what was once a fertile part of Mexico and is now fertile political country for California Republicans.
A former Supreme Court justice of Peru was indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn on charges of smuggling diamonds worth $750,000 into the United States from Israel.
A suicide in Paris was frustrated by a complex trans-Atlantic rescue effort involving a New York City patrolman, an overseas telephone operator and the Paris police.

New York University's president, Dr. James M. Hester, issued a strong warning yesterday to faculty and staff members and students that the university would not tolerate efforts by extremists to "politicize" the school during its coming academic year.

STAMFORD, Conn., Sept. 4 Hair-raising downwind starts in a southwester of 25 knots and better sent 98 yachts on their way today under twisting, writhing, hard-to-handle spinnakers in the Stamford Yacht Club's 36th annual Vineyard Trophy Race.
The Internal Revenue Service plans to set up a data-processing center on facilities leased from the Town of Brookhaven on Long Island, and expects to hire 4,000 people to staff it.
NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 4 It is true, as the dispatches from down here have been saying for several days, that more Southern children than ever before are going to desegregated schools this fall.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Treasury bill rates advanced at today's auction from last week's levels, the Government reported late this afternoon.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Sept. 4 Mr. and Mrs. James A. McKenna have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Monica Patricia McKenna, to Robert Laydon Schoelle Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Schoelle of Rockville Centre. Miss McKenna's father is former Mayor of Garden City.

LONDON, Sept. 4 A series of head-on collisions during the last three weeks that killed at least 15 persons has prompted the British Government to cut short an old controversy and decide in favor of central crash barriers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 4 (UPI) South Vietnam's top policeman warned disabled veterans in a tough 10-minute television speech tonight that they could be killed or sentenced to death if they continued to "attack, resist or interfere with" the police or the military.

Black Watch Farms, Inc., Fiskill Plains, New York, yesterday filed a petition in Federal Court for an arrangement under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act, the action aimed at permitting the company to establish a means of paying its protection.

A sizable number of women are coming here from out of town to get abortions under the state abortion reform law that went into effect July 1, according to statistics made public yesterday by the city.
Andrew J. Steiger, author and former Moscow correspondent, died Thursday in St. Luke's Hospital after a long illness. He was 70 years old and lived at 45 West 81st Street.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The United States Navy has applied for Chilean visas for 87 officers noncommissioned officers and civilian employes over the las eight months, a development that has left the Chilean Government deeply worried.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The final version of the August wholesale price index showed a slightly smaller decline than the preliminary figures, the Labor Department reported today.
The American Stock Exchange ended the week in a bulish manner yesterday as the list advanced in active trading.
Sniper shots were fired at the police and four patrolmen were injured by bricks and flying bottles in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn early today.

The city will go into State Supreme Court on Sept. 15 in an effort to obtain as eviction date for 135 families in the Corona section of Queens upon whose property it plans to build a high school and athletic field.

The Knickerbocker Championships of the Greater New York Bridge Association continue today at the New York Hilton with attention focused on the Open Pair Championship scheduled at 1:30 P.M. and 7:30 P.M.
CHICAGO, Sept. 4 (AP) Chuck Tanner, the manager of the Hawaii Islanders of the Pacific Coast League, was named manager today of the Chicago White Sox.

LITTLE FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 4 For about an hour yesterday afternoon the police in this Mohawk Valley community had in their custody two of the four young men sought in the bombing of the Army Mathematics Research Center on the University of Wisconsin campus on Aug. 24.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4. The Interior Department will soon begin using picture symbols instead of words on signs in National Park Service areas.

ROME, Sept. 4 An Italian production of the American musical "Hair," opened here last night to benign yawns from the critics and indifferent applause from an audience more interested in itself than in the play.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Stewart L. Udall, former Secretary of the Interior, said today that he had been cleared by the Justice Department of conflict of interest and charged that the investigation had been instigated by the present Secretary, Walter J. Hickel in a deliberate attempt to destroy his reputation.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 4 An 11-year-old boy testified today at the trial of Charles M. Manson that he had to call the police last December to tell them that they were apparently in possession of an alleged murder gun for three and a half months while they made an international search for it.

Three hours after James L. Buckley's campaign manager declared that the Conservative candidate for the United States Senate hoped to raise up to $1.5-million for his campaign, Mr. Buckley's running mate for Governor, Paul L. Adams, arrived here quietly and said he would be happy to get $100,000 for his campaign.

PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 4 (AP) Tom Kite Jr. shot a oneover-par 71 today after hitting a spectator on the head with his second shot of the day and held firmly to the lead after three rounds of the 70th United States Amateur golf championship.

Mrs. Jean Belden Randolph widow of John Randolph, for mer picture editor and outdoor columnist of The New York Times, died of a massive heart attack Thursday evening in Shutesbury, Mass. She was 59 years old.

Mitchell to all Federal

In an attempt to get the deadlocked talks on a new consolidated passenger steamship terminal on the Upper West Side moving, the city said yesterday that it had invited the longshoremen's union to join the negotiations between ship lines and the Port of New York Authority.

Cary E. Donham, the West Point senior who lost a court battle Thursday to make the Army release him as a consoientious objector, will resign from the United States Military Academy, his lawyer said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The United States, in a major policy innovation, is prepared to abandon the 11-year-old requirement that all its foreign aid be spent on American goods.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The United States is investigating the transfer of 800 textbooks by the Jackson, Miss., public school system to a new "segregation academy" as a possible violation of the new emergency desegregation assistance act. The Jackson system was the first to receive Federal funds under the act.

An official of the electric power industry called yesterday for a lifting of import restrictions on fuel oil as part of measures to relieve the shortage of fuels being felt by utility companies, particularly in Eastern states.

NEW ORLEANS. Sept. 4 Three players will be under Weeb Ewbank's microscope when the New York Jets try to stabilize their squad for the approaching National Football League season in tomorrow night's exhibition game with the New Orleans Saints.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Army dismissed a murder charge today against a 23-yearold corporal accused in the alleged massacre of South Vietnamese at Songmy village on grounds of "insufficient evidence."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (UPI) The South Vietnamese Embassy is understood to have advised Saigon that a visit to Washington next month by Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky to address a "march-for-victory" rally would not be wise.

There were sentimental cheers for Pancho Gonzales when he survived "sudden death" and advanced in the United States Open tennis championships yesterday at Forest Hills, Queens. But the standing ovation in the stadium this time was reserved for a winning doubles team.

The Department of Correction reported yesterday that work attendance by correction officers at the city reformatory at Rikers Island and at the Women's House of Detention in Greenwich Village had returned to normal.

The 78th Washington Square Outdoor Art Exhibit opened yesterday and will continue daily from noon till sundown, weather permitting, through Sunday, Sept. 20.
CORONADO, Calif., Sept. 4 (AP) President Gustavo Dfaz Ordaz of Mexico has sounded a warning that United States restrictions on international trade may imperil the economy of Latin America.

The Regional Plan Association said yesterday that it believed New York City had been "undercounted" by perhaps 200,000 people in the preliminary census returns.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Saturday, Sept. 5 Two candidates of the right and the extreme left battled for the lead in returns from Chile's presidential election early today. Radomiro Tomic Romero, the candidate of the governing Christian Democratic party, conceded defeat late last night.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Sept. 4 The Jersey Jays, newcomers to the Atlantic Coast Football League, made a successful debut at Hofstra Stadium tonight by defeating the Long Island Bulls, 22-21, in the season opener for both teams.

DETROIT, Sept. 4 (AP) Automobile production in the United States this week rose to 136,882 units, up from 112,361 last week and 133,627 in the corresponding week of 1969, Automotive News reported today.

Although Taplinger is performing a public service in making available Ernest Newman's 35-year-old study of Franz Liszt, that fact will not make the book any more palatable. Just when New Yorkers were taking comfort from the census disclosure that this city had held its own in population in the last decade, Pan American World Airways comes along with the jolting news that it is considering a move of its administrative operations from mid-Manhattan into the suburbs.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 3 Two Iraqi leaders paid a quiet visit to Jordan yesterday to strengthen the politically important alliance between the Arab guerrillas and the Iraqi troops here, the Baghdad radio reported.

Felipe Luciano, who led an 11-day occupation of an East Harlem church last January, has been ousted as National chairman of the Young Lords, a militant Puerto Rican organization, the group's central committee announced yesterday.

GENEVA, Sept. 4 Investors Overseas Services signed a $15-million loan agreement today with a subsidiary of the International Controls Corporation. This provides that the subsidiary, I.C.C. Investments, Ltd., will have two seats on the 27-member I.O.S. board and two seats instead of the one originally envisaged on its powerful executive committee.

The State Department's official confirmation of major Egyptian truce violations, presumably made with Soviet acquiescence, has implications that extend beyond the Mideast crisis into the whole question of world security.

The Eastern and Western railroads of the country were told by the Interstate Commerce Commission in Washington yesterday that it would not allow them to raise their freight rates again without an investigation.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sept. 4 The Minister of Immigration has set off a controversy here by suggesting that certain Americans might not be racially acceptable under New Zealand's program of subsidized immigration.
DENVER, Sept. 4 (AP) At-torneys for two men wanted in Connecticut on charges of murder and kidnapping appealed to the United States District Court here today to prevent their extradiion.

J. W. Mays, Inc., a Brooklynbased department-store chain, will report record earnings and a 9 per cent gain in sales to $165.9-million for the fiscal year ended July 31, Max L. Shulman, chairman and president, told the New York Society of Security Analysts yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 Ralph Nader accused the General Motors Corporation today of suppressing proof developed by its own engineers that early models of the Chevrolet Corvair ware unsafe.
ORANGE, N. J., Sept. 4 (AP) -For the first time in 80 years, the all-girl Beard School will have a man in charge.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4 The Soviet Union, affirming its desire for a political settlement in the Middle East, has informed the United States that it will study Washington's charges that the United Arab Republic violated the Middle East cease-fire agreement by moving new Soviet missiles into place near the Suez Canal.
WASHINGTON "Tell me, do all your guests arrive by Greyhound bus?" a neighbor recently asked Mrs. John Sherman Cooper, wife of the Kentucky Senator.
TEL AVIV, Sept. 4 (Reuters) Israeli Air Force planes attacked Arab guerrilla targets today in southern Lebanon, an Army spokesman said here.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to limit employers' use of aptitude tests and educational requirements that have the effect of retarding Negroes' employment opportunities.

ATLANTA, Sept: 4 More than 1,700 delegates to the International Congress of African People here were urged to create a World African party. The proposal, on the second day of the four-day parley. was made by Imamu Baraka, the poetplaywright; widely kown as Leroi Jones.
BOSTON, Sept. 5 It is difficult to believe that Larry Naviaux and his Boston University football squad can equal last year's 9-1 regular-season wonlost record, the finest in the Terriers' history.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 4 A Federal district judge told nine white parents today to stop interfering with the operation of newly desegregated public schools in a rural Alabama county.

LONDON, Sept. 4 The 5,000 workers of a key auto parts plant, G.K.N. Sankey in Wellington, Shropshire, voted today to continue a month-old wildcat, strike that has made idle more than 20,000 in car, truck and tractor factories throughout Britain.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 The United States said today that in its current discussions with the United Arab Republic it was seeking "rectification" of the situation arising from violations of the Egyptian-Israeli ceasefire.

The acceleration of biological engineering has been urged before Congress by Nobel Laureate Dr. Joshua Lederberg. He has called for the establishment of a National Genetics Task Force to increase the momentum of efforts aimed at unlocking the genetic code of man. Such a breakthrough in biology could lead to the prevention of many illnesses whose origin is wholly or partially in the genetic code.

YONKERS, Sept. 4 Contrary to the talk in the paddock at Yonkers Raceway, Fresh Yankeee, the American-bred, Canadian-owned 7-year-old trotting mare, will participate here in the $50,000 Gotham Trot next Friday night and in the $50,000 United Nations Trot on Sept. 18.
SAN GWANN, Malta This tradition-bound Mediterranean island, long a citadel of feudal knights, has turned with Mediterranean gusto to the manufacturing of American-style dungarees.
Robert D. Sterling, a former real estate operator and financier, died Thursday in Lenox Hill Hospital, after a long illness. He was 85 years old and lived at 19 East 77th Street.

JOHANNESBURG, South Afca, Sept. 4 Churchmen and politicians, including many critics of the Government here have expressed alarm and anger at the World Council of Churches' plan to give $200,000 in financial aid to guerrilla organizations and antiapartheid groups working against white governments in southern Africa.

BARNSTABLE, Mass., Sept. 4. Robert W. Powers, president of John O. Powers Company, an advertising agency at 116 John Street, New York, died today at the Barnstable County Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived at 35-16 79th Street, Jackson Heights, Queens, New York.
Contrary to the usual preholiday type of activity, trading was mixed and active yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade.

The Socialist Workers party criticized City Council President Sanford D. Garelik yesterday for his statement Monday that "Trotskyites and Maoists" shared the responsibility for recent attacks on policemen.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 In an inventory system being patented by Luther G. Simjian of Greenwich, Conn., a central computer will keep track of many different items in many stores or warehouses. The computer records show how much is still on the shelves and reminds the management when it is time to reorder.

With Consolidated Edison's generating capacity taxed by air-conditioners in hot, humid weather, the utility cut voltage by 5 per cent in the city and Westchester County yesterday and appealed to customers to trim electric usage.

BRONXVILLE, N. Y., Sept. 4 George A. Guerdan, who started out as a mail clerk and subsequently became an officer of the First National City Bank of New York, died today at his home here at 2 Brassie Lane. He was 72 years old today.
The new-issue market staged a strong rebound this week from the depressed levels that have prevailed during the last few months.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 4 (AP) A Circuit Court judge in Anne Arundel County yesterday overturned a law requiring all students and teachers in Maryland public schools to begin each day with a Pledge of Allegiance to the United States flag.

In Atlanta this week for Muhammad Ali's return to the ring, several Northerners expressed surprise at what they considered a paradox: local newspapers expressing pride over Georgia's national leadership in welcoming Ali also carried advertisements for tonight's Ku Klux Klan rally at Stone Mountain, a family festival promising a "cross lighting" and urging all comers to "bring robes." If Ali, a Louisville native, found surprises, he was covering nicely.
PRINCETON, N. J., Sept. 4 The Giants did a little housecleaning today not the kind that a shaky football team makes but rather the kind a team makes when it breaks Camp.

WETHERSFIELD, Conn. Sept. 4 As Pete Brown finished in a four-way tie for the lead in the $100,000 Greater Hartford open golf tournament today, the scorer's tent, the clubhouse and the press tent had been evacuated because of a bomb scare.

LONDON, Sept. 4 Natalya Makarova, a leading ballerina of the Leningrad Kirov Ballet, sought and obtained political asylum in Britain tonight. She defected to the West at the end of a six-week season at the Royal Festival Hall here.

TURIN, Italy, Sept. 4 (AP) Tom Ulan of Rutgers University gained the United States' 20th gold medal today in the sixth World University games by winning the 400-meter run in 45.9 seconds for a games record.

Carl McIntire's "March for Victory" in Washington. But that does not keep the projected visit of South Vietnam's Number Two from being objectionable on grounds of taste, propriety and judgment.
SHREVEPORT, La., Sept. 4 (UPI) Terry Bradshaw and the Pittsburgh Steelers continued to demolish the opposition, beating the Boston Patriots, 31-3, tonight.
ANKARA, Turkey, Sept. 4 (AP) Fifteen persons were killed when two buses collided in a dusk cloud raised by an accident involving two trucks on a highway near Istanbul, the police reported today.

Tickets will go on sale tomorrow at noon at the Metropolitan Opera box office for the first two weeks of the company's new season, which begins Sept. 14. A revival of Verdi's "Ernani," absent from the repertory for six years, will be the opening-night opera.

SYRACUSE, Sept.4 Senator Charles E. Goodell vigorously defended his credentials as a Republican during n visit today to this city, where many of his fellow Republicans oppose his bid to return to the Senate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 4 (AP) Thirteen Back Panthers appealed today to Supreme Court Justice John M.. Harlan to remove John M. Murtagh as the judge who is to preside at their trial in New York on charges of conspiring to blow up department stores, police and subway stations and the Bronx Zoo.

Taking note of the shortage of blood available for transfusions in hospitals here, City Council leaders announced yesterday that the Council would sponsor a "Blood Donor Day" at City Hall on Thursday.

MOSCOW, Sept. 4. The Soviet Union announced today that it had found an experimental capsule from the United States Apollo space program and would turn it over to a United States Coast Guard cutter in the northern port of Murmansk tomorrow.
Gas Mask, a jazz-rock ensemble with above-average abilities, is playing through tonigh at the Village Gate, 160 Bleecker Street.
ALBANY, Sept 4 Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo today ruled the newly formed Conservation party and the Right to Life party off the November ballot.

PARIS, Sept. 4 France celebrated with a touch of pomp but no joy today the centennial of the Third Republic a state that, as many commentators recalled, was born in one debacle, died in another, and suffered from its one great military victory.
BOSTON, Sept. 5 New England's six states vary widely in the growth of mobile homes to relieve housing shortages resulting from high land and mortgage costs and rising apartment rental rates.

HOUSE plants that spent the summer outdoors should be moved indoors before Sept. 15th. Cool night temperatures produce a chemical change in plant cells that may inhibit plant growth. Also, house plants have to readjust to the house environment before the central heating is turned on.

CHERRY HILL, N.J., Sept. 5 Mr. and Mrs. David Ward Bamford have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Ann Bamford, to Robert Murray Lynyak, son of Mrs. Robert M. Lynyak of Ridgewood and the late Mr. Lynyak.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 5 (AP) The Cragwood Stable's Red Reality, coupled with Mr. Leader in the wagering, made a late charge to win the $41,450 Kelly-Olympic Handicap at Atlantic City Race Course today.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 5 The Conservative party's candidates for Governor and Lieutenant Governor officially opened their campaign today with a motorcade through western Suffolk County and a tour of Nassau County's shopping centers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 5 They are as different as two men can be, Jim Hickman and Joe Pepitone. SOUTHPORT, Me., Sept. 5 Miss Robin Dennison Frederick, a 1970 graduate of Vassar College, was married this afternoon to George Robinson (Robbie) Whitten, a senior at Middlebury College. The Rev. Samuel G. Henderson Jr. performed the ceremony in All Saints-by-theSea, Episcopal summer chapel here.
Howard Regis Leary served as Police Commissioner of New York City during one of the most turbulent periods in its history.

ENTERPRISE, Ala., Sept. 5 Mayor Kenneth A. Gibson of Newark "came home" today to receive something of a celebrity's welcome in this small southeast Alabama community that he left 40 years ago as just another black boy among the thousands searching for a better life in the North.
AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 5 The harried Jordanian Government, bowing to Arab guerrilla demands, announced today that it had ordered the "pulling back of military units around the capital."

CAMDEN, S.C. Sept. 5 (AP) An Irish-based jumper and a champion Australian steeplechases head a list of 10 foreign-owned horses invited to participate in the $100,000 Colonial Cup Nov. 14, the richest steeplechase ever run in the United States.
MILWAUKEE, Sept. 5 A group of conservationists in northern Wisconsin is organizing for a battle next year that may have national implications in the control of public utilities.

COLOGNE, West Germany, Steamboat Bill and the speedy "Robert E. Lee" are just misty memories on the Mississippi where the passenger ship has all but disappeared, but here on the Rhine they seem to be reincarnated, updated and multiplied.
SAN DIEGO, Sept. 5 (AP) The state of California has filed suit against the Navy, contending its ships polluted the Los Angeles, Long Beach and San Diego harbors.

U. Utah Phillips, folk singer and political organizer, is making his New York concert debut through tonight at the Gaslight Cafe, 116 Macdougal Street.

Wall Street moves north today to Croton Point Park, Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y. However, the rings will not be filled with bulls and bears but with 2,514 dogs striving for the title of best in show at the Westchester Kennel Club's 53d annual event.
KIEL, Germany, Sept. 5 (AP) Lowell North and John Dane 3d of the United States finished second in their respective classes as the German sailing championships ended today.

WASHINGTON In that quieter time not so many months ago when young rebels confronted the system with taunts rather than demonstrations, a group boarded a sightseeing bus for an unusual tour. Out, out they went until they reached their goal the suburbs. With mock incredulity, they marveled at the alien quietude, snapped tourist photos of men mowing lawns, and then hurried home to the city where, they said, the action was.

A majority of issues on the American Stock Exchange and on the over-the-counter market advanced last week in moderate trading.

WINNETKA, Ill., Sept. 5 Miss Laura Jenkins Snyder, a 1970 graduate of Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., was married today to Stephen Hunter Morris, a 1970 graduate of Yale. The ceremony was performed in the Winnetka Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Edgar G. Prasse.

NEW PALTZ, N.Y., Sept. 5 Usually, when someone has been away from his trade as long as Floyd Patterson, he is brought back with a flourish and the advance billing always includes the word "new." DETROIT, Sept. 5 Leonard Woodcock, the president of the United Automobile Workers, presented the Chrysler Corporation and the General Motors Corporation today with specific wage and pension demands.

WASHINGTON In 1967 and 1968, the nation was shocked by riots that occurred in large cities. Shock has given way to a deep malaise that goes with day-by-day violence and mounting assaults against authority.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (AP) A former top lobbyist for private shipping concerns getting $200-million a year in Federal aid has become a key staff member of the House committee that approves the subsidy programs.

Following is a list of the passengers aboard Trans World Airlines Flight 741 when it was hijacked to Jordan Sunday. The names of passengers on another plane hijacked to Jordan, a Swissair jet were not available. According to reports from Jordan, about 80 women, children and old people have been freed and some male passengers will be released later. Their names were not disclosed.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7 (UPI) Vida Blue hit a three-run homer in the first game and Joe Rudi and Sal Bando each drove in three runs in the second game today as the Oakland Athletics beat the Chicago White Sox, 7-4 and 7-5.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 (AP) A bases-loaded triple by Larry Brown and Vada Pinson's threerun homer powered the Cleveland Indians to an 8-2 victory over Boston in the second game of a double-header today after the Red Sox won the opener, 4-3.

One day last week, the fall Chinook salmon began to flow out of the Columbia River into the Willamette, swimming 25 miles through a highly developed port-industrial complex at Portland Harbor reach, struggling up a man-made fishway over the 50-foot falls at Oregon City, and finally fighting their way to the upstream headwaters where they will spawn.

Arab commandos held as hostages in the Jordanian desert yesterday at least 150 of the passengers aboard two of the four New York-bound jetliners they hijacked Sunday. As ransom, the commandos demanded the release of Arab guerrillas held prisoner in Israel, Britain, Switzerland and West Germany.

SEARINGTOWN, L.I., Sept. 7 Miss Shelley Lynn Guterman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Reuben Guterman of East Meadow, was married here today to Asadur Azapian, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ohanes Elmassian Azapian of Montevideo, Uruguay.

KANSAS CITY, Sept. 7 (AP) Bob Johnson checked California on three hits and 10 strike-outs and stroked a tworun single tonight as the Kansas City Royals dealt the Angels' flag hopes another blow with a 4-1 victory. WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 (UPI) Mrs. John N. Mitchell, who first denounced Senator J.W. Fulbright for his opposition to a Supreme Court nominee, G. Harrold Carswell criticized him again today for his opposition to the Vietnam war.

Moody's Capital Fund, Inc., has adjoined until Sept. 22 its stockholders' meeting, originally called on Aug. 25 to approve a transfer of management and distribution of the fund to Vance, Sanders Co., of Boston. The present manager is a subsidiary of Moody's Investors Service, Inc., which itself is a subsidiary of Dun Bradstreet, Inc. The postponement is the second for the meeting.
In a memorable funeral for a sports personality, Vince Lombardi was eulogized for his "dynamic Christian spirit" by Cardinal Cooke yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral.

GENEVA, Sept. 7 The 19 mutual funds administered by Investors Overseas Services had a net negative cash flow in August of $35.9-million bringing the total outflow for 1970 to nearly $100-million, I.O.S. reported today.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 7 The Pittsburgh Pirates and Chicago Cubs exchanged artillery barrages at an unusually early hour today, and when it was all over in mid-afternoon the Pirates were still two games ahead of the Cubs in the National League's Eastern Division race.

A crowd of 13,826, the biggest so far, had some tough decisions to make yesterday at the United States Open tennis championships at Forest Hills, Queens. Like a threering circus, extraordinary matches kept popping up all over the place at the same time.

RUIDOSO, N.M., Sept. 7 (UPI) Rocket Wrangler beat Bunny Bid by a nose today to win the 12th running of the $670,000. All American Futurity for quarter horses, the world's richest purse in racing. His winning time was 20.09 seconds.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-calls in Congress during the week ending Sept. 4.
DENVER It was a lovely day the sky a cobalt blue with white fleecy clouds showing clear above the downtown streets.

NEWTON, Mass., Sept. 7 Dr. Percy L. Spencer, retired senior vice president of the Raytheon Company in Lexington and a well-known inventor, died today at Newton-Wellesley Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Waban.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 7 (AP) With fighting at a slow pace, United States troop withdrawals from South Vietnam moved ahead today, with American manpower reportedly falling below 400,000 for the first time since early 1967.
The Board of Education yesterday announced its 1970-71 proposals for district allocations of more than $173-million in Federal and state funds for programs to aid economically disadvantaged pupils.
MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 7 Former Gov. George C. Wallace urged the white parents of this city tonight to defy a Federal court order that assigns their children to racially balanced schools.
Arthur J. Goldberg charged here yesterday that Governor Rockefeller was patronizing Jews in the state by talking to them only about the crisis in the Middle East.

YONKERS, Sept. 7--The field for Friday night's $50,000 Gotham Trot at Yonkers Raceway was completed today with the filling of the five remaining berths for the 1 -mile event. Named to the oldest trotting test on the Westchester course's calendar were standardbreds ranging in age from 4 to 10.

VALLEY FORGE, Pa., Sept. 7 Chanting "What do you want?" and answering "Peace now," more than 100 veterans of the war in Vietnam arrived here today after a four-day march and led 1,500 other people in demanding an immediate American military withdrawal from South Vietnam.
LONDON, Sept. 7 (AP) The Bank of England was forced to support the pound sterling in the foreign exchange market today to keep it from dropping to dangerous levels.
The city's Traffic Department is marking the start of the school year with the introduction of 20,000 new school-crossing signs using symbols but no words.

WELLESLEY, Mass., Sept. 7 Mrs. Arthur W. Horton Jr. of Wellesley and Wolfeboro N.H., has announced the engagement of her stepdaughter, Miss Priscilla Hurlbut Horton, to Lowell Alfred Kleiman, son of Mr. and Mrs. George. Kleiman of Roslya, L.I.
The well-tailored man in the duplex apartment overlooking Park Avenue took out his flashlight, crawled under the desk and lay flat on his back. John Frederick Smith was working.

MOSCOW, Sept. 7 Oleg N. Yefremov, the actor and director who rebelled against conservative traditions to form a new Moscow theater in 1957, was named chief director of the venerable Moscow Art Theater today in an effort to restore vitality to that once world-famous showplace.

GENEVA, Sept. 7 With cholera afflicting sub-Saharan Africans for the first time in a century, the World Health Organization today began teaching a group of 102 doctors from 34 African countries the recently developed techniques that prevent the disease from being the scourge it once was.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 7 In the view of legal experts, the United States appeared powerless today to obtain the release of some 150 airline passengers and crew members held hostage by Arab guerrillas in Jordan.

ATLANTIC CITY, Sept. 7 (AP) Harry O.H. Frelinghuysen's Rocky Mount and Albert L. Bigelow's Flying Brick won divisions of the Ventnor Handicap for 3-year-olds on the turf today at the Atlantic City race course.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 7 (AP) The Cleveland Orchestra went on strike at 12:01 A.M. today. Anthony A. Granata, president of the Cleveland Federation of Musicians Local 4, said pickets would be posted tomorrow outside Severance Hall, where the orchestra performs.

LOS ANGELES, Sept. 7 (AP) Willie Crawford celebrated his 24th birthday tonight by blasting a two-run homer in the first game as the Los Angeles Dodgers swept a doubleheader from the Atlanta Braves, 4-2 and 6-1. Wes Parker hit a two-run double and two singles in the second game.

Mayor Lindsay has performed a useful service by emphasizing his belief that the key to solving urban poverty lies in jobs and a healthy metropolitan economy. That is a truism scarcely in need of affirmation, but it has not always seemed to have much acceptance among some of the Mayor's aides concerned with manpower, welfare and antipoverty programs.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 7 Chile's multiparty system is democratic, but it makes for strange and short-lived alliances at election time.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 The Nixon Administration is unusual in its boast that the hallmark of its appointment policy is "political emphasis." It also shows open concern about political loyalty.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 8 The leadership of the governing Christian Democratic party has cautiously indicated support for Dr. Salvador Allende, a Marxist who won a plurality in Friday's Presidential election.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 8 (AP) A year after Bolivia nationalized the United Statesowned Gulf Oil holdings, this country's revolutionary regime is now proclaiming it is preparing to reopen the doors to foreign oil operations.

Varian Associates of Palo Alto, Calif., announced yesterday development of a new computer output printer that it says is "four times faster [and at] one-half the cost of existing mechanical line printers." The new unit operates at 5,000 lines a minute, the equivalent of "an entire page of computer-generated text every second." It will cost $15,300 in a complete configuration.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 8 President Kenneth D. Kaunda of Zambia called on nonaligned nations today to establish new means for collective political and economic action in a world that he said was dominated by the big powers.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Wednesday, Sept. 9 Former Gov. Orval E. Faubus, once a symbol of Southern intransigence on the race issue, was defeated yesterday in a runoff for the Democratic nomination for Governor of Arkansas.
PROSPECTS A winning season more the result of high morale than blocks and tackles.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) The Agriculture Department said today that two manufacturers of livestock vaccines and similar products had failed to comply with Federal Production regulations and had been ordered to halt sales of their products.

ALBANY, Spet. 8 After a two-year investigation, the state Public Service Commission announced today that had concluded that the Consolidated Edison Company did not receive excess earnings through gas rates, as Mayor Lindsey charged in 1968.

Saul Kornreich, president of Saul Kornreich Sons, Inc., an insurance concern of 200 Park Avenue, died at Mount Sinai Hospital of a muscular disease on Monday. He was 77 years old and lived at 150 East 69th Street.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Sept. 8 (AP) A church-owned bus taking children to public schools missed a turn and slammed into a house today.

Subsidiaries of the Columbia Gas System, Inc., and the El Paso Natural Gas Company announced yesterday that they have reached a definite agreement for the purchase by Columbia of liquefied natural gas (LNG) to be imported from Algeria.
BATON ROUGE, La., Sept. 8 Harmon J. (Butch) Duhe, a 21-year-old junior quarterback at Louisiana State, died today in the university hospital.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 (UPI) Leonard Woodcock, president of the United Auto Workers, said today that contract negotiations with the union's strike targets, the General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation, had "ground to a halt" and that the companies had to come up with another offer quickly to avoid a strike Sept. 15.
LONDON, Sept. 8 (Reuters) Chuck Wepner, a heavyweight from Bayonne, N.J., was stopped by Joe Bugner of Britain after three rounds of a scheduled 10-round fight tonight.
NAUVOO, Ill.--The Utah Mormons, who were driven from here 124 years ago, have come back. As a result, this western Illinois village of 1,000 people will never be the same again.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) Union and railroad negotiators resumed negotiations today under Government prodding, but one union leader said "we are further apart than when we started" on a new contract to avert a threatened strike at midnight tomorrow.
HOLMDEL, N.J., Sept. 8 The Frogtown Frolic, a pet show and fair, will be held at the Cross Farm in the Frogtown area of Holmdel from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. on Sept. 26.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 A Federal court has ruled that New York City and other parties may bring triple-damage suits against the major automobile manufacturers for having allegedly conspired to prevent the development and installation of antismog devices.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (UPI) The Treasury Department began an investigation today to determine if electronic components imported from Japan were being sold at illegally low prices.

Dr. Paul L. Adams, the Conservative party candidate for Governor, called yesterday for breaking diplomatic relations with France unless the French Government cracked down on narcotics processing facilities in Marseilles and other French cities.

Wall Street celebrated its first session after the Labor Day weekend yesterday with booming volume, a surge in speculative and glamour favorites, and another recovery high in the climbing Dow-Jones industrial average.
The International Monetary Fund will report next week on the results of its year-long study of greater flexibility in foreign exchange rates.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Rexford G. Tugwell, the former New Deal "brain truster" who has drafted a proposed new Constitution for the United States, said today that he had "borrowed" some of his ideas from Warren E. Burger before he became Chief Justice.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 A dissident member of the Federal Commission on Obscenity and Pornography disclosed tonight that he would seek a court order tomorrow to prevent publication of the commission's report on smut in America.
BERLIN, Sept. 8 West Berlin's "Mount Junk," the artificial hill built of wartime bombing rubble, has something for almost everybody.
The mother of Sirhan B. Sirhan and her two lawyers were thwarted in an attempt to fly to Jordan last night to try to seek the release of 180 hostage air passengers.

CHICAGO, Sept. 8 (UPI)--Accidents are the leading cause of death for persons between the ages of 1 and 37 in the United States and the fourth leading cause of death for all United States age groups, according to the National Safety Council.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Sept. 8 (AP) Two black cadets have won top summer training honors in their respective classes at the United States Military Academy, a West Point statement said today.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 8(AP) United States military strength in Thailand will be reduced by 9,800 men within a year, a joint Thai-American announcement said today.
