United Press International has issued a statement clarifying a UPI dispatch from Syracuse on Aug. 14 that reported that Adam Walinsky, Democratic candidate for Attorney General, would take "a dim view of enforcing" flag-desecration laws if he were elected in November.
MANILA, Sept. 8 A program to control environmental pollution in the Western Pacific was endorsed today by the World Health Organization's regional committee at the close of its 21st session here.
Mayor Lindsay and his outgoing Police Commissioner, Howard R. Leary, met privately at Gracie Mansion yesterday morning.

Still resentful that women's tennis was not receiving the appreciation she felt it warranted, Rosemary Casals went on the court yesterday in a angry mood and scored a 6-4, 4-6, 6-4 victory over Kerry Melville in the quarterfinals of the United States Open championships at Forest Hills, Queens.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 8 During a battle two weeks ago, a young Cambodian company commander found half of his men pinned down behind a road embankment and afraid to counterattack enemy forces firing from a treeline a hundred yards away.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--A sudden thought struck Ralph Houk after the Yankees had battered Washington with 16 hits and a 7-3 victory tonight.

DETROIT, Sept. 8 The General Motors Corporation today priced its new mini car, the Vega 2300, about $200, or 10 per cent, above the present price of the major import, Volkswagen. The car goes on sale Thursday.
EL KHANA, Jordan, Sept. 8 Hostage crewmen of the two airliners being held in the desert by Arab hijackers said today that living conditions on board were bad and growing worse.

Miss Patricia Adele Milton, whose father, Lieut. Gen. Theodore Ross Milton, is former controller of the Air Force, was married Aug. 28 to Pvt. Junius Spencer Morgan 2d of the Army, bearer of the name of his ancestor who founded the Morgan banking enterprise.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed mixed yesterday after initial dullness.

All along, Dennis Ralston was telling anyone who would listen that he was in great physical shape, mentally keen, and eager to compete in the richest tennis tournament in the world, the United States Open.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (UPI) Two officials of the Atomic Energy Commission say fears that radioactive discharges from nuclear generating plants would cause increased threats of cancer and other diseases are unfounded.

A four-engine jet with 11 crew members aboard, but no passengers, crashed and burned on take-off from Kennedy International Airport yesterday. Everyone on the plane, including seven stewardesses, was killed.

Despite stern admonitions from State Supreme Court Justice John M. Murtagh, a defense lawyer at the trial of 13 Black Panthers here persisted yesterday in introducing statements concerning a 20year old accusation against the judge.

United Nations Secretary General Thant spoke for the conscience of civilized man yesterday in denouncing the Arab hijackers for their "savage and inhuman" actions. U. Thant, certainly no enemy of the Arab world, voiced a universal demand when he called for "prompt and effective measures to put a stop to this return to the law of the jungle."

City Council President Sanford D. Garelik believes that Pelham Bay Park swampland in the Bronx would be an ideal site for a 2,500-foothigh mountain of compacted and sanitized refuse.
MANILA, Sept. 8 (UPI) Maj. Gen. Mariano N. Castaneda, a military hero who saved the life of the republic's first president, died here yesterday. He was 76 years old.

Arthur J. Goldberg yesterday challenged Governor Rockefeller to debate campaign issues, and the Governor promptly accepted.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8(AP)--More than 200 North Vietnamese commandos smashed their way into a district headquarters and a ranger camp south of Danang today, reportedly killing 34 South Vietnamese soldiers and wounding 42. An American adviser was also reported killed and three were injured.
YONKERS, Sept. 8--In racing, a morning line is intended to indicate to the bettors which horses will be favored and at what probable odds. It is not designed to pick the winner.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 8 (Reuters) How to Catch a 747" was the headline on a Pan American World Airways advertisement today in The Daily Star of Beirut. The airline's hijacked jumbo jet refueled here Sunday before flying to Cairo, where it exploded.
BROWNSVILLE, Tex., Sept. 8 For the last four years, the Most Rev. Humberto Sosa Medeiros, the Roman Catholic Bishop of Brownsville, has spent Christmas and Easter in Texas jails.

Felipe Luciano, former chairman of the Young Lords, a militant Puerto Rican organization, said yesterday that he had agreed with last week's decision by the group's central committee dismissing him as chairman.

FORT BRAGG, N.C., Sept. 8 (AP) A defense lawyer said today that tests of Capt. Jeffrey R. MacDonald's hair showed it did not match hair found in the hands of the officer's slain wife.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP)--Workers enrolled in private pension programs would be guaranteed some minimum benefits after 10 years of service under a bill introduced in the Senate today.

MOSCOW, Sept. 6 (AP) Neil A. Armstrong, the first man on the moon along with a once-persecuted poet, Anna Aphmatova, and a former "unperson," Isaac Babel, the late Jewish author rises to the status of a historical figure in the new, rewritten version of the Big Soviet Encyclopedia. The encyclopedia is coming out in Moscow one volume at a time.

MILWAUKEE, Wednesday, Sept. 9 Patrick J. Lucey, once the leader of the Kennedy forces in Wisconsin and later a supporter of Senator Eugene J. McCarthy for President, was an apparent victor early today over Donald O. Peterson in the Democratic governorship primary.
Arrests for prostitution here decreased by 18.2 per cent in the first seven months of this year compared with the similar period a year ago, the Police Department reported yesterday.

TRENTON, Sept. 8 (AP) A Federal district judge ruled today that a local governing body could not require a man to salute the flag as a condition of letting him speak at public meetings.

Kenneth Clark's widely heralded film on 1,000 years of Western man made a remarkable hour last night on the network of the National Broadcasting Company. TRENTON, Sept. 8 John V. ARDSLEY, N.Y., Sept. 8 Robert Weiss, senior vice president of the Dollar Savings Bank of New York, died yesterday at his home here after a brief illness. He was 55 years old and lived at 87 Beacon Hill Road.
Travelers boarding jetliners at airports around the world were met yesterday by security agents who searched carry-on bags, poked through women's purses and, in a few cases, searched the passengers.

George Tornay of New York, who did particularly well in the Spingold team event last month in Boston, led a team of young experts to victory in the open team championship that concluded the Knickerbocker Sectional Tournament of the Greater New York Bridge Association at the New York Hilton Monday.

Mahlon M. Frankhauser, former regional administrator for the Securities and Exchange Commission and now a vice president of the New York Stock Exchange, will leave the exchange to become general counsel and secretary of Cogan, Berlind, Weill Levitt, Inc., the brokerage house.

The credit markets yesterday gingerly probed to determine how interest rates would move next, and the results were not conclusive. Different parts of the market moved in different directions, but none of the moves was very dramatic.

Anglo-Canadian Pulp and Paper Mills, Ltd., announced in Quebec yesterday that it would raise the price of newsprint by $10 a ton, effective Jan. 1.

Earnings of the Collins Radio Company in the fiscal year ended July 31 plunged to $432,000, or 15 cents a share, from $8,932,000, or $3.01 a share, earned in the preceding year, the Dallas-based company reported yesterday. Sales declined to $348,957,000 from $400,233,000.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 8 (AP) Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky is reconsidering his scheduled trip to the United States next month, a Government spokesman said today.

SINGAPORE (UP) Singapore has 79 Government-run dental clinics catering mainly to her poor citizens and prisoners.

The Chesapeake Ohio and Baltimore Ohio railroads have asked the Interstate Commerce Commission to dismiss a petition of the trustee of the Central Railroad of New Jersey asking the regulatory agency to require the C. O.-B. O. system to take over the bankrupt line.

MONTPELIER, Vt., Wednesday, Sept. 9 (AP) Former Gov. Philip H. Hoff scored a landslide victory over tow opponents yesterday in the Vermont Democratic Senatorial primary and will face Senator Winston L. Prouty, a Republican, in November.
Edmund P. Flynn, an editor and publisher, died of cancer yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived at 31 East 12th Street.

Seven taxi drivers and one dispatcher have been killed so far this year, as against three drivers killed in all of last year. More than 1,500 cabbies were robbed in the first six months of this year, double last year's rate.

Pan American World Airways said yesterday that there was a "possibility" that the Federal Government would pay the company slightly more than 40 per cent of the loss of its 747 jet. JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Sept. 8 (AP) Andre van Zyl, 19 years old, a South African Army corporal, has laid claim to a world record after a 1,000-mile roller skating jaunt from Capetown to Johannesburg that took him 19 days.

Mr. Gamsjaeger takes over officially in 1972.

PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 (UPI) The Pittsburgh Steelers said today a war wound suffered in Vietnam by Rock Bleier, a running back, was not healing properly and more medical treatment would be needed.

CLEVELAND, Sept. 8 (AP) Striking members of the Cleveland Orchestra set up a picket line today at Severance Hall, home of the orchestra that gained world renown under the direction of the late George Szell.
An Israeli-backed suggestion for an aviation boycott of Arab countries was taken up yesterday by officers of the world pilots' organization and debated in many other segments of the industry.

NORFOLK, Va., Sept. 8 (AP) The Virginia Squires of the American Basketball Association announced today that Ray Scott, a veteran of the National Basketball Association, had signed a "multi-year contract" with the Squires.
WARSAW, Sept. 8 (Reuters) Poland said today that Denmark's refusal to extradite a 28-year-old man who is accused of having hijacked an airliner would not contribute to combating air piracy.
Thirty-four fire bombs went off in quick succession last night in the Sears, Roebuck department store in the downtown shopping area of Brooklyn, the police said.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Sept. 8 Dr. Richard P. Harmon, associate professor of educational administration at Long Island University, died last evening of a heart attack at the Shore Acres Point Club here. He was 57 years old and lived at 730 The Parkway.
HACKENSACK, N.J., Sept. 8 (AP) A Federal inquiry officer today ordered the deportation to Italy of a 42-yearold man wanted for his alleged role in the 1963 slaying of 10 persons in Palermo, Sicily.

KINGSTON, N.Y., Sept. 8 Senator Charles E. Goodell, the Republican-Liberal candidate for the United States Senate, campaigned in low key in two mid-Hudson Valley counties today, visiting an urban-renewal project, an apple orchard and a community college, but greeting relatively few voters.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 8 Premier Golda Meir met with key ministers today to align Israeli policy on the hijackings Sunday with that of Britain, Switzerland, West Germany and the United States, the other states concerned.

ONTARIO, Calif., Sept. 7--The awards dinner of the Indianapolis 500 usually is held the day after the race because officials need that much recapitulation time to sort out the confusion of a race so complex, to tidy up loose ends and to catch up with matters overlooked on...
After a season's hiatus during which he presented five shows in London, Alexander H. Cohen is returning to Broadway as the sponsor of a musical and a romantic comedy.
Sixty householders from Corona, Queens, picketed into the night yesterday at City Hall to protest a proposed plan to tear down 69 homes and use the land for a new high school and athletic field.

RANGOON, Burman, Sept. 8 (AP) Nearly 90 persons were believed to have drowned after being swept away by flood waters near the Burmese town of Pyinmana, the state-owned newspaper The Mirror reported today.

ROCHESTER, Sept. 8 James L. Buckley, Conservative party candidate for the United States Senate, appealed tonight for the support of millions of New Yorkers who see American freedoms "in a state of siege."

Beck Industries, Inc., which acquired 10 of its 12 Disco-Fair stores from Vornado, Inc., from April to October last year, has sold the 12-unit chain back to Vornado, it was announced yes- terday by Frederick Zissu, chairman of Vornado and Manuel F. Rothberg, president of Beck.
ALBANY, Sept. 8 (AP) The state commission to oversee off-track beating plans in the state faced a delay in organization today after the loss of one of the commission members.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 The United States appealed today to 10 Arab countries, including the United Arab Republic and Jordan, to assist on humanitarian grounds in obtaining the release of the hostages held by Palestinian guerrillas in Jordan.
"I guess experience finally paid off for my mount," said Jerry Fishback yesterday with a grin, "but it certainly took its time."

If you're one of First Devonshire Corporation's 4,100 customers, you're probably confused and not a little annoyed that the New York Stock Exchange chose to suspend this member firm and not back up its customers with its celebrated trust fund.

BASEL, Sept. 8 (Reuters)--United California Bank in Basel A.G., in which the United California Bank of Los Angeles has a majority stake, today said its recent substantial losses probably were largely because of unauthorized commodity trading.

As some 200 passengers from two hijacked jetliners waited out their second day as hostages in the Jordanian desert yesterday, Britain, Switzerland, West Germany and the United States agreed to coordinate efforts to obtain their release.
Mayor Lindsay was there. Teams representing two boroughs of the city were the contestants. At stake was a trophy for the winner of the deciding game of a season's series.
SRINAGAR, India, Sept. 8 Indian sources said today that Pakistan in recent months had obtained substantial military aid from Communist China.

The chances are that not even those closest to Vince Lombardi had a true appreciation of the greatness of the man nor a proper realization of what a towering public figure he had become. But his tragic death from cancer last week brought a new appraisal and Vince began to assume even larger and more heroic dimensions.

The announcement over the weekend of the election of Dr. Salvador Allende, the Marxist candidate of a leftist coalition, as president of Chile sent copper futures up yesterday on the New York Commodity Exchange. Chile is a large producer of both copper and silver.
PITTSBURGH, Sept. 8 The Chicago Cubs further tightened the National League East pennant race today by walloping the Pittsburgh Pirates, 10-3, at Three Rivers Stadium.

Howard R. Leary, who has submitted his resignation as the city's Police Commissioner to become operating vice president of security for the Abraham Straus department stores here, got his new job through an executive recruitment company, officials of A. S. said yesterday.

BUFFALO, Sept. 8 A vice president of the Olin Corporation testifed in Federal Court here today that the company had spent more than $200,000 since last April to reduce mercury discharges into the Niagara River from its chlorine plant in nearby Niagara Falls.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 One of the odd paradoxes in America today is that there is more grumbling about the political life of the nation and yet relatively less voting in this year's primary elections than in many years. In short, it isn't only the young who are copping out of the political system, but also their elders who seem to feel that voting is not the answer to their grievances.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that all 11,700 taxicabs in the city would be required to have locked money boxes secured to their frames to help discourage holdup men.

The Alumni Association of the American Colleges in Istanbul, Turkey, and trustees of Robert College of Istanbul are sponsoring a champagne gala at an exhibition of works by contemporary Turkish artists in the United States from 9 P.M. to midnight next Wednesday. Proceeds will go to scholarships.

With the fall school term starting this week in many northeast communities, school districts in upper Westchester County, Niagara Falls and southern Connecticut were faced with strike action by teachers demanding better pay and improved working conditions.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., (UPI) A 1-year-old child is going through a stage when everything he does can be a learning experience, according to James E. Van Horn, a familylife specialist at Pennsylvania State University.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 8 (AP) Thirty professors at Harvard, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Princeton, Chicago and other universities called upon the Nixon Administration today to "keep faith with Israel."

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 8 In the Yale University football locker room there is a small cardboard sign with the numeral 4 on it. It means that the Bulldogs are going for a fourth successive Ivy League title or a share of it. No other league team ever has accomplished that feat.
ALBANY, Sept. 8 (UPI) More than $7-million in lottery tickets have been sold in New York State's first million-dollar special summer lottery, it was announced today, a week before final ticket sales.

Following is a list of the passengers aboard Swissair Flight 100 when it was hijacked to Jordan Sunday, with places where they purchased their tickets. A list of passengers aboard Trans World Airlines Flight 741, also hijacked to Jordan, appeared in The New York Times yesterday.
Archibald Davidow, a manufacturer of women's coats and suits, died in Lenox Hill Hospital Sunday. He was 79 years old and had been ill since an accident last December.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Richard M. Nixon today became the third consecutive modern President to display personal support for the rehabilitation of Pennsylvania Avenue, the historic thoroughfare linking the Capitol and the White House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 Senator Edward M. Kennedy, a former Assistant District Attorney in Boston who has not argued a case in nine years, will argue for the constitutionality of the new 18-year-old vote law in the Federal District Court here Thursday.
Religious organizations in New York voiced outrage yesterday at the hijacking by Arab commandos of airlines Sunday and the continued detention of passengers and crew members in Jordan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--The White House confirmed today that it has stalled the nomination of Sherman E. Unger to the Federal Communications Commission until the Internal Revenue Service completes a "routine" audit of his tax returns.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 The Senate opened today a historically significant debate on revamping the nation's Presidential selection system. There was a spirited flurry of talk among a few Senators but no prospect of action for some days, perhaps weeks.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 (AP) Use of intoxicating liquor by the pilot caused the light-plane crash at Germantown, N.Y., last Sept. 14 in which both occupants were killed, the National Transportation Safety Board said today.
The morale of the city's 10,100-man sanitation force is critically low.

Enter the class of '74, same 1.7 million strong, to Ivy League college and state university, to country campus on grassy hill and city school tied to subway line. As the academic year begins, mothers fret over how many sheets and towels to give their sons, how many pairs of shoes to buy for their daughters and fathers wonder where all that money will come from.
PARIS, Sept. 8 The apartment of the Cambodian military attache here has become the prize in a struggle between the embassy and supporters of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the deposed head of state.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 8--Creation of a special new unit in the Justice Department to handle criminal cases involving violations of the securities laws was announced today... by Attorney General John N. Mitchell.

CONCORD, N.H., Wednesday, Sept. 9 Gov. Walter R. Peterson pulled slightly ahead in the Republican gubernatorial primary early today. He faced a stiff challenge from a conservative, Meldrim Thomson of Orford, a publisher of law books.
ABIDJAN, Ivory Coast, Aug. 27 Early this month the Ivory Coast observed the 10th anniversary of independence, with the reappraisals and selfexamination that are customary.
BUENOS AIRES, Sept. 8 (UPI) The police reported today the slaying of two men sought for the kidnapping and murder last May of former President Pedro Eugenio Aramburu.

Steve Carlton, the St. Louis Cardinals' big left-hander, signed a two-year $40,000 contract last spring after a holdout battle that so incensed Gussie Busch, the club owner, that Busch said: "I don't care if he pitches another ball for us."

FORT HOOD, Tex., Sept. 8 (AP) The commander of the First Armored Division today dismissed one charge of assault to murder against S. Sgt. David Mitchell in connection with the alleged massacre at Songmy, South Vietnam.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 8 The meetings of three black groups over the Labor Day weekend point up the growing ethnic nationalism of a wide spectrum of black Americans as frustrations continue to grow over the slowness of change for most blacks.
PARIS, Sept. 8(AP) France is upset about wasps. A 46-year-old farmer in central France was stung in the head and died last night, becoming the fifth person to be killed by wasp stings in 10 days.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 8 The General Motors Corporation acknowledged today that Chevrolet Corvairs had overturned in secret tests but said the rollovers had been intentional.
MOSCOW, Sept. 8 In an effort to improve their own economy, Soviet management specialists these days are paying increased attention to the way American big business is run.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Sept. 8--Harold Minot Pitman, a genealogist, died yesterday in a nursing home. He was 82 years old and lived at 88 Summit Avenue.
Brooklyn's 12 City Councilmen will meet today to elect an interim Borough President to succeed Abe Stark, who is ill and whose resignation took effect yesterday.

The International Longshoremen's Association, which has been trying with varying degrees of success in recent years to prove it has developed a sense of public responsibility, is reverting to its old troglodyte habits in its battle to keep Mayor Lindsay from turning idle Hudson River piers into cultural centers.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) Lawyers for Charles Denton Watson appealed to Supreme Court Justice Hugo L. Black today for more time to press their contention that he cannot receive a fair trial in California in the Sharon Tate murders.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 The United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia heard final arguments by conservationists today on a move to force the Secretary of Agriculture to ban all uses of DDT.
The first suit arising from a bus crash last July 15 along Route 22 near Allentown, Pa., where seven Long Island children lost their lives, was filed yesterday in Federal Court in Brooklyn.
"Who me? I'm not going to vote for nobody with all these dope addicts on the street." I'm not a member of the system."
DETROIT, Sept. 9 The almost standard phrase "Just because we're far apart doesn't mean we can't reach a settlement without a strike" no longer rolls easily off the tongues of the negotiators here.

TRENTON, Sept. 9 The statewide grand jury that is investigating organized crime and official corruption in New Jersey is scheduled to hear testimony here tomorrow from John V. Kenny, the Hudson County Democratic leader, and nine other to pHudson Democratic officials.
Negotiators working to save the lives of hundreds of hostages held by Arab hijackers in the Jordanian desert won a lastminute extension of their deadline last night.
Cardinal Cooke said yesterday that one of his priests had been detached from his regular parish duties to become a fulltime battler of bureaucracy.

The combination of a chestnut mare, Queen's Lady, and her owner, Joan Broughton, was a winning one on the horse show circuit in 1958, the Queen having been one of the top green working hunters in the East. Then her owner married Michael Carusone and moved to Glens Falls, N.Y.
Two city consumer-protection regulations went into effect yesterday.
Howard W. Johnson, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology for four years, announced his resignation yesterday and urged a reassessment of the M.I.T. governing structure.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 A Federal District Court judge issued a temporary order today to restrain the Commission on Obscenity and Pornography from publishing its final report, which details the extent and effects of smut across the nation and recommends actions to cope with it.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 9 I want to change the political climate of Arkansas," Dale L. Bumpers told crowds all summer, and he appeared to have done just that yesterday in a manner that astonished almost everyone.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 9 (UPI) Lawrence F. O'Brien, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, demanded today that Nixon Administration officials take a leave of absence from the Government payroll while they campaign for Republican candidates.

ST. THOMAS, V.I., Sept. 9 (AP) In the Democratic party primary for the first elected Governor of the United States Virgin Islands, Senator Alexander Farrelly appeared to have won today the nomination by a comfortable margin.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 (UPI) Little progress was reported today as negotiations continued between a teachers' union and the board of education in a contract dispute that will delay opening of public schools for 290,000 pupils.

PARIS, Sept. 9 The Cabinet approved the national budget for 1971 today with higher spending on education than on defense for the first time in French history. This was seen as further evidence of the emphasis the French have given to domestic problems since the worker-student riots in May and June, 1968.
NEW HAVEN, Sept. 9 Teacher strikes continued today in seven of Connecticut's 173 school districts with little hope of contract settlement by tomorrow morning, when classes were scheduled to begin.
LONDON, Sept. 9 (UPI) The British pound came to life today, rising about three quarters of a cent in its best single day's increase in many months.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) The Western Union Telegraph Company asked the Federal Communications Commission today to approve the closing of 241 of its offices to cut annual operating costs by $2million.
Back in 1950, a young lawyer in search of a new suit made it a habit to patronize a particular Brooklyn store.
Interest rates moved upward decisively yesterday as a heavy volume of new bond issues was marketed to raise funds for corporations and local governments.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Sept. 9 Royal Firman Jr. and his bride, the former Mrs. Joan Loew Farley of New York, are sending out announcements of their marriage, which took place in New York on July 28.
William J. McGill, the new president of Columbia University, said yesterday that the university was "overextended" financially and would have to cut administrative and academic costs substantially.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 The World Bank reported today that its annual aid to developing countries had passed the $2billion mark, exceeding the United States foreign aid program.

HORNELL, N.Y., sept. 9 Governor Rockefeller, who has been holding his campaign down to a leisurely two days a week, began this week a five-day-a-week stumping schedule. The Governor, who is seeking a fourth term, is reserving a sixth day each week for office work.

Representatives of the newly formed Emergency Citywide Committee for the Public Schools warned yesterday that there would be turmoil in the city schools this year unless additional funds were provided for education.
On Sept. 29 the New York Shakespeare Festival will open its fourth season at the Public Theater with "The Happiness Cage," a drama by Dennis Reardon.
Sebastian Leone, little known outside of Brooklyn Democratic circles, was elected interim Borough President of Brooklyn yesterday at a special session of the 12 Brooklyn City Councilmen.
MOSCOW, Sept. 9 (AP) The first Soviet Fiats have rolled off the assembly line at the huge new plant in the new Volga River town of Togliatti, Pravda reported today.
Osborn Elliott, editor in chief of Newsweek magazine, has also been named vice chairman of Newsweek, Inc.

Federal investigators said yesterday they had no clues yet to explain why a Trans International Airlines DC-8 jetliner crashed at Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday shortly making a strange, steep take-off maneuver. All 11 persons on the plane were killed.

A City Council investigation of a possibly dispute between Mayor Lindsay and Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary leading to the Commissioner's resignation was formally proposed yesterday by Councilman Matthew J. Troy Jr.
LONDON, Sept. 9 Arab guerrillas seized a Londonbound British jetliner with 117 people aboard today and landed it on a desert strip in Jordan near two other hijacked jets.

MILWAUKEE, Sept. 9 Former Lieut. Gov. Patrick J. Lucey's solid victory over Donald O. Peterson in yesterday's gubernatorial primary has left Wisconsin's restive Democrats without any visible scars and apparently as unified as they are likely to be.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) The Senate approved and sent to the White House today a bill to give the District of Columbia's 764,000 citizens a nonvoting delegate in the House of Representatives.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 9 The name of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, the most militant of the 10 major Arab commando groups, has become synonymous in recent months with the hijackings of international airliners.

BONN, Sept. 9 A spokesman for Chancellor Willy Brandt declared today that West Germany foresaw that a treaty with Poland to normalize relations would be concluded before the end of the year despite substantial difficulties.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 9 Dr. Manuel Barkan, department chairman and professor of art education at Ohio State University, died today. He was 57 years old.
Five days remain for some serious figuring by several million taxpayers who regularly pay installments on their estimated taxes.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The chairman of the House Banking Committee, Representative Wright Patman, said today that the nation's major banks raised their prime lending rate after President Nixon's election for their own "profit taking."

I have granted the request of counsel for Denny McLain for an adjournment of today's hearing, which was scheduled to determine whether McLain's recent conduct was consistent with his probationary status.

Calling abandoned buildings here "symbols of decay, danger and despair," Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that he had directed a city planning unit "to review and revise procedures" to accelerate the sealing and demolishing of such structures.

AMMAN, Jordan, Sept. 9 Living conditions improved a bit today for the airline passengers held hostage in the Jordanian desert. But their fellow passengers who had been released spent a tense day in hotels in Amman as Jordanian troops and Palestinian commandos battled Around them.
CONCORD, N.H., Sept. 9 Gov. Walter R. Peterson, a moderate Republican, has turned back a strong conservative bid to unseat him in his party's gubernatorial primary.

Leaders of The New York Times unit of the Newspaper Guild adopted a resolution yesterday calling on its members to authorize a strike against The Times. The full membership of the Times unit is to vote at a meeting on Sept. 24.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 9 In the latest episode of a controversy that is fascinating and amusing the South Vietnamese, Vice President Nguyen Cao Ky today reiterated his intention to visit the United States next month despite some official American and South Vietnamese efforts to discourage him.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 9 (AP) Newsmen may have to be given immunity from grand jury subpoenas "in times of stress" so that lines of communications can be maintained with militant groups, a Federal judge suggested today.

A positive improvement in consumer attitudes, the first in more than a year, has been found by the University of Michigan's survey research center. The center's index of consumer sentiment rose to 77.1 per cent of "normal" in the third quarter from a low point of 75.4 per cent in the second quarter.

By combining global observations of the manner in which ocean floors are spreading, two American geologists have drawn a series of maps showing how a single continent gradually divided into the many continents that now exist.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) Senator Gale W. McGee, Democrat of Wyoming, said today that someone had hired private detectives to spy on his family. He said that he suspected the Wyoming Republican State Central Committee.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 9 Robbie Doyle of Marblehead, Mass., took a commanding lead today after the seventh and eighth races in the North America single-handed sailing championship. Doyle won both races today for a total score of 21.4 points on a low-point system.

Despite increased sales, earnings of the AddressographMultigraph Corporation fell 69.9 per cent in the fourth fiscal quarter and 69.6 per cent in the fiscal year ended July 31, the manufacturer of duplicating and data-writing equipment reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Backers of the proposal to substitute direct popular election of the President for the Electoral College have concluded that the plan cannot pass the Senate without intervention by President Nixon.
"Hello, Dolly!" edged past "My Fair Lady" yesterday as the longest-running musical in Broadway show history.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 9 On Lake Meadow Drive in the Rochester suburb of Greece there is a mustard yellow house with a swing in the back and three bicycles in front. A plaster crucifix hangs inside the door.

At Lincoln Center last night, a bunch of kids standing together in a tight group had their dyes glued on a television set, but they were not watching "Where's Huddles?" They were backstage at the New York State Theater where the New York City Opera was performing Boito's "Mefistofele," but they were not watching that either.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 9 Baron Bich's blue-hulled yacht France was given a decisive defeat today by Gretel II, this time in the rain.

The continuing ordeal of an augmented company of international air travelers held captive on the Jordanian desert by Palestinian desperadoes is the savage consequence of the failure of the community of nations to have acted decisively long ago on the crime of aerial hijacking.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) As of today, birth control pills used by 8.5 million women now come with a 150-word package insert that warns of the drugs' side effects.
WASHINGTON Sept. 9 (AP) Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia, said today that colleges should oust radical professors and students and then adopt policies to keep them out.

TRENTON, Sept. 9 Baron Johan Liljencrants, a former psychologist at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Washington, and a former editor of The SwedishAmerican Monthly in New York, died Saturday. He was 84 years old.

GENEVA, Sept. 9 The 45year-old Swiss who has been trying to beat the deadline for ransoming the hostages held by the Palestinian guerrillas is perhaps the most flamboyant and controversial figure in the staid history of the Red Cross.

Governor Luis Ferre of Puerto Rico declared in a telephone interview yesterday from San Juan that the Government would go into court within the next 48 hours to make an official request for the "condemnation" of vast sugar properties in that island owned by the Aguirre Company.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) The Secretary of the Interior, Walter J. Hickel, said today that a charge that he had tried to destroy the reputation of his predecessor, Stewart L. Udall, was ridiculous.

Mrs. Daphne Nowell MacLaury and Dr. Edgar Alsop Riley, an internist and, pulmonary specialist at Cornell University , Medical College, were married yesterday afternoon in the Dana Chapel of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. William McQuoid. A reception was given at the Colony Club.

WASHINGTON Sept. 9 A representative of working-class women told Congress today tha the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution would bring to women such as herself only "an equality of mistreatment" by employers.

One of Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's early extravaganzas was the 1969 All-Star Game in Washington. There was a Presidential reception, a number of parties and the official Start of what seems to have become a wholehearted relationship between baseball and the Administration. Scheduled to start for the American League was Denny McLain of the world champion Detroit Tigers, the Cy Young award-winner as the game's top pitcher, and most recently winner of 31 games.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 The United States ordered six Air Force transport planes today to carry medical teams to a base in Turkey for a possible evacuation of the hostages held in Jordan by Palestinian guerrillas.

The General Portland Cement Company, one of the nation's largest producers of cement and concrete products, announced yesterday that it plans to enter the home furnishings field. The company said it has agreed in principle to acquire Mangurian's, Inc., a Fort Lauderdale, Fig., home furnishings
Many of mid-Manhattan's fanciest restaurants, along with some of the plainest about 750 in all are undergoing unusually intense inspections by a special corps of Health Department sanitarians.

TACOMA, Wash., Sept. 9 (AP) Gunfire broke out today as a group of Tacoma policemen and other law enforcement officers closed in on Indians along the Puyallup River in an attempt to clear it of fishing nets. The legality of the nets used by the Puyallup Indians is in dispute.
Cassius Clay, stripped of his world heavyweight boxing title when he refused military induction in April of 1967, is going back into the ring.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Sept. 9 (AP) More than 2,000 Thai students stormed into Parliament today and occupied the chamber until Premier Thanom Kittikachorn met with them and agreed to their demands for the suspension of three top university officials.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 9 The gamble by Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr. to take unchallenged control of the Republican party in Florida lay in ruins today along with the brief political career of G. Harrold Carswell.

The stock market, psychologically buffeted by possible strikes and by jetliner hijackings, nosed downward yesterday. But it was a gentle descent that saw the largest declines in recent glamour favorites.

Thomas Joseph O'Connor, retired financial adviser to the controller of Mobil Oil Company died Monday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical rcenter, after heart surgery. He was 69 years old and lived at 12 Doris Drive, Scarsdale, N.Y.

HOUSTON, Sept. 9 (UPI) Donald K. Slayton, the former astronaut who is now chief of flight operations, said today that the nation had a lot of space pilots with no place to go because of budget cutbacks.

As in previous seasons, the New York City Opera picked the best of its recent successes to open the season. Last night the 52d New York season got under way (it must be remembered that the City Opera has a fall and "spring season, so divide by two for the approximate age of the company). The choice was Boito's "Mefistofele," to the evident enjoyment of the full house.
WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP) A Jefferson County Dedeputy sheriff was fatally wounded today while attempting to protect a wife from her estranged husband.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 9 A Dean Dudley, honorary chairman of the Lincoln National Bank and Trust Company, a division of Lincoln First Banks, Inc., and former president of the Syracuse Lighting Company (now Niagara Mohawk), died Sunday. His age was 92 and he lived here.

ALBANY, Sept. 9 Governor Rockefeller's admonition to Arthur J. Goldberg that he become "sufficiently briefed" on the issues was denounced by Mr. Goldberg today as "a snide and evasive" refusal to debate.

The Pittsburgh Lake Erie Railroad, a 93 per cent-owned subsidiary of the Penn Central Transportation Company, yesterday declared a $1.50 dividend on the capital stock payable Oct. 15, to holders of record Sept. 25.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 9 Stuart Rowe Jr., commodore of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club and one of the three representatives of Long Island Sound in the world International One-Design Class championship, won twice today in races that were virtually carbon copies so far as he was concerned.
The Federal Aviation Administration set up a task force yesterday to work out more stringent measures to prevent the hijacking of airliners.

Senator Charles E. Goodell charged yesterday that the Nixon Administration had jeopardized the Mideast peace talks by "closing its eyes" to the Soviet-Egyptian build-up of missiles in the Suez Canal cease-fire zone.

NOROTON, Conn., Sept. 9 Steven Nightingale of the host Noroton Yacht Club won the 22d annual Associate Championship of Long Island Sound for the Jesse A.B. Smith Trophy by 6 points today in a three-race regatta sailed in Tempest Class sloops in a strong southerly wind of 8 to 20 knots.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 The Federal National Mortgage Association said today that interest rates rose slightly in this week's auction.

ATLANTA, Thursday, Sept. 10 Jimmy Carter, a colorful former State Senator who veered to the right in the final days of his campaign, built a command ing lead over eight challengers this morning in Georgia's Gubernatorial primary.

The Senate debate on direct election of Presidents and Vice Presidents recalls once more the bittersweet mixture of conservatism and liberalism that marked sessions of the Constitutional Convention and produced a basic compact of government founded on compromise. It is a reminder that the long march toward a broader franchise and a more representative government has at least a few steps to go.
The Admiral Corporation announced yesterday that prices of its 1971 line of refrigerators, freezers, room airconditioners and electric ranges would be increased by 2 to 6 per cent.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday announced a ban on parking in a 50-block area below Fulton Street in an attempt to break up the Lower Manhattan traffic bottleneck.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 (AP) Secret Justice Department files show that two ship lines gave nearly $6,000 in illegal campaign contributions for key members of Senate and House committees that control a rich flow of Federal subsidies for the lines.

Homer Jones, the mercurial receiver who kept the Giants alive during five of their darkest seasons by catching 34 touchdown passes, returns to Yankee Stadium on Saturday night in the uniform of the Cleveland Browns.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 9 Official Arab opinion is divided on the hijackings and their consequences, but even persons hostile to the commandos agree that the Arab man in the street highly admires what he regards as the courage, elan and skill of the perpetrators.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 9 The talent-hunt begun by Len Jardine at Brown University four years ago is expected to come to full fruition on the gridiron this fall.
BALTIMORE, Sept. 9 Mike Cuellar of the Baltimore Orioles posted his 22d victory tonight as the Orioles scored a 1-0 triumph that ended the New York Yankees' winning streak at five games.

MONTAUK, L.I. While salmon fishing in Scotland recently I had grown accustomed to rising at 8 A.M., eating a leisurely breakfast and arriving at my beat on the river at 9:30. But Gerry Ruschmeyer, proprietor of Ruschmeyer's Hotel and Motel, quickly shattered any notions I might have had of performing similarly at Montauk.
BUFFALO, Sept. 9 James L. Buckley, the Conservative party candidate for the United States Senate, said today that he anticipated "all kinds of vote splitting in the Nov. 3 election."

PARIS, Sept. 9 Auditors examining the books of a Basel bank that reported a $30-million loss last year have disclosed that some of the difficulties arose from trading in highly volatile cocoa futures, the bank's American management disclosed today.

The recent death of Samuel Reichman is a great loss to the metropolitan chess world: With his passing, the last link between East Side coffeehouse chess and the general New York chess scene has vanished. For more than 25 years Reichman made the New York Chess and Checker Club on 42d Street his headquarters.
MASTIC, L.I. "Ordinary husbands," Roger Fessaguet was reflecting this week as he lifted a lobster from a steaming kettle, "ordinary husbands don't cook.
The American Stock Exchange ended mixed yesterday in active trading after an afternoon rally erased most of the earlier losses.

HAMILTON, N.Y., Sept. 9 Colgate decided to join the group of college football teams playing 11 games this season and as a result the Red Raiders got a pickup game with Navy at Annapolis for this Saturday. The Middies might just receive a shock from the bunch of Raiders from the quiet little valley in upstate New York.
A 21-year-old New Jersey man was accused yesterday of swindling almost $750,000 by convincing people that he was an investment wizard.
HONG KONG, Sept. 10 Communist China announced preparations today for an early meeting of the National People's Congress, the country's legislature. It last met more than five and a half years ago

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., Sept. 9 Charlotte de Cozen of Westchester Country Club, a former winner, scored 37, 37 74 at Pelham C.C. in damp weather today for a four-stroke lead after the first round of the 41st annual Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy Memorial Tournament of the Women's TriCounty Golf Association.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Administration witnesses testified today that a proposed tax on the lead in gasoline was an essential step toward cleaner air.

Jamaica Bay is the "only environmental success story in New York City so far," Dr. Rene Dubos, the Rockefeller University biologist, said yesterday as he stood in the gray drizzle and ate oysters from the half shell at the bay's wildlife refuge.
The London stock market closed firmer yesterday in quiet trading.

Five or six new motion picture houses and a legitimate theater may be built on one East Side block owned by Joseph E. Levine, a major film producer and president of Avco Embassy Pictures.

Beck Industries, Inc., yesterday announced the resignation of Bertram H. Slater as financial vice president and a director and the resignations of Harold K. Ross and John I. Taeni as directors. Beck, parent company of the A.S. Beck shoe chain and owner of varied other merchandise operations, gave no reason for the resignations.

Thousands of railroad commuters were delayed about a half hour last night when service on Penn Central lines at Grand Central Terminal was suspended after a woman apparently jumped from a passenger car in a tunnel near 59th Street.

JERUSALEM, Sept. 9 British, Swiss and West German diplomats assured Israel today that their governments were insisting that all airline passengers held hostage by Arab guerrillas and not just their own nationals be released in a bloc, the Israeli Foreign Ministry said today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 The Senate Labor Subcommittee approved a job safety bill today that would give the Secretary of Labor broad authority to set industry-wide safety standards and to enforce compliance.

Okay, so you're patting yourself on the back that you called the rise in bank stocks, and now you're thinking about locking up those summer rally profits.

Steve Poste, director of the shoe division of Howard Stores Corporation, Brooklyn, died Monday in Perugia, Italy, white on vacation. He was 42 years old and lived at 356 Red Hill Road, Middletown, N.J.
Agenor L. Castro has been appointed director of commu nity affairs for the Department of Correction, it was announced yesterday by Correction Commissioner George F. McGrath.

LONDON, Sept. 9 Occasionally, both on Broadway and in London's West End, it is permissible to wonder just how shrewd so-called commercial managements are. In London most of the enterprise is left to the major subsidized groups, the Royal Shakespeare Company, the National Theater and the Royal Court Theater.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Sept. 9 Jorge Alessandri Rodriguez, the rightist candidate who ran second in Chile's presidential election last week, declared today that he would not accept the presidency if he was offered it when Congress chooses the winner.
The United States switched from a creditor to a debtor status in its dealings with foreign central banks during the last six months, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

The Hobeau Farm's Taken Aback contributed one of her exciting late rashes to win the feature race at Belmont yesterday. The rainy-day crowd of 19,822 made the daughter of Carry Back the even-money favorite against eight rivals in the mile race, fully aware that she would apparently be away out of it in the early stages.

The happy shout, "We're No. 1," echoed through soggy Shea Stadium last night a trifle prematurely as the New York Mets tied for the lead in National League East by splitting a double-header with the Philadelphia Phillies.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Sept. 9 Miss Wendy Ann Nathan, a graduate last May of Boston University, plans to be married next June to Wilfred Rolfe Shrigley Jr. of Marblehead, Mass., assistant to the president of Great Northern Industries in Boston.
They finally found a way yesterday to stop Mrs. Margaret Court's inexorable drive toward a tennis grand slam rain.

HARTFORD, Sept. 9 Senator Thomas J. Dodd, a Democrat who bolted his party to seek re-election as an independent, has been invited to sit at the head table at the traditional Democratic party state campaign kick-off dinner here Saturday night.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 9 (UPI) Joseph A. Estes, former editor of the Blood Horse, the thoroughbred breeders' magazine, died today after an illness of several months. He was 68 years old.
PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 9 Federal District Judge Harold, K. Wood enjoined the Philadelphia Police Department today from compelling citizens to participate in police line-ups.

FORT McPHERSON, Ga., Sept. 9 (UPI) A sergeant involved in the alleged Songmy massacre charged Gen. William C. Westmoreland today with dereliction of duty and said that the general, now the Army Chief of Staff, must shoulder the blame for whatever happened in the Vietnamese village.
ROME, Sept. 9 National and city authorities are investigating a tax scandal with political overtones that followed a sensational murder-suicide drama among Rome's super-rich.

The suspension of Denny McLain, the controversial Detroit Tigers' pitcher, was "reinstated" for an indefinite period, including at least the rest of the season, by Bowie Kuhn, commissioner of baseball, yesteday.
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., Sept. 9 A bid of $3.2-million from C.Y. Tung of Hong Kong and Taipei for the former Cunard liner Queen Elizabeth appeared tonight to be the most likely to be accepted.

Msgr. Timothy F. Herlihy, pastor of St. Joseph's Church at Waverly Place and Avenue of the Americas, died of cancer yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 371 Avenue of the Americas.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 9 President Nguyen Van Thieu briefed and entertained 537 elected city and provincial councilmen today and said he planned to give them a larger share in local government.

A 57-year-old black musician who lectures at universities on African music and composes symphonic music was sworn in yesterday afternoon as foreman of the jury to try 13 Black Panthers acused of plotting to bomb public places.
Management personnel and clerical workers in about 1,000 apartment buildings scheduled for slum-clearance demolition yesterday set a strike deadline of 6:30 A.M. today.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 9 Vice President Agnew will set out tomorrow in pursuit of an objective that the White House is said to regard as unlikely a Republican majority in the Senate.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 9 At the sports field in the center of town today, Cambodian soldiers filled an old bus with mortar shells just arrived by way of Vietnam from the "Army Ammo Depot, Milan, Tenn." A few feet away, recruits were running around pretending they had guns.
The first $10,000 Gunnar Myrdal Prize, established for books of distinction in the study of human behavior, was awarded yesterday to "The Politics of Unreason," by Seymour Lipset and Earl Raab.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Sept. 9 The Security Council called unanimously today for the immediate release of all passengers and crews held as a result of hijackings and "other international travel."

HARTFORD, Sept. 9 (UPI) Young Americans for Freedom, which calls itself the nations' largest conservative youth organization, opened a four-day convention at the University of Hartford today to celebrate its 10th anniversary.

TOKYO, Sept. 9 (AP) For the overflow audience that applauded nearly 15 minutes for the New York Philharmonic, it was a concert to remember. Leonard Bernstein tossed his baton to the crowd in exultation.
LONDON, Sept. 9 "It was just a bit of desert that the boys named after me," Sir Walter Dawson said today from his home at Sunninghill, near Windsor.

MOSCOW, Sept. 9 The Soviet Union said today that the United States had been informed that although the Egyptians had not introduced any Soviet missiles into the Suez Canal zone since the cease-fire began, they had "the full right" to redeploy missiles already there.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Thursday, Sept. 10 (Reuters) A military spokesman said a flotilla of Cambodian boats and troops reached Kompong Thom last night breaking a threemonth siege by the Communists of the provincial capital 88 miles north of Pnompenh.

The City Planning Commission approved a "first-of-itskind' housing program yesterday involving the erection of 27 largely prefabricated apartment buildings on scattered sites in the Bedford-Stuyvesant and Brownsville sections of Brooklyn.

In its annual report the International Monetary Fund has sharply criticized the Nixon Administration for its economic policies. The IMF states that the Administration's approach has permitted too much price and cost inflation and has had a more severe impact on unemployment and real output than it expected.

A special mobile summer registration drive conducted with vans by the Board of Elections has added 136,282 new voters to the election rolls, Commissioner of Elections Maurice J. O'Rourke announced yesterday.

BONN, Sept. 9 Alarmed by increased crowding, land hunger and traffic density, Cabinet ministers of 17 Western European countries and observers from three more met here today to consider methods of coordinating their regional planning efforts.

Savings banks in New York City, which were sharply criticized by retailers (as well as by some bankers) earlier this year for their aggressive giveaway campaigns to promote new deposits, are planning a new round of such promotions for the fall. The intensity of the advertising, however, is not expected to be so-great as it was last spring.

MATAWAN, N.J., Sept. 9 (AP) Mrs. Laura S. Wolff, who as Laura Sawyer took leading roles in early movies, died in the Emory Manor Nursing Home here Monday. She was 85 years old, the widow of Charles Frederick Wolff. She moved here two years ago from St. Petersburg, Fla.

The president of the American Newspaper Publishers Association said yesterday that "dark days are ahead for many United States newspaper publishers" if newsprint manufturers follow the $10-a-ton increase announced Tuesday by Anglo-Canadian Pulp and Paper Mills, Ltd.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 9 Faced with stiff but peaceful resistance to a new desegregation plan, the Mobile County school board placed the burden of the plan's enforcement on the Federal authorities whom they blame for the confusion that accompanied the opening of school this morning.

Gimbels, which last year concentrated on Italy as a focus for the introduction of new fashions and furnishings, has switched this year to Spain.
HORNELL, N.Y., Sept. 9 (AP) Justice Austin W. Erwin Jr. of the State Supreme Court has asked for and received protection of armed guards in court sessions here, but declined today to say why.
The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday that its new subcompact, the Pinto, would have a suggested list price of $1,919, undercutting the price of General Motors' tiny Vega by about $150.
SIEGEN, West Germany, Sept. 9 The United States chess team swept all boards, 4 to 0, in its fourth-round preliminary match with Mexico in the 19th Chess Olympiad at Siegerland Hall here today.
With a firm hand on a pair of golden scissors, Mayor Lindsay yesterday morning cut the ribbons and officially opened Burlington Industries' handsome new $1.25-million exhibition hall.

Floyd Patterson and Charlie (Devil) Green underwent prefight physicals yesterday at the Felt Forum for their 10round heavyweight fight Tuesday night at Madison Square Garden. Dr. A. Harry Kleiman, one of the New York State Athletic Commission physicians, found both boxers in excellent shape.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., Sept. 9 Miss Grace Huffman was presented this evening to 130 guests at a dinner dance given by her mother, Mrs. Grace Ewing Huffman, on the terrace of their home here. They were joined on the receiving line, under a white and gold marquee by the debutante's six sisters and brother.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 9 There were no sessions of Circuit Court here today as a result of two bomb threats and a threat on the life of a judge.
Which of the following traditions will probably soon be eliminated from the annual Miss America Pageant in Atlantic City?
Within 30 days, 7,000 fleet-owned taxicabs in the city will have strongboxes bolted to the floors of their cabs in an effort to thrwart holdups, an industry spokesman said yesterday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 9 Views on interracial marriage have undergone a dramatic change in the last five years, with a clear majority of people surveyed nationwide, 56 per cent, now disapproving of laws that prohibit marriage between whites and blacks, the Gallup Poll reported today.
Reports of substantial wheat exports sent futures prices of that commodity up yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade with all contracts scoring seasonal highs.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Sept. 9 (AP) A senior allied commander said today that a North Vietnamese force equal to five divisions was poised for a thrust against the populated coastal lowlands in South Vietnam's northern provinces.
The New York Aquarium's 40-pound Pacific octopus has given birth to several hundred wriggling babies, but aquarium officials have been unable to track down the father.

McLEAN, Va., Sept. 9. Joan Kennedy was at Hyannis Port with the children, but her husband, Senator Edward M. Kennedy was host to 1,150 people at their home on Chain Bridge Road for a benefit for the Kent Students Medical Fund, which is to aid the nine Kent State University students and the 12 Jackson State College students wounded by National Guard fire last spring.

BRUSSELS, Sept. 9 Interpol, the international police organization, is reported to have broadcast a warning to all European security services before the hijacking last Sunday of four airliners by Arab terrorists.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., Sept. 9 The largest public school system in the Carolinas took its first hesitant step toward complete desegregation today under a Federal Court busing order that the Nixon Administration and most community leaders here have repeatedly opposed.

The president of the Association of Stock Exchange Firms predicted yesterday that 50 more brokerage firms would disappear in the next six months and estimated that the securities industry was losing money faster today than during the Depression.

The Great American Insurance Company and the Constellation Reinsurance Corporation, a subsidiary, were charged here yesterday with violating the investment and holding company provisions of the New York Insurance Law.

Mr. and Mrs. David Lipman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Betsy-Ann Lipman, to Brandon Reid, son of Whitelaw Reid of Ophir Farm in Purchase, N.Y., and Mrs. Joan Brandon Reid of New York. The announcement was made here last night at a party at the Sign of the Dove restaurant.
LONDON, Sept. 9 (AP) Nijinsky, the American-owned, Canadian-bred, unbeaten 3year-old, will put his superhorse status on the line Saturday in the English St. Leger.

Federal officials agreed yesterday to consider making an emergency grant to New York and Connecticut to help the states meet a $25-million deficit in their program to take over and modernize the Penn Central's New Haven commuter service.
Senator Charles L. Goodell toured Kennedy International Airport yesterday and inspected weapon-detection devices used by Pan American World Airways.

The First National City Bank announced yesterday that it planned to pay interest of 4 per cent to members of its Christmas Club for 1971. It became the first of the major commercial banks in New York City to break with a long nointerest tradition for such accounts. However, some of the area's 45 savings bank do pay interest on such accounts.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Sept. 10 (AP) Palestinian guerrillas started to plan this week's airplane hijackings shortly after the United Arab Republic and Jordan accepted the proposal for a Middle East cease-fire, a spokesman for the commandos said today. The cease-fire began Aug. 7.
Prices on the American Stock Exchange finished mixed yesterday for the second consecutive session in slow trading.

Wustenchef of the Augustin Stable won the $17,850 Rouge Dragon Hurdle Handicap, the feature on the card at Belmont Park yesterday. Carrying 143 pounds under Michael O'Brien, Wustenchef took the 2 -mile contest by nine, lengths over Stephen Clark's Shadow Brook, with Allison Stern's Hippocampo next in the field of eight.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 As now perceived by an anxious and frustrated government here, the negotiations for the release of about 300 hijacked airline passengers from the desert in Jordan hinge on the willingness of Israel to pay some kind of ransom to her enemies.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Over a faltering telephone line from Amman, Jordan, a 17-year-old Long Island girl told Representative Ogden R. Reid today that she and two companions on the Trans World airliner hijacked by Arab guerrillas were safe and were being well treated.

Defense lawyers exercised their, first peremptory challenge yesterday to keep a Virginia-born black man, 52-yearold Ulysses Dane, off the jury that will try l3 Black Panthers accused of plotting to bomb public places.
The overseas operations division of the General Motors Corporation announced yesterday a major realignment of executive responsibilities.
HOUSTON, Sept, 10 (UPI) Former President Lyndon B. Johnson campaigned tonight for a Texas candidate for the Senate, but said he did not have any unpleasant words for the Republican party.

GENEVA, Sept. 10 Four persons have been arrested by Swiss authorites in connection with the investigation of the $30-million loss incurred by the Swiss subsidiary of the United California Bank, Los Angeles.

GENEVA, Sept 10 The World Health Organization strongly hinted today that Iran and Iraq had cases of cholera. Neither country has reported any cholera to the organizations headquarters here this year. Travelers, however, have reported cholera in both countries, which had epidemics in 1965 and 1966.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Sept. 10 West Virginia is an added starter this year in the race for the Lambert Trophy, the award that signifies the outstanding major college football team in the East. The Mountaineers rejoined their Eastern playfellows after spending more than two decades as a member of the Southern bloc.

ROME, Sept. 10 Premier Emilio Colombo announced today that his month-old Government had decided to slow construction of new railroads and superhighways in a social-minded shift of economic priorities.

The Southern railroads of the country have decided to ask the Interstate Commerce Commission for an interim general freight rate increase of 6 per cent, to become effective Nov. 18 and to expire next Feb. 28.

The International Paper Company, the world's largest papermaking enterprise, announced yesterday that a number of its primary paper and paperboard mills were operating on a curtailed basis because of the continuing decline in business activity.

For the sixth consecutive month this year, in July, reported crime has increased in New York City over the same month of the previous year, according to statistics released yesterday by the Police Department.
Tests of an exclusive bus lane to speed 35,000 New Jersey, bus commuters to work in Manhattan each day were authorized yesterday by the Tri-State Transportation Commission.

SAN QUENTIN, Calif., Sept, 10 (AP) Sirhan B. Sirhan, convicted of assassinating Senator Robert F. Kennedy, was given a mild tear-gassing by guards after throwing a "temper tantrum" in his cell on San Quentin Prison's Death Row, Warden Louis S. Nelson said today.

Lights flickered and some electric motors stalled momentarily in parts of midtown Manhattan just after noon yesterday in a brief, but hardly comparable, replay of some of the city's more serious power crises earlier this summer.

Earnings of the British Petroleum Company in this year's second quarter fell 48.3 per cent, bringing the six-month profit 30.5 per cent below the year-earlier level, the company reported in London yesterday. The sharp drop in the face of higher sales reflected the rise in tanker rates to the highest levels in history.

Deprived of victory in regulation time by an umpire's judgment on a possible home run, the NEw York Mets held first place in the National League East yesterday by hanging on until a triple by Cleon Jones in the 14th inning gave them a 3-2 decision over the Philadelphia Phillies.
Parks Commissioner August Heckscher reluctantly granted a permit yesterday for digging a shaft for a water tunnel in Central Park.
Life was more hectic than usual in the training camps of the Giants and Jets yesterday as both clubs prepared for their final preseason games.

As demonstrators shouted in the streets below, a city antipoverty panel recommended last night reconsideration of proposed cuts in the antipoverty program. The proposal had angered Puerto Rican community leaders.
ANKARA, Turkey, $ept. 10 Turkey has decided to refuse to ban the cultivation of opium poppies despite appeals during the last three years from the United States, Turkish officials said today.

Donald C. Platten, executive vice president of the Chemical Bank, was elected yesterday as first vice president, a new position, making him heir-apparent to William S. Renchard as chairman of the $10.3-billion institution.

PNOMPENH, Cambodia, Sept. 10 The United States Embassy here began moving into larger quarters today in anticipation of the arrival Saturday of the new American Ambassador Emory C. Swank, and a few more hands to help administer the increased American aid program.
A long-term issue of bonds guaranteed by the Federal Government was priced yesterday to yield 8 5/8 per cent.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 10 Two unsuccessful America's Cup contenders, France and Valiant, snd Chancegger, the French yacht's trial horse, sailed together for two hours today, first on a long windward leg that lasted an hour and then reaching and running.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Sept. 10 Stuart B. Rowe Jr. of the Horseshoe Harbor Yacht Club of Larchmont, who won twice yesterday to take the series lead pulled up from last place to 10th in today's, second race, the fifth of the regatta, to retain first place in the International One-Design Class world championship.
PARIS, Sept. 10 Accusing each other of taking inflexible stands, participants in the Vietnam peace talks remained stalemated today at the 83d meeting.

MIAMI, Sept. 10 (AP) The season's first hurricane formed off Mexico's Yucatan Peninsula today and headed in the direction of the United States Gulf Coast, the National Hurricane Center said. The storm was named Ella.

TOKYO, Sept. 10 To Leonard Bernstein, the Japanese are a people who have wrapped themselves in layer after layer of "rules, courtesies honorifics and bowing" as protection against "an inner violence."

Commissioner Pete Rozelle turned down with "regrets" yesterday a wagering scheme of George Halas, the 75-yearold president of the Chicago Bears, that could have contributed $3-million to charity. For the coming National Football League season, the Bears are listed in Las Vegas.

Stock prices moved lower yesterday for the second straight session as the market's worries tension in the Middle East and a possible automobile strike in Detroit remained foremost in the minds of investors.

AREA A "Fair to middling" is the report along the Jersey coast, with the catches of blues, weakfish and bass along the beach seeming to improve the farther north you go. John Falkiewicz called the surf picture fair at Surf City, with the bay area a bit better. Snappers, some weakfish and fluke were biting at the south end of the bay, he said, although the big story was crabbing, which was "very, very good."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 Two months ago King Hussein observed that the situation in Jordan was "like a minefield." More than 10 Palestinian commando organizations were operating in his country all bent on destroying the state of Israel and some bent on changing the government of Jordan.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 A University of Chicago law professor urged Congress today to make clear, if it insists on passing an equal rights amendment to the Constitution, that some legal distinctions could still be made between men and women if they were "based on reason."

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) Senate committee agreed to changes in a pending air pollution control bill that could result in a one-year suspension of a proposed 1975 deadline for the production of nonpolluting automobiles.

LUSAKA, Zambia, Sept. 10 The conference of the heads of state of nonaligned nations ended today after adopting resolutions supporting the Palestine liberation movement and similar movements in Southeast Asia and southern Africa. The conference also called for the economic liberation of developing nations from the big powers.
Edward J. Hudson has been elected chairman of J. Ray McDermott Co., filling the post left vacant by the death of R. Thomas McDermott in July.
BUFFALO, Thursday, Sept. 10 (AP) Michael Fiedler, the 22-year-old son of Dr. Leslie Fiedler, has been ordered to appear today before a suburban town justice on charges of possessing a dangerous drug.

The Board of Education's proposed plan to allocate Federal and state funds for disadvantaged pupils to the 31 community districts under decentralization was sharply criticized yesterday. Remarks ranged from, "a waste of money" to "it's illegal."

William C. Freund, vice president and chief economist of the New York Stock Exchange, suggested yesterday that commission rates for stock transactions be made to fluctuate in recognition of the cyclical nature of the securities business.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Securities and Exchange Commission upheld today a decision by the National Association of Securities Dealers that a securities underwriter had received an unreasonably high compensation when the stock he received as part of the underwriting deal was taken into account.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The National Transportation Safety Board blamed deficiencies of the Federal Aviation Administration air traffic control system today for an aerial collision near Indianapolis a year ago in which 83 people were killed.

LONDON, Friday Sept. 11 The Governments of the United States, Britain, West Germany, Switzerland and Israel rejected last night as unacceptable demands that Arab guerrillas have set for the release of airline passengers they hold in the Jordanian desert, informed sources here reported.
New York State has been ordered by a Federal judge to grant an estimated total of $11million annually in additional benefits for upstate welfare families.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) Four unions resumed contract talks with the nation's railroads today after postponing a scheduled strike, but one of them set another strike deadline in two weeks over a separate issue.

CAIRO, Sept. 10 The United Arab Republic warned today that the United States was "undermining" the 90-day ceasefire and middle East peace efforts by its decision, reported yesterday, to sell 18 more Phantom fighter-bombers to Israel by the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (UPI) Secretary of Labor James D. Hodgson said today that Federal, construction contractors had exceeded their first-year goals for employment of craftsmen from minority groups under the Philadelphia plan four months ahead of schedule. In some trades, he said, they have surpassed their fourth-year quotas for 1973.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 The Japanese defense chief has asked the United States to lift the secrecy surrounding the production of enriched uranium enough to enable Japan and other countries to build a plant to produce fuel for the generation of electric power. The United States now supplies such fuel to Japan.

DETROIT, Sept. 10 Police Commissioner Patrick V. Murphy had three main goals when he took the job here last December: to bring more policemen out on the beat, to improve relations with the black community and to make the top administration of the department more efficient.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10 (AP) The nation's governors asked senators today to have the Federal Government assume the full cost of welfare, but they split over the question of whether President Nixon's family assistance plan should be enacted now.
Amos Bates Foy, an international banker, died Wednesday in New York Hospital after a short illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Montvale, N.J. He was a regular winter visitor to Sarasota, Fla.
